Mor timer have been elected senior vice presidents in the New York office of Clark, Dodge & Co., Inc., one of the oldest member firms of the New York Stock Exchange. Also an nounced were the appointments as vice presidents of Richard W. Chadwell Jr., Neville Walk er, Walter G. Neff Jr., Henry A. Collins and James R. Ruther ford.

title: Suharto Lifts State of War
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. (UPI) President Suharto has lifted a fouryearold state of war in the Central Java Prov ince and in the Jogjakarta Spe cial District of Indonesia, it was announced today. Central Java and Jogjakarta were the last two regions under the state of war imposed during an attempt ed coup by the Communists in October, 1965.

title: Pancoast Signed by Georgia As Chief Offensive Coach
description: ATHENS, Ga., Jan 2 (UPI)  The University of Georgia, which had little offensive punch this season, signed Fred Pan coast today. He is credited with having helped turn the Florida Gators to a mighty scor ing machine.

title: Knave O'Dan Victor
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Jan. 2 (AP) J. E. Bigman's Knave O'Dan registered 2length victory over Bill Ford's Sunset Gem today before a crowd of 6,495 at Narragansett Park. Knave O'Dan covered the five furlongs in 1:04 45 and re turned $8.60; $5.40 and $3.20. Sunset Gera paid $6.20 and $3.40, while C. Stars paid $2.40 to show.

title: Dentists to Induct Officers
description: Dr. Alfred J. Keck will be installed Monday night at the Statler Hilton Hotel as presi dent of the First District Den tal Society of the State of New York. Also to be installed are Dr. Joseph Blinderman, presi dentelect; Dr. Abbe Selman, vice president, and Dr, Irving Grenadier, treasurer.

title: Mexican Newsman Is Killed; Police Are Holding His Wife
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2 (AP) Carlos Denegri, one of Latin America's best known journal ists and a reporter for the Mex ico City newspaper Excelsior for 32 years, was shot to death in his home last night.

title: Artists' Guild To Hold Party
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 2  The Silvermine Guild of Artists, a nonprofit organiza tion of professional artists and art patrons, will benefit from a dinner dance at Waveny Castle here on Jan. 17. Mrs. Edward S. Smith and Mrs. Edwin C. Andrews Jr. are cochairmen of the ball.

title: MORRIS ROSEN
description: Morris Rosen, chairman of Morris Rosen and Sons, Inc., one of the largest mason con tractors in the East, died yes terday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 2465 Palisade Ave nue Riverdale.

title: Citizens Casualty Upheld; Insolvency Suit Denied
description: State Supreme Court Judge Adolph C. Orlando has ruled after a lengthy trial that the New York State. Superintendent of Insurance failed to prove the Citizens Casualty Company of New York insolvent, as the In surance Department had charged in April, 1968.

title: Susan Elizabeth Day Engaged To Robin S. Balding, a Student
description: DALLAS, Pa., Jan. 2Mr. and Mrs. J. Houston Day have announced the engagement of Mr. Day's daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Day, to Robin Sheldon Balding. He is a son of Mrs. Martin A. Quirk of Rumson, N. J., and the late Gerald M. Balding of Weyhill, England.

title: Books of The Times
description: RONALD SANDERS has written an ex emplary account of that Jewish, self contained compound that made up New York's Lower East Side In the half century that ended with World War I.

title: Jewish Leaders Pick Wexler to Head Group
description: The election of Dr. William A. Wexler of Savannah, Ga., as chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Ameri can Jewish Organizations was announced yesterday.

title: Arbitrary Regime in Zanzibar Adds to Mystery of the Island
description: ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, Dec. 29The Revolutionary Coun cil of Zanzibar has decreed that no offislander may marry a Zanzibar girl unless he pays a tax of 56,000 East African shillings, about $8,000.

title: N. CAROLINA STATE DOWNS MARYLAND
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan 2 (UPI)Undefeated North Caro lina State, with Vann Williford scoring 27 points, rolled to a 9157 victory over Maryland tonight in its first Atlantic Coast Conference basketball same.

title: Justice Denies Bid to Keep 2 New YorkChicago Trains
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart denied today the re quest of the Ohio Public Service Commission for an order to prevent the ErieLackawanna railroad from dropping two New YorkChicago passenger trains.

title: Watchmen Announce Pact
description: Terms of a new threeyear labor agreement have been an nounced by the New York. Ship ping Association and the Port Watchmen's Union Local 1456. Under the new contract, effec tive yesterday but subject to ratification, the basic daily pay will be $25. The old daily wage for watchmen was $20.36.

title: AGNEW SUPPORTS U.S.PEKING TALKS; CALLS ON CHIANG
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 3 Vice President Agnew con ferred privately this morning with President Chiang Kaishek of Nationalist China less than 24 hours after Mr. Agnew said the United States would seek meaningful dialogue with Communist China.

title: SEXUAL OFFENSES DECLINE IN DENMARK
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 2 (AP)The police said today there was a 31 per cent decline in the number of sexual of fenses reported in metropolitan Copenhagen in 1969the year all restrictions oil pornography in Denmark were lifted.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Cherrybird, EvenMoney Choice, Wins by 10 Lengths at Laurel
description: LAUREL, Md., Jan. 2James A. Bayard's Cherrybird, the evenmoney favorite in the field of five Marylandbred fillies and mares, justified the confidence of her backers in the crowd of 10,122 at Laurel race course today when she easily won the $13,750 All Brandy Handicap.

title: Jury Acquits 12 in Ceylon Accused of Plotting Coup
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 2 Twelve persons accused of having planned a coup d'tet in February, 1966, were ac quitted today by a jury.

title: St. Lawrence Beats Princeton
description: CANTON, N. Y., Jan. 2St. Lawrence University won its fifth hockey game of the sea son tonight, scoring once in each period to defeat Prince ton, 31. The Larries now have a 56 wonlost mark while Princeton's record is 17.

title: POLICE RAISE FIGURE ON HOMICIDES IN 69
description: The Police Department said yesterday that it had increased the number of homicides it re corded in the city this year as. a result of closer statistical liai son with the Medical Exam iner's office.

title: Service Chaplains Urged to Support Moral Dissent
description: An executive of the United Church of Christ demanded yesterday that chaplains in the armed services be instructed to support officers and enlisted men who refuse to carry out orders they deem in error, im moral or in violation of the laws and customs of war and crime against humanity.

title: New York Times Syndicate Names Assistant to Editor
description: Dennis R. Allen, formerly managing editor of The Des Moines Register and Tribune Syndicate, has joined The New York Times News Service as assistant to its editormanager, Rob Roy Buckingham.

title: Siemens Completes Merger
description: The merger of Siemens Amer ica, Inc., and Siemens Medical of America, Inc., into the Sie mens Corporation, a new com pany, went into effect as of Thursday. B. J. von dem Knewe beck, president of Siemens America, Was named president of the new company. Corporate headquarters will be established later this month at Iselin, N. J. The company's medical group and components division will move to the new facility from Union, N. J., in the spring.

title: Passaic Police Hunt Motive In Slaying of Union Official
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Jan. 2The police said today that they were still seeking a motive in the slaying of a labor union official on New Year's day. They said they suspected it was not a runofthemill case. The body of the victim, James Fusaro, 59 years old, was found at about 10:30 A.M. Thursday in his secondfloor office at 828 Main Avenue.

title: Floridians Drop Sutor
description: MIAMI, Jan, 2 (UPI)The Miami Floridians of the Ameri can Basketball Association put George Sutor, a 6foot9inch center, on waivers today. Sutor was acquired by the Floridians two weeks ago from Carolina. He played collegiate basketball at La Salle.

title: LAMONICA NAMES HIMSELF AS NO. 1
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 2 The Oakland Raiders, a pro football version of the Central Intelligence Agency, are up to their prechampionship, super secret tricks, but the only thing Daryie Lamonica is hiding is the plays the Raiders might spring against the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: FLOOD, GOLDBERG TO MEET ON SUIT
description: Curt Flood, whose challenge to baseball's reserve clause may set in motion major changes in the organization of professional sports, is in New York to tape a television show and begin conferences with Ar thur Goldberg, who will reprei sent him. Flood arrived last night from St. Louis, accom panied by his attorney, Allen Zerman.

title: Peggy Sue Fletcher to Marry in June
description: ?? president of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, and Mrs. Fletcher of New York have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Peggy Sue Fletcher, to Stan ton W. Newton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton of South Salem, N. Y.

title: Oil Concerns Push Refining Capacity
description: Major oil companies are con tinuing their production of raw materials relative to their re fining requirements, according to a survey released yesterday by the First National City Bank.

title: LESTER RICE IS DEAD; EXGOLF EDITOR, 80
description: Lester Rice, former golf edi tor of the old New York Jour nalAmerican, died of a heart attack yesterday in Doctors Hospital,Freeport, L. I. He was 80 years old and lived at 452 Archer Street. Freeport.

title: Lakers Down Warriors
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) Jerry West and Keith Erickson led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 12595 triumph over the San Francisco Warriors tonight.

title: HEART ATTACKCAUSE OF COACH'S AILMENT
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP)  It was a heart attack that kept Bo Schembechler, coach of the University of Mich gan football team in the hospital during yesterday's Rose Bowl game with the University of Southern California, doctors said today.

title: BIG BOARD STARTS YEAR WITH RALLY
description: The stock market started out 1970 with a crisp rally yester day, thanks partly to its re lease from the tremendous pressures of taxloss selling in December.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Jan. 2. 1970

title: 25 Arrested as Violence Follows Texas Triumph
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP) Merrymaking over Texas's vic tory in the Cotton Bowl turned violent late last night with the police arresting 25 persons, mostly for throwing rocks, beer bottles and firecrackers.

title: BRIDGE IN JERSEY OPERATING AGAIN
description: Thirty ships, halted by a frozen drawbridge, over Newark Bay, started sailing yesterday afternoon after wait ing for 42 hours for the bridge to thaw out.

title: LAWRENCE E. EKHOLM
description: NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 29 Lawrence Eskil Ekholm, vice president in charge of Eastern operations of the Climax, Molyb denum Company, a division of American Metal Climax, Inc., of New York, died in Norwalk Hospital today after a short ill ness. His age was 64, and he lived at Pequot Trail, Westport.

title: Cluttered and Cramped, Library of Congress Faces Worst Crisis Since 1814
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) The Library of Congress, which has the greatest collec tion of books ever assembled, is facing its worst crisis since 1814, when the British burned the United States Capitol and destroyed the infant Library's entire stock.

title: Rabbi Matloub Abadi Dies;. Sephardic Jewish Leader
description: Rabbi Matloub Abadi of Shaare Zion Congregation at 2030 Ocean Parkway in Brook lyn died Thursday in the Com munity Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 80 years old and lived at 2039 Ocean Parkway.

title: G.O.P. Takes Over Rochester City Hall After Dispute
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 2The old order, Democratic, passed in this city today, but it did not give way to the new, Republican  dominated ad ministration without a strug gle that took the form of words and, briefly, of a spir ited contest for possession of the Mayor's gavel.

title: STEEL PLANT BANS FOREIGN VEHICLES
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 2 United States Steel began to day closing the gates at its Fairfield Works to drivers of foreignmade vehicles here in a move apparently aimed at encouraging more domestic buying.

title: MERGERS AT PEAK IN WEST GERMANY
description: BONN, Jan. 2A record 138 West German companies, with annual balance sheets totaling $4.9billion, merged in 1969, the Federal Cartel Office an nounced this week.

title: HelmetHeaded Hornbill Flees From Park Zoo
description: A casque hornbill, a large reddishgray bird distin guished by a grotesque hel metlike growth on top of its head, escaped from the bird house at the Central Park Zoo yesterday while its cage was being cleaned.

title: Hairdos for the Spring: Think Flowers
description: Shop Talk

title: Victor Over Inflation
description: WHEN Dr. Karl Blessing stepped down on Dec. 31 as president of. West Ger many's central bank to make room for Dr. Karl Klasen, it was with the conviction that the threat of an imported inflation had been removed.

title: Flood Areas in Maine Aided
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The Small Business Administra tion has declared flood areas of Maine a disaster area, Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republi can of Maine, said today. The designation enables the agency to make longterm, 3 per cent loans to businessmen and home owners who suffered losses and damages in floods last week.

title: New Hampshire Five Halts Hofstra, 7663, Gains Final
description: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Jan. 2New Hampshire earned the right to meet Mount St. Mary's in tomorrow night's Pocono Classic final by topping the Hofstra five of Hempstead, L. I., tonight, 7663.

title: US. WOULD RESUME TALKS ON MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The State Department said today that it was ready to continue talks with the Soviet Udion on the Middle East despite Soviet rejection of the latest American proposals for a settlement.

title: Blast Perils Alabama Town
description: WETUMPKA, Ala., Jan. 2 (AP)Two downtown buildings were demolished and three oth ers were damaged today by a gas explosion that left fires burning for hours. No one was iniured.

title: Washington's Social Climate Is Mild
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 After a full year in the seat of power, the Nixon Admin istration's imprint on the so cial life of the capital is so faint as to be almost wraith like.

title: PHONE RATE CUT IS SET FOR FEB. 1
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday an $87million cut in longdistance rates to offset previously anounced rise in charges for teletype and other specialized services.

title: Excerpts From the Report on Internal Security Rules for H. E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Following are excerpts from the summary of findings and recommendations of the, re port of Harlan Reed Ellis dealing with relaxation of security procedures for part time personnel at the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare:

title: Plowshares Into Swords
description: Pope Paul's New Year's Day criticism of advanced nations which reinforce their economies by the trad ing of arms to poor nations lacking plows, schools and hospitals leaves few, if any, of the industrialized countries untouched, but it particularly hits home in the United States.

title: Jan.19Zauberflote At the Met to Mark 3 Soprano Debuts
description: Three singers will make their Metropolitan Opera debuts in Mozart's Die Zauberflote on Jan. 19, during the fourth week of the company's season. Edith Mathis, soprano, will appear in the part of Pamina, Judith) Blegen, also a soprano, will be Papagena, and Ivanka Myhal, mezzosoprano, will be the Third Genie.

title: Savannah Theaters Face $10,000 Fee for X Films
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 2 (AP) The Chatham County Com mission has passed an ordinance imposing a business license fee of $10,000 a year on movie theaters showing films rated X and R.

title: French Agreement to Sell Arms to Iraq Is Reported
description: PARIS, Jan: 2France is un derstood to be pursuing arms trade with Iraq. An Iraqi ship is reliably reported to be headed for Cherbourg to pick up military supplies, including machinegun ammunition man ufactured by an Alsatian con cern, Manufacture de Machines du HautRhin, which is based in Mulhouse.

title: Brown Routs Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) Brown University hit 30 of 54 floor shots tonight and trounced the University of Chicago, 7132.

title: RCA Won't Cut TV Price
description: The RCA Corporation de nied yesterday it planned a re duction in factory prices on its color TV receivers. The denial was made as a result of trade reports that BrunoNew York, Inc., the independent distribu tor for the city, planned exten sive price cuts. A spokesman for RCA said any price cuts would have to be made by the individual distributors and with out action by the manufacturer.

title: Britain Reports a Rise in Gold Reserves
description: LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP)Brit ain announced today that it is heading into the New Year with its reserves of gold and foreign currency showing an increase of $24million in De cember.

title: Book Theorizes That Kennedy Left Auto Before Fatal Crash
description: BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)Only three days before the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Ko pechne, a book has been pub lished theorizing that Senator Edward M. Kennedy was not with her when she died in his car last summer on Chappa quiddick Island.

title: Yippie Film on 1968 Convention Is Kept From Jury
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 2  A Yip piemade film about events at the 1968 Democratic National Convention was barred from evidence today at the Chicago conspiracy trial.

title: A.B.A. Names Star Coaches
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 2 (AP) 1Bob Leonard of Indiana and Babe McCarthy of New Orleans were named today the coaches for the American Basketball Association's AllStar game here Jan. 24.

title: Gold Medals Given To 3 Archeologists For Aid to History
description: Three archeologists, whose discoveries and scholarly writ ings have added significantly to history of the ancient world, were honored this week with the gold medal of the Archaeo logical Institute of America.

title: MRS. ADOLPH KROCH
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 2Mrs. Gertrude Kroch, wife of Adolph A. Kroch, founder of Kroch's & Brentano's bookstore chain, died Wednesday in the Kroch Retirement Home, near here. Her age was 82. Mr. Kroch founded his first bookstore in 1907 in Chicago.

title: WEST COAST TO GET U.S. ANTICRIME UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) A strike force is being es tablished by the Justice De partment to help combat crime and racketeering on the West Coast. The headquarters will be in Los Angeles.

title: Tragedy for the City
description: Even in a period when all costs are rising, the deci sion of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to raise the subway and bus fare from twenty cents to thirty cents is a cruel blow to the pocketbooks of millions of New Yorkers.

title: Beame and Garelik Take New Posts
description: Abraham D. Beame, begin ning a new term as City Controller after a fouryear break, gingerly rubbed the small of his back and ex plained to a visitor yesterday:

title: A Storage Battery Saves Space
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 A New Rochelle, N. Y. in ventor who has one battery on exhibit at the Smithsonian Institution was awarded a patent this week for another.

title: Girl, 15, on Parole, Killed by Overdose of Heroin
description: A 15yearold girl, paroled for the Christmas holiday from the Juvenile Center in the Bronx, died on New Year's Eve of an overdose of heroin.

title: '69's Active Stocks; Hit by Bear Market
description: The bear market took a heavy toll among the most ac tively traded issues on the New York Stock Exchange last year. Many old favorites were back on the list, and some newcom ers Joined the ranks, but the net results were generally dis appointing to traders.

title: Scarlett, Musical, And Star Cheered By Tokyo Audience
description: TOKYO, Jan. 2  A star was born  or rather reborn  at the Imperial Theater here to night when Sakura Jinguji re ceived an ovation for her per formance in the title role of Scarlett, a new musical based on Gone With the Wind, the Margaret Mitchell novel.

title: Law and Policy in East Africa
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania Robert Seidman, professor of law at the University of Wis consin and at University Col lege, Dar es Salaam, puts a case of witchcraft to his stu dents to indicate some prob lems of legal method in a developing country. It is based on an actual High Court de cision in what used to be British Africa.

title: Article 1  No Title
Sutton Says 12 Legislators Support Him on Districting
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan said yes terday that he had received the support of 12 state legislators from Manhattan for a bill pre serving the borough's six school districts, which are to be re duced to five under a Board of Education policy implement ing the state education law.

title: Memorial Services
description: A MEMORIAL SERVICE for HENRY BECKETT will be held Jan. 4 at 1:30 P.M. at the Community Church, 40 E. 35th St., N.Y.C.

title: Japan Expecting Exports Of $19.35Billion in 1970
description: TOKYO, Jan. 2 (UPI)Ja pan's exports in fiscal 1970 may reach $19.35billion, an increase of 15.7 per cent over the cur rent fiscal year, the Ministry of International Trade and In dustry said today.

title: FRIED LOSES PLEA; STARTS SENTENCE
description: Henry Fried, 69yearold mil lionaire contractor, surrendered yesterday in Federal Court to begin serving a twoyear prison term for conspiring to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus.

title: FINAL SHOT WINS FOR MICH. STATE
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 3 (AP)Ron Gutkowski of Mich igan State grabbed a rebound, and scored as the game ended today to give the Spartans an 8584 victory over Indiana in a Big Ten basketball opener.

title: DON C. MILLER
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., Jan. 3 Don C. Miller, a former vice president of the B. F. Goodrich Co. and Textron, Inc., died yes terday in Danbury Hospital. He was 55 years old.

title: ALTON W. GREENE
description: DUMONT, N. J., Jan. 3 Alton W. Greene, assistant gen eral manager at Abercrombie & Fitch Co., died here after a heart attack yesterday. He was 62 years old and lived at 114 Dulles Drive. His widow, the former Clare Byrne, survives.

title: French Steamer Service To the Far East Ends
description: PARIS, Jan. 3A century of regular passenger liner service between France and the Far East by the Mes sageries Maritimes ended today with the return to Marseilles of the liner Laos, which docked with 120 pas sengers aboard.

title: Carolina Nursing Home Begins Medicaid Evictions
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 3 (AP)Tipton's Nursing Home in Charlotte became yesterday the first private North Carolina nursing home to begin eviction of Medicaid patients.

title: Reveille Sounds Again Over Texas Forts
description: ABILENE, Tex.  More than 30 old United States military forts, strung out over a wide area of westcen tral Texas, are being restored by the state as tourist attractions. This com plex of military installations, known to day as the Texas Forts Trail, was created in the 1860's, 70's and 80's to protect the area's towns, ranches and farms from marauding Indians.

title: ARROLANE SCORES AT LIBERTY BELL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP) Jerry Meyer, a trainer, and Hugo Dittfach, a jockey, ac counted for their second stakes victory in three days at Liberty Bell Park today when Herbert E. Wilson's Arrolane won the $28,175 Allegheny Stakes by a length and a quarter.

title: Sugar Forecast Taken With Salt
description: When Premier Castro of Cuba talks about sugar, su gar experts listen with a knowing smile and discount about 50 per cent of what is said.

title: Miss Walkden, Hewitt Win Net Titles in South Africa
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Jan. 3 (AP)Pat Walk den of South Africa upset Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones, Britain's Wimbledon champion, 64, 62, in the final of the Eastern Prov ine tennis championships to day.

title: Miss Whitney Burnett Is a Bride
description: WILTON, Conn., Jan. 3 Miss Whitney Ann Beekman Burnett and Robert Irving Stevens 2d, were married here today in St. Mathew's Episcopal, Church. The Rev. Roger O. Douglas performed the ceremony.

title: Speaking of Books: Where Writers Have Lived And Worked
description: Not long ago, The London Times carried an unusually interesting advertisement: WORDSWORTH'S HOME for sale. Outstanding tourist possibilities or ideal family home. From another newspaper I soon dis covered that the house concerned was Rydal Mount, Ambleside, whith er the poet moved in the year 1813, when he secured a comfortable sine cure position as Stamp Distributor for Westmoreland; and that the prop erty included a double garage and tennis courts, besides many fine shrubs and trees and a splendid view of Windermere.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONYou are imminent danger at all times a coal mine. . . . You are sur rounded by all the tremendous forces of nature, straining against your effort to extract this coal. So you are in a continual struggle. Nature is out to protect its resources and you are there wrestling the bowels out of the thing. So you are in constant danger in a coal mine.

title: General Abrams Leaves Hospital After Pneumonia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 (UPI)Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, United States com mander in Vietnam, was dis charged from a military hospi tal today, fully recovered from pneumonia, a military spokesman said.

title: 2 Resident Lutheran Ministers Provide Spiritual Aid at Tropical's Backstretch
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3Tropical Park bills itself as the track that dares to be different, and this year it has come up with the entry of Homrighausen and Kruekenbergresi dent Lutheran ministers who specialize in succor for the men on the backstretch.

title: Key Merger ingredient Is the People
description: The basic ingredients of corporate merger include products, profits and money. But the most important in gredient is people.

title: Bomb Plot Suspect's $50,000 Bail Is Offered, but Judge Doubles the Amount
description: A Federal judge yesterday doubled the $50,000 bail of a man accused of conspiring to bomb Government buildings when friends and acquaintances of the defendant appeared in court prepared to post bond for his release.

title: Starr of Packers Receives Gladiator of Year Award
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3 (AP)Bart Starr, quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, was pre sented with the first annual Gladiator of the Year Award today during halftime cere monies of the Playoff Bowl.

title: RUSSIAN SUGGESTS PAY FOR JOBLESS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 3A Soviet labor economist has revived his controversial plan to provide payments to workers dismissed by enterprises seeking to re duce their labor surpluses.

title: SAIGON'S STABILITY A WORRY FOR U.S,
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Nixon Administration is re ported to be increasingly con cerned that the political and economic situation in South Vietnam is deteriorating and that this could affect the pace of Vietnamization of the war.

title: Ad Man Weds Sandra Crow
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 3Miss Sandra Baker Crow, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Crow, was married at Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, to Edward Stanley, Luneburg. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. Wendell Phillips.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: PAKISTAN PARTIES RESUME ACTIVITY
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 3 Full political activity is resum ing in Pakistan after a period of more than nine months in which it had been restricted.

title: Cairo Minister in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 3 (Reuters) Economy Minister Hassan Ab bas Zaki of the United Arab Re public arrived here today for trade talks. Aside from being Egypt's main supplier of arms and military equipment, the So viet Union exports machinery, oil products, metals and timber to the Egyptians.

title: Boat Enthusiast Found Dead Aboard His Cabin Cruiser
description: FREEPORT, L. I., Jan. 3A 40yearold Brooklyn man, the father of three, was found dead today in a bunk of his 34foot cabin cruiser, The Tigress, docked at 351 South Main Street here. A friend who broke into the locked craft found the pajamaclad body of James J. Coane, an office manager for the Republic Steel Company in New York City.

title: Project to Aid Negroes in. Studies for Medicine
description: The National Conference of Black Students in Medicine an nounced last week the estab lishment of a national clearing house to effectively channel, medical school applications of black students.

title: Photography
description: THE report of a broad survey of photographic job opportunities in this city that may well be the most intensive study of the subject ever undertaken in such depth has just been published. Ranging from jobs requiring little or no skill to posts that call for a high order of background, experi ence, and ability in the field, the study describes and dis cusses 66 job titles in eight groupings. It is based on con sultation with leaders in every aspect of photographic activity, and is written in nontechnical language for a vocational guidance audience.

title: A Look at Vegetables of the Future
description: PICKLES that grow on a plant a foot or two in diameter, pumpkins on a bushlike summer squash  these and other equally remarkable develop ments are just around the corner for home gardens.

title: Movies
description: I HAVE been interviewing Elaine May for three and a half years now. The first time I interviewed Elaine May was for The Saturday Evening Post in August of 1966, in a lavish hotel suite if, New Yorkwhy I can't remember, because she had an apartment on Riverside Drive. We had coffee and small cakes and I enjoyed it, but the material, frankly, was thin, because whenever I went to make a note, she would abruptly look anguished, cry What are you writing down?, leap ?? and look over my shoulder. Then she would ask whether that sounded right for publication and we would talk about whether it did or not, while she paced and I held the pencil uncertainly.

title: Article 8  No Title
Science
description: Rarely has there been such confrontation between science and the problems of our time as at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Ad vancement of Science which end ed in Boston Thursday. It was marked by Intensive souisearch ing as to the role that science and scientists shbule play in dealing with those problems. There were repeated interven tionssome sobering, some wild eyedfrom students, some of whom urged the overthrow of the system.

title: The World
Most of the Presidents from Washington to Monroe sat for him
description: PealeCharles Willson Peale, to distinguish him amidst that early Am erican dynasty of painting Peales is one of those artists so locked into history that it hardly seems relevant to discuss him in purely artistic terms. That, certainly, is the tack that his biographer, Charles Coleman Sellers, a Peale descendant and au thor of an earlier twovolume bio graphy of the subject, has taken in his present study.

title: Opera Strike Looms in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 3 (Reuters) Stagehands and electricians at the Paris Opera House voted today to stage a 24hour strike tomorrow, forcing cancellation of the two performances by the Bolshoi Opera of Moscow. The strike is to back demands for higher wages by the C.G.T. labor federation. It follows un successful talks involving tech nicians, the opera management and the culture ministry.

title: Chess
description: THE games appearing here, from the recent United States chess cham pionship, are indicative of the mental stresses and strains of at tacker and defender alike.

title: Results in British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE Association Cup Third Round

title: Work on the Tower of Pisa Expected to Start in 1971
description: ROME, Jan. 3rWork to prop up the Leaning Tower of Pisa is expected, to start in 1971 and will last about two years.

title: $27Billion Paid Out in 1969 In Social Security Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI)  Nearly $27  billion in Social Security benefits were paid out last year, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today. The checks reached one of every eight Americans.

title: Schembechler to Remain In Hospital at least 2 Weeks
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 3 (AP) Bo Schembechler, football coach at the University of Mich igan, who suffered a heart at tack before Thursday's Rose Bowl game, is expected to leave St. Luke Hospital's coronary care unit in two days, his doc tor said today.

title: LIBERALS LEADER RETIRES IN QUEBEC
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 3Jean Le sage, father of Quebec's quiet revolution in the early nine teensixties and one of Cana da's most influential politicians for a decade, is quietly ending his career as leader of the Quebec Liberal party.

title: ISAAC ROSENBERG
description: Isaac Rosenberg of 7140 112th Street, Forest Hills, Queens, manufacturer of dec orative ribbons, died yesterday morning of cancer at the Poly clinic Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Senators Sign Roseboro
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI)  The Washington Senators signed John Roseboro, a former Los Angeles Dodger catcher to a 1970 contract today.

title: Governor of Mississippi Backs Private Schools
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 3 Gov. John Bell Williiams, on the eve of next week's sched uled courtordered total school desegregation in many areas of the state, told Mississippians tonight that he would work to erect a private school system as a workable alternative for thousands of white children.

title: Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein Dies; Founded West Side Synagogue
description: Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein, Talmudic scholar, teacher and author, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital.. He was 79 years old and lived at 229 West 78th Street.

title: C.I.A. IS ACCUSED IN RHODESIA CASE
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 3The Johannes burg newspaper, The Sunday Times, in its early editions to day, accused the United States Central Intelligence Agency and the American consul general in Rhodesia of complicity in re cent economic spy cases in Rhodesia.

title: Black Soldier Buried Among Whites
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 3 As his teenage widow clutched a tightly folded flag and his mother wept softly into a handkerchief, the silver gray coffin slid slowly and si lently into the frozen earth and Bill Henry Terry was granted his wish.

title: Suzanne Cattier Wed To James Taliaferro
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Jan. 3Miss Suzanne Cor inne Cattier was married here this afternoon to James Denham Taliaferro, a regis tered representative with the New York Stock Exchange firm of Dominick & Domin ick.

title: MARYLAND BANS DDT EXCEPT IN EPIDEMIC
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 3 (AP) Gov. Marvin Mandel today banned the use of DDT and several other pesticides in Maryland except when public health is endangered by a threat of epidemic.

title: Colonels Set Back Bucs As Dampier Scores 44
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 3 (AP)  Louie Dampier riddled the New Orleans defense for 44 points tonight as the Kentucky Colonels beat the Western Divi sion leaders, 119107, in an American Basketball Associa tion game.

title: What's After Willie Boy?
description: TELL them Abraham Po lonsky is very much here. The onceblack listed director  his last directorial credit was Force of Evil In 1948re turned triumphantly recently with the offbeat Western drama, Tell Them Willie Boy Is Here. And now he is all set to go again, this time with an adaptation of John B. San ford's 1935 novel, The Old Man's Place. The screenplay has been written by Stanford Whitmore, and shooting should begin in Paris in the spring for Philip Waxman Jerome Minskoff Productions. Robert Blake, who played the title role in Tell Them Willie Boy Is Here, will star. He will be joined by John Marley and Seymour Cassel, both of Faces fame.

title: Letters:
description: Glove Industry

title: BUD SMITH IS FIRST IN 3 DINGHY RACES
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 3LeSueur G. (Bud) Smith Jr. of the Larch mont Yacht Club was the low scorer, by 10 points, in the second portion of the annual New Year's invitation Dyer dinghy frostbite regatta at the American Yacht Club today.

title: Giants in Kibitzer Role for Title Game
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 3The Browns and the Vikings had better put on a good show here tomorrow. If they don't the New York Giants may fly in from all over the country and whip both of them.

title: Meter Man May Go Way Of Ice Man
description: The days of the meter read er may be numbered.

title: The Uncompleted Past
description: By all the usual standards of judg ment, Martin Duberman is a highly successful young historian. His first book, a biography of the 19thcentury antislavery leader and diplomat Charles Francis Adams, won the prestigious Bancroft Prize, and his second, a biography of James Russell Lowell, was also well received. Du berman has edited an important collection of essays about the abolition ists, written several plays, including the muchacclaimed In White Amer ica, and has served as drama critic and book reviewer for a number of important periodicals. It is therefore somewhat surprising, even dismaying, to find that in his latest book, Duber man makes clear his dissatisfaction with the historical profession, not merely because he no longer finds history personally rewarding, but be cause he questions the entire relev ance of its study.

title: Tito Picks New Army Chief
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 (AP)President Tito has named Col. Gen. Viktor Bubanj chief of the Yugoslav Army's General Staff. Col. Gen. Milos Sumonja, who had held the post, was appointed Deputy Defense Minister.

title: SHIELDS, CONEYS GAIN IN REGATTA
Headliners
description: When Dean Rusk left the Government last January after serving eight years as Secretary of State, he found he was unable to follow the usual route of Cabinet members into a highly paid job. His back ground qualified him for academe; but his defense of the Vietnam war made him a pariah on northern campuses, and his liberalism on civil rights (and his daughter's marriage to a Negro) made him unwelcome in the South. So he had to content himself with recording memories under a grant from the Rocke feller Foundation. Finally, last week, a job came through. The University of Georgia, after heated con troversy within the state's Board of Regents, hired him as a professor of international law. I'm honored, Mr. Rusk said with customary restraint, and he talked of going back home where he was born on farm.

title: ExOfficial in Alioto Case Denies He Violated Laws
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 3 (LTD John O'Connell, former Wash ington State Attorney General, who is under investigation by state officials for alleged fee sharing with Mayor Joseph Alioto of San Francisco, said today: I have done nothing wrong, I have violated no law.

title: AGNEW SAYS CHINA FRIGHTENS ASIANS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 3 Vice President Agnew said today that the United States allies in Asia understood the Nixon doctrine of regional self reliance, but wanted to hear it again because they are fright ened of Communist China.

title: COMPLAINTS ON HEAT SOAR TO 300 AN HOUR
description: The number of apartment dwellers complaining of lack of heat soared to 300 an hour during certain periods yester day, a spokesman for the city said.

title: The World
description: PARIS  Israel, a small country surrounded by enemies, has long had a feeling that she has to look out for herself. And to her great embarrassment, France has just learned that Is rael can do this very well.

title: Kennedy Inquest Opens Tomorrow
description: BOSTON, Jan. 3The par ticipants in a convivial cookout party that ended in tragedy on Chappaquiddick Island last July 18 will gather at the Dukes County Court House at Edgar town, Mass., on Monday for the opening of an inquest in the death of Mary Jo Kopechne.

title: 2 Councilmen Urge City Shut Theaters For Obscene Films
description: What's been going on in Times Square is now spreading out into the neighborhoods, a City Councilman said yesterday in proposing legislation to pe nalize movie theaters that show obscene films.

title: We Climb Up Into 23 Trees
description: THE National Theater of Andorra, headed by Joachim Gotthelfen, has just arrived for its first series of performances in the United States. Gotthelfen, a slim, intense man in his late thirties, immediately made short shrift of just about every contemporary theatrical hero.

title: MINIBUS PROJECT ON L.I. IS FAILURE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 3 A federally financed pilot proj ect has found that a typical suburban community could not be persuaded to abandon its au tomobiles in favor of buses.

title: No Comment in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  A spokesman at the State De partment said tonight there was no comment on the news paper article.

title: Laurel Kramer Bride of Harold Lardaro
description: Miss Laurel Marie Kramer was married yesterday after noon to Harold Edward Lar daro in the Church in the Gardens (Congregational) in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens. The rector, the Rev. Alvin C. Brewer, performed the cere mony.

title: Personality:
description: Although he acknowledges he married one of the found er's granddaughters, Robert M. Boudeman attributes his advance to the presidency of the Upjohn Company to oth er than family connections.

title: Czechs Ask Danish Asylum
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 3 (UPI)Two more mem bers of a Czechoslovak tourist party asked for political asylum in Denmark today. Police said 28 in the same group requested asylum yesterday. The 30 were on a trip organized by the Czech staterun travel agency, Cedok. They arrived Thursday by train from Prague.

title: Thieu Tightens the Political Screws
description: SAIGONIt was a modest vic tory, at best, for President Nguyen Van Thieu, but it served his purpose.

title: Spotlight:
description: One day last week the list of new yearly lows on the New York Stock Ex change ran all the way from A (for Admiral) to Z (for Zenith Radio). The list also contained RCA.

title: Boating
description: Every America's Cup year the story is repeated that when the United States finally loses a defense series, the head of the losing skipper will replace the famous sailing prize on a stand at the New York Yacht Club. This could be the decade. There will he four chances for somebody to get his head on display be fore 1950 if the threeyear in terval between cup matches is maintained.

title: Move to Brasilia Urged in Warning To Rio Embassies
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 3 The Brazilian Foreign Ministry has announced it will be total ly installed in Brasilia next April, completing a move that will force international recog nition of Brazil's inland capital.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The halting of environmental degradation was not one of Richard M. Nixon's campaign priorities in 1968. In fact, he rarely men tioned it. In midOctober, two weeks before the election, how ever, he did issue a statement on pollution.

title: A Look at the Next Decade
description: SPORTS races into the seventies with every ex pectation that the dizzying expansion of the last decade will continue, that top athletes will get richer than ever, that ticket sales and television reve nues will continue to rise and that all sorts of things will have happened before the final forward pass of the decade is flung in 1979.

title: Tasman Series Adopts Formula A Racing Cars Under New Format
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 3With lustrous drivers like Jackie Stewart, Graham Hill, Bruce McLaren, Chris Amon and the late Jim Clark, the Tasman Series has always enjoyed a glamorous perch in motor racing. In the last few years, though, this program of seven races in New Zealand and Australia has not been a great financial success.

title: OREGON PUZZLED BY MORSE'S PLANS
description: SALEM, Ore., Jan. 3Wayne Morse is returning to Oregon early next week with an an swer, his friends and enemies hope, to two persistent ques tions:

title: APower Unit Fueled
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company is busy these days fueling the reactor of its Dresden 2 nuclear power unit. J. Harris Ward, chair man, said the loading opera tion began Dec. 22 immedi ately after the utility re ceived its operating license from the Atomic Energy Commission.

title: The Trend Is to M??
description: THERE is a most nota ble trend in the house plant hobby toward miniatures. These are plants that grow small in comparison to the average type of the same genera.

title: Charges of a Big Lie in Ban on Germ Warfare
description: President Nixon's announce ment last Nov. 25 that this coun try was ceasing to make biologi cal weapons was hailed at home and abroad by those who had become increasingly concerned at the efforts being made to produce weapons of germ war fare. The United States would destroy its stockpile of such ma terial, he said.

title: Ake Joins Ox Ridge Hunt Staff As Instructor in Horsemanship
description: THE Ox Bridge Hunt Club in Darien, Conn., begins its winter show series on Jan. 18 and most exhibitors will meet a new member of the staff for the first time.

title: Israelis Describe Raid
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 3Israel's military chief declared today that this morning's commando raid against Lebanon had the special purpose of taking pris oners, presumably to exchange for the Israeli watchman ab ducted by guerrillas on Thurs day.

title: Shifting of Weather Marker Is Tried
description: Too many yacht races have been spoiled because wind shifts have destroyed planned windward legs that test helms men's skills most, leaving reach ing and running the only points of sailing. The Royal Canadian Yacht Club race committee took an unusual corrective measure last September in running the Canada's Cup match by moving the weather mark for a second windward leg to a new position when such a shift occurred.

title: NEW HEALTH CHIEF BEGINS TOMORROW
description: Amid continuing debate over his ability to handle the job, Gordon Chase will take office tomorrow as the city's new Health Services Administrator.

title: PartTime Help: A Permanent Industry
description: Leasing, rather than own ing, property of all kinds from real estate to automo biles, from machinery to wa ter coolershas long been an accepted practice by American business. Today, moreover, many corporations are also leasing personnel, rather than employing them, for some of the same reasons and with much the same re sults.

title: T.V.A. Report Says Economic Growth Centers on Towns
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 3 Economic growth in the seven state Tennessee Valley region has concentrated in small and mediumsized towns, according to the Tennessee Valley Au thority's 36th annual report.

title: Mrs. Grielle Thomas Wright Is Married to Daniel J. Reiber
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Jan. 3 Mrs. M. Grielle Thomas Wright and Daniel John Rei ber of Portsmouth were mar ried here this afternoon in Emmanuel Episcopal Church. The Rev. Daniel Quimby Wil liams performed the cere mony. He was assisted by the Rev. Sidney Lovett, chap lain emeritus of Yale Univer sity.

title: Buffalo Outlasts Colgate
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 3 (AP)Buf talo withstood two secondhalf rallies tonight and defeated Colgate, 8076.

title: Militants Vow to Continue Protest at Harlem Church
description: Militant young Puerto Ricans who seized a Methodist church in East Harlem last Sunday vowed yesterday to continue their occupation until the police forcefully removed them or un til church officials agreed to let them run a breakfast prog gram for children there.

title: Article 4  No Title
NIXON ANNOUNCES SCIENCE MEDALS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  Achievements ranging from miniaturization of electronic circuits to the understanding of the role of viruses in cancer have been noted with the pres entation of the 1970 National Medal of Science Awards.

title: The Glass Bead Game
description: A glance at a portrait of Hermann Hesseaustere, unpretentiously bar ricaded behind steelrimmed glasses, yet sensitively openreveals the in ner contradictions of the man, his reputation, his work. And each time we meet with a new critical appraisal or another translation, these contra dictions impress themselves upon us anew.

title: FIRE ISLAND AREAS FACE NEW DANGER
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 3 Many homes facing the Atlantic Ocean in two communities on Fire Island were left vulnerable to further damage after a storm the week before last washed away much of the dunes that protect them.

title: Lam Leaves Paris Talks For Conference in Saigon
description: PARIS, Jan. 3 (AP)Ambas sador Pham Dang Lam, South Vietnam's chief negotiator at the Paris peace talks, flew to Saigon today for what he called routine discussions with his government. Be said he ex pected to be gone about 10 days.

title: Rams and Gabriel Trounce Cowboys In Playoff by 310
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3Roman Ga brief hurled scoring passes of 35 and 67 yards the first two times Los Angeles had the ball today, then he added two touchdown aerials in the sec ond half as the Rams trounced the Dallas Cowboys, 310, in the National Football League Playoff Bowl.

title: Colleen Takes Futurity at Spaniel Show Here
description: A smart little redandwhite cocker spaniel named Upsan Down's Colleen, owned by Mrs. Robert E. Grimshaw of Nor with, Conn., became dogdom's New Year's baby yesterday when she emerged as winner of the Futurity that always is an openingday highlight of the American Spaniel Club's na tional speciality.

title: L. F. AVNET DEAD; INDUSTRIALIST, 57
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3 Lester F. Avnet, honorary chair man of Avnet, Inc., one of the country's major electronics cor porations, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital after having suffered a heart attack. He was 57 years old and maintained residences here and in Kings Point. L.I.

title: SOUTH'S LATE PASS TOPS NORTH, 2423
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) Eddie Ray of Louisiana State threaded along the sideline to score on a 48yard pass play with 4:20 remaining today and John Riley of Auburn booted the deciding point as the South upset the North, 2423, in the second American Bowl game.

title: A Dual Role For Auctions In London
description: LONDONMost tourists who come to London for the first time go to the National Gallery to look at its paint ings by Renaissance and more mod ern artists and to the Tower of London to see the Crown Jewels. They usually miss Christie's and Sotheby's, the two largest auction houses in the world. Yet, each one functions as a museum with a con stantly changing collection of paintings, jewelry and other treasures on display.

title: Now Israel Fights the War of Attrition
description: JERUSALEM  On the Suez front last week, Israeli jets struck again and again at Egyptian po sitions, setting refineries on fire, hitting air defense sites, destroy ing artillery emplacements.

title: Criminals At Large
description: One way of compiling a mys tery anthology is to collect stories with a common theme. There is much to be said for this method, and a measure of its potential success can be seen in that outstanding volume The Man Who Called Himself Poe, edited by Sam Moskowitz, reviewed here a few months ago On the other hand, useful themes are not unlimited, and the inclusion of lesser tales to maintain a theme is not sup portable. It is a more common British practice to broaden the confines of anthologiesto in clude, for example, a generous portion of fact crime.

title: TANZANIA SHAPES A FLEXIBLE POLICY
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania Many Europeans and Ameri cans must have an impression of Tanzania, from the occa sional news report, as a doc trinaire place where rigid so cialist planners operate with Chinese advice and where youthful idealogues ban mini skirts.

title: Chinese Violinist Who Defected to U.S. in 1967 Reports He Has No Regrets
description: A leading violinist who es caped with his family from Communist China during the height of the Cultural Revolu tion three years ago is gradually adjusting to life in the United States.

title: Color the Next Decade a Lush Green
description: It's green, it's abundant, it's inflated. It buys oats for race horses, llama rugs for quarterbacks, domed stadiums for cities. It's money, and it will make the sports world go round in the seventies as never before.

title: FLORIDA TO DRAIN A POLLUTED LAKE
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 3Lake Apopka, which covers 50 square miles, will be drained and its bottom exposed to sunlight for several weeks in an attempt to rid the lake of pollution.

title: Gardens
description: DURING the last five to 10 years, so many new plants have been introduced that in the rush to try them, gardeners forget many older reliables. In some genera, new types and hybrids have been an improvement and in some cases they have provided wider plant usage.

description: BIFFERMrs. Louis Bi??er and family wish to thank their relatives and friends for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 3Joseph Carlyle Sitterson, Chancellor of the University of North Carolina, and Mrs. Sitterson have made known the engagement of their

title: The Nation
description: SAIGON  Have North Viet nam's leaders been forced to reevaluate their dream of a de cisive Communist military vic tory in the South and have they begun to prepare their people for a long, inconclusive and per haps futile struggle? Hanoi watchers in Saigon pondered these questions last week as they pored over lengthy news paper articles by North Viet nam's two top military leaders that suggested a possible shift of strategy because of battlefield losses and political and economic problems at home.

title: NET SAFETY BELT TESTED IN AUTOS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  Tests of a fishnetlike restraining device have aroused the inter est of Federal safety experts concerned about miscarriages in automobile crashes.

title: Builders' Repair Costs Rise
description: TWO of the major build ers of private homes in the New York area report that they are finding it necessary to in crease their outlays for repair work in newly con structed houses.

title: PRISONERS FARM ON INDONESIA ISLE
description: BURU, Indonesia Josephus Subiandi is one of 2,500 politi cal prisoners recently shipped to Buru island by the Indo nesian Government in a reset tlement Project.

title: BASEBALL FACES AN ERA OF CHANGE
description: By 1980, the baseball fan can expect the following things to come to pass:

title: Music
description: AFEW weeks ago the Wall Street Journal ran an article that surveyed predictions about the 1960's, made in 1960 by a group of prominent Ameri cans. One can sympathize with the plight of the seers, who look so foolish today. History these days zigzags like colliding atoms in a cloud chamber. It has come to the point where one hasty or stupid decision may not only alter the course of history. It may end history.

title: Rev. Dr. A. H. Lucas to Wed Mrs. Noyes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Mrs. Lelia Gordon Noyes and the Rev. Dr. Albert Hawley Lucas, plan to be married next month.

title: Who's Got the Last Hee Haw Now?
description: Do you laugh at jokes like: Do you know why a baby pig eats so much? Because he wants to make a hog of himself!

title: Alworth and Jurgensen Chosen as Top Pros
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) Lance Alworth, San Diego receiver, was named today as the outstanding player in the American Football League by the Washington Touch down Club.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: NEW YORK STATE

title: Ens. Ward Reynolds Anderson Weds Kathleen M. McConnell
description: CHAGRIN FALLS, Ohio, Jan. 3Miss Kathleen Mae McConnell, a December grad uate of Bucknell University, and Ens. Ward Reynolds Anderson, U.S.N.R., a 1968 graduate of Bucknell, were married here this afternoon in the Federated (Congrega tional) Church by the Rev. John Townsend.

title: Funds for Exploring
description: NEW models of deco rative plants are of as much value to man's welfare and economy as any other agri cultural and horticultural plants.

title: BATTLE IS NAMED TENNESSEE COACH
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 3 (UPI)Bill Battle, an assistant the last four years, was named Tennessee's head football coach today. He succeeded Doug Dickey, who resigned Wednes day to become head coach at Florida.

title: Mrs. Agnew on Her Own in Taipei
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 3 While Vice President Agnew conferred with Chinese Na tionalist officials during his oneday stay here, his wife, Judy, weathered her first ex perience in keeping her own schedule of official appear ances on their Asian tour, her first trip abroad.

title: ENEMY IN VIETNAM STRIKES U.S. CAMP; RAID 3D IN 6 DAYS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3  North Vietnamese troops made a third concen trated assault in six days on American soldiers in a field camp last night, killing seven Americans and seriously wounding 11, the United States military command reported to day. The command also reported three instances of firing and shelling attacks by enemy gun ners yesterday from positions inside the demilitarized zone, the first attacks from the zone in more than two months. One shelling resulted in an unspeci fied number of Americans wounded but none killed, Unit ed States headquarters said.

title: WALTER W. ROBINSON
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Jan. 3 Walter W. Robinson of 1 Eng lish Village, manager for many years of industrial development for the Central Railroad of New Jersey in Newark, died yester day. He was 63 years old.

title: Helen Bloom Fiancee of R. M. Lewis
description: Miss Helen Ann Bloom, public relations consultant in London, plans to be married to Richard M. Lewis, who is with the International Pub lishing Corporation, Ltd., there.

title: Josef von Sternberg 1894 1969
description: THE death of Josef von Sternberg followed a long period of enforced inactivity in his chosen profes sion. A legend resurrected in his own lifetime, Sternberg was a frequent guest of festivals, mu seums, universities and other embalming institutions. But there were no calls from the studios, and all the dream projects of his late years were effectively aborted. The unpublished writer, the unsold painter, the uncommis sioned sculptor, the unsung composer may all be dis couraged by neglect, but their output is still physically possible. By contrast, a film director cut off from financing is like a king in exile, a creature dependent for his very functioning more on politics than on poetics.

title: Hunt Urges More Imagination In Pro Football Club Operation
description: DALLAS, Jan. 3At a pro fessional football game ear lier this season, Lamar Hunt, owner of the visiting Kansas City Chiefs, contacted a rival owner about allowing the Chiefs' cheerleaders to per form during the game.

title: Private Inquiry Group Stirs Both Parties in Illinois
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 3 Mayor Richard J. Daley was so angry, recently at Chicago's Better Government Association that he aimed his roughest epithet at it. He accused it of being an arm of the Republican party.

title: INTEGRATION LOW THROUGHOUT U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) The Government reported to day that 61 per cent of the nation's Negro students and 65.6 per cent of whites still attended largely segregated schools, 14 years after the Su preme Court's desegregation decision.

title: How Much for a Volunteer Army?
description: WASHINGTONThe possibil ity of an end to the draft, with the armed forces moving into the marketplace to compete for young men like the rest of the nation's employers, seemed one step closer last week. There were reports that a prestigious Presi dential commission was about to declare such a move entirely feasible and not outrageously exoensive.

title: Milton Avery: A Confidence of Vision
description: WASHINGTON. THE career of the Ameri can painter Milton Av ery, who died on Janu ary 3, 1965, at the age of 71, was one of the most astonishing in the art of his time. It was a career without interruptions, digressions, or climaxes. There was about it no suggestion of suffering, in decision, or the problematical. In place of these familiar con stituents of the modern paint er's career there was instead a steady flow of observation, inspiration, and realization. Avery was one of the purest painters of the twentieth century, not only in America but anywhere, and his work remains even now a miracle of untroubled clarity and lyr ic grace.

title: Suddenly Ph.D.'s Are A Glut on The Market
description: We're a glut on the market, said a new Ph.D. in English last week during the frantic job seeking forays that are typical of the annual meetings of scholars.

title: Nancy Booth Affianced To Peer E. Wedvick Jr.
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Jan. 3  Mr. and Mrs. John McLaughlin Booth have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Ellen Booth, to Peer Eiler Wedvick Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wedvick of Haworth, N. J.. and New York.

title: Puerto Rico Plans New Track for '72
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 3 In Puerto Rico, where 12 months of horse racing amounts to a $50milliona year industry, a second track is scheduled to open by 1972.

title: Toynbee Says Chinese Threat May Spur Global Unity in '70's
description: Arnold Toynbee, the British historian, said this week that China has the best chance of any nation of bringing the world together into some form of unity in the nineteenseven ties.

title: Is the Missing Ingredient Commitment?
description: THE 1970's are here, and the problems that plagued the past decade in the cultural field do not look is if they are going to vanish. The recent differences between management and performers at the Metropolitan Opera and with various orchestras around the country may have been resolved for the immediate future, but the sources of those differences are still very much present.

title: HAVLICEK GETS 31
M0WRY LEADS IN GOLF ON COAST BY 2 SHOTS
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI)Larry Mowry, a six year competitor on the Profes sional Golfers' Association tour, added a 69 today to his open inground 70 for a threeunder par 139 and a twostroke lead after 36 holes of the $52,000 Southern California open golf tournament.

title: Timothy H. Harwood Is Fiance Of Josephine Osborn Prentice
description: GARRISON, N. Y., Jan. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Ezra P. Pren tice Jr. have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Josephine Osborn Prentice, to Timothy Head Harwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Harwood of North Andover, Mass.

title: Coast Ministry Seeks to Close Gap Between Various Cultures
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 3A group of men and women, joining to gether to build bridges between cultural groups in the city, waited in line with burns one recent weekend at skid row soup kitchens.

title: That's what the Weathermen are supposed to be..
description: We were talking the other night and we realized that all our heroes are dead, Bill Ayers was saying. Wow, what a trip!

title: GameBound Fan Can Pause to Pray
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 3The stock and the pillory have long since disappeared as methods of punishing the sin ful. But tomorrow, at a reli gious ceremony before the Na tional Football League cham pionship game, a repentant sin ner could very well slip into the hockey penalty box.

title: College and School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Ferre Names Finance Aide
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 3 (UPI)Gov. Luis A. Ferro has named Angel R. Martin, a lawyer, as Secretary of Fi nance, succeeding Angel M. Rivera, who resigned. Dr. Martin, who is to take office Jan. 10, has been practicing law in San Juan.

title: The. Week in Finance:
ROCKEFELLER ASKS $1.85 WAGE FLOOR
description: Governor Rockefeller will ask the 1970 Legislature to in crease the state's minimum hourly wage from $1.60 to $1.85.

title: College Football
description: In a classroom at the Uni versity of California this week about 200 students, many of them college football players, will begin the first serious sociopsychological evalua tion of intercollegiate ath letics.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: BUYERS of brownstones, who are often among New York's most enthusiastic residents, are rediscovering certain areas of Brooklyn in their unrelenting search for housing bargains.

title: Zoo's Casqued Hornbill Snared Above Park Ave.
description: A large tropical bird that eluded nets and tranquilizer guns and scorned lures of food as it swooped through the chilly skies of Manhat tan's Upper East Side was netted on a penthouse ledge yesterday and returned to the safety of captivity.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Jan. 8Bay Ridge Sports Car Club business meeting at The Gallery, 91st Street and 4th Ave nue, Brooklyn; 9 P.M.

title: Motor Sports
description: Motor racing, second only to horse racing in paid at tendance, is on the threshold of immense growth in the seventies.

title: Report Sees Losses in Freedom in '69
description: A study of the state of free dom around the world has con cluded that 1969 was a year of net losses for Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America. The report, by Freedom House, found net gains in freedom only in Western Europe and the United States and no real change in Eastern Europe.

title: Dilemma of Economic Policy
description: The United States economy enters 1970 trapped a nexus of opposing but interlocking forces. Prices are climbing at an annual rate of almost 6 per cent and, even worse, inflationary expectations have entered deeply into the calculations and decisions of business, labor and consumers.

title: LOURIA REACHES SEMIFINAL ROUND
description: GLEN COVE, LI., Jan. 3 Donald Louria of New York, the 1964 winner, led the way into the semifinal round today in the 38th Luckenbach Me morial singles squash racquets tournament at the Nassau Country Club.

title: Bohler Wins Bear Mountain Ski Jump
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 3Performing in a snow storm that made visibility poor and the landing area sticky, Karl Bohler of nearby Peekskill topped a small field in the 25th annual Torger Tokle Memorial ski jumping tournament today.

title: Reserve Clause Is a Complicated Thing
description: About Pro Baseball

title: 30C TRANSIT FARE GOES INTO EFFECT
description: The city's subway fare went up to 30 cents at midnight last night, but despite some angry complaints, long lines at the token booths, and lastminute jostling to use the old 20cent tokens, the changeover went smoothly.

title: Kalamazoo 5 Tops Wabash
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Jan. 3 (AP)  Kalamazoo College scored 11 straight points to break a 6565 tie with three minutes remaining today and defeated Wabash College of In diana, 7668, in a nonleague basketball game. Dan Laskoski scored 16 points to lead Kala mazoo.

title: Miss Sydney Weinberger Is Engaged
description: GREAT NECK., L. I., Jan. 3Col. Arthur Henry Wein berger, U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Weinberger have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sydney Weinberger, to Pvt. Edward S. Shulman, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Shulman of Syosset.

title: Reform at H.E.W.
description: Health, Education and Welfare Secretary Robert H. Finch has acted correctly and wisely in ending the system of secret, informal blacklisting that has for years denied his agency the services of some of the ablest American scientists. Moreover, as Mr. Finch's consultant, Harlan R. Ellis, noted, the security pro cedures now dropped created a Kafkaesque atmos phere in which the fundamental legal rights of those affected were denied without opportunity for redress.

title: Mickey Thompson Hurt In Snowmobile Mishap
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI)Mickey Thompson, a racecar builder, informed his sister, Mrs. Coleen Thompson,Campbell, by tele phone tonight that he had suffered four broken ribs and a broken arm when a snow mobile in which he was riding overturned.

title: Army TV Man Charges Suppression of Truth
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 (AP)A television newscaster on the American Forces Vietnam Network charged over the air today that a broadcast on the net work is not free to tell the truth.

title: Ivory Coast Reports an Attempt To Revive Secession Movement
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 3 (Agence FrancePresse)In terior Minister Nanlo Bamba disclosed this week that a se cessionist movement among the Agni tribesmen in the south east of this West African na tion had flared recently, long after it was thought to be dead.

title: ILLINOIS DISTRICTING UPSET BY U.S. COURT
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 3The 1965 apportionment plan for Con gressional districts in Illinois was declared unconstitutional this week.

title: LEMAIRE TALLIES PAIR IN SESSION
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (UPI)  Jacques Lemaire scored twice tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens out of a fourgame slump with a 51 victory over the Oakland Seals in a National Hockey League game.

title: 2 Americans Reach Hanoi As Part of Peace Group
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 3 (Reu ters)A Vietnam peace dele gation, including two Ameri cans, has arrived in Hanoi, the official North Vietnamese press agency said today.

title: Statisticians Charge Draft Lotter'y Was Not Random
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The new draft lottery is being challenged by statisticians and politicians on the ground that the selection process did not produce a truly random result.

title: Preserving Maine's Islands
description: MANCHESTER, Me.,  In only a few short years, the Maine chapter of the Na ture Conservancy has insured that the natural beauty of more than 2,000 acres of coastal and inland Maine will be preserved.

title: Postal Rates for Magazines And Newspapers Are Raised
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Post Office Department is now charging higher rates for newspapers, magazines and other second class mail and ex pects $15million additional a year from them.

title: JoAnn Albano Plans Wedding To J. A. Cohen
description: Miss JoAnn Philomena Albano, daughter of the chairman of the New York County Republican Commit tee, plans to be married to James A. Cohen, a senior at the New York University Law School.

title: West Germany Modernizing 1,310 Miles of Old Autobahns
description: BONN, Jan. 3The 1,310 miles of hastily built auto bahns that the Hitler era left West Germany will be virtually replaced by 1985.

title: Flowers Line the Tourist's Path in Europe
description: SIGHTS, shopping and amusements vary from country to country, but every where in Europe flowers line the tour ist's path. From the misty street corners of Dublin to the faded stone slabs in the no carsallowed center of Dubrovnik, flowers are part of the setting. They are sold from a battered basket at the Cais do Soda, train station in Lisbon and from a cart near the rue de la Paix in Paris. They are so plentiful in southern Europe that the names of cities, schools and other institutions of ten are florally inscribed on lawns. Through out the winter on the French and Italian Rivieras, flowers are sold daily and shipped to northern Europe. Tourists can attend flower markets and observe the goingson. There are also many organized flower shows and extravaganzas, and in many Continen tal cities, railroad stations are perked up by flowerpots hanging with the majesty of crystal chandeliers or by flower boxes set out in long lines.

title: Ellen Ross Davidson Married To Robert S. Page in jersey
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 3 Miss Ellen Ross Davidson was married here this after noon to Robert Samuel Page, a student at the Boston Architectural Center. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Hugh Liven good, assisted by the Rev. David R. King.

title: U.S. Business:
description: CADIZ, Ohio, Jan. 3Coal mine expansions in eastern Ohio costing more than $25 million have been announced by two concerns  North American Coal Corporation and the Hanna Coal Division of Consolidation Coal Com pany.

title: Janet Freer Fiancee of Michael Malone
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., Jan. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Graham R. Freer have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Janet G. Freer, to Mid shipman Michael D. Malone, a first classman at the United States Naval Academy. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Malone of Farmingdale. A

title: Bell Chosen as Top Official For N.F.L. Showdown Game
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 3 (AP)Tommy Bell, the ref eree, headed the list of offi cials named today by Commis sioner Pete Rozelle for the National Football League title game tomorrow.

title: Article 6  No Title
BALUSTRADE WINS AS LAUREL CLOSES
description: LAUREL, Md. Jan. 3 (AP) Balustrade, often in the money but seldom a winner, soundly beat five rivals today in the $16,375 Walter Haight Handi cap as Laurel Race Course completed a 49day meeting.

title: Observer: Tote That Ball
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  It was not until early December that one sensed he might be seeing something historic. It was Dec. 14, in fact, and Junius Loftlubber, fabled interior line man for the McKeesport Duck bill Platypuses had just been assisted from the field by his colleagues.

title: Legislature Will Take Up Leftover Problems of 60's
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3The 1970 session of the New York Legis lature will convene Wednesday to find the problems of the dec ade just past have spilled over into the new one.

title: Engine Standardization Urged As Sport's Route to Big League
description: THAT nonstop subject for racing's hotstove league is with us againa proposal to adopt a standard engine formula that would weld all of auto racing into one Big League. And I'm for it100 per cent. Despite the fantas tic growth of auto racing, it still operates like sandlot baseball. There are three racing leagues in the United States and they all have a different set of engine sizes. The Europeans are different still. The august Federation Internationale de l'Automobile, better known as the F.I.A., now proposes that we Americans come along on a new engine size proposal which they think might make sense for every one.

title: Advertising:
description: During an interview last week Andrew Kershaw, the recently elected president of Ogilvy & Mather, kept men tioning the name David. In the ad game, but more es pecially at Ogilvy & Mather, the name can mean only David Ogilvy, one of the more visible and talented persons in a visible business of talented people.

title: LION GUARD HITS 1000POINT MARK
description: It was a moving experience for Heyward Dotson, Colum bia's star guard, last night as he scored 30 points to lead the Lions to an 8463 Ivy League victory over Cornell in the winner's gym.

title: 2 Polish Teachers Jailed For Aiding Students in Tests
description: WARSAW, Jan. 3 (Reuters) Two college teachers have been sentenced to two years in jail for smuggling answers to students at a polytechnical college entrance examination, a Warsaw newspaper has re ported.

title: Point of View
description: IN the face of the rising awareness that the future happiness of most of us will turn upon our ability to solve the problem of the cities, it would appear that everyone must now become concerned with the proper role of local participation in the scheme of govern ment. Especially must we be concerned as to the impact of local participation on the planning of our physical urban environment.

title: Business Index Fell in Week
Lanier, Mount Choices On AllTourney Five
description: Bob Lanier of St. Bonaven ture and Rick Mount of Pur due were unanimous choices on the coaches E.C.A.C. Holi day Festival alltournament team announced yesterday.

title: Ellen Muskie Is Wed in Capital To Ernest M. Allen, a Veteran
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  Miss Ellen Muskie, daughter of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and Mrs. Muskie, was married here this after noon to Ernest Michael Allen, a 23yearold veteran who served with the Army in Vietnam.

title: Carole R. Hoffman Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Carole Ruth Hoffman and Stan Edward Mawson who met as Peace Corps vol unteers in Colombia, are plan ning an early spring wedding.

title: Different Birthday for Twins
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Jan. 3 (AP)Dennis and Betty Steed have twin sons with different birthdays. At 10:10 P.M. last Sunday, Mrs. Steed gave birth to Kim Ray. Fifteen and a half hours later, on Monday, Kyle Dee was delivered by Caesar ean section.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Reader's Report
description: The weather shelter on Gro ver Danford's pony farm in Wolverton, Tenn. shelters more than ponies. A lot of courtin goes on under it too. Here Grover has trysted with his beautiful mistress, Kathlee, whom the local color bar pre vented him from marrying. Here the farm's foreman, Jim Whittaker, had courted his wife. And here, Jeff Bazemore.

title: Love, Boy
description: When he died suddenly of a heart attack in 1963, Mac Hyman was 40, distressingly restless, and the author of a novel, No Time for Sergeants (which was also a successful play and film), three short stories and an article. A second novel, Take Now Thy Son, on which he had worked for most of his adult life, was pub lished a few years after his death, but received little attention.

title: Paris ExAide Is Freed
description: PARIS, Jan. 3 (UPI)Presi dent Pompidou has granted amnesty to Maurice Picard, former Interior Ministry official who was sentenced in 1968 to seven years in prison on espio nage charges, official sources said today.

title: Iona Defeats Kings, 8175, With Mazzella Top Scorer
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 3With Joe Mazzella pouring in 29 points, Iona recorded an 8175 basketball victory over Kings College of Pennsylvania tonight in a MidEastern Asso ciation game.

title: What Happened to the Monetary Crisis?
description: WASHINGTON If 1969 was hardly a year of good news on most fronts, it closed with the most satisfactory situation in years in an area that had pro duced its share of troublesthe international monetary system.

title: East meets West
description: The dish the Japanese call shabushabu is sometimes called oriental fondue in this country. It consists of wafer thin slices of beef (instead of chunks, as in as occidental meat fondue) cooked briefly in a boiling liquid and dipped into a savory sauce. As in the West, it is a communal dish and any number (depending on the size of the shabushabu pot) can play. Shabushabu is served at Saito, 131 West 52d Street, one of New York's best Japanese restaurants, and here we give the recipe of the Saito chef. Shabushabu is onomatopoeic; it imitates the sound of chopsticks as they swirl in the broth.

title: Bridge
