description: LOSING control at the bridge table does not mean shouting and screaming, although that does hap pen in tournament play rather more often than it should. It means reach ing a position in which your trumps, as declarer, are outnumbered by those of one of the defenders.

title: The Oppenheimer Case
description: During the decade of the 1940's, two mighty weapon systems were fashioned in the United States. Both are still very much with us. One is the nuclear bomb, in good part the work of a group of scientists and engineers at Los Alamos under the direction of J. Robert Oppenheimer. The other is the security system, under which Government agencies in vestigate the actions, opinions, asso ciations, private lives and political beliefs of individuals. Oppenheimer himself became a prominent victim of the security system in its abuse.

title: PEACE CORPS GIVES A YEAREND REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Peace Corps, in a year end report, said this week that several changes in the eight yearold organization had been made under its new director, Joseph H. Blatchford.

title: An exercise in exorcising
description: The large rooms and rambling spaces of old Long Island houses with their gray weathered shingles are the envy of many in cipiently claustrophobic apartment dwellers, but the haunted house atmosphere of many of these same structures is not. In the East Hampton house seen here, Robert A. M. Stem, a young architect, exorcised all ghosts of the past by painting all the walls and some of the floors white. He furnished the large airy shells of rooms with modem furniture and art objects. His wife had always admired the huge sideboards, kitchen tables and armoires of turnofthecentury houses, and so he designed new versions of these. Finally, an enormous porch was added to open the house to the light and air of the outdoors.

title: Coins
description: AGENERAL air of opti mism surrounds the numismatic field going into 1970. Most of the dealers we interviewed ex pect continued activity in buying and selling by col lectors of coins, paper cur rency, tokens, medals and books. A few expressed the belief that prices of proof and mint sets would level off and the public would be more cau tious and selective in its pur chases.

title: Police Cameras Click as DeCavalcante's Son Marries
description: TRENTON, Jan. 3A son of Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumb er) DeCavalcante, the reputed Mafia leader, was married here today in a Roman Catholic ser vice that was discreetly photo graphed from outside by unin vited policemen.

title: World Shipping Looks to Continued Growth in 70's
description: World shipping, with 10 years of solid economic and technical progress behind it, looks to another decade of growth.

title: The New Play
description: LAST OF THE RED HOT LOVERS, a comedy by Neil Simon, got raves from three critics, warm ap proval from two, and a mildly favorable response from three. Clive Barnes: It is extraordinarily funny and yet also endearing. This is a comedy that will linger with you even when the laughs it gave you have turned into an amorphous if appreciative memory. There is the dimension of humanity to its humor so that you can love it as well as laugh at It. Last of the Red Hot Lovers is the story of Barney Cashman's battle to join the sexual revolu tion. For my money, it is Mr. Simon's most consider able achievement to date. Robert Moore's staging makes most agreeable use of visual humor. James Coco as Barney is a joy and Linda Lavin, Marcia Rodd and Doris Roberts are admirably contrasted. Of course Mr. Simon has done it again. But I think he may have done some thing more. So naturally go and see it. But don't go just for the laughs. For Walter Kerr, see Page. 1.

title: COUGARS TRIUMPH OVER NETS, 10091
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 3 (AP) Carolina blew a nine  point halftime lead but rallied in the final period on the shooting of Bob Verga for a 10091 Ameri can Basketball Association vic tory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: Turner a Big Boost to Vanderbilt Five
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 3The re bound caromed high off the backboard and Steve Turner went up to retrieve it, but as he prepared to pass, the ball was slapped away by a smaller opposing player.

title: Name of distinction
description: In the world of fashion, where boutiques come and go like the seasons, T. Jones is something of a phenomenon. Eva and Steve Blatt opened the first T. Jones (they simply picked the name off the marquee of a movie house showing Tom Jones) in 1965. Now there are fourtwo in Manhattan, one in Boston, another in Chicago. Cognoscenti pride themselves on recog nizing a T. Jones anywhere, which pleases the Blatts enor mously, for, as Steve says, Identity is the name of the game. What identity? Well, he designs for what he likes to call the petite womanhighbosomed and highwaisted.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Maryland Express
description: PARISThere are many in dications that a dark horse may soon join the struggle for leadership of the Democratic party when Sargent Shriver, U.S. Ambassador to France, de parts in order to seek his party's nomination and election as Governor of Maryland. Noth ing is definite but if Shriver decides to enter the race he must announce his intention before this spring's primary.

title: Letters
description: DEFENSE IS WHOSE BUSINESS?

title: Both Parties Press Crime As 1970 Campaign issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The new year is bringing an old problemcrimeto the fore front as a major issue of the 1970 Congressional campaign.

title: For Democrats, Happy Days Are Not Yet Here Again
description: WASHINGTON  Hubert H. Humphrey was meditating the other day on his state of mind after he lost the Presidential election in 1968 to Richard M. Nixon. I was running dry, he said, I needed new ideas.

title: Sports of The Times
description: STILL unsettled after almost a year of sometimes acrimonious argumentation is the distribution into divisions of the 13 teams in the National Conference of the merged pro football leagues. An infinite variety of proposed groupings has been offered but angry objections have come from whatever clubs have been tentatively slotted in the same division with the Minnesota Vikings. Nobody wants any part of the Vikes.

title: Appeal for Blood Donors Cites Acute Shortage Here
description: Dr. August H. Groeschel, chairman of the Blood Commit tee of the Greater New York Hospital Association, appealed again yesterday for blood donors, saying that the supply of blood had reached the acute stage in shortage.

title: Such Happy Souvenirs
description: WHEN the American Association for the Advance ment of Science decided to hold its 1969 annual meeting in Boston, Agnes Mongan, director Harvard's Fogg Art Museum, was given the nudge to come through with a hospitable gesture of a cultural nature. Like a good housewife after a successful inventory of the freezer in a comparable emergency, the Fogg has turned out an artandscience exhibition drawn from Harvard's historical collections in both fields.

title: School Closings Threaten Several Cities in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 3 All of Ohio's 2.4 million public school pupils will return to school Monday, but the finan cial problems that closed class es in 10 school districts during November and December con tinue to increase throughout the state.

title: SYDNEY DEPLORES BILKING OF GI'S
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 3 A statement made in a United States Senate commit tee hearing on crimes against American servicemen on leave here has aroused concern among Sydney officials.

title: Ran Brown Trial Put Off
description: BEI AIR, Md., Jan. 3 (AP) A Circuit Court judge, Harry E. Dyer Jr., said this week that the trial of H. Rap Brown on inciting to riot charges had been delayed until March 2.

title: Fight for Survival
description: President Nixon's characterization of the battle against the pollution of the environment as a now ornever fight offers new hope that this survival issue will be given top priority, not in discussion nanels but in action.

title: Tennis
description: In the new decade, tennis will continue the growth that began with the recent ad vent of open competition.

title: Safe and 2 Vehicles Stolen From School for Retarded
description: Four or five men early yes terday stole a safe with $500 and two rented station wagons from the Edenwald School, which is operated for retarded children by the Jewish Child Care Association of New York at 1250 East 229th Street, the Bronx.

title: U.M.W. CHIEF ASKS PARLEY ON SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  W. A. (Tony) Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers of America, who was reelected last month after a bruising campaign in which he was ac cused of neglecting miners' safety, called on the Govern ment today to convene imme diately a national conference on enforcement of the tough new Federal mine health and safety regulations that became law this week.

title: FOUR METS PICKED BY SPORTS LODGE
description: Four members of the New York MetsTom Seaver, Cleon Jones, Tommie Agee and Art Shamskywill be honored by Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith at the organization's 19th an nual Bill Corum Memorial Awards Dinner on Saturday, Jan. 24 in the Hotel Roosevelt. The quartet will be cited by Sports Lodge for high prin ciple and achievement in sports in 1969.

title: Mekong Delta School Run by Nuns Rescues Orphaned and Runaway Girls.
description: VINHLONG, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 (AP)When Tuyet was 6 years old she ran away from her temperamental father and her home in a Saigon slum. She roamed the streets five years and became a leader of a gang of urchins who made their living by picking pockets.

title: ARMY VANQUISHES FORDHAM BY 5244
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 3 Trailing by 15 points at the half, Army limited Fordham to just 5 in the final 12 minutes and fought back to a 5244 basketball victory tonight.

title: Article 2  No Title
RAND, CALDWELL WIN SKI JUMPING
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 3 (AP)Jay Rand, a 19yearold college student from Lake Placid, captured the skijumping competition of the national Nordic combined championships today with two jumps of 179 feet.

title: Julian Bond Emerges as Symbol of Black America's Problems and Promise
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 The words used to sound odd coming from so neatly trimmed a young man and spoken in such quiet tones, with only an occasional lift of an eyebrow for punctua tion.

title: PRESIDENT GOLFS ON COAST COURSE
description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3  President Nixon, dressed in golf clothes, took a couple of stiff practice swings today, felt the small of his back and turned away from his ball in mock agony.

title: NEW TAXES SOUGHT IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 3 The 1970 session of the Penn sylvania legislature will con vene at noon Tuesday with an unsolved tax problem involving more than $200million left on its doorstep by the still linger ing 1969 session.

title: Susan Barkhouse to Be Married
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 3  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Barkhouse Jr. of the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Barkhouse, to Alan B. Daroff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell A. Daroff of Philadelphia.

title: Recordings
description: STRONGER THAN DIRT: Big Mama Thornton. (Mercury SR 61225) Wil lie Mae Big Mama Thornton is a robust, power fulvoiced blues shouter whose career reaches back to the late forties. Just as so many black performers, she served a painful apprenticeship as maid and cleaning woman both before and after she be gan to sing professionally.

title: TRANSIT SYSTEM STILL FACES DEBT
description: The new 30cent subway and bus fare will still leave the Transit Authority facing $84 million in debts to the, city for the last six months. It would produce an operating balance only by optimistic projections this year and next.

title: Like, Y'Know, a Guide To the AvantGarde
description: IS there a need for a Dictionary of the Musical AvantGarde? The fol lowing letter recently received by critic suggests there is:

title: Fill 'er Up Now Means Car and Customers, Too
description: THE growth of Interstate highways and the advent of automobiles that need servicing less frequently are hav ing a profound effect on the design of gasoline stations, especially those sit uated near superhighway exit and entrance ramps.

title: The Making Of a Red Guard
description: ON June 1, 1966, the Cultural Revolution reached our high school in Amoy, a port city in the South Chinese coastal province of Fukien. Actually, it had been vis ibly approaching in May, when in tense criticism mounted in the news papers against the literature, plays and movies called poisonous weeds. As the outside disturbances pene trated our classrooms, our teachers lost their pep and appeared uneasy. Many of them were worshipers of the poisonous weeds. They became very cautious and no longer told lit tle personal anecdotes to their stu dents.

title: 10 Civilians Reported Killed
description: SAIGON, Sunday, Jan. 4  The South Vietnamese Govern ment reported today that enemy troops fired 40 mortar shells at 3 A.M. today into two refugee camps near Anhoa, southwest of Danang, killing 10 Vietnamese civilians and wounding 50.

title: Apollo Launchings May Go Beyond '73 With One Canceled
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 3 (UN)  The Federal space agency has said it may drop one of the eight remaining Apollo moon landing missions and stretch the current lunar exploration program into late 1973 or beyond.

title: Bradshaw Gets Aggies Post
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Jan. 3 (AP)Texas A. and M. announced today that Charlie Bradshaw, a former head coach at Kentucky, had become a member of the Aggie coaching staff.

title: The System
description: Brooks are frozen in their beds, ponds and quiet reaches of the rivers are iced in, and northward into New England the land is blanketed with two and three feet of snow. Winter has settled in early, as the countryman says. And, as always in recent years, heavy snowfall and early ice cause trouble. City streets are clogged, major highways are treacherous if not impassable, power lines are down. Food sup plies dwindle at the markets. Homes are without heat for lack of oil or electricity. Emergencies are declared.

title: Long Island Boy Wins Punt, Pass, Kick Final
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3  Tony Capozzoli of East Nor wich, L. I., won the na tional championship in the Ford  National Football League punt, pass and kick contest today. The finals were held during the half time of the NFL Playoff Bowl game in the Orange Bowl.

title: Steel's MiniMills Spread
description: One of the newer bits of business folklore concerns the rapid development of the highly efficient and relative ly cheap electric furnace for making steel.

title: St. Francis Turns Back Le Moyne Quintet, 9069
description: Capt. John Conforti scored 38 points to lead St. Francis of Brooklyn to a 9069 victory over Le Moyne of Syracuse last night at the 69th Regiment Armory.

title: Two Banks Expect High Rates to Persist in International Bond Markets
description: Demands for funds in the international bond market are likely to keep interest rates high for the next sever al months.

title: Wellesley Alumna Takes Office As Mayor of Luxembourg City
description: LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 3 (AP) Colette Flesch, who is 32 years old and a graduate of Wellesley College, became the first woman mayor of this capi tal city of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg this week.

title: TEXAS G.O.P. SEEKS TWO TOP OFFICES
description: AUSTIN, Jan. 3The Repub lican party of Texas is prepared to accept the responsibility for the management of this Govern ment when the voters entrust this responsibilty to us.

title: Aide to F.P.C. Chief Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) Harry H. Voight, a lawyer from New York City, was named today as an assistant to John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission. Mr. Voight, a native of Louis ville, Ky., has been with the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York.

title: THE OPENINGS
description: THE MEMORY BANK  Tonight, Tambel lini's Gate Theater, 7:15. Two oneact plays by Martin Duberman.

title: Hubbard's Nerves Go Up in Smoke
Ballet: Holiday's Fare
description: WHAT would Christmas be without The Nutcrack er? For that matter what would The Nutcracker be without Christmas? However the yearend rituals of New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater are now settled in their ways, and The Nutcracker and Christ mas go together like witches and hemlock.

title: 14 PRIESTS DECIDE ON ACTIVIST CLERIC
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 For the first time in the history of Roman Catholicism in the United States, a bishop has sub mitted for review by a commit tee of priests a decision regard ing a cleric's assignment.

title: From Romeo To Canio
description: Having given Romeo and Juliet new elan for millions of moviegoers, particularly young ones, director Franco Zeffirelli, is now attempting to revitalize Cav and Pag for the Metropolitan Opera. His new production of the double bill opens there Thursday.

title: Protest Sent to U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 3The Lebanese mission today sent a protest note from its Government on the latest Is raeli attacks to the President of the Security Council, Trence Nsanze of Burundi. It accused Israel of aggression and kid napping and asked the presi dent to circulate the note as a Security Council document. It did not ask for a meeting of the Council however.

title: British Aide Leaves for U.S.
description: LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP)Chan cellor of the Exchequer Roy H. Jenkins left tonight for an eightday visit to the United States, where he will meet with businessmen and bankers. In Chicago, Mr. Jenkins will ad dress the BritishAmerican Chamber of Commerce and the Council for Foreign Relations. He also will visit New York land San Francisco.

title: Further Arrests Indicated in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 3 (Reuters)An Indonesian Gov ernment spokesman said today that highranking Indonesian Army officers were being ar rested because they opposed and wanted to change the present administration.

title: Bodell to Fight Quarry
description: LONDON, Jan. 3 (UPI)Jack Bodell, the first southpaw to hold the British heavyweight boxing title, will meet Jerry Quarry at Los Angeles, Feb. 23, his manager said today.

title: Virginia Lynde Is Bride on L.I. Of J. M. Headden
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Jan. 3  Miss Virginia Anne Lynde, daughter of State Supreme Court Justice Edwin Rogers Lynde and Mrs. Lynde of Brookville, was married this afternoon to Jeffrey Miles Headden; son of Mr. and Mrs. William Perry Headden of Mountain Lakes, N. J.

title: Gedo P. With Stretch Drive,  Wins Dash At Narragansett
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Jan. 3 (AP)Lynn Whiting's Gedo P. caught the pacesetting Charter Oak Bridge in the stretch today and drove on to a halflength victory in the $7,500 Pawtucket Handicap at Narragansett Park.

title: Color Films Show Slaying of a Youth At Coast Rock Rally
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI)Homicide investigators have color movies of the fatal stabbing of an 18yearold youth at last month's Rolling Stones rock festival at the Altamount race track but have been un able to make an arrest.

title: For the Black Athlete, New Advances
description: I was at a wedding; my wife and a few friends were the only Negroes there, says 0. J. Simpson, and I overheard a lady at the next table say, Look, there's 0. J. Simpson and some niggers. Isn't that weird? That sort of thing hurts me, even though it's what I strive for, to be a man first.

title: FINANCES ELICIT S 0 S FROM PILOTS
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 3 (UPI)  A group of businessmen said to day they must raise $3.5million right now or possibly give up plans to purchase the Seattle Pilots and keep the American League baseball team here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Israelis Reported Killed
description: BEIRUT, Jan. 3A Gov ernment communiqu reported today that the Lebanese Army killed three Israeli soldiers dur ing the raid on an outpost at Tal Nahas, near the Israeli bor der. The communiqu added that the Israelis blew up sev eral buildings before withdraw ing.

title: Racing
description: It's Dec. 22 and shell shocked horse players at a thoroughbred track in snowy Philadelphia gaze at the tote board odds with the fascina tion of kids watching lights blink on a Christmas tree.

title: Article 3  No Title
Growth Lag Felt in '69 By Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 3 Oregon's gross product, hit by a lagging lumber in dustry, had its third lowest real rate of growth during the last decade in 1969.

title: Hungary to Ease Travel to West In Move Toward Liberalization
description: VIENNA, Jan. 3The Hun garian Government announced today a new draft law on pass ports that is expected to make it easier for Hungarians to travel to Western countries.

title: Medicine
description: WASHINGTONThe millions of refrigerators, medicine cabi nets and night tables in the United States are filled with products that havetheoretical lybeen approved by the Fed eral Government for use by Americans. Yet 18,000 Ameri cans die and 20 million are in jured by pesticides, flammable fabrics, electric appliances and other common but hazardous products, and at least 2 million people become ill from eating contaminated food.

title: The World
description: BEIRUT, LebanonBefore he went to the Arab summit con ference at Rabat, Morocco, two weeks ago, President Gamal Ab del Nasser held a strategy con ference with King Faisal in Cairo and made a deal with him. Mr. Nasser was to avoid extreme antiAmericanism and other forms of radicalism that would embarrass Faisal. In return, Faisal was to drop his in sistence that Mr. Nasser re nounce the November, 1967, Security Council resolution which calls for political settle ment between Israel and the Arab states. Faisal was also to go along with overall Arab mo bilization against Israel as planned by Egypt's General Mo hamed Fawzi.

title: Anthony Brady Farrell Dead; Broadway Producer Was 69
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3 (AP)An thony Brady Farrell, a former producer of Broadway plays and former owner of the Mark Hellinger Theater in New York City, died today at the Albany Medical Center Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Job Changes:
description: Dr. George deStevens has been named executive vice president of the CIBA Phar maceutical Company, Sum mit, N. J. He formerly was vice presidentresearch and a member of the manage ment committee for the corn pany and will continue to direct research activities. He will also have responsibility for the development and con trol department.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 4, 1970

title: CHIEFS ARE RATED 5POINT UNDERDOG
Baltimore Papers Struck
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (UPI) Baltimore's three major daily newspapers suspended publica tion today after most of their, employes refused to cross picket lines thrown up by striking pressmen. It was the second time in less than five years that Baltimore has been left with no major news papers because of a strike.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NEW dimension has been added to the trend toward achiev ing almost complete control of the home's interior environment. In addition to automatic control of heating plants, air conditioners, hu midifiers and electronic air cleaners, a new electrically operated device recently in troduced provides the same kind of control over house hold odors.

title: Kapp and Nelsen Are Tough to Handle
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 3Joe Kapp has a scar on his cheek and jaw which came from more than 100 stitches used to sew him up after brawl in a bar. Kapp, it is told, had gone to the rescue of a teammate berserk with drink and he was cut with a broken beer bottle. The quarterback of the Minnesota Vikings, who play the Cleveland Browns here tomorrow for the National Foot ball League championship, is a tough customer. He is also the leader type.

title: LAIRD HINTS AT RISE IN SAFEGUARD SITES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird indicated today that he would not rule out expan sion of the controversial Safe guard antiballistic missile sys tem from the two sites now ap proved.

title: Fed Ponders What to Tell Lieutenants
description: Twentyseven days from today, an era will come to an end in Washington. Wil liam McChesney Martin Jr. will retire as Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board after almost 19 years of serv ice, years during which his name has come to be a sym bol of financial conservatism and orthodoxy.

title: Round Pearl, $4.40, Scores Easy New Orleans Victory
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (AP) Round Pearl raced to a three length victory today in the $12,250 Pan Zareta Stakes at the Fair Grounds.

title: Fat and Forty And Red Hot
description: OPENING night of Neil Simon's Last of the Red Hot Lovers at the Eugene O'Neill. The star of the show, James Coco, had tears in his eyes when he took his solo bow. And when the audience stood up and shouted Bravo! at him, he smiled and reached out his hands.

title: Charlie Manson: One Man's Family
description: LOS ANGELES. THE day had been soft and bright, the sort of glistening Saturday that fills the beaches and the tennis courts and the gardens of Southern California with ruthlessly robust, pleasurepursuing multitudes. In midmorning, police were called to an isolated, expensive home on Cielo Drive, back in the wooded hills above Hollywood. What they found was a scene of unimagin able horror: Five people had been brutally murdered, including Sharon Tate, a stunning blond film actress who was eight and a half months pregnant. The word pig had been scrawled in blood on the front door.

title: Divorces Rise to 18,000 a Year From 4,000 Under State Law
description: New York's state divorce rate, for years the lowest in the nation, has soared in the first two years of a liberalized matrimonial law.

title: Constance T. Cory Married in Jersey
description: DEMAREST, N.J., Jan. 3 The marriage of Miss Con stance Thayer Cory, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Cory of Demarest and Amagansett, L.I., to Roger Clark Williams took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. William Nye, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: ROYAL RALLY TOPS HAWKS BY 104102
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 3 (AP)The Cincinnati Royals, trailing by 19 points at the beginning of the final period, rallied tonight for a 104102 National Basket ball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Education
description: On a blackboard during the philosophers' convention in New York last week appeared this message: When critical philoso phers point their finger to reali ty, orthodox philosophers study the finger. Power to the People.

title: For Young Readers
description: Not all the houses in Harry Devlin's book are homes. A fire man might live in a firehouse, but whoever lived in an ice house, or would take up resi dence in a gazebo or a neces sary  even one designed by Thomas Jefferson? Some of the Devlin houses are not even houses: he gives us a school, a church, a barn, a railroad sta tion, a water mill. Yet this authorartist knows exactly What he's doing. He's showing us in strong and colorful paint ings some of the strange, var ious and historically revealing structures produced in 19th century America, and telling us in his text the interesting facts and significance of each.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: AMULTIPLE  LISTING system of offering houses for sale in Great Neck, L. I., has been challenged as a monopoly in restraint of trade by a real estate broker in that community who has been denied access to it.

title: The Earl and His Princess, Nearing 40
description: LONDON (UPI)A motorcycle sped away into the night from Kensing ton Palace and someone wondered whether the Snowdons had exchanged a few words again.

title: A $2 Bargain on Three Lakes in Switzerland
description: BIEL, SwitzerlandThere is a basic difference between Europeans and Americans when they sit down to plan a holiday trip. The expansive, outgoing American is likely to embrace two or three or more countries, covering as much terrain as he can physically encom pass in his vacation weeks. The European, on the contrary, is more likely to carve out a small section of a country, possibly even his own country, and concentrate his hol iday time therein.

title: Miss Ferrin Fiancee Of Paul Meritt Lane
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 3 Miss Barbara Ann Perrin, granddaughter of the late Kenneth C. Hogate, who was publisher of The Wall Sreet Journal and president of Dow Jones, Inc., plans to be mar ried to Paul Meritt Lane, a senior at Earlham College in Richmond, Ind.

title: 20 Boat Shows Slated to Open In U.S. and Abroad This Month
description: The fantastic thing about boat shows is not only how many there are these days, but also how more boats, more people and more records are set each year despite the same amount of space.

title: Total Attendance at Park In Maine Rises by 200,000
description: BAR HARBOR, Me., Jan. 3 Attendance figures at Acadia National Park here have soared by more than 200,000 in the last year.

title: ART FROM ABROAD ON AUCTION BLOCK
description: The auction season is start ing again, albeit slowly, after the rash of preholiday sales and the lull that followed. The ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, will offer, on Wednesday at 2 P.M., a wide variety of 17th century to 19th century English and European paintings and drawings and 20th century paintings and sculpture, including American works.

title: John Porter Doyle ofHarvard. To Marry Mary W. Carpenter
description: Miss Mary Wootten Car penter, a sophomore at Wellesley College, and John Porter Doyle, a junior at Har yard have become engaged.

title: Laos Is at War But Vientiane Yawns
description: VIENTIANE, Laos. IF the Congressional subcommittee looking into United States in volvement in Laos had paid a visit to this capital city in the guise of ordinary tourists, its members might have come away with at least two unexpected impressions. First ofall, after a few clays in Vientiane which a British diplomat once de scribed as a rather sordid Garden of Edenthey might well have con cluded that, far from being at war, Laos isn't even in a state of par ticular unrest. Second, they might have decided that not only is there no widespread American involve ment, there are practically no Ameri cans here at all.

title: Bridal Planned By Joel Chasis
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Chasis of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joel Anne Chasis, to Frederick Joseph Roll Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roll of Huntington, L. I. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
The Third Book of Criticism
description: Randall Jarrell once wrote that his heart, confronted by the super market offerings of public media, was sad; but that same sad heart, offered a good book, reacted with an almost disorderly passion of gratitude, and these posthumous essays and reviews (all previously published) breathe on every page the pleasure of suspended deprivation, as if the child with his nose pressed to the sweetshop win dow (Yeats's phrase about Keats) had suddenly been given a cake.

title: OffDuty Policeman Kills Youth To Halt Mob Attack on Brother
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 3An offduty Negro policeman shot and killed a Puerto Rican youth in downtown Jersey City today following a street argument, the police said.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Aggressor in Vietnam

title: Gentleness in Handling Urged For Young Owners of Puppies
description: FOR the new dog owner, few words of warning. Young children should be supervised when it comes to the pet, who probably was a Christmas gift. The youngsters may not be old enough to understand the difference between a live dog and toy. Rough play, squeezing or dropping the pup can cause injury. As for the older dog, a finger in the eye is likely to cause snap ping or biting. There is a temptation for everyone in the family to pick up the dog or to romp with him. Too much exercise will ex haust the pet. A bed should be provided in a quiet, draft free corner, where he can sleep undisturbed.

title: Lezlie Feiring Is Wed to Robert Migliara
description: RUMSON, N. J., Jan. 3 The marriage of Miss Lezlie Feiring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce C. Feiring of Fair Haven, to Robert Dominic Migliara of Nutley took place here this afternoon in St. George'sbytheRiver Episco pal Church. The Rev. George Willis performed the cere mony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfonse C. Migliara of Margate, Fla.

title: New York. N.Y.
description: The transit thing was an ob vious citystate conflict and it would have happened with Governor Jones and Mayor Smith, said a man who was there and knows quite well that the Governor's name is Rocke feller and the Mayor's is Lindsay and that they don't like each other.

title: WILLIAM H. JESS
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Jan. 3 William H. Jess, former di rector of advertising for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, died at his home here yester day He was 76 years old.

title: The Ten Worst Films of 1969
description: THERE were a lot of dreadful movies around in 1969, but I really can't dismiss a 12month period in which Warner BrothersSeven Arts gave us, as their Easter attraction, a horror film called Dracula Has Risen From the Grave, or in which the stockholders of 20th CenturyFox approved a motion to change the name of the company to 21st CenturyFox. I don't worry about whether such a namechange will fool anybody; I'm more impressed by the stockholders' faith in the efficacy of symbols. This is the same com pany, of course, whose management scored the miscasting coup of the year by expressing its man in the efficacy of symbolsby giving Barbra Streisand the title role in Hello, Dolly! However, if Fox had been casting the film four years ago, the role might have gone to Julie Andrewsas six years ago it would have gone to Elizabeth Taylor, and 13 years ago to Grace Kelly. Be thankful for blunders that are less major than they could have been.

title: Why Do the Laughs Grow Fewer?
description: WHEN a very funny idea is too broad an idea for the play it's in, some one's been napping some where. The idea I'm thinking about this wintry Sunday is one that turns up in the third act (or third play, since each act is a law unto itself) of Neil Simon's Last of the Red Hot Lovers.

title: High Winds Hit Islands
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, Jan. 3 (Reuters) Hurricane force winds lashed the Canary Islands today, in juring several people, uprooting trees and causing crop damage estimated at $848,000 dollars. The winds, gustinng up to 84 miles an hour, destroyed up to 40 per cent of the tomato crop in some area. Tenerife and Palma were the two worsthit islands.

title: SCIENTISTS REVIEW POLLUTION PROBLEM
description: The Scientists Institute for Public Information, a New York City organization, is preparing a series of workbooks on major environmental problems for concerned citizens, it was an nounced yesterday by Dr. Mar garet Mead, the newly elected president of the institute.

title: C. F. Dearie and Direxa Dick Marry
description: EAST ISLIP, L. I., Jan. 3 St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Direxa Virginia Dick to Christopher Farrell Dearie, a lawyer with the New York firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn.

title: Letters: On AmericanFlag Ships
description: AMID the lamentations about the layingup of United States Lines ships, has anyone thought to ask former passengers why these liners may not have paid their way? A research project takes me to Eng land each summer. In 1967, I went both ways on the United States, my first sea voyage. In 1968 and 1969, I went on HollandAmerica ships. Next summer, I shall go on the Queen Elizabeth 2. After 1967, when friends asked me which line I preferred, I said, Not the United States Lines. I have heard many others give that answer to that question.

title: J. C. Huber 3d, Teacher, Weds Christine Jones
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 3Miss Christine Llewellyn Jones was married here this afternoon to Joel Cook Huber 3d, son of Mrs. Thomas Wil ling Huber of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Mr. Huber Jr. of Haverford, Pa. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Erskine Jones Jr. of Charleston.

title: RUBBER SURFACE PASSES TROT TEST
MRS. HARRY W. LAIDLER
description: Mrs. Agnes Armington Laid ler, wife of Dr. Harry W. Laid ler, author and executive dir ector emeritus of the League for Industrial Democracy, died yesterday at her home. She was 83 years old and lived at 292 Garfield. Place, Brooklyn.

title: Colonial Williamsburg Is Given Carter's Estate by a Foundation
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 3Carter's Grove Plantation, a 215yearold estate on the James River, has been given to Colonial Williamsburg by Sealantic Fund, Inc.

title: Janet Buehler Is Bride of Officer
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 3 Miss Janet Stephens Buehler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Stephens Buehler, was married today to Lieut. (jg.) Christian Emil Kaefer, U.S.N., executive officer of the mine sweeper Fidelity, based in Baltimore.

title: Ford Foundation Controller
description: The appointment of Kieran Michael Bracken as controller of the Ford Foundation has been announced by McGeorge Bundy, president. Mr. Bracken, who was born in New York City, has been acting control ler of, the foundation since the retirement of Stanley W. Greg ory last April. Mr. Bracken graduated from Manhattan College in 1952 and became a certified public accountant in 1958.

title: Streets Here Slick As Powdery Snow Brushes the Area
description: A light, powdery snow brushed the metropolitan area yesterday, causing treacherous driving conditions and putting a deceptive layer on rockhard ice from previous storms.

title: Liberty Bell Helps Shrink Laurel's Gate and Handle
description: LAUREL, Md., Jan. 3 (AP) Laurel race course felt the ef fects of competition from Philadelphia's new Liberty Bell track during the 49day meet ing that ended today.

title: Cotton Is Seen Below Demand
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Agriculture Depart ment reports that the 1969 crop of upland cotton lacked 850,000 bales of meeting do mestic and export require ments for the current market ing year ending next July 31.

title: WEATHER IS CLEAR
Birth Notice 2  No Title
description: NEW YORK STATE

title: In The Nation: Manageable Projects for the Seventies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  President Nixon struck an ap propriate note, which he recog nized, in making his first offi cial act of the decade the signing of a bill that will strengthen efforts to make American air and water fit again for human consumption. That must be a major goal of the seventies, the President said: It is literally now or never.

title: Lollobrigida Defense: Didn't Kill Any Tigers
description: LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) Wildlife enthusiasts today criticized Gina Lollobrigida, the actress, because of her tiger skin maxicoat.

title: Television
description: AN incisive analysis of modern tele vision, one which finally reas sures a viewer that something mighty strange has been hap pening to the home screen in recent years, has come from an unexpected source: a leading man in advertising. He's as upset about the number of com mercials as the rest of us, except he knows why and how to explain it.

title: G.O.P. Picks 43 House Democrats as 1970 Targets
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The experts at the Republican Na tional Committee are poring over a list of 43 names these days.

title: Nogrady Has Full Line of Net Tutors
description: At a tennis gathering the other day, the talk came around to an intriguing ques tion: Why was it that the sons of prominent players could not approach the level their fathers had attained?

title: Final Football Poll Ranks Texas No. 1 By a Wide Margin
description: Texas, which preserved its perfect record with a mighty finish against Notre Dame in the Cotton Bowl, retained its No. 1 college football ranking by a whopping margin in the final Associated Press poll of sports writers and broadcasters yesterday.

title: Shipment of French Arms Is Believed Bound for Iraq
description: PARIS. Jan. 3 (UPI)French dockers loaded a cargo of 200 tons of French munitions aboard an Iraqi freighter today near the moorings from which five Frenchmade Israeli gun boats slipped nut of Cherbourg on Christmas to go to Haifa.

title: Article 7  No Title
Army Investigators Visit Ruins at Mylai
description: CHULAI, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 (AP)Following a mine sweeping team and a scout dog trained to detect mines and booby traps, Lieut. Gen. Wil liam R. Peers and his Army in vestigators poked through the ruins of Mylai hamlet in the Songmy village complex near here today.

title: DialaPoem Service Starts in Wales Feb.
description: LONDON, Jan. 3Britain's first dialapoem service is starting in Walesa new medium for the poetic talent of the land of song. From Feb. 1 the dialing of 29017 in Cardiff will guarantee at least two minutes of tele communicated verse.

title: 12,199 WATCH HOLE RIDE FOUR FIRSTS
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3Larry Jen nings and Mike Hole went from the ridiculous to the sublime or vice versa, depending on one's point of viewwithin the space of 30 minutes at Tropi cal Park today before a crowd of 12.199.

title: REFUGEES STREAM INTO BIAFRA CAPITAL
description: OWERRI, Biafra (Nigeria), Jan. 3 (Reuters)  Refugees streamed into tihs Biafran pro visional capital today as Ni gerian forces kept up the pres sure in war zones a few miles to the south.

title: Quakes Felt in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 (AP)Two brief and minor earthquakes shook a 30mile area south of here last night, causing no reported injuries or damage.

title: Hockey
description: With the best chance of any major United States sports organization to ex pand into European competi tion, the National Hockey League should become the broadestbased league in the world, next to soccer, in the next 10 years.

title: 9 Lima Papers Fined In a New Press Law
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 3 (AP) The Peruvian Government applied a provision of its strongly protested new free dom of the press law today, fining almost every news paper in Lima.

title: Washington: It Is Literally Now or Never
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  A great deal is being made by the Democrats in Washington these days about the difference be tween President Nixon's soar ing rhetoric on pollution con trol and his comparatively low budget requests to deal with the problem.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
ExChief of Israeli Intelligence Identifies Seized U.A.R. Radar
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 3The radar station airlifted last week by Israeli commandos from the Red Sea coast of Egypt was de scribed here tonight as the So viet P12 type designed to de tect lowflying aircraft.

title: Beirut Assails Israeli Raid; Says It Spurs Resistance
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 3 Lebanon today denounced the latest Israeli raid into her ter ritory as unjustified, and in structed her United Nations delegation to bring the matter to the attention of the Secu rity Council.

title: Golf
description: Bigger purses, a newstyle pro tour, simpler rules, a standardsize ball for univer sal use, expanded television coverage and rising playing costs loom along golf's fair ways for the next decade.

title: Marjorie Bouve Dies al 90; Founder of School in Boston
description: CENTERVILLE, Mass., Jan. 3 (UPI)Miss Marjorie Bouve, cofounder of the Boston School of Physical Education, later called BostonBouve College, died Thursday at the Center ville. Nursing home. She was 90 years old.

title: WILDCAT ACE SETS A CAREER RECORD
description: BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. (UPI)Howard Porter scored a career high of 38 points and grabbed 17 rebounds today to lead Villanova to a 10670 rout of Canisius.

title: Big Change In Store After Sato Victory
description: TOKYOThis nation of one hundred million people has en tered the decade of the 1970's with a new political map. There iS general agreement that the Dec. 27 election for the House of Representatives, which saw a great victory for the conserva tive LiberalDemocrats and smashing defeat for the Socialists marks the end of an era.

title: The Climber's Way of Conquering Copenhagen
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark  Nearly horizontal Copenhagen is not a city that comes to mind when one thinks of climbing. Yet Copen hagen, Denmark's capital and Scandi navia's largest city, offers an urban ized variety of climbing (up towers) that is especially appealing to those who re tain the childhood urge to explore the secret parts of old buildings.

title: 2 Die in R.A.F. Crash
description: CARDIFF, Wales, Jan. 3 (Reuters)Two Royal Air Force men were killed today when their jet trainer crashed into a group of farm buildings after narrowly missing a block of new houses.

title: Show Entries Close Tuesday
description: For metropolitan fanciers who are planning to show dogs in Florida later in the month, the closing date is Tuesday for Miami (Jan. 18) and Palm Beach (Jan. 20). Entries should be sent to Bow Dog Show Organization, 9999 Broad Street, Detroit, Mich. 48204.

title: Verdict on An Arsonist
description: As he told it to an Israeli court, Denis Michael Rohan be lieved he had been chosen by God to build a temple to Jesus in Jerusalem at the site of the Hebrew temple that was de stroyed in 70 A.D. That was why, he said, he had tried to burn down the Al Alma Mosque, which stands on the same site.

title: Stamps
description: ONE of stampdom's crud est products, a primi tive provisional of the mid19th century that is one of the rarest stamps ever produced and has a fab ulous history, is coming on the market after having rest ed in limbo for more than a quarter of a century. It is the 1856 1cent black on ma gentacoated paper of British Guiana, the only one known to exist. It is also believed to be the only stamp of Britain or its dominions and colonies that is not represented in the Royal Philatelic Collection, started by King George V when he was Duke of York.

title: Indian Envoy Now Governor
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 3 (Reuters) India's ambassador in Wash ington, Nawab All Yavar Jung, has been appointed governor of Maharashtra. He will assume office next month. He succeeds Dr. P. V. Cherian, who died last year.

title: Stock Prices Up in Week On Amex and the Counter
description: Most issues on the Amer ican Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market advanced last week in active trading.

title: EARLY RISE IS SEEN ON TOLLS IN CITY TO HOLD 30C FARE
description: The head of the City Plan ning Commission said yester day that bridge and tunnel tolls in the city would have to be increased in the near future to help subsidize the subways and public buses and thus fore stall another rise above the new 30cent fare that went into effect at 12:01 A.M. today.

title: Franco's Opposition Dreams of New Spain
description: MADRID  Much of Spain's attenuated political life consists of the struggle of factions with in the regime to assure, them selves of jobs now and an inside track for the future, post Franco era.

title: PITTSBURGH UNINON PRODS HOSPITALS
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3This city has become the newest battleground in a national drive to organize hospital workers that has already reached New York, Baltimore, Charleston, S. C. Memphis, Tenn., and other cities.

title: Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated:

title: Opportunity for Lagos
description: Two Nigerian Army divisions linking up on the road from Aba to Umuahia apparently have reduced what was left of Biafra by a third. If federal forces also have finally secured the road between Awka and Onitsha, they have accomplished a step essential for an effective drive on the Uli airstrip, Biafra's only major link with the outside world.

title: U.S.Drive Against Heroin Will Be Centered Here
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Treasury Department announced today that its antinarcotics forces, reinforced by 685 new agents, were being thrown into a New Yorkcentered drive against heroin smuggling.

title: Woodrow Wilson Center To Receive Applications
description: The Smithsonian Institution's Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, established by Congress in October, 1968, announced last week that ap plications for the first 40 ap pointments were due at the center by Jan. 15.

title: PRINCETON ROUTS RUTGERS BY 7550
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3A coldshooting Princeton squad relied on tight defense and 26 points from cocaptain Jeff Petrie to gain a 7550 victory over Rutgers today.

title: Endowment Is Planned By Eisenhower Society
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 3 (UPI) A society to honor the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower has been formed here.

title: Swedish Premier's Visit to U.S. Termed Move to Heal Relations
description: The recent announcement from Sweden that Premier Olof Palme would visit the United States in May explained only that he would go to Gambier, Ohio, to accept an honorary degree from his alma mater, Kenyon College.

title: Dinghy Racing Launched in 1931 by Challenge
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 3Out on Kraus's Kastle, a 10footsquare raft bobbing gently in frigid Manhasset Bay, Frostbite Yacht Club officials worked to keep warm. Breath ing smoke and drinking fire water, they took turns chipping ice in preparation for the 39th annual regatta that began last Thursday and ends today.

title: Olivares in Nontitle Bout
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 3 (AP)Ruben Olivares of Mex ico City, the World bantam weight champion, will meet Minun Ben All of Barselona, Spain, in a nontitle bout here Tuesday. Olivares is unbeaten ??n 57 fights and has 35 knock out.

title: Basketball
description: Two new franchises are ex pected soon to increase the National Basketball Associa tion to 16 teams and before the new decade is over it has been estimated there will be at least 20 teams. Walter Kennedy, the commissioner of the N.B.A., has predicted that with the advent of super sonic jet travel, international franchises are a possibility, with Italy a likely site.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: The President's signing of the tax bill has removed some of the doubts that re tailers had about 1970 and 1971. Taxes will still be oner ous, of course, but some features of the bill could work to the benefit of retailers.

title: TOM WRIGLEY
description: ELMIRA, N. Y. Jan. 3 (AP) Tom Wrigley, former managing editor of The Elmira Advertiser and Sunday Telegram and, for mer Washington bureau chief for Universal News Service, died yesterday in a hospital fol lowing a heart attack at his home here. He was 87 years old.

title: 1ST AND 2D AVENUES WILL GET BUS LANES
description: Traffic lanesclosed during rush hours to all vehicles except buseswill be set up on the midtown Manhattan stretches of First and Second Avenues starting tomorrow.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONOn an av erage day four convicts in prison across the country consider their lot, find it un necessarily unpleasant, and sue the warden. Until recent ly, they almost never won.

title: State's Big 6 Mayors Challenge Governor on Aid
description: In the first move of what is taking shape as a highly orga nized campaign, the state's Big Six Mayors challenged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to restore money to the cities before claiming credit for new programs.

title: Are Manhattan's Movie Houses Unfair to Moviegoers?
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: SLALOM CAPTURED BY AUSTRIAN GIRL
description: OBERSTAUFEN, West Ger many, Jan. 3 (AP)Berni Rau ter, a 20yearold Austrian blonde, mastered an icy second run that knocked out 13 top seeded racers and won the spe cial slalom today in the World Cup ski meet. Only 18 of the 91 starters completed both runs.

title: Clarkson Routs Princeton On 7 Goals in 3d Period, 112
description: POTSDAM, N. Y., Jan. 3 Scoring seven goals in the third period, Clarkson routed the Princeton hockey team, 112, tonight. Rick Magnusson paced the victors with three goals and two assists and Bill O'Flaherty talllied twice.

title: Auto Insurance Rise Possible in Jersey As a Result of Suit
description: TRENTON, Jan. 3  Some companies that sell auto insur ance in New Jersey may make a new attempt to get rate in creases following a decision granting a 26 per cent rise to Travelers Indemnity Company of Hartford, according to Horace J. Bryant Jr., State Corn missioner of Banking and In surance.

title: Lawrence, in Ferrari, Wins First Race in Tasman Series
description: LEVIN, New Zealand, Jan. 3 (AP) Graeme Lawrence of New Zealand, driving a 2.4liter Ferrari V6, averaged 90 miles an hour to win the 75mile Levin international motor race yesterday, the first round of the 1970 Tasman Cup cham pionship.

title: Miss Hawkey Has Nuptials
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 3 Miss Marianne Pardee Hawkey and Edward Read Langenbach Jr. were married here this afternoon in the Memorial Church at Harvard University. At the ceremony, performed by the Rev. Rich ard Griffin, Roman Catholic chaplain at Harvard, were the pupils of the bride's thirdgrade class of the Co chituate School in Wayland.

title: RAM COACH CALLS VICTORY PRICELESS
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3 (AP)Al though George Allen and his Los Angeles Rams received only $1,200 apiece for defeating Dallas today in the National Football League Playoff Bowl the personable coach said the victory was priceless.

title: Nancy Warren, D. A. Schroeder To Wed Jan. 31
description: McMURRAY, Pa., Jan. 3 Miss Nancy Montgomery Warren and David Atwood Schroeder plan to be married here on Jan. 31.

title: GLADYS AYLWARD, MISSIONARY, DIES
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 3 (UPI) Gladys Aylward, a British missionary whose life story was depicted in the motion picture, Inn of the Sixth Happiness, died today here of pneumonia. She was 67 years old.

title: NIXON HEADS LIST OF ADMIRED MEN
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 3 Three prominent spokesmen for middle America  President Nixon, the Rev. Billy Graham and Vice President Agnew have won the top three posi tions on the Gallup Poll's Most Admired Man list for 1969.

title: Boxing
description: There won't be any need to legislate against boxing because it will just about go out of business through its own inertia in the decade ahead. Except for a few scattered spots in the coun try, the sport has been losing ground steadily as a popular attraction, and will continue to do so.

title: Religion
description: Over the centuries the growth of Western science and technol ogy has been closely tied to JudeoChristian religious values. Isaac Newton and other early scientific giants explained their activities and findings in reli ious terms. The fundamental teaching of Genesis that man is created in God's image and intended to have dominion over the rest of creation gave ultimate significance to the sci entific method.

title: Rice Award to Texas Eleven
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Jan. 3 (AP)The University of Texas, top choice on four of five ballots, was named today to receive the Grantland Rice Award of the Football Writers Association of America. The award reflects the association's version of the National Colle giate championship, as voted by a fiveman committee, which also picked the No. 2 and No. 3 teams. Penn State was the runnerup. Southern California was third.

title: Bucknell Loses by 9388
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3 (AP)Wayne Canaday with 25 points and Willie Allen with 21 led the University of Miami to a 9388 victory over Bucknell tonight.

title: Dance
description: LINCOLN, KIRSTEIN sees the problems of dance so clearly that I make no apology for quoting him on provincial ballet even though I quoted him on the same subject a couple of years ago.

title: GARDEN PREVIEW 1970
description: THE arrival of seed catalogues this month will inspire dreams of sum mer flowers and vegetables in idle gardeners' heads. Usually, the first pages they will turn to are those announc ing, what's new.

title: De Carlo, Reputed Mafioso, Faces Trial Tomorrow
description: A reputed Mafia leader, in dicted as a result of a letter sent by a man who died the day after he wrote it, will go on trial with three other men In Federal Court in Newark to morrow.

title: U.N. COUNCIL LISTS 81ISSUE AGENDA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 3  As it approaches the start of its 25th year, the Se curity Council has 81 items still on its agenda, according to a list just published here by the United Nations.

title: Thomas Walsh Jr. Dies, Building Concern Head, 56
description: Thomas J. Walsh Jr., head of the Walsh Construction Com pany, died yesterday in Univer sity Hospital. He was 56 years old and had made his home in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Pupils' Cake Sale Benefits Neediest
description: The fourthgrade young sters at Public School 40 on East 19th Street were busy before Christmas planning and then making a rousing success of a special White Elephant and Cake Sale.

title: As Florida Roars Into the Seventies
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.As the 1960's drew to a close, it became apparent that the fantastic growth tourist business in Florida in that decade surpassed that of any other resort area in the world. In 1960, era tourist total was approximately 10,800,000; in 1969, this figure more than doubled.

title: HIJACKED JET GETS TO HAVANA FINALLY
description: HAVANA, Jan. 3 (Agence FrancePresse)  A hijacked Brazilian airliner with 26 per sons aboard landed here tonight after a twoday troubleplagued flight from Uruguay, where it was seized by an armed band of Brazilian revolutionaries.

title: News and Notes From the Field of Travel
description: THE Nixon Administra tion's easing, on Dec. 22, of restrictions on the purchase and en try into this country of goods made in Communist China put an end to a Hong Kong tourist problem called the Certificate of Origin.

title: Food Chains Cook and Serve It, Too
description: A number of supermarket chains are following the lead of food processors by entering the growing fastfood restaurant business.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television pro grams was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: U.A.R. Reports Crossing Canal
description: CAIRO, Jan. 3  A military spokesman announced that an Egyptian commando detach ment crossed the Suez Canal early today and ambushed an Israeli military vehicle, killing or wounding its five occupants.

title: WOLYNIEC TAKES POLE VAULT TITLE
description: Bob Beamon, the world long jump recordholder, wore Adel phi's colors for the first time yesterday and won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's senior long jump cham pionship with a leap of 24 feet 4 inches. Beamon had trans ferred to Adelphi after attend ing colleges in North Carolina and Texas.

title: NORTH STAR RALLY TIES RANGERS, 33
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan, 3Much as they did not want to, the New York Rangers had to settle for a tie with the Min nesota North Stars tonight.

title: Kerr on Seven Days of Mourning and Love Is a Time of Day
description: HUMAN beings fossilize long before rigor mortis sets in, though inside every fossil, as inside every fat man, there is a lithe and wonderfully free man longing to get out. In Seven Days of Moura ing it has been Seymour Simckes's special effort to make a play out of still breathing fossils, here in the guise of an impoverished Jewish family living beneath calcimine ceilings that are rotting as steadily as the folk under them are becom ing rigid.

title: NonSkeds Recite Woes
description: The supplemental airlines are in a bad way, to hear them tell it.

title: Whites and Negroes Agree To Confer in Georgia Town
description: SANDERSVILLE, Ga., Jan. 3 (UPI)  A racial stalemate that had plagued this town for six weeks was broken today when white leaders agreed to form a group to hold discussions with blacks.

title: Name: Agnew Role: Diplomat
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Spiro T. Agnew hopped out of the long limousine last Friday, waved to the crowd, revved up a 500kilo watt smile and waded into the middle of a mass of cheering people. He held out his right arm and six people latched onto it as bands tootled and children gig gled. It might have been in a downtown section of an Ameri can city in the fall of 196& except that the faces beaming back at the Vice President were yellow and it was downtown Taipei.

title: Millrose Tickets Go On Sale Tomorrow
description: Tickets for the Wanamaker Millrose Games to he held Friday, Jan. 30, the first of five Madison Square Garden indoor track meets, will go on public sale tomorrow at Millrose headquarters in the Hotel New Yorker.

title: Bay State Bridal for Wendy Wise
description: NANTUCKET ISLAND, Mass., Jan. 3  Miss Wendy Elizabeth Spinney Wise and John Cambron Mathis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mathis of Webster Groves, Mo., were married here this after noon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary, Our Lady of the Isle.

title: France Saves Lascaux Grotto, But Public Is Still Barred
description: PERIGUEUX, France  After six years of scientific tests and treat ment, the prehistoric cave paint ings in the Lascaux Grotto, in southwestern France, have been saved from organic deterioration. But this vic tory of science does not mean that the grotto, closed since 1963 because of microbiotic contamination brought in by visitors, will be reopened in the near future.

title: Fikes of Rice Runs Record Mile Of 4:15.9 in Iona School Games
description: The inside lane position in track is usually a desirable spot for a runner. But when Denis Fikes drew that position yesterday before the mile run in the ninth annual Iona Col lege Spike Shoe Club schoolboy meet he was most unhappy.

title: Invisible scholars with a lovely language in a golden time
description: As I drive from my countryside to the University of a morning, I slow down to look at the bulletin board outside a small Methodist church that I pass. I hope it will contain a passing thought for today, something like The devil is dead, perhaps. This morning it said, Do you love me?

title: HOFFMAN S. BEAGLE
description: Hoffman S. Beagle, president of the Electrical Testing Labo ratories of New York since 1956, died on Thursday. He was 66 years old and lived at 80 The Waterway, Plandome Heights, L. I.

title: Australian Navy Officer In June Collision Quits
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 3 (Reuters)Navy Minister James Killen said today that he had received the resigna tion of Capt. John P. Steven son, skipper of the aircraft carrier Melbourne when she rammed a United States de stroyer in June with the loss of 74 lives.

title: HAWKS STAVE OFF LATE BUCK RALLY
Chess:
description: SEVENTEEN  YEAR  OLD Henrique Mecking of Bra zil stole the show during the first two rounds of the re cent Palma de Majorca In ternational.

title: Savings Banks Association Picks Acting Chief Officer
description: The Savings Banks Associa tion of New York State an nounced this weekend that Lawrence U. Costiglio, vice president, had been appointed acting chief administrative of ficer of the association.

title: June Wedding Set By Brooke Hannay
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Jan. 4Miss Brooke Hannay and Hal Arthur Beecher, sen iors at Middlebury College, plan to be married in June.

title: Javits Bids Unions And G.E. Summon Strike Fact Board
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, Re publican of New York, urged the General Electric Company and 13 striking unions yester day to call in a factfinding board to recommend a settle ment of their dispute, which is entering its 11th week.

title: MODERATE BUDGET FOR FAMILY HERE IS PUT AT $11,236
description: A new Federal estimate in dicates it cost $11,236 a year to maintain a family of four persons on a moderate stand ard of living in the New York northeastern New Jersey area, as of last spring. This was a rise of 12.6 per cent from $9,977, as of the spring of 1967.

title: Steel Mills Find Dip Seems Sure Early This Year
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 Steel mills entered the New Year with demand lagging.

title: Prince Viggo, 76, Widower Of Peter Cooper Descendant
description: EBELTOFT, Denmark, Jan. 4 (UPI)Trince Viggo, who re nounced any claim to the Dan ish throne after marrying an American woman, died in a hospital here today after an illness of eight days. He was 76 years old.

title: The Suez Snatch
description: At this moment typewriters must be clacking away in half the film studios of the Western makebelieve world as writers reconstruct the latest thriller pulled off by the Israeli James Bonds, who snatched a seven ton radar station from an Egyptian coastal position on the Gulf of Suez and, with the lift of powerful heli copters, made it disappear. The only thing missing (besides the Russianbuilt installation) is the obliga tory nude scene.

title: MRS. LILY S. MARX, PAINTER, DIES AT 83
description: Mrs. Lily Sulzberger Marx, an artist whose works are in the collections of the Chrysler Art Museum in Provincetown. Mass., and the Walker Art Cen ter in Minneapolis, died after a heart attack Friday at the Hotel Alden here. She was 83 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Sanitas Buys 4 Companies
description: HARTFORD, San. 4 (AP)  The Sanitas Service Corpora tion, a network of industrial service companies based here, said today it had acquired three solidwaste removal companies  two in Boston and one in Baltimore  and a pestexter minating company in Phoenix, Ariz. Sales of all four total about $4.8million a year.

title: FiredUp Crew Chases Deep Freeze
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 4Dick Ericson does not ex pect to be in New Orleans next Sunday when the Vik ings in the Super Bowl. But he earned his champion ship the last two weeks when he prepared the foot ball field despite the heavy snows of the north country.

title: DR. HENRY SCHWARZ OF WELLESLEY DIES
description: BOSTON, Jan. 4Dr. Henry F. Schwarz, chairman of the de partment of history at Welles ley College, died today in his home in Wellesley. He was 63 years old.

title: Holdup Man Kills Son, 16, Of Brooklyn Restaurateur
description: A 16yearold boy was shot dead by a holdup man early last night in the kitchen of his father's Chinese restaurant in Brooklyn. The boy had tried to reach for a knife and the in truder fired a shotgun.

title: Israel Frees 3 Lebanese
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 4Three of the 22 Lebanese kidnaped from their homes in Kala early yes terday by Israeli forces were tent back across the border this afternoon.

title: Page Tops Louria in Final Of Squash Racquets Singles
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 4 Palmer Page of the University of Pennsylvania won the 38th Luckenbach Memorial squash racquets singles final today at the Nassau Country Club, de feating Don Louria of New York, a former champion, 1512, 153, 1416, 159.

title: LondonSydney Air Race Ends As 59 Planes Land in Minutes
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 4  An adventurefilled air race from London to Sydney came to a spectacular close today as 59 planes dived out of a bril liant Australian summer sky to streak across the finish line before 4,000 spectators.

title: RETIRED DIRECTOR IS SLAIN ON COAST
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 4 (UPI)A retired Broadway movie and television director, Robert B. Sinclair, 64 years old, was stabbed to death in his Montecito home South of here last night.

title: FRANKLIN L. ORTH, GUN CONTROL FOE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Franklin L. Orth, executive vice president of the National Rifle Association for the last 10 years, and president of the United States Olympic Corn mittee since last spring, died today in Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., apparently of heart attack. He was 62 years old and lived in Gaithers burg, Md.

title: Newcombe and Roche Gain In RoundRobin Tennis
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 4 (AP)John Newcombe and Tony Roche, Australian tennis professionals, easily won their first matches in the $10,000 roundrobin tournament against European players in searing heat today.

title: A RECORD OUTLAY SPENT ON PHONES
description: The New York Telephone Company spent a record $720 million on construction last year, according to figures re leased over the weekend by the company. This compared with $500million in 1968 and $399 million in 1967.

title: 3 Unions in Italy Charge Police Repress Dissent
description: ROME, Jan. 4Italy's three major trade unions have joined in the rising chorus of alarm over what many leftofcenter politicians, editors and journal ists see as a spreading police crackdown on political dissent.

title: CONEYS TAKES CUP IN PENGUIN SAILING
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 4  Matt Coneys, a Pen guin skipper from the Port Washington fleet, won the Founder's Trophy for the top percentage performance today as the 39th annual New Year's regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club ended on Manhasset Bay.

title: 2 Lawyers in Caney CourtMartial Arrive in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnams Jan. 4 (Reuters)  The de fense and prosecution law yers in the forthcoming mur der trial of First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. arrived here today as a special Army team continued its investigation of the alleged massacre of civil ians by United States troops at Mylai hamlet in the Song my village area of Quangngai Province in March, 1968.

title: Slave Ship Will Move
description: Oliver Rea's Chelsea Theater production of LeRoi Jones's The Slave Ship, a dramatic por trayal of black history, will move to the Theaterinthe Church at Washington Square, 137 West Fourth Street, on Tuesday, Jan. 13.

title: Gains in 1969 Listed By Printing Plants
description: The printing business in this city returned to normal in 1969.

title: Oregon Weighs a Depot For Radioactive Wastes
description: BURNS, Ore., Jan. 4The problem of where to dispose of radioactive wastes is causing concern here in the desolate ranching country of Eastern Oregon.

title: YOUTH FACING DRAFT A SUICIDE IN PARK
description: A 21yearold college student who reportedly was depressed since receiving a Selective Service preinduction physical hanged himself yesterday from a tree in Central Park.

title: Jess Thomas Joins Aida as Radames
description: Jess Thomas, the tenor whose big assignment at the Metro politan Opera this season was to have been in a new produc tion of Wagner's Siegfried that had to be canceled as a result of the company's de layed opening, joined the cast of Aida on Saturday after noon, taking the part of Rada mes.

title: Harvard and Radcliffe Join Commencements
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. (AP)Graduates of Radcliffe College will join their Har vard counterparts at com mencement exercises June 11 in Harvard Yard, Nathan M. Pusey, Harvard president, said today.

title: Sidle Paces Floridians To 124104 Rout of Nets
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP)The Miami Flo ridians jumped to a quick six point lead tonight and rolled on to beat the New York Nets, 124104, in an American Bas ketball. Association game.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: U.S. Policy Supported

title: Judy Zuckerman Will Be Married
description: LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., Jan. 4Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Zuck erman have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Judy Ann Zucker man, a social worker for Nassau County, to Robert David Goldstein, a vice pres ident of John De Nigris Asso ciates, Inc., a financial public relations concern in New York. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: Censors' Foe Sees Need for Limits to Freedom
description: Morris Ernst, the noted civil liberties lawyer and a longtime opponent of censorship, de clared yesterday that he would not choose to live in a society without limits to freedom.

title: THEORY IS UPHELD ON EARTH PLATES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) Two United States Government scientists have reported new evidence that the earth's crust is made up of gigantic plates that move and carry the conti nents around. But their study indicates the crust is much more complex than was thought before.

title: Chill Blows the Whistle On Officials, Computer
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn. Jan. 4 (AP)The 9degree temperature in the National Football League champion ship game today had two side effects:

title: Revolt of the Gladiators
description: CURT FLOOD, the $90,000ayear outfielder who is challenging baseball's contractual hold on its players, was asked in a recent television interview to describe his status in the National Pastime.

title: New Pinkerton for Met
description: Nicholas Di Virgilio will make his Metropolitan Opera debut tonight taking the part of Pinkerton in Puccini's Ma dama Butterfly. Enrico DiGiu seppe, who made his Metro politan debut in the same role on New Year's Day, was to appear tonight, but he will re place Franco Corelli earlier to day in a rehearsal of the com pany's new production of Mas cagni's Cavalleria Rusticana, which is to be introduced on Thursday. Mr. Corelli is recov ering from a cold.

title: HUNTER TITLE WON BY LOST FORTUNE
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 4 Margie Pollock, an 18yearold freshman from Hollins College in Virginia made her first start since graduating from the jun ior division and rode Lost For tune to the amateurowner hunter championship today at the Secor Farms horse show.

title: WINGS TOP HAWKS FOR 4TH STRAIGHT
Organist Transports Audience to a Netherland
description: First one set of organ pipes and then the other beeped, booped and groaned yesterday afternoon as the organist opened the swell shutters and the music that was billed as a journey of the soul into the world of spirit after death roared through Calvary Epis copal Church, at Park Avenue South and 21st Street.

title: MADDEN BEMOANS MISSED CHANCES
description: OAKLAND, Jan. 4 (AP)Itl all boils down to us not taking advantage of their mistakes, Coach John Madden said today after his Raiders had fallen be fore the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: JOSEPH L. KEELEY SR.
description: LYNBROOK, L. I., Jan. 4 Joseph L. Keeley Sr. died at his home here yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived at 50 Lenox Avenue here.

title: Ulric Takes Paris Trot
description: PARIS, Jan. 4 (Reuters) Mrs. Leon Olry, Roederer's Ulric led throughout the Prix de 1'Ile de France international trotting race today to win the $9,840 first prize. Ulric, the favorite and ridden by Gaston Peltier, was followed home by Georges Moreau's Sole Mio in the $18,000 race over 24250 meters.

title: Princeton Posts Higher Charges
description: Princeton University, joining a growing number of private and state schools across the country, announced yesterday that it would Increase tuition and room and board fees in September.

title: CZECHS WORK 7 DAYS IN PRODUCTION DRIVE
description: VIENNA, Jan. 4  Although today was Sunday, it was regular working day for Czechoslovaks by Government order as the people were urged in the newspapers and on broadcasts to work harder in the new year.

title: Sloop and 3 Reported Safe
description: SAN JUAN, Jan. 4 (AP)The Coast Guard called off today a search for the 41foot sloop Saranac and a crew of three after the vessel had been re ported safe by her captain in Samana, Dominican Republic.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JANUARY A, 1970

title: HUNGRY I CLOSES FOR GOOD ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 After 20 years of feast and famine, the hungry i has fi nally starved to death.

title: HungaryFinland Visas End
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 4 (Reuters)Hungary and Fin land abolished visas for travel between the two countries be ginning last Thursday, the Yu goslav press agency Tanyug reported from Budapest today.

title: Kentucky and U.C.L.A. Rolling In Quest of National Laurels
description: Which is the nation' s No. 1 college basketball teamKen tucky or the University of California, Los Angeles?

title: Short Tempers Evident as Riders Prepare
description: New Yorkers queued up at subway stations yesterday to buy the new 30cent tokens in advance of this morning's rush hour.

title: 10,000 in Rich Farm Area Go Hungry With Surplus Food Nearby
description: MODESTO, Calif.  The fields and orchards in the San Joaquin Valley were lush and green in the fall, but now they are gray and empty. The harvest of fruit and vegetables is complete and the farm laborers have noth ing left to do.

title: Agnew's Royal Host in Nepal
description: HE is King of Kings, Five Times Godly, Valorous Warrior and Divine Emperor, and, to many of his subjects, he is also an incarnation of the Hindu god Vishnu. This is King Mahendra of Nepal, who is to be host to Vice President Agnew in that Himalayan state today. Personally speaking, don't believe in all in the those things, the 49  year  old ruler once said in an in terview. But it has been evident since before he succeeded his father to be come the world's only Hindu monarch that Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva does be lieve in his own destiny as a ruler.

title: FRENCH GIRLS 12 IN GIANT SLALOM
description: OBERSTAUFEN, Germany, Jan. 4 (UPI)  Michele Jacot and Francoise Macchi of France held off a challenge by two American girls today and soared to a one, two finish in the giant slalom.

title: Broadcasters Cancel Parley Because of Peru Press Law
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 4 (AP)The 10th general assembly of the InterAmerican Association of Radio Broadcasters scheduled Jan. 12 in Lima has been can celed as a result of Peru's new press law.

title: 4 ECONOMISTS CALL A SLOWDOWN LIKELY
description: Four economists have an nounced similar forecasts of the United States economy for 1970: a slowdown, with some increase in unemployment, but nothing that would fit the usual definitions of a recession.

title: Better Balance in Transit
description: The shine will quickly wear off the gleaming new tokens millions of New Yorkers are dropping into the subway turnstiles this morning, but the thirtycent fare's dent in the living standards of lowincome work ers and their families will be a harsh and enduring one.

title: ITALY'S THEONI WINS WORLD CUP SLALOM
description: HINDELANG, Germany, Jan. 4 (UPI)Gustavo Theoni of Italy won the special slalom at the Silver Fir meet today.

title: January Takes Honors
STUDENTS TO SET UP OWN LOBBYING GROUP
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 4 Student government representa tives of 11 colleges in the New York metropolitan area met to day at Adelphi University here to discuss the formation of a student lobby organization.

title: Heart Transplant on Coast
description: STANFORD, Calif., Jan. 4 (UPI)William Van Buuren, 40 years old, of Mill Valley, was in satisfactory condition today after receiving a heart trans plant. He was operated on last night at Stanford University hospital. Dr. Norman Shumway, who performed the first adult heart transplant in the United States on Jan. 6, 1968, placed the heart of an anonymous donor in Mr. Van Buuren.

title: U.S. Envoy Silent on Charge Of Link to Rhodesian Case
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 4 (AP)  Ambassador William Rountree declined comment to day on a charge that the United States Government was in volved in economic espionage in Rhodesia.
