description: AGAINST the day when present feature  length films prove unacceptable to general family television au diences the networks one way or another are making a few films of their own. The National Broadcasting Company and the American Broadcasting Company have had partnership deals for some time but last night the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem unveiled the first prod uct of its wholly owned sub sidiary, Cinema Center 100.

title: Heller in Warning
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 9 (Reu ters)  Economist Walter W. Heller warned today that a recession of damaging eco nomic and social conse quences might be just around the corner if the Federal Re serve Board does not relax its tight monetary policy.

title: SIX ARABS KILLED IN OCCUPIED AREA
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 9  Six persons suspected of being Arab terrorists were killed and 24 captured in a series of op erations in the occupied area on the west bank of the Jor dan River reported today by Israeli military officials. They said that two large arms ca ches had been uncovered.

title: ELEANOR H. GRADY OF HUNTER IS DEAD
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 Dr. Eleanor Hunsdon Grady, acting president of Hunter Col lege in 195051, who retired as dean of faculty in February, 1953, died Tuesday. Her age was 83.

title: A Bathroom Debate at Chicago Trial
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9  When histories of the Chicago con spiracy trial are written, to day's proceedings will probably go down as The Great Bath room Debate.

title: Hijacked T.W.A. Purser Is Getting Used to It
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 (UPI)This was the second lime around for Claude Moitry, purser aboard the Trans World Airlines jet that was hijacked to Beirut to day. The passengers were being hijacked for the first time. I'm getting used to it, he said.

title: Lindsay Rides Subway; Calls It Unacceptable
description: Mayor Lindsay took a ride on the subway yesterday, re ported that the nether world was never worse and an nounced the creation of a transit watchdog committee to monitor service.

title: Barlow Named Jersey Judge
description: TRENTON, Jan. 9 (AP) George H. Barlow, 48 years old, of Ewing Township, was sworn in today as a Federal District Court Judge, filling a vacancy that had existed since mid1967 when Arthur Lane of Harbour ton resigned. Mr. Barlow, who most recently was a State Su perior Court judge, had been a United States Commissioner for eight years.

title: Those Assembly Vacancies
description: As the Legislature begins what promises to be a busy and highly controversial session, residents of two Assembly districts in this citythe 25th A.D. in Queens and the 81st A.D. in the Bronxare tem porarily without representation in the lower house.

title: Cairo and Moscow Step Up Trade in Last Year of Pact
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (Reuters) The United Arab Republic and the Soviet Union will in crease mutual trade under a protocol for 1970 signed here today.

title: Africans to Be Urged to Use Israeli Route
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 9 (Reuters)An Israeli concern is trying to persuade East African countries to use the land bridge across Israel from the Mediterranean to the Red Seato save up to 10 days on present ocean freight routes around Africa.

title: FORD WILL CLOSE ITS DALLAS PLANT
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9The auto mobile industry, making news all week, kept going today with the following developments:

title: Editor of Judaism Quits in Protest
description: Rabbi Steven S. Schwarz schild, editor of the theological quarterly Judaism since 1962, has resigned because of al leged constant interference with his editorial freedom.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
Judge in Clay Shaw Trial Denies Guilt in Vice Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 (AP) Judge Edward A. Haggerty Jr., who presided at the Clay Shaw conspiracy trial last year, pleaded not guilty today to charges stemming from a Dec. 17 vice raid.

title: 7,310 CIVILIAN JOBS ENDED BY PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Pentagon announced today the elimination of 7,310 civilian jobs at 50 military installations across the country at a report ed saving of $57million during the current fiscal year.

title: Passengers Identified
description: The passengers aboard the Trans World Airlines plane hi jacked to Beirut yesterday morning were identified as:

title: Systems Aircraft Sells 8 DC9's for $32Million
description: Systems Capital Aircraft, subsidiary of the Systems Capi tal Corporation, announced yes terday the sale of eight DC9 jet aircraft valued at more than $32million to the Commercial Aircraft Leasing Company, a re centlyorganized subsidiary of the Onival Corporation of Philadelphia.

title: Canada Helps Both Sides
description: OTTAWA. Jan. 9 (UPI)  After a twomonth delay, Canada announced today a $1million donation to a relief agency for the support of night time mercy flights to Biafra, and a $1.25million grant to the Red Cross and other private agencies working on both sides of the war between Nigeria and Biafra.

title: $19Million Given To Neediest Cases In First 57 Years
description: When Adolph S. Ochs, pub lisher of The New York Times, started the appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases in 1912, he did it with the hope of providing a means for permanent rehabilitation of the destitute  not just transitory relief.

title: Metromedia Wary on Snow Warnings
description: Metromedia Radio has or dered its 12 stations in seven cities around the country to broadcast weather information only as reported by the Weather Bureau, since elaborte warn ings and repeated suggestions of impending doom scare lis teners and hurt businesses in the comunity.

title: BUCKS VANQUISH SUNS, 120 TO 116
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 9 (AP) Don Smith's twohanded stuff shot with 31 seconds remaining gave the Milwaukee Bucks 120116 National Basketball Association victory today over the Phoenix Suns.

title: Deborah R Chiel Plans Marriage To Salem Katsh
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Jan. 9Rabbi Arthur A. Chiel of Congregation B'nai Jacob and Mrs. Chiel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Rae Chiel, to Salem Michael Katsh. He is the son of Dr. Abraham I. Katsh, president of Dropsie University for Hebrew and Cognate Learn ing in Philadelphia, and Mrs. Katsh.

title: CONVICTIONS OF 2 IN PROTEST UPSET
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 9 (AP) The United States Court of Ap peals for the Fourth Circuit re versed today the convictions of two persons arrested during antiwar demonstrations at the Pentagon two years ago.

title: Nixon Flies to Massachusetts for Birthday Dinner Cooked by Daughter
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 9  The convenience of jet travel and the prerogatives of the Presidency made possible a Nixon family reunion tonight in a small apartment near the Smith College campus. The oc casion was the President's 57th birthday.

title: Search for Climbers Halted
description: GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont., Jan. 9 (UPI)The search for five young climbers feared buried by an avalanche on the 10,488foot Mount Cleveland was called off today because of winter storms. The Park Serv ice said search operations would be suspended for the winter

title: Mohasco Names Directors
description: Alexander L. Stott, vice president and controller of the American Telephone & Tele graph Company, and Stuart D. Watson, president and chief ex ecutive officer of Heublein, Inc. have been appointed directors of Mohasco Industries, Inc. Mo hasco, Amsterdam, N. Y., diver sified floor coverings and fur niture producer, increased the size of its board in order to name the two new directors.

title: Bal de la Neige Jan. 24 to Help Fibrosis Study
description: The New York chapter of the National Cystic Fibrosis Research Foundation will hold a dinner dance, Le Bal de la Neige, in the Grand Ballroom at the Pierre on Saturday, Jan. 24, to celebrate its first decade of volunteer work in this area.

title: Bonn Sells $500Million of Metal to Restore Dollar Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Treasury disclosed today a purchase of $500million of gold from West Germanyprobably the biggest single United States gold acquisition since World War II.

title: ISRAEL BOND SALE A RECORD IN 1969
description: The Israel Bond Organization reported yesterday that $159, 041,750 in bonds were sold here and abroad last year.

title: Atlantic City Rabbi Chosen For Temple Shaaray Tefila
description: Rabbi Philip E. Schecter has been elected rabbi of Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street. He succeeds Dr. Ber nard J. Bamberger, who will become rabbi emeritus.

title: SPENDING OUTLINED BY JERSEY UTILITY
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company plans to spend more than $1billion over the next three years for ad ditions and improvements to its New Jersey service area. Edwin H. Snyder, chairman, pointed out that demand is rising at a rate that will require the utility to double its electric generat ing capacity by the summer of 1977.

title: Books of The Times
description: I F we didn't know these people, Henry Adams said in 1869 speaking of those in Horace Walpole's letters, then we know someone for all the world like them. How little the world has changed in a century! The world, as Louis Kronenberger is quick to point out, had changed enormously in the previous century. It had gone through two revo lutions in France and in the British colonies and through various upheavals in agri culture, industry and the arrange ment of society. In music the span stretched from Mozart to Wag ner's Rheingold; in travel from the carriage to the railroad car. As a historian Adams knew all this well enough and spent a good deal of his life lamenting these changes. But In what Adams had in mind, that close hothouse world of the best people, of the world of manners, of status if not stature, of finely grained social relationships, of those who prop themselves up on genealogy if not achievementthat world had not changed. It has not changed much for us either, if the novels of J. P. Marquand, John O'Hara and Louis Auchincloss are indexes. As we know, new money is never as good as old.

title: President Park Urges U.S. To Go Slow on Asian Policy
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 9 President Chung Hee Park urged today that the United States go slow with its new Asian policy in order to give time for the Asian nations to build up their own defense capacities.

title: MARGARET J. CORCORAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Mar garet Josephine Corcoran, a daughter of Thomas G. Cor coran, the Washington lawyer and former adviser to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died to day at her home at the age of 28. The cause of death was not immediately determined.

title: Romance and Reality in Africa
description: NAMANGA, KenyaOne of the great experiences for the visitor in East Africa is seeing the Masai, the warrior herds men who inhabit the dry plains of southern Kenya and north ern Tanzania. Of all tribes they match the dream of the exotic and the noble in primitive life.

title: COURT STAYS AETNA ON POLICY RENEWALS
description: COURT STAYS AETNA ON POLICY RENEWALSNEWARK, Jan. 9 (AP) Superior Court Judge Nelson Mintz issued a temporary in junction today enjoining Aetna Casualty and Surety Company from sending out notices of nonrenewal of policies to its New Jersey customers.

title: Cosmos 318 Is Launched
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (AP)The Soviet Union launched No. 318 in its Cosmos series of un manned satellites today, the press agency Tass said. Tass said that the satellite was cir cling the earth every 89.3 minutes.

title: Soviet Assails the Chinese, Tells of U. S.PekingTalks
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9  The So viet Union appeared today to link the planned resumption of talks between the United States and Communist China with what Moscow called Peking's military psychosis against the Soviet Union.

title: Arthur H. Thornhill Dead at 74; Chairman of Little, Brown & Co.
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9 Arthur H. Thornhill, chairman of the board of Little, Brown & Co., one of the oldest book publish egs in the country, died here today. He was 74 years old.

title: Northeast Lines Seeks Halt In Service at Lebanon, N. H.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Northeast Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today for permission to suspend serv ice at Lebanon, N. Y.White River Junction, Vt., for two years.

title: Wilson Threatened Before Title Game, Raiders Disclose
description: The Oakland Raiders dis closed yesterday that Nemiah Wilson, their starting corner back, received a threat against his life two days before the team's American Football League championship game against Kansas City Ian. 4.

title: I.T.&T. Public Hearing Set
description: William R. Cotter, Insurance Commissioner of Connecticut, has announced that a public hearing on the proposed ac quisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company by the In ternational Telephone and Tele graph Corporation would be held at 10 A.M. on March 10 in the department's offices at 165 Capitol Avenue in Hart ford. Persons desiring to testify have until March 2 to notify Mr. Cotter in writing.

title: Chile Cuts Escudo Again To Keep Up With Inflation
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 9 (AP)The Central Bank today ordered another minidevalua tion of 20 to 23 points depending on the rateof the Chilean escudo.

title: For Salads, for Pies: The Versatile Rutabaga
description: THE British know them as swedes and the Cana dians as rutabagas, but it's all one and the same yellow turnip. The shaded orange to purple skin covers a sweet tasting, versatile root that is used in the recipes that fol low.

title: MAHOPAC CURLERS DEFEAT DEFENDERS
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 9 The Mahopac (N. Y.) Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Lon Keller, eliminated the Brae Burn No. 1 rink of West New ton, Mass., 103, today in the second round of the 35th an nual Douglas Medal bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club. Brae Burn, skipped by Howard (Bud) Chandler, was the defend ing champion.

title: STOCKS END WEEK IN MILD RETREAT
description: Some tranchising Issues were hit by declines yesterday as the stock market closed out its first full week of 1970 with a mild retreat.

title: WOMEN AT INQUEST RULED OUT DRINKING
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Jan. 9 (UPI)Five young women told the secret inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne that there was little drinking at a party preceding the fatal accident. The women were the final wit nesses before the inquest closed yesterday after four days of testimony.

title: Rhode Island Bill Would Set Requirement for News Play
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 9 (AP)A bill that would require, news media to give the acquit tal of a defendant the same prominence accorded to his in dictment has been introduced in the Rhode Island Senate.

title: Commuters Delayed and Railroads Blame the Cold
description: The cry of the chilled com muter was heard in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday as equipment break downs, signal failures, track problems and a collision de layed railroad service.

title: DEMOCRATS SCORE NIXON'S VETO PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) House Democrats moved eagerly into battle today against President Nixon's announced intention to veto an appropria tions bill because he feels that it contains more money for edu cation than should be spent now.

title: VIETNAM KILLINGS LAID TO KOREANS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The former director of a pri vate research project in Viet nam said today that his inter viewers turned up evidence in 1966 that South Korean forces had murdered hundreds of South Vietnamese civilians.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 8Planting his red track shoes on the classroom floor, a teaching assistant at the University of California here tugged the peak of his baseball cap, rolled his shoulders under a gym shirt, blew a whistle and barked: This is Education 191D. There are two rumors about this course. One, it's a mick. Two, it's a trap for athletes. I'm supposed to be a radical guy and halfway through I'm going to pile on the requirements and make everyone ineligible. Several hundred students smiled warily, shifted in their chairs and exchanged glances. Among them was a senior football captain seeking to clarify his ath letic motivations, some of his varsity teammates who thought the 3point course would be a Mickey Mouse breather, several varsity dropouts hoping to rein force their moral justifica tion for quitting, a number of girls suspected of chas ing jocks, young student assistant coaches and scores of undergraduates lured by the prospect of uncharted inquiry implicit in the course's title: Inter collegiate Athletics and Ed ucation: A SocioPsycho logical Evaluation.

title: F. A. Morgan Easton, 83, ExPartner in Brokerage
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Jan. F. A. Morgan Easton, who retired 10 years ago as manag ing partner of Newborg & Co., a New York Stock Exchange firm, now part of Oppenheimer, Newborg & Neu, died yesterday in Valley Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 445 Al pine Terrace.

title: Lawyer Is Sentenced
description: Philip Peitz, 36yearold lawyer, of 230 Central Park South, convicted of illegally getting information about an investigation of the Georgia Pacific Company from an em ploye of the Securities and Ex change Commission, was given a threemonth prison sentence yesterday by Federal Judge Ed ward Weinfeld.

title: COFFEE PRICES UP AT GENERAL FOODS
description: The General Foods Corpora. tion raised wholesale prices of Maxwell House ground coffee yesterday by 5 cents a pound or an average of about 5.5 per cent.

title: South African Role Seen
description: ZURICH, Jan. 9  South Africa was today thought to have been depressing the free market gold price so as to take advantage of the recent agree ment under which it might sell gold to the International Mone tary Fund as soon as the free market price dropped to $35 an ounce.

title: McDonough Named Referee
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 (AP) John McDonough of Santa Ana, Calif., a 10year player in the American Football League, will be the referee of Sunday's Super Bowl football game be tween the Minnesota Vikings and Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Lakers Down Hawks, 127112
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 9 (AP) Jerry West, Elgin Baylor and Harold Hairston combined for 68 points tonight and led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 127112 victory over the At lanta Hawks. West scored 26 while Hairston and Baylor tal lied 21 apiece.

title: U.S. Opposed to Purchases
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 United States officials said to day they had no knowledge of a move in Europe to organize a central bank pool to buy gold on the free market when necessary to prevent a drop in the price.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS VOLUME GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange mostly declined yes terday although the trading pace quickened.

title: British Assured on Market Political Talks
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 9  Britain received from five of the six members of the European Com mon Market today a promise that no binding political deci sions would be made before negotiations for Britain's ad mission began.

title: Diamond Sales Set Mark
description: LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP)Dia mond sales set a record $691.2 million in 1969, up 15 per cent on the previous year, De Beers central selling organization said today. De Beers holds an al most world monopoly in the diamond trade.

title: BOARD BACKS PLEA IN OCEAN EL RIFT
description: A 26hour sitin at the Board of Education by 75 members of the Ocean Hill  Brownsville Community Education Center ended last night after the board agreed to put on the center's payroll 11 persons who had been involved in a dispute.

title: Rate of Job Growth Remains Sluggish
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The growth in the total number of jobs in the United States con tinued last month to show a sluggishness that belied the ap parent strength of the low un employment rate, which re pained at the November level of 3.4 per cent. Both figures were reported today by the Labor Department.

title: Topics: Judgment on Mylai
description: What actually happened at Mylai in March of 1968 is and may well remain obscured by the fog of war, the passage of time, and the selfinterest of surviving participants. But their accounts have raised questions of the greatest momentques tions that will not be sufficient ly answered by trial of a hand ful of accused soldiers.

title: Raid Termed Heaviest
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9  What was described as the heaviest Israeli air raid ever to hit Lebanon tore up the hill side between villages on the western side of Mount Hermon for the fourth time in a week. The Israeli aircraft again ap peared to be seeking out Arab commando bases.

title: MISSISSIPPI SHOWS INTEGRATION GAIN
description: JACKSON, Miss. Jan. 9 (UPI)  School integration was peacefully carried out today in Leake and North Pike Coun ties. They were the latest to integrate under an order handed down by the United States Supreme Court in Octo ber calling for the complete and immediate desegregation of 30 Mississippi districts.

title: RUSSELL H. HUGHES, EXTELEPHONE AIDE
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 9Russell H. Hughes, a re tired, vice president of the New York Telephone Company, died yesterday at the Phelps Memo rialHospital here after a long illness. Mr. Hughes, who lived at Strawberry Hill, Irvington onHudson, and Cape Haze, Fla., was 77 years old.

title: Young and Frivolous Even in Chiffon
description: I'VE decided there's nothing for me but the short skirt.

title: 1,500 Atlanta Students Protest Teacher Transfers
description: ATLANTA. Jan. 9  About 1,500 students walked out of Atlanta schools this morning and marched a mile in 12de gree temperatures from Atlanta Stadium to the Federal Building to protest the impending trans fer of 1.800 Atlanta teachers.

title: SHIRLEY VERRETT CHARMS MILANESE
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 9Shirley Verrett scored both a public and a critical success in her opera debut here last night, singing Delilah in La Scala's new production of Saint Saens's Samson and Delilah.

title: Harvard Hearings Boycott
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 (AP)Thirtysix Harvard Ne groes said today that they would not report to a series of disciplinary hearings that begin next Monday regarding their occupation of University Hall last month. The students, who have been served with com plaints from the university, said they would avoid the hearings because we cannot recognize the university's legitimacy in constructing the laws for the mechanism for which it seeks to enforce them.

title: Eileen R. Cooney, A Teacher, to Wed
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 9Mrs. Arthur E. Cooney has announced the engage ment of her daughter, Miss Eileen Regina Cooney, to Timothy A. Hogan Jr. He is the son of the late Chief Warrant Officer Hogan, U.S.A., and the late Mrs. Hogan of Washington.

title: Primary Reform Is Needed
description: The probability that the fields will be crowded in the Democratic primary contests for gubernatorial and senatorial nominations points up the clear and over riding need for electoral law reform. This reform will require Republican support in Albany, where the G.O.P. controls both houses of the State Legislature.

title: 15 Rockets Strike a City in Laos; Pathet LaoHanoi Units Blamedl
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 9 (AP) Pathet Lao and North Viet namese forces were reported to have fired 15 rockets today into Pakse, Laos's second largest city. It was said to be the first time in the Laotian conflict that they had fired rockets at a major city.

title: YABLONSKI CAUSE CITED BY EULOGIST
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Jan. 9 Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter were buried here today on a bitterly cold and windy hilltop. About 1,000 mourners were urged to con tinue his struggle for reform in the coal fields.

title: Dialogue With Peking
description: The Administration has scored a notable advance in winning Peking's agreement to resume the long interrupted talks between American and Chinese ambassadors in Warsaw. Reopening of a direct com munications channel between the leaders of the United States and of the Chinese People's Republic could pave the way toward the stilldistant goal of full normalization of United StatesChinese relations.

title: Jordan Complains to U.N
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 9  Jordan complained to the Security Council in a letter today that Israelis killed 67 Jor danians on the east bank of the Jordan River in the last five months of 1969 in artillery and air attacks.

title: Top Lindsay Aide Expected to Leave His Staff Soon
description: The man who had been Mayor Lindsay's only special assistant is scheduled to be leaving that position soon, in what City Hall sources call an exercise of power by Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio and the Mayor's new political allies.

title: Words of Socialism From New Delhi Upset Wealthy in Bombay
description: BOMBAY, India, Dec. 31 Socialism has reared its head over Bombay's highrise skyline, and the business community in this shrine of free enterpriseIndia's com mercial center, banking hub and busiest portis worried and angry.

title: Professor of Jargon Finds That Yesterday's Ins Are Out and Outs Are, Too
description: About 10 years ago, for purposes not yet clear to him, Robert K. Merton, a so ciologist of Columbia Uni versity, prepared a list of plus words  words that had drifted from the social sciences into the vernacular.

title: DIPLOMATS OF U.S. ELECT ACTIVISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  A young activist faction in the professional organization of United States diplomats has re tained control of the, group in an election that was a test of its strength.

title: Agnew Hints at Aid to 4 Nations
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 9  Vice President Agnew indicated to day that the United States might extend some types of technical and moralebuilding aid to Singapore, Malaysia, Aus tralia and New Zealand to help them in their efforts to fill the defense gap left by Britain when she pulls her forces out of the region next year.

title: Price Proceedings Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)  The Agriculture Department announced today a oneweek delay in proceedings aimed at protecting Florida tomato prices by cutting shipments from that state and imports from Mexico.

title: OUTLOOK FOR CATV IS GIVEN BY BURGH
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Chairman Dean Burch of the Federal Communications Com mission told the cable tele vision industry today that it could expect that most of the rules governing broadcast sta tions will eventually also be applied to cablecasting.

title: DECLINE IS SHOWN IN ORANGE JUICE
description: The Florida weather experts squeezed the juice out of orange juice futures recent price rises with their estimate yesterday that recent freezing temperatures probably had not caused crop damage.

title: Ideas Flourishing at Start Your Own Business Show
description: The vanguard of an expec ted 50,000 potential entrepre neurs filed into the New York Coliseum yesterday afternoon as the annual Start Your Own Business Exposition opened for a fiveday run.

title: Hijacker Faces 3 Charges in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 Eight of the passengers of a Trans World Airlines jetliner hijacked near Paris and flown here during the night departed for Rome today. The ninth  a 26yearold Frenchman identi fied as the hijacker  was jailed and faced three possible charges.

title: Art: David Levine's Wonderful World
description: WEAK from laughing and tonguetied with admi ration, no critic should be asked to do more than gasp out the address of the Forum Gallery, 1018 Madison Ave nue at 79th Street, and the advice to get there quick to see David Levine's new show. It makes no difference if you have already seen these cari catures of literary and polit ical personages in the New York Review of Books, or if you have clipped them for your scrapbook or have been wearing your favorites in a locket. They never grow stale, and the originals have a brilliant presence that is partly lost in reproduction even though they were drawn with reproduction in mind.

title: A Beach Boy Is Convicted
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (UPI) Carl Dean Wilson, a member of the Beach Boys singing group, will be sentenced Jan. 29 for failure to report for a civilian work assignment as an alternative to military service. A jury of nine men and three women deliberated 20 minutes yesterday before finding Wil son, who is 22 years old, guilty. He failed to report to his local draft board Nov. 25.

title: M.I.T. Announces Penalties For Student Demonstration
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. (AP)Demonstrations last fall at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have resulted in the disqualification of one student and the imposition of probation on two others.

title: Maggots in a Sack of Flour
description: Reflecting on the population explosion, the French anthropologist Claude LeviStrauss recently likened the human predicament to that of maggots in a sack of flour.

title: The Little Virginia Town That Thrives on Making Furniture
description: BASSETT, Va.In this hilly country in southwest Vir ginia, one notices the chim neysso many, so tall, so busy sending long curls of smoke melding into the slate sky. And why not, in a lum berrich area, where firewood is cheap, and in a town that's the home of the world's larg est furniture producer?

title: Sales of Retail Stores in 1969 Rose 4%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)  The nation's retail stores did $352.08billion worth of busi ness last year, up 4 per cent over 1968's total of $339.32 billion, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: Sweden Deposits Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (Reu ters)Sweden today deposited its instrument of ratification of the international treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons. The deposition at the State Department was the 25th made to date. The treaty comes into effect when 43 countries de posit their instruments of rati fication.

title: INCOME GAIN CITED BY FLORIDA POWER
College Basketball
description: AT, CHESTNUT TVCHANNEL BOSTON COLLEGE

title: U.S.PEKING TALKS STIR SOVIET BLOC
description: VIENNA, Jan. 9  Eastern European diplomatic sources said today that the foreign af fairs chiefs of the Soviet bloc might soon meet again to eval uate the forthcoming talks be tween the United States and Communist China.

title: JULIAN B. ERWAY, EXSTATE SENATOR
description: Julian B. Erway, a former State Senator from Albany, died yesterday in Fort Lauder dale, Fla., where he had been vacationing with his wife. He was 70.

title: Activist Labor Priest
description: MSGR. CHARLES OWEN RICE, who delivered the eulogy yesterday for his old friend Joseph A. Yablonski, recalls with wry amusement that his own definition of the priesthood as a vocation for activists has sometimes put him in conflict with his church. In 1948 or there abouts I support ed the teamsters in a bad strike, he said. When Cardinal Spellman used seminarians to break the strike [of grave diggers], I said, A scab is a scab regardless of whether he wears cardinal red or denim blue. After a brief, reminiscent pause, Monsignor Rice added with a chuckle: It didn't go over.

title: Teacher City College Ousted in 1933 Is Cleared
description: Dr. Arthur J. Kraus has been wandering about the world for 37 years trying to convince people that he was wronged when he was dis missed from the City College faculty in 1933 after conduct ing a hunger strike to protest fascism in Europe and isola tionism at home.

title: Red Cross Actions After Storm Called Dehumanizing by Negro
description: BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 9 A Gulf Coast official of the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People today told a United States Senate subcommittee investi gating Hurricane Camille relief operations that the American Red Cross history of discrimi nation against black people manifested itself during recov ery from last August's storm.

title: 7 Chinese Jump Ship; One Is Captured on S.I.
description: The mystery of six Chinese seamen from Hong Kong who jumped ship continued last night after the Coast Guard suspended its search for them at the entrance to New York Harbor.

title: ABRAHAM J. FRANKEL
description: LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 9Abra ham J. Frankel of 1115 Holly wood Road, chairman of the Union County Welfare Board, died yesterday in Runnells Hos pital, Berkeley Heights. He was 77 years old.

title: A New Center for Moslems Here
description: New York's Islamic com rnunity, numbering 30,000 families, will begin soon to build a $19million cultural center On the Upper East Side.

title: War Protester Loses Case And Gets 10Day Sentence
description: A 40yearold hospital ad ministrator whose suit to have the war in Vietnam declared unconstitutional was dismissed in United States District Court earlier this week, was given 10 days in jail yesterday for causing a disturbance in the court.

title: Elizabeth Harford Prospective Bride
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., Jan. 9Miss Elizabeth Lovejoy Harford, a granddaughter of William T. Piper of Lock Haven, Pa., founder of the Piper Aircraft Corporation, and Robert Leo Barrett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Barrett of Lawrenceville and Spring Lake, are planning to be married.

title: Dr. William Cumming, 42, Dies; Columbia Psychology Professor
description: LEONIA, N. J., Jan. 9Dr. William W. Cumming, profes sor of psychology at Columbia University, died yesterday of a hemorrhage at his home, 402 Allaire Avenue. His age was 42.

title: Israeli View Given
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 9 (AP)The Israeli Foreign Ministry declar ed today that the planned French sale of arms to Libya far surpasses that country's needs, and said that the weap. ons would undoubtedly wind up in Egypt for use against Israel.

title: MRS. ALLAN R. CAMPBELL
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 9 Mrs. Gertrude H. DuBois Campbell, the widow of Allan R. Campbell, a New York City and Westchester County law yer, died yesterday in her home here at 22 Sagamore Road. She was 91 years old.

title: FogProof Ski Glasses Produced
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 American sportsmen are wearing what are advertised as the world's only fog proof ski glasses. The lenses are coated on both sides with a transparent plas tic known as Hydron. A patent for the coated lenses was re ceived this week by the Na tional Patent Development Corporation, New York. The inventors are Dr. Thomas H. Shepherd and Francis E. Gould, officers of Hydron Laboratories, a research sub sidiary at Princeton, N. J.

title: OHIO FIRE KILLS 21 IN NURSING HOME
description: MARIETTA, Ohio, Saturday, Jan. 10Hospital officials said at least 21 persons were killed and 22 others injured last night as fire destroyed a nursing home in this southeastern Ohio city. The police said the death toll might rise as high as 36.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Nasser Danger Disclosed
description: CAIRO, Jan. 9A Cairo edi tor, Mohammed Hassanein Hey kal, disclosed today that an airliner carrying President Ga mal Abdel Nasser to Benghazi, Libya, from Tripoli 12 days ago, was involved in an emergency when the front landing gear jammed. A crash landing was averted, the editor said, when the crew succeeded in lowering the gear manually.

title: Ecuador Ferry Sinks With 50
description: Guayaquil, Ecuador, Jan. 9 (AP)  A motor ferry boa carrying 50 passengers sank in sharkinfested Guayaquil Gulf this morning and rescue work ers feared Mit most of those aboard perished.

title: Shell Calls Conference On Oil Tanker Hazards
description: LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) Shell Petroleum, the British Netherlands oil group, said today it had called an inter national conference of tanker owners to discuss fire haz ards on giant tankers.

title: Frigid Air Grips City; Thousands Without Heat
description: The coldest weather of the winter enveloped the metropolitan area yesterday, leaving thousands of families shivering in heatless apartments and subjecting commuters to hardships throughout the day and evening.

title: STEELERS TO GET FIRST DRAFT PICK
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9  When a 1921 silver dollar thudded into a conference table and came up tails after being tossed today by Commissioner Pete Rozelle, the Pittsburgh Steelers were awarded the first choice of college talent in the Jan. 27 by the 26 pro football teams.

title: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships
description: SAILING TODAY

title: TEN RESERVE UNITS FOUND TO BE UNFIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) A spot check found that Army Reserve units selected for high combat readiness had neither the training nor the equipment to mobilize fast in an emergency, Congressional investigators reported today.

title: DAVENPORT TIES HURDLES RECORD
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 9 Trailing by 10 yards starting the final lap, Marty Liguori re sumed his place as America's premier miler tonight with a victory in the National invita tion indoor track meet at Cole Field House.

title: Lawyer to Wed Sallie H. Campbell
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Camp bell have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Sallie Hedren Campbell, to John Codman Ruhnka, who is associated with the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Ruhnka of Chestertown. Md.

title: Bullets Subdue Celtics
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP)Five Baltimore players, led by Wes Unseld, scored 19 or more points as the Bullets posted a 142130 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight. Unseld notched 29 points.

title: Flood Says He Won't Play Unless His Suit Is Settle
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9 (AP) Curt Flood said today he did not intend to play baseball un til his legal challenge of the reserve clause in the players' contract was settled.

title: Nixon Planning to Name A New Envoy to Sweden
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Reu ters)President Nixon is plan ning to name a new ambassador to Sweden soon, filling a diplo matic post left vacant for a year because of Washington's displeasure with Swedish sym pathy for North Vietnam. The State Department spokesman, Robert J. McCloskey made the disclosure today but refused to say who the new envoy would be.

title: Hoffa Files an Appeal
description: CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 9 (AP) Attorneys for James R. Hoffa filed an appeal yesterday to re verse a United States District Court judge's refusal to order a new trial for the imprisoned president of the Teamsters' union.

title: F.B.I. MAY JOIN HUNT FOR WILTON KILLER
description: WILTON, Conn., Jan. 9The Federal Bureau of Investigation may be brought into the search for a convicted rapist who is suspected of having strangled a Wilton mother of four and attacked two other women Wednesday, police said today.

title: Lockheed Contract Gains
description: A $100million addition to its existing Air Force contract for production of C5A cargo planes has been received by the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation. This award brings the total allocated for the C5A to date to nearly $2.03billion. it was said.

title: Indonesian Head to Visit U.S.
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 9 (UPI)  President Suharto will visit the United States and Canada later this year, Foreign Minister Adam Malik said to day. No date was given, but Mr. Malik indicated the visit would probably be in April or May.

title: OWNERS RESISTING RIVALRY CHANGES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9Re alignment of the 13 teams that will be In the National Confer ence next season, which has provoked an impasse for six months, will be discussed to morrow when those club own ers interrupt their Super Bowl festivities to assemble for a National Football League meet ing.

title: MATT WEINSTOCK, 66, COLUMNIST ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP) Matt Weinstock, a Los An geles Times columnist, died last night at the Medical Center of the University of California at Los Angeles. He was 66 years old.

title: Sonics Top 76ers, 135132
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (AP) The Seattle Sonics went ahead on a goaltending basket by Bob Rule with 1 minute 37 seconds remaining, and then converted 11 free throws to defeat the Philadelphia 76ers, 135132, tonight.

title: Bail Set for 2 Young Lords Refusing to Agree to Pact
description: Two members of the Young Lords, a militant Puerto Rican group, were released yesterday in $500 bond each, which was set after they refused to prom ise a judge they would not re occupy an East Harlem church.

title: S.E.C. Rules Talley Must Offer Better Terms to General Time
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Securities and Exchange Commission, by a 3to1 vote, held today that terms of the proposed merger of General Time Corporation into Talley Industries, Inc., are not fair to the stockholders in General Time and must be amended before the commission will approve the merger.

title: As the Democrats Line Up
description: The first hat is in the ring. It will not be the last. The chief races in New York's election this year will be those for Governor and United States Senator; and in this generally capricious season for both politics and weather, announcement of candidacies can soon be expected to fall as thickly as winter's snows.

title: Quakers Take 10th
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 Pennsylvania, lifting its won lost record to 101, took the lead for good four minutes from the end of the first half and went on to defeat Dartmouth's basketball team, 8975, in an Ivy League game tonight be fore a slim Palestra crowd.

title: Ford Plans Japan Tractors
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9 (UPI)The Ishikawajima Shibaura Machine Company said today it would shortly sign a contract with the Ford Motor Company that would let it produce Ford farm tractors. They would be sold through a sales company Ford plans to establish with the Hokkai Motor Company.

title: Art: Pat Adams Paintings
description: THERE are painters whose work shouts to us from the rooftops, never for a mo ment lowering its voice; and there are others whose work discloses itself with an air of intimacy and confidence. The paintings of Pat Adams, currently on view at the Za briskie Gallery, 699 Madison Avenue, are distinctly of the latter nersuasion.

title: Air France to Expand
description: PARIS, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Air France, the French staterun airline, said today it proposed doubling its capital to onebil lion francs ($180million dol lars) to finance investments over the next five years. The French Government has a 98 per cent holding in the com pany and existing shareholders will have first option to buy the new issue:

title: Cornell Downs Brown, 7259
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 9 Cornell sped to a 265 lead after 12 minutes of play and defeated Brown tonight, 7259, for the Big Red's first Ivy League tri umph of the year. Cornell had previously lost twice to Colum bia while Brown remains with out a victory in three league starts.

title: Janice B. Copenhaver, Student, Engaged to Per Erwin Jonas
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 9 The Rev. Dr. Charles Leon ard Copenhaver, senior min ister of the Reformed Church here, and Mrs. Copenhaver have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Janice Bernice Copenhaver, to Per Erwin Jonas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin A. Jonas of Bronxville and Kragero, Norway. The senior Mr. Jo nas is executive vice presi dent of the Thor Dahl Com pany, an international ship ping concern, and president of the Norwegian  American Chamber of Commerce.

title: Chicago Fares May Rise From 40 to 50 Cents
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9  The Chicago Transit Authority is expected to increase its fares about Feb. 1, when the fare may go from 40 to 50 cents, which would be the highest in the nation. The C.T.A. board's 1970 budget, adopted last month, anticipates a deficit of $21.5million.

title: 3% Rise Estimated In U.S. Citrus Crop
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The nation's citrus fruit crop this season will be up 3 per cent from last year but slightly less than indicated, the Agri culture Department announced today.

title: Mediator's Talks With G.E. And Strikers Are Fruitless
description: J. Curtis Counts, director of the Federal Mediation and Con ciliation Service, yesterday at tempted for a second day to find some common ground for bargaining in the General Elec tric strike, but there was no word of success, United Press International reported.

title: Stocks Make a Quick Recovery As Tokyo Weighs U.S. Curb
FRANCE CONFIRMS LIBYANS WILL GET 50 MIRAGE PLANES
description: PARIS, Jan. 9After much hesitation, French officials ac knowledged tonight that about 50 Mirage jet fighter planes would be sold to Libya.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Lower Interest Rates

title: Accountant Identifies Paychecks Involved in Youth Corps Thefts
description: A certified public accountant yesterday identified 13,480 pay checks totaling $523,262.52 that Coy D. Smith was charged with stealing when he was the chief fiscal officer of the city's Neighborhood Youth Corps.

title: India to Buy 7 Airliners
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 9 (Reuters) India will buy seven Amer ican Boeing 737 jet airliners for her domestic airlines, the Civil Aviations Minister Karan Singh, announced tonight.

title: Mirage a Successful Plane
description: The Mirage, a successful deltawinged fighter aircraft, was designed originally as a highspeed highaltitude inter ceptor, but with capability of lowlevel ground support as well.

title: Strike Threatened at TWA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The International Association of Machinists said today that, it would strike Trans World Air lines at 2 A.M. Thursday unless there was further progress in contract negotiations.

title: JAPAN WELCOMES U.S.CHINESE TALKS
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9Sources in the Japanese Foreign Ministry welcomed today the announce ment that Washington and Pe king are to resume ambassa dorial talks in Warsaw on Jan. 20, they said Japan was ready to open highlevel official talks with Communist China at any time.

title: Passengers Arrive in Rome
description: ROME, Jan. 9  Eight weary passengers and an equal num ber of crew members of the Trans World Airlines plane hi lacked from here to Beirut early this morning returned to Rome today on an Alitalia plane.

title: Libyans Maintain Denial
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 9 (Rent ers)Official Libyan sources are maintaining their denial of any arms deal with France. They have been silent about reports from foreign capitals about FrenchLibyan arms ne gotiations.

title: McClellan Weighs Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said to day he had ordered the staff of a Senate investigations sub committee to begin a prelimi nary investigation of the slay ings and the election.

title: DEFIANCE IS FINED, $60,000 IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (UPI)De fiance Industries, Inc., an Ohio corporation, once controlled by Roy M. Cohn and Victor Mus cat, the New York financiers, was fined $60,000 today after its officers pieacied guilty to violating Illinois banking laws.

title: JOHN J. SHABET
description: John J. Shabet, a former en gineer at Bell Telephone Lab oratories here, died Tuesday at St. Francis Hospital in Jersey City. He was 70 years old and lived at 216 Princeton Avenue, Jersey City.

title: Car Falls, Kills Sea Captain
description: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 9 A retired sea captain of the United States merchant marine was killed Thursday evening when his car fell off a jack and landed on him. The police said that Archie L. Massey, 69 years old, was found by his sister, Matilda Massey, with whom he lived, with one of the car wheels resting on his body. Mr. Massey retired from the Mer chant Marine five years ago. A native of New York City he had Hived in the city for 50 years and was a member of the Mas ter, Mates and Pilots Associa tion.

title: Vespucci MS. Given to U.S. Library
description: A narrative by Amerigo Vespucci of his four voyages to America between 1497 and 1502 has been donated to the Library of Congress as part of a collection of 162 historical documents span ning 300 years of colonial Spanish America.

title: Displaying Wife: Style Changes
description: Styles in showing off have a tendency to keep up with basic economics. So it is that the inflated sixties end ed with some recessive symp toms even in the way the ty coons of the seventies will be displaying theirmost precious possessions, namely their wives.

title: Steel Companies Seek More Profit in Related Fields
description: It is not impossible that, by the end of this decade, one of the best jobs in some American steel company will include making aluminum foil for candy bars in Aus tralia.

title: RED MONK SCORES IN BOWIE FEATURE
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 10 (AP) Red Monk, passed over in claiming race three weeks ago, scored a frontrunning victory today in the $20,000added Southern Maryland Hanicap at Bowie Race Track.

title: Asian and Pacific Jews Form Federation to Preserve Identity
description: SYDNEY, Austrialia, Jan. 10 The small but prosperous Jewish community in Asian and Pacific countries has formed an international body in Sydney to combat erosion of their identity and culture.

title: Agnew: A Roving Envoy Comes On Strong
description: SINGAPORE  When Vice President Spiro Agnew and his entourage swept into Kuala Lum pur, Malaysia, last week, the American Embassy there hand ed out a list of special rules of courtesy to be observed with Muslims. Among the items in the Don't column was one warning: Never place ones foot or feet on a table or desk when talking to guests.

title: Publishers Retreat From Technology
description: Many leading publishers believe that the era of large scale mergers of the kind that marked the last decade in trade and textbook publish ing is coming to a close.

title: George Du Maurier
description: The Paris art training of George Du Maurier was financed by part of the 10,000, plus annuities, settled on his grandmother and her daughters half a century earlier by Frederick, Duke of York, brother of George III. The lady was the Duke's discarded mistress. Much in Du Maurier's back ground has this romantic coloration. His father and grandfather were irresponsible dreamers and impossi ble providers, and he was not only halfFrench and halfEnglish, but the grandchild of a Frenchman exiled in England, and of an Englishwoman exiled in France. Even his aristocratic surname was an invention, the truth about which he never knew.

title: COLUMBIA ACCUSED OF BIAS ON WOMEN
description: A group of women faculty members at Columbia has is sued a report charging dis crimination against women in the university's hiring policies and asking for afull study of employment opportunities for women at Columbia.

title: Phyllis M. Reynolds Is Married
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 10Miss Phillis M. Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and M. Francis W. Reynolds, wa married here this afternoon to Bradford Gage Weekes 3d.

title: 81 MOGER MONGER TRIUMPHS BY A NECK
description: PAWTUCKETT, R. I., Jan. 10 (AP)Moger Monger, carrying the light weight in the field at 107 pounds, caught the pace setting Lucky Richard in the stretch today and drove to a neck victory in the $7,500 Prov idence Handicap at Narragan sett Park.

title: Move to Increase Engine Size Threatens Grand Prix Racing
description: THERE is an adage in the legal profession that says, No matter how high you build a legislative fence, someone will always find a way to jump over or crawl under it. The current situa tion with regard to the famous longdistance motor races counting for the World Man

title: In Advertising, Crystal Gazing Is a Routine Technique
description: If you couldn't say any thing else about the seven ties, you could certainly says they're being talked about. And talked about. And talked about.

title: Instant mythology in New Mexico
description: On June 5, 1967, Reies Lo pez Tijerina and a small band of followers staged a raid on the county courthouse in Tierra Amarilla, a dusty little town in an impoverished area of northern New Mexico. Their aim was to make a citizen's arrest of Alfonso Sanchez, a district attorney whose harass ment tactics had kept Tijerina and his allies parading through a series of jails and court rooms on rather insubstantial charges. Sanchez was not there, a policeman drew a gun some one started shooting two people were wounded. The state of New Mexico, apparently con vinced that it was tottering on the brink of anarchy called out the National Guard  fully equipped with tanks and heli coptersto round up the raid ers.

title: Home Improvement
description: ONE of the most annoy ing and unsightly home maintenanec problems that can occur is a bad ly cracked or bumpy old ceil ing that seems to defy all attempts at permanent re pair  cracks are continu ously popping open, no mat ter how carefully they are filled; paint seems to always peel; lumps and bumps are always visible because of years of improper patching and painting.

title: Author's Query
description: I am seeking surviving let ters and other manuscript ma terials relating to the life and work of Benjamin Banneker (17311806), a selftaught Afro American astronomer and al manac maker, for consideration in a documented biography which is now nearing comple tion. Also of interest are cor respondence, personal papers and scientific instruments of George Ellicott, who was asso ciated with Banneker in his studies.

title: THE OPENINGS OF THE WEEK
description: THE MEMORY BANKTonight, Tambellini's Gate Thea ter, 7:15. Two oneact plays by Martin Duberman. Postponed from Jan. 4.

title: A Rose For R. Strauss
description: THE way the record business is going now adays, it sometimes seems that the publi cation of literature and illus tration is becoming the tail that wags the dog. A major album that appears without a voluminous array of texts, notes, explanations, essays, photographs, drawings, etc., is almost unthinkable and, one would guess, almost un sellable in a market that of fers countless choices of the bestknown works.

title: Miss Margaret Badenhausen Wed to the Rev. Alan French
description: IPSWICH, Mass., Jan. 10  Miss Margaret Baden hausen and the Rev. Alan French were married here this morning at the Ascen sion Memorial Church (Epis copal), of which the bride groom is rector, by the Rev. Tao Steman, a Franciscan priest. The Very Rev. Harvey Guthrie, dean of the Episco pal Theological Seminary in Cambridge, assisted.

title: Speaking of Books: Not in My Autobiography
description: The nasty, bitchy, intolerable side of me: is it in my autobiography? It must have slipped into its rightful place, yet surely I was not scrup ulously slaving over pen and paper to guarantee its prerogatives.

title: 80,997 TO ATTEND
List of Major Expiring Labor Contracts
description: Following is a list of major collective bargaining agree ments terminating in 1970, each covering 4,000 or more workers. These plus other contracts to be renegotiated this year cover five million workers. The list has been compiled from information prepared by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Davenport Equals His Record In 45Yard Hurdles at Boston
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10Willie Davenport lost a race tonight, but it didn't count.

title: Deborah Ruth Conley Married To Vern P. Gray, Navy Veteran
description: IRVINGTON, N. Y., Jan 10 Miss Deborah Ruth Con ley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Agnew Conley, was mar ried this afternoon to Vern Peter Gray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon L. Gray of Am herst, N.H.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  If one were looking for conceptual turning points in the long course of American involvement in Asia, they might be found in two Presidential backgrounders one held by President McKin ley, tormented over his decision to turn the Philippines into an American colony, and the other held 70 years later by Presi dent Nixon, tormented by an American war in Vietnam.

title: Passengers Will Ride to 70's on Hopes and Problems
description: If a variety of economic, political and social problems can be overcome, transporta tion experts predict that the 1970's could produce sweep ing changes in the way Americans travel on land, over water and through the air.

title: THE QUESTIONS
description: EnvironmentIs the present agitation for restoring the environmentan end to air and water pollution and ona political fad, or will the substantial cost of fighting pollution have to be added to the costs of doing business?

title: GREEK PRESS LAWS INCUR A PROTEST
description: ATHENS, Jan. 10The after noon newspaper Ethnos pro tested today that under the present Greek militarybacked Government, freedom of the press means that newspapers are free to print but not free to sell unless they back the, Government.

title: Stamps
description: ERRORS of omission, as do those of commis sion, spark the lives of stamp collectors. As a result, collectors will get two United Nations stamps this year marking the 25th anniversary of that world organization.

title: Drug Rule Is Overriding Issue For A.H.S.A. Convention Here
description: THE American Horse Show Association will hold its annual convention at the Wal dorfAstoria Hotel from Wednesday through Saturday, with the new rule on drugs uppermost in the minds of virtually all the expected 700 delegates.

title: Spotlight:
description: A few years ago, one of the most successful prac titioners in the mutual fund field confided to a friend that he indulged in a bit of industrial navelwatching in order to catch turns in the stock market.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 book stores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Resiraints on Handling and Use Of Moon Rocks May Be Eased
description: Restrictions on the handling and use of the moon rocks are expected to be relaxed with the distribution of samples from the Apollo 12 Mission to scien tists in early February.

title: Judge Commutes Sentence Of Man in Court Protest!
description: A 33yearold hospital admin istrator who was jailed Fri day for causing a disturbance in United States District Court was released after several hours when Judge George Rosling commuted his 10dav sentence.

title: To Ludvik, optimism was the opium of the people
description: The Jokea Czech novel that measures up to Czecho slovakia's wonderfully human films  is 40yearold Milan Kundera's first novel but far from his first work. His collec tion of poems, Monologues, was practically the only book of love poetry published in Czechoslovakia during the Sta linist era, and his three volumes of short stories, Ridiculous Loves, have been best sellers there for several years. The lyrical and narrative skill he demonstrates in these earlier works comes through clearly in his novel.

title: Oxygen Process in Steel Favored
description: This year will see the basic oxygen process for making steel, which has been overtaking the older open hearth method for several years, become the way most American steel is made.

title: ARMY TRACKMEN WIN INDOOR MEET
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 10 A pair of distance runners from the Metropolitan area, Don Rowe of St. John's Uni versity and Jim Schindler of New York University, raced to victories in the mile and two mile events today in a trian gular meet in Army's fast in door track.

title: Miss Cynthia B. Michalis Is a Bride
description: Miss Cynthia Brooks Mi chalis, a December graduate of the University of Michi gan, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Jay Harlock, who was graduated with honors last May from the University's School of Architecture.

title: Libya Names 12 Members Of Revolutionary Counci
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 10 (Reuters)The 12man Revolu tionary Command Council, whch ousted King Idris of Lib ya Sept. 1, was publicly named for the first time today.

title: The taste of the year
description: There is one thing evident about the recipes that readers liked best of those that appeared on these pages during 1969. They were in ternational in scope, which is no great surprise. Interest in dishes from around the world has soared during the last decade. The three most popular recipes, here reprinted, were Lee Lum's lemon chick en, a recipe of the chef at Pearl's Chinese Restaurant in New York; coquille SaintJacques, or scallops baked in the shell, and Min etry's Miracle, a richasCroesus contrivance from Memphis, Tenn.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Three years ago I wrote a lit erary letter from San Francisco called Where the Action Is, and after it was published I received delicious midnight telephone calls from dizzy travelers blessing me for discover ing, among other things, hippies and bands with funny names, such as The Grateful Dead.

title: HUMPHREY SCORES NIXON LEADERSHIP
description: Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey attacked the Nixon Administration yesterday for operating like a corporate structure without a vision of the seventies.

title: PAIRINGS DRAWN FOR CUP SOCCER
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10 (AP) Mexico and the Soviet Union will meet in Aztec Stadium May 31 to open play in the ninth World Cup soccer tourna ment.

title: Technology: Miracles Aren't Enough
description: In some periods, science and technology seem to be running out of art. Then only new chemistry, new physics, basically new devices can give technology a fresh start. That isn't true today.

title: Agnew Visits His First Asian Household
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 10  The soft breeze off the Singapore Strait fluffed through the laun dry hanging from bamboo poles outside the 16thfloor apart ment of the Fung Yao Pao family as the Vice President of the United States pulled up before the public housing proj ect in a green RollsRoyce.

title: Classes for Boatmen Start Tomorrow
description: You hear it over and over again: Spread the gospel of boating education. Get your friends to take classroom study. Bring in the sailor who needs the education. Still, not every one who should heeds these words. When it comes to boat ing, everyone needs an educa tion.

title: Children of The Desert
description: By Phyl and Noel Wallace. Illustrated. 64 pp. Camden, N. J.: Thomas Nelson & Sons. $4.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Pentagon Retreats On Fiscal Front
description: WASHINGTON  The De fense Department, operating under a new, less ambitious global strategy, has drawn up a budget request for about $72 5billion. This is $4.5bil lion less than the Administra tion expects to spend during the present fiscal year, which ends June 30.

title: Boston City Hospital Loses Commission's Accreditation
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)Bos ton City Hospital has lost its accreditation by the Joint Com mission on Accreditation of Hospitals, Health Commissioner Andrew P. Sackett has an nounced.

title: Rocket Bearing Insured Satellite Misfires in a Launching Attempt
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Jan. 10 (UPI) A rocket carrying a commer cial communications satellite, the first insured against launch ing failure, misfired with a flash tonight and remained safely on the firing Dad.

title: Dickinson Homestead In Delaware Recalls The Forgotten Patriot
description: DOVER, Del.  The wind blows across the open flatlands south of this capital city; and the trees and the reeds bend with it. The area is very reminiscent of the Netherlands, which sent the first settlers to the region in the 17th century.

title: RALPH BARONE
description: IRVINGTON, N. J., Jan. 10 Ralph Barone, founder and pres ident of Ralph Barone and Sons, a construction company, died Thursday at Orange (N. J.) Me morial Hospital, in Kennilworth. He was 72 years old and lived at 365 Nesbit Terrace here.

title: U.N. YOUTH PARLEY STIRS MISGIVINGS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10Prospects for a world youth assemblyto bring as many as 1,000 young people of all ideologies to the United Na tions next Julyare kindling enthusiasm here but also stir ring misgivings.

title: Article 2  No Title
Painful Transition
description: Never has inflation in the United States of the current intensity5 to 6 per cent a yearbeen controlled with out a recession. The present one appears to be no ex ception.

title: MEADOWS GROUP FACES PROBLEMS
description: The Hackensack Meadow lands Development Commission is facing conflicting pressures against its plans to impose zoning on the 14 municipalities that lie within the meadows' boundaries.

title: Photography
description: THE JOURNALS of two great American explora tions of the 19th cen tury provide the scripts for illustrative modern photo graphy that is surpisingly close to what the original travelers saw.

title: The Cold Truth
description: Now the snow lies deep on the countryside and there is a deceptive simplicity in the winter land scape. Most of the trees stand naked, the hilltops are open to the sky, the brooks are stilled and the drifts are like icing on the flatness of the fields. The world seems stripped to its fundamentals.

title: Barbara Beer Is Wed To Sgt. David J. McGee
description: Miss Barbara Ellen Beer and Sgt. David John McGee, U. S. A., were married last evening at the St. Regis Sheraton by Rabbi Kenneth Rivkin.

description: QuestionWhat were the principal changes in textile manufacturing and distribu tion in the last decade??

description: When Monsanto's plastic house of the future in Disney land was torn down after 10year display, neither steel balls, torches, chain saws nor jackhammers were able to help the wreckers.

title: Facts on Super Bowl Game
description: Title at stakeWorld professional football championship.

title: Sale of 50 Mirage Fighter Jets to Libya Stirs Angry Criticism of the Government in France
description: PARIS, Jan. 10The French Government came under angry attack today for having ap proved the sale of some 50 Mi rage fighter jets to Libya.

title: Author's Query
description: In connection with the world wide centennial celebration in 1970 of the birth of the re nowned psychiatrist Alfred Ad ler, I would be grateful for any letters, photographs reminis cences and other memorabilia, either on loan or for permanent use in the Alfred Adler archives.

title: R. E. Imperato Weds Joan Pugliese
description: Miss Joan Marie Pugliese, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Pugliese of the Bronx and Point Lookout, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Ralph Edward Imperato, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Imperato of Pelham Manor and Southampton, L. I.

description: CHICAGO.

title: A Leader in Steel Finds Role Costly
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10In a short time, the McLouth Steel Corporation, generally ranked as the industry leader when it comes to new technology, will report one of the indus try's poorest profit perform ances for 1969.

title: Personality:
description: To the casual investor the term chemicals brings to mind du Pont, Dow, Union Carbidemaybe even Stauf fera group, of companies whose stocks fared poorly during 1969.

title: Matich of Australia Victor In New Zealand Grand Prix
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 10 (UPI)Frank Matich of Australia took the lead from the start and was never in trou ble as he won the 101.5mile New Zealand Grand Prix in his McLaren5000 at Pukekohe to day.

title: Maddox Urges Dropping School Attendance Law
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 10  Gov. Lester G. Maddox, again involv ing himself in this city's worst school integration crisis, called today for the Georgia Legisla ture to abolish the state's com pulsory school attendance law.

title: FANS CELEBRATE IN VIEUX CARRE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 The streets belonged to the people last night, at least on Bourbon Street.

title: Fogarty
description: By Emily Cheney Neville. 182 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $3.95. (Ages 13 and Up)

title: Taste of Retailing Is Bitter
description: Merchants now sweating out the final Weeks of a troubled fiscal year that ends this month might not take very kindly to being queried on how to view the chal lengeg of the nineteenseven ties. The answer just might be caustic.

title: POLLUTION DEFIES EUROPE'S BORDERS
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. 10Ris ing European concern about air and water pollution across na tional borders found expression in Norway this week when a leading scientist declared that our freshwater fish and our forests will be destroyed if these developments continue uncontrolled.

title: Georgetown Tops Seton Hall
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 10  Georgetown University sank 25 of 30 free throws in the second half tonight and posted an 8880 victory over Seton Hall. With the score tied, 5353 with 13 minutes to play, the Hoyas outscored the Pi, rates, 92.

title: Pamela Ann Blafer Is Wed Here
description: Miss Pamela Ann Blafer, an actress, was married here last night to Andrew Rich ard Lack, assistant to the producer of Skyline Films. The ceremony was per formed at Temple EmanuEl by Rabbi Nathan A. Peril man.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ALEXANDER CALDER'S Black Widow is included in the Museum of Modern Art's current show of work by the artist for whom Dean of American Sculptors is a technically ac curate but psychologically inappropriate designa tion. With seniority and international distinction as yardsticks, Calder's deanship is indisputable, but he is difficult to imagine in an academic chair. Since the 1920's he has been a modernist who never bothered to worry about whether he was modern or not, an innovator who became one by doing what came naturally, and a phenomenon whose fusion of wit, engineering, and fantasy has been car ried on with unflagging and unquenchable high spirits. The exhibition, with the title A Salute to Alexander Calder, directed by William Lieberman and drawn entirely from the museum's collection, includes 30 sculptures and construc tions in wire and wood, stabiles, mobiles free mov ing and electrified, and drawings, prints, illus trated books and jewelry. It goes back as far as the 1920's with Calder's wellknown caricature of one of the happiest symbols of that era, Josephine Baker. The exhibition closes Feb. 15.J.C.

title: Restriction Changes Set For Junior Car Drivers
description: ALBANY, Tan. 10  A change in the restrictions for 16 and 17yearolds who hold New York junior driv ers' licenses has been an nounced by the State De partment of Motor Vehicles.

title: Beer Can Rings in Meters
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 10 (UPI) Mayor Chauncey Lang said this week that he had requested beer can manufactur ers to change the size of the cap rings on their cans. Mayor Lang said that more than 800 beer can rings, the size of a nickel, were inserted in park ing meters last month.

title: Prospect for Release of More Mafia Eavesdropping Data Called Doubtful
description: The Federal Government has an untold amount of startling transcripts of underworld con versations that it eavesdropped illegally, but it is doubtful now whether they will ever be made public.

title: Some Over 65 Can Ask A Home Tax Cut Feb. 1
description: City Finance Administrator Fioravante G. Perrotta an nounced today that home owners with small incomes who have, reached the age of 65 may apply for a 50 per cent real estate exemption by filing a simple form be tween Feb. 1 and March 15.

description: ACROSS

description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated:
