description: Major league baseball is tak ing steps to strengthen its se curity against professional gambling.

title: 11Day Paris Boat Show Is Under Way With Display of 1,300 Craft
description: PARIS, Jan. 10The Paris Metro opened a line to the sea yesterday.

title: Susan Embree, F. A. Parker Jr. Plan Wedding
description: Miss Susan Newlin Embree and Frederick Andrew Park er Jr. of New York plan to be married here next month.

title: Richard Lee: Urban Pioneer
description: When Richard C. Lee stepped down as Mayor of New Haven a few days ago, after eight terms and sixteen years in that office, a significant chapter American urban history was concluded. His was the story of one of the pioneers of urban renewal.

title: Calm Follows Monetary Storm
description: WASHINGTON  The in ternational monetary sytem according to a knowledgeable traveler recently returned from Europe, is awash in a Sea of Tranquility.

title: The British Are Corning Back
description: LONDONBritons have been in the grip of a dreary cold spell but, for the Government, it might as well be spring. For the Labor Government is reaping world ac claim for what appears to be the spectacular success of its tough economic measures. Britain is re covering and last week Roy Jen kins, the Chancellor of the Ex chequer, was in the United States telline American business men that his country had en tered a period of strength in our balance of payments such as we have not had in years.

title: TEXT OF LETTER
description: Following is the text of the letter from Mr. Schleger to the Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority seeking fare increases:

title: BULLETS DEFEAT HAWKS, 130 TO 109
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 10 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets thwarted a thirdquarter rally by Atlanta with a 12point string tonight and defeated the Hawks, 130 109, in the second game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader.

title: History Flows Along Rhode Island's Blackstone River
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I.  Scenically, the Black stone River is ordi nary. Historically, it is remarkable, for it has played a dramatic role in the nation's development, both as an influence on America's first settlers and as a source of industrial power.

title: Purchasing Men Find Indicators Are Down
description: All business indicators (ex cept price and forward com mitments of capital equip ment) used by the National Association of Purchasing Management, Inc., ended last year on the downside, ac cording to the association's business survey committee.

title: 11 Chinese to Learn Cricket in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jam 10A member of New South Wales parliament has brought a group of 11 physical train ing students from Taiwan to Sydney to teach them cricket because, he says, cricket helped make the British peo ple great.

title: REDMEN'S PAULTZ GETS 16 REBOUNDS
description: All is well with Lou Carnes ecca again. He has his car back, his back feels better and his St. John's basketball team won last night.

title: THE REPLIES
description: FRANK E. BARNETT, chairman of the the: Union Pacific Railroad Company, calls environmental problems a simple matter of survival. He thinks Govern ment will wind up doing most of the work, with private enterprise assuming and passing onthe rest as a cost of doing business.

title: College Given $200,000
description: WENHAM, Mass., Jan. 10 (AP)Gordon College has an nounced an anonymous gift of $200,000 to aid in construction of a $500,000 physical educa tion complex. The building will include a gymnasium, a swimming pool and a handball court. Construction is to begin next spring.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Sherlockian pastiches have of fered wide and understandable appeal to the writing fraternity for decadesnot only to those commonly occupied with detec tive fiction, but also to such mainstream authors and hu morists as Stephen Leacock and John Kendrick Bangs. Most of the takeoffs are short stories. Two booklength exceptions that come to mind are H. F. Heard's A Taste for Honey (1941) and Reply Paid (1942).

title: Labor Gives Way to Leisure
description: Why should life all labor be? asked Alfred Lord Ten nyson in the 19th century. Others have puzzled over the amount and qualityof man's leisure time before and since, most not so poetically but many with even more inten sity.

title: Tailored for TeenAgers, But ill It Fit?
description: CONCOCTED in, of all places, Hershey, Penn sylvania: sampled in such hip way stations as Philadelphia, Memphis, Des Moines, and Madison, Wisconsin; tasted last week by 16yearolds in Austin, Texas, and by college fresh men in San Diego, The Show, television's newest at tempt to involve the young, goes network tonight.

title: Foy's Beagle Takes Honors At Massillon Park's Show
description: MASSILLON, Ohio, Jan. 10 Ch. Kings Creek Triple Threat, the topwinning beagle of 1969, started the new year by taking best in show today at the allbreed Agathon Kennel Club fixture at the Massillon Park Civic Center, leading field of 813 dogs.

title: New Pattern Of Black And White Emerges In Nation
description: WASHINGTON  One of the bitter Ironies of the long strug gle over school desegregation is that nationwide there probably is more racial isolation in the public schools today than at the time of the 1954 Supreme Court decision, which held the dual system by law and policy to be unconstitutional.

title: Hybrid Feed Gives Cattle Room to Roam
description: KANSAS CITYAmerican affluence, manifesting itself in the form of an intense de mand for beef cattle over the last 10 years, has turned tra ditional patterns of cattle feeding topsyturvy.

title: Yale Gets Delay in N.C.A.A. Hearing on Langer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Yale has received a fiveday reprieve and will not appear be fore the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council un til Thursday to defend its use of Jack Langer, a basketball player declared ineligible by the association.

title: Miss Street Wed to Dr. Gerald Whitman
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10Miss Virginia Howell Street was married here this afternoon to Dr. Gerald Whitman in civil ceremony.

title: Janice Adele Hansen Is Fiancee Of William G. Moeller of Tufts
description: MEDFIELD, Mass., Jan. 10 Miss Janice Adele Hansen, a senior at the University of New Hampshire, plans to be married in June to William Griswold Moeller, a senior at Tufts University.

title: Little Hope for Slide Victims
description: OSLO Norway, Tan. 10 (Reuters)A rescue team with dogs battled its way through a 90mileanhour blizzard early today to the scene of an avalanche that buried seven tunnel workers in West Nor way. They reported no sign of life.

title: Science
description: Scientists from many parts of the planet earth who, two months ago, received the first specimens ever brought back from another celestial body, met last week in Houston to com pare notes on their findings.

title: All Quiet On the Kennedy Front in Edgartown
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  Main Street relapsed into hibernation this weekend after a fourday closed investigation of the most publicized automobile accident in history. Gone was the motley throng of reporters and camera men that had waited in the snow and cold outside the redbrick Dukes County Courthouse dur ing the inquest into the drown ing of Mary Jo Kopechne nearly six months ago.

title: Engagements
description: BOSNIAKHOFFMANMr. & Mr. Arthur Hoffman of East Meadow Long Island an nounce the engagement of their daughter Elyse Ruth to Michael P. Bosniak, son Mr. & Mrs. Sidney S. Bosniak of Philadel phia, Pennsylvania on Dec. 30, 1969.

title: Consumers Are Wooed In Capital
description: WASHINGTON  Hesi tantly but with ostensible conviction, the Nioxn Admin istration has moved to iden tify itself with the viable and politically potent national force known as consumer ism.

title: Burns at Helm: Time for a Turn?
description: WASHINGTON  Arthur F. Burns, a scholarly econ omist with a good political sense, will be taking the helm at the Federal Reserve Board this year when the nation's monetary policy, in chiding its technique of oper ation, has come to a fork in the road.

title: Auto Makers Predict Lean Year to Begin Fat Decade
description: DETROITAt the outset of the 1960's, Detroit's auto mobile industry confidently predicted that sometime dur ing the decade car sales would pass the 10 million a year mark.

title: CONSERVATIVE UNION SCORES RELIEF PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) The. American Conservative Union declared today that Pres ident Nixon's welfare proposals are not deserving of Republi can support in Congress be cause they do not match the party's principles.

title: Bowdoin Six Triumphs, 62
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 10 Bowdoin College remained un defeated on its home ice by beating the University of Con necticut, 62, tonight before more than 2,000 fans.

title: Debbie Meyer Triumphs In 100Meter Title Swim
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 10 (AP)Debbie Meyer, the Olym pic champion from Sacramento, Calif., defeated. Jenny Watts of Australia by a touch for the 100meter freestyle title today In the New South Wales swim ming championships.

title: An Economist Samples Nixon's Menu of Policies
description: Forty years ago, as the national economy was sliding into depression, there was great confusion about what actions the Federal Govern ment could or should take. Looking back to those grim days in his memoirs, Presi dent Hoover confessed that he did not know what he should do: No President be fore had ever believed there was a governmental respon sibility in such cases. . . Presidents steadfastly had maintained that the Federal Government was apart from such eruptions; they had al ways been left to blow them selves out.

title: Mississippi School Enrollment Is Near 80% of Goal
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 10 As it approaches the halfway point, Mississippi's latest and largest round of school deseg regation has not frightened nearly as many white students away from the public schools as white politicians had pre dicted.

title: Greece Erects Lightning Rods To Protect Her Ancient Ruins
description: ATHENS, Jan. 10Alarmed by the irreparable damage often caused by lightning to valuable ancient monuments in Greece, the Greek Archeological Service put aside its esthetic misgivings this week and set up special lightning rods to protect four historical sites, including the Athens Acropolis.

title: Montclair State Wins 13th By Beating Delaware, 6361
description: DOVER, Del., Jan. 10  Montclair State extended its winning streak to 13 games tonight by downing Delaware, 6361.

title: Computers Take Step to Maturity
description: A generation ago, there were no electronic computers. By 1960, 6,000 had been in stalled; and by today, 60,000. Midway through the 1970's, that number could double.

description: Sherlockian pastiches have of fered wide and understandable appeal to the writing fraternity for decadesnot only to those commonly occupied with detec tive fiction, but also to such mainstream authors and hu morists as Stephen Leacock and John Kendrick Bangs. Most of the takeoffs are short stories. Two booklength exceptions that come to mind are H. F. Heard's A Taste for Honey (1941) and Reply Paid (1942).

title: HOUSING IN CITY DECLINED IN 1969
description: Production of government subsidized housing in the city dropped to the third lowest point in a decade last year, ac cording to the Housing and De velopment Administration.

title: Andrew Turnbull Is Dead at 48; Biographer of Scott Fitzgerald
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 Andrew Turnbull, biographer of F. Scott Fitzgerald and Thomas Wolfe, committed sui cide today at his home here. His age was 48.

title: At Movies, Production Costs WriteOffs Climb as High as Ticket Prices
description: Motion pictures took in al most $1.1billion at the box office last year, ticket prices rose to almost twice that of the 195759 level and the new multiauditoriums, or minitheaters, attracted the interest of a broad range of moviegoers. Only a funny thing happened on the way to the bank  many of the big film producing and dis tributing companies had what are euphemistically de scribed as severe financial problems.

title: TRAVELERS HELP NEEDIEST CASES
description: Some vacationers back from spending the holiday season at resorts are remem bering to heed the appeal of the 58th annual Neediest Cases Fund of The New York Times.

title: The World
description: BEIRUT, LebanonThere Is a sense in Lebanon of inexorably approaching catacylsm. The fear is of a progression of events under which increased action by Palestinian guerrillas based on Lebanese sail would be followed by increased Israeli reprisals agairist Lebanon, resulting in drastic political repercussions in Beirut.

title: 60th Boat Show to Draw Fleet of 500
description: If this will be the 60th Na tional Boat Show opening at the Coliseum on Jan. 24 for nine days and the first show was held in 1905, what hap pened to the six missing shows? Answer: There were no boat shows held from 1942 to 1946 because of World War II, or in 1919 because of World War I.

title: For Investors, New Year Ring Is Flat
description: The bear market of 1969 is now a sad memory of yesteryear, but it has left a lingering malaise with most investors. They are in quandry over whether last year's dismal pattern will persist or whether now is the time to be planning for a turnaround.

title: Owners of Color TV Sets Challenge Welfare Ruling
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan. 10 (Ap)  Three Forsyth County residents have challenged the authority of the North Carolina Department of Social Services to cancel welfare payments for owners of color television sets.

title: Tunney Picks Frazier to Stop Ellis in Title Bout Here
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Jan. 10 (AP)Joe Frazier is the best heavyweight boxer in the world today and should easily beat Jimmy Ellis in their world title bout in Madison Square Garden Feb. 16, former heavyweight champion, Gene Tunney, said yesterday.

title: Coaches Honor Walters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Charles (Rut) Walters, who re tired as track coach at the Uni versity of Wisconsin last June, was named indoor coach of the year today by the United States Track Coaches Association. It was the first such award by the association, which will also pre sent winter and spring (out door) awards.

title: Point of View
Berio's Opera A Titanic Relic
description: THE sinking of the Titanic in 1912 has cast a long shadow in time. The latest echo of that tragedy is to be found in Luciano Berio's first fulllength opera, which will he given its world premiere by the Santa Fe Opera next summer. It is called simply Opera, not in relation to the art form but as the plural of opus, the Latin word for work. The composer regards it as a kind of synthesis of several ideas, and as a stage niece it will function on many theatrical levels.

title: SUIT AGAINST POLICE REJECTED IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) Seventeen Chicago policemen have been dismissed as defend ants in a $12million lawsuit that stemmed from a raid on the campaign headquarters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy during the 1968 Democratic Na tional Convention.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  Mr. Presi dent, this Is the first significant trade liberalization measure passed by Congress since the end of World War II.

title: CALEDONIAN RINKS SCORE IN CURLING
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 10  Two rinks representing the New York Caledonian Curl ing Club moved into the semi final round of the 35th an nual Douglas Medal bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club today. Mahopac, N. Y., and Boston entries also advanced with 10 end quarterfinal victories.

title: ProBusiness Hands Shape Regulatory Policy
description: WASHINGTON  When President Nixon was elected a little more than a year ago, one of the changes in the Government that business men generally hoped for was in its attitudes and policies toward business itself.

title: Let's Say It Right
description: The story of the Vietnam war comes in large part from military press officers, and how that story sounds often depends on what terms they use. Recent ly the United States Command indicated it did not like some of the terms being used and issued to its briefing officers a guidance directive banning cer tain terms and substituting others. The directive, titled Let's Say It Right, included the following changes:

title: lob Changes: National Sugar Refining Company Elects President and Chief Executive Officer
description: Myers Bud Cather, 52 years old, has been elected president, chief executive of ficer and a director of the National Sugar Refining Com pany, and its subsidiaries. He replaces Thomas T. Heney, who has resigned from Na tional Sugar, a subsidiary of Haven Industries, Inc.

title: Produce New Evidence of the Danger in Smoking
description: Autopsy studies of 942 men have yielded further evidence that cigarette smoking contrib utes to the development of cancer in tissues exposed to the smoke, three scientists re ported yesterday..

description: Left

title: ROCKETS SET BACK KNICKS BY 123115
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 10The New York Knicks were seeking their fourth straight triumph all on the roadas they faced the Rockets tonight at the San Diego Sports Arena. It marked the first game in which the Knicks had faced the Rockets since Alex Hannum took over the coaching duties from John Kerr on Dec. 10.

title: Wall St.: The Fun Stopped
description: A man goes into a Chinese restaurant and eats a hearty meal. Then he crumbles open the fortune cookie and ex tracts the slip of paper that is about the width of stock ticker tape. Beware of the eggdrop soup, warns the messaee.

title: New Jailhouse Combo
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 10 (AP)Prisoners at the United States penitentiary here have formed a musical combo of piano, drum, guitar and bass They call themselves The Fifth Amendment.

title: Theater Keeps Its High Rank as Glamorous Place for Losing One's Shirt
description: There are unquestionably easier ways of losing money than investing in the theater. You could, just for example, have your pocket picked. Paper money also burns, and if you get all your money out of the bank and set fire to it, this is also one of the most effective ways of los ing money known to man. But the theater isn't far off the pace.

title: The Struggle For the Middle East
description: The decade of the sixties saw the flourishing of Soviet influence and participation in the politics of the Middle East, a substitution by invi tation  not by conquest  for the traditional Western presence. In geopolitical context, this appeared to be the final realization of a Czarist dream.

title: A.M.A. DISCLOSES POLITICAL OUTLAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The nation's doctors and their allies spend about $5million during an election year on lobbying and helping to elect and reelect medicine's friends to Coneress.

title: MR. SMITH PLANS WASHINGTON STAY
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 10 It was 8 A.M., 8 degrees below zero and 300 days before the first Tuesday in November when Senator Ralph T. Smith climbed into a small plane at Meigs Field on the Chicago lakefront this week.

title: The Justices Of the United States Supreme Court 17891969
description: President William Howard Taft at his last press conference revealed that his proudest achievement was select ing six of the nine members of the Supreme Court. In 1929 Taft as Chief Justice believed that President Hoo ver would appoint extreme destroy ers of the Constitution to fill vacan cies on the Court. I am older and slower and less acute and more con fused, he wrote. However, as long as things continue as they are, and I am able to answer in my place, I must stay on the Court in order to prevent the Bolsheviki from getting control. By his standards Taft was right. Hoover appointed Charles Evans Hughes, who championed the civil rights of Negroes, Communists and pacifists; Owen Roberts, who wrote the opinion of the Court sustaining the power of the states to fix prices; and Benjamin Cardozo, whose most enduring opinion upheld the constitutionality of the Social Security Acts.

title: Petrocelli to Get Award
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) Rico Petrocelli, the AllStar shortstop of the Boston Red Sox, was named the recipient today of the seventh annual John F. Kennedy memorial trophy as the outstanding Ital ianAmerican athlete in the na tion by the Greater Boston ItaloAmerican Associates.

title: NorwegianBorn Stenerud Prefers Warmer Climate
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 Jan Stenerud, the fine Kansas City kicker, was born in Nor way and went to Montana, State University on a skijump ing scholarship. He will be kicking for the Chiefs in the Super Bowl game tomorrow against the Minnesota Vikings.

title: A 2,300YearOld Statue Of a Pharaoh Is Discovered
description: CAIRO, Jan. 10  A 2,300 yearold statue of one of the last ruling Pharaohs has been unearthed in the delta region of Egypt, about 84 miles northeast of here. Dr. Hassan Sobhy el Bakry, director general of the Department of Antiquities, went to the site to examine the statue of Kheber Ka Raa, which was found by an Egqptian expedi tion. He described it as a mas terpiece of ancient Egyptian art.

title: A Correction
description: A Chart printed in this section on Jan. 4, 1970, stated incor rectly that Syria derives an an nual revenue of $200million from her oil production. Industry sources estimate the return on Syria's national oil production at $14million a year. The Times re grets the error.

title: Clarifying Guam Doctrine
description: Whirlwind foreign tours such as Vice President Agnew's current 23day trip to eleven Asian nations are of dubious value and full of potential pitfalls, espe cially for a man with Mr. Agnew's diplomatic inexperi ence. To his credit, Mr. Agnew so far has given generally good account of himself in some difficult situations.

title: VIKINGS THRIVE ON KAPP'S FIGHT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 The Fight, as his teammates refer to it, was what won for Joe Kapp the acceptance and admiration of the Minnesota Vikings that led to a place in the Super Bowl tomorrow. He will be the quarterback of the favored team, the Vikings, against the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: South Africa Police Use Copters to Find Fieldsof Marijuana
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 10Teams of police men, aided by South African Air Force helicopters, have seized and destroyed tons of marijuana valued at $70million in a remote area of the Dra kensberg Mountains in Natal.

title: NAY AR WINS OPENER IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 10 Anil Nayar, national champion and former United States Inter collegiate titleholder from Har vard, was extended to 158, 1415, 157, 157 in defeating Bill Wilson, of the home club, as Nayar opened his defense of the Merion Cricket Club invita tion squash racquets tourna ment for the William F. White Memorial Cup today.

title: 2 U.A.R. BOMBERS REPORTED DOWNED
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 10  Israel said that her missiles destroyed two Egyptian fighterbombers today duringg an Egyptian raid against Israeli military positions in the Sinai Peninsula, on the eastern coast of the Gulf of Suez.

title: EARLY ROCK SUNG BY FATS DOMINO
description: Fats Domino recreated some of his throaty bestsellers of the early years of rock n roll at the Fillmore East this week end. He appeared Friday and Saturday on a bill with the Ike & Tina Turner Revue, a soul group, and Mongo Santamaria, the percussionist, and his band.

title: Southwest Seeks More Jobs and Water
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Eco nomic experts believe that industrial growth in the Southwest in the 1970's de pends on two things  un deremployed manpower, of which it has an abundance, and water, of which there is a shortage.

title: Movie Mailbag Brim Back M. Verdoux ?
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Princeton, on 5 Goals in 2d, Ties Brown in Hockey, 66
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10 IA fivegoal surge in the second period today gave Princeton 53 lead over Brown's hockey team, but the Tigers just man aged to get a 66 tie.

title: The World
description: An aura of drama has begun to swirl up around the evolving triangular relationship of the United States, the Soviet Union and the People's Republic of China.

title: Executives' Lives Get Rural Style
description: One day, perhaps, Robert W. Fox will be assigned to Union Carbide Corporation's New York City office. But for the present he makes his headquarters in the Sterling Forest compound at Tux edo, N. Y., where the com pany maintains a nuclear re actor and a research di vision.

title: COUNCILMAN SEEKS BAN ON COPTER PADS
description: Helicopter landing pads would be banned from all of New York City except the shoreline under legislation filed yesterday by a newly seated Councilman at Large, Robert I. Postel, a Democrat from Manhattan.

title: BRITAIN PRESSES ENTRY IN MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 10George Thomson, the Minister who will direct Britain's third at tempt to enter the European Common Market, emphasized to five of the members today his country's economic and political credentials for mem bership.

title: Hunchback Methuselah from the Renaissance
description: Although the hero of Bo marzo is some 450 years old, the story he offers us is one, relatively speaking, of his youth, in the Renaissance as the hunchbacked Prince Pier Francesco Orsini, Duke of Bo marzo, who, having sustained a long, heroic and sometimes successful battle against impo tence through two marriages, fought without distinction in the battle of Lepanto. The tone of the novel recalls Italo Svevo's Confessions of Zeno. MujicaLainez shares Svevo's candidly endearing irony, and like Zeno, Bomarzo is able to bring to bear on his corn plexed Renaissance life the lessons of psychoanalysis that he has learnt, centuries later, in Buenos Aires.

title: Foreigners Probing For U.S. Markets
Lisa McIlvaine Is Wed To Norris Strawbridge
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 10  Miss Elise Pettit Mc Ilvaine was married here this afternoon to Ens. Norris Strawbridge, U.S.N.R. The bride known as Lisa, is de scended from the Right Rev. Charles Pettit Mcllvaine, Epis copal Bishop of Ohio and founder of Kenyon College. The bridegroom is descend ed from Justus Strawbridge, a founder of Philadelphia's Strawbridge & Clothier de partment store.

title: A Transit Man Dissects the Subways
description: IN the 1970's, metropolitanarea resi dents can expect massive new ad ditions to the New York subway system. These new lines, adding up to 40 route milesan expansion of about 20 per centwill be airconditioned and, where technology permits, fully auto mated.

title: Author's Query
description: I am currently writing a book dealing with the problems and experiences of Mayors, past and present, of cities and towns throughout the world. I would appreciate receiving any anecdotes, humorous or offbeat experiences that have occurred to Mayors while in office in any community.

title: 1,700 GRAVEDIGGERS MAY STRIKE TONIGHT
description: A state mediation spokesman said yesterday that no progress had been made to avert a strike by 1,700 gravediggers set to begin after midnight tonight at 40 nonsectarian, Roman Catholic and Jewish cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

title: Marriages
description: FOGELKERNMrs. Sydelle Stroller Kern and Dr. Bernaro J. Fogel announce their marriage on January 8, 1970 In San Fran cisco.

title: Buddhist Sect in Japan Accused Of Effort to Suppress Criticism
description: TOKYO, Jan. 10  The Ko meito, the militant Buddhist po litical party that won 47 seats in the Dec. 27 election for the House of Representatives is em broiled in a controversy regard ing freedom of speech.

title: J. J. Miner Fiance Of Miss Mockridge
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 10 Miss Nancy Gleason Mock ridge and Joseph James Miner, students at the Uni versity of Connecticut, plan to be married Jan. 24 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

title: 116 Seized in Paris Housing Protest
description: PARIS, Jan. 10A protest group including the playwrights Jean Genet and Marguerite Du ras occupied the headquarters of the French employers organi zation today to demonstrate against living condition of for eign workers. All of the 116 persons involved were arrested.

title: 40 Seek Alligator Permits
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 10 (AP) More than 40 persons rushed to beat a Jan. 1 deadline to ap ply for a permit to keep alli gators, the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department reports. The applications cover about 600 alligators.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Jan. 18  Pompton Valley Sports Car Club rally; start at Bremen Auto, Route 23, Wayne,N.J. Registration: 12:30 P.M., first car off 1 P.M. Information:Jackie MacDonnell, phone (201) 6976474.

title: A Gusher of Trouble in Oil Fields
Vikings Coach Provides Proof Success Has No Boundaries
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 Bud Grant of the Minnesota Vikings is a successful football coach, according to Jim Finks, the Minnesota general manager who hired him, because he I knows how to win.

title: New York
description: ALBANY  Although the vot ers will decide in November whether Nelson A. Rockefeller will be in any position to guide the state further into the pres ent decade, the Governor seemed pretty sure of himself last week.

title: Bulk Win in Overtime
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) Chet Walker scored 9 consecu tive points in a torrid fivemin ute overtime period tonight to give the Chicago Bulls a 116 112 victory over the Los Ange les Lakers in a National Basket ball Association game.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: The wholesale buyer led a busy life last year and it looks like it's going to be even busier this year. He can hold inflation responsi ble for the extra trips to market  consumers have balked at the higher prices, and their pace of buying was slowed as a consequence. Stores had little choice but to try harder to put in lines of merchandise that fit into their customers' budgets.

title: Lag Burns Toabacco Men
description: The cigarette industry is preparing steppedup market ing and advertising strategies to help overcome last year's drop in sales, its first since 1964, when the Surgeon Gen eral reported a link between cigarette smoking and cancer and other illnesses.

title: Participatory Esthetics
description: THE new Spaces ex hibition, which Jen nifer Licht has organ ized at the Museum of Modern Art, places the vis itor to the museum in an un familiar situation. At least the situation is unfamiliar so far as museumgoing is con cerned, though the visitor to the exhibition will already have gleaned something of its basic strategy it he has had any experience of the new styles of theater and dance, or the old happenings, or, for that matter, group therapy, discotheques, graduate semi nars, political demonstra tions, cooking classes, orgies, cocktail parties, holy com munion, public baths, or the family dinner table. He must, in other words, be prepared to become a participant in an event which is social or com munal character if he is to experience anything of its nature substance.

title: Report From
description: SANTIAGO, Chile. THE Argentinian sociologist who met me at the airport in San tiago knew I was arriving from Brazil, where people were loath to talk politics because of the dictator ship. No problems like that in Chile, he said. The whole country is engaged in a kind of political strip tease. It was Octoberspring below the equator  and the presidential candidates for next September's elections had already sprouted, as varied as the wild flowers blooming everywhere. To many, it was all politics as usualthe Right and the Left engaging in fancy footwork be fore taking their traditional stances behind one candidatebut to others different developments seemed in the offing. It was altogether possible that with new adherents the Left might win this year's elections and begin the peaceful implementation of So cialism in Chile. the equator  and the presidential candidates for next September's elections had already sprouted, as varied as the wild flowers blooming everywhere. To many, it was all politics as usualthe Right and the Left engaging in fancy footwork be fore taking their traditional stances behind one candidatebut to others different developments seemed in the offing. It was altogether possible that with new adherents the Left might win this year's elections and begin the peaceful implementation of So cialism in Chile.

title: New Tourist Trails On the Arizona Strip
description: COLORADO CITY, Ariz.  Highway builders have invaded this state's al most deserted northwest corner, an area known as the Arizona Strip. Giant earthmovers are slicing a multilaned path for Interstate 15 through the Virgin River Gorge, on the northwest extremity of the Strip, and Arizona State Route 389 and Utah State Route 59 have been hard surfaced, thus giving tourists a smooth new link from the Grand Canyon to 115 and thence to Las Vegas.

title: ARMY TURNS BACK COLGATE, 75 TO 58
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 10  Army's defenseminded ca dets, held to a 2point lead at halftime by Colgate, broke the game open in the early min utes of the second half and went on to a 7558 basketball victory in the field house to night.

title: JETS SET UP SHOP ON MEMORY LANE
description: Earl Morrall...prestige... John Unitas...parity...Bubba Smith...upset...John Mackey ...$15,000.

title: Satellite Zeroes In On Weather
description: An advanced weather satellite capable of provid ing twicethecoverage of the world's weather of previous systems is scheduled, for launching Thursday.

title: Charles Olson, Poet and Leader Of Black Mountain Group, Dies
description: Charles Olson, the poet, died yesterday after a short illness at New York Hospital. He was 59 years old.

title: Mimi Kerr to Be Wed in Spring
description: FLOURTOWN, Pa., Jan. 10Mrs. S. Logan Kerr has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mar garet Royal Kerr, to Richard W. Baker 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Baker Jr. of Prince ton. N. J.

title: New Drive in Albania
description: VIENNA, Jan. 10The pro Peking Albanian Government opened a drive of coercive mass action in agriculture and indus try this week that recalls the Great Leap Forward campaign in China and the canecutters brigades of Cuba.

title: . . . And Two Oldtimers Continue to Thrive
description: NOW that jazz is no longer the music of the young, the pend ulum seems to have swung the other way. We find, for instance, that one of the most valuable expositions of jazz piano styles recorded last year was the work of 86 yearold Eubie Blake, that one of the most exciting jazz solos on a record released during the year was played by Joe Venuti, a violinist who admits that he is around 70 (75 seems a likely figure), and that the best big jazz band in the world is led by a man who turned 70 last May, Duke Ellington.

title: Article 3  No Title
Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Angus Twombly to Wed Deborah Mary Robb
description: LOUDONVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 10Miss Deborah Mary Robb, a junior at Syracuse Univer sity, and Angus Holbrook Twombly, a senior there, plan to be married this summer.

title: Marymount Mothers' Lunch
description: The Mothers Club of Mary mount College in Tarrytown, N.Y. has arranged its an nual winter luncheon and fashion show for Jan. 22 in the WaldorfAstoria's Empire Room. Tickets at $10 each may be reserved from Mrs. Joseph F. Czechlewski of 445 East 14th Street in New York or from the college.

title: NET HURLER CITED AS PLAYER OF YEAR
description: Tom Seaver will collect an other award on Sunday, Feb. 1, at the annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Base ball Writers Association of America, when he will receive the Sid Mercer Award as the Player of the Year for 1969.

title: Letters: When the Planes Don't Fly
description: TO THE EDITOR: ON Christmas evening, a snow. storm descended on Washington, D. C., and I had occasion to see several National Airlines planes Prom cities in the Southeast, and en route to New York, forced to terminate their flights in Washington.

title: Dance
description: EVENTS creep up on one like stealthy spies in the night. I will never forget the feeling of surprise I experienced on my 21st birthday, and I will never forget what it felt like to be 40. Now a new mile stone has dropped resound ingly in my lifeI have been writing dance criticism for 20 years. It not only seems a lifetime, it now is a life time.

title: For Research, Decade of the Payoff
description: THERE was a period shortly after World War II when doing research and development in industry was considered fashionable.

title: Gifts for St. Augustine
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla.  The latest addition to this 404yearold city's restoration program is the Sanchez House on St. George Street, or Calle Real. The house was reconstructed by the Independent Life Insurance Company of Jacksonville at a cost of $223,000.

title: U.S. STUDY DOUBTS HARM OF STRIKES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz cited new evidence today to support his theory that some major strikes do far less widespread economic harm than generally feared.

title: President Is Reported Leaning to a New Method of Helping the States and Cities Fight Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan., 10  President Nixon, according to informed sources, has about made up his mind to ask Con gress to change the method by which the Federal Government helps states and cities pay for waste treatment works to con trol water pollution.

title: The Friendly Chateaus Along La Route Jacques Coeur
description: BOURGES, FranceDuring the Ren aissance, the wealthy of France de veloped country life to a splendor that had never been known before. The sternlooking medieval chateaux forts, or fortified castles, went out of style when gunpowder made their fortifications obso lete; the aristocracy then started to build chateaux de plaisance, huge country houses designed for lavish living.

title: DecisionMakers Seek More Scope
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  As our business organization and social systems have grown, they have become too com plex for human judgment and intuition. Management scien tists and economists have tried to analyze the systems to establish rules for making more effective decisions. So far, these efforts have been embryonic.

title: Zoning Change Approved For West Village Coop
description: A rezoning change approved by the Board of Estimate has eliminated the last barrier to erection of the controversial West Village cooperative walk up housing project. The 457 units are to be constructed on small sites on the west side of Washington Street between Bank and Morton Strets in trucking and warehouse dis trict.

title: Coal Power Gets Assist From Youth
description: The coal industry ended the Sixties in a cheering mood as it watched nuclear plant orders fall far behind the previous two years. It also grew optimistic as con servationists began probing into possible thermal effects of nuclear plants and youth groups started to single out nuclear power as a target akin to napalm.

title: Religion
description: Several months ago a re porter asked Bernard Cardi nal Alfrink, the Roman Cath olic Primate of the Nether lands, whether priests would eventually have the choice of marrying or not. With a ?? smile he replied, They already do.

title: Madeleine Clark Hillman Is Affianced
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mc Leod Hillman have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Made leine Clark Hillman, to Jeff rey Croner Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Earl Thompson. Both fami lies live here.

title: Thai Police and Rebels Clash in Holiday Verse
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 10 (Reuters)Thai police and Communist guerrillas have exchanged New Year's greetings in verse, declaring their mutual desire to de stroy each other.

title: Article 6  No Title
Land Purchased In Puerto Rico
description: The purchase of about 325 acres of land from the Aguirre Company at Lugo Vina and Aguirre West on the south ern coast of Puerto Rico has been announced by the Com monwealth of Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority.

title: U.S. Presses a Landmark Case in Pasadena, Seeking to Prove That the City Has Segregated Schools
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10In a bright new courtroom before a large crowd, a young Justice Department lawyer started out this week to try to prove that segregation is rampant in the public schools of one of the na tion's picturebook cities.

title: '70 Could Be the Year Milton Friedman Wins a War
description: WASHINGTON  The year 1970 is shaping up as one in which Milton Friedman may lose a battle and win a war.

title: Young Drug Addicts
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 10 (AP)The State Mental Health Division reports that 12 Oregon residents under the age of 14 sought help to break the drug habit during a threemonth peal riod in 1969. One 9yearold was listed among the 490 per sons asking aid.

title: Martha S. Wood Prospective Bride
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 Federal Judge Harold Ken neth Wood of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Wood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Smiht Wood, to David Cartwright Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs, Sturgis S. Wilson of Sum mit, N.J.

title: MISS GORDON WINS IN HUNTER CLASS
description: READINGTON, N. J., Jan. 10 Linda Gordon of Madison, N. J., won her second Medal Class of the season and rode Changing Tide to the novice hunter cham pionship today at the Four Sea sons Farm horse show.

title: Mary Ann Rosenfeld Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Mary Ann Rosenfeld, assistant vice president of Marcel Dekker, Inc., pub lishers in science and tech nology, was married here last night to Dr. Peter Ben jamin Liebert, an attending obstetrician and gynecologist at the Albert Einstein Col lege of Medicine. The cere mony was performed at the St. RegisSheraton Hotel by Rabbi Ronald Sobel.

title: West German Bobsledders Win European 4Man Title
description: CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 10 (AP)The West Ger man crew, piloted by 27year old Wolfgang Zimmerer, placed first tonight in the European fourman bobsledding cham pionship.

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS BAN ON G.I. PUBLICATION
description: CLINTON, N. C., Jan. 10 (AP) A Federal judge has ruled that a military base commander has the right to restrict dis tribution of publications that he believes would undermine the morale of his men.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Elections in Japan

title: Mexican Contrasts Fade in Veracruz
description: TAMPICO, MexicoMexico's insist ent anachronisms, those abrupt clashes of past and present that have led generations of travelers to call it a country of contrasts, are almost forgotten in the northern portion of the state of Veracruz. Here, the oil town of Poza Rica is new and the fes tival town of Papantla is old, and, if their chronological difference narrows, it does so unobtrusively in the small ports of Tuxpan and Tecolutla. There, a few modern hotels and many more archaic fishing boats comfortably share the fin est beaches on Mexico's Gulf Coast.

title: 9 Major Road Projects Going Onin Westchester
description: Concrete totem poles sprouting through the snow around the old Hawthorne Circle are an augury of a new $25.7million interchange for the Taconic, Saw Mill River and Sprain Brook State Parkways.

title: DEMOCRATS FOUND TO FAVOR PULLOUT
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10  The Gallup Poll has found that Democrats tend to favor withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam immediately o by the end of the year, while most Republicans favor with drawal only when the South Vietnamese are able to handle the war themselves.

title: Youth Corps Plans To Help Dropouts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) The Labor Department has an nounced a major shift in the Neighborhood Youth Corps pro gram, shifting emphasis to get ting dropouts back into school and training those who do not return.

title: Slower Growth in Profits Predicted
Real Battle in '70
description: As 1970 begins, the United States economy is in uncer tain and precarious condition, and economists' views of the outlook for the year ahead run the gamut from explosive boom to serious recession.

title: Congressman Says U.S. Mideast Policy Is Appeasing Arabs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Representative Jonathan B. Bingham of the Bronx accused the Nixon Administration today of appeasing the Arabs, of heading toward betrayal of Is rael, and of unwisely trying to play Mr. Fixit in the Middle Eastern conflict.

title: FAVORITES ADVANCE IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: All the favorites advanced yesterday in quarterfinal matches of the City. Athletic Club's Class B invitation squash racquets tournament.

title: Miss Bette Ann Bierwirth Fiancee of Frederick Callahan
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Jan. 10 Mr. and Mrs. G. Granger Bierwirth of Westfield and of Lake Arcadia, West Milford, have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Bette Ann Bierwirth, to Fred erick Reck Callahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Cal han of Westfield

title: Beame Sees Transit Fare Rise Costing Families One to Two Weeks' Net Pay
description: The transitfare increase will cost the average New York family of four between one and two weeks of its annual take home pay, Controller Abraham D. Beanie estimated yesterday.

title: Thieu Gets Tougher With Everyone
description: SAIGONIt was not so much what President Nguyen Van Thieu said at his press confer ence last week as the way he said it that left the 200 news men in his audience with the distinct impression that he had adopted a new, hard line on everything from American troop withdrawals to the motives of his political opposition.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: The Mastodons

title: Margaret Stack Plans Marriage To P.K. Noonan
description: Miss Margaret Mary Stack, a credit analyst with the Bankers Trust Company, and Peter Kissell Noonan, a lend ing officer trainee at the bank, are planning to be married in the spring.

title: Bent of Dartmouth Leads In Skiing at Big Bromley
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 10 (AP)Chuck Bent of Dart mouth won one race and placed fifth in the second to take the lead today in the 23d annual Louise Orvis Derby at Big Bromley.

title: Soviet Skater Sets Mark
description: ALMA ATA, U.S.S.R., Jan. 10 (AP)Ludmilla Fechina of Moscow set a world record of 1 minute 29.09 seconds today in the women's 1,000meter speed skating event at a na tional championship here, ac cording to Tass, the Soviet press agency. The agency said she shaved 44 hundredths of second off the mark set yes terday by Lyudmila Titova.

title: LAW FIRMS HERE CHANGING STYLES
description: New York City's largest law firms were reported yesterday to be undergoing increasing democratization, with wider openings for Jews and Negroes and encouragement for practice among the Door.

title: Well, If Not DDT, Then What?
description: BELTSVILLE, Md. THE Department of Agriculture's Research Centera think tank for farmerssits on a wooded, 10,738acre site in the Washington suburb of Beltsville. It consists of cluster of 70 laboratories, 40 green houses, 700 barns, poultry houses and other buildings, all connected by winding roads which have been pic turesquely named after the disciplines practiced at the facilities to which they lead. Thus, driving through the Beltsville grounds, you encounter Research Road, Entomology Road, Poultry Road, S.C.S. (for Soil Con servation Service) Road, even Pesti cide Road. I'd just as soon have them rename that one, one Agricul ture employe commented to me re cently while we were on our way to see Dr. Edward F. Knipling. (Knipling, director of entomology research for the Agricultural Re search Service, can be classified as the chief thinker at the Beltsville think tank.)

title: The Amazing Maze
description: By Harry Hartwick. Illustrated by Reynold Ruffins and Simms Taback. 39 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton & Co. $4.95. (Ages 7 to 11)

title: Architecture: Seen Any Good Buildings Lately?
description: END  OF  THE  DECADE appraisals are already out of date, and we have no intention of of fering another. But we have been writing for this paper for a coincidental 11 years, with the job of architecture critic since 1964 (if we may be permitted one parochial backward glance, the job of staff architecture critic was a first for The New York Times among American newspapers), and what has happenea to architecture in that period is explosive and shattering.

title: S.L. Root Marries Christina V. Mills
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 10  Miss Christina Van Or den Mills, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Wickham Mills Jr. of Middletown and New Marlborough, Mass., was married this afternoon to Stephen Lewis Root, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Harris Root of Barnesboro, Pa.

title: ST. BONAVENTURE ROUTS KENT STATE
description: KENT, Ohio, Jan. 10 (UPI) Bob Lanier scored 42 points tonight in sparking unbeaten St. Bonaventure to a 9465 vic tory over Kent State and its 10th victory.

title: TEXAS MEXICANS WIN NEW RIGHTS
description: CRYSTAL CITY, Tex., Jan. 10The struggle in Texas by MexicanAmericans to win full political and social rights may have had its most significant development this week since 1963, when the brown power movement began.

title: Mrs. Lotte Witmer Married Here
description: Mrs. Lotte Rex Witmer of Newport, R. I., and John Staf ford Edwards of New York were married here yesterday afternoon in the Unitarian Church of All Souls by the Rev. Di. Walter Donald Krine.

title: SHIP SAID TO PICK ON OLD L.I. BRIDGE
description: ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., Jan. 10  The Atlantic Beach Bridge, ap unassuming little structure that crosses Reynolds Channel between here and Lawrence, has been the target of a large oil barge for the last 21 months, according to bridge officials.

title: SaltWater Engine Invented
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 10 (UPI)  Prof. Martin Sussman of Tufts University has invented a turbine engine fueled by salt water. The next step is to find a use for it.

title: GROUP HERE URGES A NEW PALESTINE
description: American organizations that favo support for an independ ent state of Palestine in the west bank area of Jordan, an area now occupied by Israel, held a closed meeting here yes terday to plan political strategy for a 10year campaign toward their goal.

title: Rattle Data Won't Cite Distances From Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10 (Reuters)United States war communiques no longer give the distances of battles from Saigon because the United States command is trying to eliminate the overemphasis on their closeness to the capital, a United States spokesman said today.

title: Commodity Year: Good (to Brokers)
description: Commodity brokers, if not all of their customers, can wear Cheshirecat smiles as 1970 begins. In the wonder land of commodity futures trading the year just ended brought record volume.

title: Tennis' Suicide Stride
description: The comparisons tennis experts make between their sport and golf have the markings of a selfdestruct cartridge in Mission Impos sible.

title: MANHATTAN TOPS HOFSTRA BY 5750
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 10 Clutch shooting by Ron Man ning in the final three minutes led Manhattan to a 5750 vic tory over Hofstra tonight.

title: FREDERICK STREET TAKES TUSCARORA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 (AP)Frederick Street won the $27,450 Tuscarora Handicap at Liberty Bell Race Track today by 2 lengths under Chuck Baltasar, who flew in from Miami for the ride.

title: Article 4  No Title
Industrialists Get Word: Environment
description: IN California, three major power plant projects are stymied by pub lic objections to their prospective smog emissions.

title: Helen R. Kirkpatrick, Designer, Is Bride of Robert Moorhead
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 10 Miss Helen Rudisill Kirkpatrick and Robert George Chad bourne Moorhead were mar ried here this evening in Watts Chapel of the Presby terian Union Theological Seminary by Dr. Ben R. Lacy Jr., president emeritus.

title: Point of View
description: Hardly a day passes with out a prominent businessman making a speech about the importance of business lead ership in solving social probe lems, or without the an nouncement of some compa ny's new investment in a ghetto facility.

title: Hope for the Cities:
description: There is a hint of hope on the horizon for the nation's cities, sunk as they are in the night of rising costs and sta tionary revenues, the flight of the middle class to the suburbs and the inflationfed demands of the needy.

title: Chemistry Joined In Pollution War
description: Economic forecasts indicate that the coming decade will be a fairly vigorous period for United States industry, with growth opportunities in the offing. Speculation has it that by the end of this year the ra of the trilliondollara year economy will be ushered in.

title: El Comandante Pays $52,317 to Poolwinner
description: SAN. JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 10 (AP)Avelino Alva rez Vega received $52,317 to day, the highest amount ever paid to a poolwinner at the El Comandante race track. He picked six winners yester day.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayFour Seasons Farm, Hillcrest Road, Readington, N.J. Novice, limit, open and amateur owner hunters, limit and open jumpers, pleasure horses. 8:30 A. M.

title: Line Sets Its Course on Time Charters
description: The average large shipowner traditionally is happiest when half of his fleet is on profitable time charters and the other half free to take advantage of the spotcharter market.

title: Coins
description: THE new Philadelphia Mint, the world's larg est and most modern, is producing coins at the rate of 8million per day, it has been announced by Eugene T. Rossides, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury. Breakingin of the $18mil lion assay facility, which fronts on Independence Hall, will continue through the cal endar year 1970. Then the Mint is expected to be operat ing in two shifts on a full fivedayaweek schedule. On the basis of current produc tion, the plant's output will likely reach 16million or more coins per day.

title: New Company Set
description: The Rohm & Haas Com pany, manufacturer of chem icals, plastics and health products, and the Battelle Development Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, announced that they have formed a new company, Micromedic Sys tems, Inc., which will make a new generation of micro analytical instruments for medical diagnostic purposes.

title: ORR ADDS 3 POINTS TO SCORING LEAD
description: TORONTO, Jan. 10 (UPI)A goal by Dave Keon at 3:12 of the third period proved decisive, tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Boston Bruins, 43, in a National Hockey League game.

title: The Nation
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss.A blast of icy air swept across the Mis sissippi Delta early last week, dropping temperatures to the lowest level in years. But Forrest County school superintendent Milton Evans was not at all upset by the cold wave. He even hoped that it would snow; if it did, then maybe he could delay the opening of schools for the second semester and thereby forestall a little longer the demise of seg regation in this citadel of white supremacy.

title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow 150 Years Later
description: IRVINGTONONHUDSON, N. Y.  It was just 150 years ago that Rip Van Winkle woke up from his 20yearlong sleep and Ichabod Crane was mowed down by a pumpkin that he understand ably mistook for the legendary head of the Headless Horseman of Sleepy Hollow. To be more accurate, it was 150 years ago that the book in which Washington Irving reported these events, The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon, Gent., was first pub lished. Overnight, the book made Irving, as well as Rip and Ichabod, international literary celebrities. as well as Rip and Ichabod, international literary celebrities.

title: MOTHER, 3 CHILDREN DEAD IN JERSEY FIRE
description: PARSIPPANY, N. J., Jan. 10 A mother and her three chil dren died tonight in a fire that swept their $40,000 home when a dry Christmas tree burst into flames, the police said.

title: Headliners
description: Two and a half years ago, the odds that Connecticut's Thomas J. Dodd would run for reelection to the Senate when his term was up were almost prohibitive. He had just been censured by his Senate colleagues for diverting funds raised at political testimonial dinners to his personal use, and the Department of Justice was investigating him for possible income tax violations. But last month, Attorney General John N. Mitchell called off the investigation. So last week Senator Dodd stepped before microphones Hartford and declared that he was seeking renomination as the Democratic candidate this fall. I've been vindi cated, he said. I didn't break any laws. What did I do? But renomination may not be easy. A half a dozen Demo crats have already publicly declared themselves in the or about to.

title: French Court Rules Hovercraft Does Not Need a Harbor Pilot
description: PARIS, Jan. 10A French civil court has ruled that hovercraft is not a floating mo tor vessel and hence, is not subject to piloting fees.

title: New Mental Health Centers. Bring Psychiatry Close to Home
description: PHILADELPHIAA short, plump community worker ex cused herself from a staff meeting in a church office here the other day and walked over to a large wooden desk to make a telephone call.

title: For More Output
description: Despite the Federal Gov ernment's sincere effort to control inflation, there are some uncomfortable doubts about the overall kit of med icine now being prescribed for, the economy. Is it pos sible that some of the pre scriptionp to cure today's in flation are as feeble and out ofplace as the formulas of 1929?

title: After Vietnam, What? Industry Has Optimistic View
description: If the longest war in the history of the United States, the war that has helped po larize the nation into two camps and radicalize the young people, came to an end tomorrow, the impact on industry and business with little or no direct connection with the war effort would be minimal.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: THE first cooperative apartments in the city to be financed under a Federal belowmarket interestrate program will start to rise this spring in the West Side Urban Renewal Area.

title: Recordings
description: WHEN grizzled record collectors con verse, the name dropping byplay can get a trifle esoteric, even when they go no further back in history than the long play era. If you don't own, or at least know about, say, a Roland Hayes recital on A 440 Records, or Pagliughi's Lucia on Cetra, or Cher kassy's Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2 on Concert Hall, then you at least had better be able to discuss the Flying Dutchman highlights by Astrid Varnay and Paul Schoeffler on Remington. Lacking any specific infor mation, you might try spar ring for time by dropping names of labels that long ago disappeared under the long playing waves. Zodiac, per haps, or Rachmaninoff. Or, make up a label and contend that its products were the only real records ever made.

title: Guatemalan Electrical Plant
description: GUATEMALA CITY, Jan. 10 Guatemala opened its largest hydroelectric plant this week, increasing the country's output of electricity by almost 80 per cent. President Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro activated the first 20,000kilowatt unit of the plant, 30 miles south of here.

title: Law
description: On June 4, 1969, a Federal Court in the District of Colum bia declared invalid under the Constitution a statute embody ing a loyalty oath that had been sworn to by millions of Federal employes. The statute requires employes to swear that they did not advocate the overthrow of our constitutional form of gov ernrpent or belonged knowingly to organizations that advocate overthrow. Mrs. Roma Stewart, a school teacher, had refused to subscribe to the oath on the ground that it was contrary to her obligation as a citizen and objectionable as a matter of con science.

title: Washington: Deceptive Calm Before A Decisive New Year
description: WASHINGTON  It looked like a sleepy little village, hiber nating, perhaps, with the Presi dent and the Congress away and all the civil servants still re cuperating from holiday. When they went to lunch here they were just leaving breakfast out in San Clemente, and with the heart of the White House out of touch so much it was almost out of mind. But it was a decep tive calm; the momentous months of the Nixon Administration are at hand.

title: Bridge
description: COME players like to make an im pression by playing with light ning speed. But they do not realize that the impression they give may be a bad one: a good player knows that obvious plays made instantane ously often turn out to be wrong, and a short pause for reflection never does any harm.

title: Murder of a Miner May Bring Reforms
description: CLARKSVILLE, Pa.  Two weeks before he was killed by five 38 caliber bullets, fired at short range in the dark of night in his bedroom here by a gun man who also methodically mur dered his wife and daughter, Joseph A. Yablonski wrote, I shall die an honest man. He had finally rejected the strange, sycophantic mystique of the union to which he had devoted his life. It was a very late but, many believe, a genuine and im portant reformation.

title: Opposition Party in South Korea Is Torn by Factional Struggles
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 10 Intense factional strife is under way in the opposition New Democratic party of South Korea as a result of the in tended resignation of the ailing party president, Dr. Yu Chin Oh.

title: IRWIN CARDS 203, LEADS BY STROKE
LENOIR CHAMBERS, VIRGINIA EDITOR
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 10 (AP) Lenoir Chambers, the Pulitzer Prizewinning retired editor of The VirginianPilot and author of a biography of Stonewall Jackson, died today of a stroke he suffered at his home Thurs day. He was 78 years old.

title: Raska Wins Ski Jumping
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 10 (UPI)Jiri Raska, the Czech skijumping star, won a contest at Plavy, Northern Bohemia, today with leaps of 79 and 76.5 meters and received a total 212.9 points. Second place went to Bernd Eckstein of East Ger many, with 215.7 points, and jump of 78.5 and 77.5 meters.

title: Williams College Accepts Women Degree Candidates
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 10Williams College, a men's liberal arts college since 1793, has accepted women as its first coeducatiodal degree can didates.

title: 10Year Summary of Financial Events
description: Following are some of the news highlights of a decade of changess

title: GROUP OF ISLANDS
description: Jigsaw of a county. The green sea has made a shire But narrowly. Nowhere is the seabed Much more than an arm's length away. Danger is compressed Into a few feet of ocean And the navigator's skill Must be sharper than his funny stories. Through mild winters and tart summers Earth and water keep in close touch. A dog barks at a shag That holds its breast as high As an Egyptian cat. A gob of foam hops into the boat. People intermarry. After a traumatic voyage You see the same faces. And the wind at its worst Pierces everybody and strings them together. Just beyond the last reef, Where puffins can be spotted in lucky weather, Down go the rocks without trace, down, Too deep now to be called submerged, Into a darkness where no comparisons are possible Miles below the fields That raise flowers like tissue paper And gorse like Hong, PATRICIA BEER

title: Aimoni Hits 213, 210 Feet To Lead in Ski Jumping
description: FELDKIRCHEN, Austria, Jan. 10 (UPI)Giacomo Aimoni of Italy won the first event of the CarinthiaSlovenia international ski jump today.

title: An Encounter With Winter . . . A Beginning
description: A WINTER'S walk is just a beginning. There's more to buds, jays and ice crystals than science sup poses. The current ecologomania seems to ex plain all, but the final analysis leaves a residue that keeps us panting. Somehow it's not new technology but a sense of wonder that inspires us.

title: Norwich Sinks Bates, 8372
description: NORTHFIELD, Vt., Jan. 10 (AP)  Rick Weeks scored 34 points and set up eight field goals with neat passing today as Norwich led all the way in an 8372 basketball victory ever Bates.

title: The Heat Is on Lenny the Cool
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10In tomorrow's Super Bowl game, Len Dawson will be playing in the shadow of a doubt.

title: Frederick Friebele Dupree Jr. To Wed Sunny Acuff Seiler
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 10Judge Robert Eld ridge Seiler of the Supreme Court of Missouri and Mrs. Seiler have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sunny Acuff Seiler of Cambridge, Mass., to Frederick Friebele Dupree Jr., of Cambridge and Northeast Harbor, Me. He is the son of Mrs. Dupree of Knoxville, Tenn., and the late Dr. Du pree, a psychiatrist.

title: HIJACKED AIRLINER FLIES BACK TO PARIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 10 The Boeing airliner that was hijacked yesterday flew back to Paris today.

title: A New Swiss Peak in Alpine Dining
description: MURREN, SwitzerlandWith the opening of a revolving restaurant on top of 9,650foothigh Schilt horn Peak above this tranquil, automobilefree resort, Alpwatching has entered a lazy new era in Switzerland. Spectators no longer need to leave their tables to enjoy the sights; here, once every 60 minutes, the entire circular pan orama of Jungfrau, glaciers, sky and gray naked rock passes in front of them. Spectators no longer need to leave their tables to enjoy the sights; here, once every 60 minutes, the entire circular pan orama of Jungfrau, glaciers, sky and gray naked rock passes in front of them.

title: The Drive on Rubella
description: Last Wednesday in his State of the State Message, Governor Rockefeller announced that he would ask the New York Leg islature to establish a statewide program of compulsory immu nization shots against rubella, or German measles, for all school children.

title: Births
description: BERKEDoctor and Mrs. Ronald Berke (ne Shot) announce the birth of Mark Jay. sister, Lisa Ann, named In memory of he maternal grandmother, Rebecca Fritz an paternal grandmother, Anna Dubin, Jan. 1970.

title: Texas at Arlington Eleven Slates Toledo for '71, '72
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Jan. 10 (AP)Chena Gilstrap, the ath letic director announced yes terday that Tangerine Bowl champion, Toledo, has been added to the University of Texas, at Arlington football schedule for 1971 and 1972.

title: Buchanan and Culp Provide Kansas City With Big Lift
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 Buck Buchanan, the 6foot7 inch defensive tackle, has the most trunk strength while Curley Culp, also a defensive tackle, has the most limb strength among the Kansas City Chiefs, a weightlifting team. This is according to Alvin Roy, the strength coach for the Chiefs who play the Minnesota Vikings in the Super Bowl to morrow.

title: Unbeaten Columbia Fencers Turn Back Harvard, 18.9
description: Columbia won eight of nine bouts in foil yesterday to lead the unbeaten Lion fencing team to an 189 victory over Har vard.

title: Can the How Become the What?
description: HANS HOFMANN died almost four years ago at the age of 86, leav ing behind a huge oeuvre which included an astonishing succession of late masterpieces as well as nearly lengendary reputation as a teacher and guru of young painters. General ap preciation of his singular character and influencean appreciation which began coming his way only very late in lifehas been grow ing rapidly ever since. Just how good the paintings of his last decade are is made abun dantly clear by the selection included by Henry Geldzahler in the current New York Painting and Sculpture show at the Metropolitan, consti tuting one of that exhibition's really pleasant surprises. And now the Einmerich Gallery has mounted a show of 12 unfamiliar canvases just re leased by the Hofmann es tate, canvases spanning Hof mann's career from 1940 to 1965, providing the occasion for a few new thoughts about this very special American master.

title: A Legacy Of Trouble For 1970's
description: THESE are the times that try men's souls. The words of the political radical Thomas Paine, written when the cause of the American colonies seemed so desperate in 1776, convey the mood of the populace on many issues at the start of this new decade.

title: New Dutch Group Is Publishing Writings of Soviet Dissenters
description: A group of West European scholars have set up a non profit organization, the Alex ander Herzen Foundation in Amsterdam, to disseminate works by dissident Soviet writers.

title: POLITICAL PICTURE CLEARS ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10The political sediment began to settle in California this week, clearing the outlook for this year's critical Senate election.

title: DION OF AIR FORCE WINS AT BEAR MT.
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 10 Lieut. Douglas Dion of McGuire Air Force Base soared to victory in the Norse men ski jumping tournament today.

title: G.A.O. SAYS AUDITS SAVED $187MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) The Government Accounting Office said this week that the 1,023 audits it accomplished for Congress in the last fiscal year saved the Federal Govern ment $187.6million.

title: Uchacz Gets Lacrosse Post
description: NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 10 (AP)Gene Uchacz, 22 years old, of Garden City, L. I., who starred in soccer, lacrosse and track from 1965 through 1969 at Tufts University, was named coach of Boston College's new varsity lacrosse team today. Uchacz was captain and the most valuable player on the Tufts squad in his senior year.

title: Subway Victim Identified
description: The police last night identi fied the boy who died on Fri day after being hit by an IRT Lexington Avenue line subway train as Aaron Sheppard, 13 years old of 315 108th Street.

title: Tennessee Paper Is Target of Arson
description: MADISONVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 10Dan Hicks Jr., an editor of a weekly newspaper who in 1969 won two national awards for courage in journalism, today was the target of an arson at tempt, the latest of several at tacks on the editor and his paper.

title: Toll at Nursing Home Laid to Smoke
description: MARIETTA, Ohio, Jan. I0 (AP)Smoke felled most of the 22 elderly persons who were killed and 26 others who were injured last night in a fire that flashed through a private nurs ing home, investigators reported today.

title: Czech Aides End Soviet Visit
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (Reuters) A delegation of Czechoslo vak Communist party officials led by Josef Lenart, a national party secretary, left by air today after a fiveday visit for talks on economic reforms.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Knickerbocker Dachs hund Club match for dachshunds from 3monthsold; Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West 73d Street; judg ing at noon.

title: McCarthy Feted at Moscow AvantGarde Theater
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10Eugene J. McCarthy, the Senate's most celebrated poet, talked about the human condition, verse and ice hockey today with Andrei Noznesensky, the poet, and Yuri Lyubimov, director of the avantgarde Taganka Theater.

title: New Players Group Formed
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 (AP)A new players associa tion was announced today, representing members of the National Football League and the American Football League. John Mackey, tight end of the Baltimore Colts, was elected president of the newly merged organization, which represents more than 1,000 players on 25 teams.

title: Perle Mesta Is Now Down to a Size 10 Dress, But Her Party Style Is Still Ample
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The party last night was Perle Mesta revisited.

title: FourWheel Drive Opens the Route To Sonora's Wilds
description: TUCSON, Ariz.  This burgeoning city in the Spanish Southwest is the starting point for many kinds of trips into the Mexican state of Sonora, just south of the border. Although most people go through No gales and stick to two paved highways, Mexico's north south Route 15 or its east west Route 2, there are sev eral other ports of entry, all accessible from Tucson.

title: News and Notes From the Field of Travel
description: THE 43yearold Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla., long an exclu sive haven of the socially prominent and wealthy, is changing ifs image. To seek some convention business, it is opening its fa cilities to selected executive groups; to provide more com fort, it is fully aircondition ing the premises (a process that will take two years), and, to make more money, it is contemplating yearround operation. that will take two years), and, to make more money, it is contemplating yearround operation.

title: Lords Lose a Skirmish
description: The Young Lords, a group of Puerto Rican activists that mod els itself on the Black Panthers, evolved out of a Chicago street gang whose leader, Cha Cha Jiminez, was converted to the ideas of Eldridge Cleaver, the Black Panther leader, while serv ing a fail term.

title: Black Executives Who Move Find Housing Problem
description: THE nation's housing shortage and high mortgage interest rates are posing a burden to those young executives, particularly Negroes, who are asked by their companies to transfer to other cities in order to receive promotions.

title: Theater: A Historian Takes a Hard Look at Wilson in the Promise Land
Observer
description: WASHINGTONWe were all sitting around the radio, the whole family, waiting for a bulletin on how rails had done that day in the stock market. None of us held any rails, of course. None of us had any stock at all, or even any taxfree municipals. Uncle Charley had once owned 10 shares of stock in a varnish concern, but had sold them because, he com plained, they kept him awake nights worrying whether the price would rise or fall next day when the market opened.

title: Audubon
description: Robert Penn Warren proposes, in this recent new brief sequence of poems, a new hero for our time: the naturalistartist John James Audubon. He is a hero peculiarly acceptable to the American intellectual mind, a mind which trusts next to nothing not its own abstract byways, not the visionary corridors of art, not the blunt highroad of social engagement. When these delusory paths, promising only more refinement, more mysti cism, or more crudeness, seem yet the only entries to the actual, a man like Audubon, who blended art and science, the natural and the cere bral, the tender and the violent, with out any consciousness of unease, ap peals irresistibly as a model.

title: Since Spiro Agnew brought up the subject, How Well Does TV Present The News?
description: IN the old days monarchs some times beheaded messengers who brought bad tidingsand today's rulers, though shorn of the divine right of kings, occasionally still feel the same urges. When the Nixon Ad ministration sent Vice President Ag new forth in November to attack the TV networks for their bad tidings, he asked the citizenry to cut them down to size with letters and wires.

title: Education
description: The big city school superin tendency has become one of the most crucialand embattledof public offices. But last week New York, with the nation's largest school system, suddenly found itself with the prospect of being without leadership at the super intendent's level at a moment of precarious transition. Dr. Na thaan Brown, 57, who had been Acting Superintendent since last. August following the retirement of Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, an nounced that he would step down at the end of next month to assume the presidency of a new college in Israel. Dr. Brown has been in the system 32 years.

title: Florida Conservationists Unite for '70s
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  After many years of somewhat ineffectual pro tests against what extremists have called the rape of the environ ment, Florida conservationist groups have united under the name Conserva tion 70s, Inc., and are pushing a get tough policy that has stirred attention throughout the state and even in Wash ington.

title: Laver vs. Gonzales Features Tourney Here Jan. 21, 23
description: The Madison Square Garden invitation tennis tournament Jan. 21 and 22 will include a challenge match between Rod Laver of Australia and Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles. This match will be the first in a se ries called the Tennis Cham pions $200,000 Classic, which is being coordinated by the Na tional Tennis League, a sub sidiary of Tennis Champions, Inc., of New York.

title: MILLARD FIRST IN DOWNHILL RACE
Troubled Wall Street. Faces Basic Changes
description: The foundation for a dec ade of radical change on Wall Street was laid in 1969 a year of shuddering crisis, chaos and challenge for the securities industry.

title: St. Louis Soccer: Made in U. S. A.
description: There is a plethora of for eignborn soccer players in American colleges and univer sities and as a result their schools have good teams. The St. Louis University team, however, consists only of Americanborn players and its team has captured more na tional titles in the last 15 years than any other college.

title: Thomas Bresnahan Dies; Rowing Regatta Judge, 73
description: Thomas Breshnahan, a judge for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, died Friday night at La Guardia Airport, appar ently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived at 50 East 79th Street and in Han over. Me.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Sherlockian pastiches have of fered wide and understandable appeal to the writing fraternity for decadesnot only to those commonly occupied with detec tive fiction, but also to such mainstream authors and hu morists as Stephen Leacock and John Kendrick Bangs. Most of the takeoffs are short stories. Two booklength exceptions that come to mind are H. F. Heard's A Taste for Honey (1941) and Reply Paid (1942).

title: New Yorkers Venture Out, Lured by Sun and Climbing Mercury, but Railroads Report Weather Woes
description: The city's Arctic weather turned around early yesterday: The sun was shining, the mer cury climbed to a compara tively balmy perch in the mid 20's most of the day, and pedestrians emerged from their protective cocoons to walk at a normal, brisk pace instead of scurr??ng for shelter.

title: A HighProfit Business: Organized Crime
description: The infiltration by organ ized crime into the national economy has become so great in recent years that it is estimated that the rackets collect more than $30billion a year in the United States, with a net profitof$7billion to $10billion.

title: HUGHES, CONSIDINE WIN SKATING RACES
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP)An 18yearold from the Bronx, Bob Hughes, making his first start in the senior men's division, took first place in the 440yard event of the Eastern states outdoor speed skating championships today.

title: COLON OUTRUNS FIKES IN RELAY
description: Tony Colon of Power Me morial spotted Denis Fikes of Rice 10 yards on the 880yard anchor leg of a twomile relay yesterday and then beat him by inches.

title: North Seniors Tie South, 3737
description: MOBILE, Ala, Jan. 10 San Diego State's Dennis Shaw threw three touch down passes, two in the final quarter, to lift the North to a 3737 deadlock with the South today in a Senior Bowl football game dominated by dazzling passers.

title: Farm Exports Show a Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)The Agriculture De partment says farm exports have picked up in recent months and for the year ending June 30 may total more than $6billion after slumping to a sixyear low in 196869.
