title: One of Miami's Most Peaceful Spots
description: MIAMILess than a mile fro' Miami's tallest sky scrapers and busiest streets lies one of the city's most peaceful spots, the Japanese Garden. Situ ated on Watson Island on MacArthur Causeway, the garden's lovely pathways, Japanese structures and quiet lagoon make it an oasis in this busy metropolis. is one of several touristoriented facilities on the island.

title: How Losantiville Became The Athens of the West
description: CINCINNATIWhoever thought of touring Cincinnati? Can the city fathers be serious when they invite tourists to this midwest ern metropolis?

title: Movies Are Passions and My Great Passion Is Politics
description: CALLING Z a good thriller is like calling Easy Rider a pleasant travelogue. According to Costa Gavras, at any rate. Gavras is the earnest, Greekborn director of Z, the hit French movie about political corrup tion in Greece that currently has New Yorkers standing on footfreezing line at the Beekman Theater. Recently  a few days before he was named best director and Z was named best film by the New York Film Critics Gavras sat in his unfancy suite at the Algon quin, patiently answering questions. And in his own charming, wellmannered way, he was quite angry. He simply could not comprehend how Vincent Canby could deny the film's political motivation, choosing to see it as nothing more than a crackling suspense yarn.

title: All the Reviews Fit to Print?
description: FOR the last several months, in the eve nings and on week ends, I've been taking a long, hallucinating trip in short, prosy hops, pushing my way through mostbut by no means allof the approxi mately 16,000 New York Times movie reviews (1913 1968) that will be published in six volumes later this year. The price of the collection $395is such that it will not be the sort of thing most families, or even film buffs, will be able to afford, at least until they have paid off the last installments on the color TV set and on the Encyclo paedia Britannica.

title: Stocks Up On Counter And Amex
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthe counter market started the new year in fairly good style last week as most stocks ad vanced on moderate volume.

title: Thousands in Dublin Attack South African Racial Policy
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Thousands of demonstrators against apartheid, hurling eggs and waving banners, scuffled with police for two hours today, outside Landsdowne Stadium during a match between the South African national and the Irish national rugby teams.

title: A Shaky Balance
description: The jury is still out on the question of the likely pace and direction of economic activity in 1970. Pending an official verdict, my own judg ment is that the economy is moving through a period of precarious balance. Inappro priate policy actions  either monetary or fiscal  could adversely tip that balance, setting in motion a domino like chain of undesirable eco nomic events.

title: A Cocker Spaniel Helps Make History In 4,817Mile Flight
description: AN 11monthold cocker spaniel puppy and her handler caused a stir last Sunday at the American Spaniel Club specialty in the Statler Hilton. The fact that BlowUp of Moonlight Bay failed to get a ribbon didn't keep the ringsiders from ap plauding, for the pup was making dog show history. She had been flown 4,817 miles from Rio de Janeiro to com pete here  the first time a Brazilianbred cocker spaniel ever had been shown in North America. Handling her was Gilson Ta varas de Moraes e Castro, who also was making his bow in a ring on this continent.

title: New and Recommended
description: CHARLES WILLSON PEALE, by Charles Coleman Sellers. Painter, in ventor, naturalist, the American artist's life, well and fully told here, is a fascinating slice of social history and Americana.

title: Brazil's New Government Sets Goals for Its Development Plan
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 10 The twomonthold Brazilian Government headed by Presi dent Emilio Garrastazu Medici made its first broad policy definitions this week in an at mosphere of continuity and economic optimism.

title: My Favorite Plant Choices
description: GOLD DUST. Basketof gold. Madwort. By whatever name, Alys sum saxatile is a pe rennial treasure that adds an airy, elegant fluff of bright yellow bloom to my May gar den. Madworts are partial to sundrenched sites where drainage is sharp: the tops of walls, rock gardens and raised planters are ideal. The grayish evergreen spreading foliage is ornamental the year round.

title: Observer: The Boy, It's Cold Out There! Blues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Cold weather occurred in Washington this week as it usually does during January, and there were the usual problems.

title: Grandmother in N. J. Building House
description: LANOKA HARBOR, N. J. Mrs. Eleanor Byer is a 65 year  old doityour selfer who goes beyond the usual weekend puttering. She is building her own house.

title: Plan to Limit G.I. Flights On Charters Is Protested
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) A Civil Aeronautics Board proposal to tighten the rules applying to military personnel charter flights, particularly trans  Atlantic flights, has stirred up many protests.

title: The Fed's Role
description: To THE FINANCIAL EDITOR: The Jan. 4, 1970, article in The Times about the chang ing role sought, by some members of the Federal Re serve omitted a, pertinent point.

title: Buck Fund Fights Curb
description: HARRISBURG. Jan. 10 (AP)  The Pearl S. Buck Foundation filed a petition in court yester day to reverse an order pre venting the organization from soliciting funds in Pennsyl vania. The State Commission on Charitable Organizations handed down the order Tues day after an investigation prompted by alleged misman agement of funds.

title: Chess
description: IF there is to be a prize for the most gallant competitor during the recent United States championship, the honor perforce must go to the Rev erend William Lombardy of St. Mary's Church, the Bronx.

title: Forests and Boeing Keys for Northwest Economy
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The economic health of the Pa cific Northwest in the 1970's will continue to be depend ent on two giant industries, forest products and the Boe ing Company, and both enter the decade facing big ques tion marks.

title: In Credit Markets Only Rates Change
description: In some fields, times change. At the end of the nineteenfifties, the New York Rangers were in last place. The Baltimore Colts, coached by Weeb Ewbank beat the Giants for a divisional title and were praised by Vice President Nixon. President Eisenhower, back from a 22,000mile, 11country good will mission was lauded by President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: Puerto Rico Confident of Major Gains
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico On an island once termed a backwater area, government economic forecasts glow with an optimism reflected in the newspapers and in the stores. It is widely assumed that the economy will leap ahead by 10 per cent a year dur ing this decade.

title: The Subway Crisis Enters a New Phase
description: Scattered protesters avoided New York City's new 30cent fare by vaulting subway turn stiles or sneaking through exit gates last week. A handful of arrests was made. A group of Democrats mapped a campaign to roll back the fare to where it had been20 centsprior to the stilltobe ratified agreement on a contract granting sizable wage and other increases. In junctions barring the fare boost, paid with a new token a mite smaller than a quarter, were sought in New York courts.

title: Leaders of Mississippi's Black Activists Confident of the Future
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 10 They talk of their love for Mis sissippi. They talk of this poor est state as the new frontier. They talk about a future in which a black political and ecol comic revolution will bring back to the Magnolia State thou sands of Negroes who fled dis crimination and poverty for What they hoped would be a better life in the urban North.

title: Yippy For the Yippies
description: ABBIE HOFFMAN, who has been ac cused by the Government of conspiring to incite a riot in Chi cago during the 1968 Democratic Convention, is now conspiring to make a movie. The young leader of the Yippies (Youth International Party) will join director Jacques Levy and producer Hil lard Elkins in putting Revolution for the Hell of It, Hoffman's collection of anti  establishment essays, before the cameras.

title: Shaggy Hair Hinders Headwork, Coach Says
description: ROME, Jan. 10 (AP)Ital ian soccer coaches are on the warpath against players with hippie hair growth and long whiskers, threatening long  haired players with fines.

title: Susan Secor Engaged To Portner Humes Jr.
description: WESTBURY, Jan. 10  Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Le Boutillier have announced the engagement of Mrs. Le Boutillier's daughter, Miss Susan Senor, to J. Portner Humes Jr. He is the son of John P. Humes, United States Ambassador to Aus tria, and Mrs. Humes of Vi enna.

title: Five Jailed in Kidnapping Of Girl in Texarkana, Ark.
description: TEXARKANA, Ark., Jan. 10 (UPI)Five persons, including a 16yearold girl, were in jail today in the kidnapping of a highschool girl. Federal and state investigators sought three other persons as accomplices.

title: PRESS CURBS GROW IN SOUTH AMERICA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 10  The last year has been a bad one for South American news papermen, even in the region's nominal democracies.

title: AMERICAN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHTS GAMES

title: Sometimes charming, sometimes cruel, but more comic than devil
description: An Alien in Asian and African Art. By Cottie A. Burland. Photographs by Werner Forman. 140 pp. New York: McGrawHill Book Co. $10.95.

title: Cost to City of Welfare Island Project May Lessen
description: The city has a chance to choose a cheaper price for de veloping Welfare Island than an initially contemplated fee to the State Urban Develbp ment Corporation that could run to $4million over a 99 year period.

title: Even Leo the Lion Roars for Revolution
description: THESE days, Revolution has just about re placed Racism as the. topic for coffeehouse, teatime and cocktailparty conversatidn. The Beatles have had a hit song called Revolution. Life Magazine has run a picture series on it. Two documentary movies have limned its sensational aspects. The Mad Ave boys have all but run the black flag of anarchy up the pole, and although Motivational Research hasn't brought back figures on how many cus tomers are saluting, there's little doubt that ads and com mercials will continue to feature hairier boys, nuder girls, wilder whites and black er blacks.

title: France Urges Aid for Biafra Refugees
description: PARIS, Jan. 10As reports here and in other capitals told of the Nigerian advances into the heart of the secessionist region of Biafra, the French Government and private groups attempted today to rally help for Biafran refugees against possible massacres.

title: Wilson Calls for Restraint on Wages
description: LONDON, Jan. 10  Prime Minister Wilson, faced with new pay demands from more than two and a half million workers, warned Britain today against frivolous dissipation of her economic recovery.

title: 2 Japanese Skiers Dominate Jumping On Lake Placid Hill
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan 10 The diligent efforts made by the Masters ski jumping tour nament's organizing committee every year to assure a top in ternational field here were evi dent today when athletes from five nations captured the first, six places.

title: Blacks Still Say Show Us Despite Nixon Effort on Philadelphia Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The hope by some in the Nixon Administration that the White House effort that saved the controversial Philadelphia Ian might change the atti tude of Negroes toward the Administration could be wish ful thinking.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Army's Newsmen Want to Tell It Like It Is
description: SAIGONThe fact that we lost a battle is sort of imma terial. I mean, it happens, in battle, and anyway, we don't like to publicize it.

title: NEW DATA ACCUSE KOREAN SOLDIERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10A staff member of the Rand Cor poration said today that inter views he conducted in Viet nam late in 1966 turned up hearsay evidence of South Korean troop atrocities against South Vietnamese civilians.

title: PICTURE CREDITS
description: 1THE NEW YORK TIMES (GEORGE TAMES)

title: Oil Expansion Set
description: The Continental Oil Com pany is investing more than $10million in new and expanded facilities in Okla homa this year, John G. McLean, president, has an nounced. A new polyvinyl Chloride plant at Oklahoma City will cost more than $6million and refining capac ity, at Ponca City will be expanded 10,000 barrels a day, an increase of 13 per cent over present capacity.

title: Wright Morris: A Reader
description: After more than 25 years of sus tained productivity, during which he has published 19 books  many of them distinguished  Wright Mor ris seems to have become arrested permanently on the brink of major reputation. The obvious injustice of this has troubled his admirers for a very long time and caused them to insist, as each new book of his appears, that surely this one will bring him the kind of general rec ognition he so clearly deserves. Yet when the publication furor dies away and critics have written their usually laudatory reviews, Morris seems to be more firmly established than ever in his position as the least well known and most widely unappre ciated important writer alive in this country.

title: A $2Million Libel Suit In Kentucky Is Dismissed
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 (UPI) Common Pleas Court Judge Robert V. Wood has dismissed a $2,040,000 libel suit filed here by two former Covington, Ky., city commissioners against the Kentucky Post and TimesStar.

title: Order Brings $8,000 But No Game Tickets
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 10 (AP) Robert Barbeau, an investi gator in the Hennepin County Attorney's office, ordered tickets for tomorrow's Super Bowl game, but got $8,000 instead.

title: HilaLouise Chashin, Physician, Is Engaged
description: BAYONNE, N. J., Jan. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Chashin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. HilaLouise Chashin, to Otto Allan Grossman of Sher man Oaks, Calif., son of Mrs. Samuel Stark of Beverly Hills, Calif., and the late Herman Grossman of Kosice, Czech oslovakia.

title: L.I.R.R. Gives Alternative: 20% Increase on All Fares
description: The Long Island Rail Road revised yesterday its request for a fare increase, asking for either a 20 per cent rise on all tickets or an increase of 20 cents a ride or $9.20 on month ly commuter rates.

title: Point of View
description: Successful conglomerate companies of the 1960's were a product of several impor tant forces at work in the American economy. Among these were the growth of sys tems analysis, the large in flux of engineers and scien tists into the mainstream of American business, the de velopment of very large mar kets after World War II, and the amazing size and flexi bility of the American capital market.

title: Another Crime Buster Tries to Break the Mafia in New Jersey
description: Is he okay? Those three words are practically a pass word among politicians and po licemen in New Jersey. You hear that question about a cop in Atlantic City, about a purchas ing agent in a Jersey City hos pital, about an assistant prose cutor in Essex County, about an important state Senator in Tren ton. Is he okay?

title: STAND BY ISRAEL, GOLDBERG PLEADS
description: Arthur J. Goldberg declared last night that the American people were not willing to aban don their commitment to Israel for the sake of currying favor with those states which level the charge of onesidedness at the United States Govern ment.

title: New Freedoms at 18
description: LONDONNo one in Britain seems to be holding their breath waiting to find out what will happen now that the age of full legal capacity has dropped from 21 to 18. Even the 18 yearolds seem bland about it. They can now vote, marry with out their parents' consent, buy on the installment plan, take out mortgages or get mail from their bookmakers but this sud den power does not seem to matter much.

title: How to Tweeny Up Those Orgy Scenes
description: AMONG the leastpublicized special ists in show business are the men who write the material shown between the sex scenes in for eign movies.

title: Lindsay Pulls Off A Political Coup
description: The whirlwind courtship of Robert M. Morgenthau by John Lindsay and Richard Aurelio gave the city a third Deputy Mayor for the first time in its history, gave the mayor a coup that won national attention, and left politician watchers wondering why it was all necessary.

title: On L.I., Planning Is Showing Results
description: THE relentless march of suburban growth toward the tip of Long Island is arousing new interest in comprehensive planning in communities long suspicious of professional planning guidance.

title: Toll Road Deaths Low
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) The International Bridge, Tunnel and Turnpike Associa tion, Inc.. says that only three of the nation's 42 toll roads re ported fatal vehicle accidents over the New Year weekend. One fatality each was reported in accidents on the Connecticut Turnpike, the Kentucky Turn pike and the Central New Hamp shire Turnpike.

title: Barbara E. Doty Plans Marriage To Judge's Son
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 10An nouncement. has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Espy Doty of Rye and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Elisabeth Doty, to James Bernard Dwyer 3d, son of James B. Dwyer, presiding judge of the Orphans Court of the Sixth Judicial District of Pennsylvania, and Mrs. Dwyer of Erie.. Mr. Doty is a general partner of the in vestment banking house of Goldman, Sachs & Co., in New York.

title: May, Reichardt Among Six To Sign Pacts With Angels
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP)Six California Angels, including Rick Reichardt, out fielder, Rudy May, pitcher, have signed 1970 contract.

title: Aerospace Men See Peace Profits
description: LOS ANGELESThe com panies that make the nation's largest and most advanced military equipment are look ing toward peace as a booster for business in the Seventies.

title: Music
description: ROUND the turn of the century, the great conductor Arthur Nik isch had a few words to say, generically, about the gentlemen who appeared under his baton. Not the soloists, but the anonymous special ists who make up the orchestra itself. Nikisch came to the conclusion that a player's psyche depended upon the in strument he played. Clarinetists, for instance, are inclined to be sentimental. Violists and the higher brass instru ments are calm and goodnatured. But oboists and bassoonists are different. They have to blow into a narrow reed in such a manner that a great amount of air remains stored in the chest, to be released cautiously and gradually. This makes the blood rise to the brain and makes them so nervous they can be addressed only with the greatest tact.

title: Iowa State Extends Pact
description: AMES, Iowa, Jan. 10 (AP, The football coaching contract of Johnny Majors of Iowa State University was extended for five years today. Majors was hired as head coach in Decem ber, 1967, on a fiveyear ap pointment.

title: Football's Road Show Is a Rich Hit
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 Gov. Claude Kirk of Florida, annoyed because the Super Bowl is being played here this year rather than in Mi ami as in 1968 and 1969, said last Thursday: Those pro teams don't care about sunshine., They're interested in making money.

title: Making Executives of students Will Take More Than Haircut
Energy Producers Strive to Meet Economy's Needs
description: If the economy is to grow, it must have power.

title: New Foods Pamper Cooks
description: The average American in 1980 will be eating about what he eats now, according to spokesmen for major fac tors in the food industry, and it will probably be better for him. The changes that do occur will be largely in the accelerated development of conveniencetype foods.

title: Can U.S. Money System Bend?
description: On the threshold of a new decade, fundamental ques tions are being asked about the viability of the American financial system.

title: Charlotte Gardner Fiancee of Student
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 10  Miss Charlotte Welles Gardner, a graduate of the Chandler School in Boston, plans to be married to Richard A. Palmer Jr., a junior at Tarkio College in Missouri.

title: Letters
description: SEEKERS

title: Pentagon And Senate Square Off For Another ABM Battle
description: WASHINGTON  The stage was being set last week for a return match between the Ad ministration and a substantial element of the Senate over the controversial question of missile defense.

title: Cardigan Bay
description: There is hardly a horseman in the United States, especially those who have aided in improving the breed of trotters and pacers, who has not heard of (and more, than likely seen) Cardigan Bay, the New Zealandbred pacer who has won more than $1million on tracks Down Under and in the United States. Now, the famous gelding is to be honored on a multicolored 10cent postage stamp to be issued by New Zealand on Jan. 28.

title: In Decade's Blueprints: 26 Million Homes, 110 New Cities
description: America's second largest industry enters the 1970's with goals more clearly de fined than those set for any other major sector of the economy. The vast and sprawling construction indus try has been told that it will be expected to build at least 26 million new homes in the Coming decade, that it will have to rehabilitate scores of decaying urban centers across the land, and that it must begin to create 110 new cities that the expanding United States population will require by the end of the century.

title: Chelsea's Unbeaten Streak Ended by Leeds' 52 Victory
description: LONDON, Jan. 10 (Reuters) Leeds United, the defending league champion, today broke Chelsea's 12game home un beaten streak in the English Football League First Division with a decisive 52 victory.

title: House in the woods
description: When Don Metz, a young architect, decided to aban don city life and live yearround in New Hampshire, he set to work designing and building a comfortable but inexpensive house just large enough for him, his wife and their two children. The walls are covered with roughgrade spruce used horizontally, vertically and diagonally for diversity of line and texture. The ceiling of the twostory living area soars to a graceful plywood arch that is painted white with a sandy tex ture. Almost all the furniture was built into save money and space. A balcony above the dining area gives a sweeping view of trees and valleys. The compact 22by30foot house cost $15,000 to build, including the driveway and the well.

title: Anniversaries
description: LAYMANAnna and Alec. The LanesClaire and Stanley, Rebecca and Michael, Marcia and Douglas, Bill and Selena congratulate with great pride and lay our parents and grandparents on her 50th wedding anniversary January 18, 1970

title: South Carolina Island Is Center of Dispute as Groups Fight Chemical Plants
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., Jan 10 (AP)  This palmetto fringed resort island is the cen ter of a controversy between local groups and a chemical manufacturer.

title: Article 7  No Title
Miss Barbara Diaz, Teacher, Is Engaged to George Noonan
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Jan. 10Mr. and Mrs. Man uel Diaz have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Diaz, to George A. Noonan. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Noonan of Brook line and Osterville, Mass.

title: Besides Rockettes, Let There Rock
description: LAID on our doorstep like a squalling Gargantua, rock music has become the enfant terrible of contemporary culture. No small part of the problem it creates is the insoluble diffi culty of finding a theater big enough and grand enough to accommodate its vast and protean energies. Too big now for those black cribs beneath the city streets where it used to rock, too splendid for sock hop balls in sweaty gyms, too pacific, too mature for a punchthrowing, canhurling, screamup at the Brooklyn Fox, rock has become a glam orous flying circus touring the capitals of the world like some great virtuoso. the city streets where it used to rock, too splendid for sock hop balls in sweaty gyms, too pacific, too mature for a punchthrowing, canhurling, screamup at the Brooklyn Fox, rock has become a glam orous flying circus touring the capitals of the world like some great virtuoso.

title: ENEMY SHELLINGS IN VIETNAM CAUSE SEVERE U.S. LOSSES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10Enemy troops, firing 15 mortar rounds, inflicted severe casualties last night on Ameri can troops at an artillery base about 300 miles northeast of Saigon, according to United States headquarters.

title: New Roadblock to Arms Control Progress
description: The Pentagon argument that deployment of MIRV multiple warhead missiles must go for ward unless the Soviet Union limits its antiaircraft defenses has set off a major behindthe scenes controversy that could upset the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks. Two major reasons exist for this grave possibility:

title: Daley of Times to Get Pro Football Award
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 Arthur Daley of The New York Times was named today as the 1970 recipient of the Dick McCann Award for long and distinguished writing in the field of pro football by the Professional Football Writers of America.

title: Irving's Thoughts on His Life, Times and Travels
description: I have had considerable pleasure in my life, and have two or three times come very near being happy which, I believe, is as much as most men can say.

title: Kenya Acts Against Asian Traders
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 10 Nearly a thousand Asian trad ers in Kenya have been ordered by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry to close their busi nesses by June. The ministerial notices informed the traders that their licenses would not be renewed.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: IT is difficult to estimate the probable damage to a river and the life it supports that would result from the addi tion of one more source of pollution, whether industrial, domestic, thermal or pesti cidal.

title: My Dad George, $4.40, Takes $28,450 Tropical Park Stakes
This Computer Has Rangers' Number
description: An example of the form the Bickings use to record Ranger, statistics. On the top line, 120 under goal is for Juha Widing, who scored the first Ranger goal. The 102 for Brad Park, who assisted. There was no second assist. The Per, Min and Sec give the period and time when the goal was scored. The G/A is for goal against. It was scored against Al Smith, a Pittsburgh goalie. The 1 in the Special box is the code number for a power play. All Rangers are coded by their numbers plus 100; all Penguins by their numbers plus 1,200. Thus Widing, No. 20, becomes 120 on the form. The form was compiled during a RangerPenguin game last Wednesday, won by the Rangers, 53.

title: PRINCETON DOWNS DARTMOUTH, 7364
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10 Flawless foul shooting in the final minutes and a defense that made repeated steals and forced errors gave Princeton a 7364 victory over Dartmouth tonight in a seesaw contest.

title: Letters
description: The Literary Sixties

title: Minnesotan Named Head Of Highway Users Group
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) Harry Heltzer, president of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company of St. Paul, has been named chairman of the new Highway Users Federation for Safety and Mo bility.

title: Reader's Report
description: By Michel Larneuil. Translated by June P. Wilson and Walter B. Michaels. 160 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $4.95.

title: Key Brain Hormone Reported Isolated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Scientists in Texas have reported the isolation and synthesis of a longsought hormone in the brain that controls important functions of the body's master gland the pituitary.

title: Diversified Dixie Is Aim for Decade
description: ATLANTA  In Dixie, the transition from the sixties to the seventies means a deter mined new emphasis on di versification and skilled labor  with hopes that the South politicians and business men will provide the needed education and innovation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 11, 1970

title: Pistons Stave Off Sonics
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10 (AP)The Detroit Pistons started fast to night and held on to down the Seattle Supersonics, 129128.

title: SPANISHSOVIET TALK REPORTED BY PAPER
description: MADRID, Jan. 10 (AP)A Spanish newspaper said today that Foreign Minister Gregorio Lopez Bravo met with a So viet official in Moscow in De cember, the first meeting of high Spanish and Soviet offi cials since the Spanish civil war.

title: John Kimberly Becomes Fiance Of Miss Christy
description: OLDWICK, N. J., Jan. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Fowler Christy have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Lenox Christy, to John Robert Kimberly. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Taylor Kimberly of New Haven. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Sherlockian pastiches have of fered wide and understandable appeal to the writing fraternity for decadesnot only to those commonly occupied with detec tive fiction, but also to such mainstream authors and hu morists as Stephen Leacock and John Kendrick Bangs. Most of the takeoffs are short stories. Two booklength exceptions that come to mind are H. F. Heard's A Taste for Honey (1941) and Reply Paid (1942).

title: Mrs. Jean Mahoney to Be Wed
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 10 Mrs. James L. Starkey has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Jean Mahoney of New York. to Bill Brown, also of New York. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Randolph F. Brown of New Rochelle. A wedding in the apring is planned.

title: Violence and the city child
description: TENyearold Paul's bike was stolen in the park last week by a pair of 12yearolds. But that was nothing new. His kid sister's bicycle was taken away from her in the same area of the park last year. And several of his classmates have either had theirs stolen or have had to fight off an attempted theft.

title: Quotes
description: DEAN RUSK, former Secretary of State, in a speech students in Valdosta, Ga.; It is simply too late in history to pursue a policy of total hostility for any nation or any people. We must set aside our glandular reactions and try to find agreement even with those that consider themselves our personal adversaries.

title: Dance Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: School Chief Implores Parents Not to Allow TakeOvens by Activist Groups
description: Dr. Nathan Brown, Acting Superintendent of Schools, warned yesterday that the city would not be a fit place to live in if the Schools,. under the new decentralization plan, were taken over by irrespon sible activist groups instead of responsible parents.

title: John N. Page Jr. to Wed Helen May
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Jan. 10 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis B. May of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Hartman May, to John Nor cross Page Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Page of Montclair, N. J.

title: Dr. Ethelann Murray Wed on L.I.
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 10  Dr. Ethelann Murray, a postdoctoral fellow in he matology at the YaleNew. Haven Medical Center, and Dr. Peter Joseph Savage, a medical resident there, were married here this morning at the Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: Ethical Culture Aide Elected
description: The New York Society for Ethical Culture announced yes terday that Jerome Nathanson had been elected chairman of its board of leaders, a position recently created through a revision of the society's bylaws. Mr. Nathanson is also chairman and founder of the New York Committee to Abolish Capital Punishment and a member of the Clergymen's Advisory Com mittee of Planned Parenthood of New York City and the National Committee for Support of the Public Schools.

title: Who Makes Music and Where
EGYPTIANS WORK WITH U.S. OILMEN
description: EL ALAMEIN, United Arab Republic, Jan. 7  At a time when some United States oil interests appear uneasy about their future in the Arab world as a result of tensions over Is rael, Americans and Egyptians are continuing to cooperate quietly and in apparent har mony for the exploration and development of this country's oil potential.

title: Celtics Bow to Bucks
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 10 (AP) Flynn Robinson scored 31 points tonight as the Milwau kee Bucks crushed the Boston Celtics, 124109.

title: Chinese Open Agricultural Drive
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 10  A drive to increase arable land and the production of food grains is getting under, way throughout Communist China.

title: That Angry Voice? It's a Consumer's
description: Not enough quality. Inadequate service. Too much builtin obsoles cence.

title: Bankers' Nemesis
description: A MAN who has often been described as the last of the great populists, Mr. Patman has waged a long and lonely war against what he regards as power and privilege in American society . . . Last year, probably as much to his surprise as any one else's, he scored some notable successes . . . His archenemies, the commercial banks, were saddled with an extra $250million a year in taxes, and onebank holding companies faced forced sale of many post1956 ac quisitions because of the generalship of the venerable 76yearold chairman of the House Banking Committee . . . Now the Texas Demo crat is zeroing in on the secret bank accounts that many Americans  from ap parently respectable stock brokers to the friendly neigh borhood Mafioso  maintain abroad for a variety of illegal and a few legal purposes.

title: COLUMBIA DOWNS BROWN FIVE, 8854
description: Jim McMillian and Heyward Dotson combined for 43 points and 18 rebounds last night as Columbia easily defeated Brown, 8854, in an Ivy League contest before 1,410 fans in University Gym.

title: The Bookie and the Syndicates
description: After two busysignals, the football fan got through on his phone call to Brooklyn. This is A for Horse, he said. What's the line on the Vikings? . . . Okay, gimme the. Vikings 20 times. You got it, the man at the other end of the line said, and hung up.

title: Mutual Funds Go Deeper Into U.S. Mainstream
description: Jim Baxter, whose new Chevrolet turned out to be lemon, is able to tell his mutual fund not to invest any of his money in General Motors.

title: Heir, 21, Hires a Jet to Proclaim: He Wants to Aid Poor and Peace
description: A 21yearold millionaire, who says he wants to help fight poverty and win peace, and his bride returned to New York from their honeymoon in Ja maica yesterday in solitary splendor aboard a Boeing 707 jet they had chartered for $7,954.

title: Broadway Will Sing This Spring
description: After getting off to a slow start, Broadway's song  and  dance world is humming with prepara tions for new musicals. Here are five currently in rehearsal. Also promised for this spring: Com pany, Tattered Tom, Look to the Lilies, Purlie, and, Off Broadway, the BrechtWeill Mahagonny, starring Barbara Harris and Estelle Parsons.

title: 2 More Ship Jumpers Found On a Raft in Harbor Here
description: Two more Chinese seamen from Hong Kong who jumped ship in rubber rafts when their vessel entered New York Har bor were picked up early yes terday clinging to one of the rafts. After examination at the United States Public Health Hospital on Staten Island they were turned over to immigra tion authorities.

title: Holy Cross Names Layman
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 10 (AP) Charles S. Horgan a New York lawyer, has been elected the first lay board chair man of the Board of Trustees at Holy Cross College.

title: MISS BARTKOWICZ IS BEATEN, 64, 86
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Af rica, Jan. 10 (AP) Mrs. Ann Jones, England's Wimbledon champion, avenged a defeat of a week ago to Peaches Bart kowicz today by beating the seventhranked American from Hamtramck, Mich., 64, 86, in the final of the Orange. Free State tennis championships.

title: Yale Downs Cornell, 7260
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 10  Yale scored the game's first basket and was never headed tonight in defeating Cornell 7260.

title: School Bells Ring
description: THE. Horticultural Society of New York, Inc., announces The re open ing of its free, public library at a new location, 128 West 58th Street. A complete selection of books and information on gardening and plant care is available. Library hours are from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday through Friday, except on the first and third Wednesdays of the month. Saturday hours are from 10:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M.

title: Sports of The Times
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10It has been a miserable week in this supposedly gay and charming city. An embar rassing cold wave even produced a low of 22 degrees one day, a level that hadn't been reached since 1879. Worse than that, though, is the possibility that the Super Bowl game on the morrow between the Kansas City Chiefs and the Minnesota Vikings may be played in a chill rain.

title: Affluence Makes Aged a Business Target
description: Much that is new today involves the old. The ranks of the aged are considerably enlarged and, as a new dec cade commences, their num bers, their endurance and their place in the United States economy are getting more attentionpublic and privatethan they did a dec ade ago.

title: Telegram Sent to Joe Kapp By 3,000 British Columbians
description: VANCOUVER, British Co lumbia, Jan. 10 (AP)Go, go, Super Joe. You gave British Columbia our first and only Grey Cup. We know you will deliver the Super Bowl to Min nesota today.

title: Kings Point Loses in Boston
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10Jim Hayes with 20 points led a balanced attack tonight as Boston Uni versity defeated Kings Point, 10770. John Miller had 12 points for the Mariners.

title: WagePrice Wheel Could Spin Faster
description: The goforbroke spirit of a Las Vegas gambling casino hangs over the collective bar gaining table as labor sets its sights on sharply higher wages in the 1970's.

title: Apparel Men Baste Fashions
description: The $40billion apparel in dustry is due for sweeping changes in the seventies to make it less vulnerable to fashion obsolescence and yet more capable of producing fashionable clothes.

title: FIVE ARRESTED HERE IN AIRPORT THEFTS
description: The Federal Bureau of In vestigation reported yesterday the arrest of five men in con nection with the theft of more than $200,000 in jewelry, coins and watches from the North west Orient Airlines at Kennedy International Airport last Wednesday.

title: The 1960's Should Have Been No Surprise for the Demographer
description: No one standing on the threshold of the sixties could possibly have forecast what has happened in the decade now ending. Yet the biggest surprise, perhaps, is that so much should have been a sur prise.

title: A Black View of Sambo
description: RIP off. Another black man ripped off by this freakish age in which we live. Cold dead wind of hippie breeze, homo sexuals writhing and wailing a Lawrence Welk tune. The energy that has sustained us and nourished us dished up by imitation black entertain ers like Janis Joplin and Tom Jones. White America longs for orgasm, clutches at its private parts, and begs us to contribute to the continua tion of her life, when we know deep inside that our hymns portend her destruc tion. Save me! Save me! the whore hollers and the little black boy goes right on danc ing and doing his thing against the most awesome circumstances.

title: Efforts Pressed to Ease High Costs for the Retired
description: City and state officials, and private citizens alike, are in creasing their efforts around the country to ease the pinch that retired people face as result of soaring prices.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: LIKE the traditional yearend stock 14 rally, the perennial infusion of new funds into the market each January has not'bloomed to any great extent this sea sonso far at least.

title: Pop
description: Maj. Glenn Miller, direc tor of the United States Air Force Band, is missing on a flight from England to Paris, it was announced today. No trace of the plane has been found.

title: On the Hill, Responsibility vs. Priorities
description: WASHINGTON  Con gress enters the new decade torn between the constraints of fiscal responsibility im posed by the Nixon Adminis tration and a desire to re order national priorities by spending more on domestic programs.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Dr. Shirley A. Mayer, As sistant Commissioner of Health; Georgia McMurray, director, special projects, Hu man Resources Administra tion; Dr. Frederick Green, di rector, Children and Youth Comprehensive Medical Care Program, on Right Now, Channel 9, 9 A.M.

title: Nets Triumph Over Pipers In Two Overtimes, 143139
description: ALTOONA, Pa., Jan. 10 (AP) The New York Nets defeated the Pittsburgh Pipers, 143139, in double overtime tonight in an American Basketball Asso ciation game at Jaffa Mosque.

title: PRIMARY CONCERN IS PERFORMANCE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 10 Whipping furiously, Al Winger drove Soundtrack N. to victory tonight in the second race at Roosevelt Raceway. The crowd of 22,750 cheered as the crack of the whip appeared to rally the 5yearold gelding to a $22.80 payoff for a $2 bet.

title: Television
description: WHEN all the repercussions of Vice President Agnew's attack on the television medium are collected in a doctoral thesis a few years hence, its outcome may be seen as materially different from cur rent judgments. At this juncture, how ever, several developments are worth noting. For one thing, Vice President Agnew may have rallied the silent majority to the side of President Nixon. In consequence, the networks were left open to some legitimate criti cism for failure to give any live cover age to the massive peace march in Washington. If one of the largest crowds in the country's history turned out to disagree with the White House, what more was required to make the demon stration qualify as news on TV? What was clearly an event was virtually con verted by television into a nonevent. were left open to some legitimate criti cism for failure to give any live cover age to the massive peace march in Washington. If one of the largest crowds in the country's history turned out to disagree with the White House, what more was required to make the demon stration qualify as news on TV? What was clearly an event was virtually con verted by television into a nonevent.

title: Volume Declines For TaxExempts
description: The volume of taxexempt bonds decreased 30 per cent last year as states and cities ran up against record interest rates.

title: Copper Test Set By Cities Service
description: The Cities Service Com pany is studying the feasibil ity of sinking a 4,000foot shaft at the company's copper discovery near Miami, Ariz., with a view to making a producing mine of the prom ising ore body.

title: Point of View
description: ALL I could see from where I stood, were three, long mountains and a wood. What a marvelous view this must have been from Murray Hill some 600 years ago. Now, looking north ward from the 24th floor of 2 Park Ave nue I find myself gazing onto the smil ing faces of countless fauns and satyrs who glare contemptuously down on the streets from the top of the once beautiful Hotel Vanderbilt, designed somewhere around 1912 by Warren & Wetmore, the architects of Grand Central Station.

title: Malawi Dissents From Africans' Stand Against White Regimes
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 10 (Agence FrancePresse)An 11 nation conference of East and Central African foreign min isters ended here this week with Malawi, the first black African nation to establish dip lomatic relations with South Africa, sharply dissenting from the final communique.

title: Point of View
description: ONCE upon a time there was a great nation. East and west it reached from sea to sea. In the north the ice never melted even when the sun shone all night. In the south flowers bloomed all winter. Down the middle, through a vast fertile valley, ran mighty river, a ready made waterway for trade.

title: Foundations Find Tax Act Acceptable
description: Foundation leaders who feared the worst from Con gress in the last year have con cluded that the new tax re form law will not significantly hamper their billiondollar phil anthropic activities.

title: Modern Voyageur
description: A 45YEAROLD chemical engineer from Iowa who was chosen to head the oil industry's $45million gamble at opening the Northwest Pas sage through the voyage of the tanker S.S. Manhattan... Admits he is not a sailor for either fun or profit . . . Named because he had been a persistent advocate of a marine solution to the prob lem of moving oil from Alas ka's North Slope to East Coast and European consumption centers . . . If route proves feasible, and this will not be known until early summer, the Arctic's wealth will be available and a new trade route over the top of the world will be open . . . If Mr. Haas is wrong, one associate commented, the oil industry has a lot of pretty miserable places to send people.

title: What Are Trees For? The List Grows
description: Ten years ago, the forest products industry was basic ally three separate industries  a lumber industry a ply wood industry and a paper industry.

title: In The Nation:
description: WASHINGTON  The public release by Federal Judge Robert Shaw of 1,200 pages of tran scripts and logs of alleged Mafia conversations, all over heard years ago by illegal Government wiretapping and bugging, means that the dis appearing American individual has lost another round in the battle to protect his rights against the rights of society.

title: John Pirovano to Marry Mrs. Joanne F. Langdon
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 Mrs. Joanne Field Langdon, a greatgreatgranddaughter of Marshall Field, founder of the Chicago department store, plans to be married on Feb. 14 to John Pirovano, a private investor in New York. The couple plan a church wedding here, to be followed by a reception at the home of the future bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Bross.

title: ... My Whole Life Passed Before Me
description: I DIDN'T actually imagine I was drowning as I sat through the first preview performance of Instruc tions for the Running of Trains, Etc. on the Erie Railway to Go Into Effect January 1, 1862, though of course one could easily go under the tidal wave of that title if Marat/Sade hadn't long since taught us all how to swim.

title: Detectives Stop 4 Times And Arrest 11 in Bronx
description: Three police detectives rid ing in an unmarl d car ar rested 11 narcotics suspects yesterday in four stops along a 16block stretch of Brook Avenue in the Bronx, the last eight while the policemen were on their way back to the Alexander Avenue sta tion house.

title: Illinois Survey Finds Business Bullish
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10  Pros pects for the Illinois econ omy in 1970 are generally good, a survey of business leaders throughout the state indicates, although the slow down predicted for the coun try as a whole will be felt in the state.

title: FOREMSKY TAKES KANSAS BOWLING
description: WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 10  Skee Foremsky, of Houston de feated four straight opponents today to win the $45,000 Wich ita Centennial open bowling tournament.

title: Mann of Lions Wins Award
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)Errol Mann, a kicker for the Detroit Lions in the National Football League, was named today as the recipient of the first John Unitas Award, given by the South Shore Quarterback Club of Boston.

title: Nixon, in 2d Year, Shifts Goals to Quality of Life
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10De spite tight budgetary restric tions, President Nixon is find ing ways to change the direc tion, tone and emphasis of his Administration as it heads into its second year.Under Presidential orders, the Bureau of the Budget, Cabinet officers and White House ad visers are completing work on a program to enable the Presi dent to propose a number of innovations without violating his pledge for a balanced budget.

title: Head of State Police In Jersey Is Stricken
description: SOUTH AMBOY, N. J., Jan. 10Col. David B. Kelly, the Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, was in serious condition in the South Amboy Memorial Hospital to night, after suffering what a hospital spokesman described as a possible coronary attack in his home here.

title: Analysts Fiddled As Bonds Plunged
description: All the time interest rates were climbing last year to the fantastic levels reached in December, much of Wall Street and Washington and others found it difficult to believe. The unforgettable year produced the following unforgettable views.

title: In Public Domain
description: PRESIDENT of Donald son Lufkin & Jenrette an institutional brokerage house that, though dwarfed by the Merrill Lynches of the securities industries, made more waves on Wall Street last year than all of the industry giants com bined. . . . Mr. Donaldson and Dan W. Lufkin both 38 years old and Richard H. Jenrette, 40, filed a registra tion statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission May 22, cover ing the public offering of 800,000 common shares of their company. . . . Move brought to a head the long simmering controversy over public ownership of stock ex change members and promp ted Big Board to change its rules to permit public sale of memberfirm shares. . . . Concern was only 10 years old on Dec. 10 and has only branch in

title: Gloster Is 2d Richardson To Play in the Super Bowl
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 Gloster Richardson, a wide re ceiver for the Kansas City Chiefs, is following in the foot steps of his brother, Willie Richardson, who was a per former in the Super Bowl last year. He was a wide receiver for the Baltimore Colts.

title: Advertising:
description: My wife beats me at bridge, paddle tennis and bowling and my sons beat me at golf so I spend a lot of time gardening. said J. Garry Valk, half kidding.

title: Where it all began
description: BERKELEY, Calif. THIS is where it all began, the caldron in which the dark brew of student discontent first spilled over five years ago. It is the best place to try to dis cover what came of the bold young dreams and what Berkeley's experi ence signifies for all of higher education.

title: Washington: The U. S. and the Middle East Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10For the last month, the U.S. and Israeli Governments have been fussing with each other over Secretary of State Rogers's formula for settling the Middle East crisis. Washington is ap pealing to the world to see that Mr. Rogers's formula is fair and reasonable. Israel is arguing that the formula is unreasonable and even dangerous, and this leaves most people in an awk ward position, because they don't know what the Rogers's formula is.

title: Arlo: Kids Want To Be Free
description: WASHINGTON. Mass.

title: PAVEL BELYAYEV, ASTRONAUT, DEAD
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10  Col. Pa vel I. Belyayev, a Soviet astro naut who commanded the first flight from wpich man walked in space, died today from com plications following an opera tion for stomach ulcers, it was officially announced tonight.

title: Seashore Home on Cape Cod Wins Design Award
description: ASEASHORE house of stark rectangles and bold curvesset on a part of Cape Cod where dormer windows and pitched roofs are the traditionhas won a design award.

title: Picture Cloudy for TV Networks
description: Television networks will be facing their toughest compe tition in history over the next several years. But this compe tition holds out no distinct promise of improved pro graming.

title: Dispute on Soviet Missiles Hampers U.S. Arms Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 The Defense Department has injected a complication into preparations for negotiations with the Soviet Union on con trolling strategic arms, by ar guing that the United States cannot stop developing multi ple warheads for missiles un less the Soviet Union limits its antiaircraft defenses.

title: In Brief
description: Beginning with, a nightmare, of dreadful premonition which is soon fulfilled, this sounds more like something out of The Arabian Nights than the autobiography of a United States Senator. But then, that suggests the way it was in Washington back when Joe Mc Carthy had the town mesmer ized.

title: Art
description: IT IS a great pleasure for this often grouchy re porter to say that on one gray, icy Friday re cently the Metropolitan, Mu seum, onceremoved in the form of its medieval branch, The Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park, afforded him three, make it four, very happy ex periences simultaneously.

title: Pilots Group Names Aide
description: The Air Line Pilots Associa tion has appointed Francis E. Martineau to succeed the late Edward Modes as director of public relations. Mr. Martineau a longtime newspaper adver tising and public relations man, is also a pilot.

title: Boom Seen For Land In Rockies
description: DENVER  The Mountain States, fearing a loss of their cowboy individualism under a rush of urban living, enter the decade knowing that there is much money to be made.

title: Article 11  No Title
GOV. DEMPSEY BARS CONNECTICUT RACE FOR A THIRD TERM
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 10Gov. John N. Dempsey announced in a surprise move today that he would not seek reelection to a third term.

title: U.S. Firm In Battle Of Prices
description: WASHINGTONWhen the Nixon administration took of fice a year ago it soon pro duced a game plan for the battle against inflation. Des pite some disappointments, that plan has not changed as 1970 begins.

title: Miss Edinger Plans Wedding
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Edinger Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Ed inger, to Robert Allan Boas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan C. Boas of South Hadley, Mass.

title: Philippines to Give All Foreign Airlines Unrestricted Entry
description: MANILA, Jan. 10The Philip pines plans to open her air ports to the unrestricted entry of foreign air traffic for a one year test period in the hope of increasing tourist revenue.

title: University Names Chief
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 10 (AP)Dr. Dolphus Whitten Jr., who had been serving as acting president at Oklahoma City Uni versity since last June, has been named president of the school.

title: Seaver to Be Honored
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 (UPI) Tom Seaver, the pitching hero of the world champion New York Mets was named the professional athlete of the year today by the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association and will be honored at the writers' annual dinner here Jan. 26.

title: Still Hotter Than a Pistol. Why?
description: NETWORK television is a relentless, remorse less programswilling beast that gorges on pilots and spits ulcers. The numbers tell the story, and when the numbers are wrong, the attendants are trained to push the Abort button. That's how it's been ever since advertisers learned to count. Selling The Product is the name of the game. To paraphrase the Media Maven, the show is the sideshow.

title: PresidentMaker
description: ON two consecutive days last year, the selfmade millionaire installed new pres idents at companies he had taken over . . . First came MGM where James T. Aubrey, former C.B.S. televi sion network chief, got the job of restoring the hoarse lion's roar ... Purchase of 40 per cent of MGM stock cost him $100  million and snatched the company away from Edgar M. Bronfman, the liquor heir . . . With Mr. Aubrey safely seated, Mr. Kerkorian flew to California to put the icing on the cake of his 28 per cent holding in Western Airlines, where J. ?? Taylor a 60yearold financial specialist, was made head man . . . Son of an Ar menian immigrant, the 52 yearold yachtsman has sub stantial real estate holdings in Las Vegas, including the $54million, 1,500room Inter national Hotel.

title: Mets Are Forced to Platoon FrontOffice Personnel During Illness of Murphy
description: A crisis in management has struck the New York Mets just as they are bracing to defend their world title. And the Mets, who reached the top by some of the most furious platooning in baseball history, are meeting the problem by platooning the talent in their front office.

title: Fordham Fencers Split
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 10The Fordham University fencing team split a triangular meet at Southeastern Massa chusetts University today. The final scores were Fordham 14, Holy Cross 13, Southeastern 19, and Fordham 8, Southeastern 15, Holy Cross 12. The South eastern Massachusetts attack was led by Ron Caisse with six saber victories.

title: ILLINOIS DEFEATS OHIO STATE, 7759
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 10 (UPI)  Fred Miller and Rick Howat scored 20 points each today to lead Illinois to a 7759 Big Ten basketball victory over Ohio State and enable the Illini to remain in a tie with Iowa for first place in the conference.

title: Max Rafferty:
description: Education in the seventies will confound a lot of self appointed prophets. It will move toward decentraliza tion and local control, not to ward the skyscraper parks plaza and Orwellian effi ciency.

title: '69 Air Traffic Gain Was Paced by Rise Of 27% for Freight
description: Every category of air traffic grew in 1969, with air freight showing the greatest gain27 per cent over 1968according to the annual computation by the International Civil Aviation Organization.

title: NAVAR GAINS FINAL IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 11 Anil Nayar, United States champion and 1969 intercol legiate titleholder from Har vard, rallied today to win the Merion Cricket Club invitation squash racquets tournament and the William F. White Me morial Cup for the second straight year.

title: Defense Role of U.S. Colleges
description: The need for university participation in national de fense research will not dimin ish in the next decade. The public debate about that par ticipation will probably con tinue.

title: Judge Irving I. Schreckinger, 63, Of City Criminal Court Is Dead
description: Judge Irving I. Schreckinger of the New York City Criminal Court died yesterday in Me morial Hospital, after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 1701 Popham Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE more we earn, the less we work, the more we play, right? As work time approaches zero, play time ap proaches infinity right? Before too long, our days will be spen picking daisies, read ing books, cultivating ??urselves, right? And since a utopia of leis ??re seems not wholly undesirable, sane economic policy dictates that we go on increasing productivity, that we go on watching the grossnational product indices in the fervent hope that they swell and burgeon. Right? No, wrong. Wrong, says the frazzled suburbanite racing from school to supermarket to train station to martini in the wagon her hus band spent last Sunday morning polishing at the sacrifice of a golf match or a sail. Wrong, says Swedish economist Staffan B. Linder in his little bombshell of an essay, The Harried Leisure Class. Wrong. Wrong. Wrong.

title: TV Review
description: THE Columbia Broadcasting System managed to de vote four hours yesterday afternoon to coverage of the Super Bowl in New Orleans without ever once using the word gambling. Instead, the announcers, who are actually under the control of profes sional football rather than the network, merely com pounded their own journal istic misdemeanor by allud ing mysteriously to the ex tra strain suffered in the last week by Len Dawson, quarterback for the Chiefs.

title: College Hockey
Florida State Five's Probation is Extended for New Violations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Florida State, which has one of the strongest independent quin tets in the nation, will not be eligible for the National Col legiate championship tourna ment this season or next as its basketball program was placed on a twoyear probation by the National Collegiate Athletic As sociation council today.

title: Russel of France Wins Slalom; Duvillard Is Victor in Combined
description: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 11 (AP)Patrick Russel, the World Cup leader, gave France its second straight victory of the warmweather plagued Lau berhorn Alpine ski meet today by winning the special slalom on a day which also was good for the United States team.

title: KEY OFFICIALS SAY MILLIONS MAY DIE
description: Officials of private relief or ganizations around the world said yesterday that millions of Blafrans might die within a week unless new emergency steps were taken to provide the wartorn country with vast Quantities of food.

title: Chief Ignores Broken Finger
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (UPI) Few persons noticed Aaron Brown, the Chief tackle, leaving the game today after having stopped a Viking play. He came right back after the next play. It turned out he had broken the middle finger of his right hand.

title: Mrs. Nugent Has a Girl
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 11 (UPI) Mrs. Patrick Nugent, daughter of former President Lyndon 131 Johnson, gave birth today to sevenpound, 10ounce girl. Doc tors at Seton Hospital said that Mrs. Nugent and her unnamed daughter were doing well af ter a normal birth.

title: 12TH SNOW ALERT OF SEASON CALLED
description: With a twoinch snowfall forecast by the Weather Bu reau, the Sanitation Depart ment declared its 12th snow alert of the season last night and readied men and equip ment sufficient to deal with even greater accumulations, should they develop.

title: Carl Kaysen:
description: The last years of this dec ade have shown a growing disillusionment among the public, and especially its po litical leaders, with the fruits of science.

title: Johnson School Aide Named
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 11 (UPI) Dr. Alexander Clark, a 40 yearold native of Scotland and acting director of the Division of Behavioral Sciences in the National Academy of Sciences has been appointed associate dean of the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public, Affairs at the University of Texas. John A. Gronouski, the school's dean and former Ambassador to Po land, announced the appoint ment today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for the week follows:

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Writers Honor Three Mets
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP)Gil Hodges, who managed the New York Mets to a World Series triumph, and two of his play ers, Tommie Agee and Al Weis, were among those honored at the annual Chicago baseball writers diamond dinner tonight.

title: 30 Homeless in Lowell Fire
description: LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 11 (AP) A general alarm fire swept through a brickframe apart ment building early today, leav ing 30 persons homeless and in juring two firemen and an oc cupant.

title: The 1970's: Education For What?
description: AMERICAN education today is like a parent who, though unsure of the validity of his own values, knows that he is expected to transmit them to his children.

title: THE FINANCIAL SQUEEZE IN EDUCATION
description: While enrollment in American ele mentary and secondary schools is ex pected to level off during the decade ahead, the upward trend in spending for such schools promises to continue as perpupil costs rise. This is already putting a squeeze on local taxpayers, who must bear the brunt of rising costs. Result: Taxpayer resistance across the United States.

title: City Schools Look To New Remedies
description: The unresolved educational failures of the New York City school system are the chal lenge of the 1970's, except that merely resolving what should have been solved in the sixties will not be enough. The 1970's must deliver a radically altered and rejuve nated system of public educa tion.

title: IRAQI MIRAGE DEAL REPORTED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Monday, Jan. 12 (AP) The influential daily news paper Le Figaro reported today that an Iraqi armspurchasing mission arrived a few days ago to negotiate a contract for 50 French Mirage jet fighter planes.

title: HOLIDAY TREE FIRE KILLS 4 IN JERSEY
description: PARSIPPANY, N. J., Jan. 11 (UPI)A mother and her three children died yesterday when a Christmas tree caught fire in their living room, trapping them in the second story of their home as the father tried in vain to douse the flames.

title: Negro Colleges Face a Crisis
description: Profound and dramatic changes in the near future will affect Negro students and colleges in the United States.

title: Lag On Making Ideas Work
description: In the decade of the six ties, Innovation was the name of the education game. Schools were to be nongraded and teamtaught. Curriculums were to be infused with new content and method. And stu dents were to have tailor made lessons, individually scheduled and even taught by computers.

title: Cahill Considers Letting State Deputies Fight Crime in Counties
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11A plan to relieve County Prosecutors of the primary responsibility of fighting organized crime and give it instead to Deputy State Attorneys General is being con sidered by Gov.elect William T. Cahill.

title: Nancy Gonzales Becomes Bride Of B. N. Clune Jr.
description: In St. James Roman Cath olic Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Nancy Gon zalez was married to B. Nev ling Clune Jr. by Msgr. John P. Sullivan.

title: Advertising: Braniff Routes Solo in Print
description: Braniff Airways, flying against a trend, is throwing all of its advertising into print for 1970. And, at the moment, the only firm plans are for newspaper advertis ing  sevencolumn ads in 70 papers in 46 cities as often as three times a week.

title: For Teachers, Bigger Role
description: In 1960 there was not a single comprehensive nego tiated agreement between a teacher organization and a school board in the entire United States. In the ab sence of state or Federal leg islation, school boards uni versally appealed to the con cept of sovereignty to avoid the bargaining table.

title: London Sees Vindication
description: LONDON, Jan. 11  The British Government said tonight that it would be quite wrong to assume that genocide would follow the apparent victory of the Lagos authorities over se cessionist Biafra.

title: 400 Couples Mark Jubilee by Renewing Vows Here
description: While several thousand of their children, grandchildren and great  grandchildren looked on, more than 400 couples who will celebrate their 50th wedding anniver sary this year renewed their marriage vows yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The couples then pro ceeded up the center aisle, some in wheelchairs, as their names were called, to re ceive a Golden Jubilee scroll, kiss the ring of Cardinal Cooke and receive his con gratulations.

title: MISS PERRY RIDES HUNTER TO TITLE
description: READINGTON, N. J., Jan. 11 Michelle Perry of Berkeley Heights, N. J., made her first start in the open riding divi sion today and, with Strictly Business, won the regular working hunter championship at the Four Seasons Farm's horse show.

title: Big City Mayors Will Disclose Urban Program Today
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11The may ors of the state's six largest cities, who recently formed a joint lobby to pressure Gover nor Rockefeller and the Repub licancontrolled Legislature into providing more state aid to urban areas, will announce the details of their longrange pro gram here tomorrow.

title: Miss Rauscher Fiancee Of Donald Van Sinderen
description: BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Jan. 11Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rauscher have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Joanne Rauscher to Donald Van Sinderen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen Jr. of Bedford Vil lage.

title: BeltoisePescarolo, in Matra, Take Argentine Auto Race
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11 (AP)  Jean Pierre Beltoise and Henri Pescarolo of France, driving a Matra, won the City of Buenos Aires 600mile in ternational prototype sports car race today.

title: Computerized Instruction Shows Promise in 3 Cities
description: Mr. Prince, I got 85 per cent! This call, ringing across the schoolyard from a black fourthgrader in McComb, Miss., to Julian Prince, Superintendent of Schools, is one of my favorite anecdotes about the possibilities of education in this country.

title: 5 on L.I.R.R. Advisory Board And Nickerson Fight Fare Rise
description: MINEOLA, L.I, Jan. 11 Nassau County Executive Eu gene H. Nickerson said that he and five members of the Long Island Rail Road Advisory Board had agreed today to seek post ponement of a proposed in crease in railroad fares.

title: Yancey Accepts Track Post
description: Joe Yancey, director of the New York Pioneer Club track squad, agreed yesterday to coach the Virgin Islands team, which will compete in the Cen tral AmericanCaribbean Games at Panama City, Feb. 28 through March 15.

title: Colleges Are Straining to Meet Society's Demands
description: The traditional missions of colleges and universities as transmitters of the culture and as creators and dissemina tors of knowledge appear simplistic to day. Numerous questions are being raised about the manifest or stated pur poses of education and also about the latent, unstated or even concealed pur poses.

title: Fighting the Mainstream Seen for Black Decade
description: Three basic assumptions inform and undergird much of my thinking about the future of black education in the seventies. Naturally enough, these points of view grow out of the living and the pondering of that strange set of cele brations and lamentations which have shaped the experiences of black people in America since World War II.

title: Establishment's Ranks Infiltrated by Dissent
description: So far the emphasis on the genera tion gap has focused on the gap between parents and children, teachers and pupils, professors and students. There has been recurrent speculation about whether today's young dissenters will settle down when they are given the responsibility of adulthood.

title: Administration Seeks ShortRun Gains in Nation's Medical System
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Six months ago yesterday the Nixon Administration branded the nation's medical system a cottage industry and warned of a breakdown in the deliv ery of health care unless im mediate concerted action is taken.

title: World Student Unrest Still Smolders
description: Educators and social work ers note a hardening of mu tual mistrust between youths and adults. Mature observers feel that the youth rebellion can only increase.

title: WMANUS TAKES TASMANIAN TITLE
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 11 (AP)Jim McManus of Berke ley, Calif., upset Bob Carmichael of Australia today and won the Tasmanian tennis championship. The scores were 75, 64, 61.

title: Obituary of a Heroin User Who Died at 12
description: Walter Vandermeer the youngest person ever to be reported dead of an overdose of heroin herehad been identified by many of the city's leading social service agencies as a child in desper ate need of care long before his body was discovered in the common bathroom of a Harlem tenement on Dec. 14, two weeks after his twelfth birthday.

title: Hughes, Sue Bradle Capture Eastern Skating Crowns
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 11 (AP)Bob Hughes, an 18yearold New York speed skater, making his first entry into the Eastern States outdoor speed skating championships, came away with top honors today in senior men's division.

title: Austrian Offers a Simple Plan To Seek Monetary Stability
description: The head of one of Europe's smaller, but nonetheless influential, central banks has proposed a surprisingly simple, yet still imaginative, plane for international monetary re form. In a paper being circu lated privately in financial circles, Wolfgang Schmitz, president of the Austrian Na tional Bank, has suggested that the International Mone tary Fund be given new pow ers to take the initiative in devising the means to elimi nate disturbances in world money markets. form. In a paper being circu lated privately in financial circles, Wolfgang Schmitz, president of the Austrian Na tional Bank, has suggested that the International Mone tary Fund be given new pow ers to take the initiative in devising the means to elimi nate disturbances in world money markets.

title: VICTOR SURPASSES $1MILLION MARK
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 Billy Casper hit the million dollar mark in professional golf today.

title: Dapper Disciplinarian Gains Acceptance Among His Peers
description: Perhaps the 25 to 30 suits, 15 sports jackets and 22 pairs of shoes, which are part of his fourcloset ward robe, made him appear a dude. Perhaps his instant charm alienated older and lesspolished fellow coaches. Perhaps his failure to win with talent often called the best inthe sport left his abil ities suspect.

title: ROLAND R. HUMMELL
description: Roland Reed Hummel, presi dent of Taub, Hummel & Schnall Inc., customs brokers of 26 Broadway, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 40 East 78th Street.

title: Negroes and Storm Relief
description: BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 9Part of the quandary of life In the United States for the Negro has been the pattern of discrimina tion that he beholds. That he is discriminated against is un challenged. But the black man has become increasingly per plexed in recent years over whether the antecedent of this discrimination is the color of his skin or his low economic standing. The latter argu ment gained a measure of support this week during hearings held here by a Senate Public Works subcom mitte investigating the role of Federal disaster relief agencies in the aftermath of Hurricane Camille.

title: HAWKS DEAL KINGS A 3TO1 SETBACK
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) Chicago's rookie goaltender, Tony Esposito, clinched the Vezina Trophy for the first half of the National Hockey League season tonight as the Black Hawks posted a 31 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Capture of Foe's Radio Monitoring Post Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 12 (AP)  American forces have uncover ed a major North Vietnamese communications center just north of Saigon that intercepted at least 1,400 operational mes sages and presumably com promised some field operations, official sources disclosed today.

title: GRANT ANALYZES DEFEAT OF TEAM
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (AP)Coach Bud Grant had simple explanation on the loss of his Minnesota Vikings today, to the Kansas City Chiefs in the Super Bowl.

title: DAWSON RECEIVES HAIL FROM CHIEF
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (AP) Lenny Dawson had to spell his name twice for the longdis tance operator and hold a finger in his right ear to hear the Pres ident of the United States after the Chiefs' Super Bowl victory today.

title: ELLER, MARSHALL DOUBLETEAMED
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 Hank Stram, the coach of the Kansas Chiefs, disclosed today that their game plan consisted primarily of passing in front of the cornerbacks while dou bleteaming the Minnesota Vi kings' defensive ends.

title: Bank in Westchester Names 2 Executives
description: The National Bank of West chester announced over the weekend a realignment of senior management. Fred erick Sunderman was named chairman and James R. Hand president. Ralph T. Tyner, re tired chairman, remains a di rector.

title: U. S. Troops Apply Pressure in Tayninh
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  United States soldiers were reported today to be continuing to press North Vietnamese troops in Tayninh Province northwest of Saigon. A United States spokesman said that 15 of the enemy had been killed in the area where 61 North Vietnam ese were said to have died in heavy fighting yesterday.

title: Graduates Take Social Role
description: American graduate and professional schools, which Like all of higher education were buffeted by strong forces of change in the late 1960's, are facing some pro found challenges in the new decade.

title: Dissatisfied Customer
description: One of the biggest white elephants in the Pentagon's zoo of horrors is the F111 fighter bomber, now esti mated to have cost $4 billion above the original $3.3 billion projection.

title: Agnew Relaxes on Bali
description: DENPASAR, Indonesia, Jan. 11 (UPI)Vice President Agnew interrupted his official Asian tour today to relax on the island of Bali where he was entertained by dancers in sarongs. Mr. Agnew and his wife, Judy, and their party flew to Bali from Singapore for a twoday break after vis iting eight Asian countries. The Vice President will continue from Indonesia to Canberra, Australia, and Auckland, New Zealand.

title: AMERICAN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JANUARY. 12 1970

title: Temirkanov Leads Moscow Group in U.S. Debut
description: Oistrakh, Cliburn and Kon drashin were the big names at the Carnegie Hall concerts by the Moscow Philharmonic this weekend, but Yuri Temirkanov made the big news.

title: New Learning Looks Longer And Broader
description: OVER the last half decade the rising concern of the American people for better health care and greater opportunities through education have made health and education the fastest growing major components the Federal budget.

title: Classroom Indoctrination
description: The preparation by the United Federation of Teach ers of a detailed teaching unit of four lessons on the General Electric strike for use in the city's secondary schools is a flagrant abuse of the classroom.

title: Viking Defense Vexed By Backfield in Motion
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 (UPI)There were so many guys running around there in that backfield, it was hard to figure out what was going on, Roy Winston, Minne sota linebacker, said follow ing the Vikings' loss today.

title: What Kind of Education in Poor Lands?
description: India, with an average in come of 20 cents a day, a lit eracy rate of 30 per cent and a population growth that eats up most of its annual gains in agriculture and in dustry, has all the problems of a developing country.

title: Supplementary OverCounter List
Education for All an Unkept Promise
description: The strongest force for change in elementary and secondary schools in the 1970's will be pressure to do in fact what all along they have been claiming to do  to educate all the children of all the people. Until re cently school people and the public have been so im pressed by the schools' ac complishments that the fail ures have been largely over looked.

title: Personal Finance
description: Doctors, lawyers, writers, ance men, other salesmen, and or professional men belong to bankers and brokers, insur many independent business clubseating clubs, men's social clubs or country clubs, where they often en tertain business contacts.

title: Elizabeth Drew Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wallace T. Drew of London, formerly of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eliz abeth Connell Drew, to Daniel Joseph Carlsson, son of Mrs. Carol Carlsson of Edgerton, Wis. The wed ding is planned for June in Scarsdale.

title: Rubinstein and the Guarneri Quartet
description: ARTUR RUBINSTEIN may well be the most glam orous solo pianist of the gen eration, but he also likes to play chamber music. He al ways has liked chamber mu sic.
