In the 1930's he re corded with the Pro Arte Quartet, and he made an even more famous series with Jascha Heifetz and Emanuel Feuermann. Nor did he stop there. His discogra phy is dotted with the mas terworks of the chamber repertory.

title: Boy Scouts' Helpers Are Rallied for Dance
description: Mrs. George Zauderer will rally about 100 guests in her Park Avenue apartment this afternoon to inspire them to sell tickets and do other chores to bring success to the May 11 Diamond Jubilee Boy Scout dinner dance at the WaldorfAstoria.

title: Vatican Visitor to the New World
description: THE Vatican has sent to the United States, on a mission of world peace and economic development, an envoy regarded in Rome as a strong man who achieved high rank by having the taste and capacity for it.

title: Political Science Seeks New Solutions
description: The 1960's created a flood of unsolved political prob lems. The 1970's will be cry ing out for solutionsand for a modern political science capable of discovering and communicating them.

title: Riml of Austria Captures Slalom Event at Morzine
description: MORZINE, France, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  Gerhardt Riml of Austria won the slalom today at the Morzine skiing grand prix and also took the com bined title that included re sults from a downhill race yes terday.

title: Refugees Choke Roads Still Held by Biafrans
description: ULI, Biafra (Nigeria), Jan. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)  The three main roads still held by the Biafrans are choked with thousands of refugeesmen, women and children.

title: Gravediggers Break Off Wage Talks and Call Strike for Today
description: Contract negotiations were broken off yesterday as 1,700 gravediggers prepared to go on strike at 7 A.M. today in 42 nonsectarian, Roman Catholic and Jewish cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

title: Gladys L. Reilly Dies at 33; Times News Stenographer
description: Gladys L. Reilly, a pool ste nographer in the news depart ment of The New York Times, was found dead Saturday morn ing in her home at 1056 New York Avenue, Brooklyn. She was 33 years old.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: SATURDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Clemency for Dr. Matthew
description: President Nixon showed the quality of mercy by freeing Dr. Thomas W. Matthew after he had served two months of a sixmonth jail sentence for failing to file incometax returns. This wellknown neurosur geon, a Negro, had run afoul of the law because he insisted on using his personal funds to advance the work of the black selfhelp organization (NEGRO) which he heads, instead of paying Federal taxes. Punishment for violating the tax laws was entirely in order, no matter how noble his intentions; but now, after making restitution, it will be possible for him to resume his work of providing training, jobs and bus services in several communities. President Nixon's first act of executive clemency was well chosen.

title: Commandos Accuse Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 11 A gathering of Palestinian com mando groups in Amman, Jor dan, accused the Lebanese Gov ernment last night of violating the Cairo agreement of Nov. that ended two weeks of conflict between commandos and the Lebanese Army and laid down.

title: Investors Give a Lift to Credit Markets
description: The money and capital mar kets rallied last week, spurred onward by individual investors dissatisfied with lower yields on savings accounts and stocks.

title: The Present Puts History on Defense
description: Works of history pour from the presses; quality paper back sales continue to soar; there are more men and wo men in the United States who call themselves professional historians than are to be found in any other part of the world. Historical study of the United States reaches such proportions that it may soon be thought to qualify as a new light industry.

title: Powell Surprises Politicians With Report That He's Healthy
description: Representative Adam Clayton Powell said yesterday that the results of medical tests he underwent last month had shown him to be in perfect health and had cleared the way for him to seek reelection this year.

title: U.S. Envoy in Athens Gets Warning on Interference
description: ATHENS, Jan. 11 (Reuters) A proGovernment newspaper today told Henry J. Tasca, new United States envoy, that Greece was not prepared to ac cept any interference In her in ternal affairs.

title: Laura J. Shore Becomes Bride Of James Piccone in Tarrytown
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 11Miss Laura Jan Shore and James Corrado Piccone were married here this after noon at the home of Mr. and William B. Shore, parents of the bride. The Rev. Peter H. Samson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Watt Wins Ski Jumping
description: MIDDLETON, Wis., Jan. 11 (AP)Adrian Watt of Duluth, Minn., won the Blackhawk, Club's annual ski jumping lau rels today with 220.2 points on two jumps of 201 feet apiece.

title: It's Not the War News
description: In Paris during the First World War, the lieutenant in charge of Stars and Stripes, the grandfather of Army newspa pers, placed his managing edi tor, Pvt. Harold W. Ross, under arrest because of an argument over the correct use of a comma. Ross stood in the corner for awhile; then the lieutenant freed the future edi tor of The New Yorker because he didn't know how to put out the paper himself.

title: Authority Over the Public ...
description: Residents of the metropolitan area, unhappily inured to the imperious ways of the Port of New York Author ity, are discovering that the new Metropolitan Trans portation Authority can be just as arbitrary in making decisions that affect both the quality and cost of life for millions.

title: A Search for the Black Eldorado
description: TIGONI, KenyaI've been here four months, and I have to say there is no Kikuyu culture. You know, nothing you could call a real culture.

title: J.C. Kirby Peake to Wed Virginia KemballCook
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 11 Denis Basil KemballCook, president and chief executive officer of the Shell Oil Com pany, and Mrs. KemballCook have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Virginia KemballCook, to Jonathan Charles Kirby Peake, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirby Peake of Bronxville, N. Y.

title: A NEW TRADE BILL APPEARS LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Al though there has been much talk and much maneuvering, Congress has not passed any general trade legislation since 1962, the longest gap in the postwar period. The current year is likely to break that string.

title: MAYOR WILL RESUME HIS WEEKLY TV SHOW
description: Mayor Lindsay will return as host and moderator of his own weekly television program on WNEWTV at 10:30 P.M. next Sunday.

title: HUNT LAUDS DAWSON AS A GREAT PLAYER
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 Lamar Hunt, founder of the American Football League and owner of the Kansas City Chiefs, termed his team's tri umph today beyond compare with any other event in the league's decade.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Home Loan Bank Post
description: George A. Mooney has been appointed vice chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, it was announced over the weekend. Mr. Mooney is president of the Washington Heights Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: No Pickup Evident In Steel Prospects
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11With the first full week of 1970 be hind, steel makers have seen nothing to brighten their out look for the first quarter. If anything, some producers are becoming more pessimistic in their outlook.

title: 17 Campus Whites Express Their Views
description: It is a remarkable phenomenon that few, if any, American social scientists predicted the 1968 campus revolution.

title: H. Bentley Glass:
description: The next decade will per haps raise us a step above despair to a cleaner, clearer wisdom and biology cannot fail to help in this. As we become increasingly aware of the ethical problems raised by science and tech nology, the frontiers be tween the biological and social sciences are clearly of critical importance  in population density and prob lems of hunger, psychologi cal stress, pollution of the air and water and exhaus tion of irreplacable resources.

title: Deaf Youths Lend a Hand To Neediest
description: A group of deaf youngsters and the alumni club of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children dismissed their own handicaps to turn their attention to the woes and misfortunes of others.

title: Bridge:
description: THE chief executive posi tions in the American Contract Bridge League have long been filled by men with many years of experience in the game. Breaking with this tradition, the league has ap pointed 32yearold Steve Becker of Greenwich, Conn., executive editor of its Bul letin.

title: Pilot Says Situation In Biafra Is Chaotic
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 12 (UPI)The pilot of the last plane out of Biafra early today described the situation there as chaotic and said the landing strip at Uli had been bombarded for three days.

title: Sandager and Cindy Root Capture Badminton Honors
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 11 Hans Sandager of Denmark and Cindy Root of Philadelphia won the men's and women's badminton singles champion ships today in the Westchester open, the first major tourna ment of the 1970 season.

title: BIAFRA APPEARS NEAR COLLAPSE; KEY AIR LINK CUT
description: LONDON, Jan. 11Biafra's last major airstrip was reported out of action today, and Nigeria confirmed that she had taken Owerri, the Biafran secession ists' provisional capital.

title: Behavioral Field Widens Horizons
description: The behavioral sciences will be called upon in the next decade to contribute to the solution of many compli cated and pressing social problems.

title: Peking Assails Soviet on Taiwan News
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 11  Communist China denounced the Soviet Union today for de scribing Taiwan as a country and said its embassy in Mos cow had protested to the For eign Ministry against this des picable political provocation.

title: Nixon Executive Style Combines Desires for Order and Solitude
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11One day during the Eisenhower Ad ministration, Vice President Nixon came upon the President signing an immense stack of mail in his office. Mr. Nixon watched quietly for a moment and then asked the General how, with all that mail, he ever found time to think about the big problems of the country.

title: Boyle Tops Pick in Final
description: Conrad Boyle of the Seventh Regiment Armory defeated his clubmate, Pablo Pick, 1511, 1510, 1415, 1514, yesterday in the final of the City Athletic Club Class B invitation squash recquets tournament.

title: Mental Ability Linked to Childhood Diet
description: Evidence has mounted that a child receiving the wrong food or not enough food during the critical first three years of life will in all likelihood suffer some degree of permanent physical and men tal impairment.

title: Article 1  No Title
The Practical Uses of Pure Research
description: Writing about Government supported science in 1957, A. H. Dupree, the historian, said:

title: John Brademas:
description: The 91st Congress is, in several ways, assigning edu cation high priority on the nation's agenda for the sev enties.

title: Visual Impact of Winterbranch Accents a Cunningham Program
description: For a dance that can scarcely be seen clearly, Merce Cunning ham's Winterbranch has an extraordinarily powerful visual impact. It is a theatrically heightened correlative of the dimly perceived encounters that cumulate into the fabric of life. The Cunningham Company pre sented it Saturday evening for the first time during the current season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: George Dennison:
description: We Americans have suf fered such losses of humane communality that we cannot allow ourselves to see the waste of life that stares us in the face. Our very sense of crisis is often nothing more than a refined technique of avoidance. Thus we have a problem of the schools, and talk to each other solemnly about improved facilities, bet ter methods of instruction, more supervision, ignoring all the while the painful truth that what children need most is for the lives of their elders to make sense.

title: MRS. E. L PHILLIPS, EDUCATOR, 90, DIES
description: Mrs. Kathryn Sisson Phillips, an educator and the widow of Ellis L. Phillips, who was pres ident of the Long Island Light ing Company, died yesterday here. She was 90 years old and lived at 820 Fifth Avenue.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcement of deaths, marriages, births and engagements may be tele phoned to OX ford 53311 until 11 P.M, in suburban offices. 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday Newark,. (201) Market 33900: White Plains (914) WHite Plains 95509: Hempstead (516) Ivanhoe 36660: Commack (516) 5435400: Stamford (203) 3187767.

title: Police Seize Arms in Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 11 (AP)The police raided five houses in some of Sydney's most fashionable North Shore suburbs today and seized an ar senal of arms and ammunition along with Nazitype uniforms and insignia. Nazi party litera ture and recordings of Nazi marching tunes and films were also seized.

title: Harvesting Riches of the Sea
description: Photographs from outer space dramatically confirm that the predominant feature of our planet is the blue of the oceans which cover 70.8 per cent of the earth's sur face. Yet we began to explore these pervasive seasrather than the continentsonly 100 years ago.

title: Research Agency to Seek Ways to Fight Urban Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The research wing of the Government's crimefighting agency announced today plans to finance studies seeking new methods for dealing with rob bery, assault and vandalism in the nation's cities.

title: Murray GellMann:
description: I think it is essential in our day to shift certain patterns of incentives for the applica tion of science and technol ogy. One important example is the need to move away from the traditional mastery of nature for the benefit of man and toward the protec tion and restoration of our natural environment.

title: Miss Kluver Wins Slalom
description: TURIN, N. Y., Jan. 11 (AP) Katherine Kluver of St. Law rence University scored her fifth straight triumph in the women's division of the 16th annual Oneida Silversmiths' slalom races today at Snow Ridge. Miss Kluver was timed in 1 minute 47.8 seconds for the two runs through 54 gates. John Koheler of Bradford, Pa., was the victor in the men's division in 1:39.7.

title: Day Care Needs Careful Upbringing
description: The youngest and most mal leahle of Americansthose vulnerable little people rang ing from one minute to five years of ageare squarely in the middle of what is emerging as one of the more serious educational issues of the early 1970's.

title: Schools Look to Society as a Resource
description: The first point that must be recognized in discussing the future of American edu cation is that there are sev eral different problems that demand different solutions.

title: Italian Industry and Unions Wooing Women Workers
description: ROME, Jan. 11  Italian women may be bosses in their own homes, but they are often the lowliest work ers in the office or factory, where they seldom receive the equal treatment consti tutionally guaranteed.

title: CRY FOR CONTROL OF RENTS GROWS
description: Gov. Francis W. Sargent, of Massachusetts, has added his mice to the small chorus of ?? officials, mostly in the East who are asking for local rent control laws to curb rising housing costs.

title: Psychiatry in Ferment
description: The century is coming to a boil and psychiatry is thor oughly immersed in the hot water. The mental health field produces far more of this heat than is generally real ized.

title: Relics From 2 Diggings Indicate Thais Were the First Agrarians
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 11 (AP) Archeological discoveries in Thailand are disputing the es tablished theory that civiliza tion was spawned in the rich TigrisEuphrates Valley.

title: GoldSupport Plan Is Dropped for Now
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Jan. 11 Despite the concern of sev eral European central banks over the skidding price of gold, plans to establish a market floor have been at least tempo rarily spiked because of strong opposition by the United States.

title: Debbie Meyer Captures Medley Event in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 11 (AP)Debbie Meyer of Sacra mento, Calif., won for the sec ond time in four events today in the New South Wales swim ming championships. She took the open 400meter individual medley in 5 minutes 20.4 sec onds.

title: Will the Violence Beget Repression?
description: CHICAGOThe 1960's be gan with the hopeful rhetoric of John Kennedy, and histor ically more important, the attempt of four Negro stu dents in Greensboro, N. C., to buy a cup of coffee at a Woolworth's lunch counter.

title: 3 Sailors Hurt in Flash Fire
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP)Three sailors were injured, two of them seriously, in a flash fire aboard the air craft carrier Shangri  La, a Navy spokesman said today. The three, hospitalized at Jack sonville Naval Air Station, were identified as Airman Ap prentice S. B. Williams, 21 years old, of Montclair, N. J., seriously burned; Airman James E. Sexton Jr., 21, of Lacka wanna, N. Y., seriously burned, and Aviation Structural Me chanic 3d CI. George Rose, 21, of Oak Forrest. Ill.

title: Young Lords Mar Services, Including East Harlem's
description: Small groups from the Young Lords organization and their supporters disrupted morning worship services yesterday at half a dozen Methodist church es here, including the one in East Harlem that the group had occupied for 11 days. There were no arrests.

title: Education Is Key To Employability
description: The United States, with a gross national product of $942.8billion, is enjoying un precedented prosperity. Yet there are more than three mil lion unemployed youths and adults and a great many more underemployed.

title: PAUL T. GRAFF
description: FARMINGTON, Me., Jan. 11 Paul T. Graff, a former proj ect engineer in New York, Bos ton and abroad, who retired and moved here from Scarsdale, N.Y., in 1967, died here today. He was 69 years old.

title: Two Killed at Steel Plant
description: GARY, Ind., Jan. 11 (UPI) Two persons were killed, six were injured and one was re, ported missing today when gas pipe collapsed at the United States Steel Corporation plant.

title: Teaching Machines: A Long Way to Go
description: In the middle of the 1960's it was freely predicted that technology would remake the schools and colleges in the following decade. Hardware and software (a rather unfor tunate word to describe intel lectual content) would com bine either to replace the teacher or to make him more efficient, or both.

title: M'CARTHY ENDS VISIT AFTER KOSYGIN TALK
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11 Senator Eugene J. McCarthy met for 90 minutes with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin today and later said the discussion covered general problems between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Sound of Deflating Footballs Accentuates Gloom in Vikings' Dressing Room
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 Joe Kapp's tan suit was hang ing on a hook in the corner of the dressing room, but the Minnesota quarterback was out in a trainer's room having his injured left shoulder inspected. He is expected to take Xrays tomorrow morning before fly. ing home.

title: GREECE ITEMIZES I.O.S. COMPLAINTS
description: ATHENS, Jan. 11The Greek judicial authorities are inves tigating preliminary charges involving 10 criminal offenses by representatives and sales men of Investors Overseas Ser vices, Ltd., the giant Geneva based mutual fund organization, for alleged illegal transactions in Greece.

title: Sports of The Times
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 11A tall man in a suede trenchcoat, his shoulders hunched into a wet wind, crossed a busy street against a Don't Walk sign. Half a block away, someone said, That's Bill Bradley, coach. Can't you teach him to cross at the green? Coach Red Holzman shrugged, That's nothing. He doesn't even know what city he's in.

title: Israel Offers to Exchange 18 Lebanese
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 11Israel formally notified Lebanon to day that the price for the re turn of 18 Lebanese prisoners still held after a recent Israeli commando raid was the release of an Israeli watchman ab ducted by. Arab guerrillas a few days earlier.

title: Nigerian War at a Glance
description: THE COUNTRYAfrica's most populous state, Nigeria is on the western bulge of the continent just north of the Equator. Independent from Britain since 1960; rich in nat ural resources, including oil, coal and iron. The 55 million to 60 million people, in a territory larger than Texas and Oklahoma combined, comprise several hundred tribal and linguistic groups.

title: Philippines Air Crash Kills Grandson of Wartime Chief
description: MANILA, Jan. 11 (AP)  Jaime Laurel, 31, grandson of Jos P. Laurel, who headed the Japanese puppet government in the Philippines during World War II, was killed today in a helicopter crash.

title: C.B.S. Fills Post
description: Robert M. Rice has been ap pointed vice president, finance, Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., effective Feb. 16. He for merly was with the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, where he had been vice president, director of fi nances and controller, I.T.T. Europe and I.T.T. assistant con troller.

title: Charles I. Foltz:
description: Just 29 per cent of our population lives in rural areas, bid 41 per cent of the nation's poor live there. And one of each four persons in these sections is classified as Door.

title: Dawson Keeps His Cool After Game, Too, as Week of Inner Torment Ends
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 When the Super Bowl game ended, Len Dawson was the first of the Kansas City Chiefs to enter their locker room. Typically, his boyish face was expressionless.

title: Psychologists Advance Efforts to Probe the Mind
description: The complementary themes of growth and differentiation are among the most profound and puzzling attributes of liv ing systems. There are two great con troversies surrounding the growth and differentiation of the human mind.

title: Inflation Is Called A Yugoslav Threat
description: PARIS, Jan. 11Yugoslavia is poised for rapid economic ex pansion in 1970, but like capi talist countries it must guard against inflation, the Organiza tion for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: Foundations Face Uncertain Future
description: Philanthropic foundations, accused of doing too much for themselves and too little for society, have in the last year been more stringently criti cized, more feverishly defend ed and more extensively regu lated by Congress than at any time in their halfcentury of existence.

title: GOODELL ASSAILS U.S. MIDEAST PLAN
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell accused the State Department yesterday of unfairly favoring the Arab states in its policy on the Middle East.

title: Music: Flair for the Camerata Singers
description: ABRAHAM KAPLAN and his Camerata Singers and Symphony Orchestra gave a very spiffy concert last night in Philharmonic Hall. The program was interest ing, the solo work of a high order, and the execution lively. Mr. Kaplan has real flair, and he makes music with exuberance. There is a feeling of real commitment in his work.

title: HAWKINS, GOODRICH PACE SUNS' VICTORY
description: OMAHA, Jan. 11 (AP)  Connie Hawkins and Gail Goodrich combined for 75 points to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 125118 victory over the Cincinnati Royals in the National Basketball Association tonight.

title: Laotian Front Has Hanoi Unit
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)An information bureau of the pro Communist Laotian Patriotic Front was opened here last night.

title: REDS BACK MOVE FOR HIGHER RATES
description: The pressure for higher In terest rates has spread to the Communist world where low interest ratesor no interest charge at allwere once ideo logical fundamentals.

title: Margaret Jo Printz of Boston Wed
description: BOSTON, Jan. 11Miss Margaret Jo Printz, former community services director of WBZTV, was married here this afternoon at the Sheraton Plaza Hotel to Paul Michael Steinle. Mr. Steinle, the Saigon bureau chief for the Westinghouse Broadcast ing Company, was formerly an awardwinning producer and reporter for WBZ, the local Westinghouse channel here. Rabbi Burton Padoll performed the ceremony.

title: Involuntary Confinement Of Mentally Ill Opposed
description: An end to involuntary com mitments to mental hospitals was advocated yesterday by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Thant Asks for Nigeria Data
description: LOME, Togo, Jan. 11 (Reut ers)Secretary General Thant of the United Nations, arriving here today on his marathon tour of African countries, asked reporters to keep him informed of every development in Ni geria.

title: A New Humanism Outside Humanities
description: I am not very sanguine about the survival of the of ficial, formal study of the humanities.

title: Welfare Toughness Charged
description: The city Social Services Department's union of case workers and aides charged yesterday that a get tough policy was under way against applicants for relief, and it called on Mayor Lindsay to investigate the agency.

title: Computer Spurring Research
description: In the last third of the 20th century, mathematics has be come the key tool in almost all of the physical and so cial sciences. A high degree of mathematical knowledge is now expected routinely not only of physicists and chem ists but also of biologists, economists, sociologists and even some historians and po litical scientists.

title: A Catholic Paper in Madrid Backs SpanishSoviet Ties
description: MADRID, Jan. 11 (Reuters) The influential Roman Catholic daily Ya called today for the establishment of diplomatic re lations between Spain and the Soviet Union.

title: Time for Nigerian Compassion
description: Surprising comebacks have been so much a part the Nigerian civil war that some caution is still advisable toward reports of the full collapse of the secessionist Biafran Army. Yet the capture of the pro visional capital of Owerri by federal forces, the appar ent flight of General Ojukwu, the rebel leader, and the destruction of the key Biafran airstrip at Uli all provide impressive evidence of massiveand perhaps conclusivemilitary gains for the central government in Lagos. The world will hope that the cruel suffering on both sides is about to end.

title: NORTON SIMON, INC., WILL MOVE TO CITY
description: Norton Simon, Inc., one of the nation's largest corpora tions, will move its world head quarters to New York City from Fullerton, Calif., by the middle of the year, the Mayor's office announced yesterday.

title: Hellenic Lines Buys 2 Ships
description: Hellenic Lines Ltd. has an nounced it has purchased two 4,750ton Dutch cargo ships for a total of $900,000.

title: Laird Says Nixon Hopes to Phase Out School Deferments
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Nixon Administration would propose this year a gradual elimination of student and occupational draft deferments.

title: Perils and Promise of College for All
description: Predicting changes for pub lic higher education and the State University of New York is, in a way, a whim sical undertaking. Yet, the outlines of certain develop ments seem reasonably clear.

title: LEIBOWITZ ENVISIONS DEATH PENALTY HERE
description: Samuel S. Leibowitz, who re tired on Dec. 31 as a justice of the State Supreme Court, pre dicted yesterday that capital punishment would be reinstated in New York State. The death penalty was abolished in the state in 1965.

title: Msgr. James C. Donahue:
description: The 1970's will witness a growing demand for di versity, competition, and freedom of choice in educa tion. As school becomes a more central part of human development the monopolis tic nature of American ele mentary and secondary edu cation will become intoler able to an increasingly large number of parents.

title: Senator's Son Wins Seat
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 11 (AP)  Hiram L. Fong Jr., 30yearold son of Hawaii's senior United States Senator, has won a seat in the Hawaii House. A special election yesterday was held af ter a series of recounts and court suits followed the 1968 election's close results. Unof ficial returns showed Mr. Fong a Republican, with 6,924 votes and Clarence Akizaki, a Demo crat, with 6,786.

title: Social Theories Awaiting Resolution
description: Theoretical knowledge is a central and crucial feature in the post  industrial society, Whose lineaments are now be ginning to emerge in the United States. It is the source of innovation and policy making.

title: 40CENT FARE IN '72 FORESEEN BY KHEEL
description: The subway and bus fares could go to 40 cents within two years and 75 cents by 1980 un less subsidies are increased, two transit experts said yes terday.

title: Pope Prays That the Nigerians Won't Massacre Biafran Rebels
description: ROME, Jan. 11Pope Paul VI termed reports from the Nige rian civil war very alarming today and prayed that there would be no slaughter of Bi afrans by Nigerians.

title: Educational Cohesion A Must for the Future
description: We hear from many sides today that the American educational system is in trouble. Such a message is chilling be cause support of education is our prom ise to our children that we will prepare them effectively for that unknown fu ture that lies between us and the year 2000.

title: Refugees Flee to Island
description: LISBON, Jan. 11One hun dred and two refugees from, Biafra were flown out of the war zone last night to the Portuguese island of So Tome official sources said here to night. They were missionaries nuns, relief workers for Joint Church Aid, as well as Bia frans.

title: To Many, Moderation Is the Path to Change
description: MARIETTA, OhioRevolution is not in style at Marietta College. It never really has been, either at Marietta or at a majority of colleges and universities across the United States.

title: EgyptianSoviet Trade Rises
description: CAIRO, Jan. 11 (AP)Has san Abbaas Zaki, the Egyptian Minister of Economy and For eign Trade, said today that the EgyptianSoviet trade agree ment for 1970 had been in creased by $46million. Mr. Zacki, who returned from Mos cow yesterday after signing the agreement, said the new fig ure, a record, was $391million.

title: TALKS SCHEDULED ON JAIL CROWDING
description: State Senator John R. Dunne said yesterday that the heads of the city and state correc tions systems would meet to morrow to work out details for transferring some prisoners from overcrowded city institu tions to state facilities.

title: In Health, the Accent Switches to Prevention
description: WASHINGTONIf the hopes and ex pectations of medical scientists come true, the 1970's will be most notable for the things that don't happen, not for the things that do.

title: Philosophy's Ivory Tower Is Crumbling
description: Since World War II the major influence on American philosophy has been exerted by British analytic philoso phy, which forswears the large speculative syntheses of previous philosophic systems, and seeks instead a piece meal solution of philosophic problems.

title: Chess:
SKI JUMP VICTORY SCORED BY KONNO
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 11Bruce Jennings of the Uni versity of Wyoming turned in the day's longest flight, 233 feet, but the superlative effort failed to keep Japan's colors from the top for the second straight time as the Kennedy Memorial International ski jumping event was staged to day.

title: Miss Gross Is Wed Here To Engineer
description: Miss Jessica Beth Gross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Gross of Bayside, Queens, was married here yesterday to John Otto Schairer, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Swift Schairer of Bellevue, Wash. The cere mony was performed by Rabbi Arthur Gilbert at the Croydon.

title: City U. Faces Up to the Urban Realities
description: Unlike its privately support ed counterpart, the public uni versity in America has long been regarded as an agency of social change as well as a repository, conveyer and ex pander of knowledge. Today this responsibility is especial ly acute for the public univer sity in the city, the locus of our most vexing social prob lems. For the foreseeable future, Institutions like the City Uni versity of New York will be expected to respond more rapidly and directly to condi tions in their urban environ ment. The great private insti tutions, with a rising share of their support coming from the public purse, will also find their shape altered by the needs of a much broader con stituency than the one they previously had served.

title: Ocean Hill Struggles for Identity
description: The rhetoric: Community Control. The Commitment: Selfdetermination through participation. The place: Ocean HillBrownsville in Brooklyn.

title: Yemeni Executions Reported
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, Jan. 11Two Yemenis were publicly beheaded today in Liberation Square in Sana, the Sana radio reported in a broadcast heard here. They had been convicted of laying mines in civilian roads, the report said. It added that the bodies were then crucified and hung from one of the seven gates of the city. The report said crowds watched the execution, the first public be heading in Yemen since 1968.

title: WEST'S JUMP TAKES JERSEY SKI TROPHY
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 11  Don West, a 32yearold mathematics teacher from Plattsburg State Teachers Col lege zoomed out from the Vet erans' Class today to take top honors in the New Jersey ski jumping Championship.

title: Met Introduces Skrowaczewski In Zauberflote
description: The Metropolitan Opera ac quired a new conductor on Saturday night with the sea sonal introduction into the repertory of Mozart's Die Zauberflote. He is Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, music direc tor of the Minnesota Orches tra, and his work in this per formance indicated that he will be a strong addition to the Metropolitan's musical staff.

title: Nixon Consults Wilson
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The White House announced readiness today for an expan sion of civilian relief opera tions in Nigeria and proposed a strengthening of internation al observer teams to ward off feared atrocities against Biaf ran refugees.

title: Philippine Quake Reported
description: MANILA, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  An earthquake of moderate intensity shook parts of Minda nao Island in the Southern Philippines Saturday but there were no immediate reports in Manila of damage or casualties. Intial reports said buildings had swayed in the threesecond quake.

title: London: Old Theater Myth, New Toys
description: LONDONThe London the ater is famous throughout the Englishspeaking world for its adventurous, outspo ken, taboobreaking young playwrights, its new genera tion of gutsy, forceful, virile performers, its willingness to take a chance on fresh, un tried talents. Or so the visi tors wno surge in to sample these much  advertised bargains have been led to believe. There is no doubt that playgoing here is much more of a posi tive, physical pleasure than it is in New York. Seats are half to a third the price. Scalping is unknown and tickets for even the biggest hit can be obtained, at a maximutn of 10 days' notice, from efficient, reputable agen cies, which add no more than 75 cents to the bill. As you pass through the lobbies on Broadway, you feel you are being counted, processed and canned like so many peas. The scowling men on the door, in their hard hats and overcoats, manage to give the, impression, that, once you're inside, they will bolt the doors and decamp with, the takirigs for Miami. You feel you are grossly inconvenienc ing the staff by staying on to see the show.

title: Health Care Faces Severest Demands
description: Whatever else it may wit ness, the nineteenseventies will see the most severe test of America's capacity to de liver decent health care to those who need it.

title: To Solve Problem, First Define It
description: I RECENTLY began an article in The American Scholar with a statement by George Bernanos that the worst, the most corrupting of lies are problems poorly stated. I will do the same with these notes on the subject How to get things done?, contending that the crucial phase in solving a problem is the process by which it comes to be defined.

title: Bent Gets Second and First To Win Big Bromley Slalom
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 11 (AP)  Chuck Bent of Dart mouth won the 23d Louise Orvis slalom ski derby today at Big Bromley.

title: Answer for Disadvantaged Is Effective Teaching
On Campus, the Gap Persists
description: The above quote comes prom an interview with a Druze agriculturalist, aged 72, and a resident on the Is raelioccupied Golan Heights. His description of the genera tion gap in his family has been echoed by many of the older men that I have inter viewed as part of my re search on the psychology of later life.

title: GEORGE PERCY, WON MEDAL ON IWO JIMA
description: George A. Percy, a retired stockbroker and a Marine vet eran of both World Wars, who won the Navy Cross for extra ordinary heroism at Iwo Jima in 1945, died Saturday at Bruns wick Hospital, Amityville, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: CHANGES WEIGHED ON IMPORTED OIL
description: Prospective changes in oil import controls will not have much of an effect on the profits of most domestic integrated petroleum companies, accord ing to a study released over the weekend by Equity Research Associates, Inc., a brokerage and investment advisory con cern.

title: U.S. TEAM IN PARIS RENEWS PRESSURE FOR PEACE TALKS
description: PARIS, Jan. 11The United States delegation to the Viet nam peace talks here is step ping up its pressure on the Communist side to negotiate an end to the war.

title: The Burdens of Technology
description: In the last 25 years, tech nology has become increas ingly a subject for discussion in the Western world. Young and old people are question ing the values of technologi cal progress; the accusation is that technology deals only with material values and pays no attention to other values that have to do with peace of mind, love, happi ness, even contemplation.

title: The Theater: Duberman's Memory Bank Opens
Sesame Opens Door to Knowledge
description: There is a young and impressionable mind out there that is very hungry for information, and very capable of receiv ing and storing it, in large doses, begin ning noticeably soon after birth. It has latched on to an electronic tube as its main source of nourishment.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Plight of City People

title: Statistics of the Game
Canadiens Rout Rangers, 41, Getting Goal 17 Seconds After Start
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 11  Ca nadien lightning, by a French man named Sheehan no less, jolted the Rangers awake early today, and the New Yorkers, failing to cope with the situ ation, dropped a 41 decision to the champions.

title: Schools Hire Own Guards As Violence Rises Sharply
description: Crime and violence appear to have increased sharply in public schools in urban areas.

title: I.O.S. Denies Violating Law
description: GENEVA, Jan. 11Investors Overseas Services Ltd., rejected tonight all suggestions that it had been engaged in illegal ac tivities in Greece.

title: Biological Goal: Human Welfare
description: It is almost as difficult to make a succinct forecast of the seventies as it would be to encapsulate the scientific riches of the expiring decade in a few paragraphs.

title: Caledonian No. 1 Captures Douglas Medal in Curling
description: MT. HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 11 The New York Caledonian Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Vernon Hambly, the 1968 winning skip, captured the 35th annual Douglas Medal bonspiel championship today.

title: Stafford's 290 Wins in Golf
description: FREEPORT, Bahamas, Jan. 11 (AP)Roland Stafford of Ve rona, Pa., shot a 73 today for an aggregate of 290 and won the 72hole fifth annual Grand Bahama open golf tournament by two strokes.

title: Clock Watching Became His Career
description: JOSEPH FANELLI has time on his hands  literally. Mr. Fanelli is the owner of Clocks & Things, a new ven ture at 209 Columbus Avenue (near 69th Street) where he sells and repairs old clocks. The & Things refers to his wife Cindy's small but well priced collection of antique jewelry and as sorted oddments the couple have collected to give customers an ex cuse to browse at leisure. Buying a clock is like buying a piece of furniture, Mr. Fanelli explained on a re cent, snowy morning. A cou ple may come back two or three times before they make up their mind about whether a certain clock will fit in with their scheme of living.

title: New Frontiers for the Atom
description: There is no doubt that the 1970's will be a turbulent era for nuclear energy, as it will be for many of the technolo gies that affect our society so profoundly.

title: LINDSAY PRAISED BY MORGENTHAU
description: Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday that he believed May or Lindsay would make a good Governor but hastened to add that he had no reason to be lieve that the Mayor might be a candidate for the office.

title: Medical Center Names Damrosch to New Post
description: Dr. Douglas S. Damrosch has been appointed to the newly created post of direc tor of the ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center, the institution announced yester day.

title: Crash Kills 36 in Colombia
description: Bogota, Colombia, Jan. 11 (UPI)A passenger train struck a bus at a crossing near Santa Marta today, killing 36 persons on the bus.

title: Story of Secessionist Biafra: Tribal Hatreds, Civil War and Starvation
description: LONDON, Jan. 11  Biafra ?? born at 2 A.M. on May 1967, when the Eastern Re ??on of Nigeria was proclaimed ??n independent, sovereign state by the leader of the Ibo tribe and the symbol of resistance, Odumegwu Ojukwu. Five weeks later eight battalions of Nige rian troops attacked Biafra, beginning a desperate civil war ??hat has lasted for two and a ??alf years.

title: Human Ecology and Ethics Are Inseparable
description: The 21st century may witness a world of halfstarved, depressed human masses, gasping for air, short of sweet water, struggling to avoid the constant pres ence of one another, living at a degraded, subsistence level with all those fellow creatures that now share our planet either exterminated or domesticated and bred out of any resemblance to what they once were.

title: Sciences May Beggar Predictions
description: THE transistorized crystal ball of the scientist is no more uptodate than the silent shimmer of the poet's. They share the same ancient modes of operation, and they both use only two means: continuity and analogy.

title: Tijuana Smalls Aim at Swingers
description: Tijuana Smalls, which might sound like a pot prod uct but isn't, is being intro duced today in Boston by the General Cigar Company with the aid and comfort of Ogilvy & Mather.

title: Bertelsmann Forms Unit
description: The Bertelsmann Group of West Germany has established a North American subsidiary, MohnBertelsmann Corporation, at 620 Fifth Avenue. The new company will be headed by Otto A. Kaletsch as president and Claus F. Rossin as general manager of sales and opera tions. It will act as marketing affiliate of the parent company, which is one of the largest communications enterprises in Europe.

title: Article 3  No Title
NIAGARA QUINTET STAYS UNBEATEN
description: The nation's list of major unbeaten college basketball teams remained at five Satur day night and four of them the University of California; Los Angeles; Jasksonville, Ken tucky and St. Bonaventure held down the first four spots in scoring. The fifth team and the one that least figured to be unbeaten is Niagara.

title: Biafran Aide Refuses Comment
description: LISBON, Jan. 11The Bia fran mission in Lisbon would make no comment today on the new Nigerian offensive, except to say that Telex com munications with Biafra had been maintained.

title: Wives Proud of BestDressed Husbands
description: THE women who are named on it may appear to be blas, and the men can't per mit themselves to be carried away. But the International Best Dressed List, which has emanated from Eleanor Lambert's office in New York since the Paris version went out of business at the start of World War II, has ac quired a new group of shame less enthusiasts.

title: Cleaver Aide Back in U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Ian. 11 (UPI)An aide to Eldridge Cleaver, the Black Panther lead er, returned to the United States today, but the fugitive militant's wife and infant son canceled their flight from Al giers at the last minute. Emory Douglas, minister of culture for the Panthers, told newsmen waiting for Mrs. Kathleen Cleaver that she had decided to remain in the Algerian capi tal with her husband.

title: COLUMBIA PLANS AN ETHNIC SCHOOL
description: Columbia University's Urban Center proposed yesterday the creation of a new School of National Studies on the Morn ingside Heights campus to teach ethnic and urban affairs.

title: DUNAS DANCES JOB AT JUDSON CHURCH
description: For almost two years, William Dunas has been presenting a series of performances that saw a relatively conventional dance solo expand into a string of dra matic images linked by black outs) offering a casebook view of a man suffering in solitude.

title: France Asks for U.S. Aid In Protection of Biafrans
description: PARIS, Jan. 11Foreign Min ister Maurice Schumann of France asked for United States cooperation today in an inter national effort to protect the Biafran population.

title: F. P. BARTLETT, 60, FORMER DIPLOMAT
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 11 Frederic P. Bartlett, who re tired in 1964 as director of the Bureau of West African Affairs in the State Department, died Saturday at the University of North Carolina Memorial Hos pital. He was 60 years old.

title: Biologists Try to Learn Exactly How We Learn
description: Since the ability to learn and remem ber is so prominent a characteristic of man and the higher animals, determin ing the basis of this ability is crucial is a thorough understanding of behavior.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lerlding agencies here:

title: Population (2) of Aroya, Colo., Halved, Making Room for Weeds
description: AROYA, Colo.  Marvin Sargent, 78 year old, sat in the tiny living room of his small stucco house in what is left of downtown Aroya.

title: Laird Disclaims Koreans' Acts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that alleged atrocities by South Korean troops against South Vietnam ese civilians were not the re sponsibility of the United States command in Vietnam.

title: Col. Kelly Still Critical
description: SOUTH AMBOY, N. J., Jan. 11Col. David B. Kelly, super intendent of the New Jersey state police, remained in criti cal condition today in South Amboy Memorial Hospital fol lowing a heart attack yester day.

title: George B. Kistiakowsky:
description: As the decade of the sev enties begins the American public is voicing doubts and skepticism about the social values of science and science based technologies. It is my hope, indeed my optimistic expectation, that well before the end of the seventies our public opinion will swing so that science with its techno logical offspring will again be endorsed as an essential al though certainly net the sole contributor to social progress.

title: Opera Bus Fare Raised
description: The fare of the special Met ropolitan Opera bus service from the opera house to the East Side after nightly per formances has been raised from 50 cents to 75 cents. Also, the fare must be paid with exact change.

title: What Giant Steps Left for Science?
description: In a recent attempt to look down the road of future scientific and technologi cal development, Dr. J. Tuzo Wilson, head of Erindale College at the Univer sity of Toronto, noted that the first half of this century had produced two of the most fundamental discoveries in the history of science: relativity and quantum mechanics.

title: A Program of Priorities For the Coming Decade
description: Fundamentally, the goal of America in the 1970's with respect to education can be no different than it has been in any other decadenamely, to guarantee each individual throughout his life a full and equal opportunity to secure the skills, the knowledge and the under standing necessary to fulfill himself as an individual and as a constructive member of society.

title: RESTRICTIVE PLAN ON BANKS FOUGHT
description: Heavy pressure is being brought to bear on the Federal Reserve Board to abandon, or at least defer, its proposal to bar bank holding companies from raising funds in the money market through the sale of commercial paper. The result could be a general over haul, not only of the commer cial paper proposal, but of the Reserve's overall approach to the regulation of the payment of interest on deposits.

title: Turnpike Hearing Postponed
description: The date for the start of National Transportation Safety Board hearings on the New Jersey Turnpike chainreaction collisions and fire on Nov. 29 that took six lives has been postponed from tomorrow to Feb. 3. Twentyfive witnesses are expected to testify at the Board of Inquiry hearing at Cherry Hill Inn, Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: . . . but No Better Service
description: The most galling part of the higher transit and com mutation fares is that the riders can count on no improvement in service. Ontime performance on the subway has been slipping badly, with no basis for con fidence that the trend will be reversed. Needed mainte nance is being skimped, and motormen are being put on the road with much less yard training than they ought to have for passenger safety.

title: An Apartment That's Furnished With Memories of Other Places
description: WHEN Budd Schulberg wrote his first novel, What Makes Sammy Run? in; 1941, Louis B. Mayer, the pep pery movie magnate, was furious at its unflattering view of Hollywood. He went to his friend and former partner, B. P. Schulberg and said that his 27yearold son was a traitor to his class and should be deported.

title: KANSAS CITY BEATS MINNESOTA BY 237 IN ME SUPER BOWL
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11  Kansas City was all Chiefs and no Indians on the field today as the American League cham pions upset the Minnesota Vikings, 237 in the Super Bowl game before 80,998 fans at Tulane Stadium.

title: Snow and Rain Hit Italy
description: ROME, Jan. 11 (AP)Heavy snow and rain fell in northern Italy from Genoa to the Dolo mite Alps today, triggering avalanches and floods. About 150 passengers were tempor arily trapped in a train north of Genoa after the tracks were blocked by fallen trees and power lines.

title: Scalpers Soaked as Rains Pass
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11The fans stayed safe and dry today as neither rain nor tornado descended upon them during the city's first Super Bowl. Only the scalp ers appeared to be taking a bath.

title: Canada Resumes ColdWeather Test of Turbotrain
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 11 (Ca nadian Press)  Canada's first turbinepowered passenger train has made the first in a long series of coldweather tests, after failing to make the grade last winter.

title: New Transit Plan to Aid Job Holders in L.I. Areas
description: The TriState Transportation Commission plans to add two services to its project of pro viding public transportation to Long Island places of employ ment situated outside central business districts.

title: A Tyrolean Tip to Dawson
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (UPI) Bart Starr, the Green Bay Packers' quarterback who has played in two Super Bowl games, showed up for the one here today in a Swissstyle Tyrolean hat and tipped it to Len Dawson, Kansas City quar terback. Fantastic, he said of Dawson's performance. Abso lutely fantastic.

title: William O. Baker:
description: Until relatively recently, re search strategy has been largely what could be called components research and dis coverysomeone discovers a virus, or invents a laser, or synthesizes a molecule.

title: Task for 70's: To Be At Home in Space.
description: Man made at least two discoveries in the sixties that are bound to influence his life for the rest of the century.

title: Stenerud the Man With a Kick, Season's Top Scorer for Chiefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (UPI) Jan Stenerud, who kicked field goals of 48, 32 and 25 yards for Kansas City today in the Chiefs' upset victory over Minnesota in the Super Bowl game, was the Chiefs' leading scorer during the 1969 regular season with 119 points.

title: Britons Plan to Raise Titanic Electronically
description: BALDOCK, England, Jan. 11  A group of salvage en thusiasts today announced plans to raise the liner Titanic, which sank in 1912 when it hit an iceberg about 430 miles southeast of New foundland.

title: CAHILL PROPOSES A 5% SALES LEVY IN BUDGET CRISIS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12  Gov ernorelect William T. Cahill warned today that New Jersey faced a major state fiscal cri sis and said that the exist ing 3 per cent state sales tax must be increased to 5 per cent.

title: LEBANON TO ARM BORDER VILLAGES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 12 The Lebanese Government de cided tonight on a new defense policy to counter Israeli attacks on the southern border.

title: Joint Concern Is Planned
description: PitneyBowes, Inc., and the Alpex Computer Corporation announced yesterday plans for formation of a jointlyowned company to manufacture and sell computerized pointofsale register systems developed by Alpex. The new company will be known as PitneyBowes Alpex Inc., with Alpex putting substantially all of its assets into the new venture, while PitneyBowes will put in $9.5 million in cash.

title: Strain Sees Strong Interleague Rivalry Continuing Despite Pros' Merger
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 In a glow of satisfaction, Hank Stram, coach of the world champion Kansas City Chiefs, predicted today that there would always be a strong rivalry between the American and National League teams de spite the merger of the 26 pro football clubs under the National League banner next season.

title: Burials Stalled as Gravediggers Strike
description: Burials were halted yester day in all but six cemeteries in the metropolitan area as 1,700 gravediggers went on strike in 44 Roman Catholic, Jewish and nonsectarian ceme teries.

title: COURT REBUFFS BID BY FIEDLER'S SON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) The Supreme Court refused to review today the conviction of a Buffalo man who was ar rested after a police spy had operated In his home for sev eral weeks.

title: DUTCH PRELATES DISOBEYED POPE
description: ROME, Jan. 12The Dutch bishops who abstained in a vote on mandatory celibacy for priests last week had been urged by Pope Paul VI to take a firm stand in favor of celi bacy and other contested points of doctrine.

title: 23 Men Die in Fiery Crash Of Greek Military Plane
description: ATHENS, Jan. 12Only four of 22 Greek Army rangers aboard a Dakota transport fly ing them for a parachute prac tice drop survived today when the plane crashed and burst into flames on a mountain, 43 miles northwest of Athens. Twentythree soldiers and crew members were killed.

title: Advertising: D.D.B. Gets Acquisition Chief
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach has hired a Wall Street specialist in venture capital invest ments and put him in charge of its own acquisitions. That probably makes this publicly held company the first agency to have a fulltime man with this kind of assign ment.

title: Music: Romantics by Sidney Foster
description: SIDNEY FOSTER went ro mancing last night in Tully Hall. The American pianist built his program around three big romantic works Chopin's F minor Ballade, the Liszt Sonata and Scriabin's Ninth Sonataand surround ed them with romantic trifles of the sort our grandparents loved.

title: UpsideDown Flag Leads L.I. Housewife to Trouble
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 12 A 26yearold mother of two who had been searched, handcuffed and fingerprinted before being released in $500 bail for having flown the American flag upside down in an antiwar protest was freed from bail today and will stand trial on March 17.

title: About 100 Europeans And Americans in Biafra
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Jan. 12 (AP)Estimates by relief workers today put the num ber of Europeans and North Americans left in Biafra at fewer than 100. Most are missionaries. Eight Red Cross workers also remained in the besieged areas. They were listed as six Frenchmen, a Briton and a Yugoslay.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: At Cat Cay
description: OAT CAY, BahamasHis lean flanks gleaming in the bright afternoon sun, 3foot barracuda twisted out of the water twice before we brought him to gaff and gingerly plucked the silver spoon he had mistaken for a baitfish from his long, sharp toothed jaws

title: Nixon Seeking to Prevent Starvation and Reprisals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The United States took eco nomic and diplomatic steps today to help avert mass starva tion in Biafra and the possibility of reprisals against the Biafrans following their surrender to the Nigerian forces.

title: EYES OF ROSSINI ARE UPON TEXAS
description: Lou Rossini, seeking a panacea for future New York University basketball teams, spent the weekend recruiting in Texas. The Violet coach and Harry Kotcher, a lawyer and N.Y.U. alumnus, flew there to watch the powerful Wheatley High School team and its star, Dwight Jones. They also viewed the talent at Kilgore Junior Col lege. They came away with high praise and hopes.

title: Court Rejects Suit by Citizens Seeking to Bar 30Cent Fare
description: A legal challenge to the 10 cent increase in the transit fare was dismissed yesterday by state judge, who ruled that the Transit Authority could act in its judgment alone in raising fares.

title: Copper Producers Hail Inquiry Into Cause of Sharp Price Rise
description: American copper producers indicated yesterday that they were not only willing but also eager to explain to a White House committee why copper prices had been rising sharply in the last few years.

title: City Accepts $222Million Bid For 13.7Mile Water Tunnel
description: The city announced yester day the award of a $222, 593,477 contract for a 13.7 mile water tunnel, the largest addition to the water distribu tion system in 35 years.

title: DE CARLO DEFENSE IS BALKED AGAIN
description: NEWARK, Jan. 12A second defense lawyer in the extortion conspircy trial of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, reputed Mafia figure, failed yesterday to shake the testimony of a key Gov ernment witness.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAME

title: Miss Carol E. Werber Fiancee of John Frost
description: RUMSON, N. J., Jan. 12 The engagement of Miss Carol Elizabeth Werber to John Hall Frost has been an nounced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jerome Werber. Her fianc is the son of. Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Raymond Frost of Waterford, Conn.

title: Harvard Chooses Watson As New Athletic Director
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 12 Robert B. Watson, dean of students in Harvard College for six years and chairman of the faculty committee on athletic sports, will become Harvard's director of athletics on Sept. 1. He was acting director of athletics in 1960 and 1961.

title: AUSTRALIAN BANK PLANS U.S. OFFICE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 12 To facilitate the rapidly ex panding commercial contact between the United States and Australia through banking channels, the Bank of New South Wales  Australia's big gestannounced today that it would open a New York of fice shortly.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Theater: Hair Moves Into Toronto
Pakistan and Poland in Pact
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 12 Pakistan and Poland will ex change goods worth nearly $47million in 1970 under terms of an agreement signed today at Islamabad.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: S. Donald Wiley, general counsel of the H. J. Heinz Com pany, has been named a cor porate vice president. His new title will be vice president and general counsel.

title: Observer: Tool Meanness
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Tools follow very interesting laws. Consider the most irri tating of all, which is the tendency of tools to gather in houses where they will never have to work.

title: Rotz Hurt in Spill at Tropical; 2 Injured Horses Are Destroyed
description: MIAMI, Jan. 12 (AP)John Rotz was badly bruised today in a bad spill at Tropical Park involving three horses and riders. Two of the horses had to be destroyed.

title: Jeannette Replaces. Clark As Coach of Pipers Quintet
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12 (UPI) John Clark, 32yearold rookie head coach of the Pittsburgh Pipers, was replaced today, by Harry E. (Middy) Jeannette, who also is American Basketball Association team's director of operations.

title: The Theater
Drive Planned to Halt Radiation From Ovens
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. A national drive to find and repair microwave ovens that leak radiation was projected today by Government and industry Pepresentatives.

title: In The Nation: Talking Tough in Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The toughest problem for President Nixon in pursuing Vietnamiza tion of the war may not be those domestic critics who think that, at best, the scheme will take too long and, at worst, that it is a plan for fighting a proxy war ad infinitum. Presi dent Thieu of South Vietnam is likely to cause more trouble than any of these unheeded voices.

title: PROFIT IS UP 15% AT HARSCO CORP.
Gunman Wounds Four in Garment Area Hiring Hall
description: A grayhaired and grimly si lent gunman strode into a hir ing hall in the heart of the garment district yesterday and opened fire on a crowd of un employed cutters, wounding four, two of them seriously.

title: Tampa Electric Profit Up
description: The Tampa Electric Company reported yesterday net income of $15,549,801, equal to $1.37 a share, for 1969. This com pared with $13,230,041, or $1.18 a share, in the preced ing year. The figures were con tained in a preliminary annual report, subject to future audit. The utility serves electricity in a radius around. Tampa on the West Coast of Florida.

title: Hearing Seton Voting Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) A Senate Judiciary subcom mittee will start a new round of hearings Jan. 27 on voting rights legislation. Last month the House, by a vote of 208 to 203, substituted a proposal by President Nixon that would make the Voting Rights Act of 1965 apply nationwide for A bill that would have extended the law for five years.

title: Hancock Life Elects Chiefs
description: The election of Gerhard D. Bleicken as chairman and chief executive officer of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company and Frank B. Maher as president and chief oper ations officer, was announced yesterday following a directors' meeting.

title: WITNESS RECALLS THEFTS FROM CITY
description: A witness who expressed teal for his life testified behind locked doors yesterday in the trial of a former official charged with the theft of more than $500,000 in payroll checks from the city's Neighborhood Youth Corns.

title: OFFICERS CHANGED BY COMMONWEALTH
description: There has been another shift in top management of the Commonwealth United Cor poration, the Beverly Hills based conglomerate that has been so dependent in the past for financing from subsidiaries of Bernard Cornfeld's Investors Overseas Services of Geneva.

title: 3 IN FAMILY KILLED IN A QUEENS BLAZE
description: An elderly woman, her daughter and grandson were killed in a predawn fire yester day while they were asleep in their secondfloor apartment in the Richmond Hill section of Queens.

title: Fort Dix Bars a Bishop
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Jan. 14 The Roman Catholic auxiliary bishop of Caguas, Puerto Rico, and a group of his supporters were refused permission today to visit the post stockade and see those they referred to as prisoners of conscience. The clergyman, the Most. Rev. An culio ParrillaRenilla, is travel ing to prisons across the coun try to make such visits.

title: Europe Awaits Approval Of Lagos on Aid to Biafra
description: LONDON, Jan. 12  Govern ments and relief agencies in Europe formulated plans today for aid to Biafran refugees but found themselves unable to move pending word from the Nigerian Government.

title: Prosecutor's Aide Named
description: George S. Popielarski was named yesterday an assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, with headquarters in Brooklyn. Mr. Popielarski, 38 years old, had been an assistant Attorney General for New York and special prosecutor for the Vil lage of Hempstead, L. I., where he lives with his wife and four children.

title: Bergdorf's Importing an Antiques Shop
description: LONDONMallett & Son, the Bond Street antique firm whose name has a very old and lovely glow for Britons is coming to Bergdorf Goodman in April.

title: Drama Fills Performance By Luisito Rey, Guitarist
description: My boy, said Pablo Pi casso to Luisito Rey when he sought out the then 19year old singer and guitarist back stage after hearing him at the Olympia Theater in Paris, you are like a chill that can he heard.

title: Maritime Hearing Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 12A oneweek delay in the start of hearings on the Administration's 10year, $3billion maritime pro gram was announced here today by the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries. The hearings are now scheduled to start on Jan. 26.

title: Times Names New Editor To Head Travel Section
description: Robert. W. Stock a staff member of The New York Times. Magazine, has been appointed editor of The Times Sunday travel sec tion, replacing Paul Fried lander, it was announced yesterday by Daniel Schwarz, Sunday editor.

title: Soviet Renews Drive Against Alcoholism as Ban on Sale of Vodka Is Suggested
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12  The soberingup station at 1 Pet rovsky Boulevard was operat ing normally. In a 30minute period, policemen firmly led in four men ranging in age from about 25 to 50, none shabbily dressed.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION DOWN 2.4% IN WEEK
description: Steel production declined 2.4 per cent last week, compared with that of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester day.

title: 3 Japanese. Firms Elected To Boston Stock Ekchange
description: The Boston Stock Exchange announced yesterday that representatives of three Japa nese brokerage houses had been elected to membership on the exchange. Technically, the three are top officers of the American affiliates of the Jap anese concerns.

title: MANSFIELD PLANS EARLY FUND FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, set the Stage today for an early confronta tion with the Administration. He scheduled as the first order of business, when Congress re turns next Monday, an appro priations bill that President Nixon has threatened to veto.

title: Rhode Island Wins
description: KINGSTON, R. I., Jan. 12 (AP)Rhode Island lost an early bid, then pulled away again with a fastbreak attack in the second half for a 7866 Yankee Conference victory over Vermont tonight.

title: Store Credit Business Off 5% in Two Years
description: Bank credit cards are making inroads into store credit plans, a retailers' con vention was told here yes terday.

title: Music Instrument Co. Elects New Chairman
description: Directors of the Chicago Musical Instrument Company yesterday elected H. Norton Stevens as chairman.

title: Ojukwu Is Expected to Arrive By Plane in Capital of Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 12 Unconfirmed reports here to night said that Gen. Odumegwu Ojukwu, the Biafran leader, would arrive in Lusaka in the next 24 hours by air from Libre ville, Gabon.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOUSE OF GOLD. By Elizabeth Cullinan. 328 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $5.95.

title: So Carolina Beats Virginia
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 12 (UPI)Thirdranked South Carolina overcame the slow down tactics of Virginia to night for a 6342 Atlantic Coast Conference victory.

title: Biafra Aid From South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 12A Biafra appeal fund organized in whiteruled South Africa has already, reached almost $30,000 and has received pledges in excess of a million dollars. The fund started by a Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Desmond Cur ranwas set up to buy medical supplies, clothing and food for Biafran war victims.

title: Article 2  No Title
MOVE ON SINATRA WEIGHED IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Jan. 12The State Commission of Investiga tion, which for seven months has tried in vain to question Frank Sinatra about organized crime, is debating whether to seek the singer's indictment for criminal contempt.

title: India Picks U. S. Airliner Over Russians
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 12In an EastWest competition, Ameri cans have outbid Russians in the sale of passenger planes to the Indian Government for its domestic airline.

title: PARK PERMIT BAN LINKED TO DALEY
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 12A de fense witness said today that he had been told that Mayor Richard J. Daley was blocking permits for demonstrators to sleep in parks two weeks be fore the 1968 Democratic Na tional Convention here.

title: U. S. PICKS TEAM FOR NORDIC SKIING
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 12  In the wake of yester day's Kennedy Memorial ski jumping tournament here, four athletes today were named to the National Nordic combined team that will represent the United States in the Federation Internationale de Ski world championships at VsokeTatry, Czechoslovakia starting Feb. 14. Three of the men picked, Teyek Weed of Etna, N. H. Bob Kendall of Auburn, Me., and Mike Devecka of Government Camp, Ore., earned berths by topping aspirants for the com bined team in two crosscoun try meets and one jumping event held at this Adirondack Mountain report over the week end.

title: 433 Donors Give$18,132 To Neediest
description: A threemonthold girl born with deformed feet and in need of an operation if she is to be adopted a 3year old boy in need of continued psychiatric treatment to re pair the ravages to his mind resulting from a broken home a young couple desper ately trying to keep their family together and face the further trials of life an elder ly couple, destitute and alone, trying to live out their lives in dignitythese are a few of the Neediest.

title: U.S. Asks U.N. Initiatives To Cone With Drug Abuse
description: GENEVA, Jan. 12The United States called today for bold new initiatives to com tain the growing menace of drug abuse as the United Nations began the study of a proposed treaty to bring new categories of drugs under in ternational control.

title: Brewster Wins 2d Delay In Federal Bribery Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) Former Senator Daniel B. Brewster, of Maryland, still hos pitalized in Ireland, won a sec ond delay today in his arraign ment on Federal bribery charges.

title: Florida Embargoes FrostHurt Citrus
description: MIAMI, Jan. 12 (UPI)The Florida Citrus Commission to day clamped a sevenday embargo on the shipment or sale of all fresh fruit because of heavy frost damage last week. It was the first such embargo since the 1962 cold spell.

title: 2 Widows to Get $750,000 In Plane Crash Settlement
description: Settlements of more than $700,000 were reached yester day in Manhattan Supreme Court in cases involving the deaths of two passengers in an American Airlines crash near Cincinnati, Ohio, Nov. 8. 1965.

title: Patrons' Event Set By Jewish Congress
description: The women's division of the American Jewish Con gress will honor Mrs. Harry Haber of Harrison, N. Y., its national campaign chairman, and. Robert Ryan, the actor, at its annual patroness lun cheon, to be held Jan. 27 at the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: 5% Tax Would Narrow Jersey's Selling Edge
description: A 5 per cent state sales tax in New Jersey, as proposed yesterday by Gov.elect Wil Liam T. Cahill, would still make purchases a litle cheap er in that state than in New York City, where buyers pay a total of 6 per cent in sales taxes.

title: Rider Tops Scranton
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12 (AP) Rider stopped a late rally by Scranton tonight and gained its fifth consecutive victory, 7259.

title: U.N.Did Not Act on War, Terming It Internal Issue
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 12  A spokesman for the United Nations, William Powell, answered with a curt yes this morning when he was asked whether the head quarters of the world organ ization had been surprised by the rush of events in Nigeria.

title: It Was a Super Day For Television, Too
description: The Columbia Broadcast ing System estimated yester day that 57 million people watched at least part of. Sun day's Super Bowl football telecast.

title: The New U.S. Ambasador to Sweden
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Last April, a small group of militant students at Hamp ton Institute in Virginia de manded the resignation of the college's president; Dr. Jerome Heartwell Holland.

title: Institutions Found Likely to Own 33% Of All Stock in '80
description: Investment institutions will continue to increase their ownership of stocks in the next decade, but individual inves tors will still own most of the outstanding stock, according to a study issued yesterday by the New York Stork Exchange.

title: 3 Chinese Who Jumped Ship Are Caught a Second Time
description: Three Chinese seamen who jumped ship last week and were caught, escaped custody again Sunday and were caught again yesterday.

title: Funding Academic Research
description: The Defense Department's pledge to comply with new Congressional rules prohibiting it from sponsoring any university research that is not directly mission oriented could go a long way toward eliminating overdependence of educational institutions on military grants.

title: C.B.S. SHIFTS POLICY ON SUNDAY NEWS
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System will inaugurate a prime time evening newscast on Sun day evenings beginning Jan. 25. The C.B.S. televised football season will end the Sunday be fore, averting a broadcast con flict but only temporarily.

title: Credit Cards Good in 9 States For Paying U. S. Income Taxes
description: The versatility of the credit card was broadened yesterday with the disclosure that tax payers in at least nine states would be able to pay their Fed eral income taxes by credit card.

title: Peru's Press Fights for Life
description: With a sweeping decree for controlling the press, the military government of Peru has provoked the strongest and broadest opposition it has had to face in the fifteen months since it seized power. It has tossed away the support of the country's biggest newspaper and united against it bitter historic rivals from the fields of journalism and politics together with outstanding leaders from the other professions.

title: The Governor Says No
description: The Mayors of the state's Big Six cities, joining together for the first time in presenting demands on Albany, unveiled their proposals yesterday. Gov ernor Rockefeller rejected them. The request by the Mayors was modest. The rejection by the Governor was initially peremptory.

title: Most Miners in Spain End Strike After Ultimatum
description: MADRID, Jan. 12Twothirds of the 14,000 miners who were on strike in northern Spain obeyed a company ultimatum and went back to work today.

title: In Soviet Union, Shopping Entails a Wait in Line
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12In the departmentstore section of Moscow's central market, a man waits 10 minutes in line to order three small foam rubber crocodiles for his young son. The crocodiles cost $3.30, but the price is not the buyer's principal pain.

title: Alioto Out of Race To Oppose Reagan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 Mayor Joseph Alioto, regarded for many months as an un announced candidate for Gov ernor, removed himself abruptly from the race today.

title: VOODOO N. TAKES PACE AT WESTBURY
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 12 Cesare Gennari, the 41yearold track superintendent at Roose velt Raceway, started work at 7:15 this morning to get the track into shape for the night time ninerace operation. And he and his crew came through with a most satisfactory ac complishment, as indicated by the times turned in by the con testants.

title: PRICES SHOW DROP IN TOKYO TRADING
U.S. TENNIS RANKS STAN SMITH NO. 1
description: The guessing game ended yesterday as Stan Smith was ranked No. 1 by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

title: KENTUCKY WHIPS GEORGIA BY 7271
description: ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 12 (AP) Mike Pratt scored 7 points in the final 4 minutes tonight, to spark secondranked Kentucky to a 7271 victory over Georgia giving the Wildcats the South eastern Conference basketball lead.

title: Florida Triumphs, 5756
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 12 (UPI)Andy Owens hit a 15 foot jump shot with 1 minute 38 seconds left in overtime to night to give Florida a 5756 victory over Tennessee.

title: High Court to Hear Case of Greek Hurt In U.S. Harbor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed to day to consider whether a Greek sailor injured aboard a Greek ship in a United States harbor could seek damages in United States courts.

title: Son of the Air Force Chief Missing After Jet Crashes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) The son of Gen. John D. Ryan, Air Force Chief of Staff, was listed as missing after the F4 jet fighter he was flying plunged into the San Francisco Bay today.

title: N.A.A.C.P.Official Says Nixon Did Little for Negroes Last Year
description: The Nixon Administration's first year was a mixed bag with more negative than posi tive aspects for black Amer icans, the assistant executive director of the National Associ ation for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday.

title: Biafran Here Fears Mass Slaughter
description: A Biafran in New York yes terday deplored the Nigerian victory in the civil war and expressed fear that it would be followed by widespread kill ing of Biafrans.

title: Chase Bank to Stuttgart
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank has announced plans to open new branch in Stuttgart, West Germany, its fourth in that country. The First National Bank of Chicago plans to open a branch in Panama City, Panama it said.

title: JUANITA SADDLER OF Y. W. C. A. DIES
description: Juanita Jane Saddler, a lead er in the integration movement in the Young Women's Chris tian Association and other or ganizations, died Sunday at her home, 80 La Salle Street. She was 78 years old.

title: PLAN PROISRAELI, SOVIET TOLD U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12In the latest Soviet note on the Middle East, American peace proposals were rejected as onesided and proIsraeli.

title: High and Lows
description: MONDAY, JAN. 12, 1970

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: N.I.H. Budget Cuts

title: Marcus Pleads Guilty to Charge He Took a Bribe From Con Ed
description: Former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus pleaded gullty yesterday to a charge of hav ing solicited and received a bribe from Consolidated Edi son to approve the utility's 3. quest to rebuilt its transmis sion line in Westchester Coun ty.

title: Solzhenitsyn Novel Before Cameras
