description: In a move to help curb cr edit card frauds and losses, the Diners Club announced here yesterday that it was planning to introduce a new creditau thorization system for its two million credit card holders in cooperation with the Audac Corporation, Burlington, Mass., manufacturer of a touchtone telephone device.

title: $4,000 in False Claims Laid to a Midtown Dentist
description: A midtown dentist was ar rested yesterday on charges that he submitted insurance clams totaling almost $4,000 for dental work he never per formed.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Sports of The Times

title: Benton & Bowles Gets Mound Account Share
description: The moundmakers at Pe ter Paul, Inc., have decided to slip some of their candy products over to Benton & Bowles. All of the products of the Naugatuck, Conn., sweets folk are now handled by DancerFitzgeraldSample, which has been its agency for 13 years. It is understood that the annual Peter Paul advertising outlay is over $4 million.

title: History Lesson
description: NOT many people realize, said smiling Billy Sullivan, the presi dent of the Boston Patriots, the extra measure of satisfaction that all American Football League owners got when one of our teams beat the Minnesota Vi kings in the Super Bowl. It was great for us a year ago, of course, when the Jets beat the Colts, but there wasn't the same undercurrent that was running against the Vikings, the same deep feelings.

title: Three Convicts Killed As. Guard Opens Fire
description: SOLEDAD, Calif., Jan. 13 (UPI)Three prisoners were shot to death today when a guard opened fire with a car bine on a group of convicts brawling in a prison exercise yard.

title: Councilmen Nominate Cancer Expert for City Hospital Board
description: Manhattan's eight Councilmen yesterday chose a prominent cancer specialist to serve on the 16member board that will gov ern the city's 18 public hospi tals starting July 1.

title: Al Freeman Jr. and Claudia McNeil Take Star Roles
description: Two prominent black art ists have signed contracts to star in Broadway and Off Broadway productions this season.

title: A Priority for Education
description: President Nixon's threat that he will veto the $20billion appropriations bill for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare goes to the heart of the matter of national priorities. The amount at issue is $1.1 billion, most of it earmarked for education, in excess of the Administration's recommendations.

title: Rogers Calls Pollution International Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI)  Calling pollution an international problem, Secre tary of State William P. Rogers today announced the creation of an Office of Environmental Affairs.

title: CHANGE OPPOSED IN BREEDING RULE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 13 Lee Benson spent a small for tune last year keeping his 2 yearold trotters and pacers eligible for stake events. None of the youngsters ever got to compete in those events.

title: HOSPITAL INVADED OVER ADDICT CARE
description: About 20 members of two Organizations invaded the Community Psychiatry Unit of St. Lukes Hospital yesterday to demand that the hospital pro vide immediate bed space to de toxify heroin addicts under 18 rears old.

title: Regime of le Tout Paris Getting to Meet le Tout NewYork
description: Regine, the locomotive who leads le tout Paris (as the Seinebased chapter of the jet set calls itself) hasn't quite met everybody who's anybody in New York since she arrived Sunday for a week's visit. Just enough to fill the economy section of one of the new jumbo jets.

title: Bronx G.O.P. Vote Voided by Justice Over Equal Rights
description: The issue of women's rights weighed heavily yesterday in decision by Supreme Court Jus tice Abraham J. Gellinoff or dering a new election of county leaders by the Bronx Republi can organization.

title: A Negro in Virginia Is, Named to Staff Of GovernorElect
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 13Vir ginia's Republican Governor elect, Linwood Holton, an nounced today that he had ap pointed a Negro as a key mem ber of his executive staff.

title: International Rules On Business Asked
description: PARIS, Jan. 13An Ameri can and a French authority on multinational companies agreed today on the need for some form of international supervi sion of the giant enterprises to avoid conflicts with national administrations.

title: Bridge:
description: THE Circus led by Omar Sharif began a seven week North American tour in Chicago last night fresh from its rubber bridge victory over an English partnership.

title: Canadians Agree to Suspend Copper Price Rise Two Months
description: Canadian copper producers said yesterday they had agreed to suspend their recent 16 per cent price increase for two months at the request of the Dominion Government. The action was voluntary, but it was taken, in the words of one company president, with extreme reluctance. Fi nance Minister Edgar J. Benson announced yesterday after noon in the House of Com mons that the Government had made the request, and the major companies reported later in the day that they had agreed to it. noon in the House of Com mons that the Government had made the request, and the major companies reported later in the day that they had agreed to it.

title: Bishop Assails Chaplain System After Visiting Military Prisons
description: The Most Rev. Antulio Parilla Bonilla, a Roman Catholic Bish op from Puerto Rico who has visited what he called political prisoners in 19 civil and mili tary jails over the last four weeks, called yesterday for the abolition of the military chap laincy.

title: Analysis of Student Protests Finds Most Nonviolent, With New Left a Minor Factor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The firpt complete study of student protests last year at colleges and, universities shows that most were nonviolent and did not interrupt routine, that new left groups were a minor fac tor, and that the protesters were less concerned with the Vietnam war and related is sues than with conditions on the campuses.

title: NO REAL GROWTH SEEN FOR ECONOMY
description: OMAHA, Jan. 13 (UPI)  Treasury Under Secretary Charts E. Walker said today it appeared there would be a con tinued lack of a real growth in the American economy well into 1970.

title: McCarthy Sees Hanoi Aide, Returning to U.S. Today
description: PARIS, Jan. 13 (AP)Sena tor Eugene McCarthy spent four and a half hours in cor dial and informative conversa tion today with Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief delegate to the Paris peace talks, a spokesman for Mr. CcCarthy said.

title: Negro Shuns Coast Race
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP) City Councilman Thomas Brad ley said today that he would not run for Lieutenant Governor Mr. Bradley, who tried unsuc cessfully last year to become the first Negro Mayor of Los Angeles, was regarded widely as a likely candidate for the Demo cratic nomination for the state's No. 2 post.

title: Cartoonists to Cite Hodges
description: Gil Hodges, the manager of the world champion New York Mets, was selected yesterday to receive the No. 1 award by the national Cartoonists Society as its sports figure of the year. The award will be presented at a dinner at the Hotel Commo dore on Jan. 27.

title: LAWYER HERE TO AID SAIGON G.I. NEWSMAN
description: Leonard Boudin, counsel for the National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee, an nounced here yesterday that he would represent Specialist 5 Robert Lawrence, the Army newscaster who was removed from his television assignment in Saigon after he had charged the military authnrities with censoring of news broadcasts.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
Executive Changes
description: Alvin V. Shoemaker has been elected a vice pres ident of the First Boston Corporation lie is a mem ber of the company's municipal department.

title: City Will Auction A Column of Air For $33Million
description: The city will try to have its cake and eat it too on January 28 when it will put the fivestory Commercial High School Annex on East 46th Street between Second and Third Avenues on the auction block.

title: New Children's Book Uses Playing to Teach English
description: A book to help children ex pand their capacity to use the English language, called Lan guage Through Play, has been published here. It is specifically designed so children can cut it up, as part of the learning process.

title: Hoffa Files Another Appeal
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 13 (AP) The United States Court of Ap peals for the Sixth Circuit has received notices of further ap peals of jury tampering con victions from the Teamsters Union President, James R. Hoffa, and two codefendants, Thomas E. Parks of Nashville and Larry Campbell of Detroit. The brief appeal notices, filed yesterday, inclded no particu lars.

title: The Victors' Responsibility
description: The Nigerian Government's insistence on maintain ing Federal supervision over all foreign relief opera tions in wardevastated Biafra is perfectly under standable. But Nigeria's demand that all foreign aid be channeled through officials in Lagos, if this is to be taken literally, is tragically unreasonable. And if General Gowon's statement yesterday means that he rejects all help from agencies that have participated in Biafran relief, his position is, nothing short of un conscionable.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID U.A.R. ARMY DEPOT IN A CAIRO SUBURB
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 13  A military spokesman said that Is raeli jets attacked Cairo's sub urbs today in the second raid in a week in the Nile Delta.

title: U.S. Is Sure There Won't Be Reprisals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Under Secretary of State, Elliot L. Richardson, said today that we have every reason to be encouraged that there would be no indiscriminate kill ing of Biafrans by the victori ous forces of the Nigerian Gov ernment.

title: More Sales Tax for New Jersey
description: Governorelect William T. Cahill's effusive shock over New Jersey's deep fiscal plight only reflects a previously shallow understanding of that state's obli gations and needs. His proposed solution, increasing the sales tax from 3 per cent to 5 per cent and per haps including some items now excluded from taxa tion, represents a shortsighted response to this plight.

title: Chicago Bank Posts A Rise in Earnings
description: The First Chicago Corpora tion, whose only component is the $5.4billion First National Bank of Chicago, reported yes terday that net income rose 44.5 per cent last year to $58, 594,000, or $5.84 a common share. This compares with $40, 544,000, or $4.05 a share, in 1968.

title: Lennon's Lithographs Picture His Love Life
description: LONDON, Jan. 13If it was anyone else, they'd lock him up, the London matron Sniffed, as she peered through the plate glass window on Bond Street to see John Len non's lithographs of his sex life with Yoko Ono, his wife.

title: Clarion Concerts Unearth Old Work
description: Reading the program notes to Newell Jenkins's Clarion Concerts year after year, one gets the general impression that most of the early works to which he regularly gives local premieres were discovered just the other day in a Spanish monastery.

title: Increases in Inventories Slackened in November
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The likelihood of a recession this year appeared lessened to day after the Government is sued a report on a sensitive sector of the economybusi ness inventories.

title: Rhodes Formula Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  The United States stood by its support of the socalldd Rhodes formula for future ArabIsraeli negotiations today despite the Soviet Union's rejection of the procedure.

title: FIVE RAMS NAMED TO ALLPRO ELEVEN
description: CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 13 (AP) The Los Angeles Rams placed five players on the first Pro Football Hall of Fame allpro team and Kansas City's Super Bowl winners grabbed four places as the National Football League dominated the first team.

title: ProducerRetailer Collaboration Urged for Boys' Wear Progress
description: A call for greater cooper ation between merchants and manufacturers of boys' wear was made here yesterday by Philip M. Hawley, president of the Broadway. Department Stores in Los Angeles.

title: PROFIT MARK SET BY AMERICAN ENKA
description: Operations of the American Enka Corporation in 1969 re sulted in record sales and earn ings, reflecting demand for fine denier textile nylon yarns and some other textiles, Claude Ramsey, president, reported yesterday.

title: In Hunts Point, This Year Is Like Any OtherBad
description: This is a complaint about the total disregard by all city agencies regarding our street. We are referring to. Simpson Street in the Bronx. This whole area is one big garbage dump.

title: Proposal Scares Barber
description: KLANG, Malaysia (AP) When a woman asked the local barber, 22 years old, to marry her, he ran to the police sta tion for protection. His admirer is 50 years old and has 13 children.

title: Market Place
description: A BELIEVER in the old max im J. P. K. Fontaine says, if you don't succeed, try, try again.

title: SharpEyed Buyers Swarm to Town
description: The buyers are in town again, in greater force than they were last year. But their faces are a bit more sober and contemplative as they troop around in the slush with their open notebooks and full briefcases and crowd into the showroom buildings.

title: Lagos and Rome: Opposite Reactions to Biafra's Fall
YOUTH CORPS AIDE ADMITS TO THEFTS
description: Coy D. Smith interrupted his trial yesterday to plead guilty to, the theft of almost $400,000 in pay checks when he was the chief fiscal officer of the city's Neighborhood Youth Corps.

title: HUGHES REPEATS INCOMETAX PLEA
description: TRENTON, Jan. 13Gov. Richard J. Hughes urged the Republicandominated Legisla ture today to approve a state income tax in a final legislative message that recalled what he regarded as the greatest achievements of his eight years in office.

title: BUGS HAND NETS 126106 SETBACK
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 (AP)Red Robbins and Jack Moreland led a thirdperiod outburst that enabled the New Orleans. Buccaneers to break open a close game and go on to a 126106 victory over the New York Nets tonight in an American Basketball Associa tion game.

title: Arthur Wiesenberger, Broker And Mutual Fund Adviser, Dies
description: ROME, Jan. 13Arthur Wies enberger, a New York financier, died of a heart attack here yes terday at his nearby villa. He was 73 years old. He is sur vived by his widow, the former Frances Glenning Bayes; a son, Arthur F., and a sister, Mrs. Helen Trotsky of New York.

title: QUEBEC ASSERTS ECONOMY THRIVES
description: QUEBEC, Jan. 13  The provincial government asserted today that the Quebec economy performed about as well as did the national economy in 1969 and will keep pace in 1970.

title: JERSEY TRIAL FIGURE WINS COURT LENITY
description: NEWARK, Jan. 13 (AP)An East Orange truck driver who pleaded guilty last June to two charges of attempting to influ ence jurors in a conspiracy trial of Ruggiero (Richie the Boot) Boiardo and 18 others received a suspended sentence today.

title: FRANCE DISCERNS MIDEAST PROGRESS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13The representatives of the Big Four powers discussed the Middle East conflict for four hours today.

title: Satellite Launching Halted
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Jan. 13 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration post poned the launching tonight of a commercial communications satellite, because of a gas leak in the second stage of the Delta rocket, the first insured against failure. The launching was post poned four straight nights last week because of weather and technical troubles. Another at tempt will be made tomorrow.

title: PRINCETON DOWNS PENN STATE, 7738
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 13 Easily containing a Penn State squad that hit only 21 per cent from the floor, Princeton needed only Jeff Petrie's 22 points and John Hummer's 17 to down the Nittany Lions to night. The Tigers won, 7738, after leading at halftime. 3621.

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 22% FOR JAN. 110
description: DETROIT, Jan. 13It's the coldest January in a decade and that report doesn't come from the weather man  it comes from Detroit.

title: 6 RARE DISEASES YIELD KEY SECRET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Six rare hereditary diseases have each been forced to give up their crucial secret, and sci entists have begun experiments to translate that victory into methods of treatment.

title: Mahagonny, Once Set for 1957, to Open in March
description: In December, 1956, Carmen Capalbo, the producer of The Threepenny Opera, an nounced that the following fall he would present the United States premiere of the neglected Kurt Weill Bertolt Brecht classic Ma hagonny. This week, 13 long years later, Mahagonny finally is in rehearsal.

title: Stephen D. Greenberg To Marry Myrna Katz
description: Miss Myrna Wien Katz, a graduate student in educa tion at New York University, plans to be married in May to Stephen D. Greenberg, a Yale senior she met at a Briarcliff mixer three years. ago.

title: Bond Says Two Chicago Defendants Feared Police Violence Would Occur
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 13  Julian Bond, the black state legis lator from Georgia, said today that Tom Hayden told him several months before the 1968 Democratic National Conven tion that he feared police violence here during the con vention.

title: Watchdog Can Remain, Despite Lease
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that because of the present cir cumstances of rampant crime, a tenant might keep a dog in her Lower East Side cooperative apartment de spite a ban against animals in her lease.

title: Article 3  No Title
Youngsters Learn The Art of Giving To Neediest Cases
description: Among the thousands of letters received in answer to the 58th annual appeal of the New York. Times Neediest Cases Fund there is an in creasing number of letters from youngsters who are learning the art of giving from their parents.

title: Nixon's Influence Already Apparent in the Government's Independent Regulatory Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13A large part of the policymaking layer of government is pur posely insulated from sudden shifts of Presidential power in the socalled independent regulatory agencies. But Rich ard M. Nixon, like other Presi dents before him, is finding the takeover process  even in these protected corners of Washington power  quicker and easier than it looks in the textbooks.

title: Soviet Ministry's Voice
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 13 When the Soviet Union decides, as it rarely does, to speak directly to foreign corre spondents, the voice it uses is that of Leonid Mitrofano vich Zamyatin.

title: Federal Judges Rule Out Benefit for Segregated Private Academies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 A threejudge Federal District Court here ordered the Internal Revenue Service today to stop granting taxexempt status to segregated private schools in Mississippi.

title: Rowe Steel, 70, Controller Of Rockefeller Foundation
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 13 (UPI)Rowe S. Steel, former controller of the Rockefeller Foundation, died here yester day. He was 70 years old.

title: Student Group Asks F.C.C. To Set Standard on TV Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 TUBE, a new student organiza tion at the George Washington University Law School, filed to day a petition with the Federal Communications Commission.

title: WHIRLWIND VIOLIN MARKS KLIMOV SOLO
description: Valery Klimov, the Soviet violinist, was soloist with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra last night in a concert given at Philharmonic Hall under the direction of Kiril Kondrashin.

title: Chase Bank Will Offer Computer Tax Service
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday its entry into the income tax preparation field with a com puterized service called Tax Pak designed to process Fed eral, state and city returns.

title: Army Consolidating Songmy Inquiry at Georgia Base
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Army announced today that it was going to transfer to Fort McPherson, Ga., or nearby bases most of the ac tiveduty servicemen connect ed with the investigation into alleged atrocities at Songmy, South Vietnam.

title: Ratelle, Long Overdue, on AllStars With Gilbert
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Jan. 13There was perhaps a slight hint of regret in Jean Ratelle's voice as he spoke of the thrill of being selected today to the Nation al Hockey League's AllStar team for the first time.

title: F111 Order Is Cut $1Billion by U.S.
description: The Defense Department has slashed plans for purchase of the F111 attack plane by $1 billion or more over the next two fiscal years, official sources disclosed yesterday.

title: POLLUTION LINKED TO POWER NEEDS
description: WASHINGTON, San. 12 (AP)Congress has been given a chilling account of potential disaster from air and water pol lution if conventional methods are used to satisfy the nation's growing desire for electrical Power.

title: U. S. GIRLS PLACE 4TH, 7TH AND 8TH
description: BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 13 (AP)  Unheralded Ingrid Lafforgue led the French to an other Alpine skiing victory to day when she won the Silver Jug slalom, considered one of the most important events be fore next month's world cham pionships. Three American wo men placed among the top 10.

title: Fairleigh to Raise Tuition
description: TEANECK. N.J., Jan. 13 (AP) Fairleigh D??kinson Univer sity announced tuition in creases to day for students at its campuses here and in Rutherford and Madison. The Provost, Richard Drake, said tuition for fulltime undergrad uate day students would go from $675 to $850 a semester, beginning in September. He said the undergraduate credit rate tor parttime day students would go from, $43 to $53 and the cost for evening students would go from $40 to $53.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS HIT RECORD HIGHS
Nigeria Reports Sending Supplies to War Victims
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Wednes day, Jan. 14 (Agence France Presse)Six hundred tons of relief supplies have been sent to Southeastern State and an additional200 tons to Riv ers Statetwo of the three states that make up the former Eastern Regionthe Governmentsponsored Na tional Rehabilitation Commis sion announced here last night.

title: Gambling Investigation Report Called Cruel by Dawson's Wife
description: Besides Hank Stram's imaginative game plan, Len Dawson had one other bit of advice to follow in the Super Bowl:

title: STARS' TAX AIDE ACCUSED OF BRIBES
description: An accountant who repre sented foreign opera stars and conductors was indicted yes terday by a Federal grand jury on charges of having paid more than $2,500 in bribes to three former Internal Revenue Serv ice auditors.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Budd
description: SYOSSET, L. I., Jan. 13 Mr. and Mrs. Bern Budd Jr. of Laurel Hollow have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Beekman Budd, to Michael Beh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Beh of Lloyd Neck, Huntington.

title: The Screen: 'Last of the Mobile Hot-Shots' Opens
description: AS Tennessee Williams's play, "The Seven Descents of Myrtle," was being turned into a movie, it went through several title changes, including "Blood Kin" and "Last of the Mobile Hot-Shots," the latter being the title of the film that opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and Trans-Lux West Theaters. I mention "this information  ordinarily the sort that belongs in a scholarly footnoteonly because it illustrates the futile indecision that still racks the entire movie."The Last of the Mobile Hot-Shots" is slapstick tragicomedy that looks and sounds and plays very much like cruel parodyof Tennessee Williams. However, it may well be that any slapstick tragicomedy must, by definition, be parody.The locale, a decaying old Delta, plantation house that Williams once called Belle Rive but now is named Waverley, is as familiar as the life- and death-forces who do battle within it.They are, in inverse order of their ability to conceive issue: Jeb Stuart Thorington (James Coburn), the last of the legitimate Thoringtons, a man who seems oddly muscular for someone suffering from terminal cancer of his one lung; Myrtle (Lynn Redgrave), the healthy hooker whom Jeb has married on "The Happy Couple" television show, to get children and a $3,500 check to restore Waverley, and Chicken (Robert Hooks), Jeb's black, alluvium - earthy half - brother, who possesses the new blood by which the Thoringtons will survive.While dat ole debil ribber (the Mississippi) rises to flood stage, Jeb lies dying in his room at the top of the house dreaming theatrical flashbacks (he and Chicken used to take their whores together and apparently, though it's never really clear, have each other).Downstairs, Chicken quietly waits for Jeb to expire, while Myrtle spends most of her time running between the floors, trying desperately to get Jeb to make love to her, and making love to Chicken, who possesses a legal deed to what she wants to inherit.The movie is haunted by ghosts of earlier, more memorable Williams characters who are easily identifiable even though there have been some changes in sex and color. Myrtle has the strength of Stella Kowalski and carries on in non-stop, expository monologues that could have been tailored for Baby Doll. She's down at the heel, but not at the bosom.Jeb fondles Big Mama's Old Mardi Gras gown and carries on like Blanche DuBois, though he looks like Lee Marvin. Chicken is Stanley Kowalski in the blackface that Williams pretty well ignored in his earlier plays.Sidney Lumet, who improved Williams's "Orpheus Descending" when he returned it into "The Fugitive Kind" with Marlon Brando and Anna Magnani, has directed this new film with a kind of desperate extravagant theatricality, which can't hide the fact that the original play, adapted and expanded by Gore Vidal, might better have been written by Ronnie Graham as a sketch for "New Faces of 1952."Lumet actually stages some scenes as if they were taking place within a proscenium, which I rather like, but the frantic, farcical pacing makes the performers, especially Miss Redgrave and Hooks, seem even more inept than is, perhaps, absolutely necessary, considering their talents.The title, incidentally, derives from the information that Myrtle, when introduced, is the lone survivor of a topless, all-girl band called the Mobile Hot-Shots, whose other members all seem to have expired rather violently.One, I remember, was ravished under a railway trestle by person or persons unknown. It's a curious thing about Williams, especially late Williams, that what happens off-stage is often more vivid than what happens on.

title: L.I.R.R., Hoping for State Loan, Halves Monthly Fare Rise Bid
description: In anticipation of a loan of $8.5million from the state to help cover its losses from freight haulage, the Long Is land Rail Road announced yes terday that it would seek a pas senger fare rise of $4.60 a month instead of the $9.20 monthly increase it had re quested on Saturday.

title: Stocks on Sao Tome
description: SAO TOME, Jan. 14Inter national relief organizations have 14 planes here loaded with medicine, food, clothing and vehicles ready to take off at five minutes' notice, when word comes from Lagos.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT PISTONS, 123118
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP)The Boston Celtics, behind the play of Henry Finkel, the unheralded Bill Russell replacement, rallied in the fourth period tonight for a 123118 victory over the De troit Pistons at the Boston Garden.

title: Kivlan and Brown Keep Titles in A.A.U. Meet
description: The 79th running of the Met ropolitan Amateur Athletic Un ion senior championships in the 102d Engineers Armory last night was a time for overcom ing adversity and Brian Kivlan and Barry Brown both respond ed to the challenge.

title: PRICES ARE EASIER ON STOCK MARKET
description: Some of the high  flying glamour stocks trimmed their recent gains yesterday as the general market closed with modest losses.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Assessing Blame in Massacres

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 15, 1970

title: U.S. STEEL LIFTS BAN ON FOREIGN VEHICLES
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 14 (UPI)The United States Steel Corporation backed down to day from its ban on parking foreignmade automobiles on the grounds of its Fairfield plant.

title: Owners Chided for Allowing Dogs to Get Too Fat or Thin
description: UNDERWEIGHT dogs in the winter and over weight ones in the summer needed close watching by owners, particularly those with hunting breeds, said Dr. Armour C. Wood of Trenton at the Dog Fanciers Club luncheon at the Over seas Press Club yesterday. Wood is a veterinarian, a dog breeder and president of the Trenton Ken nel Club. His topic was dog nutrition.

title: DIP IS EXTENDED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Losses outnumbered a vances on the American Stock Exchange yesterday by a wid margin as the trading peeve slackened.

title: Manhattan Is Beaten
Mrs. Dorothy Stone Married To Geoffrey Doyle in Kingston
description: Mrs. Dorothy George Stone and Geoffrey Car penter Doyle were married in Kingston, Jamaica, last Thursday. The ceremony at the home of Vincent de Roulet, United States Am bassador to Jamaica, was performed by the Rev. David Lapsley of the Web ster Memorial Presbyterian Church.

title: FUTURES BUYING ACTIVE IN CHICAGO
description: Continued bitter cold weather in the Middle West caused considerable buying of com modity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade early yester day. However, profit taking later in the day almost wiped out early advances.

title: Cahill Appoints 4 More Men to Posts in His Cabinet
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21Gover norelect William T. Cahill, who takes office next Tuesday, as New Jersey's first Republican Governor in 16 years, an nounced four more Cabinet ap pointments today.

title: Ellen A. Foster, '68 Debutante, Engaged to James P. Stirling
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan. 14Mr. and Mrs. Volney William Foster have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Adair Foster, to James Paul man Stirling, a vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Co., the investment bankers in Chicago.

title: Vornado Buys Own Stock
description: Vornado, Inc., announced yes terday that it had completed the purchase of about 245,000 shares of its common stock. Frederick Zissu, chairman, said that these transactions followed two offers of substantial blocks from private sources and a third that was consummated on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Parisot Plays 2 New Works for Cello
description: The particular strength of Aldo Parisot's concert last night at Alice Tully Hall proved to be the way the Brazilianborn cellist directed attention toward the music he played without letting one lose sightor soundof the fact that he was performing extraordinarily dif ficult works extraordinarily well. Mr. Parisot, a member of the Yale University music fac ulty, made his best impression in three contemporary pieces, one of which, Donald Martino's Parisonatina al'Dodecafonia, proved to be a technical hair raiser that drew on every imag inable cello device while still contriving to sustain musical, interest. the Yale University music fac ulty, made his best impression in three contemporary pieces, one of which, Donald Martino's Parisonatina al'Dodecafonia, proved to be a technical hair raiser that drew on every imag inable cello device while still contriving to sustain musical, interest.

title: U.S. Arms Reported Shipped to Israel Via Belgian Port
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 14Belgium is investigating reports that United States weapons and mili tary equipment are being shipped to Israel through the port of Zeebrugge, the Foreign Ministry disclosed today.

title: Schniebs, Skier for 74 Years, Still Hitting Trail at Whiteface
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y. Jan. 14Considering that Otto Schniebs will be celebrating his 75th year as a skier next winter, the old skiemeister came schussing down the slopes of Whiteface Mountain with surprising speed.

title: In Postwar Nigeria, Growing Oil Output Is Seen
description: The end of the war in Nigeria is expected to result in a prompt revival of the nation's oil industry, which had been one of the country's brightest hopes for economic develop ment.

title: 3 OFFICERS RESIGN AT A GENESCO UNIT
description: Genesco, Inc., manufacturer and retailer of apparel, an nounced the resignations of three top officers of Berkshire Apparel Corporation, a major unit that manufactures women's dresses with headquarters at Malden, Mass. They are Sidney S. Stogel, president; David A. Wise, executive vice president, and Donald I. Spund, treasurer.

title: Hofstra Tops Kings Point
EARLY KEON TALLY AVERTS A SHUTOUT
description: TORONTO, Jan. 14The New York Rangers trampled Toronto tonight, 71, spoiling the lastplace Leafs' sixstraight skein without a loss and rude ly welcoming back to bigtime hockey Gerry McNamara, late ly of the Orillia Terriers.

title: Confidence Declines
description: Consumer confidence in the state of the economy has eroded further since early fall and has adversely affected con sumer buying plans for durable goods, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yes terday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Posh Playground Revives
Priest and Author Describe the Last Days of Biafra
description: The final days in the 30 month life of the Biafran na tion saw thousands of frighten ed, starving refugees hurrying in all directions to escape the advancing Nigerian troops while the rumble of artillery and the fire of small arms could be heard in the distance, ac cording to an Irish priest and Ian American author.

title: HARRY M. WOODS, COMPOSER, DEAD
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 14 (AP) Harry MacGregor Woods, (composer of When the Moon Comes Over the Mountain, I'm Looking. Over a FourLeaf Clover and Side by Side, was struck and killed by a car last night. He was 73 years old.

title: Flies to Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) President Nixon flew to his Camp David retreat in the Maryland mountains today to work on his forthcoming mes sages to Congress.

title: Don't Jog, Track Coach Says, Run to Your Nearest Workout
description: The next time you leave the house in your sweatsuit and sneakers for that week end workout, don't jog, says Payton Jordan, run.

title: SONGMY INQUIRY WIDENED BY ARMY
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 14 The Army's investigation of the alleged massacre at Songmy has been widened to include 13 soldiers and 18 former soldiers, five more men than were pre viously known to be under scrutiny.

title: HOLLEY MIMS IS DEAD; EXPRIZE FIGHTER, 40
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Holley Mims, a former mid dleweight boxing contender, died in Providence Hospital last night of a kidney ailment. He was 40 years old.

title: Saigon Reports Defection
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (Reuters)The chief of staff of the North Vietnamese Army's. Second Division has defected to the South Vietnamese side, a military spokesman said today. He added that Col. Dang Toa presented himself to a company of South Vietnamese militia men in Quangnam Province, 1.7 miles southwest of Danang yes terday.

title: Two Urban Alliances Bid Nixon Spend More on Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The National League of Cities and the United States Conference of Mayors urged President Nixon today to make an im mediate commitment to spend the whole $800million that Congress appropriated last De cember for water pollution con trol this fiscal year.

title: Bookstore License Rejected
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Judge Francis J. W. Ford ruled today in United States District Court that a Boston city or dinance requiring licenses for bookstores selling adult only literature was invalid and un constitutional. He said the law imposed a prior restraint on rights guaranteed by the First Amendment.

title: JOSEPH SILBERMAN
description: NEWARK, Jan. 14Joseph Silberman, president of the Es sex Hardware and Metal Com pany of Nutley, died yesterday at the Beth Israel Medical Cen ter here. He was 58 years old and lived at 120 South Wyo ming Avenue, South Orange.

title: LINDSAY IN QUEENS TO CONFER ON NEEDS
description: Mayor Lindsay went to Queens last night, starting new series of visits to talk directly with neighborhood civic leaders.

title: New Meteorite Quickly Traced By a Prairie Camera Network
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)  Excited scientists were studying today a 21.6 pound meteorite that fell in Oklahoma 11 days ago, for clues to the creation of plan ets and perhaps of the uni verse itself. The meteorite was the first to be found by a network set up in 1964 to quickly trace such objects.

title: US. FINDS EUROPE COOLER TO TALKS
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 14Euro pean members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are taking a more skeptical attitude toward the Soviet Union's proposal for a European security conference, United States officials said today.

title: TV: Appeal and Relevance of Hamlet
description: A REVIEW of the timeless appeal and relevance of Hamlet was presented last night by National Educa tional Television, Channel 13, with Sir John Gielgud acting as guide to visits with the troubled Dane in many dif ferent countries and among successive generations of actors and directors.

title: Executive Arrested on Charges Of Lying at Inquiry Into Mafia
description: The president of a bottling concern was arrested yester day on charges that he corn mitted perjury at a State In vestigation Commission hearing seeking to determine the ex tent of organized crime's infil tration into legitimate business.

title: Travel Delays Linked To Business Loss Here
description: Mass transportation delays are costing businesses here thousands of dollars a day in time lost, and are becoming a factor in whether business es stay in the city or move to suburban headquarters, ac cording to Ralph C. Gross, president of the Commerce and Industry Association.

title: A Strap Here and There . . .
description: JON HAGGINS chose the red plush lounge of the Ziegfeld Theater to show off his supercontemporary sum mer clothes. As the models danced lightly around the circular ottoman in the cen ter, just grazing the candy counter, it proved to be a good idea. The clothes, very spare and free as usual, looked very comfortable in the Victorian surroundings.

title: Coal Miners of Asturias Restive Once Again as Political Uncertainty Prevails
description: OVIEDO, Spain, Jan. 11 The Nalon River, which winds like a black thread through the steep green hills near here on the way to the Bay of Biscay, runs paler these days. The mines of Asturias, whose coal is washed in the Nalon and its tributaries, were paralyzed by strikes all last week.

title: Court Administration School Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Bernard G. Segal, president of the American Bar Associa tion, announced today plans to establish the first comprehen sive program to train court ad ministrators.

title: Prisoners Fast on Coast
description: SOLEDAD, Calif., Jan. 14 (UPI)A group of black pris oners began a hunger strike to day, demanding a Federal in vestigation of the killing of three convicts by a guard. The superintendent's office at Sole dad State Prison said that 13 black inmates quit eating at the prison adjustment center where the shooting occurred yesterday.

title: Miss Linda Jeanne Gibson
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 14Miss Linda Jeanne Gib son and John Frederick Preston 3d plan to be married this June.

title: Guatemalan Gunmen Kill Nation's Chief Detective
description: GUATEMALA CITY, Jan. 14  The chief detective of the Guatemalan National Police was killed by machinegun fire here late yesterday. Justo Lopez Castanaza was shot to death by three young men in a car. A detective, Demetrio Enriquez, who was with Mr. Lopez, was gravely wounded.

title: Brooklyn's Cobble Hill Designated Historic Area
description: The Cobble Hill area of Brooklyn, which in the words of the Landmarks Preservation Commission retains almost un touched its 19thcentury resi dential atmosphere, was desig nated by the commission yes terday as a historic district.

title: Sports of The Times About Bill BradleyI
description: HE was sitting in a coffee shop booth, slightly angled so his legs would not be clamped under the table, and he had received a questionAre you having fun? without blink or smile. He seemed to examine it for catches or flaws in the fine, cool chambers of his mind, and then he spoke slowly, carefully, in a deep and even voice.

title: SECURITY PACIFIC ADDING N.Y. UNIT
description: The Security Pacific National Bank, Los Angeles, announced yesterday the establishment of New York headquarters for its Security Pacific International Bank subsidiary.

title: PORTUGAL'S CABINET REVISED BY CAETANO
description: LISBON, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Premier Marcello Caetano re shuffled his 15month old Cab inet tonight and reorganized the governmental structure.

title: Patricia Grant to Be February. Bride John Preston 3d Will Wed
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 14Miss Patricia Beth Grant, a speech pathologist, and Dr. Howard Roy Cohen, a resident in radiology at the New York. University Medical Center, plan to be married Here next month.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LONDON, Jan. 14Anxiety mounted today in Europe over the fate of the fleeing Biafrans as relief agencies and govern ments continued to be puzzled by the attitude of the Nigerian Government.

title: Murphy of Mets, 61, Dies
description: Johnny Murphy, the general manager of the New York Mets, died last night at Roosevelt Hospital where he had been in an intensivecare unit since suffering a heart attack on Dec. 30. Murphy, 61 years old, was an outstanding relief pitcher for the Yankees in the midnineteenthirties. Obituary on Page 45.

title: Thant Expected to Fly To Nigeria on Sunday
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14Secretary General Thant is almost certain to fly to Lagos Sunday for talks with Maj. Gen. Yakubu Go won and other Nigerian leaders, informed sources said today.

title: High Court Bids Six States Integrate Schools by Feb. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The Supreme Court ruled today that desegregation of pupils in the public schools of six Deep South states could not be put off until next fall.

title: Revlon Acquires Mitchum Concern
description: Revlon, Inc., announced yes terday it had signed an agree ment in principle to acquire the net assets and business of the Mitchum Company, a maker of antiperspirants, medicated face and body creams and related products.

title: River Battle Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (AP)Field reports said to day the crew of a United States Navy river patrol boat and Army helicopter gunships en gaged 10 to 15 North Vietnam ese soldiers trying to cross the Saigon River about 18 miles north of the capital and killed eight of the enemy with ma chinegun fire.

title: RESERVE PUTS OFF A NEW BANK CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  The Federal Reserve Board postponed today for the third time the effective date of its new regulation aimed at limit ing the sale of commercial paper by subsidiaries of banks.

title: THE PURPLE KID WINS BY A NOSE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14  Hobeau Farrn's The Purple Kid, a 4yearold Floridabred geld ing, scored his first victory today, outlasting Hustlin' Ray niond to take the $5,500 fea ture race by a nose at Liberty, Bell Race Track.

title: 7 Dead in Spanish Floods
CANADIENS RALLY TO BEAT KINGS, 42
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 14 (UPI) The Montreal Canadiens over came a twogoal deficit tonight with three powerplay goals, two of them by Jacques Le maire, and recorded their fifth straight victory with a 42 tri umph over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: NIXON TO STUMP FOR ROCKEFELLER
description: Governor Rockefeller told the Governor's Club last night that President Nixon had per sonally promised him full sup port in his bid for reelection this year.

title: No Progress in G.E. Talks
description: A union spokesman report ed yesterday that there had, been no progress in efforts to settle the strike against the General Electric Company, The Associated Press said. The spokesman commented after a meeting between the unions and Federal mediators at the Summit Hotel. The strike be gan Oct. 27.

title: Mays Discounts the Marichal Incident
description: Whether Juan Marichal criti cized Willie Mays or not, Mays doesn't like the idea that the controversy has been created at all.

title: In The Nation: Subway, Suburb and Subsidy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Finding a proper relationship between the poor inner city and the prosperous outer ring of suburbs is a genuine Amer ican dilemma. Eugene McCarthy and Robert Kennedy debated whether to enrich the life of the ghetto, which requires tax ing the suburbs, or to disperse the ghetto's residents into the suburbs. The Kerner Commis sion wrestled somewhat incon clusively with the same prob lem, and one of the most con troversial questions deriving from it is whether to bus school children from ghetto to suburb, or vice versa, or both.

title: Johnny Murphy Is Dead at 61; General Manager of the Mets
description: Johnny Murphy, general man ager of the New York Mets during the team's miraculous climb from the depths of base ball to its heights, died last night. He was 61 years old.

title: Canadian Reports From Biafra: No Evidence of Any Atrocities
description: OTTAWA, Ian. 14 (Canadian Press)Brig. Gen. John Drew ry, a Canadian military obser ber in Nigeria, has reported that the physical condition of Biafran refugees is much bet ter than was feared.

title: Main Czech Paper Denounces Dubcek Over Rightist Efforts
description: VIENNA, Jan. 14The main newspaper of the Czechoslovak Communist party today strong ly criticized Alexander Dubcek and some of the former party chief's associates who, the newspaper alleged, had or ganized a rightist center.

title: A Young Turk at Foggy Bottom Charles William Bray 3d
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Among the most atten tive listeners to a speech to day by a Deputy Under Sec retary of State on moderniza tion of the State Department was Charles William Bray 3d, a career Foreign Service offi cer.

title: U.A.R. Scorns Israeli Raids Near Cairo
description: CAIRO, Jan. 14The United Arab Republic today scorned Israeli air strikes in the vicin ity of Cairo as futile efforts to achieve political and psycho logical effects.

title: Niger Awards Concessions To the Continental Oil Co.
description: The Republic of Niger has awarded petroleum exploration concessions covering 71,630, 600 acres to the Continental Oil Company, the company announced yesterday.

title: U.F.T.Accused of Using District Plan to Help Board Candidates
description: ALBANY, Jan. 14  The United Federation of Teachers was accused by Democratic leg islators today of lobbying against new decentralization lines in Manhattan to promote unionsupported candidates in the local school elections in March.

title: Cellulosics Advanced
description: The Dow Chemical Com pany announced yesterday planned to increase the ?rice of Methocel methylcellulose products by 5 cents a pound in truckload quantities, effec tive Feb. I.

title: Census Bureau in U.S. To Start Count April 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The United States Census Bu reau is preparing in some un usual ways to conduct the na tional headcount beginning April 1.

title: Boston Museum Names Cronkite for $5,000 Prize
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) Wal ter Cronkite was named yes terday the 1970 recipient of the Bradford Washburn award for his superlative presenta tion of the American space program.

title: Credit Plan Set Up For Economic Bloc
description: PARIS, Jan. 4With a sys tem of shortterm credit sup port worked out by its central hankers the European Econom lic Community is moving ahead with deliberate speed in strengthening monetary cooper ation.

title: Utilities' Leader Denies Blackouts Menace Nation
description: The president of the trade as sociation of the investorowned electric utilities described yes terday as sheer nonsense re ports that the nation is threat ened with blackouts and power shortages.

title: Advertising: A.B.C. Aims at NonTV Users
description: Faced with the prospect of smokefree airwaves, the A.B.C. television network has created a newbusiness team and a road show that next Monday begins a sixcity tour aimed at bringing nontelevi sion advertisers into the medium.

title: Cat Cay Is Rebuilding Toward Former Game Fishing, Sailing Prominence
description: CAT CAY, Bahamas  A cold gale came out of the northwest during the night gusting to 50 knots and moaning through the coco nut palms. Windrows of sea weed piled on the white beach,, spray burst over the coral headland and 15foot waves rolled in the Gulf Stream between Cat Cay and the Florida mainland 50 miles away.

title: Marine Trainees Isolated
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Jan. 14A 290man Marine Corps training company has been placed in isolation follow ing the disclosure of the third meningitis case here since the first of the year base officials said. Pvt. Gene William O'Brien, 20 years old, of Greencastle Ind., was admitted to the base hospital Jan. 9.

title: Youngsters Act to Save Tree Growing in Brooklyn
description: Seventyfive youngsters gath ered in the chilled morning air yesterday to help save an 85yearold magnolia tree in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: 4 BOMBING SUSPECTS FACE 23 NEW COUNTS
description: A 23count superseding in dictment was returned yester day by a Federal grand jury charging two men and two wo men with conspiracy in the bombing of Federal properties in Manhattan.

title: Observer: The Ability to Come From Everywhere
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 President Nixon's habit of ap pearing in winning teams' lock er rooms, in person or by tele phone, became a familiar part of the American football ritual this winter, as did the Presi dent's incisive sports commen tary.

title: Fares in Moscow Low, but Riders Have Problems
description: MOSCOW, Jan .14Probably the only evil of metropolitan public transportation the Mus covite does not worry about is a fare increase. According to the Communist party program for transport of the masses in Mos cow, the already relatively low fares will, like the state, even tually wither away.

title: Engle Gets Stagg Award For Services to Football
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 14 Charles (Rip) Engle, former head football coach at Penn State and Brown, received the annual Amos Alonzo Stagg award today as the individual whose services have been out standing in the advancement of the best interests of foot ball.

title: Smith, Ashe and Ralston Advance in Victoria Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 14 (AP)Stan Smith, who has replaced Arthur Ashe as Amer ica's No. 1 player, was forced to the limit by 18yearold John Alexander of Australia today as he advanced to the third round of the $14,000 Victoria open tennis championship.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
U.S. Seeks to Jail De Carlo Until His Trial Ends
description: NEWARK, Jan. 14The prosecution asked Judge Rob ert Shaw today to jail Angelo De Carlo, reputed Mafia figure, and three men on trial with him in Federal District Court until the trial is over.

title: G.M. SEES AUTOS FUMEFREE BY '80
description: DETROIT, Jan. 14  The Federal Government will soon tell the automobile industry to come up with virtually pollu tionfree engines by 1980, Ed ward N. Cole, president of the General Motors Corporation, said today.

title: Texas and Penn State Will Meet on Sept. 12
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Texas and Penn State, who finished one, two in last sea son's football rankings, will meet Sept. 12 in the opening game of the 1970 season at University Park, Pa. The ar rangements were made by the coaches, Joe Paterno of Penn State and Darrell Royal of Texas, tonight during the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention.

title: Addict, 17, Seized In Cabby Holdups After Gun Battle
description: A 17yearold paroled nar cotics addict, who the police said had held up at least 10 taxi drivers here in the last three weeks, was critically wounded by detectives last night.

title: ELECTRICITY OUTPUT ROSE 9.6% IN WEEK
description: The nation's electric power production rose 9.6 per cent in the week ended Jan. 10, from the level in the corresponding 169 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute.

title: Black Panther Philosophy Is Debated at the Bernsteins
description: Leonard Bernstein and a Black Panther leader argued the merits of the Black Pan ther party's philosophy be fore nearly 90 guests at a cocktail party last night in the Bernsteins' elegant Park Avenue duplex.

title: GAIN AT CHEMICAL AND BANKAMERICA
description: The BankAmerica Corpora tion and the Chemical New York Corporation, onebank holding companies that rank among the nation's largest banking institutions, reported yesterday increases in 1969 earnings.

title: GREEKS SENTENCE 5 WHO LIVE ABROAD
description: ATHENS, Jan. 14A military tribunal in Athens today sen tenced five Greeks who are living abroad to prison terms and fines for antinational ac tivities.

title: TV: A Satire About Shameful Secrets
description: THERE is only one thing wrong with a satire of soap operas. Nothing can be more outrageously improb able than the originals. Last night the National Broadcast ing Company made a decent try with The Shameful Se crets of Hastings Corners, a spoof of Peyton Place that was frequently droll, some times clever but much too lighthearted to draw blood.

title: Board of Education Approves Record Budget $1.64Billion
description: The Board of Education yes terday approved a record operating budget request of $1,640,946,293 for the fiscal year beginning next July 11.

title: Jimmy and Pete Bostwick Gain in Open Court Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 The Bostwick brothers, Jimmy and Pete, of New York, won their first matches in the United States open court tennis sin gles championship today at the Racquet Club.

title: AWOL Harlem Airman Kills Himself in Terminal
description: A 20yearold Air Force pri vate from East Harlem who, the police said, had been ab sent without leave for a month from a Puerto Rican airfield, shot and killed himself early yesterday while sitting in the waiting room at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Retailer Stresses Urgency for Negro Aid
description: Retailers have not done enough, either to raise the Negro's employment potential in their stores, or to improve his lot in the community, de spite many pioneering ef forts along these lines by individual merchants, a new national spokesman for re tailers said here yesterday.

title: SABOT AGE IS HINTED AT U.S. ATOM PLANT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Federal agents are investiga ting indications of sabotage at an Atomic Energy Commission plant, Government sources dis closed today.

title: Nevada Judge Is Penalized
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 14 (UPI)Chief Justice Jon Col lins of the Nevada Supreme Court will lose his driver's li cense for six months for refus ing to take a bloodalcohol test after his arrest last month, the State Department of Motor Vehicles said today.

title: Bridge: New Editor of League Bulletin Demonstrates Skill as Player
description: THE first major tournament for New York enthusi asts in this decade begins today at Grossinger's in the Catskills. It is the TriState Regionals, offering a chance for those on the life master trail to win red points and gold points.

title: Liquor Query Draws Hazy Cigarette Reply
description: Having completed a talk entitled Selling Cigarettes Worldwide . . . Ground Rules and Exceptions without giv ing away any trade secrets or saying anything controver sial, Fred A. Goldstein, direc tor of marketing research for Liggett & Myers, accepted questions from the luncheon guests.

title: Intoxication Test Upheld
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 14 (UPI)The Ohio Supreme Court ruled today that the law order ing a motorist to submit to a chemical intoxication test was constitutional. The ruling was in the case of Herbert G. Starnes of Toledo, who charged that the law was unconstitu tional because it permitted un reasonable search and seizure and compels a person to be a witness against himself.

title: Amex Seat Sale Up
description: The American Stock Ex change reported yesterday that arrangements had been made for the transfer of two seats on the exchange, one at $185, 000, up $5,000 from the last sale on Jan. 7 and the other at $180,000. The current price, it said, was $170,000 bid, $190, 000 asked.

title: Robbers' Slayers Accused
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 14 (UPI) Two brothers who shot three wouldbe robbers to death in their Euclid Avenue grocery a week ago were cited yesterday for a building violation. The citation involved the automatic electric lock Robert and Jack Montgomery have on their front door. The lock was used to trap the wouldbe robbers inside the market. Building Commissioner Carlton Rush said the lock violated fire safe ty standards.

title: Will Maine Show the Way?
description: Legislators of Maine, meeting in special session this month, have a unique opportunity to help preserve for their constituents and for millions of envious fellow Americans the natural splendor of one of the nation's leastspoiled states.

title: AIR NEW ZEALAND WESTBURY VICTOR
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 14 The wonder at Roosevelt Race way tonight was that a total of 13,076 persons turned out for the program. The temperature was 17 degrees, but the wind velocity made the chill factor high enough to make ski cos tumes de rigueur.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON HOLD FIRM TONE
JEWS WIN RULING ON BURIALS HERE
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice ordered striking gravedig gers yesterday to permit burials of Jews in metropolitan ceme teries in accordance with Orthodox religious law.

title: 435Carat Diamond to Aid Peace Drive
description: The discovery of a 435 carat rough diamond, 2 inches long and 2 inches wide, in West Africa last year was announced here yester day.

title: Fire Damage Award Upheld
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP)The United States.Court of Appeals has upheld awards of more than $475,000 against the Penn Central for damages suffered by six companies in a fire at the railroad's Allston Freight terminal in 1965. They are Sears, Roebuck & Co., Gaigny Chemical Corporation, City Products, Boeing Company, North American Rockwell Cor poration and Austin Shoe

title: Business Records
description: EASTERN DISTRICT

title: Mrs. Kennedy Has Surgery
description: Mrs. Joan Kennedy, wife of Senator Edward M. Kennedy had her tonsils and adenoids removed yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. The Senator was at the hospital during the hour long surgery, which a hospita. spokesman said went very well Mrs. Kennedy is expected to remain in the hospital for sev aral days.

title: LATIN AMERICANS PLAN NEWS AGENCY
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 14A group of major LatinAmerican newspapers are founding a news agency that will report on hemispheric and world af fairs from a LatinAmerican point of view.

title: RUSSELL LUTZ, 67, SHIPPING EXPERT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 E. Russell Lutz, retired steam ship executive, maritime law yer and former State Depart ment legal adviser, died Mon day of heart failure at George Washington University Hospit al. He was 67 years old and lived here at 1427 34th Street,, N. W.

title: BELL & HOWELL SEES DECREASE IN '69 NET
description: The Bell & Howell Company introduced yesterday a new system for showing and storing color slides. The showing at Lincoln Center came after a DowJones interview with Peter G. Peterson, chairman and chief executive officer, in which he said he expected the company to report that 1969 operating net would be down as much as 15 per cent from the 1968 level.

title: Hussein Wants Western Arms
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 14 King Hussein of Jordan has re asserted his intention to arm Jordan with weapons, including aircraft, from the West, despite pressures on him to take arms from the East.

title: Errors Charged in '22 Baseball Ruling
description: Curt Flood's impending suit against baseball's reserve clause has stirred so much interest within the legal pro fession that the New York Law Journal began yesterday a threepart series, displayed prominently on its first page, analyzing some of the under lying issues.

title: Con Ed Shelved Study on Executives
description: Consolidated Edison paid $795,000 for an efficiency survey, of the company by an outside firm of manage ment consultants but when the consultants reported that the utility was topheavy with executives nothing was done about it, according to testimony before the Public Service Commission yester day.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS PRESS FOR A RISE IN EDUCATION AID
description: ALBANY, Jan. 14The Dem ocratic minority leaders in the Legislature today presented a program for the 197071 school year that calls for adding $720 million to the anticipated schoolaid budget of more than $2billion.

title: State G.O.P. Leaders Consider Endorsing Celler
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Republican leaders in New York are considering the unu usual step of endorsing the re election of Representative Emanuel Celler, the 81yearold Brooklyn Democrat who will be seeking his 25th consecutive term in the House next fall.

title: Queens Widower Awarded $315,000 in Wife's Death
description: A Queens chemist was awarded $315,000 In Queens Supreme Court Tuesday follow ing a sixday trial concerning the death of his wife, who was suffering from arthritis.

title: CarTrain Crash in Kenya Kills 3 in U.S. Peace Corps
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)  Three young women mem bers of the Peace Corps were killed in Eldoret, Kenya, yes terday when their car was struck by a train, a corps snokesman said today.

title: Memorial Services
description: RODGERSMortimer W. M.D. Memorial service will be held in Einhorn Auditorium of Lenox Hill Hospital, 131 E. 76th St., 4 P.M. Thursday, Jan. 15. Friends and former patients are invited.

title: Market Place: A Caustic View Of Penn Central
description: THE story in this column relating a brokerage house's glowing opinion of Penn Central stock came at the wrong time for W. S. Wurzburger, a principal in a small Wall Street brokerage house and a daily commuter on the Central's Harlem divi sion.

title: Chicago Exchange Seeks New Rules; Members Protest
description: The Midwest Stock Ex change in Chicago announced yesterday that it had submit ted rules changes to the Securities and Exchange Commission covering public ownership of member firms.

title: Fish Protein Concentrate Fails First Test in Effort to Produce Food Additive for the Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Fish protein concentrate, once heralded as the big weapon in the war on hunger, remains an illusive dream despite the best efforts of Government and private business to produce it commercially.

title: Music: Balance in Ottawa
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 14Where symphonic music is con cerned, American cities with a population of 300,000 might well look at what is happening in Ottawa, a city of comparable size. The Canadian capital, with its new National Arts Center, has established an enlight ened and very satisfactory situation, exemplified by the midseason concert given by the center's orchestra last night.

title: N.C.A.A. Denies Bid for Council To Sanction Maccabiah Sport
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The National Collegiate Ath letic Association refused today to give its Council explicit power to sanction the basket ball competition in the Mac cabiah Games. The association members did this by tabling a motion that would have given this right to the Council. The proposed rule was presented to the 64th annual N.C.A.A. mem bersnip meeting by the eight Ivy League colleges.

title: A High School Dropout and, at 17, a Ballet Star
description: IN ballet circles, she has emerged as somewhat of a prodigy. She has been likened to a young princess. But when Gelsey Kirkland is not at New York State Thea ter, where she danced lead ing roles at the age of 16 with the New York City Bal let this season, what is she like?

title: A U.S. AIDE IN TEXAS IS FORCED TO RESIGN
description: TYLER, Tex., Jan. 14 (AP) United States Attorney Richard B. Hardee of Texas' eastern dis trict resigned today under pres sure from the Department of Justice.

title: Burns U.S.L.T.A. Aide
description: Michael J. Burns joined the staff of the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday as an administrative assistant. He will be concerned primarily with public relations and the promotion of membership. He previously coordinated tennis activities for Madison Square Garden Center.

title: NEWARK EMPLOYE CITED IN TAX CASE
description: NEWARK, Jan. 14A munic ipal employe was indicted by a Federal grand jury today and charged with 18 counts of as sisting in the preparation of false income tax returns for his clients.

title: STATE INQUIRY ASKED IN PROTESTER'S CASE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 14 The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court and the State Attorney General were asked by the Nassau County Executive today to investigate the treatment received in court by a 26yearold mother of two who was arrested for flying the American flag upside down as an antiwar protest.

title: The Professor Has Proved a Good Student of French Cooking
description: IT isn't mere happenstance that Maur ice Shroder's West Side apartment has a Gallic ambiance. On a clear day the sun pours into the place as if it were Provence; there are bottles of Chateau Ausone, 1942, stashed away here and there, and it smells like stale Gauloise. Mr. Shroder is a professor of French at Barnard College and a corking good cook.

title: F.A.A. Criticizes Boeing 747 Escape Chutes
description: The head of the Federal Avia tion Administration said yes terday that it was not satisfied with the emergency evacuation system of the new Boeing 747 and raised the possibility that the jumbo jet would not be allowed to begin commercial service on schedule next week.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS MORE BUDGET CUTS IN INFLATION FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 President Nixon has ordered further substantial cuts in the budget for the fiscal year 1971 to combat inflation, the White House said today.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Unit Plans to Turn Rentals Into Coops
description: The head of the Metropolitan Housing Council of the National Association for the Advance ment of Colored People an nounced yesterday that the council was negotiating to turn several large apartment build ings into coops for low and moderateincome families.

title: Schooner's Crew Saved In MidAtlantic Storm
description: The seven crewmen of the threemasted schooner Tina Maria Doncie were transferred safely to an American freighter yesterday in the midst of gale force winds in the midAtlantic.

title: KING SPEECHES READ TO SOUL ROCK HERE
description: A jazz group made up of for mer inmates of Rikers Island Prisonincluding Maurice Wal ler, son of Fats Waller, the late jazz pianistimprovised accom paniment to a program of read ings from the speeches and let ters of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King. Jr. yesterday at the Holy Family Roman Cath olic Church, 315 East 47th Street.

title: L. I. Mother of Four Gets Term in Husband's Slaying
description: MINEOLA, Jan. 14 (UPI)A Plainview, L. I., mother of four was sentenced today in Nassau County Court to a onetonine war prison term for the slaying of her husband, an insurance executive, on Aug. 4, 1968.

title: Cunningham Solos Lend Frantic Tinge To Abstract Place
description: Choreographers are not French restaurants. But if any one is handing out four stars, Merce Cunningham's Place could go to the top of the list. Last night, the Cunningham Dance Company performed the piece, probably Mr. Cunning ham's finest, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: A.E.C. Aide Scoffs at Radiation Fears
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 14 Theos J. Thompson, com mission of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, said today that excessive con cern by environmentalists over radiation hazards had been carried to an almost ridiculous extreme.

title: SERVICES TODAY TO HONOR DR. KING
description: Commemorative services will be held in the city and through out the nation today on the 41st anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. the assassinated civil rights leader.

title: ... and Deal With Strikes
description: The disclosure that the Nixon Administration plans to ask Congress for new laws to deal with national emergency strikes would be more encouraging if it were not accompanied by a Labor Department study minimizing the effect of such strikes.

title: Books of The Times
description: THIS savage, eloquent, factfilled book seems a sort of Unhappy Birthday card to Martin Luther King. Dr. King proposed the 1968 Poor People's March on Washington less than a week before his assassination, and Let Them Eat Promises is partly a body count of that abortive engagement. It's as though our national con science were a cement block, and Nick Kotz resolved with a sledge ham mer to drive spike after spike of re proach into it un til it crumbles or is shaped into something not quite so ugly. No more sophistry, he insists: The poor est Americans who have been buried in the Deep South, the Indian reserva tions, the barrios of the Southwest, and the big city ghetto did not fail to make it in America because they lacked ambition or ability. The plantation system, the migrant system, the mining system, the Indian welfare sys tem all created long odds against a man's breaking out of a cycle of abject, depend ent peonage.

title: Music: Miss Horne Sings
description: FOR a good part of the New Jersey Symphony program last night in Carne gie Hall, the large audience waited patiently for one thingto hear Marilyn Horne unleash her full powers in the Rossinian fioritura. The first part of the program was devoted to Act II of Gluck's Orfeo ed Euridice, which offers relatively few oppor tunities for allout virtuoso work. Miss Home's faithful following applauded this faithfully; but it remained for a pair of arias from Ros sini's Siege of Corinth to turn everybody into some thing approaching lunacy.

title: Scranton Teachers Return
description: SCRANTON, Pa, Jan. 14 (UPI)Striking teachers in the public school system decided to go back to school today be cause their twoday strike ap parently lacked solid support. The Scranton Education Asso ciation voted Sunday night to walk out to back up demands for a $640 annual wage in crease, but many members crossed their own picket lines today. The Scranton Education Asso ciation voted Sunday night to walk out to back up demands for a $640 annual wage in crease, but many members crossed their own picket lines today.

title: NEW SATO CABINET STRESSES U.S. TIES
description: TOKYO, Jan. 14Eisaku Sato, reelected Premier of Japan by the parliament today, named a Cabinet emphasizing continuity in proAmerican foreign policies and moderately conservative domestic programs, but with interesting nuances in both fields.

title: Washington Aide Finds No Evidence of Reprisals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The State Department reported to day that Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, Nigeria's head of state, had told an American repre sentative of his warm appre ciation of American offers of aid.

title: Vassar Dean Quits at Simpson's Request
description: Dr. Nell Eurich resigned as dean of the faculty at Vas sar College yesterday at the request of the college's pres ident, Dr. Alan Simpson.

title: Chapman Says U.S.Will Keep Marine Division in Okinawa
description: NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 14 Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., commandant of the United States Marine Corps, said here today that the Marine troop strength in Okinawa would re main at the present level of 19,000, even after the island reverts to Japanese administra tion in 1972.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
COUGARS BEAT NETS AS VERGA SCORES 40
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 14 (UPI)Bob Verga scored 40 points tonight to pace the Carolina Cougars to a 112107 victory over the New York Nets in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Senate Committee to Open Vietnam Hearings Feb. 2
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee plans to open its public hearings on the Vietnam war on Feb. 2, committee sources said today.

title: SISCO MEETS HEADS OF JEWISH GROUPS
description: Joseph J. Sisco, the State De partment's negotiator on the Middle East, met privately with Jewish leaders yesterday in an effort to allay their concern about United States policy to ward Israel.

title: Two Fliers Killed on Guam
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)  Two crew members of an F4C Phantom fighterbomber were killed yesterday when their plane collided with a Strategic Air Command tanker aircraft on a runway at Ander son Air Force Base on Guam. The Air Force listed the dead as Lieut. Col. Michael E. Styer of Phoenix, Ariz., and First Lieut. Terry L. Banning of Rock Island, Ill.

title: BRANDT REVISES POSITION ON EAST
description: BONN, Jan. 14Chancellor Willy Brandt proposed today that West Germany and East Germany begin talks soon with an open agenda, aimed at achieving a regulated rela tionship.

title: Typhoid on an Ocean Liner Brings Quarantine in Port
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Jan. 14 (Canadian Press)  The ocean liner Oronsay was held in quarantine for four hours here today while health authorities checked the crew and passengers for typhoid.

title: 2 CAR MAKERS SET OUTPUT CUTBACK
description: DETROIT, Jan. 14  The Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company an nounced today more production cutbacks in the wake of falling car sales. The company also disclosed its 1970 capital spend ing budget would be down to $300million from $376million spent in 1969.

title: Chess:
description: DR. OREST POPOVYCH of Brooklyn, an experi enced competitor outscored 105 players for first place during the recent 16th North Central Open in Milwaukee.

title: Elisabeth Krautter Is Betrothed
description: Elisabeth Ward Krautter and Alexander Ferguson Treadwell, reporters for Sports Illustrated magazine, Dian to be married in March.

title: STATE DEPT. MAPS INTERNAL REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The State Department unveiled a wideranging plan today to reassert its leadership in for eign policy, to revitalize the nation's diplomatic service and to make better use of its per sonnel.

title: $ MAFIA FIGURES BALK AT HEARING
description: Joseph Colombo, reputed to be a powerful leader of the Mafia in Brooklyn, invoked the Fifth Amendment 50 times yes terday on questions about the, underworld.

title: Udall Says Nation Must Curb Growth to Spare Environment
description: Stewart L. Udall, the former Secretary of the Interior, said last night that limits would have to put on this country's growth in the next decade to avoid destroying the environ ment.

title: In Memoriam
description: BANWER Irving, Daddy dearest, your second birthday in Heaven.

title: Big Six Mayors Move
description: ALBANY, Jan. 14The 1970 71 state budget, which Gov ernor Rockefeller will present to the Legislature next week, is virtually completed, but the mayors of the state's six largest cities have only begun a new kind of struggle for po litical leverage they hope will change that budget. This struggle, which re lies mainly on efforts to mobilize public opinion, is a new twist in a state more ac customed to a system in which party policy is translated into public policy.

title: Man, His Culture and God: Foundation Sours a Union
description: When Graham Grove looks at a church, he sees more than its steeple or facade. He sees an art gallery, not in use. When he surveys the whole church scene, he sees a potential 300,000 art gal leries.

title: Eban Scores Paris on Arms
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 14Israel appeared today to have finally written off France as an arms supplier and to have decided to denend on the United States.

title: Buddhist Students' Peace Rally In Saigon Is Dispersed by Police
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 15The Saigon police broke up a meeting this morning at the An Quang Pa goda in which militant Bud dhist students had called on the people to rise up in a national campaign for peace.

title: Beirut Frees Hijacker Of U.S. Jet on $8 Bail
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 14 The Lebanese Government today released Christian Be Ion, the 26yearold French man, who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet to Beirut last Friday, on bail of $8. However, Belo decided to spend another night in cus tody pending word from the French authorities on wheth er they would try him if he returned to Paris. He is stay ing at a prison hospital out side Beirut. spend another night in cus tody pending word from the French authorities on wheth er they would try him if he returned to Paris. He is stay ing at a prison hospital out side Beirut.

title: GIBSON OF CARDS TO DRAW $125,000
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 14 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals an nounced today the signing of Bob Gibson for a salary re ported to be $125,000, second highest in the major leagues.

title: U. S. Jury Indicts a Swiss Bank And Former Shearson Official
description: The former first vice presi dent of Shearson, Hammill & Co., Inc., stockbrokers, and a Swiss bank and its general manager were indicted yester day by a Federal grand jury in an alleged conspiracy to use secret Swiss bank accounts to evade margin requirements in the purchase of securities.

title: Justice Is Redesignated
description: ALBANY, Jan. 14 (AP)Jus tice Harold A. Stevens of Man hattan was redesignated Wednesday as presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, First De partment, which covers the Bronx and Manhattan. Justice Stevens, named by Governor Rockefeller, will serve a term running concurrently with his term as a Supreme Court Jus tice, ending Dec. 31, 1977.

title: To Stop the Inflation ...
description: The Nixon Administration took office a year ago with the commendable goal of halting inflation without causing a recession. It sought to do this by gradually tightening fiscal and monetary policy but without re so??ng to wageprice guideposts or Presidential jawboning.

title: Witness Says Police in Chicago Broke His Arm During Protest
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 14A col lege student said today that his arm had been broken by Chi cago policemen as they pulled him from a statue in Grant Park during demonstrations at the 1968 Democratic National Con vention here.

title: 4 Seized Protesting Penalty In Class Use of Nude Models
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 14 (UPI)Four students were ar rested today at Long Beach State College during a protest over the suspension of two as sistant professors who had used nude models to teach a class in sociology.

title: Flight Safety Unit Elects
description: Murray Sargent Jr., a New York and Westport, Conn., cor porate official and lawyer, has been elected president of the Flight Safety Foundation, Inc., of Arlington, Va. He succeeds Joseph D. Caldara, who re signed last December. The foundation is a nonprofit or ganization concerned with all phases of global flight safety.

title: Studies Find Low Doses of Carbon Monoxide May Be Perilous
