description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 17 Papwa Sew golum, a leading nonwhite pro fessional golfer, says that he thinks he may he forced to leave South Africa and play overseas to earn a living. He said so at his home in Durban after being told that the Gov ernment had turned down his application to play in the South African Open at Duman next month.

title: Hospitality in the Berkshires
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass.  Paul Bousquet, whose father founded Bous quet's ski area here in the Berkshires in 1932, is back at his childhood home with the aim of giving Bousquet's some of the character it enjoyed back in the days when the rope tow was considered a luxury.

title: Barbara Frelinghuysen Is Married
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Jan. 17  Miss Barbara Fre linghuysen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Freling huysen, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Craig Israel, son of Mrs. Eleanor Israel of Washington and Adrian Cremieux Israel of Stamford, Conn. The Rev.

title: Con Edison's Request for Rate Rise on Electricity Contains Escalator Clause for Tax Increases
description: A staff analysis by the Public Service Commission has shown that Consolidated Edison's ap plication for a 15.3 per cent in crea??e in its electricity rates includes a plan to introduce a surcharge automatically pass ing on to all its customers any increase in local taxes.

title: In The Nation: Philadelphia, Chicago and Meany
description: WASHINGTON  President George Meany of the A.F.L. C.I.O. sought this week to jus tify his fight against the Nixon Administration's socalled Phil adelphia Plan to expand minor ity employment in the building trades. But union officials themselves were part of an agreement in Chicago that sud denly left Mr. Meany even more exposed in his strange opposi tion.

title: Drama Mailbag: For Coco, Love and Hate
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Gallic Exuberance Of St. Lucia
description: CASTRIES, St. Lucia, W. I.  Because it is so beautiful and so many wars have been fought over it, the island of St. Lucia has been called The Helen of the West. Situated halfway down the Lesser Antilles, St. Lucia is neither large nor small by Caribbean standards (it measures 238 square miles), but it was so strategic in the struggle between England and France that it was exchanged between the two 14 times between 1650 and 1814, when it finally became English.

title: Pro Basketball
description: AT BOSTON

title: Prey
description: HERMANN PREY has found an island, not in the Pacific but in the North Sea. Win ter there is bitter cold but last summer, the German lyric baritone says, Amrum was like the Riviera. Why would an internationally celebrated opera and lieder singer choose a tiny spot off the Danish coast as a place possibly to move to with his wife, three children, large dog, two birds and hamster? Partially because he found and bought a lovely twocen turyold brick home there, but really because of the frightening predictions made by Nostradamus about the coming Third World War.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: Rediscovering Louisiana's Evangeline Country
description: EUNICE, La.Communities and even entire sections of the country have been known to collapse as tourist areas when a new Interstate high way siphons traffic from old roads. This fate loomed for the Evangeline country of southern Louisiana three years ago, when Interstate 10 was opened and took away the onceheavy visitor traffic along U.S. 190.

title: Mitchell Depicts Ripon Society As Little Juvenile Delinquents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell today called the Ripon Society, a liberal Republican organization, those little ju venile delinquents.

title: A Mann for Bach At Bethlehem
description: IN the musical world, at least, 1970 is the Beethoven year, because it is the 200th anniversary of his birth. But what year isn't a Beethoven year, judging by the amount of the composer's music that is played? And what year isn't a Bach year, with annual festivals at Bethlehem, Pa.; Cranbrook, Mich.; Berea, Ohio; Carmel, Caiif.; Winter Park, Fla., and still other places?

title: Stamps
description: HERMAN MELVILLE'S Moby Dick will be embossed on a com memorative United States envelope to be issued March 7 at New Bedford Mass., in honor of the author as well as to recall the Amer ican whaling industry that once flourished from that Massachusetts port.

title: Article 3  No Title
PROCTOR IS WINNER IN COAST AUTO RACE

title: 3 Killed in Clash in India
description: MADRAS, India, Jan. 17 (Reuters)  Three Persons were killed last night in a clash be tween ??

title: Democrats Are Not Finding Nixon an Easy Target
description: WASHINGTONAs the 91st Congress returns this week for its second session, Congressional Democrats suddenly find them selves bereft of issues at the very time they are casting around for political points to use against a Republican Administra tion in the Congressional elec tions next fall.

title: COLUMBIA POSTS VICTORY IN TRACK
description: Columbia's track team built a 3311 lead in the five field events, then held on to defeat Lafayette, 5652, yesterday at Baker Field. The victory broke a 20meet losing streak.

title: Historic Turn in Bonn
description: Germany's first Socialist Chancellor in four decades, Willy Brandt, is setting the Bonn Republic on a dra matically new course. In his first State of the Nation speech he has addressed himself almost entirely to West German relations with East Germany  and its bearing on policy toward East and West as a whole.

title: KNIGHTS OF MALTA TO INDUCT 48 HERE
description: ROME, Jan. 17The premier of the smallest sovereignty in the world, the Sovereign Mili tary and Hospitaler Order of St. John of Jerusalem of Rhocies and of Malta, is scheduled to go to New York on Monday to help induct 48 new American knights into the Roman Catholic order.

title: Is the Alligator Doomed?
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Is the al ligator, which is one of Florida's major tourist attractions, doomed to extinction? Although the United States Department of the Interior has placed the alligator on its list of en dangered species, the Florida Game and FreshWater Fish Commission reports that this is one of the few states where the animal still survives in large numbers.

title: Cynthia Coren Future Bride
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan 17Mr. and. Mrs. Hary V. Coren have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Cynthia Librescot Coren, to Richard Michael Gottlieb. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Gottlieb of New York.

title: The 1 to Beat: STP's GermanBuilt Racing Team
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 17  Andy Granatelli is now turn ing to Germany for the race cars he will campaign on the championship trail of the United States Auto Club. Granatelli, owner of the STP Racing Team, announced here yesterday that four new cars would be built by German craftsmen for Mario Andretti to drive in this year's compe tition.

title: Adveture Into a Virgin Forest
description: IN 1911, in Paris, the Italianborn American ar tist Joseph Stella had glimpse of the promised land of modern art. He was 34 at the time, and his en counter with the major fig ures of the modern movement made an indelible impression on his artistic consciousness.

title: Soviet Distorted Recent Maps; Security Is Believed the Reason
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Government cartographers have discovered puzzling locational shifts in recent Russian atlases that seem to indicate distortion of the entire map of the Soviet Union for national security.

title: Injured Right Knee Shelves Thurmond Rest of Season
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 (UPI)Nate Thurmond of the San Francisco Warriors will: be sidelined for the rest of the National Basketball Association season as a result of a torn cartilage in his right knee, the club said tonight.

title: MANHATTAN BEATS ARMY FIVE, 6057
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 17  Henry Seawright converted, three free throws in the final minute of play tonight to lead Manhattan to a 6057 victory over Army.

title: MADISON SCHOOL PUZZLED BY BOMB
description: The small bomb that exploded in the office of the dean of boys at James Madison High School early last Monday startled and puzzled officials and students at what has long been among the most stable and peaceful of the city's high schools.

title: Air Canada's New Chief Winds Up Big First Year
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 17Yves Pratte, the chairman of Air Canada, has been running the airline for only a year, but he has gotten off to a fast start by purchasing aircraft and equipment worth about a bil lion dollars, by challenging the airline industry to simplify its complex fare structure and by expanding routes.

title: Lagos Bars Danish Plane
description: GENEVA, Jan. 17  The Ni gerian Government has denied permission for a Danish Red Cross plane with 10 tons of medical supplies to land at La gos, the International Commit tee of the Red Cross said today.

title: Economist Takes a Look at Growth Patterns
description: The Sixties answered two fundamental questions posed by the Fifties: Could the United States economy still grow? And would growth solve its problems?

title: WAKE FOREST TOPS NO. CAROLINA, 9190
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 17 (AP)Charlie Davis, Wake For est guard, paced a secondhalf rally that gave the Deacons a 9190 victory over the seventh ranked North Carolina Tar Heels today.

title: Egyptians Deny Reports
description: CAIRO, Jan. 17 Reports from Jerusalem that Israeli commandos penetrated Egypt's Eastern Desert last night and severed telephone and power lines between Cairo and Port Suez were denied here today as fictitious and unfounded.

title: ECONOMIST SEES POPULATION SHIFT
description: A City College economist predicts Manhattan's nonwhite population will begin to de crease after this year. The per centage in Manhattan's over all populatiion, however, he esti mates will increase as whites thin out even faster.

title: Gardens
description: PREVIEW spring by coax ing violets into flower on a window sill in a covered glass contain er. Any terrarium type plant er may bemused if it is about six inches tall to accommo date the foliage. My prefer ence is an old tank aquarium but there are oval fish bowls, cookie jars and gallon brandy glasses.

title: Courses Suspect in CanAm Failures
description: WHAT'S happening at American Raceways, Inc.? A.R.I., which runs a sort of chainstore operation in motor racing (four tracks operating and one being planned,), relinquished two CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup races last week because it could see no prospect of making a profit. Giving up two races with the CanAm's poten tion is a signal that A.R.I. has problems. CanAms are among the most soughtafter dates in racing. Promoters, A.R.I. included, have been willing to offer up to $75,000 in prize money and about $7,500 in sanction fees, be sides their normal operating expenses, for a CanAm date. Why, then, did A.R.I. bomb in its Michigan and Texas CanAms last season?

title: Mrs. Hoffert Has Son
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 17 A son was born Jan. 5 at the YaleNew Haven Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Jay Hof fert.

description: Management TO THE FINANCIAL EDITOR:

title: SECRECY IN INDIANA IS SCORED BY PRESS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 17 The Indiana State Press Asso ciation says that efforts to end secrecy in the Indiana General Assembly will be taken to the state's voters later this year if legislators themselves fail to abolish closed committee ses sions.

description: PELHAM, N. Y., Jan. 17 Paul E. Bacas, a certified pub lic accountant since 1926 and a former adjunct professor of accounting at New York Uni versity, died today at his home, 12 Young Avenue.

description: Norman E. Alexander, presi dent of the Sun Chemical Cor poration, has been named a trustee of the BronxLehanon Hospital Center, Seymour Mil stein, president, announced yes terday. The center has 600 beds and a staff of 2,000

description: AMPURIAS, Spain  Thanks to the sand that covered them and to the archeologists who uncovered them, it is possible, here on Spain's Costa Brava, to walk through the ruins of both a Greek town once called Neopolis and an adjacent Roman settlement known as Emporion.

title: STUDY FINDS JEWS COLLEGEORIENTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The proportion of Jewish college age youth attending schools of higher education may be as high as 95 per cent about double the national average for American youth.

description: CAN the truth prevail against false idea whose time has come?

title: Doctor Given Irish Chair
description: Dr. Kevin M. Cahill, director of the Tropical Disease Center at St. Clare's Hospital here, has been appointed to the chair of tropical medicine at the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland. Dr. Cahill will direct courses and studies given through the cooperation of the World Health Organization. He will continue to hold his position at St. Clare's.

title: MAYOR ASKS AID IN ALBANY BATTLE
description: Mayor Lindsay urged 2,000 members of the United Parents Association yesterday to help him battle in Albany for gradual stepbystep assump tion by the state of the fund ing of education.

title: Fern Sklover To Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Fern Patricia Sklover to Don ald Prosnitz has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. I. T. Sklover of Queens Village, Queens. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Prosnitz of East Hills, L. I.

title: NUCLEAR PROJECT FOUND IN TROUBLE
description: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 17A threeday symposium on Prc Plowshare ended today, nuclear program's probl seemed as impressive as accomplishments.

title: Pets Are Blessed in Rome
description: ROME. Jan. 17 (Reuters) Italian animal lovers took their dogs horses, cats, even birds to church today to have them blessed on the feast day of Saint Anthony of Egypt, pro tector of animals. In Rome, the City Council made its annual presentation of oats to more than 100 of the city's carriage horses.

title: C.L.U. SEEKS TO CURB UNDERCOVER AGENTS
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday announced it would start a campaign to curb what it termed the growing use of undercover police agents to infiltrate private associations, particularly schools and polit ical organizations.

description: HOUSTON, Jan. 17In a domed crypt with 30,170 mourners, the American Foot ball League was interred quiet ly today as its Western All Stars routed the Eastern All Stars, 263.

title: Wives of 4 Missing Fliers Seek Information in Laos
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 17 (AP)The wives of four Amer ican fliers missing in Vietnam flew to Laos today to seek the assistance of North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao officials in obtaining information about their husbands.

title: Assessment Results To Be on View Soon
description: BY next Sunday the an nual job of assessing each of the more than 835,000 parcels of taxable real estate in the city must be complete. The figures are then made ready for public inspection in each borough from Feb. 2 to March 16, during which time appeals can be filed.

title: The World
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon was exuberant. As the five Biafran leaders walk ed into the conference room at Dodan barracks to submit their formal surrender to the head of the Federal Nigerian Govern ment, he shook hands with them. How are you? Glad to see you again, he said to one. How are you? Welcome back, he said to another.

title: Architecture
description: LAST week we offered a subjective summary of the architecture explo sionor how building has turned into environment in the last ten years. For the arch??tect  planner  environ mentalist in 1970, this means that he must be a combina tion of gutsociologist, Olym pian formgiver, esthete, hu manitarian, economist and oracle, with an equal grasp of systems technology, zon ing regulations, people hang ups and that elusive thing called quality of life. Gentle men (and ladies): lots of luck.

title: Symposium Point Proved
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 17 (UPI)  Nearly 2,000 persons had to be turned away from symposium on the University of California campus because of lack of space. The sympo sium which was held Wednes day night, was on the Popula tion Explosion.

title: Six Aspiring Democrats Give State Preview at Syracuse Forum
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 17  Six Democratic politicians who want to be Governor, United States Senator or State Attor ney General sought some early traction for their bandwagons today here in the icy heartland of New York.

title: Birth Defect Clinic For Prenatal Care Starts in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE. Jan. 17 (AP) Johns Hopkins Hospital has announced the establishment of a prenatal birth defects pre vention center.

title: Congress at the Half
description: As the 91st Congress goes into its second session, the factors that made it seem less than effective are, if anything, aggravated. The normal strain between a President and a Congress of opposite parties can only be increased in an election year. What is more, the tugofwar between those who want to cool the economy and those who want to step up social spend ing is bound to be fiercer under the conflicting pulls of a growing inflation and an incipient recession.

title: The Two Nations At Wesleyan University
description: THE old John Wesley House, a splendid campus landmark with white Ionic columns, turned into the Malcolm X House one sunny day last April. Overnight it became a conspicuous presence on the startled New England landscape. The sky did not fall and the earth did not tremble; neither did the alumni with draw their support. But Wesleyan, a small, estimable, historically white university in Middletown, would never be the same. We have passed the point of no return, says a Wes leyan administrator. The blacks are here in force and they are here to stay.

title: Demand Gains; Output, Prices Of Coal Rising
description: In most parts of the coun try, an American has to be near middle age to remember when the coal man came to the house. Looking like a fugi tive from a minstrel show in his veneer of black dust, he used to back his truck to a cellar window. Then he would empty burlap bags of coal or coke down a chute into a bin near the furnace.

title: Rights Commission Told U.S. Agencies Fail to Stop Racial Bias in Suburbs
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17Larman Wilson, a softspoken Negro school teacher, was testifying before the United States Com mission on Civil Rights:

title: GLENN'S OPPONENT IN UPHILL BATTLE
description: COLUMBUS. Ohio, Jan. 14 Can you imagine a less likely candidate? Howard Metzen haum asked a friend earlier this month. A Jew, a labor lawyer, a Clevelander and a millionaire.

description: QUEBEC, Jan. 17Delegates to a Quebec Liberal party con vention chose Robert A. Bou rassa, a 36yearold Harvard trained economist, today to be their new leader.

description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 17Mr. and Mrs. D. Bruce Mansfield have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Jane Elliott Mansfield, to Samuel Clark Oliver Holt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thad Holt of Birmingham, Ala.

title: Art in Paris
description: PARIS. O DD, one begins to think, that art should ever be otherwise. Women, flowers, the sky, mem ories of childhood, adult joys and hopes, color, excitement. Why paint at all, if not about the life that surges through you, the things that are you and are worth celebrating?

title: CRACK RULER WINS 2D HALF OF STAKE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) Wattle I Get and Crack Ruler captured divisions of the Gel mantown Handicap before record crowd of 21,926 today at Liberty Bell Race Track.

title: Dominica A Diamond In the Rough
description: ROSEAU, Dominica, W.LThis West Indian island offers perhaps the best of Caribbean enchantments, if only in small quantities. It has several oneofakind excursions not even approx imated on any other island, and it is utterly lacking in the banal: There is not one casino, and not even a limbo show, and there are no Hong Kongmade straw bags lettered Souvenir of Dominica.

title: Miss Susan Wolins Plans Wedding
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 17The engagement of Miss Susan Wolins to Arthur Schaefer has been announced by her parents, Mr. andMrs. Lester Wolins. The future bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Sidney Schaefer of New York and the late Mr. Schaefer. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Why Is Ghe! On Trial?
description: THE current trial of Lennox Raphael's Che! for obscenity, sodomy and lewdness Is a disgrace to the theater. Books and movies have al ready been accused of some of these dreadful crimes but it is only now that the theater is considered worthy of them. It shows how sluggish our stage has become.

title: Anniversaries
description: JACOBSONIda and Leon. Haney 35th an niversary to the couple thaat would rather fight than switch.

title: New Mexico Skiers Eye Big Season
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M.  Unusually heavy early winter snows promise a longer season than ordinary for the ski slopes of Sandia Peak, the high est point in the Sandia Mountains. The mountains overlook Albuquerque, from where the longest aerial tramway on the continent whisks winter sports devotees and sightseers alike up the 10,695foot high peak in a matter of minutes.

title: Stage: Hedda Gabler, the Good Person
description: THE OPPOSITES COM PANY, described by it self as an acting company that believes the esthetic realism of Eli Siegel has something to say to the thea ter, has been operating on this fond possibility for some years off off Broadway. On Friday night, it brought its production of Hedda Gabler to an Off Broadway Theater, the Actors Playhouse.

title: KENTUCKY TRIMS TENNESSEE, 6852
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 17 (AP)Undefeated Kentucky got its fast break in gear early in the second half today and de feated Tennessee, 6852, in Southeastern Conference bas ketball game.

title: Television
description: THERE is one element of broadcasting that someday should stand up with the glamorous Emmy winners and receive its just reward for public serv ice. It is local radio, suburban and rural broadcasting, which in an emergency is the real voice to which a sen sible listener turns. Their very smallness  many such stations operate at night on only 250 watts and cannot be heard beyond their own town limits  forces them to concentrate on local con ditions and to deal with lo cales with which the listener

title: The Lambert Revels
description: What fun! You lucky lucky read ers. Here is a period piece, gay, sexy, comic and discriminating. Since these glimpses of a certain place at a certain moment are getting fewer, it is pure joy to come on one so sure in its handling and its ambience, even if the subject is as unlikely as this English colonials in County Wicklow in the early 1950's. Admittedly, the joy is minor, but collector's items usually are. Both the connoisseur of comedies of manners and the arm chair sociologist will recognize Ter ence de Vere White's novel as vin tage stuff.

title: One Book That Shook the Business World
description: Spring, 1965. Ralph Nader, young Washington lawyer, leaves his job at the Department of Labor to write a book on automobile safety design, under contract with Grossman Publishers, a small Manhattan house.... Nov. 30. Publication date of Unsafe at Any Speed, by Ralph Nader. Advance sale: 10,000 copies.... Dec. 1. Auto manufacturers dismiss thesis of Unsafe that they have sacrificed passenger safety to style and speed. . . . Feb., 1966. Nader appears before a Senate subcommittee on traffic safety to repeat accusation that American cars are unsafe in design. . . . March 5. Nader says that he is being harassed by private in vestigators inquiring into intimate details of his life and that on two occasions pretty girls made suspicious propositions to him.... March 8. Federal Government announces it will demand higher safety standards on the cars it buys for its own use.. .. March 9. General Motors admits that its law firm hired a private investigator to determine whether Ralph Nader was acting in behalf of litigants in suits arising out of accidents in which its Corvair was involved.... March 22. Before Senate subcom mittee investigating traffic safety, James T. Roche, president of G.M., publicly apologizes for the investigation of Ralph Nader. ... March 30. Sales of Unsafe running at 6,000 per week, 27,000 sold to date.... April 25. In an abrupt Uturn, auto industry announces it will support mandatory Federal safety standards of cars. . . . May 5. William B. Murphy, chairman of the Business Council, says, This country is on a safety kick. It is a fad, on the order of the Hula Hoop. We are going through cycle of overemphasis on safety.... May 29. President Roche an nounces sales of G.M.'s Corvair, criticized in Nader's book, were 70% off in May compared with the previous year.. .. June 24. Administration's Traffic Safety Bill passed in Senate by vote of 760.... Sept. 9. President Johnson signs the Traffic Safety Act of 1966 empowering the Federal Government to impose safety standards on 1968 model cars.

title: BERGHORN VICTOR IN BEAR MT. JUMP
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 17Chuck Berghorn, a 21 yearold Lake Placid star, made the longest jump of the season here today to win the 46th an nual Swedish Ski Club cham pionship.

title: Prague Describes a Trotskyite Plot
description: VIENNA, Jan. 17The Czechoslovak Government said today that a Trotskyite plot, reportedly uncovered earlier this week, had aimed at over throwing throwing the Communist sys tern not only in Czechoslovakia, but also in other socialist countries, in particular in the Soviet Union.

description: Jersey Joe Walcott, who won the heavyweight title at the age of 37, and Carmen Basilio, the former welterweight and middleweight champion, have been elected to the Boxing Hall of Fame, it was announced here yesterday by Nat Flei scher director of the hall.

title: What Can Business Do About Watts?
description: April, 1965, was a critical turning point in America. The burning, loot ing and violence of Watts drove a wedge through the heart of the na tion, dividing black from white and opening a wound for which we still seek sutures.

title: Headliners
description: Delicate Mission

title: KING MURAL PUT UP AT ROSELLE SCHOOL
description: ROSELLE, N. J., Jan. 17Thei Roselle Board of Education de cided last night to allow a con troversial mural of the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to be hung at Abraham Clark High School here.

title: Miami Is Becoming a Major WinterCruise Port
description: MIAMIThis resort's newest cruise liner has joined the growing fleet that is making Miami one the nation's most important pleasure ports. The spanking new Skyward, the third Norwegian Caribbean Lines ship to make Miami her home base, was greeted with the biggest hoopla in this city's recent maritime history when she came into the new Port of Miami earlier this month.

title: NARCOTICS MEETING IS SET FOR ANKARA
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 17 (AP)  Narcotics agents from the United States, France and Turkey will meet here Monday in an effort to shut off a large illegal drug supply line that originates in Turkey, Interior Ministry sources said this week.

title: Kansas City Diversifies Economy
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 17 Kansas City no longer has an economy that is dominat ed by agriculture but has become a diversified area that is based upon commer cial and industrial expansion.

title: Child to Mrs. P. S. Smith
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 17  A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Peter Sheridan Smith on Jan. 5 in Sinai Hos pital. Mrs. Smith, the former Miss Marjorie D. Kester, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Kester of East Norwich, L. I.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: ST. LUKE'S YIELDS ON DRUG FACILITY
description: I A fourday sitin in the office of the Community Psy chiatry Division at St. Luke's Hospital ended yesterday with an announcement that the hos pital would establish a 28bed center for the detoxification of adolescent drug addicts.

title: Vanity Press for Big Business
description: The publishing game has more wrinkles than a $30 suit, and a growing but little known development within the past few years shows promise of providing a potential escape hatch for publishers in their ceaseless struggle to escape the reaches Outer Remainderdom. This is the promotional or tiein book. A promotional book is a book used by a business to promote its product; its content, naturally, is calculated to enhance the de mand for the product with the readerconsumer, who may find it inside each and every pack, or be given it free at a retail out let, or buy it by means of a special coupon offer on the package.

title: Nancy C. Culbertson Engaged To Lieut. Sean Connor of Army
description: KENT, Conn., Jan. 17Mr. and Mrs. William Howard Culbertson of Kent and Ja maica, W.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Cos grave Culbertson, to Lieut. Sean Crombie Connor. U.S.A. He if the son of Col. John Powers Connor, U S.A., re tired, and Mrs. Connor of Fair Haven, N.J. A June wed ding is planned.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Thousands of retailers con vened last week in New York under the sponsorship of the National Retail Merchants As sociation for a discussion of their mutual problems. It was a time for soulsearching from which there will emerge many resolutions on the part of individual operators to make those changes that should improve their chances for increased profits and provide consumers with bet ter service and a wider choice of goods.

title: World Cup Soccer
description: No soccer follower expected it, but it has happened. Eng land, the World Cup holder, and Brazil, England's prede cessor, have been drawn in the same qualifying group next June, in Guadalajara where they'll meet on June 7.

title: $3.95 Monthly Phone Rate
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 17 (UPI) The Maryland Public Service Commission has a plan for telephone service for $3.95 a month. The Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company had proposed the service for families on fixed or low in comes, allowing them to receive unlimited calls but limiting out going calls to medical service) and emergencies. Maryland is the first state to adopt such a plan, a company official said.

title: Article 1  No Title
OPENINGS
description: WATERCOLOR and CRISS CROSSING  Wednesday, ANTA Theater, 245 West 52d Street, 7:30. Two one act plays, by Philip Mag dalany. Production of The Playwrights Unit.

title: When Business Sits for Its Portrait
description: Successful corporations, like successful men, sooner or later find them selves having their portraits painted. When they pay for the portrait (and they sometimes pay sums comprising six figures), they generally want to be painted prettyprettier, in fact, than they really are. If, on the other hand, the portraitist is financially independent of them, they tend to be wary, suspecting him of being a sardonic Hogarth or Daumier, and often refuse to sit for him at all. The result is that most of the information and opinion that the public gets in book form about corporationsthose so crucial institutions in all of our livesis either tainted or fragmentary.

title: Leslie Miller, Wellesley '66, To Be a Bride
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 17Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Quentin Miller have announ ced that their daughter, Miss Leslie deBenneville Miller, and George Wiltshire will be married on Feb. 14.

title: 2 JAILED IN MURDER SEEK A NEW TRIAL
description: Two men convicted of mur der in the death of a 59year old Queens woman are await ing what they hope will be dramatic turn in the case this week, when a convicted mur derer now serving a term of 25 years to life is brought into Queens Supreme Court.

title: FORMER DEAN, 80, REFLECTS ON TIME
description: Somewhere among the books and the filing cabinets in Carl William Ackerman's large West Side apartment, there is wheelchair. It has never been used.

title: Handel's People Are Sympathetic
description: SAMSON, Old Testament hero, and Theodora, Christian martyr, are the subjects of two oratorios produced by Hand el during his mature years. Aside from the great beauty of their music, the two works could not be more dif ferent, and they are a tribute to the composer's enormous expressive range. Excellent recordings of both were is sued last year. They deserve anyone's attention, prefer ably in tandem, since they set each other off so superbly.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Lieut. Col. Philip Effiong and other offi cers of the Biafran army returned yesterday to the dense forests and marshlands of the territory that was Biafra to help Nigerian Army patrols coax holdout Biafran soldiers from the bush. The officers were said to be carrying leaflets proclaiming a general amnesty for everybody in the territory. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: The Next Thirty Years
description: Few of our social institutions are more oriented to the future than business. It knows that adaption to change is the meas ure of survival in a competi tive world. The preoccupation of managers with the future has been redoubled by the furious pace of technological innova tion. Perhaps the one volume that has contributed most to business futurism is The Year 2000 by Herman Kahn and Anthony J. Wiener (Mac millan, $9.95). It presents in remarkable detail the anatomy of a predictable surprisefree future along with contingent alternative futures for which business seeks to prepare itself.

title: Entry of 2,611 Dogs Is Led by Poodles
CONGRESS FACING BATTLE OVER VETO ON EDUCATION AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The 91st Congress returns Monday for an election year session that, in a prelude to the poli ticking ahead, will begin with confrontation between the Ad ministration and Senate Demo crats over the issue of domestic spending.

title: Against Secret Research
description: The movement to get the universities out of research work for the militaryindustrial complex scored a victory last week. The Senate of Columbia Universitymade up of 78 faculty and administration officials and 23 students adopted regulations Friday preventing faculty members from taking part in secret research projects, directly or indirectly involving the university, for either government or private industry. Existing classified contracts, under the new regulations, will be modified or terminated within a year.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: PICTURE CREDITS

title: Grandfather a Pensioner
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17 (AP) The paternal grandparents of Mr. Brody live on a $200a month steelworker's pension, but they said today that they were not asking for any of the money their grandson said he was giving away.

title: Alioto Bows Out
description: For nearly two years, San Francisco's Mayor Joseph Alioto has been an allbutannounced candidate for the Democratic nomination to oppose Gov. Ronald Reagan in the November election. In recent months, however, the road to the California Governor's mansion has been ren dered slippery by an article In Look linking him to alleged Mafia figures (he filed a $12.5million suit against the magazine); by the disclosure that he had split $2.3million in legal fees while still a private lawyer with two public officials in Washington State; and by the announced guber natorial candidacy of powerful Democratic leader Jesse M. Unruh. If he ran for Governor, Mr. Alioto said last Mon day, he would simultaneously have to fight a hard pri mary campaign, conduct his suit against Look and still fulfill my obligations as Mayor. Since he could not do all three without jeopardizing each effort for the others, he decided to Just continue as Mayor.

title: Fine Line Drawn on Band
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Mrs. Leodina Wilke will have to return a $59.95 wedding hand to the man she almost married, but the law says she can keep the 950$ engagement ring he gave her Judge Thad deus J. Pruss ruled the wedding ring must go back to Clemen Boehm of Regina, Saskache wan but Mr. Wilke can keep the engagement ring because he was willing to pay for ?? because be liked her, the ludge said.

title: Pier 16 Haul for Win, Place, the Show
description: Anybody who races a Grand Banks dory on the East River these days must have something in mind other than sport, so the six men who will do it tomor row morning were suspected of seeking more than the 4 British gold sovereigns (about $54) that were at stake.

title: Heir Eludes Crowds Seeking to Share Promised Millions
description: Hundreds of people, most of them poor, began lining up in midtown before daybreak yes terday, waiting in vain for the arrival of Michael Jamos Brody Jr., the 21yearold who says he is a multimillionaire and who has promised to give away millions of dollars to those in need.

title: The Undiscovered Country
description: The question: Is Julian Mitchell's novel merely bright, or does it say something important? A bit of both, perhaps, but not enough of either to get very far into the new year. It comes with the highest recommenda tions from Britain, where the late Aldous Huxley and similar intellec tual saints have been invoked in its praise. It arrives in an America so saturated in angst and so high on sex that Mitchell's literary gifts may go unheralded for having been em ployed in the service of yesterday's neurosis. At the age of 35, he writes like a truly wise man: a man of about 65, but truly wise.

title: Why Can't Today's Actors Sing Out?
description: HAVE participants in the theaterrite on both sides of the curtain been irremediably ear washed by speaker systems? Have performers neglected their responsibility to pro ject? Have audiences become too passive to listen acutely?

title: Sammis's Team Advances In Platform Tennis Event
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 17Jesse Sammis 3d, the Na tional champion and No. seeded player, and Gordon Grey led the way into the semi finals today of the ninth annual men's platform tennis tourna ment, which drew 60 teams from five states, at the New Canaan Field Club with a 62, 64 victory over Dick Hornigold and Steve McGeenv.

title: Miss Mary L. Raftery Is Bride In Rumson of Dexter C. Koehl
description: RUMSON, N.J., Jan. 17 Miss Mary Louise Raftery and Dexter Clark Koehl were mar ried here this morning at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Frank Stroud performed the cere mony and celebrated the nuptial mass. He was assisted by Msgr. Joseph Sullivan.

title: New again
description: This could be the year the tank suit gives the bikini competition. The onepiece swimsuit be gan to get attention last summer at European beaches, and indications are that it is coming on strong at America's favorite resorts this winter. In either Mack Sennett stripes or off beat geometrics, the tank suit adds up to1970.

title: M. R. Carton 2d And Sybil Baker Married on L. I.
description: OYSTER, BAY, LI., Jan. 17Miss Sybil Kent Kane Baker, daughter of Mrs. Ross W. Baker, was married here this afternoon to Maurice Roger Carton 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Henri Car ton of Ville Laval. Quebec.

title: My My, Obtained After Tragedy, Died in Tragedy
description: MY MY, perhaps the great est fivegaited saddle horse of all time, showed practically no potential as 3yearold.

title: Dr. Peter's Little Wonder Book
description: One last (that's a promise!) small observation on the past decade: the leading best seller in the sixties' terminal year was a book prominently sub titled Why Things Always Go Wrong.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Chess
description: THE most heroic tournament tri umph of the past decade Grandmaster Bent Larsen's first place victory in the recent Ma jorca, Spain, International. The 18man round robin contains the strongest com petitors in Europe and South America. In the opening round, Denmark's ace mauled for a loss by the former prodigy, 17yearold Enrique Mecking of Brazil. In the second round, Larsen is cut down when world champion Boris Spassky, of the Soviet Union, outwits him in cliffhanger.

title: CHALLENGE RAISED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17Shortly after Senator Edward M. Ken nedy was involved in a fatal automobile accident last sum mer, the chairman of the Re publican State Committee said that the Massachusetts Demo crat has got to be seriously challenged, and it will he done.

title: OFFICE QUEEN, 21, FIRST AT HIALEAH
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17This has been a fortuitous week for John L. Rotz. Last Monday the jockey was lucky to escape with his life in a dreadful spill at Tropical Park.

title: A SILENT DESPAIR ENGULFS SAO TOME
description: SAO TOME, Jan. 17There is a deadly calm on this lush Portuguese island off equato rial Africa, which last week was the busiest communica tions center for the continent.

title: BALL CLUBS PICK 357 YOUNG STARS IN AMATEUR DRAFT
description: The major leagues drafted 357 college and high school players yesterday, a record number for baseball's midwin ter search for amateur talent.

title: GREEK CYPRIOTES WARNED ON STRIFE
description: ATHENS, Jan. 17Extrem ism and violence within the Greek community of Cyprus drew a denunciation today from the leaders of the Greek and the Greek Cypriote Gov ernments. In the past, both leaders have been viewed as stanch partisans of the Greek Cypriote community on the eth nically divided island.

title: JUDGE'S SON HELD IN NEW ACCIDENT
description: Gareth Martinis, the judge's son who won acquittal in 1963 on eharges of drunken driving and leaving an accident in which five persons were killed, was freed in $5,000 bail yester day on similar charges in a new accident that occurred at al most the same place.

title: One Way to Halt PoachingGator Farming
description: PALMDALE, Fla.  Cecil Clemons wants to raise alligators commer cially the way a farmer raises ??. As owner of Gatorama, a scenic 16acre alligator farm three miles cast of this central Florida town on U.S. 27, Mr. Clemons believes that, if he could operate a commercial farm on which gators were sold for their hides or for breeding, it would help stop alligator poaching, an act that is causing the creature's alarming depletion.

title: LargeMouth Bass a Big Florida Lure
description: LEESBURG, Fla.  Increasing numbers of motoring tourists tooling along busy Interstate 95 en route to Palm Beach, Miami and other Gold Coast points have been breaking out of the traffic pattern and heading into central Florida and its freshwater fishing grounds. In 1968, the last year for which figures are available, freshwater fishing licenses were issued to more than 175,000 out ofstate residents as inland fishing blossomed into a multimilliondollar business.

title: TALLEST BUILDING SET FOR CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17Standard Oil Company (Indiana) will con struct Chicago's tallest building to provide new headquarters for the company and its Chicagobased subsidiaries.

title: 60% Decline in Smallpox Since '67 Reported by WHO
description: GENEVA, Jan. 17Smallpox has receded by almost 60 per cent since the launching of a worldwide campaign against the disease three years ago, the World Health Organization said today.

title: To Iris Barry (18951969)
description: SHE was a brassy little girl in Bir mingham, England, who shocked her grandmother by spending every spare hour at the movies, when the movies were a thin cut above the poolroom. She shocked the rest of the family when, having spent the First World War in a succession of unlady like jobs (shipping telephone poles for the Post Office, ordering machine guns for the Ministry of Munitions), she made a profession of her vice and be came the first woman film critic in England.

title: Sarah Morgan Married Here
description: Miss Sarah Elizabeth Mor gan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Morgan of Little Silver, N. J., was mar ried here yesterday to John Robert Cushing in the Lady Chapel cf St. Patrick's Cathe dral. The Rev. Raymond Schroth of Fordham Univer sity officiated.

title: Recordings
description: THE usual summer home of the American Wind Symphony is a red barge anchored off the north side of a park in Pittsburgh located where the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers join to form the Ohio. When the weather is right, the symphony weighs anchor and sets out down the Ohio, serenading along the way.

title: Temperate Modest Shrewd Lucky Retiring Conservative Calculating
description: WASHINGTON. THERE is little doubt, after a year, that Richard Nixon is trying to fulfill his every prom ise. The question that remains is whether he can also perceive and fulfill the country's.

title: Gill Wins Snowmobile Title
description: McHENRY, Md., Jan. 17 (AP) Robert Gill of New Baltimore, N. Y., won the Class B stock, Skip Bernard of McHenry the Class C and William Frye of Manchester, Pa., the Class D in the Maryland snowmobile cham pionship races today.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Photographs by TIM KANTOR

title: First You Live It, Then You Film It
description: IT'S simple. You live it, then you film it. At least, that's the way it seems to go for Claude Berri. Thus far, the French film maker has shown us chunks of his boyhood in Occupied France (The Two of Us and his love life (Mary Me, Marry Me) and has just fin ished a film about his tour of duty in the French Army (Le Pistonne. He's also looking forward to making a movie about his father, whom he idolizes, and  who knows? He's only touched on a few of his 35 years. Next, we might be seeing Claude in school, or Claude's life in Paris with his real wife, Anne Marie. Or his son, Julien, who is only 1  but who might turn out to love acting and writing, like his father and grandfather.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayOx Ridge Hunt Club, Route 124, Darien, Conn. Green, junior, amateurowner and regular working hunters; ponies, equita tion. 9 A.M.

title: Stocks Off On Counter And Amex
description: Most quotations showed losses last week on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter mar ket in moderate trading.

title: Boom in Office Space Demand Slows a Bit
CASING DE PARIS GETS A NEW LIFE
description: PARIS, Jan. 17The Casino de Paris, long second to the FoliesBergre on most tourists scheduled Paris nightlife, is on the brink of a new career. Roland Petit has taken over its direction and on Jan. 23 will present a modern $600,000 dollar revue starring his wife, Zizi Jeanmaire.

title: Do You Believe In the Principle Of Museums?
description: THE exhibition called A Salute to Alexander Calder, which is cur rently installed at the Museum of Modern Art, is the latest in the museum's cur rent series of exhibitions drawn entirely from its own permanent collection. To ac company the show, the muse um has published a modest but excellent catalogue, which contains  in Bernice Rose's introductory text the best single essay on Cal der's work I have read any where. There is much to be said about Calder's sculpture. Indeed, though he is a popu lar artist as well as a great one, he has been unlucky in his critics, at least in this country. So far as the higher criticsm of contemporary sculpture is concerned, Cal der's oeuvre can hardly be said to exist  a circum stance that tells us far more about the higher criticism than it does about Calder. Let us hope that Bernice Rose's essay signals a change in the critical weather.

title: A Swinger Does His Thing in TakeOvers
description: Peter Huang  pronounced Wong  is the takeover specialist of the City Invest ing Company, with the title of vice president for corpo rate development. He also is a swinger.

title: JIM BOSTWICK WINS COURT TENNIS TITLE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 Jimmy Bostwick won the Unit ed States open court tennis championship for the second year and the sixth time in 10 years today by beating his brother Pete, the world open titleholder, 62, 62, 64, at the Racquet Club.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: LEVITT & SONS, which has built 90,000 houses in the last 35 years, will begin producing factorybuilt homes on a mechanized as sembly line beginning next fall.

title: Dance
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM is concerned with movement the way a composer is con cerned with sound, or a banker with money. To Cun ningham movement is com plete in itself  he has no desire to translate it into literature, to tell stories, draw pictures or paint characters. He is not above suggesting the occasional joke, but even these jokes are really about movement itself, rather than banana skins.

title: Agnew Relaxes in Hawaii After 11Nation Asian Trip
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 17  Vice President Agnew is spending a quiet weekend here after con cluding his 21day tour of 11 Asian nations.

title: Tudor Scott, Baird Up, Scores at Fair Grounds
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 (AP) Heavily favored Tudor Scott, topweighted at 123 pounds, hung on to win by half a length in the $15,000 Black Gold Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

title: Bruins Farm Out Doak
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The Boston Bruins sent Gary Doak, an ailing defenseman, to Okla homa City of the Central Hock ey League yesterday to play himself into shape. Doak has missed the Bruins' last six Na tional Hockey League games be cause of a thigh injury.

title: The Way to Go In Grindelwald Is By Velogemmel
description: GRINDELWALD, SwitzerlandFarmers from this tiny mountain village were perhaps the area's first winter sportsmen, although they would have been astonished if anyone had called them that. Long before snow fans began to visit some of the most famous peaks in the Alps in the closing years of the 19th century, the farmers were using sleds and sleighsoften out of necessity. And a halfcentury before modern vaca tionists discovered skibobs, farmers were skimming over snow on a local invention called a velogemmel.

title: $1Million for Bucknell
description: LEWISBURG, Pa. Jan 17  Bucknell University has an nounced receiving a gift of $1million from the Richard King Mellon Charitable Trust of Pittsburgh. The gift is the third largest in the university's history and will he used to strengthen Bucknell's instruc tional and administrative pro grams.

title: Governor of Virginia Asks Tolerance
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 17Racial tolerance and environmental upgrading were the major themes of A. Linwood Holton Jr. today as the Republican took office here as Virginia's Governor.

title: College Fund Needs Outstripping Business Gifts
description: American business gave an estimated $340million to higher education in 1968, but by 1976 these corporation gifts must reach $700million to keep pace with the ex pected needs of colleges and universities.

title: Iona Rally Wins, 8976
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 17John Carey scored 25 points and Joe Mazzella chipped, in with 23 as Iona rallied in they second half tonight to defeat Seton Hall, 8976, at Iona Prep.

description: Vision

title: Jewish Group Bids Court Rule for Pacifist Atheists
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The American Jewish Con gress asked the Supreme Court today to give atheistic pacifists the same right to he exempt from war duty as religious pacifists.

title: Apollo Shock Absorber Adapted for a Road Barrier
description: A new type of shockab sorbing system adapted from the Apollo spaceexploration program has been installed along Kansas state highways in and around Topeka to pro tect cars that run into high way barriers.

description: WILLIAMSTON, Mass. Jan 17 (UPI)Mrs. Edwin Clark of Willtamstown has embarked an a campaign to save the bears in ??

description: The report in II Tempo re ferred to an article in the Jan. 8 issue of The Long Island Catholic written by Robert R. Holton, staff correspondent in the Vatican.

title: London Paper Says Aides Ousted General Ojukwu
description: LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 18 (AP)The Sunday Times of London said today that Gen. Odumegwi Ojukwu the form er Biafran leader, was over thrown by military colleagues who had decided the civil war with Nigeria was lost. They forced General Ojukwu to leave the country.

title: Leeds Wins and Takes Division Lead in English Soccer
Caveat Emptor Alarms and Counsel
description: In a message to Congress last October, President Nixon declared: ConsumerismUpton Sinclair and Rachel Carson would be glad to know is a healthy development that is here to stay. Having crushed the last hope of those who assumed con sumerism is one of those issues which tend to flourish only when Democrats are in power, he advocated a program which seeks to provide improved con sumer representation in the govern ment policymaking process, tougher enforcement of consumer laws, and an improved flow of information to help consumers make rational buying decisions. Since then there has been a virtual stampede of Republicans and Democrats alike to identify with the parcel of consumer bills which are likely to pass in 1970.

title: Alta Grooms Trails To Flatten Fears Of Deep Powder
description: ALTA, Utah  Easterners will find Western skiing considerably easi er this season if they trek to the deepsnow country of the Western Rockies. A majority of the new lifts added at older resorts or installed at new areas are rated beginner or intermediate.

title: MarcianoClay: The Computer Knows
description: Not even Cassius Clay knows the outcome of his computerized Super Fight with Rocky Marciano, the producer of the film insisted yesterday.

title: JOANNE DARAKJY WINS SKATE TITLE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17  Joanne Darakjy, a darkhaired beauty costumed in white, came through with a magnificent free skating performance to win the Eastern senior ladies' figure skating championship before a standingroomonly crowd of 1,100 at the Wissahickon Skat ing Club tonight.

title: A Woolgathering Vacation on an Australian Sheep Ranch
description: COWRA, New South Wales, AustraliaFor those who do not con sider a trip to Australia as getting far away from it all, there is now a way to go even farther afield: Visit an outoftheway sheep station here in New South Wales.

title: Episcopalians Install Negro Diocese Head
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17  The Right Rev. John Melville Bur gess was installed today as the 12th Bishop of the Epis copal Diocese of Massa chusetts.

title: $35,000 Benvenuti Income Far Below Fight Figures
description: TRIESTE, Italy, Jan. 17 (UPI) Italian tax authorities said today that Nino Benyenuti,_the world middleweight champion, earned $35,000 last year, less money than boxing promoters said they paid him for one of his two fights in Italy in 1969.

title: Miss Dianne Phillips Wed in Ohio
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 17 Miss Dianne Alexander Phillips was married here this afternoon to John Jeffrey AV Ion, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Avlon of New York. The cere mony was performed by the Very Rev. Isaiah Chronopou los in St. John's Greek Ortho dox Church.

title: O'SHEA SPOILS BID
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 17Last Thursday in Philadel phia; Ed Giacomin got a night off in the New York Ranger goal. Tonight, in the Metropoli tan Sports Center, Giacomin gave the Minnesota North Stars an almost complete evening of frustration in leading his team mates to a 31 National Hockey League victory.

title: As Tastes Change, So Does Broker's Pitch
description: REAL, estate brokers, keenly aware of the ever changing desires of the homebuying public, are adjusting their sales approach to entice prospective purchasers.

title: ROLLICKING WINS SPRINT AT BOWIE
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 17 (AP) Covering seven furlongs In 1:23 4/5, the J. I. B. Farms, Rollicking won the $22,000 added Palmer Heagerty Stakes at Bowie today by threequar ters of a length.

title: Great Mosque Planned in New Pakistani Capital
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Pakistan plans to build a national mosque that will be in keeping with the modern grand scale of her new capital here. It has been planned to rank with Islam's most splendid places of wor ship.

title: High School Runners Are Plagued by Bad Passes of the Baton at the St. Francis Games
Would They Throw Bras At Arnold?
description: ISSUR DANIELOVITCH changed his name to Kirk Douglas because some body thought it sounded more glamor ous. Tula Finklea became Cyd Charisse. Spangler Arlington Brugh became Robert Taylor. Alexandra Zuck became Sandra Dee. Frances Gumm became Judy Garland. Marion Morrison became John Wayne. Shirley Schrift became Shelley Winters. Betty Perske became Lauren Bacall. Lucille Le Sueur became Joan Crawford. Archibald Leach became Cary Grant. Margarita Can sino became Rita Hayworth. Edythe Mar rener became Susan Hayward. Arnold George Dorsey became Engelbert Hum perdinck.

title: Between the Bullet And the Lie
description: The Spanish Civil War of 1936 1939 remains amazingly alive with controversy. Sometimes the dispute affects individuals: Was Joe Dallet shot in the back; was Dave Doran a murderer; was Oliver Law a coward? These questions can be asked of in dividuals within the group of inter national volunteers of any country, not just the volunteers of the Ameri can Abraham Lincoln battallion. Sometimes the quarrels affect great issues and their historians: Was the Republican cause damaged more by Communist arrogance and insensitiv ity or by anarchist indiscipline, utopi anism and terror? Thus Noam Chom sky, in his recent denunciation of North American imperialism, American Power and the New Man darins, devotes about 60 pages (out of, in the English Penguin edition, 320) to what he conceives to be bi ased and antianarchist historical in terpretation on the part of Gabriel Jackson of Princeton and myself: Jackson, Mr. Chomsky tells us in his selfrighteous way, makes little attempt to disguise his antipathy to wards the forces of popular revolu tion in Spain or their goals, with out however realizing that he him self has been suborned into accepting the fallacy that the forces of popu lar revolution were uniquely an archosyndicalist.

title: They Wined and Missed the Moon
description: MIENS, France  In this age of lunar exploration, when moon dust, capsules, modules and gigantic rockets are becoming almost commonplace, it not surprising that Jules Verne's house here Amiens is becoming a popular place to visit. After all, Verne almost drew the Apollo 8 flight plan in 1865.

title: Islanders Flee Volcano
description: RABAUL, New Britain. Jan. 17 (Reuters)Villagers living on the fringe of the Mount Lluwan volcano on this South Pacific island fled when it erupted again today. The 7,500 footpeak spewed lava, smoke ond ash in its second big erup tion in 12 hours.

title: Better Early Than Late
description: IF THIS is not exactly a vintage year for election to baseball's Hall of Fame, there is at least one candidate with all then sparkle and appeal of the finest cham pagne. As the lodge brothers in the Base ball Writers' Association study their bal lots, one name on the list should command attention and inclusion. It belongs to Early (Gus) Wynn, one of the toughest pitchers ever to scare a batter into nervous qui escence.

title: Coins
description: A SPECIAL coin, with the denomination of 5 Bal boas, will be issued by the Republic of Panama to commemorate the 1970 Central American Caribbean Games to be held in Panama City from Feb. 23 through March 15.

title: New Hampshire Wars on Thefts of Ski Gear
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H. Well aware of the yearly increase in the theft of skis and ski poles, the New Hampshire Ski Area Op erators Association has embarked on a pio neering plan of skiequipment registration.

title: DR. PALUEL FLAGG, ANESTHESIOLOGIST
description: YONKERS, Jan. 17Dr. Paluel Joseph Flagg, a former presi dent of the New York Society of Anesthesiologists, died today in St. John's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 87 Alta Avenue.

title: Skiing Activity At a New High In Woodstock, Vt.
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt.This beautiful central Vermont village, with its colonial charm and neat busi ness section, is again throbbing with skiing activity. A giant twoday storm that brought several feet of snow late last month has caused sports enthusiasts to set their sights again on Mount Tom and Suicide Six; both of these modestsized ski centers are only a fiveminute drive from Woodstock's picturesque village square.

title: Innovations on 747 Expected to. Calm the SafetyMinded
description: When the Boeing 747 takes off on its scheduled inaugu ral commercial flight Wed nesday night from Kennedy International Airport, it will carry aloft innovations in air safety that experts are predicting will calm many safetyminded critics.

title: Who Makes Singers Great?
description: BECAUSE our under standing of mass art is conditioned by the methods and terminol ogy of the movies, record producer is an unfortunate title. Record director would be better, for just as films are identified with their di rectors, so the theoretical re sponsibility for an LPwith all the sophistication of form content and technique that has come to imply over the past few yearsfalls to its producer. The artistic success of three recent releases from Warner Brothers  Norman Greenbaum's Spirit in the Sky (Reprise 6365) Lorraine Ellison's Stay With Me (War ner Brothers 1821) and Ella Fitzgerald's Ella (Reprise 6354)is due primarily to sensitive direction from three producers, each of whom de serves more credit than small type on the back of the jack et. Respectively, they are Erik Jacobsen, Jerry Ragovoy and Richard Perry.

title: Job Changes:
description: Thomas W. Russell Jr., has been elected chairman of the board and chief executive of ficer of the Abex Corpora tion. He will succeed Wil liam T. Kelly Jr., who has retired but remains a direc tor of the corporation.

title: Gen. Davis, Negro, Named Cleveland Safety Director
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 17Lieut. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr. of the Air Force, the highest ranking Negro in the United States armed forces, was named by Mayor Carl B. Stokes today to become the next public safety director of Cleveland.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: TRAINING your own bird dog is almost as demanding an enterprise as marriage, but every year hundreds of innocent sportsmen enter into this dogman relationship with scarcely a second thought.

title: LEGAL ACTION VOWED IN M.I.T. OCCUPATION
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 (AMSwift legal action was promised today against 55 youths who ended a 34hour occupation of administration of fices at Massachusetts Institute of Technology last night, leav ing behind What a spokesman called a shambles.

title: Rehabilitation in Africa
description: A significant event in the expansion of rehabilitation services for the physically handicapped in Africa will take place tomorrow in Kampala, Uganda, with the beginning of the first international training course for the manufacture and fitting of artificial limbs and braces to be held in Africa.

title: A Scenario For the Fireworks At Tet
description: SAIGON  Will the enemy launch an offensive during the Tet Lunar New Year holidays next month?

title: Javits Favors Iranian Role
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 17 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Re publican of New York, said at a news conference here today that he planned to propose a regional cooperation company for development projects in countries from Morocco to India under Iranian leadership.

title: Dayton Closes Gym Doors After Fights at Games
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 17 When an official blew his whistle to start a high school basketball game here last week, the only spectators were sub stitute players, a few members of the press and a handful of ceredited individuals.

title: Last Hurrah for Marshal and His Horse
description: George Gayer, who has been the marshal at Roosevelt Raceway for most of his 23 years at the track, has a sad duty to perform Tuesday. He will ride his 25 yearold white gelding, Sonny, to the post for the final time.

title: Art
description: THOMAS EAKINS, the greatest American painter (and let's have no nonsense to the contrary: he was and is), is also attracting attention these days as a photographer. His wellknown serial action photo graphs have perhaps been given exag gerated importance for some time, but his portraits and landscapes, less well known, are only now coming into their own.

title: Stolen Signs Bring Fines
description: RADFORD, Va., Jan. 17 (UPI) Five Virginia Tech University students have horn fined $10 plus $12.25 in costs for stealing traffic signs to give to their girl friends. The signs, stolen from residential neighborhoods said Watch For Children.

title: Miss Lois Von Gehr, Teacher, Is Engaged to Lowell Livezey
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17Miss Lois Von Gehr and Lowell Welden Livezey, candidates for doctoral degrees at the University of Chicago, plan to he married next summer.

title: Moira Carney Fiancee
description: IRVINGTON, N. Y., Jan. 17Miss Moira Gae Careny, a sophomore at Ohio North ern University, and William Ernest Riddleberger, a senior at Ohio Northern, have be come engaged. The future bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward M. Carney of Irvington and Madison, Conn., who have announced her engagement, and a niece of Art Carney, the actor. Her father is a dentist. Mr. Riddleberger's father is owner and operator of the Lewis town Ice and Storage Com pany.

title: Marsha Dubrow Bride of Daniel Chaykin
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 17  Miss Marsha Ann Du brow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Dubrow of South Orange, was married here this evening to Daniel Leon Chaykin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Chaykin of Brooklyn. Rabbi Theodore Friedman performed the ceremony at the Alpine.

title: Going to Sea on the Mazatlan Ferry
description: MAZATLAN, Mexico This bustling city at the southern end of the trumpetshaped state of Sinaloa, on Mexico's west coast, is famous for its magnificent sunsets. And few cities have a more spectacular approach from the air. The plane de scends against a background of cocoacolored mountains, and the blue Pacific shows its white teeth as it sprays against sandy beaches lined with many firstclass hotels resplendent in gay pinks, greens and blues.

title: Baseball Chiefs Attack Flood Suit; Illegal English Soccer Clause Survives
description: Curt Flood, whose Federal suit against baseball's reserve clause was filed Friday, was attacked yesterday by the presidents of the two major leagues for having failed to honor his contract.

title: Nixon Mapping Program Calling for Incentives
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 President Nixon's program for improving the quality of the environment will emphasize in centives to private industry rather than large new outlays of Federal funds, according to informed sources here.

title: Jazz: Some Old Favorites Are Back
description: SINCE the seasonal bills are already upon us or well on their way, this might be a good time for the jazz record buyer to turn to the cutprice reissue labels.

title: Bettina Schaefer Becomes Bride
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 17 Miss Bettina Kelly Schaefer, daughter of Mrs. David Kro ger Homan and Edward Ar thur Schaefer Jr., was mar ried here this evening to An drew Marshall Jamison 3d. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jamison Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, and Sewells Point, Fla.

title: Article 5  No Title
Miss Bartkowicz Beaten
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 17 (AP)Mrs. Ann Jones of Britain overwhelmed Peaches Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., 61, 62, in the final of the Western Province tennis tournament today.

title: FINAL CURTAIN
description: PROMENADE, the musical by Al Carmines and Maria Irene Fornes, closes to night at the Promenade after 258 performances.

title: New York
description: William J. Ronan was never the most popular man in New York, but no one ever thought that he would need eight body guards.

title: Business Index Rose for Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Ac tivity rose last week to 337.4, from 333.0 a week earlier. A year ago, it was 347.0.

title: 4 Killed in Collision Of Two Light Planes In Hartford Area
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 17  Four men were killed today when two private planes collided in the air near Brainard Field, a small private airport on the outskirts of Hartford.

title: House Of Gold
description: Novelists are rarely snobs; any life can be a matter of particular con cern. Thus fictions affirm, among other things, possibility. But they are just as apt to search for it in the ordinary as elsewhere. The dust that settles over a household during one day in a given lifetime can suffice as atmosphere for the truly percep tive writerwhereas even the flares of a Gehenna would fail to illuminate the imagination of the runofthemill faker.

title: Price Hunt For Liquor Rewarding
description: Liquor prices are one of the few items that apparently carry lower price tags today than they did two years or more ago.

title: Brazilian Torture Charged In Underground's Leaflets
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 17 (AP)The underground group that said it kidnapped Ambas sador C. Burke Elbrick of the United States last September, mailed out leaflets today call ing on Brazilians to protest what it termed the torture of political prisoners.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Credit for Nixon

title: MILLER'S 61 SETS MARK AT PHOENIX
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 17 Gene Littler, shooting a 67, moved into a onestroke lead today after three rounds of the 72hole, $100,000 Phoenix open but John Miller, a young pro, stole a share of the show by shooting a courserecord 10 underpar 61.

title: Gabriel and Berry to Pass for West in 20th Annual Pro Bowl Game Today
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (AP) The 20th annual Pro Bowl game a prestigious affair for the players if not a palpitating public, goes on tomorrow with the giants of the National Foot ball League on display.

title: Tropical Fish and Fowl Enhance Hialeah's Appeal
description: MIAMI BEACH  People used to say that the winter season here began when the horses started running at nearby Hialeah Race Course. That old saying hasn't rung true in years, for the season begins considerably earlier now.

title: K. of C. Meet Is Slated For Feb. 6 in Garden
description: The 51st annual Knights of Columbus track meet will be held Friday night, Feb. 6, in Madison Square Garden.

title: Man Held as Snow Thrower
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 17 (AP) A man who identified himself as a schoolteacher was arrested today and accused of throwing snowballs at a passing fire, truck. Leonard Rusin, 22 years, old, of North Tonawanda was charged with violating a city ordinance banning the throw ing of missiles. He was re leased on $25 bond to await a hearing in Tonawanda City Court Monday.

title: Using the Community To Help Children Learn
description: While critics castigate the slow pace with which urban public school systems respond to de mands for change, small islands of experimentation have been created by educational pioneers in scattered parts of the country.

title: Finnish Trade Group in China
description: PEKING, Jan. 17 (Agence France  Presse)  12member Finnish Government delegation arrived here today to negotiate renewal of the annual Sino Finnish trade agreement.

title: KEOGH IS VICTOR IN TWOMILE RACE
description: The 14th annual St. Francis Prep Games, a 10hour school boy track affair, got off on the wrong foot yesterday, but end ed with some outstanding per formances.

title: Bay State Hunger Inquiry
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)Dr. Jean Mayer, the Harvard nutri tionist who organized the White House conference on hunger last December, will tes tify Wednesday at a hearing of a Massachusetts commission in vestigating hunger.

title: Cogan, Berlind, Long Unstructured, Gets Boss
description: Roger S. Berlind is a 39 yearold frustrated song writer who is doing much better on Wall Street than he might have done on Tin Pan Alley.

title: To the Rich Who Ski by Day and Party at Night, Sun Valley's Neat Again
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho Have you been poured yet? That is the question here. It doesn't mean having a drink or even a leisurely half hour or so in the sauna. It means new Peter Kennedy ski boots, in which the linings are poured into the shell and molded to the foot. They're comfy and expensive ($70 a foot), and if you're with it this year, you've been poured or are going to be.

title: Bowdoin Six Tops Williams
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 17 Bowdoin College remained un defeated on home ice today by beating Williams College, 42. in hockey. Two secondperiod goals by Erland Hardy paced the Polar Bear attack.

title: Federal Expert Says Bureaucratic Conflicts in Cabinet Agencies Are Depriving Indians of Water Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17An Interior Department expert on Indian water resources has ac cused his department and the Justice Department of depriving Indians of the water rights the departments are pledged to pro tect.

title: NIXON ENDS RETREAT AFTER 3 DAYS' WORK
description: WASHINGTON, Tan. 17 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House today after], three days of solitary work at his Camp David, Md., mountain retreat.

title: Marguerite Scott Funston Is Married
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 17Miss Marguerite Scott Funston and John Milton Per kins Thatcher 3d, who were classmates at the Greenwich Country Day School, were married here this afternoon at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Home Improvement
description: WALLmounted shelv ing systems, which have become in creasingly popular in recent years, are now more versatile than ever. In addition to providing the homeowner with a factory finished wall shelving sys tem that enables him to in stall shelves on any wall, and in almost any conceivable ar rangement, homeowners can now also purchase wall mounted furniture units that can be hung from the same wall standards  with or without the matching pre finished shelves that are part of the system.

title: Education
description: In the current issue of the student newspaper in one of the city's leading high schools, the principal summed up the 1960's by saying that so little has changed. He regretted that more students fail to subscribe to the school's motto that noth ing can be accomplished with out hard work. He noted an alarming increase in drug addic tion. But in the main, he was cheered by the unchanged de votion of the faculty, athletic triumphs and the winning of more than our proportionate share of... scholarships.

title: Hong Kong Flu Is Affecting Millions in Wide Areas Around World
description: Throughout Europe and other widely scattered areas, epidemic Hong Kong influenza is sending millions of aching people to bed with fever and respiratory symptoms and causing thou sands of deaths.

title: Competition Dip Forces Remodeling of Stock Industry
description: The changes occur quietly, with no fanfare. Ticker ma chines stop clattering, win dows are shuttered, accounts are transferred, desks become vacant, salesmen start pound ing the streets.

title: Two Issues From U.N. March 13
description: THE first 1970 stamps from the United Nations will be issued March 13. Both stamps were designed by Ole Hamann.

title: Mitterer Is Upset Victor In Cup Downhill Skiing
description: VILLARS, Switzerland, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Paul Mitterer of Austria scored a surprise vic tory in the World Cup downhill skiing today, beating the fav ored Frenchmen in an event marked by rapidly changing weather.

title: The Metropolitan Museum of Art / Lectures
description: After Impressionism

title: Medicine
description: At last it looks as though scientists are accumulating sufficient data to begin pro grams to prevent alcoholism, a disease that has trapped, by conservative estimate, four million Americans. They are beginning to tease out the causes of alcohol addiction and, perhaps, of other drug addiction as well.

title: Three More Explosions
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Three bombs ex ploded outside British property near Nicosia tonight. There were no casualties or damage.

title: After Zonked, Zapped
description: GRIMSHAW, the Off Broadway producer, was sitting with his tax lawyer over marijuana and coffee at Downstairs at the Uptight, the Sardi's of St. Marks Place. Grimshaw, producer of Zonked, lis tened intently as the lawyer detailed the profit figures of the smash musical.  . . . and counting road companies, movie rights and cast album, your share so far comes to over $287,000, the lawyer wound up.

title: Miss Deppe Future Bride
description: BRIARCLIFF, N.Y., Jan. 17 Miss Marlaina Deppe and F. Michael Donahue Jr., stu dents at New York Univer sity, plan to be married in September.

title: Churchmen's Group Bids South Africans Reject Apartheid
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 17  A group of leading churchmen and other prominent South Africans is ap pealing to voters in the general election in April with the mes sage Vote Christian  reject apartheid!

title: Bourdase Defeats Petraglia, Wins Los Angeles Bowling
description: ARCADIA,. Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) Ed Bourdase of Fresno, Calif., rolled a 201 in the final round today and won the $50,000 Greater Los Angeles open bowl ing tournament. The 41year old bowler scored his first vic tory since joining the pro tour in 1961.

title: Youth Held in Bus Theft
description: Reginald Adams, 17 years old, of 334 West 84th Street, was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing a large crosscountry bus, an Adiron dacks Trailways vehicle, from, a Port Authority parking lot at 40th Street and Eighth Ave nue. Asked why he took the, vehicle, the police said, he re plied, I just like to drive buses.

title: Miss Jane Hamlin to Be a Bride
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Conde Hamlin have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Jane Hamlin, to Richard James Schulten, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Spencer Schul ten of Darien and New Mil ford.

title: Suspension of a Kentucky Rights Lawyer Sought
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 17 A trial committee of the Ken tucky Bar Association has rec ommended a oneyear suspen sion for Daniel T. Taylor, a civil rights and criminal lawyer who was accused of showing con tempt for a Louisville judge.

title: BIG TEN ON BROADWAY
description: OFF BROADWAY

title: C. W. TUDOR IS DEAD; EXART CHIEF AT LIFE
description: Charles William Tudor, a for mer art director of Life maga zine, died Friday in Doctors Hospital, He was 66 years old and lived at 518 East 89th Street.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The second act of the twilight drama of that undramatic Boston politician, John W. McCormack, the 78 yearold Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, began unfolding last week.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Smoot, Edward Curtis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Mrs. Francis LeBaron Smoot Jr. has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss MarieAdle Constance Denise Smoot, to Edward Peregrine Sacheverell Curtis of London.

title: Digging Under Ground
description: BECAUSE of the great number of commercial film openings here in the two weeks before Christmas, I was unable to attend the 71th New York Film Festival, arranged by the Filmmakers' Cinema theque and held at the Elgin Theater, Dec. 1624. The fes tival, designed to survey some of the most recent achievements in underground film, sounded most high spirited from its initial press releases, which included a piece of mail promotion par odying the newspaper ads for the 7th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center.
