Andy Warhol's newest six or eighthour epic (nobody seems to be quite sure of how long it really runs), Imitation of Christ, was described as having won the Hollis Al pert Award for Achievement in Cinema (that's how a film should be made)? and the Pauline Kael and Judith Crist Award for seriousness and depth of Content and Form and Relevance to Contempo Life.

title: Lehigh Boy Records a 2:01 25 Mile in Early Bird Pace
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 17 I wanted to wait, but I didn't want to wait too long. I wanted to rest, but I didn't want to, rest too long. I wanted to go, but I didn't want to go too soon.

title: CADETS' DEDMOND TIES DASH MARK
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 17. Manhattan dominated the distancerunning events, but gave away too much in the field events today as the Army trackmcn registered a 5851 victory. The cadets won seven of the 13 events while scoring 37 of a possible 45 points in the five field events.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: DEAD GREEN BERET AIDS THE' NEEDIEST
description: When Ricky was 9 years old, he sought to escape the con stant quarrels at home between his schizophrenic mother and his unstable father.

title: Seals Snap Canadiens' Streak With a 30 Victory, as Smith Excels at Goal
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 17 (UPI) The Oakland Seals, led by the brilliant goaltending of Gary Smith, ended the Montreal Ca nadiens' fivegame winning streak tonight with a 30 vic tory.

title: Tokyo Stays Bullish Despite Weak Market
description: Although the Tokyo stock market has taken a tumble from its record highs, Japa nese investment specialists continue to display a bullish attitude.

title: MRS, THOMAS FLETCHER
description: Mrs. Eudora Plummer Fletch er who retired in 1956 as principal of Public School 99 Avenue K and East Ninth Street, Brooklyn, died Friday in Largo, Fla. She was 79 years old and was the widow of Thomas Fletcher, a structural engineer.

title: Guam Newspaper Sold
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 17 (AP) An agreement in principle has been reached for the sale of The Guam Dailly News to a group of purchasers headed by The Honolulu StarBulletin. The announcement was made Wednesday in a joint statement by Joseph Flores, president of Pacific Press Inc., owner of the Guam Newspaper, and A. S. Atherton, president of The Honolulu StarBulletin. The sale price was not disclosed.

title: JUDGE REOPENS TRIAL FOR 4 IN DRUG CASE
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Jan. 17 (AP)Reports that four de fendants in a narcotics case drew straws to determine who would plead guilty has prompt ed a City Court judge to reopen the case.

title: Amended Timetable For New School Plan
description: Following is the city's school decentralization time table as amended Tuesday by the State Legislature:

title: Calvin Murphy Marries
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 17Calvin Murphy, the Niagara basketball allAmerican tonight married Vernetta Sykes, a freshman at the school, at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church here.

title: Lebanon Says Mrs. Meir Is Threatening Aggression
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17  The Lebanese Government ac cused Israel today of planning aggression against Lebanon fol lowing strong statements by the Israeli Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, regarding a kidnapped Israeli watchman.

title: 2 Soviet Skaters Set Marks
description: ALMA ATA, U.S.S.R., Jan. 17 (AP)  Two women's world rec ords in speed skating were broken here today in the open ing of the Soviet Union's women championships. Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said Tatyana, Sidorova had eclipsed the world stand ard for 50 meters with a time of 43.22 seconds. Later Nina Statkevich was credited with a recordbreaking time of 2:17.82 for 1,500 meters.

title: Economy Now Suffering Worst of Both Worlds
description: WASHINGTON All year long the Nixon Administration and the Federal Reserve Board have been trying to slow the American economy, with the aim of eventually curbing the dangerous rise in prices. By the fourth quarter, the policy had succeeded: Growth came to complete halt, it was disclosed last week.

title: Hey, 007, There Goes Peter Hunt
description: HAVING finally made it as the director of On Her Majesty's Secret Service after eight years of serving as assistant director on five previous James Bond adven tures, Peter Hunt is now pre pared to break away from that happy associationat least for a time. The 41year old Londoner is set to direct a musical that will star Maurice Chevalier and Mi reille Mathieu, the 22yearold Parisian singer. Tentatively titled Big World and to he filmed in Franco and Eng land, the film tells the story of 11 youngsters who are adopted by a lonely old couple and then are orphaned again when their new parents

title: A Gamble That Might Just Pay Off
description: IAM sick of driving about the country and seeing the increasing number of magnificent college theaters so few of them at the disposal of, or allied with, playwrights in any but the most fleeting way. On the premise that no real playwright can resist fill ing up an empty stage, I suggest the following to the country's colleges: Invite a playwright to serve in resi dence for three, six or 10 months, and offer him $25,000 so that even the most burdened can accept. Ground

title: I.R.S. Is Now Tapping Plastic Credit
description: A mediumsized Ohio bank widely known for its innovations, the City Na tional Bank and Trust Company of Co lumbus, introduced last week what may be the ultimate in credit card services.

title: Jewish Center in Queens Salutes Mets, Jets Today
description: The Men's Club of the Jewish Center of Jackson Heights will honor Queens' two champion ship teams, the New York Mets and the New York Jets, at their Salute to the Champions luncheon today at 1 P.M., at the Center, 3425 82nd Street, Jackson Heights.

title: Niarhos to Pilot Farm
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 17 (AP) Gus Niarhosi 49 years old, former major league, catcher, was named manager today of the Jacksonville Suns of the Class AA Southern League. The Suns are operated jointly by the Montreal Expos of the Na tional League and the Seattle Pilots of the American League.

title: Keino, Davenport Suffer Upsets In Mile, Hurdles at Coast Meet
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (UPI) A pair of Olympic champions, Kipchoge Keino and Willie Davenport, were beaten in their favorite events tonight at the Sunkist Invitation indoor track meet.

title: CAHILL'S OFFICES SOUGHT BY MANY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  The telephones have been ring ing steadily in recent days at the office of Representative William T. Cahill with calls from,. aides of other House members asking when his of fice will he closing here.

title: Myra G. Aichholz To Wed Saturday
description: TERRACE PARK, Ohio, Jan. 17Miss Myra Gertrude Aichholz, an assistant buyer with Lord & Taylor in New York, and Thomas Perry Rhoades 3d, who is with the New York public relations office of the Ford Motor Company, plan to be married in St. Thomas Episcopal Church here next Saturday.

title: L. B. Stauffer Weds Priscilla Ferguson
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 17Miss Priscilla Ferguson was married here this after noon to Lawrence B. Stauf fer. The Rev. Alfred W. Wishart Jr. performed the ceremony at the Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Chuch.

title: Travel and Photography
description: THE Terra Magics scries of travel hooks, under the general editorship of Hanns Reich, are among the most handsomely reproduced in this lied. All adhere to the same for mat of a short introduction to a volume consisting mostly of photographs, selected by Mr. Reich from the work of varitios photographers. This provides a crosssection of impressions and ohservations of the country treated.

title: Article 6  No Title
City Aides Reportedly Selected To Direct Neighborhood Plan
description: The man who coordinated volunteers in Mayor Lindsay's reelection campaign is ex pected to be the central figure in the Mayor's plan for a net work of neighborhoodlevel governments.

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS FOUND UNCERTAIN ON DRAFT LOTTERY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The new lottery system, which was intended to give young men better idea of whether they would be drafted has, for the time being, resulted in confu sion and doubt among college students and their advisers.

title: Colgate Victor in Track
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 17 Colgate won the mile and two mile relay events today to edge Dartmouth, 5752, in a track meet in Leverone Field House, A Dartmouth record was set in the weight throw by a senior, Dewitt. Davies, with a heave of 59 feet 9 inches. A sopho more, Ted Moody, set a Dart mouth record in the shotput with 536.

title: Miss Lorna Boyajian Is Fiancee
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17Mr. and Mrs. John H. Boyajian have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Lorna Louise Boyajian, to David Goodrich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick N. Good rich of Montclair and Marl boro, Me. A July wedding is planned.

title: Skiing Is on the Upswing In the Northern Midwest
description: BOYNE FALLS, Mich.  A ski minded visitor might find it difficult to believe, after noting that al most half of Michigan's 72 ski areas are equipped with snowmaking ma chines, that an average of 140 inches of snow is dumped on some sections of this state every winter.

title: Jewish Former Envoy in Exile Maintains He Is Still a Pole
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 17Julius KatzSuchy, a former Polish representative at the United Nations, who has been granted political asylum in Denmark, says, I'm still a Pole, and Poland will always be my country.

title: Cathie Marie Call Planning Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Call of Fresh Meadows, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cathy Marie Call, to Lieut. (jg.) John Walter Newcomb, U.S.N. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Newcomb of Bay side, Queens.

title: L. R. Witlen Fiance Of Patricia Landman
description: WANTAGH, L. I., Jan. 17 The engagement of Miss Patricia Ann Landman to Larry R. Witlen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Witlen of Valley Stream, has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Her man Landman.

title: Lake Placid's Skijoring, Ski Touring In Comeback
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y.Winter sport has come full circle in this busy Adirondack Mountain resort coun try. Ski touring, popular earlier in the century, has made a comeback; ski joring, behind snowmobiles now instead of horses, is once again part of the local scene, and the newest uphill transporta tion system for downhill skiers is a rope towimported from Switzerland.

title: The Saving of the Everglades
description: President Nixon rightly calls abandonment of the projected jetport near the Everglades National Park an outstanding victory for conservation. It is, in fact, a victory that goes beyond even the saving of that priceless natural haven. It is a hopeful indication of what can be done to save the remains of a magnifi cent national heritage when groups of private citizens are wise enough and determined enough to work together to that end.

title: Taiwan Is Big Isssue In U.S. Talks With Peking
description: WASHINGTON  American backing of the Chinese Nation alist Government on Taiwan has always been a major road block in the way of any im provement in relations between Washington and Peking. This Tuesday in the Chinese Embas sy in Warsaw, Walter J. Stroessel Jr., the American Am bassador, and Lei Yang, the Charge d'Affaires of the Peo ple's Republic of China, will re sume the conversations the two countries broke off two years ago. One signal as to what, if any, progress can be expected may lie in the attitude each side takes toward Taiwan.

title: Vatican Giving Priority to Studies of Sex Education for the Catholic Schools
description: ROME. Jan. 17The Vatican said today that it was giving a certain priority to preliminary studies of sex education courses in Catholic schools.

title: The Retirement Village: A New Life Style
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 A whole new style of life is opening up for elderly Americans freed from the daily responsibility of earn ing a living.

title: A ManMade Mountain Moves Arizona Highway
description: CLIFTON, Ariz.  Travelers who have driven the Coronado Trail (U.S. 666) from here to Springer ville will be happy to learn that those rugged first 20 miles of the north south route are about to be relocated off to the east, out of the deep and gloomy canyon that the highway now follows.

title: Midwinter Vacations
description: 1970 part 1

title: G. E. Strike: A Lesson in How Not to Negotiate
description: When New York's gravedig gers halted burials by going on strike last week, a union leader involved in the 12weekold General Electric strike com mented: It won't make any dif ference to G.E. They buried col lective bargaining long ago.

title: Louise C. Harris Is Betrothed To Charles A. Meriwether Jr.
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 17Mr. and Mrs. James Calhoun Harris have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Cleveland Harris, to Charles Albert Meriwether Jr. of Atlanta.

title: The Legend of the Man With the Silver Skull
description: LOS GATOS, Calif.If there had been a newspaper reporting the events in the Santa Cruz Mountains in 1854, when grizzly bears outnum bered people here, the following dispatch would probably have appeared:

title: Gen. Charles Girard Dies; Commander in Saigon, 52
description: SAIGON, Jan 17 (AP)  Brig. Gen. Charles J. Girard. commander of the United States Capital Military Assist ance Command here, died last night in his quarters, appar ently of a cerebral hemor rhage. He was 52 years old.

title: Prague Permits the Laying Of Wreath on Youth's Tomb
description: VIENNA, Jan. 17Small del egations from institutes of high er learning in Prague started taking turns this afternoon lay ing wreath at the tomb of Jan Palach, the 20yearold student who set himself on fire a year ago yesterday in protest against the Soviet led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

title: Spotlight:
description: Last week was hardly time for loud cheering in the automobile capital of Detroit.

title: James Manuel Lombard Weds Miss Susan Sweet at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17Miss Susan Sweet was married here this afternoon to James Manuel Lombard in the Memorial Church at Harvard University. The Rev. Charles P. Price performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Dominican Policeman Killed
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Jan. 17 (Reuters) One policeman was murdered and another was shot and wounded here last night. It was the second murder of a Santo Domingo policeman within a week. The incident added to tensions as the campaign for next May's elections began to gather strength.

title: Music
description: THIS is going to be my annual threnody about stereotyped pro grams, intellectual laziness and the easy, if not cynical, way of doing things. It is prompted by such things as the nearsimultaneous perform ances, two weeks ago, of the Brahms First Symphony. Claudio Abbado and Georg Solti came proudly to town, heads high and tails wagging, bearing the Brahms First like puppies who have unearthed a particularly succulent tin can. Presumably they expected to be rewarded with a pat on the head for such enterprise.

title: The Complete Operas Of Verdi
description: Charles Osborne's new book on the Verdi operas sets one to thinking about the rise, fall and subsequent deification of Giuseppe Verdi. It is not a subject that Osborne examines, but it is important for an under standing of his book and of Verdi today.

title: 1949 Magic Carpet Is Recalled
description: RECALLING the 20th an niversary of the 1949 Operation Magic Carpet, which brought Yemenite Jews to Israel by aircraft (rather than the eagles wings of their prayers) Israel has is sued a 30agorot multicolored stamp, designed by Amram Prath. It shows a jewellike plane in flight. A tab on the bottom row contains this quotation in Hebrew and Eng lish: I bore you on eagles wings and brought you to myself, from Exodus 19:4.

title: Elizabeth J. Morrison Is Married
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 17Miss Elizabeth Jennings Morrison and John Milnes Baker were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Morrison. Mayor Edward Haskell Hewson of Harding Township performed the ceremony.

title: Rare Copy of the Constitution Will Be Auctioned
description: Books, broadsides and maps that deal with various phases of early American history will be auctioned on Tuesday at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The collec tion, from the Library Company of Philadelphia and the Penn sylvania Historical Society, will be offered in two sessions, at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M.

title: Air Pollution Is Following Population to the Suburbs
description: The smell of burning garbage in backyards, soot and smoke seeping through windows, and exhaust fumes on local roads have become major nuisances for residents in some suburban communities that surround the city.

title: Miss Fontein, Design Student, Is a Bride Here
description: Miss Madeleine Fontein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pieter M. Fontein of Oradell, N. J., was married here yes terday afternoon to Wayne de Vries, son of Mrs. Raymond Drum of Zeeland, Mich., and the late Raymond de Vries.

title: WAR ON INFLATION GAINS IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 17The fight against inflation, which Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has made his paramount con cern for 1970, took important steps ahead this week. Whether the advances marked a turning point in the battle seemed to depend, however, on how serl ously business and labor would take Mr. Trudeau's pleas for support.

title: St. John's Crushes St. Francis; Georgetown Upsets Columbia
description: The Terriers of St. Francis had been barking loudly before entering the St. John's gym last night. They had scored seven victories in their first eight games, and were leading the country in fieldgoal percentage with a 55.6 average, but the St. John's Redmen took the bite out of them before 4,168 fans with an 8965 victory.

title: Why the Afro? You're Not That Kind of Guy
description: AL FREEMAN Jr. remembers going on a shopping expedition in Gal veston, Texas, shortly before traveling to the nearby Gulf Coast town of Port Bolivar where work was about to begin on My Sweet Charlie, in which he costars with Patty Duke on NBC's Tuesday Night at the Movies this week. When the wardrobe man who accompanied Freeman told the store keeper where they were heading, the man exclaimed, You mean you're gonna take a black man to Port Bolivar? They have pretty strong attitudes over there, Freeman, who was born in San Antonio but who hasn't spent much time in the South since his high school days, sighed and thought, Well, it's starting

title: Agriculture Post Filled
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)Edwin L. Kirby, 50 years old, has been promoted to $33,495ayearpost as adminis trator of the Agriculture De partment's Federal Extension Service. Mr. Kirby has served since September as associate administrator of the service, the Federal unit in the Federal stateslocal cooperative exten sion service, which operates the world's largest outofschool education system.

title: Budapest Radiates a New Vitality
description: BUDAPESTThis Communist capital city is not exactly swinging yet, but the idea is no longer preposter ous. Budapest is moving astonish ingly fast to reclaim its preWorld War status as the Queen of the Danube, as spritely and gay as Vienna.

title: Basic Pointers on the Care of House Plants
description: NINETY per cent of all problems in houseplant growing can be ex plained by one or more of the fol lowing reasons:

title: Catholic Lay Teachers Prepare to Strike Tomorrow as Pact Deadline Nears
description: Lay teachers of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York prepared to go on strike tomorrow as their leaders met with church officials yesterday in an attempt to negotiate a new contract.

title: OPEN HOUSING LAW WORKS IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 17In the first five months that the Nassau County Open Housing Law has been in effect, it has been credited with resolving 33 cases charging discrimination in the sale or rental of housing in the countyand in not one case was it formally invoked.

title: SafetyRecall System For Cars Is Proposed
description: The National Highway Safety Board has proposed a regulation for motorvehicle makers to keep track of how well their campaigns to re call cars from owners for cor recting possible defects have worked out.

title: $25,880 Chase Taken By Guest's L'Escargot
description: HAYDOCK, Scotland, Jan. 17 (Reuters)  L'Escargot, owned by Raymond D. Guest, a former American Ambas sador to Ireland, won the W. D. and H. O. Wills'pre miere steeplechase final at Havdock Park today.

title: Springfield Tops Dartmouth
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 17 Led by the clutch shooting of Denis Clark, Springfield upset Dartmouth, 7068, tonight in Alumni Gym. Clark scored 28 points, 19 in the second half.

title: John Pintaro Marries Miss Wendy J. White
description: RAMSEY, N. J., Jan. 17 Miss Wendy Jean White, daughter of Mrs. Lincoln Scholl of La Jolla, Calif., and the late William Ross White Jr. of Santa Monica, Calif was married here this after noon to John A. Pintard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Millard C. Pintard of Ramsey. The Rev. Leon Plante performed the ?? in St. John's ?? ?? Church.

title: Study of the San Andreas Fault
description: Cicatrix. The scar tissue of an earthy crustal faultin this case, the San Andreas, which precipitated the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and is considered likely to rupture again before the end of the centuryshows up with special clarity in the radar produced photograph above. Left, a view across the San Andreas Fault

title: Washington: The President, the People, and the Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The President has gone off to Camp David to work on the national budget. It is not an ideal way to spend a weekend. Nevertheless, if we think of him as the head of our vast and diverse American family which, poor man, he is, then we may be able to see his devilish task in somewhat simpler terms.

title: Miss Gelfand Sets Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herman G. Gelfand of Flushing, Queens, have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Ann Gelfand, to Harold W. Kestenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kestenbaum of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Extremes Meet at the Chapel Of Unorthodox Sydney Pastor
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17 A barefoot couple in hippie garb awaiting their turn at the altar watched Flight Lieut. Ian Maxwell Bryant of the Royal Australian Air Force and his bride, the former Nannette Shirleen Gwin of Reno, emerge beneath the traditional arch of swords held by the bride groom's fellow officers.

title: Floridians Score, 116115, On GoalTending by Colonel
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 17 (AP)Don Freeman scored 43 points tonight, including 2 on a lastshot goaltending call against Jim Ligon, as the Miami Floridians defeated the Ken tucky Colonels, 116115, in an American Basketball Associa tion game.

title: Lagos Ousts 4 Newsmen Who Visited Rebel Area
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 17 (Reuters)  Four London based journalists were ex pelled from Nigeria this morning for visiting the for mer secessionist territory of Biafra.

title: Manmade environment
description: Clean and spacious was the environment architect Arvin Shaw wanted to come home to . . . in congested, sootswept New York City. He found the space  a duplex pent house overlooking the East River  but before making it his own, he had to undo what looked like a pseudoGeorgian mansion. In its place he created a cool shell of glass, white walls and white marble floors to set off meticulously detailed furnishings.

title: Fatalism in Cairo: Nearby War Dismissed With Shrug
description: CAIRO, Jan. 17War has come to the gateways of this crowded and turbulent city, with Israeli fighterbombers screaming low over targets as close as nine miles away. But the four million Cairenes seem as serene as the eternal Nile that created the patient character of this country.

title: Pie and potable
description: A chronicler of drinks tells us that the brandy Alexander, that smooth combination of cognac, cream and crme de cacao, came into being during the Prohibition era. He adds that the cocktail was undoubtedly made with ingredients just off the boat  the ferry boat, that is, straight from Hoboken. No matter what its origin, a brandy Alexander is an interesting drink and its ingredients, for which we are no longer dependent on bootleggers, fortunately, make an equally interesting pie.

title: Movies
description: HOLLYWOOD. HOLLYWOOD may be at the end of its rope, but you can't hear the death rattle over at Jean Simmons' and Richard Brooks' house. Recently, for example, when some of the critics started roasting their new film The Happy End ing, Brooks just opened an other can of beer, lit up his pipe and laughed. Unlike most people who create movies, Richard Brooks has very lit tle interest in critics. I've done everything I believed in, he says. I love the pic ture, I'm proud of it. If I worried about things like critics, I'd never get any work done. Every few years they get on somebody's back. Now it's my turn. Fifteen years ago the same thing happened on The Blackboard Jungle. Now they forgot what they said. I don't want to fight in the press. I'll fight by making another pic ture. Galileo didn't go to jail for nothing.

title: Outstanding Recent Books
description: A highly selective list of business books of general in terest published during the past year, compiled by the ed itors of the Book Review with the counsel of Morris Harth, publications editor of the Na tional Industrial Conference Board, and Sylvia Mechanic, Business Librarian of the Brook lyn Public Library.

title: Pope and Briton Discuss Aid
description: ROME. Jan. 17 (AP)Brit ain's Under Secretary for For eign Affairs. Maurice Foley, returning to London from a trip to Lagos talked today with Pope Paul VI on the situation in Nigeria. Vatican informants said the talks revolved around relief efforts under way to help victims of the war.

title: CHAPOT ELECTED U.S.E.T. DIRECTOR
description: Five new directors, including Frank Chapot, a fourtime Olympic rider, were added to the board of directors of the United States Equestrian Team yesterday. The action took place at the annual meeting of the group at the WaldorfAs toria Hotel at the closing session of the American Horse Shows Association's 53d annual convention.

title: Foaling Breeds Discord
description: Like his thoroughbred counterpart, the 2yearold harness horse faces multiple hazards in getting to the races and staying; there.

title: BIAFRAN OFFICERS COAXING HOLDOUTS TO LEAVE THE BUSH
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 17 The commanders of the shat tered Biafran army scattered across the former rebel terri tory today, helping Nigerian patrols coax holdouts to come out of the bush and turn them selves in.

title: Marine Psychology Helps Save Part of a Loyal Herd of Whales
description: By exercising some im provised whale psychology, Florida marine patrolmen have managed to save 22 of nearly 200 black pilot whales that beached themselves a week ago.

title: East Backs Bid by Sections to Share Open Fee Paid to U. S. L. T.
description: The Eastern Lawn Tennis As sociation endorsed yesterday proposal that would sanction fees to a section holding an open tournament.

title: Snowmobiling Up in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me.No one knows the exact number of snowmobiles that are cruising about Maine this winter because, while no snow treaded vehicle can be operated in the state unless registered (at a fee of $10), no registration is required for those snow scooters operated by an owner on his own land. What is known is that there are now 43 snowmobile clubs in the state with a combined membership of about 6.000.

title: Registration to Open Tomorrow For Local School Board Voting
description: Voter registration will begin tomorrow and continue through Jan. 31 for the community school board elections that will. for the first time in the city's history, give parents and others a direct voice in the operation of their local schools.

title: Misty'n Fleet, at $26.40, Takes Narragansett Dash
description: PAWTUCKET, R. T., Jan. 17 (AP)Ernest E. Edgar's long shot. Misty'n Fleet, closed strongly today to win the $7,500 Block Island Handicap at Narragansett Park.

title: Speaking of Books: Marx on the Food Shelf
description: For several months in the year 1941 you could run into a strange thing at the New York Public Library branch on 161st Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. If you looked up Das Kapital, Volume I, by Karl Marx, the catalogue would tell you to go to 331M on the economics shelf. But if you went to 331M, you'd encounter only a gap. If you asked the librarian to check her onloan file, she'd find no record of anyone borrowing the book. If you assumed it had been stolen, you'd be wrong too. It was on the premises. Way at the opposite end of the reading room it lay hidden behind the volumes on the food shelf. There it stayed en tombed all day until I came along in the afternoon, pulled it out, studied it for a magic hour, then hid it again when nobody was looking.

title: Field Of Travel
description: CONSTRUCTION on the Keio Plaza Hotel in the Shinjuku district of downtown Tokyo has begun. When completed in June, 1971, as part of an urban development project, the 51story building will be the world's tallest hotel.

title: Underwriting Losses Surge for Insurers
description: The underwriting loss or the nation's property and li ability insurance companies surged to an estimated $500 million during 1969 from $200million the year before, a result that threatens to re strict their capacity to meet rapidly expanding demands for coverage.

title: Memphis Debates Road Through a Park
description: MEMPHIS, Jan. 17A $35 million bridge across the Mis sissippi River is taking shape while nature lovers and conser vationists are in court trying to prevent construction of a high way to connect its eastern end.

title: SONG FOR OLD AGE
description: Gaunt Ulysses, homeward bound, Spidery hand in a winedark sea, Feeling the night in whispers brush The naked mind with urgency.

title: Business With a Social Conscience
description: At no time in our history have more voices been raised supporting the view that business must break out of its conventional preoccupation with profit and do more to meet pressing social needs. The chorus has been joined by leaders from govern ment, education, labor and all minor ity groups. Business leadership has acknowledged the demand for en larged corporate responsibility in ways which can only reflect a pro found attitudinal change, individually and collectively.

title: Words on The Safety Of the Pill
description: WASHINGTON  At the opening last week of Senate subcommittee hearings on birth control pills, Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, commented that the public had been exposed to many conflicting reports on the dangers and efficacy of the pills. The public was con fused, he said, and he ex pressed the hope that claims concerning the oral contracep tivesnow being used by an estimated 8.5 million Ameri can womenwould be anal yzed as objectively and sci entifically as possible.

title: U.S. Business:
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 Taking risks does not mean playing Russian roulette, says William Zucker, presi dent of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Development Fund.

title: 61% PRAISE NIXON IN YEAREND POLL
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 17 On the eve of the first anni versary of his inauguration, President Nixon wins a vote of confidence from 61 per cent of the nation's adults, according to the latest Gallup poll.

title: BULLS WIN, 132130; END BUCKS' STREAK
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 17 (UPI) The Chicago Bulls, trailing by 15 points with 4:20 left in reg ulation play, rallied behind the shooting of Shaler Halimon and Bob Weiss to break the Bucks' fivegame winning streak, 132130, in overtime today.

title: Aid Shipment Arrives
description: LAGOS, Jan, 17 (UPI)The first shipments from abroad of aid for refugees arrived tonight from Britain. A British transport plane brought seven Land Rovers and ?? ??

title: Caliente to Open Fridays
description: AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 17 (UPI)Caliente race track will begin Friday racing next week. A track spokesman said today the extra day of racing here would be canceled if Santa Anita's winter meets gets started. A strike has closed the Arcadia, Calif., track. Caliente races normally are held Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Blanche DuBois Was Here
description: KILROY was not here. Amanda Wing field was, but not Kilroy. Blanche DuBois was, but not Kilroy. Kilroy was not here because Tennessee Williams forgot to invent him. He just named him, and put the Name on the stage.

title: BUDGET GAP PAYS ITS ANNUAL VISIT
description: The city's Budget Director yesterday added up what city agencies would like to spend next year and what the govern ment expects to take in and came out $1billion short.

title: CZECH TAKES HONORS IN SWISS SKI JUMP
description: LE BRASSUS, Switzerland, Jan. 17 (AP)Tomas Kucera of Czechoslovakia led a fourman East European sweep of the combination jump today as the last major warmup for next month's Nordic world cham pionships got underway.

title: Article 2  No Title
U.S. SAYS VIETCONG SHOT 2 PRISONERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 (AP)  The United States Command said today that the Vietcong had hauled two Amer ican captives from one village to another, placed them on ex hibition and then shot them to death.

title: ForeignFlag Container Ships Found Gaining in the Atlantic
description: Foreignflag competition is coming on fast in North At lantic container shipping.

title: Westward to Laughter
description: While some people have been biting their nails over the possibilities og survival for the modern novel, it turns out that the 18thcentury novel is alive and well. Robinson Crusoe and Gulliver's Travels, despite attacks of abbreviation, adaptation and animation, never have been sick. Tom Jones showed undiminished vigor in a film just a few years ago. That figure so popular in 18thcentury narratives, the goodnatured rogue who can escape one impossible situation only by rushing headlong into another, appears with increasing frequency in contemporary fiction.

title: Kathryn Wiley Is Bride Of Louis P. Thebault Jr.
description: WARRENTON, Va., Jan. 17 Miss Kathryn Langhorne Wiley, daughter of Mrs. Bar rett Wiley of Mantoloking, N. J., and Middleburg and the late James Langhorne Wiley of Gordonsdale Farm, The Plains, was married here to day to Louis Philip Thebault Jr. The ceremony was per formed in St. John's Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Edward L. Melton, assisted by the Rev. Neal Morgan.

title: When the Crunch Comes, Can Taiwan Hold Together?
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan. AFTER visiting Taiwan recently to investigate the possibility of relocating there the nuclear armed B52's now stationed in Oki nawa, a highranking American offi cer bluntly told colleagues in Taipei: I give your place about five years. Then it's anybody's ball game.

title: What's New in the Theater
description: CAMINO REAL, a revival of Tennessee Williams's play, got four favorable reviews, two mixed and three nega tive. Clive Barnes: There are people who think that Camino Real was Tennes see Williams's best play, and I believe that they are right. It is a play that seems to have been torn out of a human soul, a tale told by an idiot signifying a great deal of suffering and a great deal of gal lantry. Clearly Williams has put an almost agoniz ing amount of himself into the play. Yet it is at times enormously funny as well as poetically mysterious, and it is illuminated with that special theatricality that Williams has always shown, even in the lower depths of his career. Mil ton Katselas's staging is most striking and Peter Wexler's most beautiful setting not only uses the Beaumont Theater better than ever before but pro vides the visual accompani ment to the fantasy. Jes sica Tandy is quite mar velous as Camille and I ad mired equally Clifford David as Byron and Philip Bosco as Charlus. This is a lovely play, a play of gen uinely poetic vision. For Walter Kerr, see Page 1.

title: The South Fights an Agonizing But Losing Battle
description: JACKSON, Miss  The good old days that white diehards is the South now dreamily refer to are no longer peopled with delicate ladies in hoop skirts attended by shuffling Uncle Toms; rather, the vision goes back only a few months to last September, when freedomof choice tokenism seemed capable of indefinite survival and the top civil rights attorney in the Justice Department insisted that forced school desegregation would be impossible to obtain by the 1970 school term.

title: Toward Spring
description: The depth of winter, in terms of daylight and dark ness at least, occurred almost a month ago. No matter how deep the snow lies back in the hillsand it is still measured in feet, many placeswe now are definitely on our way toward spring. The span of day light today is almost half an hour longer than it was at the year's nadir, at the time of the winter solstice. The sun moves north, as we say. We now gain almost two minutes of daylight each day.

title: SCHNEERSON HAILED BY ORTHODOX JEWS
description: Orthodox Jews from various parts of the country paid trib ute last night to Rabbi Mena chem M. Schneerson on his 20th anniversary as spiritual leader of one of the world's largest Hassidic groups.

title: Peking and Moscow You're Another . . .
description: The Chinese Say:

title: LIBERALS SUGGEST UTILITY ISLANDS
description: The Liberal party suggested yesterday that offshore ?? ity islands might he c??n structed to combat pollution.

title: Of Woodpeckers and Finches
description: THE wind howled through the yard. Pine trees heeled over as each gust pushed them and snowy rain pelt ed the windows. A suet feeder, hanging from one of the pine branches, swayed wildly in all the wintry goings on. But a hairy woodpecker, clinging fast, didn't seem to mind. It was lunch time.

title: Kevin A. Coles to Marry Anne G. Cotter
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 17 Miss Anne Galvin Cotter, a junior at Trinity College in Washington, and Kevin And rew Coles, a senior at Georgetown University there, plan to be married.

title: Gorman, Umpire, to Get Slocum Award on Feb. 1
description: Tom Gorman, a National League umpire since 1951, will receive the W. J. Slocum Award for long and merito rious service to baseball at the annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Base ball Writers' Association on Feb. 1 at the Americana Hotel.

title: Palestinians Entertain Belon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Christian Belon, the young Frenchman who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet to here on Jan. 9 was entertained today by Palestinian comman dos wihle he visited the histor ic city of Baalbek.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: THE stock market and the economy were as chilled the weather in many parts of the country last week. Temperatures were reduced by the frigid winds uncertaintyover business conditions, corporate profits, inflation, monetary policy and the Government's fiscal plans.

title: CARD PLAYERS FOIL HOLDUP IN BROOKLYN
description: Four robbers tried to hold up 20 men who were playing cards in a Brooklyn social club yesterday morning, but the card players jumped them and two of the gunmen ended up with serious gunshot wounds.

title: PUERTO RICO SEEN STATE IN 10 YEARS
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 17 (AP)  One year after pulling the biggest political upset in this island's history, Luis A. Ferro, a United States style Governor who wants Puerto Rico to be the 51st state, believes state hood is still at least 10 years away.

title: A Correction
description: On Page 17 of Section 2, the caption under the photograph of Janet Baker, the English mezzosoprano, says that Miss Baker will sing at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening. Miss Baker's recital will be given there on Tuesday evening as listed in Who Makes Music and Where on Page ?? of Sec tion 2.

title: Israeli Forays Into Egypt Viewed as a Tactical Shift
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17  Last night's ground attack by Israeli commandos only 40 miles from Cairo and the recent bombing raids deep inside Egypt are being interpreted here as sig nals of a significant change in Israeli tactics.

title: RED WINGS SCORE OVER FLYERS, 53
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17 (UPI) Alex Delvecchio scored one goal and set up two by Frank Mahovlich today as the Detroit Red Wings snapped the Phila delphia Flyers' sixgame un beaten streak with a 53 vic tory.

title: Dean Appointed at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 (AP)Harvard University has announced the appointment of Maurice D. Kilhridge as dean of the Graduate School of Design. He has been acting dean since the retirement of Jose Luis Sert last summer.

title: Some Catalogue Gleanings
description: MANY gardeners rely on seed and nursery catalogues to de cide on the plants they will grow this year. Ev erything needed to plant and tend a garden can be pur chased from catalogues. Al though most sell the same kinds of seeds or plants, it is a rare gardener who is satisfied with only one.

title: Arthur R. Gatewood, 70, Dead; Led American Shipping Bureau
description: Arthur R. Gatewood, who retired in 1964 as chairman of the American Bureau of Ship ping, an international ship classification society, died Thursday, apparently of heart attack, near his home at 106 East 35th Street. His age was 70.

title: Photography
description: SPOTTY references to Thomas Eakins, the noted American realis tic painter of the 19th century, as also an avid pho tographer who frequently used the camera as an aid to painting have been appear ing occasionally for years. To see approximately 200 of them gathered in a single place in a major museum ex hibition comes as a complete surprise.

title: MARINE POLLUTION STUDIED IN FRANCE
description: MARSEILLES, France, Jan. 13The tuna fleet working off the oilrefining center of Fos recently had to dump a hand some catch because it smelled of petroleum.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: An Oracle in a Slump

title: In Search of Adventure In the Wilds of Guyana A New Tourism Frontier
description: GEORGETOWN, GuyanaThe char tered eightseater aircraft landed neatly on the bank of the Potaro River, and as we disembarked from that vantage point the mist and roar of Kaieteur Falls could be seen and heard. It was hot even though it was November, and the footing was treacherous as we rounded the curve and slid down an embankment.

title: Miss Meyer Wins 2 Events
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 17 (AP)Debbie Meyer collected two more titles tonight in the Queensland swimming cham pionships. The Olympic cham pion from Sacramento, Calif., won the 1,500 meters free style easily in 18:20.9 and then coasted to victory in the 400 meter individual medley in 5:22.4.

title: Florida Vegetables Hit Hard by the Cold
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. Jan. 17  The continued cold spell is beginning to take heavy toll of Florida's vege table crnos according to re ports from North Broward and Palm Beach counties, along with such rich areas as Immokalee, Belle Glade, Homestead and even the Ba hamas.

title: Bridge
description: TAKING the low road is celebrated in song as the most effective road to Scotland, and in bridge books as the soundest policy for a defender in second position. Consequently play ers tend to play low automatically when a suit is led from the hand to their right.

title: ITALIANS DETAINED IN SOVIET PROTEST
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17  Two young Italians were apparently arrested today after demon strating in a Moscow depart ment store against the detention of Soviet dissidents.

title: Old  Timer to Join Newport Cup Fleet
description: Aside from watching the America's Cup races them selves, the next best thing to do at Newport, when the com petition begins Sept. 15, is to watch the spectator fleet. While the really large yachts such as Corsair and Sea Cloud are no longer there, the fleet has included the graceful Her reshoff doubleender Thania, which has had only two owners since 1905, the sleek black Lit tle Stranger, built by Consoli dated in the nineteentwenties, and other handsome craft built in an era when appearance counted for more than the number of berths per foot.

title: Mobutu Agrees to Meeting
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, Jan. 17 (Agence France  Presse) President Mobutu of the Congo today accepted a suggestion by President Bokassa of the Cen tral African Republic that Gen eral Mobutu meet President Ngouabi of the Congo Repub lic on Jan. 22.

title: African Violet Care
description: FEW plants have the enormous popularity bestowed on the Af rican violet. An Eng lish Garden Periodical, sent to me by a friend states, Af rican violets are a way of life in America, you grow them with a passion.

title: First Aid for Investors
description: Anyone who has recently been engaged in Wall Street re search and money management must be aware that the rules of the technical game have changed radically. Publicity given to any system attracts adherents who by their very activities tend to reduce what ever predictive value the sys tem ever had. In addition the substitution of a relatively small number of professional man agers for a relatively large number of public speculators in recent years has tended to encourage the growth of anti systems, set up precisely to operate against anticipated Pav lovian responses of the more naive speculators (professional or otherwise) to classic buy and sell signals.

title: Observer: For Those Who Have to Quit the Habit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Fol lowing are a few tips aimed at helping the American man re adjust to society while break ing one of the most powerful habits of all:

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: After wading through Tom Wicker's interminably long winded piece concerning John Edgar Hoover and the F.B.I. (What Have They Done Since They Shot Dillinger? Dec. 28), I have come up with sev eral obvious observations.

title: Cargo Assessment Plan Is Assailed
description: A new Method or assessing stevedore companies for fringe benefits to longshoremen was attacked yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

title: Japan Aiding in Food Output
description: TOKYO  Japanese com panies, encouraged by the Government, will be helping underdeveloped countries to increase their food produc tion. And they hope to help themselves to the big con sumer markets in these na tions once they develop selfsufficiency in food.

title: Thursday to Be a Glorious Evening
description: A gala benefit for the Uni versity of the Streets will be held Thursday night at the or ganization's fivestory build ing at 130 East Seventh Street, at Avenue A near Tompkins Square Park.

title: Roger Hall of RCA Records To Head Carolina Arts Unit
description: Roger Hall, manager of Red Seal artists and repertory for RCA Records here, will become president of the North Carolina School of the Arts Foundation, effective March 1, the founda tion announced yesterday. At the same time, Robert Ward, president of the North Carolina School of the Arts in WinstonSalem, announced that Mr. Hall had been appointed, executive director of the school.

title: Jailed Mexican Students Near the End of a 40Day Hunger Strike
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18A hunger strike by some 80 impris oned student leaders, now 39 days long, has aroused protest demonstrations at Mexican uni versities and criticism of the country's judicial system among Roman Catholic priests.

title: Carr Is Dazzler of Notre Dame Quintet
description: Austin Carr has come of age. The Notre Dame hack courtman, who has all the flash of a Harlem Globetrot ter, has reached the stage where college coaches and pro scouts are comparing his shooting and moves with those of Elgin Baylor, the Los Angeles Laker superstar, in his prime.

title: Laurie J. Lees Future Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Zeeman Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Zeeman's daughter, Miss Laurie Jane Lees, to James Richard Bottomley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bottom ley of Geneva. A June wed ding is planned.

title: Hybrid Rice Helps Vietnamese Farms
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam A middleaged man with mudstained ankles plods be hind a water buffalo in a landlord's flooded rice field, while hoping that the com batants on both sides of the war will leave him alone. That has been the picture of the South Vietnamese farm er for the past five years.

title: VIRGIL FOX REJOICES IN LA BELLE EPOQUE
description: Virgil Fox so evidently en joys giving organ recitallec tures, and his admiring audi ence, seated in the semidark, so obviously takes pleasure from luxuriating in the floods of sound that he sends forth that it seems churlish to point out that the sort of playing that went on last night at Philhar monic Hall would be hard to surpass for naivete and vul garity.

title: Bridge:
description: THE Tri  State regional championships at Gross ingers in the Catskills ended last night with most of the major titles going to little known players.

title: Austerity Chokes Vietnam Business
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Like a patient undergoing harsh cure, the South Viet namese economy was still gasping at the end of 1969 from a dose of bitter medi cine administered in the fall by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: LINDLEY MURRAY CHEMICAL LEADER
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 18 (AP) R. Lindley Murray, retired chairman of the Hooker Chemical Corporation, and a former national tennis singles champion, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 77 years old and lived on Mountain View Drive in suburban Lewiston Heights.

title: Another Great Leap By Chinese Reds?
description: HONG KONG  In the annals of Communist China, 1969 may go down as the year in which the stage was set for a major new effort at economic advance in the seventies.

title: Hirt Reelected President Of Harness Writers Group
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 18 Clyde Hirt, of the Roosevelt Raceway publicity staff, was reelected today president of the New York chapter of the Harness Writers Association.

title: SAFETY PERKS UP VICTOR'S OFFENSE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP) The West, waking up after its defense scored a safety, ral lied today and defeated the East, 1613, in the 20th annual National Football League Pro Bowl game.

title: Threat of Welfare Bill Veto Is Decried by Humphrey
description: WILIMAR, Minn., Jan. 18 (AP)President Nixon's threat to veto the health, education and welfare appropriations bill is an attempt to repeal the nineteen sixties, former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said last night.

title: No One Answer to Drugs
description: There are, by official estimate, about 100,000 hard core heroin addicts in New York City and, in addition, perhaps ten to fifteen times this number of persons with serious drug abuse or alcoholism problems. There are thousands of teenage heroin addicts and still more who are hooked on gluesniffing, LSD and a variety of other dangerous pills and chemicals. The problem of drug abuse among the young seems to be growing in alarming fashion as the average age of heroin addicts declines and the availability of drugs in school cor ridors increases. Children as young as twelve years of age are dying in this city from the use of drugs.

title: Ryan, McGee Handle 3Hour Program
description: Harvard School of Public Health while Fanny Lou Han mer, a leader in organizing poor people, speaking in Mis sissippi, described families of 16 members living on $500 a year.

title: Register for School Voting
description: After all the planning and controversy, the success of the decentralization of the city's schools depends in large measure on the citizens' concern and partici pation. Only selection of able and conscientious candidates for the new community school boards can translate good intentions into sound policies. A vital element in that process is informed and intelligent balloting by parents.

title: Point of View
description: INDIA'S central problem for the next several decades is to improve the ratio of food to people. In greater or lesser degree, this applies to almost all the countries of South and Southeast Asia. In size, and perhaps in severity, India's problem is the most difficult and the most significant.

title: ISRAELIS UNEARTH A TALMUDIC NAME
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18Arche ologists today discovered the name Bar Katros inscribed on a stone weight in the ruins of a house in Jerusalem destroyed by the Romans 1,900 years ago.

title: In Naples, Housing Booms, Sewers Falter and Streets Collapse
description: NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 16 When the winter drizzle in Naples becomes a downpour, as it has now, water breaks through the 110yearold sew er ducts, streets collapse, houses crumble and people die.

title: WALLACE C. PHILOON, RETIRED GENERAL, 86
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 18 Maj. Gen. Wallace C. Phil oon, U. S. A., retired, who commanded the Army's cen ter at Fort McClellan, Ala., from 1942 to 1944, when 200,000 infantry replacement troops were trained for World War II, died on Friday in a hospital in Portland. He was 86 years old.

title: Personal Finance
description: Timeliness is a virtue that the embattled taxpayer should keep in mind when problems arise with the Internal Revenue Service. It's important to follow the procedural rules exactly. Suppose that the I.R.S. noti fies a taxpayer that on a re turn filed two years ago, it has discovered a mistake or challenges a return more than three years after its filing date. the I.R.S. typically sends out its socalled 30day letter, or preliminary notice. Within the time limit, the taxpayer can request a conference in the district director's office or he can go to an appellate division conference, usually in a re gional office. Sometimes he might do both.

title: Pope Terms the News on Nigerian Situation Good
description: ROME, Jan. 18Pope Paul VI said today that he had good news from Nigeria where responsible Govern ment authorities have indi cated there would be no vio lence or vendettas.

title: Art Biennial Opens in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 18 Puerto Rico, known for its Casals Festival each June, has made a serious bid for another place on the world's cultural map with the first San Juan Biennial, presenting 700 graphic works by 180 artists from Latin America and the Carib bean. The exhibition opened Friday and will continue through March 15.

title: LITTLER, JOHNSON IN TIE FOR SECOND
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 18 (UPI)Dale Douglass shot a 66 in the final round to pull away from the pack and win the $100,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today with a 72hole total of 271, two strokes under par. The first prize was $20,000.

title: BOSTON'S CHARGE PACED BY BRYANT
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18The York Knickerbockers, with the exception of Willis Reed, suf fered a disastrous shooting drought in the third quarter that brought about a 109102 defeat at the hands of the! Boston Celtics, the National, Basketball Association's defend ing champions, in a nationally, televised game today at Boston Garden.

title: Queens Democrats Choose Candidate for Assembly
description: Democratic leaders in the 25th Assembly District of Queens picked Emanuel R. Gold of Kew Gardens Hills yesterday as the party candidate for the Assembly seat formerly held by Supreme Court Justice Moses M. Weinstein.

title: MRS. SAMUEL D. LEVISON
description: Mrs. Clara Lustig Levison, retired principal of Public School 25 in Brooklyn, died yes terday at the Bronx Municipal Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived at 2550 84th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. Her husband, Samuel D. Levison, is principal of Public School 56 in Brooklyn.

title: SANE Bids U.S. Curtail Idiocy of More Weapons
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 18 (UPI) The National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy called to day for a shift in national pri ority from what it described as the idiocy of producing more weapons to providing homes, health care and education, which are our real needs.

title: Barbara Cochran Wins Slalom; Russel Takes Combined Title
description: MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, Jan. 18 (AUPI)  Barbara Cochran of the United States captured the slalom event today and took top honors in the two day competition counting to ward the women's World Cup championship in Alpine skiing.

title: THEODORE GAILLARD, FREELANCE WRITER
description: Theodore Lee Gaillard, a member of the society news department of The New York Times in the nineteenthirties anti forties, died Saturday of a heart attack in Polyclinic Hos pital. He was 62 years old and lived at 400 West 57th Street.

title: Keino Is Upset by Lawson in Coast Mile
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP)The indoor track and field scene shifts eastward this week and at least one 1968 Olympic champion, Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, will he seeking to reverse his first loss of the winter season.

title: India Doubling Her Effort To Control Population
description: NEW DELHIA simple red triangle, the symbol of India's birth control pro gram, is seen everywhere these days from the lapels of public offiicals to the sides of locomotives.

title: Article 1  No Title
A CRITICAL PERIOD LOOMS FOR BONDS
description: The money and capital mar kets are heading into a cru cial threeweek period that will largely determine the course of interest notes this year.

title: NETS ARE BEATEN BY PACERS, 129111
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 18  The Indiana Pacers have the best wonlost record in professional basketball, but their coach says they're not quite ready to dominate every team in the business.

title: AmericanIsraeli Unit Plans To Honor Five Next Month
description: The Torch of Learning Award, bronze statuette sculptured by the New York artist Chaim Gross, has been created by the American Friends of Hebrew University to honor leaders of AmericanJewish communities who have advanced the cause of higher education in this country and Israel.

title: GINSBERG REPORTS ON CHILD CENTER
description: A new city Children's Center for 250 neglected or abandoned children is a project that Mit chell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administra tor, said yesterday that he honed to see before I die

description: OSAKA, Japan  Mohari Makka?

title: EARNINGS DECLINE AT BANKERS TRUST
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported over the weekend that its 1969 earnings, calculated in conformance with new bank accounting regula tions, totaled $40,832,000, or $3,99 a share.

title: Economic Ties to U.S. Arouse Canadian Fears
description: mounting Canadian debate on economic relations with the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Penn Central Service

title: WarPrisoners' Committee Opens Office Here Today
description: The Committee of Liaison With Families of Servicemen Detained in North Vietnam, or ganized by antiwar activists to facilitate the exchange of mail between American prisoners held in North Vietnam and their families, opens its office today at 365 West 42d Street, accord ing to the chairman of the group.

title: Bowdoin Drops College Boards; Scores Are Said to Show Bias
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 18 The Bowdoin College faculty has voted to eliminate all Col lege Board examination require ments for prospective students.

title: Saigon: Funds Needed Urgently
description: SAIGON, South VietnamAs South Vietnam concluded a decade of war and faced the prospect of a reduced American presence in the coming dec ade, the need to attract foreign capital for reconstruction and growth took on a special urgency.

title: Philadelphia Cites Ormandy
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (UPI) Eugene Ormandy, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, was named yesterday as the 49th recipient of the Philadel phia Award for outstanding public service.

title: Hector's Cafeteria Closes; In Times Sq. Since 30's
description: Hector's bustling cafeteria in Times Square, where one help ing of strawberry shortcake could make an instant disaster out of a calorie  limited diet, closed at 12:30 A.M. today.

title: Bauxite Giving Birth to Town
description: SYDNEY, Australia  On one of the most remote sites in Australia, 400 miles from the nearest habitation, work will start this month on an all airconditioned town for 3,000 residents.

title: Point of View
description: THE Japanese economy has witnessed a high rate of growth for almost a quarter of a century since the end of World War II. We have at times been criticized for at taching too much importance solely to economic growth. But I think it has been a tre mendous achievement to have reached the present stage.

title: VAN CLIBURN SHINES IN LISZT CONCERTO
description: The Moscow Philharmonic closed out its concentrated, eightconcert New York mini season last night at Carnegie Hall. Kiril Kondrashin, conduc tor, and Van Cliburn, pianist, who have been heard with each other, off and on, since Mr. Cli burn became famous by win ning the Tchaikovsky Prize in Moscow in 1958, were featured in the Liszt Piano Concerto No. 1.

description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Complacency Worries Singapore
description: SINGAPORE  By now it should be no secret that this city state of two million peo ple is one of the economic marvels of the developing world. A recent book on the third world referred to the growth of brokenbacked states  countries with good infrastructures from their colonial governments, but which were slowly grind ing to a halt economically.

title: 76ERS VANQUISH ROYALS BY 141116.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) A burst of 11 straight points midway through the second quarter today keyed a 141116 victory for the Philadelphia 76ers over the Cincinnati Royals.

title: Seoul's Goals Remain Tough
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In 1964, when the South Korean Government started the coun try's present export drive and set the year's goal at a little over $100million, the general feeling here was: How can we achieve it? Isn't the target too high?

title: Asia Bank Finding Its Own Aid Niche
description: MANILAThe Asian De velopment Bank, a stripling among the major internation al development financing in stitutions, showed signs of developing a distinctive per sonality durina 1969.

title: HOTA SOCCER SQUAD WINS TWICE INDOORS
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18  The twoday indoor German American Soccer League tour nament got under way at the County Center today before 1,100 fans with all the Major Division teams, except Hellenic, playing a total of 14 games.

title: Road Progress Stop and Go
description: BANGKOK, ThailandThe development of road trans port in Asia, an absolute es sential for economic progress over the vast expanse of the continent, is proceeding in a slow tempo of patchwork and paradox.

title: The Summaries
WALLACE CRITICIZES NIXON SCHOOL POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) George C. Wallace said today that he was ready to start a new political offensive aimed at defeating President Nixon in 1972 unless Mr. Nixon did something to stop the destruc tion of the public school system.

title: NEWLEFT YOUTHS PROTEST IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Jan. 18Brilliant with multicolored banners and helmets, some 5,000 students and young workers of the so called new left gathered in Tokyo park today to com memorate the battle of Yasuda Hall and to pledge new efforts to bring their version of a reyo lutior to Japan this year.

title: Negro Baptist in St. Patrick's Pulpit
description: The first Negro Protestant to preach in St. Patrick's Cathe dral opened a nationwide ob servance of the annual Week of Prayer for Christian Unity yesterday.

title: A Confusion at Appomattox
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 18 Since the war of secession began, two and onehalf years ago, the street lights have been turned off in Lagos. The few people who venture out in the dark of the steamy nights feel their way to avoid drainage ditches around most buildings.

title: Hertz Service in Pakistan
description: Hertz International has an nounced the extension of its carrental service to Pakistar with Travel Walji's Ltd of Is lamabad as licensee.

title: ALFRED PHILLIPS, STAMFORD MAYOR
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 18 Alfred Noroton Phillips, three time Mayor of Stamford during the nineteentwenties and thir ties, and a former United States Representative, died at Stam ford Hospital this afternoon of a heart attack. He was 75 years old and lived at 29 Middlesex Road, Darien

title: Foyt Wins on Coast
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP)A. J. Foyt of Houston, Tex., won a crashmarred River sideMotor Trend 500mile stock car race today by about three seconds in his 1970 Ford Torino.

title: Nixon's Nov. 3 Speech: Why He Took the Gamble Alone
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 President Nixon's State of the Union Message Thursday is eagerly awaited in Washington, but it is not likely to be as revealing or profoundly impor tantto him, to his staff, per haps even to the country as his speech to the nation on Viet nam last Nov. 3.

title: Negro Tries to Reach Buyers
description: Jackson Champion, a North ern Negro who embarked on a difficult career of sales rep resentation 20 years ago, has a dream. He hopes to see the day when any black salesman can get a hearing at the lower echelons of large chain and department stores and at post exchanges and other Government buving offices.

title: Pastry Tarts to Vary Winter Dinners
description: ARICH pastry tart is ideal to serve with tea or cof fee. For ending a winter din ner try a light, lemony des sert pie. Recipes for them are offered below.

title: Christian Overture to Jews Called Hoax by Rabbi Here
description: The executive vice president of the Synagogue Council of America said yesterday the re cent notion that Christians were interested in all forms of interreligious contact with the Jewish community was a hoax.

title: Tokyo Company Mirrors Economy
description: TOKYOA mountain as high as Fuji needs vast skirts from which to soar. When you look at the economic heights Japan has achieved, you should remember the solid base of teamwork on which this achievement rests.

title: Professor Vanishes at the University of Colorado
description: BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 18 A Czechborn associate profes sor of modern Russian history has disappeared from the Uni versity of Colorado campus.

title: Columbia Screens Psychologist for Presidency
description: William J. McGill, chancellor of the University of California at San Diego, has emerged as a leading candidate for the presidency of Columbia Univer sity.

title: Soviet Economic Woes...
description: Foreign observers have been aware for some time that the Soviet economy was in trouble. Shortages of meat and other goods have recently been visible even in Moscow, the bestsupplied of Soviet cities. There has been increasing evidence of Soviet inability to keep up with the pace of world technology, a weak ness symbolized bybut not confined toMoscow's poor performance in the moon race. Finally, the latest batch of Soviet economic statistics released last month testified that a serious slowdown of economic growth took place in 1969, a retardation without precedent since Nikita Khrushchev's ouster in 1964.

title: Israelis Bomb Near Cairo For 4th Time This Month
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18Israeli jets raided military targets out side Cairo again today in the fourth such attack since Israel began striking at the Egyptian interior earlier this month.

title: Lisbon Offers Asylum
description: LISBON, Jan. 18The Portu guese Government stated today its intention to extend hospital ity to Biafran refugees and to maintain all facilities on the is land of So Tom for relief work. In an official note the Government said it joins its voice to the international ap peals that everything be done to avoid a massacre of the ci vilian population and to or ganize relief.

title: Official Says Hawks Clicked With Camera, Not Puck, on Disputed Goal
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Tom Moon, the goal judge at last night's ChicagoBoston hockey game, said a camera inside the net might have been mistaken for the puck by Bill Friday in the referee's disputed call that led to a 10 National Hockey League vic tory by the Black Hawks over the Bruins.

title: Mrs. Helen Cook Wed To William Vanderbilt
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 18  Mrs. Helen Cum mings Cook of Wendling Farm, Williamstown, and Wil liam H. Vanderbilt of Wil liamstown, former Governor of Rhode Island, were married here this noon at the bride's home.

title: Nixon's Inflation Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18For a long time now12 months to be exactthere has been a lot of theoretical discussion about what President Nixon would do when his antiinfla tion policy began to bite. There are still no sure answers, but the question is theoretical no longer.

title: Cyclists Race in Vietnam With Politics in Tandem
description: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 18With army helicopters circling overhead for protec tion, 73 riders set off this morn ing on what must qualify as the world's most hazardous sports event: a sixday bicycle race through half the length of South Vietnam.

title: Hon Kong Likes U.S. Cigarettes
description: HONG KONG  United States cigarette manufactur ers have found an expanding market in Hong Kong, where smokers have developed taste for American brands.

title: FOURGOAL RALLY SINKS MONTREAL
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  Bobby Orr broke his season scoring record for defensemen and his Boston Bruins team mates staged a fourgoal rally in the final period tonight for a 63 National Hockey League victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: U.S. Auto Club to Keep Championship Dirt Races
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 18 (AP) The United States Auto Club's board of directors voted today to continue dirttrack races as part of its championship car series.

title: Pakistan Tries to Find Its Pace
description: KARACHI, PakistanLast year saw the installation of a national administration pledged to a more equitable distribution of the fruits of this country's notable indus trial and economic progress. This year finds the country looking forward to implemen tation of several specific promises:

title: MAKARIOS CONFERS WITH CONSTANTINE
description: ROME, Jan. 18Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cy prus, visited the selfexiled King Constantine of Greece for three hours here today amid speculation that the Greek prelate had come to urge the King to return to Greece at the request of the military regime.

title: Students and Soldiers Protest Closing of Antiwar Coffeehouse
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 18 One of the loudest, if not the largest, protest marches ever held in this city took place without incident today over the closing of the UFO, one.of the nation's first antiwar cof feehouses.

title: Rome: De Chirico, the Authenticator
description: ROMEGiorgio de Chirico, one of the undisputed founding fathers of modern painting, will be 82 next July 10. He still looks like the self portraits he did years ago: The lock of white hair across his forehead, the heavy lids over watchful eyes, the aqui line nose, the thick underlip have not changed. He is still vigor ous, vain, polem ical and sarcastic. When asked re cently who should be the next President of the Republic, he answered simply: De Chirico, who else? He lives (with his Russian wife) in silent, solitary, and some what contemptuous splen dor above the turmoil and confusion of modern Rome: His house is next door to the one in which John Keats died, in Piazza di Spagna. The noise of traffic arrives muf fled to his topfloor apart ment, whose walls are cov ered from floor to ceiling, in the fashion of other cen turies, with hundreds of paintings.

title: Malaysia Loses Momentum
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malay sia  The May 13 riots in the capital, Malaysia's worst ra cial disturbances since inde pendence, inflicted, apart from lost productivity for a few days and decreased con sumer spending for a few months, little shortterm dam age to the country's economy. They did, however, put a damper on Malaysia's in dustrialization program.

title: PICKUP AWAITED IN STEEL ORDERS
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28Steel mills are searching hard for an order improvement.

title: 2 AIRLINES REACH MERGER ACCORD
description: American Airlines, Inc., the nation's secondlargest air car rier and TransCaribbean Air ways have reached an agree ment to merge, it was an nounced here yesterday by George A. Spater, chairman of American, and O. Roy Chalk, chairman of TransCaribbean.

title: Hidden Afghan Money Now Surfacing
description: KABUL, AfghanistanAny smart Afghan who wants a loan to start a business or who wants to buy or sell some foreign currency would not dream of going to Kabul's big commercial banks. These banks are cumber some, conservative institu tions designed primarily to serve the whims of the waelthy men who founded them.

title: Film Institute Begins Showings of Silent Classics
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 It was a classic silent film, complete with longsuffering heroine, handsome prince and happy ending.

title: ROCHE FORFEITS AUSSIE NET FINAL
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 18 (Reuters)A recurring el bow injury forced Tony Roche of Australia, the world's No. 2 ranked tennis player, to with draw today from the men's singles final in the Victoria State onen chamnionshins.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18An intense prebudget struggle has been taking place within the Government over the financing devices to be used for several important programs, notably the attack on water pollution

title: HILTZIK IS VICTOR IN JUNIOR SKATING
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 Dean Hiltzik of New York gave a crisp freeskating exhibition today in winning the junior men's singles title of the East ern figureskating champion ships at the Wissahickon Skat ing Club.

title: A Decade of Disappointment for Asia
description: TOKYOThe end of the development decade of the 1960's found many Asian countries precisely where they started 10 years agoon an economic treadmill.

title: H.P. Frankel Weds Allyne S. Pollack
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 18Miss Allyne Susan Pollack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Pollack of North Woodmere, was mar ried here today in the West Hempstead Jewish Center to Harvey Paul Frankel, a jun ior at the University of Southern Illinois. The cere mony was performed by Rabbi Abraham Moseson.

title: ExU.S. Aviation Aide Is Named by Law Firm
description: The former chief of the State Department's aviation negotiations division, Elias C. Rodriguez, has joined Fisher & Gelband, a Washington law firm, which has added his name to the company's.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  B'nai B'rith, in a documented analysis of textbooks used in Soviet schools, accused Moscow today of systematically excis ing history in an attempt to make the Jew a nonperson.

description: Claude Robinson, an employe of The New York Times since 1933, died of a heart attack Saturday at Parkchester Gen eral Hospital in the Bronx. He had marked his 64th birthday the day before.

description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18(AP) Dave Lundmark of Duluth, Minn., defeated six members of the United States national team today to win the Class A division of the 65th Norge Ski Jump and the Central Division championship of the United States Ski Association.

title: Precisely Takes Laurels At Ox Ridge Horse Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 18 Mrs. Edward Bulkeley's Pre cisely stepped out of her cus tomary surroundings today and won the regular working hunter championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club indoor horse show.

description: HOUSTON, Jan. 18 Pros pects for the housing industry in 1970 were described today as dismaland getting worse by the leadership of the 51,000 member National Association of Home Builders.

title: Saturday's College Basketball
NIXON DRAFTS BILL FOR BODY TO RUN PASSENGER TRAINS
description: The Nixon Administration has decided to propose legisla tion for the creation of a semi I public corporation empowered Ito take over and modernize the nations ailing intercity pas senger train system.

title: NewHaven:Same Old Story
description: Beleaguered commuters on the New Haven Railroad, who have been promised a bright future as a result of a plan to put the railroad under state control, are almost daily strug gling to cope with a nightmare of ancient, crowded cars, fre quent delays, confusion and breakdowns.

title: Aquarius Will Star at 5 Towns Ball
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Jan. 18The tenth annual Red Feather Ball, sponsored by the Five Towns Commu nity Chest, will be held Jan. 31 at the Seawane Golf and Country Club here. Aquarius will be the theme and an un derwater world of pearls and seashells will be created for the evening.

title: Pollution is Protested By a Flotilla In Venice
description: VENICE, Italy, Jan. 18 UPI)  About 50 barges, motorboats and fishing craft but no gondolascruised through the canals of Venice today in a demonstration against pollution.

title: Indonesia Finds Stabilizing Painful
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Stabilization has been pain ful, says Dr. Widjojo Nitis astro, chairman of Indo nesia's National Planning Board, but I think that 1969 was the transition year and we may be able to start smile development in 1970.

title: U.S. Aides Reach Warsaw For Opening of China Talks
description: WARSAW, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Two State Department repre sentatives arrived here today to bolster the American team for talks with China that are to begin Tuesday.

title: Point of View
description: THE Asian region is big. The problems facing the region are big. They are many faceted. Half of the world's population lives here  hun dreds of millions of people, eager to enjoy and to get, but who have to contend with hunger and with the lack of opportunity to substantially better their lives.

title: 13th in Row for A.B.A. Rockets: Stars Top Chaparrals, 137124
description: DENVER, Jan. 18 (AP)The Denver Rockets whirled to their 13th straight victory in the American Basketball As sociation today with a 135112 decision over the Carolina Cougars before a standing room crowd of 7,014.

title: Hong Kong Woes Grow With Profits
description: HONG KONGLast year was a boom year for Hong Kong that brought big prof its to the colony's basic manufacturing industries and an increased interest from abroad in its investment po tential. But fears were ex pressed that the boom was generating side effects that could dampen future invest ment in this British Crown Colony.

title: Singapore: Housing Burgeons
description: SINGAPOREEvery 35 minutes last year a new public housing unit was completed in Singapore. Thirty seven hotels with 11,000 rooms are un der construction.

title: Gravediggers Picket Across From St. Patrick's
description: About 100 striking grave diggers and members of their families picketed across the street from St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to urge that officials of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York lead the way toward settlement of the weekold walkout.

title: Election to Decide Ceylon's Direction
