description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive ses sion as the trading volume drooped sharply.

title: UTILITY REGISTERS GAIN IN EARNINGS
description: The Southern Company and operating subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net in come of $94million, or $1.82 a share, for 1969. This compared with $80.4million, or $1.63 a share, in 1968.

title: TV Review
description: THE Canadian Broadcasting Corporation sent a report er and camera crew to Com munist China during last fall's trade fair in Canton. They brought home the fa miliar propaganda film, as Chinese guides decided what could be photographed. In the documentary, seen last night on Channel 13, Bill Cunningham acknowledged he had been in China for less than two weeks, and always stressed that he was under censorship wraps.

title: Paris Urban Planners Rally to Save Gare d'Orsay
description: PARIS, Jan. 20  Defend ers of French scenery are undertaking an 11thhour ef fort to save the Gare d'Orsay, which dominates the Left Bank of the Seine opposite the Louvre. The ornate railroad station, described by some architects as a flawed mas terpiece of the belle poque and by others as an ugly example of 1900 academic style, is slated to be replaced by the Palais d'Orsay, a de luxe hotel in Hilton moclerne.

title: David D. Thomas Resigns As Deputy Chief of F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  David D. Thomas announced his resignation and retirement today as deputy administrator of the Federal Aviation Admin istration, effective Feb. 15.

title: LEBANON TO POLICE 15 REFUGEE CAMPS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 19 Interior Minister Kamal Jum blatt indicated today that Leb anese forces would return to refugee camps to maintain law and order there.

title: Galley Silent on Charges of PreSongmy Murder
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 19  First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with killing 109 Vietnamese men, women and children at Songmy, de clined to testify today at a hearing on an additional charge that he murdered a Vietnamese civilian about six weeks prior to the alleged Sonamy action.

title: Washington Record
Beame Names Executives To Advise City on Investing
description: Contraller Abraham D. Beame yesterday announced the ap pointment of six banking and insurance executives to advise the city on investment policy and debt management.

title: Education Group Asks Student Deferment Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)The American Council on Education, representing the nations major institu tions of higher learning, rec ommended today that no further 2S draft deferments be granted for college stu dents.

title: Windows Blown Out of Plant In Jersey in an Explosion
description: KEARNY, N. J., Jan. 19A rollingmill furnace exploded here early today forcing tons of steel through a 40foothigh roof and blowing out the fac tory's steel window frames.

title: Tricia Nixon is FIu Victim
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Tricia Nixon said today she was well on the road to re covery after a weeklong bout with influenza. The President's 23yearold daughter was being treated at the White House by Dr. Walter Tkach, Mr. Nixon's personal physician, it was dis closed today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Theater
Mrs. Court to Head Field of 10 In $5,000 Indoor Tennis Here
description: Ten of the world's best women tennis players, who have graced courts all over the world, are going to compete at one of the strangest places they've ever been for a tour nament  the third floor of the Grand Central Terminal building here.

title: The Congo People's Republic
description: A decade or so ago, when the Cold War in Africa was at its height, the announcement that an African state had proclaimed itself a people's republic, adopted MarxismLeninism as its official creed, and made the red flag its banner would have created a worldwide furor. But a few days ago the news from Brazzaville of the formation there of the People's Republic of the Congo seems to have provoked mainly yawns. There has been neither celebration in Moscow or Peking, nor panic in Washington or London or Paris.

title: Lifesaver for Welfare
description: The most creative proposal in the first year of the Nixon Administration was the President's program for redeeming the colossal failure that public wel fare has become. It will be a national tragedy if elec tionyear politics prevents Congress from acting on the Nixon plan at this session.

title: Indian Nuclear Power Plant Is Dedicated by Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELPHI, Jan. 19Prime Minister Indira Gandhi dedi cated today India's first nuclear power plantthe largest inin Asia.

title: Chamberlain to Rejoin Lakers Early in March
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (UPI)Wilt Chamberlain will rejoin the Los Angeles Lak ers before the regular season ends, Dick White, a spokes man for the National Basket ball Association Club, said today.

title: 19 Reported Injured as Okinawan Workers Strike Against U.S. Bases
description: NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 19 (AP)More than 7,000 Oki nawan workers began a scheduled fiveday strike at United States military bases today, and five Americans and 14 Okinawans were re ported injured in picket line incidents.

title: Executives Move To New Top Posts
description: Three senior corporate exec utives moved to get new jobs for themselves yesterday.

title: BOARD OF AIR WEST MEETS TOMORROW
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP)Air West, Inc., a fi nancially troubled airline seek ing to complete its sale to Howard Hughes, announced to day its directors would meet Wednesday.

title: F. D. A. Bids Doctors Tell Of Risks in Birth Pill Use
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Food and Drug Administra tion urged the nation's doctors today to pay close attention to the risks involved in the use of birth control pills and explain to their patients the potential hazards of the pills.

title: $7.3BILLION STATE BUDGET, WITHOUT INCREASE IN TAX, IS ASKED BY ROCKEFELLER
description: ALBANY, Jan. 19Governor Rockefeller called today for an electionyear budget of nearly, $7.3billion that he described as a socially responsive and fiscally responsible program that could be financed without increasing state taxes.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
UNIONIST DERIDES RACKETS CHARGE
description: A longpending complaint by a Brooklyn dock worker that he was once asked to join a so called Cosa Nostra family and lost his job after he wouldn't do so was reported yesterday to be close to a decision by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Canada Reports Fund Flow
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 19 (Canadian Press)There was a net inflow of $25,578,000 into Canada in October in trading in outstand ing Canadian and foreign secu rities, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. For the first 10 months of 1969, the net inflow of such funds was $114,600,000.

title: DEANS' DISMISSAL URGED IN SUFFOLK
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 19 A Suffolk grand jury recom mended in a report made pub lic today that the dean of stu dents and an assistant dean at the State University Center at Stony Brook be dismissed for neglecting to enforce univer sity rules governing the use of drugs on the campus.

title: ARMCO LIFTS PRICE FOR SHEET STEEL
description: The Armco Steel Corporation announced increases of about 3 per cent yesterday on basic prices of sheet products used in automobiles, appliances and other consumer durables.

title: California Republican, a Former Congressman, Replaces Lapin
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)  President Nixon named Al lan Oakley Hunter, former Re publican Congressman from Fresno, Calif., today as presi dent of the Federal National Mortgage Association.

title: A Correction
description: Mrs. Phyllis Walter Goodhart Gordan, who was elected member of the board of trustees of the New York Public Library, was incorrectly identified as having been curator of the library's Berg Collection from 1940 to 1968 in a story in Fri day's New York Times. That position had been held by Mrs. Gordan's late husband.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN I.B.M. set a record at 387 on Friday, trad ers must have had a rather heady notion of the kind of earnings the giant computer company was going to show for 1969.

title: PIPELINE PROJECT FALTERS IN ALASKA
description: ANCHORAGE, Jan. 19 (Reu ters)The TransAlaska Pipe line System, the organization that planned to build an oil pipeline from Prudhoe Bay in Alaska to Valdez in that state, said today that bids for con struction of the project were unacceptable and that the pro gram was being delayed for the time being.

title: WeekLong Auction To Help Channel 13
description: Channel 13 will hold a weeklong auction on the air in June to raise funds for next season's programing.

title: Oil Quota Report Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI)  The report by President Nixon's Cabinetlevel task force on oilimport quotas will be delayed until late this month or early February, the White House announced today. No reason was given. Previously, it had been indicated that the findings would be ready some time after last Thursday.

title: Lebanon and the Arab Dilemma
description: The Government of Lebanon faces a nearly hope less choice as it tries to placate militant Palestinian guerrillas and their followers while maintaining suffi cient control over its vulnerable borders to avert disastrous clash with Israel. The prospects are dim for the continuing success of this desperate balancing act, at which the Lebanese have been adept in the past.

title: DRAFT OF CRITICS OF WAR IS CURBED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The Supreme Court ruled to day that the Selective Service System lacks the legal power to accelerate the induction of young men who turn in their draft cards to protest the Viet nam war.

title: Observer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Sounds of the sky, overheard when the jets were getting big ger than ever:

title: Books of The Times
description: JOHN DEMOS has not written a strident book. He seeks in the past neither sanctions for what we do now, nor symptoms of a cultural terminal disease about which to attitudinize. But The Little Commonwealth is nonetheless provoca tive, and Mr. Demos, assistant professor of history at Brandeis University, is more con wincing in his graceful way than all those rhapso dists who discover absolute truth ev ery morning at breakfast and are hungry again by, teatime. His essay is ambitious with out really seeming so: a study of how the idea and the function of the family has changed in the 300 years from Plymouth Col ony to the Ameri can present; a ten tative reinterpreta tion of 17thcen Plymouth Governor tury Puritan psychology; a meditation on the historian as detective (pondering the artifacts) and as artist (reinventing the past as it was probably perceived by those who lived it).

title: Couple Fights Children's Return To Parents Who Starved Sister
description: A Westchester couple who fear their two foster children will be returned to their natural parents  a man and woman previously convicted in the starvation death of a third child  went to the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday in an effort to retain custody.

title: SENATOR CLARIFIES HIS VIEW ON OSWALD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said today he never believed that Lee Harvey Oswald assassinated President Kennedy without at least some encouragement from others.

title: Whales' Echo Detector May Falter Near Shore
description: The mass beaching of whales at Fort Pierce, Fla., on Jan. 10 may have come about be cause the echoranging equip ment of the animals could not detect a shelving shore.

title: PANAMA REACHES PIPELINE ACCORD
description: PANAMA, Jan. 19The Pan amanian Government signed to day an agreement with the Brit ishGormanItalian consortium to build a wholly Panamanian owned oil pipeline across the Isthmus of Panama which, ac cording to its promoters, will compete with the Panama Canal.

title: N.B.A. DISMISSES TALKS OF MERGER
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 Two views of what constitutes priority clashed today at the National Basketball Associa tion's business meeting, and the result was a strong statement against accommodation with the American Basketball Associa tion and a delay in adding teams to the N.B.A.

title: Morgana King Charms Her Audience With Style
description: In the field of popular music where a distinctive style often means little more than the use of a few set musical or oral manner isms, Morgana King, who is singing at the Rainbow Grill, has carved out an area that is completely her own.

title: B'nai B'rith Assails U.S. Mideast Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The B'nai B'rith Board of Governors, the policymaking body of the 500,000member Jewish organ ization, charged today that American prestige and credibil ity had been poorly served by the State Department's policy of proposing concessions while seeking a peace formula for the Middle East.

title: Darien Honors MacPhail
description: Larry MacPhail former presi dent of the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Yankees, was honored last night at a dinner given by the Darien Old Timers Athletic Ass??tion in Darien, Conn.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW DOWNTURN
Case of the Switched Trotters Stirs Racing Circles in France
description: PARIS, Jan. 19  French racing inspectors are investi gating the strange case of a suspected reverse ringer in a trotting race at Vincennes.

title: I.B.M. SLIDES 19 AS STOCKS DROOP
description: I.B.M. held center stage in Wall Street yesterday as its stock tumbled 19 points to 350 in response to the latest earnings report and sent trem ors into both the glamour and bluechip sectors of the market.

title: Article 1  No Title
Dr. James B. Donovan, 53, Dies; Lawyer Arranged Spy Exchange
description: Dr. James Britt Donovan, the lawyer and educator who ar ranged the trade of a Soviet spy for the U2 pilot Francis Gary Powers and negotiated the ransom of prisoners taken by Cuba in the Bay of Pigs invasion, died early yesterday. He was 53 years old.

title: MasseyFerguson Denies Canadian Tractor Charge
description: MasseyFerguson, Ltd., de nied yesterday that it was mak ing handsome profits from the sale of farm machinery in Canada and added that it would welcome discussions with the Canadian Government about pricing policies.

title: SelfRegulation by Funds Rejected by S.E.C. Head
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Securities and Exchange Com mission has apparently closed the door against the type of selfregulation of mutual fund fees that was recently proposed to Congress by the fund in dustry's trade organization, the Investment Company Institute.

title: SIMON KOVAR
description: ENCINO, Calif., Jan. 19  Simon Kovar, second bassoonist with the New York Philhar monic from 1923 to 1949, died at his home here on Saturday of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.

title: Injured Driver's Condition Remains Extremely Critical
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI)Jim Cook remained in extremely critical condition to day following his spectacular accident yesterday in the Motor Trend 500 at the Riverside In ternational Raceway.

title: ANDERSON TO LEAD BUSINESS ARTS AID
description: Robert O. Anderson, a petrol eum executive, rancher and civ ic leader, was elected last night chairman of the Business Committee of the Arts at its third annual meeting at the Mu seum of Modern Art. He suc ceeds C. Douglas Dillon, who has been chairman since the committee, an organization of prominent business leaders set up to stimulate corporate in volvement in the arts, was formed in 1967.

title: ALFRED SONDER
description: Alfred Sonder, a director of Roehrenlager, Mannheim, A. G., a West German steel and tub ing concern, died of cancer at Doctors Hospital here Sunday. He was 74 years old and lived at 180 East End Avenue.

title: Jean O'Connor Is Future Bride
description: Miss Jean Katherine O'Con nor, who is on the financial relations staff of Ruder & Finn, Inc., public relations concern, and La Rue Apple gate, vice president in charge of press relations and publi cations for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., plan to be married at the Unitarian Church of All Souls here on Feb. 14.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CONNECTICUT'S Board of Fisheries and Game is reminding anglers that many of the state's lakes and ponds are open to the taking of all species of fish through ice until Feb. 22.

title: GUERIN BEMOANS THURMOND LOSS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 On the eve of the National Basketball Association's 20th annual AllStar game, the con versation among the arriving players, coaches and front of fice officials was predominant ly about a man who will not play.

title: Caballe Concert Deferred
description: The American Opera Society has postponed its orchestral concert featuring Montserrat Caballe, soprano, from Feb. 6 to March 19 in Carnegie Hall. Miss Caballe sustained serious knee injuries when she fell during a performance of Bel lini's Norma at the Teatro del Liceo in Barcelona last week.

title: Mets Name Scheffing Vice President, General Manager to Succeed Murphy
description: Bob Scheffing, onetime catcher and manager in the major leagues, was named vice president and general manager of the world champion New York Mets yesterday.

title: Auto Repair Code Urged
description: DETROIT, Jan. 19 (UPI) Senator Philip A. Hart, Demo crat of Michigan, called today for Government licensing of auto repair shops and coverage of used cars under Federal auto ??

title: U.S. IS CHALLENGED ONTEXTILES ACCORD
description: BRUSSELS, Tuesday, Jan. 20 (Reuters)The European Com mon Market Executive Com mission directly challenged to day the United States Govern ment's view that an interna tional accord is needed to limit certain textile exports to the United States.

title: Ghetto Experience Is Subject of Dance By Fred Benjamin
description: The Fred Benjamin Dance Company has a slick perform ing panache, at least three firstrate dancers, including Mr. Benjamin and an almost insup portable load of soapopera choreography.

title: Leftist Jailed in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Jan. 19 (Reuters) A former leftwing student leader was given a 10month jail sentence today for having ordered six other students to invade a United States Army hospital in March, 1968. The court reserved judgment on six other radicals who led demonstrations protesting the opening of the hospital, at Camp Oji in Tokyo's northern suburbs, for treatment of wounded United States service men from Vietnam. Several hundred persons were injured in the rioting.

title: STRIKERS ARRESTED BLOCKING HEARSES
description: Thirteen striking gravedig gers were arrested yesterday when they tried to prevent hearses from entering the Ro man Catholic Calvery Ceme tery in Long Island City, Queens.

title: 3 Copter Crewmen Rescued After Evading Foe 3 Days
description: I SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 (AP)A rescue helicopter has located three American helicopter crewmen who had evaded the enemy for three days and lifted them to safety only 50 feet from a North Viet namese patrol, the United States Army announced today.

title: Marshal Bars Boy, 14, From School
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 19 (AP)A 14yearold boy was taken into custody by a Unit ed States marshal today after a Federal judge's order that he not attend his neighbor hood school was defied.

title: Fathers of Hair Sing at Cradle
description: Messrs. Ragni, Rado and MacDermot, aided by 19 members of the Broadway company, performed about a dozen of the musical numbers in the highceilinged Anspacher Theater, one of the playhouses in the New York Shakespeare's Public Theater at 425 Lafayette Street, where Hair originally opened in October, 1967.

title: Popi's Producer Signs to Make 5 More Films to Cost $7Million
description: Herbert B. Leonard, the pro ducer who made his movie I debut last year with the com edydrama, Popi, starring Alan Arkin, will film three addi tional features and two movies for television, at a cost of about $7million. The first two films, Mr. Leonard said, will be made for United Artists, which sponsored Popi.

title: No Hint of Abuse of Biafrans, Says Thant in Lagos
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 19  Secretary General Thant of the United Nations left Lagos for Paris today, apparently satis fied after a day in Nigeria that the human distress in the terri tory that had been Biafra was not so serious as it had some times been nainted.

title: CATERPILLAR. CO. LAGS IN QUARTER
Myrna Margulies Planning Nuptials
description: The engagement of Miss Myrna Debra Margulies to William Arthur Breitbart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Breitbart of New Rochelle, N. Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Margulies of New York.

title: Congress Learns Inflation Ranks As the Voters' Chief Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Congress came back to the Capitol today with the state of the nation's economy as its chief concern.

title: D. C. Dobson Fiance Of Miss Marinelli
description: BRIDGEWATER, N. J., Jan. 19Miss Barbara R. Marinelli and Douglas Chip man Dobson plan to be mar ried in April. Their engage ment has been announced by the future bride's parents, Frank Marinelli, corporate controller of the Fedders Corporation in Edison, and Mrs. Marinelli. Mr. Dobson is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Her man S. Dobson of North Windham. Me.

title: Accountants Nominate
description: Ettore Barbatelli, president and chief executive officer of the Amercian Appraisal Com pany, has been nominated as president of the National Asso ciation of Accountants for the fiscal year 1970, starting July 1. He is expected to be elected at the annual national confer ence of the association in Min neapolis in June.

title: Supreme Court Choice
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 19G. (for George) Har rold Carswell lives in a white brick house with green shut ters on the banks of a five milelong lake north of Tal lahassee. The house has a 10acre garden around it, with roses, camellias, shrubs, trees and grass where he sometimes putters around. Judge Carswell was sit ting at home at 1:15 P.M. today fending off a houseful of relatives when President Nixon called him and told him he had been nominated to the Supreme Court. It was the first time that Judge Carswell, who is 50yearold Federal Appeals Court Judge, had ever talked to Mr. Nixon.

title: Credit Cards Revised
description: Master Charge credit card holders of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company are getting slightly revised cards to reduce the likelihood of im proper use, the bank said yes terday. Instead of a date of ex piration, as before, the new cards will have both a date when the card becomes effec tive and the date of expiration. After the cards are mailed out, a followup letter will inform the recipient he had been sent a new card. If he has not re ceived it, he will be advised to notify the bank so that the card may he canceled.

title: 3 Plane Passengers Fined After Gander Disturbance
description: GANDER, Newfoundland, Jan. 20 (AP)Three passengers were removed from a Trans World Airlines plane at Gan der International Airport aft er creating a disturbance and were convicted today. Each was fined the maximum amount for the offense, $50, or 14 days in jail. They paid the fines and were expected to leave by Air Canada for New York.

title: Mafioso and His Son Convicted of Bribery In Trucking of Mail
description: A reputed Mafia figure, John A. Masiello, and his 23yearold son, John Jr., both of Yonkers, were convicted last night of bribing postal officials who supervised mail trucking con tracts in New York.

title: As Nixon Begins 2d Year, Some Officials of Capital Fear Crime Is Winning Control of Parts of the City
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20  When President Nixon moved into the White House a year ago this week, he saw this city as an illusiongrand but also forbidding.

title: RATIFICATION VOTES IN TRADES OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) A Presidential commission recommended today that con struction workers give up ratifi cation votes and, instead, elect union negotiators with binding power to negotiate labor con tracts.

title: LACEY SEEKS AID OF MORE JUDGES,
description: NEWARK, Jan. 20  United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey appealed today for more judicial manpower to ease a large backlog of criminal cases that has arisen partly because of the Federal investigation of municipal crime and corruption.

title: DempseyTegeler Gets Loan; 33 of Its 60 Branches to Close
description: Another major Wall Street brokerage house, Dempsey Tegeler & Co., Inc., has been forced by operational difficulties to go bed and the financial community for a major infusion of capital. It was disclosed yesterday that John M. King, chairman of the King Resourc es Company, had arranged to lend the firm stock worth between $5million and $10 million to help it meet the requirements of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: WALTER SPAHR, 78, ECONOMIST, DEAD
description: Walter E. Spahr, chairman of the department of economics Of New York University from 1927 to 1956, died Monday, ap parently of a heart attack. Dr. Spahr, who was 78 years old, was stricken on the 28th Street station of the BMT.

title: Thieu's Army Shifts
description: President Thieu's replacement of three major tac tical commanders in the Mekong Delta brings critical ly needed changes in the South Vietnamese Army.

title: Ignorance of a Law Wins Acquittal for Reputed Mafia Figure
description: The United States Court of Appeals yesterday punctured the adage that ignorance of the law is no excuse.

title: Meteorite Is Traced to Asteroid Belt
description: For what is believed to be only the second time in the history of astronomical obser vations, it has been possible, from a quick succession of photographs, to determine the orbit of a meteorite.

title: Law on Possession of Heroin Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Supreme Court upheld today a 61yearold Federal law that makes possession of heroin sufficient evidence of illegal importation of the drug.

title: Market Place: Glamour Stocks And PE Ratios
description: IT seems incredible to some thoughtful Wall Streeters that a few stocks are draw ing hordes of investors and are selling at soaring price earnings multiples when the market generally is in a mal aise.

title: BANKS PERMITTED TO LIFT THE RATES THEY PAY SAVERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20  The Federal Reserve Board an nounced today sizable increases in the interest rates the com mercial banks can pay to savers both consumer type savers and large corporate depositors.

title: Panther Lawyer Obtains a Writ Seeking Removal of Trial Judge
description: A lawyer's motion that contended the District Attor ney's office handpicked a judge to hear almost all Black Panther cases led yes terday to an order directing State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh to show cause why he should not be removed from the trial of 16 Black Pan thers on bomb conspiracy charges.

title: $3.5Million Raceway Slated for Maryland
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 A new road course, con ceived to bring majorleague road racing to the Northeast Corridor and protected from competition by an unusual franchising arrangement, was announced today. The $3.5 million facility, named Chesa peake International Raceway, will be built at Elkton, Md., mid way between Philadelphia and Baltimore. I t s first race is scheduled for May 2, 1971. The anouncement was made at a reception held by the raceway at the Warwick Hotel.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN ON LONDON BOARD
Marciano's Widow Stirred By Cheers and Realism
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 20 (AP) Barbara Marciano, widow of Rocky Marciano, watched her husband knock out Cassius Clay tonight in a computerized fight and said, I was nervous just like I used to be.

title: Dividends Announced
description: STOCK

title: Revision of Hudson Power Link At Stony Point Wins Approval
description: NEW CITY, N.Y. Jan. 20 (AP) The Hudson River Valley Commission announced today that it found no unreasonably adverse effect in the revised plans of Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., for a 345,000 volt transmission line at Stony Point, N.Y.

title: 7 PLEAD GUILTY IN CAMPUS SITIN
description: Seven persons pleaded guilty in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday to the illegal occu pation of a student center on the City College campus early on Nov: 7, 1968, and were sentenced to pay $25 fines or to serve five days in jail.

title: Gonzales Heads Old Pros in Tennis Here Tonight
description: Three months ago, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales announced his retirement from competi tive tennis, but tonight he will return to Madison Square Garden, one of his favorite stages, for its sixth annual invitation tournament.

title: London Council Asks Barrier Against Thames Flood
description: LONDON, Jan. 20The Gov ernment was urged today by the Greater London Council to pro tect London from possible river flooding by financing a $120 million moveable tidecontrol barrier across the Thames.

title: A South African Sees Emergence of Black Power
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 20  There are be ginnings of a black power feeling in South Africa, accord ling to Fred Van Wyk, incoming director of the South African Institute of Race Relations, a private institution.

title: Nigeria Scatters SafeConduct Passes
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 20  Nigerian planes dropped mil lions of safeconduct passes into the forested hills of the former secessionist region of Biafra and into the swamps west of the Niger River today to persuade Biafran soldiers and civilians to leave their hiding places.

title: Carswell's Credo Is Restraint
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Judge G. Harrold Carswell President Nixon's new nominee to the Supreme Court, has a virtually unblemished record as the type of strict construc tionist that Mr. Nixon prom ised to appoint when he cam paigned for the Presidency.

title: Detectives Renew Drive To Win Job Tenure Here
description: Defeated last month by Mayo Lindsay's veto, the proposal to give tenure to detectives is being pressed anew by the De tectives Endowment Association of New York.

title: BOURGEOIS IDEAS ARE LAID TO DUBCEK
description: VIENNA, Jan. 20  A hard line member of the present Communist leadership in Czechoslovakia, Alois Indra, de nounced Alexander Dubeek to day as unstable ideologically with marked inclination toward petit bourgeois ideas.

title: The Black Theatergoer: Who Is He?
description: The average Broadway theatergoer is white. He is an educated man or woman about 37 years old with a family income of $18, 000 a year, a home or apart ment owner with at least one car (bought new). He prefers Scotch, dines out frequently and owns stocks, bonds or mutual funds.

title: Albania Signs New Trade Pact With China and Condemns U.S.
description: VIENNA, Jan. 20  Albania announced today the signing of a new trade an I financial accord with Communist China that would establish even closer ties between the two countries.

title: Howe and Hull Lead East AllStars to 41 Hockey Victory
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (AP) Gordie Howe and Bobby Hull scored a goal apiece and the East Division routed the West, 41, tonight in the National Hockey League AllStar game.

title: Art Venture Planned
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., which already is engaged in a variety of enter prises, yesterday further broad ened its operations by enter ing the art reproduction busi ness.

title: Two New Principals Dance in Serenade With the City Ballet
description: Serenade, given last night by the New York City Ballet with two new principals, Karin von Aroldingen and Peter Mar tins, was the first ballet choreo graphed by George Balanchine in this country.

title: Jackie Robinson Scores Nixon On Black Capitalism Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Jackie Robinson praised the franchise business today as a potential solution to the prob lems of black capitalism, but he severely criticized President Nixon's efforts in the field.

title: Bridge: Dallas Aces Off to a Big Lead In Series With Sharif's Circus
description: THE Dallas Aces, designated representatives of the United States in this year's world team championship in Stockholm in June, built up a substantial lead in the first stage of a marathon match against Omar Sharif's Circus, a group of European stars.

title: Great Neck FarmAnimal Ban Prompts Suit
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Jan. 20  In this affluent suburban community a man's home may be his castle but apparently not his farm.

title: Trial Begins for Policemen Charged in Detroit Motel Beatings
description: FLINT, Mich., Jan. 20The Algiers Motel incident was re opened here today as three Detroit policemen and a pri vate guard went on trial in Federal court in connection with the beating of eight Negro youths and two young white women in the motel annex dur ing the Detroit riots of 1967.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS MAKE A REBOUND
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Mail Robbery Suspect Held
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP)Calvin Jones, a 22year old Washington, D.C., man, was arrested in an apartment here yesterday by postal inspectors and policemen here on charges, stemming from the armed hi jacking of a mail truck laden with $382.000 in old currency Dec. 23, the police said today. Three persons were earlier arrested in Washington on charges of possessing currency stolen in the holdup the largest such robbery in the nation's capital.

title: Year Out of White House, a Texas Rancher Is Content
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Jan. 20 The easy life he never had before holds continued satisfac tion for former President Lyn don B. Johnson at his beloved LBJ Ranch on the Pedernales River.

title: 2 HELD WITH TRUCK CARRYING DYNAMITE
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 20 (AP)Po lice and Treasury Department agents arrested two young men tonight and seized 40 cases of dynamite, which they said was apparently destined for Cuban exile terrorists in New York City.

title: Ireland Lifts Industrial Exports
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 20Eleven yearsago, when Ireland's plan for economic development wo, started, agriculture was pr me source of export earnings. Today, industrial exports account for more than onehalf of the Repub lie's external trade, with manufacturers the largest employers.

title: City Pays a Record 7.31% On Its Construction Bonds
description: The city had to pay 7.31 per cent interestits highest everin selling $176,860,000 worth of bonds yesterday for public improvements. The city's total interest cost over the average 6year life of the taxexempt bonds will be $82.8million. That means the city will be paying $1.47 for each $1 borrowed.

title: Manufacturers Elects Board Vice Chairman
description: The election of John F. McGillicuddy as a director and a vice chairman of the board of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company was announced yesterday. He will succeed Eugene S. Northrop, vice chairman, upon his retire ment June 1.

title: Pressure for PollutionFree Cars Is Increasing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Administration, Congress, state governments and public opinion are all increasing pres sure on the auto industry to build pollutionfree cars.

title: SILVER FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Silver futures prices dipped yesterday in moderate trading with the nearby January con tract dropping to $1.88 an ounce from $1.90 the day be fore.

title: Don'tGiveaDamn Budget ...
description: Governor Rockefeller's proposed $7.3billion budget for New York State is both too large and too small too large in its reliance on bonded debt and too small in its provision for the desperate needs of urban areas. It is at once an underfunded and recklessly expensive document that deprives cities and feeds the fires of inflation. It is a notax budget, a spendbig budget, an electionyear budget.

title: ALIOTO AND 2 SUED ON $2MILLION FEE
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 20  Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Fran cisco and two former Wash ington state officia's were sue today by the state and 12 mmuni cipalities and utilities for $2, 321,308.0,5 that the plaintiffs said the three men conspired to share illegally.

title: CLAY'S RESPONSE: CAN'T WIN 'EM ALL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP)It takes a good cham pion to lose like that, said Cassius Clay as he watched himself knocked out by Rocky Marciano tonight in their com puterized fight.

title: Rocky Suffers a Knockdown, Scores 3 in Computer Bout
description: Undefeated by the living, Cassius Clay lost his heavy weight title to a dead man last night.

title: MICH. STATE FIVE TOPS NOTRE DAME
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 20 (AP)Ralph Simpson's 35 points led Michigan State to an upset 8582 basketball victory, over Notre Dame tonight.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Real Heart of Darkness
description: PARIS Nigeria's civil war was a second major battle in the struggle to prevent all Africa from dissolving into unmanage able tribal chaos. It was grue some, brutal and crippled devel opment of the continent's most promising black state. It was also inevitable.

title: Sports of The Times
description: WHEN Bob Scheffing was only 24 years old he was appointed player manager of a minor league team in the St. Louis Cardinal chain. The man who picked him was Branch Rickey and it is doubtful whether baseball ever had more perceptive judge of men and talent than the now legendary Mahatma. That early endorsement by the Top Branch has to be recognized as a high testimonial to Scheffing's abilities.

title: Interest Levels on Bonds Tested in Heavy Volume
description: With a massive volume of Federal, municipal and corporate financing taking yester day, the credit markets tested a wide range of interest rates levels.

title: Supreme Court Ruling
description: WAS HINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)  The Supreme Court ruled today that minority stock holders can bring damage suits based on illegal proxy solici tation material promoting a merger without first proving that the proxy statement in duced the merger.

title: Queens Woman Dies in Fire
description: A 54 year  old woman died early this morning in a fire in her twostory brick house at 5213 72d Place, Maspeth, Fire men found the victim, Mrs, Marry Turner on the first floor and rescued her hushand, Wil liam Turner, from the second ??

title: Chaparrals Trounce Stars With Late Surge, 141119
description: DALLAS, Jan. 20 (AP)The Dallas Chaparrals scored 17 consecutive points in the third quarter tonight and went on to rout the Los Angeles Stars, 141119, in a battle for third place in the American Basket ball Association's Western Di vision.

title: Sonny, Lead Horse at Westbury, Answers the Call to Retirement
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 20 Sonny, the 25yearold white gelding who has heard the marshal's call more than any other horse at Roosevelt Raceway, was retired at the track tonight in a driving snow.

title: U.S. Voices Concern Over Intensity of Laos War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The United States expressed con ern today over the rising level of fighting in Laos. A State Department spokesman said it appeared that North Vietnam might be preparing to launch a dry season offen sive there.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Appropriations Bill
Susan E. Greenberg Is Affianced
description: Miss Susan Ellen Green berg, who is studying for a Ph.D. at Teachers College of Columbia University, plans to be married in April to Dr. Arnold L. Gordon, who has a Ph.D. in oceanography from Columbia.

title: Old and New Congressional Districts in the Metropolitan Area Are Compares
SURVEY SEES BIAS IN BROADCASTING
description: A Fordham University Con ference on Equal Opportunities in Broadcasting has conclud ed, as have similar conferences before, that television and radio as industries discriminate against blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: No. 60 Set as Limit For February Draft
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The Selective Service System issued instructions to draft boards to day not to order for induction next month men whose lottery number is above 60.

title: Hockey Pros Seek Voice on Tourneys
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (Canadian Press)The players want an equal voice with club owners in any decisions regarding pro posed international tourna ments, the National Hockey League Players' Association said today.

title: EXSHORTSTOP, 52, GETS 232 BALLOTS
description: Lou Boudreau, the former boy manager of the Cleve land Indians, became the 114th member of baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday.

title: M'GOVERN OFFERS PLAN ON POVERTY
description: Senator George S. McGovern proposed last night that the Federal Government give par ents an allowance of $50 to $65 a month for each child in an attempt to eliminate poverty.

title: Computer Makes Debut
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 20 (UPI) The Cincinnati Milling Ma chine Company, a machine tool builder, introduced today two low  cost, microprogramable real  time computer models, marking the company's entry into this computer field. One model is specifically designed for specific applications and the other for general purpose operations.

title: From Obscure to Unknown
description: In naming Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court, President Nixon has displayed more glaringly than ever a talent for seeking out undistinguished candidates for the high bench.

title: Aide Ousted by Air Force Hired by Congress Group
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, an nounced today that A. E. Fitz gerald, the Pentagon cost ex pert dismissed by the Air Force, had been hired as consultant to the SenateHouse Economic Commitee.

title: JAPAN ASKS DATA ON TEXTILE FLOW
description: TOKYO, Jan. 20 (UPI)  Kiiohi Miyazawa, the new Min ister of International Trade and Industry, said today there would be no immediate resumption of the deadlocked United States Japan textiles talks unless Washington accepts Japan's basic thinking on the matter.

title: George M. Humphrey, 79, Dies; Former Secretary of Treasury
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP) George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisen hower Administration from 1953 to 1957, died tonight in University Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Miss Greenwood Plans To Wed in the Summer
description: GLADWYNE, Pa., Jan. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Greenwood have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Green wood, to James Gordon Har rison. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Harrison of New York and Dorset. Vt. The wedding is planned for the summer.

title: Private Bus Lines Request Approval Of a 30Cent Fare
description: Eight private bus companies operating in the city will seek approval of a 30cent fare in place of their current 20cent rate at a hearing tomorrow be fore the Board of Estimate at City Hall.

title: DELAY IS REJECTED IN HEARING ON EGGS
description: Judge Dudley B. Bonsai of the United States District Court refused yesterday to delay for more than a day a hearing on a request for a preliminary in junction against John P. Bauer and Bauer International, im porters, for issuing certain statements about the purchase and shipment of about 425,000 cases of Spanish eggs.

title: Chicago Suburban Realtors Agree to Bar Discrimination
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP)An association of Chicago subur ban real estate brokers, accused in a Government suit of prac ticing racial discrimination, agreed today to sell or rent homes to prospective buyers regardless of race.

title: . . . and Federal Credibility
description: A standard topic of economic debate for many years has been whether the Federal Reserve is too inde pendent of the Administration. With the accession Dr. Arthur F. Burns to the chairmanship of the nation's central bank, the question may well be whether the Administration is sufficiently independent of the Fed.

title: Giants Sign Five Players
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (AP)The San Francisco Giants announced the signing today of four established players Mike McCormick, Jim Hart, Ron Hunt and Hal Lanierand a minorleague outfielder, Bernie Williams.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Carol Fialkov To Be a Bride
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Herman Fial kov have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Fran Fialkov, to Richard Eric Kopelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Kopelman of Roslyn Heights.

title: Plan to Raise Tax For Social Security In'71 Reported Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) President Nixon plans to ask Congress for higher Social Se curity taxes next year by rais ing the taxable wage base from $7,800 to $9,000, Administra tion sources said today. One of every five workers would be affected.

title: Attempt To Spin Bowie Victor; Francinette Scores by a Head
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 20 (AP) John A. Manfuso's Attempt To Spin won the Glenwood Purse; at Bowie race course today just before the track management called off the final two races of the ninerace program be cause of snow.

title: Thant, in Paris, Says Saigon Needs BroadBased Regime
description: PARIS, Jan. 20 (AP)Secre tary General Thant of the Unit ed Nations said today that South Vietnam's top priority was a broadbased govern ment. He was immediately ac cused by Saigon's peacetalk team of meddling.

title: Complacency Termed Barrier to Ecumensism
description: LONDON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The Archbishop of Canter bury, Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, said today that com placency was sweeping over the ecumenical movement.

title: VIKINGS WILL KEEP CUOZZO AS BACKUP
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 20 (AP)The Minnesota Vik ings will keep Gary Cuozzo, their backup quarterback, Gen eral Manager Jim Finks said to day.

title: Canadians Value Old Bottles
description: DARTMOUTH, Nova Scotia (Canadian Press)The price on old bottles has gone up here now that they have become col lectors' items. The Acadia Bot tle Club, in a newsletter, sug gests that people should study glass and bottles to make sure they are old before buying.

title: ASSURANCE GIVEN TO HOMEBUILDERS
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 20  The Federal Government, in a strong bid to draw homebuild ers into the lowcost housing market, assured builders today that public funds were now available to facilitate construc tion of 400,000 publicly as sisted dwelling units.

title: SOVIET TRIAL HINTED FOR 3 PROTESTERS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20Pravda, the Communist party news paper, today denounced as political provocateurs three young foreigners who staged public demonstrations in sup port of Soviet dissidents here last weekend. Pravda said that it was assumed that the demon strators, two Italians and a Belgian, would be investigated.

title: U.S. and Chinese Resume Talks After Two Years
description: WARSAW, Jan. 20The United States and Communist China resumed formal ambassadorial talks today after a twoyear suspension. The session was officially described as useful and business like.

title: Poison Prevention Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) President. Nixon today pro cleimerl the week of March 15 as National Poison Prevention Week and urged programs against a cidental poisonngs ?? to young

title: Coast Banker Is Heart Drive Head
description: The American Heart Asso ciation announced yesterday that Rudolph A. Peterson, a San Francisco banker, would head the association's 1970 fundraising campaign.

title: Arkin to Direct New Feiffer Comedy
description: A new comedymystery by Jules Feiffer called The Whitehouse Murder Case will he presented at the Cir cle in the Square on Feb. 19 by the producing team of Theodore Mann, Paul Libin, Harold Leventhal and Orin Lehman.

title: Yale Admissions Dean, 34, Will Head Horace Mann
description: R. Inslee Clark Jr., the 34 yearold dean of admissions at Yale, has been named head master of Horace Mann School, a leading private institution here.

title: Family Circle Magazine Names New Publisher
description: Fred D. Thompson, presi dent of Family Circle maga zine, announced yesterday the appointment of Robert F. Young as publisher. Mr. Young, who had been a vice president and assistant to the president, replaces Carl J. Schaefer, who retired at the end of la.st year. Before join ing Family Circle, Mr. Young was a senior vice president at Benton & Bowles.

title: Model of an Ambassador
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20As an undergraduate at Stanford 30 years ago, Walter John Stoessel Jr. had to make what seemed to be a crucial decision about his future: to pursue his interest in inter national affairs by going into the Foreign Service or to ac cept a tempting offer to become a movie ac tor in Hollywood. In retrospect the decision was not so crucial, for it is clear that he was bound to play the role of an ambassador whichever way he turned.

title: Canada to Send Medical Aid
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 20Canada will ship $250,000 worth of medicines and drugs to Nigeria in the next few days, Mitchell Sharp, Secretary of State for External Affairs, announced to day. The shipment is being made in response to an urgent request for drugs from the Nigerian Red Cross, he said.

title: Possibility Boy Was Beaten Investigated at Creedmoor
description: The New York State Depart ment of Mental Hygiene began an investigation yesterday of charges by a Queens mother that her 7yearold son might have been beaten while a pa tient at Queens Children's Hos nital.

title: Excerpts From Governor Cahill's Inaugural Address
description: I do not think it would be an exaggeration for me to say that never before in the history of New Jersey has an incoming Governor been con fronted with the enormity of problems, both in variety and degree, which now face this administration.

title: Washington: Who Said Love Makes the World Go Round?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20A big change is taking place in the language of politics. Offi cials are not only talking about home affairs rather than for eign affairs these days and tossing around a new vocabu lary of environment, pollution and ecology, but they are talk ing about control of the growth of population.

title: SUN OIL REPORTS DROP IN PROFITS
Split With Dutch Church Feared in Vatican in Dispute Over Priestly Celibacy
description: ROME, Jan. 20  Serious fears of split between the Roman Catholic church of the Netherlands and the Holy See are being expressed in respon sible Vatican circles in the wake of what they consider repeated acts of indiscipline by the Dutch hierarchy and clergy.

title: TV: My Sweet Charlie
description: MOVIES made especially for television hardly have been noteworthy for coming to gripes with con temporary reality, so last night's production of My Sweet Charlie was an en couraging forward step. David Westheimer's play and novel on a pregnant South ern white girl and an edu cated young Negro lawyer from New York was adapted and produced by Richard Levenson and William Link for the National Broadcast ing Company's Tuesday Night at the Movies.

title: Profit Recession
description: The chill that went through the stock market after Inter national Business Machines Corporation reported lower fourtl quarter 1969 earnings seems likely to be repeated as more companies issue their reports. Such events may do little to alter the conviction of fore casters who have asserted that there isn't going to be any re cession in 1970. But they may cause other watch ers of the econ omy to question a major premise of the no  recession forecasters: the belief that businesmen will per sist in their plans to buy new plant and equipment.

title: Advertising: B.&B. Adds Two Ties Abroad
description: Almost like a meeting of the United Nations Security Council and almost as well covered by the press was a news conference mounted yesterday by Benton & Bowles.

title: TAX MEN IN BRITAIN SAID TO BE OUITTING
description: LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP)  Britain's tax collectors were reported today to be quitting their jobs by the hundreds be cause of what one of their spokesmen termed intolerable, conditions. Frank Swift, dep uty general secretary of the Inland Revenue Staff Federa tion, said that the collectors, simply could not cope with the tremendous amount of work created by new changes in the tax system. Mr. Swift said, Hundreds of them are resign ing up and down the country. In one London tax office alone, he said, seven out of the 14 tax men in the office had re signed within a week. They immediately got jobs at double their salary, he added, plus bonuses year.

title: Blue Ridge Ball Is Still Going Strong
description: Having survived the De pression, the temptation to go big time and the demise of its charitable beneficiary, the annual Blue Ridge Ball will be held for the 61st time here next week with all the enthusiastic congeniality of a Southern family reunion, which it almost is.

title: 10 Youths Seizedin Jersey Drug Raids
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 20State, county and local policemen from at least six communities joined in a ninehour series of raids last night and early today in which 18 persons were ar rested on charges of selling or possessing hashish. LSD, marijuana and Den gills.

title: JEWS IN LEBANON GET ASSURANCES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 20 The Lebanese Interior Minister, Kamal Jumblatt, assured the Jewish community here today of Government protection and of his regret over an explosion at a Jewish school last Sunday.

title: SHORT INTEREST PLUNGES SHARPLY
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange plunged 2,945,102 shares in the month ended Jan. 15, in one of the sharpest monthtomonth fluc tuations in stock exchange his tory, the Big Board announced yesterday.

title: STUDY OF COPPER AIMING AT ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20It has become evident that a study of copper prices by the Nixon Administration is aimed at getting action, not merely information.

title: Murder Trial of a Sergeant In Vietnam Put Off 6 Weeks
description: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (UPI)The defense won a sixweek delay today in the courtmartial of a 20yearold American solider charged with murdering a South Vietnamese man last September.

title: Girl in Tate Case Held
description: LOS ANGELES Jan. 20 (AP) Superior Court Judge Mal colm M. Lucas today denied motions for dismissal of murder and conspiracy charges against Linda Kasabian, 20 years old, one of six persons accused in the killings of the actress Sharon Tate and six others last August. He also declined to set bail for her.

title: JANET BAKER OFFERS ELEGANT ART SONGS
description: The better singers of art songsand Janet Baker is one of the few important ones to day  come halfway to meet you, no more. It is up to the listener to take at least half the journey, and join the singer in the circle of music felt as well as heard.

title: REGENTS PROPOSE CENTER ON LATINS
description: The State Board of Regents has proposed the establishment of an educational center in La tin America as part of a broad ened approach to international understanding by teachers and students.

title: Knicks' Captain Looking Ahead To Club Gaining Division Title
description: PHILADEDPHIA, Jan. 20 A grinning Willis Reed sat contentedly inside his dress ing stall tonight, a few econds after having been voted the mostvaluable player award for leading the East to victory in the Na tional Basketball Associa tion's 20th AllStar game, and said, Now all I want is the big one.

title: Contends City Was Denied Fair Share of AidBig 6 Stand Hailed by Mayors
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20Mayor Lindsay contended today that Governor Rockefeller's new $7.3billion budget would add to rather than ease the city's financial problems.

title: Court Told Nixon Urged Galley Trial
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 20  A report that President Nixon, Commander in Chief of American armed forces, had personally urged a murder trial for First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr. was submitted today by defense counsel as an argument that the lieutenant could never receive a fair trial in a military court.

title: ExVicePresident Candidate Is Appointed to State Post
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 20William E. Miller, who was the Repub lican candidate for Vice Presi dent in 1964, will be appointed chairman of the Niagara Fron tier Transportation Authority to succeed Charles R. Diebold. The appointment was an nounced by Earl W. Brydges, State Senate majority leader. The salary is $30,000 a year.

title: Opponent of DDT Warns Against a Total Ban of It
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The man whose report to the Government resulted in the par tial banning of DDT said today that the total elimination of such longlasting pesticides would endanger the world's fond production system.

title: Nixon, Welcoming Agnew, Says He Plans State of the World Message
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Nixon announced today that he would submit to Congress a State of the World message about two weeks after the traditional Slate of the Union address that he deliver on Thursday. In a relaxed and talka tive mood on the first anni versary of his inauguration as President, Mr. Nixon informed newsmen of the unusual special message during a pic turetaking session with Vice President Agnew, who returned last night from his long Asian lour. The President said the first draft of the State of the Union message, which he has been writing here and in Camp David, Md., for the last two weeks, would have taken two hours and five minutes to deliver. He expressed hope that he could come closer to the mark ?? by Woodrow Wilson, who once sped through a State of the Union address in 15 minutes. The trimming process, the Presi dent suggested, has been ac complished in part by limiting the traditional State of the Union message largely to domestic matters, and by saving the annual review of foreign policy for a special message to be submitted to Congress in written form during the first week of February.

title: Delays on Subways Infuriate Riders
description: Mrs. Joseph DeGaetano says that what should be a onehour subway ride to work from Richmond Hill, Queens, inevitably takes two hours now, and that she is so upset she's afraid she will get a nervous break down and may (quit ber job.

title: Music
description: ALTHOUGH Dmitri Shosta kovich composed his Symphony No. 13 in 1962, it remained for Eugene Orman dy and the Philadelphia Or chestra to introduce it to New York, which they did last night in Philharmonic Hall.

title: A Power in the Capital
description: When George speaks, Pres ident Eisenhower said of Mr. Humphrey, all the rest of us listen.

title: Relief Stocks at Sao Tome Unlikely to Reach Nigeria
description: SAO TOME, Jan. 20 (Agence FrancePresse)A new hangar at the airport here, packed from floor to roof, holds enough food to feed five million people for 20 days.

title: Northeast Chief to Pan Am
description: James O. Leet has been elect ed senior vice president marketing of Pan American World Airways. He is resigning as president of Northeast Air lines and will assume his new post at Pan Am on Feb. 23. He succeeds Norman P. Blake, who will serve as senior vice presi dent on the staff of Najeeb E. Halaby, president and chief ex ecutive officer. Mr. Leet left Pan Am in 1959 when he was district sales manager, New York.

title: CAHILL IS SWORN IN; VOWS CRIME FIGHT
description: TRENTON, Jan. 20  Pledg ing his new administration to search out and destroy organ ized crime and corruption in New Jersey, William Thomas Cahill was inaugurated today as the state's 46th Governor and the first Republican one in 16 years.

title: Geneen Seeks Spokesman For Business in Government
description: Harold S. Gencen, chairman and president of the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, proposed yester day that the Government cre ate a cabinetlevel department that will unabashedly and openly speak for business and solely represent it in Govern ment.

title: MOTFIERS DISRUPT H. E. W. HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20  A group of welfare recipients from Connecticut disrupted a hearing of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare today on the state's welfare program.

title: Now or Never
description: The zeal for purifying the environment is spreading so fast among the nation's youthful idealists that coordinating their activities is already a major con cern. Hardly a college campus is without something like an Ecology Student Association or Students for Environmental Defense.

title: DEMOCRATS REACT TO REDISTRICTING
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20  State Democratic leaders met here today to discuss legal action to try to block a Republican plan that would reapportion Ncw York's 41 Congressional dis tricts along lines that would favor G.O.P. candidates in many areas.

title: Marchi Seeks Licensing Of Election Pollsters
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20  State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican  Conservative can didate for New York City may or last November, introduced a bill in the Legislature today that would require the licensing and control of professional election pollsters.

title: N.A.I.A. Picks Hockey Site
description: KANSAS CITY, Tan. 20 (UPI) Lake Superior State College in Sault Ste., Marie, Mich., Will be host to the third annual National Association of Inter collegiate Athletics ice hockey tournament March 6 and 7, A. O. Duer, the N.A.I.A. exec utive secretary, said today.

title: Advance Is Shown in Trading on Amex
description: Advances barely managed to outnumber declines in mod erate trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: N.B.A. REAFFIRMS EXPANSION MOVE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 The National Basketball Asso ciation reaffirmed by a 122 vote today its desire to expand next season. It saw the pos sible addition of four teams, but said a final decision would be made at another meeting within two weeks.

title: PASADENA SCHOOLS TOLD TO INTEGRATE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20A Federal District Court judge ordered the Pasadena school district today to submit a plan for desegregation of its public schools by Feb. 16. The plan, covering all schools in the dis trict in suburban Los Angeles, would go into effect next September.

title: HallofFame Voting
'68 RIOT WARNING GIVEN TO CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 20More than a month before the 1968 Democratic National Conven tion here, a United States Assistant Attorney General warned there might be a na tional disaster in Chicago's streets unless city officials and demonstrators developed a working relationship.

title: Eisenbud Quits City Job; Admits Rift With Heller
description: Merril Eisenbud submitted his resignation yesterday as the city's $35,000ayear En vironment Protection Admin istrator, effective May 1, and became the fifth super agency chief to quit the Lind say administration since Election Day.

title: U.S. and Bonn End 7Year Joint Effort to Build a Tank
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The United States and West Ger many have decided to go their separate ways in developing a futuristic tank, Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard an nounced today.

title: 2 FOUND MURDERED AT L.I. RESTAURANT!
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 20  Two men were found slain to day in an apartment they shared in the rear of the Villa Sorrento, a restaurant at 198 Glen Cove Avenue here.

title: Boudreau Only One Among 46 Candidates Elected to Baseball Hall of Fame
description: During his active baseball career, Lou Boudreau gained fame as the boy wonder of managing. In more recent years, however, he has be come better known as Denny McLain's fatherinlaw.

title: Nixon Panel Urges Full Pollution Fund Be Spent as Voted
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20The Preident's Water Pollution Con trol Advisory Board has formal ly recommended the disburse ment of the entire $800million voted by Congress to help cities build sewage treatment plants.

title: PAPAL AIDE, IN U.S., HOPEFUL ON NIGERIA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Archbishop Giovanni Benelli, the Deputy Secretary of State at the Vatican, said today that he hoped that wartorn Nigeria would accept relief aid from the Vatican..

title: In Rome, YawnsOn 7th Ave., Applause Even Before a Show
description: ROME, Jan. 20It is hard to feel even the slightest shiver of alarm at the hun dreds of long skirts seen in the Roman haute couture salons where the new spring summer clothes are now be ing shown.

title: Lawyers for De Carlo Maneuver Over Zelmanowitz's Testimony
description: NEWARK, Jan. 20The de fense counsel in the extortion trial of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, and Daniel (Red) Cecere made; a variety of attempts in Fed eral Court today to find a way to discredit the testimony of the prosecution's chief witness.

title: 2 Indian States in Dispute Over Dream City They Share
description: CHANDIGARH, India, Jan. 10Smoking is being dis couraged in the Punjab half of the massive government building here  the ashtrays have been removed from Punjab offices and cigarettes are not sold in the Punjab canteen. All the smokefilled rooms are in the Haryana sec tion of the ninestory struc ture.

title: Marciano, Bleeding From Programed Cuts, Stops Clay in the 13th
description: Rocky Marciano, with cut on nose, catching a left on the jaw from Cassius Clay in the computerized match.

title: Administration Devises Plan to Spur Hiring of HardCore Jobless
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 After a full year of work, the Administration has devised a plan to fulfill one of President Nixon's major campaign prom isesa taxincentive program aimed at encouraging more businesses to hire and train the hardcore unemployed.

title: Equal Time Is Granted To AllStar Organists
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (AP)  The National Hockey League's AllStar organ de bate was settled amicably to day. T.he host, St. Louis, al lowed its home organist, Norm Kramer, to share the keyboard with Al Melnar of Chicago, who was imported by the Black Hawks for the occasion.

title: Washington: For the Record
MARTINIS HEARING PUT OFF TO FEB. 10
description: A hearing in the new drunken driving case against Gareth Martinis was postponed yester day in Bronx Criminal Court until Feb. 10.

title: Paper Says Egyptians Killed 10 Israeli Frogmen in Canal
description: CAIRO, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram said today that Egyp tian defense forces killed at least 10 Israeli frogmen who tried to swim across the Suez Canal near Ismailia Sunday night.

title: Emigrant Savings Is Given Approval For Thrift Merger
description: Frank Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks, ap proved yesterdaywith certain conditionsthe merger of the City Savings and Loan Associa tions into the Emigrant Sav ings Bank.

title: Role in Day Care Is Urged for Companies
description: A group of ranking New Yorkbased business execu tives sat down to a school lunch yesterday with repre sentatives of the Bank Street College of Education and learned, among other things, of a role their companies might play in the field of Providing daycare facilities.

title: 80 Arrested in Pakistan After Violence Fatal to 4
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 20 Eighty persons have been ar rested in connection with po litical violence at a public meeting in Dacca, the East Pak istani capital, two clays ago, in which four persons were killed and more than 400 were injured.

title: Books of The Times
description: MORE drivel has been written about Whittaker Chambers than about al most any other contemporary Amer ican fantasyfigure with the possible excep tion of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. Some men need to hate Chambers. If they can't Cooke the facts or Jowitt them away, they will Zeligsize or Cruise O'Brien over them.

description: Theater TONIGHT

title: U.S. Files Consent Decree In Coast Pipe Trust Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Government moved to day to setle a fiveyear anti trust case by requiring the American Pipe and Construc tion Company of Monterey Park, Calif., to sell a competing pipemanufacturing plant that it acquired in 1963 from U. S. Industries, Inc.

title: US. OPPOSES A CUT OF G. I'S IN EUROPE AS THREAT TO NATO
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Nixon Administration de clared today that any reduc tion of United States troop strength in Europe would be militarily unwise, politically unsettling and financially in significant.

title: Airline Gives Bus Service From Terminal to Planes
description: Passengers arriving at or leaving the Love Airfield at Dallas usually have an unusu ally long walk between the ticket counters and the plane.

title: The Airlines Accept Pollution Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The nation's major airlines agreed today to meet the threeyear deadline proposed by the Nixon Administration for eliminating nest of the smoke pollution from let aircraft.

title: Dr. Thomas H. Andrews, 59; Served in Hospitals Here
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 20Dr. Thomas H. An drews, who had been chief of the staff of St. Elizabeth Hos pital, New York, died of a heart attack here whil eworking at a local hospital, His age was 59.

title: Rohauer Resigns Key Posts At New York Cultural Center
description: Raymond Rohauer has re signed as film curator and nro gram director of the New York Cultural Center. He had held the post since July when Hunt ington Hartford transferred control of the center in Colum bus Circle, then called the Hart ford Gallery of Modern Art, to Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: G. & W. Unit Changes Name
description: The G. & W. Land and De velopment Corporation an nounced yesterday a change in its name to the Transnation De elopment Corporation. Philip J. Levin, chairman, told share bolders that since Gulf & West ern Industries, Inc., no longer owns the majority of the stock in the company and plans to reduce its proport innate interest in the near future, directors decided to change the name to reflect this moze.

title: Screen: A Royal Battle of the Sexes:'Anne of 1,000 Days' Bows at Plaza Burton Cast as Henry Miss Bujold Stars
description: NO American playwright has ever found a completely satisfying language for historical drama. Several years ago, in his "A Lion in Winter," William Goldman decided to make Henry II of France and Eleanor of Aquitaine sound like a contemporary suburban couple who had stumbled backward through their television screen and landed in a bickering heap in history.One of the most prolific and tireless of American playwrights, the late Maxwell Anderson ("Elizabeth the Queen," "Mary of Scotland)" developed his own neo-Elizabethan verse-and-prose rhythms that were more stately than dramatic. However, I've always remembered Anderson's 1948 "Anne of the Thousand Days" with a special fondness, principally because of the performances given by Rex Harrison as Henry VIII and by Joyce Redman as Anne Boleyn, the second of Henry's six wives. My suspicion that "Anne" was really an actors' vehicle is now confirmed by the movie version that opened yesterday at the Plaza Theater.This "Anne of the Thousand Days" is one of those almost unbearably classy movies, like "A Man for All Seasons" and "Becket," that have a way of elevating the reputations of moviemakers without doing much for the art. It's been photographed in color and with care in all sorts of lovely English settings; the Tudor costumes are chic and seemingly wrinkle-free; it has a score by Georges Delerue that is mostly alarums and excursions, punctuated by an occasional madrigal, and it makes an extremely complex period in English history (the Reformation) comprehensible by defining it in terms of private personalities who were also public figures.Like the original play, the screenplay by John Hale and Bridget Boland, from an adaptation by Richard Sokolove, is the story of Henry's courtship of Anne (while he is still married to Katherine of Aragon), his break with Rome when he decides to divorce Katherine to marry Anne, and his final break with Anne when she cannot provide him with a male heir.The play has been opened up considerably, to take advantage of the exterior locations, but the heart of the film is still a sort of epic battle of the sexes, with Richard Burton, as Henry, in one corner, and Genevieve Bujold, as Anne, in the other. Burton, whose film career has included a series of almost-great performances ("Look Back in Anger," "Night of the Iguana," "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?"), is in excellent form and voicefunny, loutish and sometimes wise.Miss Bujold, the French-Canadian actress ("King of Hearts," "Isabelle"), is a constantly delightful surprise as the young girl who first comes to respect Henry for the power she can wield, and then, just about the time he is growing tired of her, to love him. I say she's a surprise only because she has such a perfectly conventional beauty that her intelligence seems an unexpected dividend.It is the very real intelligence of these two performers, as well as of Anthony Quayle (Cardinal Wolsey) and John Colicos (Cromwell), that lessen the pompous effect of the Anderson dialogue. "By God!" Henry might say, "Nobody has ever talked to me like that before!" And you know he's about to tell Anne how beautiful she is when she's angry.Anne, on the other hand, is gifted with the sort of foresight favored in second-rate hindsight dramas: "My Elizabeth," she screams at Henry, "will be a greater queen than any king of yours!" When Henry goes letching after Anne, old Wolsey is likely to wink and observe: "Where the dove is, the hawk cannot be far behind." In Anderson's play, poor old Sir Thomas More, whose battle with Henry was the basis of "A Man for All Seasons," is limited to what is, in effect, a couple of glum, walk-on scenes."Anne of the Thousand Days" was directed by Charles Jarrott, a newcomer from television, but I suspect the film's conventionally reverential style was dictated by Hal B. Wallis, the producer. Wallis, at 71, is himself one of Hollywood's longest-running commercial hits. Among his credits are "Little Caesar," "King's Row," "The Strange Love of Martha Ivers," "My Frienda Irma" and "Gunfight at the O.K. Corral," plus occasional cultural binges like "Becket" and "Anne of the Thousand Days." He's entitled.

title: Nigeria Says Russian Help Was Vital to War Victory
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20Nigeria's Ambassador said today that So viet aid to his country was the most important factor in the defeat of the Biafran seces sionists.

title: Executive Positions Filled By Bank of AmericaN.Y.
description: The Bank of AmericaNew York announced yesterday that A. H. Brawner Jr. will become chief executive officer of the international institution, suc ceeding Tom B. Coughran on April 1.

title: Snow and Cold Imperil Walking and Driving Here
description: A fresh cover of snow and frigid temperatures combined to make walking and driving hazardous in the New York metropolitan area last night and early this morning. At A.M. at was 18 degrees.

title: Executive Changes
description: H. Barclay Morley, 40 years old, has been named executive vice president of the Stauffer Chemical Company. He will assist Roger W. Gunder, president and chier executive officer and have primary respon sibillly for the future growth of the company.

title: Agostino T. Galluzzo, Teacher, To Marry Miss Jane L. Heffer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jacob M. Seiler of New York and Ma maroneck. N. Y., have an nounced the engagement of Mrs. Seiler's daughter, Miss Jane L. Heffer, to Agostino T. Galluzzo of Springfield, Mass. Miss Heffer is the daughter also of the late Jerome Heifer, who was a vice president and counsel for the Empire Mutual Insur ance Company in New York. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Galluzzo of Springfield.

title: Lagging British Paper Changes Its Direction
description: LONDON, Jan. 20 The stanchest readers may pre tend not to notice the differ ence, but The Guardian has changed.

title: Hill and Lunn Tie for Lead In New P.G.A. Point Plan
description: Dave Hill and Bob Lunn are tied at 144.9 points for the lead in the new system established by the Professional Golfers' Association of America Tourna ment Players Division.

title: Danny the Red Is Ejected in Tumult In Montreal Court
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (AP)  Daniel CohnBendit, leader of student demonstrations in Paris in 1968, was among the demonstrators ejected from Su perior Court here yesterday during the sentencing of an ac cased terrorist for contempt of court.

title: Coast Drilling Ban Sought
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI)The California As sembly, the lower house of the state legislature, has unani mously called on the Nixon Ad ministration to prohibit all oil drilling in the Santa Barbara Channel. A massive oil leak from a Union Oil rig last year coated the beaches of Southern California. There have been several smaller leaks since then from wells being drilled in the channel under Federal leases.

title: Miss Perine Plans Bridal
description: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 20Miss Deborah Perine, teacher at the Easterly Park way Elementary School in State College, Pa., and Jacob John Kleinschuster, a doctor al candidate at the chemistry department of Pennsylvania State University, will be mar ried in June.

title: Leary Found Guilty Again On Marijuana Charges
description: LAREDO, Tex., Jan. 20 (UPI) A Federal Court jury found Dr. Timothy Leary guilly today of helping import three ounces of marijuana info Texas four years ago in his teen  age, daughter's ??.

title: HARRY GRIFFITH, 85; HEADED AD CONCERN
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 20 Harry C. Griffith, who retired in 1964 as chairman and treas urer of the WardGriffith Com pany, Inc., newspaper represen tatives, in New York City, died yesterday in the Greenwich Hospital after a short illness. He was 85 years old and lived at 10 Verona Drive here.

title: Arson Found in Fire That Ruined Torahs In Bronx Synagogue
description: A fire that swept the interior of a Bronx synagogue Monday night and destroyed five Torah scrolls and other religious ob jects was called arson yester day by the City Fire Marshal's office.

title: East Wins N.B.A. AllStar Game, 142135
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 Although they dissipated big leads twice, the East AllStars defeated the West in the 20th annual National Basketball Association AllStar game, 142 135, tonight before a crowd of 15,000 in the Spectrum and a national television audience.

title: SENATE APPROVES AID TO EDUCATION; NIXON TO VETO IT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Democraticcontrolled Sen ate laid down a political chal lenge to the White House today by endorsing, 74 to 17, a $19.7 billion health and education appropriations bill that Presi dent Nixon has threatened to veto as inflationary.

title: TEACHERS WARNED ON CONTROVERSIES
description: The city school system has reminded teachers that contro versial subjectssuch as the issues in the current strike against General Electric should be treated in a scholarly and objective manner.

title: New York Aide Named Whittier College Head
description: WHITTIER, Calif., Jan, 20 (AP)Dr. Frederick M. Binder, Associate Commis sioner for the New York State Education Department, was named today as presi dent of Whittier College.

title: 2 DISAPPEARANCES GET POLICE STUDY!
description: The possibility that two re bellious gang members were murdered recently by fellow soldiers in the Mafia family of Joseph Colombo is being in vestigated by the Brooklyn Dis trict Attorney's office.

title: GERMANY RECALLS BONDS OF U.S. EARLY
