description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 20 (AP)The Bundesbank disclosed today that it has pre maturely recalled a billion marks of United States Treas ury bonds purchased in 1968 to offset the dollar drain caused by the stationing of American troops in West Germany.

title: Atrocity Charges Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) The Army told Representa tive Lionel Van Deerlin today that it was investigating charges that a United States infantry company used a South Viet namese village for target prac tice. The California Democrat released a letter from Maj. Gen. William A. Becker saying that reports that a ninth Infantry company division fired on vil lage huts in June, 1969, near Dongtam in the Mekong Delta were under active investiga tion. The allegations had been made by an Army doctor, Capt. J. L. Sugarman.

title: Richard A. Tewkesbury Dies; Walked the Isthmus of Panam??
description: Richard A. Tewkesbury, who in 193940 walked from the Panama Canal to the border of Colombia to demonstrate that the Darien Isthmus was not a barrier to plans for a Pan American Highway, died in New York City on Dec. 19.

title: Few React to New Haven Fare Plan
description: They weren't saying any thing about it this morning but I'm going to take a week off the day it goes into effect.

title: Bowrey Is Extended to Five Sets by Sedgman
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 20 (AP)  Frank Sedgman, Aus tralian tennis star of 20 years ago, carried his countryman. Bill Bowrey, a current Davis Cup player, to five sets today before succumbing in the Aus tralian open championship.

title: Elbert Isom, Oil Engineer, Dies; Headed Civil Air Patrol Region
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 20  Elbert C. Isom, a former petroleum engineer and Civil Air Patrol officer, who once survived the disintegration of his plane in the Atlantic, died at Stamford Hospital here yes terday of cancer. He was 73 years old and lived on Bowery Road in New Canaan.

title: INFLATION DEFIES FRENCH CONTROL
description: PARIS, Jan. 20 Economic conditions in France and the United States show striking timilaritiesstrong credit con trols, record high interest rates the start of an upward curve in unemployment, the leveling aff to industrial production, and ao relief from rising prices.

title: Nixons' Redecorating: Money an Object
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon had only two major instruc tions for her interior decora tor at the Western White Housemake it light and airy with lots of yellow, and don't make it too expensive.

title: Jumbo Jet, 362 Aboard, in Debut Today
description: Last minute preflight groom ing was under way here yester day on a huge Pan American World Airways Boeing 747 jet that is scheduled to start a new era in aviation today by flying from New York to London with all its 362 seats filled.

title: PantsBan Tempest at C.B.S.
description: A STYLISH new form of passive resistance, spon taneously christened a pants in, took place yesterday at noon at the C.B.S. Broadcast Center_ 524 West 57th Street.

title: Mrs. Nixon Discusses Rewarding First Year
description: WASHLNGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today that the first year in the White House had been interesting and rewarding and that the President thought it had been a great year.

title: Cocoa Merchants Elect
description: Arie Nugteren has been elect ed president of the Cocoa Mer chants of America, Inc., Mr. Nugteren, who is with A. C. Israel Cocoa, Inc., succeeds William Stern.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To Cure Young Addicts

title: Afghan Line Buys 727 Jet
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 20 (Reuters)Ariana Afghan Air lines has taken delivery of a Boeing 727 jet airliner in New Delhi and will put it into serv ice on its London route. This is the second Boeing jet aircraft purchased by Arians. The first crashed near London Airport last year.

title: GROUP IN NEWARK SEEKS BIAS STUDY
description: NEWARK, Jan. 20  A group of local black and Puerto Rican leaders, seeking broader employment for minority group members in publicly supported construction projects here, has called on the United States Labor Depart ment to investigate alleged dis crimination in the building trades in Essex County.

title: FLOOD TRUST SUIT GRANTED A DELAY
description: A Federal judge gave organ ized baseball two more weeks yesterday to prepare its reply to Curt Flood's suit challenging the game under the antitrust laws.

title: Jersey's Crime Unit is Upheld on Right to Force Witnesses to Testify
description: TRENTON, Jan. 20  The power of the State Commission of Investigation to seek the indefinite imprisonment of wit nesses who refuse to testify after being granted immunity from prosecution was unani mously upheld today by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: COUNCIL CHANGES PROCEDURE RULES
description: City Council members made a linebyline study of 20 typed pages of suggested new proced ural rules yesterday to come up with some changes that will increase the power of individ ual councilmen to press ford legislation they have spon sored.

title: SOPRANO SPARKLES IN RECITAL DEBUT
description: The Concert Artists Guild distinguished itself last night by presenting Sandra Darling, a gifted young soprano in her New York recital debut at Car negie Hall. Miss Darling is not unknown, having sang with the New York City Opera, the Met ropolitan Opera Studio and other companies of quality, but her ability to carry off a recital with the aplomb and skill of a veteran came as a pleasant sur prise.

title: Lesley Loser, Todd Johnston Are Betrothed
description: YARDLEY, Pa., Jan. 20 Miss Lesley Ann Loser, a senior at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., and Todd Douglas Johnston, a student at Boston University Law School, plan to be married in June.

title: The Theater: Jacques Brel Revisited
description: ELIOT'S Prufrock, a saga cious if boring man, measured out his life in cof fee spoonswhich is great if you have a special thing going for coffee. Drama crit ics, less sagacious if no less boring, measure out their lives with hit shows. Tomor row Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris will have been alive, well and living in New York for two years. And it seems but yesterday . . . however.

title: Leslie Ayvazian To Wed Upstate
description: SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 20Miss Leslie Ann Ayvazian and Pvt. David Graham Webster of the Army plan to be married here in August.

title: Excerpts From Richardson Speech on the Troops in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Following are excerpts from a speech made in Chicago to day by Under Secretary of State Elliot L. Richardson, as made available here:

title: Card of Thanks
description: RUTHENAlbert. The family of the late Albert Ruthen wishes to express sincere thanks and appreciation to their many friends who showert their sympathy during their hour of sorrow.

title: WARRANTY ORDER OF G.M. IS SCORED
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 20 (AP) The General Motors Corpo ration told Chevrolet dealers last month that they should ignore defects covered by war ranty unless the defects were to safety or were discovered by the customer. Senate in vestigators were told today.

title: CHURCH COUNCIL TO NAME 3 BLACKS
description: TULSA, Jan. 20Three top positions in the National Coun cil of Churches will be filled soon by blacks, the council's general secretary disclosed here today.

title: BULLET IDENTIFIED IN PANTHER DEATH
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 20A police firearms expert told a coroner's jury today that a bullet re covered from the body of the slain Black Panther leader Fred Hampton was from a 30caliber carbine.

title: Article 1  No Title
Japan's Payment Surplus Had Sharp Rise in Month
description: TOKYO, Jan. 20 (AP)Japan had a balanceofpayments sur plus in December equivalent to about $260million, compared with a surplus of $161million in December of 1968, the Fi nance Ministry estimated today.

title: Inquiry Finds No Violation by U.S. Military Network in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (UPI)Military investigators studying charges that the American Forces Vietnam Net work censors news broadcast to servicemen in the war zone agreed today that the network had not violated Defense De partment policies.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
CONSTITUTION COPY SOLD FOR $160,000
description: A heavily annotated second draft of the Constitution of the United States, printed on Sept. 12, 1787, was auctioned yester day for $160,000. It was the secondhighest price recorded] for an American historical document.

title: Met Postpones Fanciulla
description: The Metropolitan Opera has postponed the introduction of Puccini's La Fanciulla del West into this season's reper tory from Feb. 4 to Feb. 11, because of scheduling problems arising from the shortened sea son. Puccini's La Bohme will be performed Feb. 4, with Teresa Stratas, Colette Boky, Richard Tucker, Frank Guarrera and Cesare Siepi.

title: Larceny Is Curbed on Ski Slopes As Operators Cry Stop, Thief!
description: LARCENY at ski centers continues to be a major problem plaguing area opera tors. Thieves are still taking advantage of careless skiers who leave a pair of $200 skis unguarded outdoors while having a snack or cof fee break indoors.

title: Senate Opens Debate on Crime Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The Senate opened debate today on a tough crime control program amid suggestions that the Re publicans may seek to revive the issue for their Congression al campaign this year.

title: Executive Changes
description: Guerdon D. Smith has joined Shelby Cullom Davis & Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, a vice presidentcorporate finance. He formerly was a vice president of Blyth & Co., Inc.

title: BEAK SCORES LAG ON 2D AYE. SUBWAY
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had stalled the Second Avenue subway project.

title: POPE PAUL DECRIES CATHOLIC DISUNITY
description: ROME, Jan. 21 (UPI) Pope Paul VI said today Roman Catholics must stop fighting among themselves before they copld hope to overcome the divisions with Protestant or Orthodox churches.

title: Top Officers Selected By Miller Brewing Co.
description: The election of B. William Kostecke as president of the Miller Brewing Company, Mil waukee, was announced yes terday. He succeeds Charles W. Miller, who becomes chairman of both the board of directors and the com pany's executive committee. Mr. Kostecke had been treas urer and chief financial of ficer.

title: Carswell's Racist Remarks in 1948 Were for Expediency, Son of His Political Foe Says
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 21The son of the man who defeated Judge G. Harrold Carswell in his first political venture 22 years ago said tonight that he thought Judge Carswell's racist remarks in that campaign were inspired more by political expediency than by personal conviction.

title: Harvey's Stores Elects
description: Officers and directors of Del anair, Inc., which now holds a controlling interest in Harvey's Stores, Inc., a readytowear ap parel chain here, have been elected to new posts and to the board of Harvey's. William L. Richter becomes chairman and Gerald L. Cohen becomes exec utive committee chairman and chief executive officer of Har vey's. Bernard S. Hirsch contin ues as president.

title: The Districting Maze
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21There was a guard stationed outside a fourthfloor room of the Cap itol today as Republicans made lastminute changes in their plan to reapportion the state's 41 Congressional districts. At 2:30 P.M., the guard was sent downstairs to get precinctby precinct vote totals for the 1968 Congression al election in the Sixth District of Qeens. That little errandthe fig ures were needed to make sure that the new Sixth would contain neighbor hoods that had voted for Rep resentative Seymour Halpern, a Republicanshould be enough proof for anyone that the re apportionment plan is a po litical document.

title: Smalls Gain Ascendancy in N.B.A. Expansion Plans
description: THE National Basketball Association's 20th annual AllStar game passed into history in snowy Philadelphia Tuesday night, but all the really interesting aspects of the twoday gathering con cerned the future. Next year will be the 25th season for the N.B.A., which began with a life expectancy of about onefifth that in 1946 as the Basketball As sociation of America. After two years of contraction, it acquired four strong teams from the other league, the National, an older circuit con taining the top pros of the day, but smalltime financial ly.

title: TAX LOAN FEE IS CUT BY BANK OF AMERICA
description: The Bank of Americathe biggest bank in the worldap parently bowed yesterday to criticism from two California legislators and sharply reduced the interest it would charge its three million creditcard hold ers who elect to pay income taxes as part of the bank's loan program.

title: Bonnies Turn Back De Paul Five, 8359, As Lanier Tallies 28
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Jan. 21 (UPI) Led by Bob Lanier's 28 points and 22 rebounds, fourthranked St. Bonaventure won its 11th in a row tonight by beating De Paul, 8359.

title: Point of No Return
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Virgin Islands University has forfeited its basketball game scheduled for tomorrow night, against George Washington University, because the team had returned home after play ing games Friday and Saturday night at Jacksonville, Fla., and Richmond, Va., and could not arrange, transportation to re turn.

title: DAVID WALLACE, 81, HELD AUTO PATENTS
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21  David A. Wallace, who joined the Chrysler Corpora tion as a master mechanic and rose to be president of the corporation's Chrysler Division, died at his home here today. He was 81 years old.

title: Rain and Withdrawals Heap Woes on Aussie Tennis Tourney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 21 (Reuters)Rain washed out all matches today in the $14,000 Australian open tennis cham pionships and plunged the tour nament into a crisis.

title: Blanche Yurka Is Due in Madwoman Off Broadway
description: Blanche Yurka, who has had a long, varied and no table career on Broadway, is returning to the local stage but, this time, off Broadway. She will star in The Mad woman of Chaillot, Maurice Valency's adaptation of Jean Giraudoux's play, opening March 22, in Sokol Hall, the Czechoslovak cultural center at 420 East 71st Street.

title: Manhattan Savings Bank Elects
description: The Manhattan Savings Bank has named Francis J. Ludemann and Russell G. Smith to its two top execu tive posts to succeed Willard K. Denton, it was announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Gives $50Million More To Pay for Saigon's Imports
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 (AP)The United States has given $50million more to South Vietnam to aid in financing im ports, it was announced today.

title: ORANGE JUICE SHOWS ADVANCE
description: Prices of frozen orange con centrate futures rose yesterday on the New York Cotton Ex change.

title: Report Compiled in '68 Says Excessive Allied Bombing in South Vietnam Stirred Hostility to Regime.
description: WASHINGTON,. Jan. 21  Some. South Vietnamese refu gees told American researchers in Saigon in 1968 of exces sive and misdirected allied bombing and shelling that made many of them hostile to the South Vietnamese Government.

title: CHICAGO TRIAL TOLD OF A M'CARTHY PACT
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UPI)A 1968 campaign aide to Senator Eugene J. McCarthy told a Fed eral court jury today that the Senator's staff antiwar protest leaders had an informal work ing agreement before and dur ing the turbulent Democratic National Convention.

title: Nixon Economic Adviser Doubts Nation Is Moving Into Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Ad visers, conceded today that the housing industry was suffering a recession but said of the economy generally:

title: Panel Finds Number Of Nursing Homes Quitting Medicare
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP)  Mushrooming discontent with the administration of Medicare has led hundreds of nursing homes to quit the Fed eral health care program, a nationwide study disclosed to day.

title: U.S. Expects Further Talks With the Chinese Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 United States diplomats who have scrutinized Chinese Com munist remarks about the pos sibilities for improved relations said today that the dialogue that opened at Warsaw yester day would be pursued in fur ther meetings, possibly in the near future.

title: Bridge.
description: THE prize awarded for the best overall perform ance in the TriState Re gional Championships at Grossinger, N. Y., last week end was convincingly won by two young New York experts, Warren Kornfeld and Richard Khautin.

title: Ken Scott's Recipe for Fashion: Fried Egg and Pasta
description: ROME, Jan. 21The least forgettable number in the Italian springsummer couture shows, which end today, might just be the long white eve ning dress splattered with fried eggs. If it is not that one, the runnerup could be the long dress whose print is raw chicken parts, or the anklelength black party dress with the pasta print. Actually, the pasta is rigatoni, which Americans know as elbow macaroni.

title: BELL ISSUE PLAN DEPRESSES BONDS
description: The Bell System's mammoth $1.57billion debenture issue announced yesterday afternoon weighed heavily upon the bond market, depressing prices of most outstanding corporate bonds and slowing the sales of some new issues.

title: Betty C. Blanchard Is Engaged
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 21Miss Betty Clarice Blan chard and Lyle William John son, who is serving in the Marine Corps, will be married here Aug. 29 in the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation.

title: Brown Rebuffed by London After Mideast Trip
description: LONDON, Jan. 21  The Wilson Government rebuffed George Brown today following the former Foreign Secretary's return from a private trip to the Middle East that was marred by reports of illtem pered remarks.

title: Ford and Chrysler Announce Closings
description: DETROIT, Tan. 21Car pro duction schedules were trimmed again today by the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Cor poration.

title: Bus Hearing Adjourned
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 21A public hearing by the Public Service Commission on a pro posal by the Jerusalem Avenue Bus Line, Inc., to operate de luxe bus service from Nassau County to the East Side of Manhattan was adjourned to day until Feb. 9 at the commis sion's Manhattan offices.

title: AUSTRIA INCREASES BANK RATE TO 5%
description: VIENNA, Jan. 21 (Reuters) The Austrian National Bank raised the discount rate today to 5 per cent from 4.75 per cent, effective tomorrow.

title: Contact in Warsaw
description: Renewal of formal SinoAmerican diplomatic con tacts has been accompanied by the usual deep secrecy that has surrounded the Warsaw talks in the past. Nevertheless, WashingtonPeking relations are so important that every major World capital is subject ing the little that is known about this week's meeting to microscopic analysis.

title: Cartoonist Strips Boxer of His Mustache
description: Pat Murphy drives a green 1969 Charger and he also owns a green 1950 Ford and a green 1935 Chevrolet. When last seen yesterday he was wearing a green double breasted suit with green shoes and green socks and a green bandana round his neck.

title: Charles S. Kichler, Served Commerce Department Here
description: Charles S. Kichler, a special ist in international trade for the Department of Commerce, died Tuesday night at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. He was 59 years old and lived at 51 Riverview Avenue, Ards le. N. Y.

title: Substitute 747 OH for London; Engine Trouble Causes Delay
description: The following article is by Richard Witkin, aboard the first commercial Boeing 747 transAtlantic flight.

title: RAYMOND L. GARMAN, A SINGER EXECUTIVE
description: YONKERS, Jan. 21Dr. Ray mond L. Garman, vice presi dent, technology, for the Singer Company, died at St. John's Riverside Hospital here yester day. He was 62 years old and lived at 50 Summit Drive in HastingsonHudson.

title: H.E.W. Finds Laxity In School Aid Here
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has charged that state and city education authorities were lax in their handling of millions of dollars of Federal funds given to education projects here.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME DROPS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended slightly higher yesterday on moderate trading.

title: U.S. TERMS NIGERIA ADAMANT ON RELIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  State Department officials told impatient Senators today that Nigerian insistence on control over internal affairs was the main roadblock to United States and church aid for the ill and starving in the former rebel enclave of Biafra.

title: 2 Panther Deaths In Raid in Chicago Ruled Justifiable
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 21A special coroner's jury ruled today that the deaths of two Black Pan thers slain in a predawn police raid were justifiable.

title: 29 Charged in M.I.T. Seizure
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 21 (AP)Trespassing complaints were issued today against 29 persons who allegedly partici pated in the twoday seizure last week of the administration office at the Massachusetts In stitute of Technology. An East Cambridge District Court judge. Harold E. Magnoson, denied complaints in two other cases. The complaints involved 15 stu dents, three former students, nine nonstudents and two mem bers of the teaching staff.

title: Detention Centers 60% Over Capacity
description: Throughout the day and into the night the vans that shuttle people between free dom and confinement roll up to the Baxter Street entrance of the Criminal Courts build ing, pouring their manacled cargoes into the funnel of the city's overcrowded cor rectional system.

title: Excerpts from Carswell Talk
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by G. Harrold Carswell that appeared in The Irwinton Bulletin on Aug. 13, 1948; Judge Carswell's statement to the Columbia Broadcasting System last night, and a statement by Attorney General John N. Mitchell:

title: WindDriven Ship Tears a Gap in Chesapeake BridgeTunnel
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Jan. 21An amphibious Navy cargo ship broke loose from her an chorage early today and smash ed a gap in the Chesapeake Bay BridgeTunnel, the 17.6mile crossing between Virginia's mainland and the Eastern Shore.

title: Chess:
description: THE most recent competi tor in the international arena to attain the status of grandmaster was Jesus Diez Del Corral of Spain. He earned this accolade during the 18man roundrobin in Majorca, Spain.

title: DE CARLO WITNESS  DESCRIBES FEARS
description: NEWARK, Jan. 21  At the insistence of the defense and over the protest of the Govern ment, Gerald Martin Zelmano witz was returned to the stand to be questioned about his pri vate life today in the Federal conspiracyextortion trial of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, reputed Mafia figure.

title: Most Large Institutions Adopt New Ceilings, Some Uneagerly
description: Most of the nation's large commercial banks and thrift institutions moved swiftly yesterdaythough with vary ing degrees of enthusiasmto put into effect the higher in terest rates they are permitted to pay depositors.

title: M'INTYRE RESIGNS POST AS PRELATE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 James Francis Cardinal McIn tyre, widely regarded as the most conservative member of the American Catholic hier archy, resigned today as Arch bishop of Los Angeles. He was immediately succeeded by Co adjutor Archbishop Timothy J. Manning, who was designated the Cardinal's successor last June.

title: RECORD EXPECTED IN 600 AT GARDEN
description: At the National Collegiate outdoor championships last year, Lee Evans and Larry James spent so much time wor rying about each other in the 440yard dash that Curtis Mills, a Texas A. and M. sophomore, won the race and set a world record.

title: TV and Radio to Carry Nixon Message Today
description: President Nixon's State of the Union Message will be carried live at 12:30 P.M. to day by the following tele vision channels:

title: WESTBURY PACER COOL TO WARMUP
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 21  Red Kap, a fidgety 5year old bay gelding, and his groom, Roy Raulins, were in agree ment at Roosevelt Raceway to nightneither wanted to work.

title: Collision in Rotterdam Fog
description: ROTTERDAM, the Nether lands, Jan. 21 (UPI)A float ing grain elevator and a British ship, the 10,338ton Hardwicke Grange, collided in the New Waterway today in heavy fog. The grain elevator sank, Rotter dam police reported. Two of the three crewmen aboard the elevator were injured and the third was missing. The Hard wicke Grange suffered little damage, the police said.

title: POPE IS GIVEN REPORT OF TORTURE IN BRAZIL
description: ROME, Tan. 21The Pontifi cal Commission on Justice and Peace can make no judgment on alleged political torture in Brazil, the head of the organi zation said in a letter released here today, but the commission has transmitted to Pope Paul VI a dossier documenting such charges.

title: Personal Finance: Icing by Ma Bell
description: The 3.1 million sharehold ers of American telephone and Telegraph Company yes terday had a sweetener to consider. Would it be as plain as apple pie or would it be icing on a cake?

title: New U.S. Adviser for Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 21 (Reu ters)  Maj. Gen. Livingston Taylor has been appointed chief of the United States Military Assistance Advisory Group in Taiwan, the government's mili tary information service re ported today lie replaced Maj. Gen. Richard C. Ciccolella, cur rently on three  month sick leave in Washington. General Taylor is expected to assume, ??

title: U. S. STEEL JOINS PRICING INCREASE
description: The United States Steel Cor poration announced yesterday it was following other producers who have raised their prices for construction prod ucts.

title: PHYSICIAN WARNS BIRTH PILL USERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  Women who use birth control pills should have their blood pressure tested every three months, a specialist said today at a Senate subcommittee hearing.

title: Revision of P. S.C. Is Demanded In Albany by Commuter Council
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21Members of the Council of Commuter Or ganizations, which says it rep resents more than 200,000 frus trated commuters, have de manded that the Public Service Commission be totally re vamped and then be given jurisdiction over the autono mous Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority.

title: New Head of Business Arts Panel Presents Plans
description: The next big push of the Business Committee for the Arts should be to establish a clearing house of information and guidance for corpora tions ready to involve them selves in the arts but not yet certain about what direction to take.

title: MARTINS PERFORMS IN ROBBINS'S DANCES
description: If there is no such thing as a Peter Martins critic, he will have to be invented. Last night at the State Theaterfor the third time since he swung back into repertory Sunday as guest artist with the New York City Ballet  Mr. Martins glided smoothly into a new role. This time it was in Jerome Robbins's Dances at a Gathering.

title: Ric Buys Canada Leases
description: DALLAS, Jan. 21 (UPI)Ric International Industries, Inc., announced today the purchase of priority rights for undevel oped oil and gas leases on 41,800 acres in the Kandik Basin and Bristol Bay Basin areas of Alaska and the Kandik Province of Canada. The pur chase was made for $102,000 in cash and 18,160 shares of Ric International common stock.

title: Strike Talks Break Down
description: CINCINATTI, Jan. 21 (UPI) Talks between union and city officials to end the 17dayold strike of 1,500 nonuniformed city employes have broken off without a settlement or any fur ther sessions scheduled.

title: Books of The Times
description: BEFORE Ronald Radosh, there were probably still people around who believed in the Heroic American Trade Unionist, just as there are people around who believe that the National Football League lost two Super Bowls in a row by accident; George Meany on a Styrene foamie would come floating to the rescue of all those black men who can't get into his craft unions; the Teamsters would stop deliv eries to supermar kets that sell Cali fornia grapes; the United Mine Work ers would develop iron lungs; and we would singalong in tremolo our Solidarity Forever! Alas, Jay Lovestone and Ir ving Brown and Se rafino Romeraldi won't be members of chorus. They will be, suggests Mr. Radosh, off some where in Western Europe or Latin America, on Central Intelligence Agency credit cards, playing the ideological policeman of trade unionism.

title: In The Nation: Other Thoughts in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 21An air of unreality hangs over the trial of the socalled Chicago Seven, and not merely be cause it keeps turning up such witnesses as Country Joe, the leader of the rock group known as Country Joe and the Fish.

title: Feb. 2 Luncheon to Help U.J.A.
description: Mrs. John V. Lindsay will be the special guest at a luncheon Feb. 2 in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Meshulam Riklis on East 80th Street to benefit the women's division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York.

title: Mrs. Klein Gets City Post
description: Kate H. Klein, who has been the unsalaried coordinator of nighttime volunteers in the Mayor's action center, was ap pointed yesterday as director of the center at $12,500 a year. Mrs. Klein succeeds Sheldon Brosoff, who has been ap pointed assistant Commissioner of the Sanitation Department.

title: NIXON ASKS NEW USE FOR A NASA CENTER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) President Nixon has asked his chief science adviser to ex plore possibilities for making other governmental use of space agency electronics re search center at Cambridge, Mass., which is to be closed because of budgetary restraints.

title: French Envoy Summoned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Secretary of State William P. Rogers summoned the French Ambassador, Charles Lucet, to hear a sharp warning that France's arms sales to Libya could disturb the arms balance in the Middle East, the State Department announced today.

title: Benefit on Jan. 31 To Aid Hungarians
description: Hungarian refugees, par ticularly students in Europe, will benefit on Jan. 31 when the Hungarian Catholic League of America bolts the 16th annual Hungarian Char ity Ball at the Pierre.

title: TV: Premieres Herald Changes in A.B.C. Schedule
description: THE American Broadcasting Company is overhauling its evening television schedule this week after most of its Monday night programing had proved a costly disaster. As part of the process of rear rangement and replacement there were two premieres and one returning show last night, and there will be two more premieres this evening.

title: Venezuelan President Shifts Armed Forces Posts
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 21 (AP)The top command of the Venezuelan armed forces was reshuffled today on orders of President Rafael Caldera and his Defense Minister, Brig Gen. Martin Garcia Villasmil.

title: ESSEX is SOUGHT BY U.S. PLYWOOD
description: United States PlywoodCham pion Papers, Inc., one of the na tion's leading forest products concerns, announced yesterday it has agreed to acquire Es sex International, Inc., for stock valued at about $365million.

title: NUCLEAR DISPOSAL OF WASTE STUDIED
description: A concept for using nuclear energy to convert junk cars, beer cans and other solid wastes into their basic, re usable elements is stirring wide interest among scientists as means of alleviating man's mounting wastedisposal and pollution problem.

title: Yugoslav Aide in New York Asks for Residence in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) State Department officials said today that Aleksa Kapicic, a consul in the office of the Yugoslav Consulate General in New York, had asked for per manent residence in the United States.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS DEFIANCE OF NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 With a newfound unity, House and Senate Democratic leaders staged a preemptive political attack on the Administration today, seeking to put a Demo cratic stamp on the crime, pol lution, education and health is sues before President Nixon de livers his State of the Union Message tomorrow.

title: Savings and Loan Post Filled
description: The election of John J. Shee han as a director of the Wash ington Heights Federal Sav ings and Loan Association was announced yesterday. Mr. Shee han, who retired last year as cashier of The New York Times, replaces George D. Burchell, who resigned.

title: 17 Years After Watchdog Unit Began, Pier Crime Still Thrives
description: The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor was cre ated in 1953 to combat half a century of crime and corrup tion on the waterfront, of kick backs, usury and labor racke teering, of bloodied heads and murder.

title: Amman Describes a 24Hour Battle; 2 Tanks Destroyed, Guerrillas Assert
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 21 The Jordanian Army along with a Saudi Arabian battalion and Palestinian guerrillas, fought a 24hour running battle with an Israeli armored column of more than 60 tanks and other ar mored vehicles in the rugged mountains southeast of the Dead Sea, the Jordanian Army and Palestinian guerrillas an nounced tonight.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
Dayan Breaks Ankle Leaping From Copter
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 21  Defense Minister Moshe Day an fractured his right ankle today when he leaped onto rocky ground from a heli copter that was about to land.

title: Anthony J. De Andrade Dead; President of Pressmen's Union
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Anthony J. De Andrade, presi dent of the International Print ing Pressmen and Assistant's Union of North America, died yesterday, apparent of a heatr attack. He was 73 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: OCRACOKE ISLAND, N. C. A skim of ice twice the thickness of a window pane held the big skiff and its load of decoys in cold embrace at Quork's Ham mock Creek, and our guides, Earle Gaskins and Paul Teeter, were not happy.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: TONIGHT'S GAMES

title: President Cites Humphrey As Man of High Dedication
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) President Nixon mourned the death of former Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey today. He praised Mr. Humphrey as a man of firm purpose unremitting ef fort and high dedication.

title: Nigerian Reconciliation Seen
description: GENEVA, Jan. 21Henrik Beer, secretary general of the League of Red Cross Societies, said today that he saw a sincere desire for reconcilia tion among Nigerians and Biafrans. Speaking at a news conference on his return from Nigeria and an intensive two day tour of the former rebel region of Biafra, Mr. Beer said he had seen no sign that the Biafrans might be victims of genocide.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: PITTS AND CAFFEY DEALT TO CHICAGO
description: An interconference swap of two experienced quarterbacks  Charlie Johnson of the St. Louis Cardinals for Pete Beathard of the Houston Oilers  provided the highlight of four trades among pro football clubs yesterday.

title: Phone Company Says Service Is at Low
description: A New York Telephone Com pany executive said yesterday that phone service in and around the city was worse now then it had ever been, and he added that it would not im prove appreciably until the spring.

title: Clergymen Seek to Raise Million Bail for Panthers
description: A group of 30 churchmen and laymen have begun an attempt to raise bailin some cases by putting their church buildings up as collateralfor 16 Black Panthers who have been in jail since April 2 awaiting trial on bombing conspiracy charges.

title: W.H.O. Acts to Deter Smoking at Meetings
description: GENEVA, Jan. 21The Executive Board of the World Health Organization adopted a resolution today calling on persons attending its meet ings to refrain from smoking.

title: Arab Rebels Continue to Pose Challenge to Regime in Chad
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21De spite gestures by the Govern ment of Chad aimed at soothing tensions with Arab rebels, the Central African na tion remains beset by internal strife between Arab and black Chadians.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Crisis in Research

title: LINDSAY FORESEES NO NEVI TAX IN '70
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that no new city taxesinclud ing a rise in the income tax were likely this year despite a projected budget gap of $1.5 billion.

title: Horne Cooking That a Sultan Would Envy
description: CEDARHURST, L. LIn the homes of America, catered affairs notwith standing, there is probably no table more sumptuous, elaborate and exotic than that of the Raphael Elmalehs in this suburban village.

title: DRESS WORKERS WIN A 20% RAISE
description: Union dressmakers and the dress industry in the metropol itan market area reached agree ment yesterday on a new con tract that will give 80,000 work ers 20 per cent wage increases over three years.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Urges Senate To Reject Carswell Bid
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called yesterday upon the Senate to reject President Nixon's nomination of Judge G. Harold Carswell to the Su preme Court because of his pro segregation record.

title: BANK RATES ARE SET FOR MASSACHUSETTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) The Federal Deposit Insur ance Corporation set a ceiling today of 5 per cent on reg ular deposits that mutual sav ings banks may pay in Mas sachusetts.

title: Getty Reports Rise
description: Increased petroleum pro duction and higher prices for domestic crude oil enabled the Getty Oil Company to lift earnings in the fourth quar ter and the year 1969, the report disclosed yesterday.

title: Jeffrey Wohlstadter, Lawyer, Will Wed Barbara A. Harrison
description: SKOKIE, Ill., Jan. 21Mr. and Mrs. Bernard P. Harrison have made known the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Harrison, to Jeffrey K. Wohlstadter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Wohlstadter of Brooklyn, New York.

title: BITTER COLD WAVE GRIPS NORTHEAST
description: The Northeast continued yes terday to suffer from the bitter Arctic cold that brought tem peratures close to or below zero in parts of 30 states and caused major delays in transit and in terruption of some fuel service.

title: New Jack Byrne Agency Formed
description: The Shelton Towers Hotel (selected for its steam bath and swimming pool) is the temporary office of a new agency called Jack Byrne Advertising.

title: A Correction
description: James Goldman wrote the play A Lion in Winter, the authorship of which was credi ted to William Goldman in yes terday's film review of Anne of the Thousand Days. Wil liam Goldman, the brother of James, wrote the screenplay for Butch Cassidy and the Sun dance Kid as well as the book The Season.

title: China Berates U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 21  Ar ticles in the Chinese Commu nist press about the activities of the Nixon Administration at home and abroad have under lined the difficulties facing the American officials who resumed talks with representatives of Communist China in Warsaw yesterday.

title: Baldwin and Jones Set Reading of New Works
description: James Baldwin, the novel ist essayist and playwright, and LeRoi Jones, poetplay wright, will join in an eve ning of readings of their most recent works on Feb. 4 at Town Hall, 113 West 43d Street.

title: Study Finds Armed Whites Widely Involved in Civil Disorders
description: Armed white civilians were more widely involved in civil disorders during the last dec ade than is commonly believed, according to a study prepared by two scholars under a grant from the National Institute of Mental Health.

title: 14 AT FORDHAM OPT FOR CITY GUIDANCE
description: Fourteen Fordham students, charged with criminal trespass in campus disorders last Nov. 12, accepted six months' super vision by the city's Youth Counsel Bureau yesterday in lieu of trial.

title: LilyTulip to Relocate Headquarters in Spring
description: The LilyTulip division of OwensIllinois, Inc., announced yesterday it would transfer its headquarters from New York to Toledo this spring.

title: Observer: Guess What's Still Alive in Washington?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21We went to see Congress. It ap peared to be dead.

title: HARTACK GUIDES HIALEAH WINNER
description: MIAMI, Jan. 21It was no comment time once again at Hialeah today as Bill Hartack returned to Florida in triumph winning the $32,400 Hibiscus Stakes with the California colt, George Lewis.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Jan. 22, 1970 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Miss Michelle Holovak Betrothed
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) State Representative David E. Harrison, Democratic state chairman, is engaged to marry the daughter of a for mer Boston Patriots and Bos ton College football coach, the parents of the brideto be announced yesterday.

title: DOW JONES & CO. NAMES EXECUTIVES
description: Dow Jones & Company, Inc., promoted a number of its exec utives yesterday.

title: Toomey Named Top Athlete
description: LOS GATOS, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPDBill Toomey, the 30 yearold world decathlon rec ord holder, was named today the outstanding track and field athlete of 1969 by the maga zine Track and Field News.

title: Koppers Co.
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21Rec ord sales and earnings for 1960 were reported here today by the Koppers Company, a diver sified producer of chemicals, plastics and forest products, which also engineers and builds heavy equipment for the steel industry.

title: JAMES A. GREENE JR.
description: James A. Greene Jr., a for mer vice president of the 195 Broadway Corporation, a sub sidiary of the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company, died yesterday at a hospital in Opelika, Ala. He was 64 years old and lived at 49 Rockledge Road in Yonkers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Governors in the South Promise to Battle Busing
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 21 The flag of defiance, tattered but still politically useful, is flying once again here in this state capital and in others across the South where Federal courts have ordered massive school integration.

title: Research Shift in Pentagon Gives Services Wider Role
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21(AP) The Pentagon announced today that its chief research office was being trimmed in a move to give the individual armed services more respon sibility over their defense re search nroiects.

title: SavingsLoan Interest Rises Allowed; Banks and Thrift Units Increase Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  The Federal Home Loan Bank Board moved reluctantly to day to authorize the nation's savings and loan associations to pay higher interest rates on a wide variety of savings in struments.

title: SOVIET REAPPRAISAL ON MIDEAST IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 UPI) A State Department official said today that there had been some progress toward getting the Soviet Union to reconsider its rejection of United States peace proposals for the Middle East.

title: ShortChanging Education
description: In 1968, one month before he won the election, Richard M. Nixon said: When we talk about cutting the expense of government . . . the one area we can't shortchange is education. What was true then is even more pertinent today. The threatened veto of the $19.7billion appropriations bill for the Depart ments or Labor and Health, Education and Welfare is contrary both to the national interest and to the President's own promise.

title: Oh! Calcutta Producer Prefers Franchises to Road Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The producer of the contro versial play Oh! Calcutta! told a Senate subcommittee to day that the future of theat rical works produced in New York was in arranging fran chises for their production in other cities rather than putting together road companies.

title: Porsches Dominate Monte Carlo's Rally Entering Last Stage
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 21. (Reuters)  The West German Porsche of Sweden's Bo Walde gaard roared onto the dockside here today well ahead of the field after the first two stages of the Monte Carlo rally.

title: Moscow Ends Svetlana Alliluyeva's Soviet Citizenship
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 21The So viet Union has stripped Svet lana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Staliri, of her citizenship. Miss Alliluyvea defected to the United States in the spring of 1967, and now lives in Prince ton. N. J.

title: Legislative Hearing Is Told Subways Are Dirty and Unsafe
description: A procession of public offi cials and private citizens told a legislative committee yester day that the city's subways were dirty, didn't run on time and were sometimes unsafe.

title: STATE HIGH COURT EXTENDS GROUND FOR DIVORCE SUITS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21The Court of Appeals ruled today that separation decrees and agree ments obtained before the 1967 reform of the state divorce law could be considered grounds for divorce.

title: No Progress in G.E. Talks
description: J. Curtis Counts, head of the Federal Mediation and Concilia tion Service, finished his second week here yesterday as chief mediator in the General Elec tric Company strike talks with out any indication of movement toward a settlement of the 13 week walkout. He continued to meet separately with company officials and representatives of the two largest of the 13 unions representing 148,000 strikers, United Press International re ported.

title: WARD'S PLANS USING NEGROHELD BANKS
description: Montgomery Ward & Co., Chicago, following the lead of Sears, Roebuck & Co., is mak ing a substantial commitment to aid black capitalism.

title: BROOKLINE RINK GAINS IN CURLING
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 21The Country Club rink of Brookline, Mass., skipped by Mrs. Henry Jackson, led the way through the quarterfinal round tonight in the 16th an nual Empire State women's bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: Reynolds Advances
description: The Reynolds Metals Com pany, the nation's No. 2 aluminum producer, second only to Alcoa, increased fourthquarter earnings by 90.4 per cent and annual prof its by 85.8 per cent, accord ing to the 1969 statement issued yesterday in Richmond, Va.

title: Taft Files for Senate Race
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 21 (AP)  Representative Robert Taft Jr. filed petitions today to become a Republican candidate for nomination as United States Senator. His major opponent is expected to be Gov. James A. Rhodes. Mr. Taft yesterday gained the endorsement of the Hamilton Cuonty (Cincinnati) Republican Executive Commit tee on a 6838 vote.

title: Pilot Urges F.A.A. to Set Airport Safety Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI)  An airline pilot testi fied today that 223 persons killed in airline accidents since 1957 might still be alive if the Federal Aviation Administration had set minimum standards for airport safety.

title: Yablonski Inquest Set
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Jan. 21 (AP)  The inquest into the deaths of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter will be held Friday in a courtroom that will accommodate 200 persons, the Washington County Coro ner, Farrell Jackson, said today.

title: Foe Shells 55 Targets in Heaviest Attacks in 7 Weeks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21Enemy gunners fired rock ets and mortars into 55 military and civilian targets in South Vietnam last night in the most extensive shellings in seven weeks.

title: Formation of a National Group Is Urged as an Aid to Stewards
description: IF sufficient interest devel ops, a meeting to discuss the formation of an informal national federation of clubs devoted to ring stewarding at dog shows will be held in New York during the West minster Kennel Club Show in Madison Square Garden Feb. 9 and 10. The proposal was made by Alan J. Stern of Need ham, Mass., who is a steward, judge and breed er and a former president of the Stewards Club of New England.

title: Screen: Radicals in Love
description: THE way I look at it, says Mike to his girl, it boils down to this. You've got a brainand you've got a body. If you commit one and hold back the other, you're a phony. That's what liberals are all about. And before the next reel is out lovely Lee James has succumbed and has consummated a union that ought by rights have signified the start of a fine romance and an end to ideology.

title: Iraq Reports Executing 16 After Foiling Coup Attempt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 21  The Baghdad radio announced that 16 persons were executed today after an attempt to over throw the Iraqi Government failed.

title: PROFIT OF UTILITY TOPS $100MILLION
description: The American Electric Power Company's net income topped the $100million level for the the first time in 1969, Donald C. Cook, president, told yester day's luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

title: MarketPlace
description: THE dowager queen of the investment world, Ameri can Telephone and Telegraph, surprised and titillated Wall Street yesterday in announc ing an offering to sharehold ers of an intriguing new pack age of securities.

title: Squash Racquets
description: METROPOLITAN LEAGUE

title: EscapeClause Tariff Decisions Face Nixon on Pianos and Glass
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21A divided Tariff Commission has opened the way for President Nixon to raise the duty on pianos and some types of glass. The two separate escape clause cases will be the first Mr. Nixon must confront. They are the first to reach any President in years. The re port on glass was released to day, that on pianos last week. The present commission clearly differs from its recent predecessors on what tests must be met to win escape clause relief. Cases are now easier to win before the com mission. But the two cases also, disclose a wide diffusion of individual opinions.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW FIRM TREND
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange were fine yesterday, helped by selective buying.

title: Vincent C. Berberich, Head Of Jersey Highway Bureau
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Jan. 21 Vincent C. Berberich, super visor of highway engineers and chief of the Bureau of Urban Development for the New Jer sey Department of Transporta tion, died here yesterday at his home. He was 60 years old and lived at 3716 Liberty Ave nue.

title: BANKER CALLS U.S. IN RECESSION NOW
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 21 Robert E. Lewis, senior econ omist of the First National City Bank of New York, said here today that the United States is several months into a re cession.

title: Austrian Wins Pro Slalom
description: LE CLAUSEZ, France, Jan. 21 (AP)Egon Zimmerman of Austria won the special slalom of the pro ski tournament to day. In the final, Zimmerman defeated France's JeanLou ??.

title: ROBERT A. HOLTGREN
description: COLONIA, N. J., Jan. 21 Robert A. Holtgren, a program director for National Broad casting Company television in New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 48 years old and lived at 1 Runnymede Road. He was associated with N.B.C. for 20 years.

title: EURODOLLAR RATE DIPS ON U.S. MOVE
description: PARIS, Jan 21  Interna tional interest rates for the dol lar receded today, following the move taken yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: ROADS INTO BERLIN OBSTRUCTED BY REDS
description: BERLIN, Jan. 21The East Germans blocked access routes to West Berlin today in a spo radic sequence, apparently to protest against West German parliamentary committee ses sions scheduled to open here tomorrow.

title: FRANCE NOW SAYS LIBYANS WILL GET TOTAL OF 100 JETS
description: PARIS, Jan. 21The French deal for the sale of combat air craft to Libya is twice as large as originally announced, De fense Minister Michel Debre disclosed tonight.

title: D.C. Police and U.S. Agents Announce an Antigun Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  The District of Columbia police and the United States Treasury Department said today they would start a cooperative local Federal law enforcement crack down on guns in this city, making the joint campaign the first in the country against gun carrying criminals.

title: Michigan Utility Expanding Capital Outlays This Year
description: JACKSON, Mich., Jan. 21 (UPI)  The Consumers Power Company today announced plans to spend $232million on capital expansion in 1970, up from $198million in 1969.

title: Laver Thinks Bigger Than Australia
description: The phrase grand slam has become almost a part of Rod Layer's name. It's on his new aluminum racquet. And when he was awarded the Martini & Rossi Gold Racquet yesterday as the tennis player of 1969, he was applauded for having registered a grand slam of the world's four major championshipsUnited States, Wimbledon, Australia and France.

title: Vietcong Attack Delays Bicycle Race for 3 Hours
description: DINHQUAN, South Viet nam, Jan. 21 (AP)  The Vietcong delayed the Tour de Vietnam bicycle race for three hours today by attack ing South Vietnamese troops clearing the highway. One Government soldier was re ported killed.

title: The Family, to Lorenz, Is All
description: Dr. Konrad Lorenz, author of the widely read book On Aggression and a founder of the young science of ethol ogy (the study of animal be havior in the wild) argued yesterday that large and stable family groupings were essential to the survival of human society.

title: 3 Held in Yablonski Deaths; Cleveland Hearing Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The Federal Bureau of Investi gation announced here tonight the arrest of three men in Cleveland in connection with the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter three weeks ago.

title: A.C.L.U. Recalls Its Humble Beginning as It Marks 50th Birthday and Hails Founder
description: The beginnings of the Ameri can Civil Liberties Union were hardly auspicious. It was the winter of 1920. with much of America already engulfed by Red scares.

title: Allied Up Sharply
description: The Allied Chemical Cor poration reported yesterday that its earnings in 1969 would amount to about $2.44 a share, a strong improve ment over the 1968 perform ance of 64 cents a share, or $1.46 before extraordinary writeoffs and writedowns.

title: 30 M16 Rifles Stolen at Fort
description: FORT DEVENS. Mass., Jan. 21 (AP)The theft of 30 M16 rifles from a locked storage room here was disclosed today by the military police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. A military spokesman said in vestigators had some leads, but added that no arrests had been made.

title: Reputed Magia Chief Indicted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (UPI) Angelo Bruno, identified by the Fthe Federal Bureau of In vestigation as leader of an in terstate Cosa Nostra family, was indicted on tax conspiracy charges today following a three year investigation. The indict ment by a Federal Grand Jury here accused Mr. Bruno of con spiracy and aiding in prepara tion of a false incnme tax re turn for his wife for the year ??.

title: Lakers Purchase Tresvant
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPI)The Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball As sociation purchased a forward, John Tresvant, from the Seattle SuperSonics today.

title: Aide Says Hanoi Will Not Publish Prisoner List
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  The charg d'affaires of North Vietnam here said today that Hanoi would not publish the list of American pilots it holds prisoner.

title: PENGUINS' RALLY TIES SEALS, 33
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Penguins scored three goals tonight in the last 26 minutes to salvage a 33 tie with Oakland in a National Hockey League West Division game.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 22, 1970

title: Saigon Delegation Arrives In Israel to View Defenses
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 21 (Reuters) A sevenman South Vietnam ese delegation led by Senator Tran Van Don, a former gen eral who now is a member of the South Vietnamese Senate Committee for National Secu rity, arrived here today to study technical aspects of the Israeli defense forces.

title: Heart Patient, 9, Dies
description: HERMISTON, Ore., Jan. 21 (UPI)Becky Howland, 9 years old, who waited in vain two years for a heart transplant, died today. Doctors were un able to find a suitable heart for the child.

title: Giovanoli of Switzerland Captures Giant Slalom in Yugoslavia
description: KRANJSKA GORA, Yugosla via, Jan. 20 (UPI)Dumeng Giovanoli of Switzerland won giant slalom honors in the Vit ranc Cup men's Alpine ski tour nament today.

title: Bache Deletes Yearend Bonus; E. F. Hutton Trims Staff Pay
description: Bache & Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, will pay no yearend bonuses to its employes and all of its officers have accepted salary reductions as part of an overall policy to cut costs and improve profitability.

title: Advertising: Newspapers Want Data Bank
description: The nation's newspapers, whose share of the national advertising dollar has been declining steadily, appear to be moving toward some form of standardized audience research.

title: Waterfront Agency Is Split Over Testimony on Mafia
description: The two members of the bi state Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor split yester day over a dock worker's charge that Brooklyn longshore leaders, including Anthony Scotto, wanted him to join a socalled Mafia family led by Carlo Gambino. The split meant commission dismissal of that charge.

title: Athens, Disturbed by Political Rebuffs From the West, Is Increasing Trade Links With Soviet Bloc
description: ATHENS, Jan. 21The mili tarysupported Government of Greece, disturbed by recurring political snubs from the West, is moving to bolster economic relations with the Soviet bloc.

title: Brandt Asserts Germany Won't Be a Major Power
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany said yesterday, in a videotaped interview broad cast here, that Germany would never again become a major power.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
Nepal's Crown Prince To Marry on Feb. 27
description: Crown Prince Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva of Nepal and Crown Princess Aish warya Rajya Laxmi Devi Rana will be married on Feb. 27 in Katmandu, capital of the mountain kingdom The festivities in connection with the Hindu ceremony will last for two days.

title: A T.&T. IS SEEKING RECORD FINANCING OF $3.1BILLION
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company called on its giant stockholder family yesterday to help raise a record $3.1  billion for its expansion needs.

title: A CURB ON SPECIALS IN STORES IS BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (U.R.I) The Nixon Administration endorsed today a crackdown on supermarket bait advertising under present law rather than under a proposed new Federal Trade Commission rule.

title: Edwin John Beinecke Dies at 84; Headed Sperry and Hutchinson
description: Edwin John Belnecke, who became president of the Sperry and Hutchinson Company, the tradingstamp concern, in 1923, and remained as its chief ex ecutive under various titles until 1967, died yesterday in, Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 84 years old and lived on Cliff dale Road in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Leaking Tank Car's Fumes Fell
description: DICKINSON, W. Va., Jan. 21 (UPI)Nine persons were hospitalized tonight, and the area around the Dickinson Railroad Yards was sealed off when a tanker car began leaking lethal ammoniatype gas fumes.

title: Johnsons in Acapulco
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, Jan. 21 (AP)Former President and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson arrived here this afternoon from Austin, Tex., by private jet for what Mr.. Johnson called their first vacation since leaving the White

title: Marciano vs. Clay: A Computer Makes the Decision
description: Knocked out by a National Cash Register 315 computer in his Super Fight with Rocky Marciano, Cassius Clay emerged yesterday as a big cash winner.

title: JUDICIAL NICETIES HALT PROCEEDINGS
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 21  The niceties of judicial ethics forced the cancellation of a Supreme Court hearing in mid argument today, as one Justice disqualified himself from the case. There were not enough Justices left to hear it.

title: T. H. M'KITTRICK, WORLD FINANCIER
description: Thomas Harrington Mc Kittrick, who was president of the Bank for International Settlements during World War II, died yesterday at the New ton (N.J.) Nursing Home. He was 81 years old.

title: MOSCOW STRESSES PERIL FROM CHINA
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 21The So viet Defense Ministry news paper warned today against underrating Communist China's potential military threat to the security of the Soviet Union and other neighbors of the Chi nese.

title: Buchwald Agonizes As Play Rehearses
description: After Art Buchwald writes a newspaper column, he never retypes it. But he has al ready rewritten his first play, Sheep on the Runway, about 15 times.

title: Naval Officer Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Lieut. Terrence P. Ryan of Summit, N. J., of the Navy, has died of wounds suffered in the Vietnam war, the Pentagon an nounced today.

title: ASSEMBLY REJECTS TWO DOGFEE BILLS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21Dogs that are snagged and impounded by dogcatchers and the price their forlorn young masters might have to pay for their release were the major subject of de bate in the Assembly today.

title: Builders Hail Statement
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 21  The 51,000member National Asso ciation of Home Builders today applauded President Nixon's statement, but the organiza tion's officers were unable to list any specific commitments they had received from the White House.

title: Bid for Bail Cut Rejected
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP)I George L. Brady, charged with conspiracy and larceny in the disappearance of $749,000 from the Boston Common Under ground Garage, was denied a bid for freedom today. Justice John V. Spalding of the State Supreme Court denied a motion that Mr. Brady be released in personal recognizance or in no more than $5,000 bond. Mr. Brady is being held in $200,000 bond.

title: Los Angeles Archbishop Timothy Manning
description: IRELAND, once a great source of priests for the Roman Catholic Churches in America, on occasion has contributed a cleric who ad vanced to the episcopacy. In that traditron is Timothy Manning, who yesterday suc ceeded James Francis Card inal McIntyre as Archbishop of Los Angeles. Indeed, when Timothy Manning at the age of 18 came from Mun gret College in Limerick to St Patrick's Sem inary in Menlo Park, Calif., to finish his junior and senior year of college and go through the four years of theological study, he had just the right touch of brogue, according to a re tired theologian who taught at St. Patrick's in the early nineteenthirties, the Rev. Dr. Lyman A. Fenn.

title: Air Force Dismissal Appealed!
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) A. Ernest Fitzgerald, an Air Force efficiency expert who lost his job last November after disclosing soaring costs on the C5A jet transport program, asked the Civil Service Com mission today to reinstate him. Mr. Fitzgerald and the Ameri can Civil Liberties Union filed an appear, asking the commis sion to overrule his dismissal from his $31,784ayear job.

title: RAIN JOINS FIELD FOR CROSBY GOLF
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21The shops in nearby Car mel are selling Crosby boots. A team of meteorologists pre dicts rain and storms during the next four days. These are regarded as typical portents for the $125,000 Bing Crosby pro amateur golf tournament that begins tomorrow.

title: Nigerians Detain 80 Newsmen After Biafran Trip
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 21 About 80 foreign journalists were held by Nigerian military authorities in Port Harcourt to night and were prevented, at least temporarily, from re turning to the former Biafran enclave.

title: JAMES J. WELDON, POLICE AIDE, DEAD
description: James J. Weldon, a former deputy chief inspector of the Police Department, died in his car at the entrance to the Queens Midtown Tunnel Tues day afternoon, apparently of a heart attack.

title: No Optimism at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 21Diplomats who have been closely following the Big Four talks on the Middle East said today they saw no signs that would justify French ex pressions of hope for an early ArabIsraeli peace.

title: Biafrans Returning Home to Uncertainties
description: OWERRI, Nigeria, Jan. 19 The hardpressed people of Bia fra finally have peace  but little else.

title: Philadelphia Bank Sells All Of Small Investor Notes
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (AP)  Two weeks after the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company put its $20million is sue of low  denomination, high interest notes on sale, they were sold out. The new notes were designed to attract the dollars of the small saver.

title: Court Upholds Dismissal Of Two Sheppard Suits
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld today dismissal of two damage suits filed by Dr. Sam Sheppard, who was imprisoned for 10 years on charges that he murdered his wife but was acquitted at a second trial.

title: West's Welcome Mat Is Out for Hull
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24 (AP) The National Hockey League's West Division, loser to the East by 41 in last night's AllStar game, will have a little extra going for. it in next year's game at Boston.

title: Washington Record
description: THE PRESIDENT Humphrey. President Nixon issued a statement mourning the death of George M. Hum phrey, former Treasury Sec retary. Mr. Humphrey was praised as a man of firm purpose, unremitting effort and high dedication.

title: OIL AN ELEMENT IN FRENCH POLICY
description: PARIS, Jan. 21OilFrance's need of it, the hope of her in ternational companies to pro duce more of itis a factor in French diplomacy in Libya and the other Arab countries.

title: Salesmen Fight Plan
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., a large member organization of the New York Stock Exchange, told its sales staff yesterday that its percentage of com missions on securities transac tions was being reduced under a new compensation plan.

title: A Little Law Goes a Long Way
description: The major airlines have demonstrated once more that in private industry nothing so encourages volun tary action in the public interest as a hint of coercion on the part of government. Until this week the lines were stoutly maintaining the position laid down by the Air Transport Association last August that it would cost the industry $30 millionand take until the end of 1974to bring an end to pollution of the skies with jetengine smoke.

title: Sellout in Paris
description: The Gaullist Government of French President Pompi dou has stooped to a new low in international irre sponsibility with its decision to sell thirty Mirage jet fighters and twenty training planes to Libya in addition to fifty Mirages previously ordered. This new arms deal with one of the most belligerent of Arab states sweeps away any lingering pretense that France still seeks to help maintain some kind of arms balance and to promote peace in the Middle East.

title: The Computer Fight
description: ROCKY MARCIANO did not like Muhammad Ali. Some years ago, Marciano said that Ali's conduct in and out of the ring reflected unfavorably on all boxers, and in retrospect chipped away at his own formidable repu tation. Kids don't seem to be as interested in boxing any more, said Marciano, wistfully. I do a lot of afterdinner speaking and I find it's the fathers, not the sons, who ask the questions and come up afterward. It's a very bad situation now because there's a lack of respect for the present champion, and that creates a lack of respect for all past champions. Nobody questions my fights, they were all tough ones, but people just don't treat you the same way since he came along.

title: PASS INTERFERENCE GETS ADDED PENALTY
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) College football's rules mak ers stiffened the penalty against pass interference and announced today a plan that could elimi nate belowthewaist blocking.

title: Israelis React Bitterly
description: JERUSALEM, Jan 21Israeli officials spoke bitterly tonight of reports from Paris that France had agreed to increase her order of Mirage jet fighters to Libya.

title: Valerie A. Kent, James H. Taylor Planning to Wed
description: Miss Valerie Anne Kent and James Hopkins Taylor plan to be married on March 21 in Nairobi, Kenya, where the future bride's father, a retired British Army officer, operates a safari business.

title: Essex County Sheriff Ordered To Halt Sale of Special Badges
description: NEWARK, Jan. 21The Es sex County Sheriff was ordered by a judge today to halt the issuing of honorary badges fol lowing a recent disclosure that two alleged gamblers were carrying them at the time of their arrest.

title: GAS DISCOVERIES CITED IN 2 AREAS
description: Discoveries of natural gas in the North Sea off Britain and in northern California were an nounced yesterday.

title: CASSOU CONNECTS ON RAM REBOUND
description: It's nice to go traveling, but there's no place like home. Tordham, which hadn't played basketball in its Rose Hill gym for more than a month, came home last night to score a 6261 victory over the Uni versity of Massachusetts.

title: MRS. WALLACE MARTIN
description: Mrs. M. Gladdieus Martin, a former member of the New York State Commission of the Blind, died Tuesday at Manettee Memorial Hospital, Bradenton, Fla., apparently of heart fail ure. She was 77 years old, the widow of Wallace J. Martin.

title: CITY PANEL BACKS PROJECT NEAR U.N.
description: The City Planning Commis sion yesterday narrowly ap proved the controversial plan to build a $300million glass enclosed office and public building complex across First Avenue from the United Na tions headquarters.

title: Israelis Tell of Little Resistance To Most Extensive Attack Since '67
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 21Israeli armored units this evening completed their most extensive ground operation since the sixday war of June, 1967, a 23hour attack against Arab guerrillas in Jordan south of the Dead Sea.

title: 5 Young Conductors Reach Mitropoulos Contest Finals
description: Five young orchestra con ductors from four countries were chosen as finalists in the 1970 Dimitri Mitropoulos Inter national Music Competition yesterday following semifinal auditions held at Carnegie Hall Tuesday and yesterday. The finals will he held Sunday at Carnegie Hall before an invited audience.

title: M'CARTHY REVOLT EBBS IN MINNESOTA
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 19Two years ago, supporters of Sena tor Eugene J. McCarthy flooded into the Democratic party's pre cinct caucuses in every section of Minneapolis and St. Paul.

title: Minutemen Leader Guilty
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 21 (AP)Robert DePugh, leader of the Minutemen, was convicted by a Federal District Court jury today, of bond jumping. Sen tencing will be deferred at least 25 days. He was returned to the Federal penitentiary at Leaven worth, Kan., where he is serv ing a oneyear term on a Fed eral firearms violation. DePugh was charged with willful failure to appear for trial in the Dis trict Court on Dec. 3, 1968.

title: TANGUYPRIGENT, LED BRETON ANTINAZIS
description: PARIS, Jan. 21  Franois TanguyPrigent, a Resistance hero and member of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's first post war Cabinet, died last night at his home in Morlaix in Britanny after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

title: Elizabeth Terlep Prospective Bride
description: ELKHART, Ind., Jan. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Vincent B. Terlep have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ward Terlep, to Kevin Michael O'Connell, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. O'Connell of Ridgewood, N. J. The wedding is planned for June 27.

title: De la Renta and Brooks Concur on Lower Hems
description: OSCAR started the day and Donald ended it. This put fashion enthusiasts roughly in the same state that the rock crowd would be in if it faced the Beatles and the Rolling Stones on the same bill. Both Oscar de la Renta and Donald Brooks are among the half dozen or so leaders of the fashion force that looks to New York for what's happening. And so both were obligated yester day to assert their leader ship position by dropping hemlines.

title: STOLLE DEFEATS ROSEWALL, 63, 75
description: Serving consistently and vol leying sharply, Fred Stolle of Australia defeated one of his countrymen, Ken Rosewall, 63, 75, for the $2,000 singles prize in last night's opening program of the sixth Madison Square Garden invitation tennis tour nament.

title: Carborundum Adds Unit
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Jan. 21 (UPI)The Carborundum Company ??nounced today for mation of a pollution control division. The new unit will coor dinate and expand Carborun dum's manufacture and market ing of systems and equipment for the control of air and water pollution.

title: Army Acts to Close Coast Coffee House Where G.I.'s Relax Off Duty and Damn the War
description: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 21 In a quiet block far from the noise and the neon glitter of Tacoma's G.I. town, the coffee house sits almost hid den in a narrow, shabby store front.

title: RECEPTIVE AUDIENCE FOR MISS PARKINSON
description: Zaidee Parkinson had the kind of audience for her debut recital at Carnegie Recital Hall last night that every young pianist would probably like to have. It almost filled the hall and included many people prominently identified with the arts here. Miss Parkinson, who is the wife of Richard Dufallo, the conductor, gave them the music of two composers Schumann's Davidsbilndler tnze and Book I of Debussy's Preludes.

title: Wille Hinted for F.D.I.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks since 1964, is a leading con tender to head the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Republican sources disclosed today.

title: Creation of a New Puerto Rican District stirs Controversy
description: The newly proposed Congres sional district embracing parts of the Bronx. Manhattan and Queens has become known as the Puerto Rican 21st, but Puer to Ricans and some politicians agree that the descriptive title is half truth at best.

title: POLL ABROAD SEES U.S. AS TOP NATION
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21 Citizens in key countries of the Western world predict that the United States will have the leading position in science and the strongest military forces in the years ahead, the Gallup organization reported today.

title: Screen: 'Change of Habit':'House of Cards' Also Shares Double Bill
description: THERE's something good to be said for do-gooders to judge by "Change of Habit" and "House of Cards," the mixed bag of brightly colored dedication and melodrama that was opened yesterday at local houses. In short, the good guys triumph in good causes, more or less, a fact that's been commendable even before film was invented.But each item in this double bill is merely exemplary of professional technique and dialogue rather than memorable characterization and emotion. And, despite the obvious fireworks and sincerity, "Change of Habit" and "House of Cards" simply emerge as satisfactory entertainments.Since they are not literally comparable, it should be noted that "Change of Habit" is a mite closer to true dedication than "House of Cards." In "Change of Habit," the 35-year-old Elvis Presley, is, believe it or not, starring in his 31st film, this time as the hip, devoted medico heading a clinic in a Latin-Negro slum neighborhood.He is abetted by three nuns, portrayed by Mary, Tyler Moore, Barbara McNair and a newcomer to movies, Jane Elliot, who shed their traditional habits and are secretly sent out in fetching miniskirts and hairdos to get closer to the laity while alleviating suffering as nurses in that clinic.Devoted Presley fans, who have been fascinated by his swaying hips and rock rhythms ever since the 1956 "Love Me Tender," should know that he strums the guitar to a few new tunes (including a rock spiritual in a church) this time too. But he is mostly the somewhat subdued, callow, slightly unconvincing and largely mystified Pasteur to the poor throughout most of the proceedings.He can't be blamed, really. As a speech therapist, Miss Moore gets herself involved with an autistic child, a stuttering, dangerously sick, teen-age Puerto Rican boy, and, amorously, with our confused hero. Miss McNair, as the black nun and herself a ghetto product, is really caught up with her own militant black "brothers" as well as the local loan shark tycoon, and Miss Elliot's run-in with supermarket scroungers eventually drives her from the church.Let's face it. Nuns and their habits have changed and if the religious they portray seem a bit too with it, enough to raise the hackles of their reactionary parish priest, Mr. Presley can't be faulted for remarking confusedly, "I get a feeling there's a message here." But it's only a slight and not terribly impressive one.The message is a good deal slighter but set in an infinitely more complex adventure format in "House of Cards," the adaptation of the 1967 Stanley Ellin novel that was shot in Italy and France. In this case, George Peppard, as an itinerant boxer-writer-drifter in France, becomes enmeshed in single-handedly combating a sinister, neo-Fascist group bent on taking over Europe and, perhaps, America.Mr. Peppard is bland, tough and athletic as the impecunious adventurer, who is hired as a tutor of Inger Stevens's young son. Miss Stevens is not only pretty enough to turn any adventurer's head, but also, it turns out, is surrounded by a coterie of her late general-husband's relatives, millionaire refugees from Algiers, and others bent on fomenting that vague takeover, who have labeled her an alcoholic and generally unstable.The foggy indications are that Mr. Peppard is a gent, who is sort of opposed to their dirty plans, and a red-blooded American boy, who only casually has eyes for that rich widow-lady, Miss Stevens.Set against the opulent backgrounds of a Parisian mansion, a chateau in Dijon and Roman settings such as the Colosseum, his efforts to free her and her kidnapped son, become a long, improbable but action-filled chase, strewn with a half-dozen killings, in which complicated incidents often mystify rather than excite a viewer.Mr. Peppard, as noted, is an indestructible citizen, who, like the rest of the cast, is aided by some casual but sometimes effective lines. Miss Stevens is attractive either in gowns or practically nothing, as she shares a train berth with her rescuer. As members of that dastardly crew, Keith Michell, Ralph Michael, and Orson Wells help keep a viewer attentive on several occasions. Welles again plays a bearded, malevolent, Buddha-like villain that has become almost a stereotype. And, one got the feeling finally that "House of Cards," despite all the complications, is largely a stereotype too.

title: Buzea's Pinkerton Betrays Butterfly And Also Puccini
description: Lieut. Benjamin Franklin Pinkerton is, of course, a cad and a clod, and it's hard to understand what dear little Cio CioSan sees in him. But, if that happens to be the average tenor's interpretation of his part in Madama Butterfly, there are nonetheless subtler ways to delineate the character than Ion Buzea discovered last night in his first Pinkerton for the Metropolitan Opera.

title: MANSFIELD AFFIRMS FIGHT FOR TROOP CUT
