title: Screen: Johnny Cash Onstage and Off:Elfstrom Documentary at Theaters Here Among the Highlights, a Remarkable Debut
description: JOHNNY CASH: THE MAN, HIS WORLD, HIS MUSIC," which opened yesterday at the De Mille and several other theaters in this area, is a slightly lengthened version of a documentary shown last March over the National Educational Television network. Directed by Robert Elfstrom, the movie was fine on television, and it seems to me even better in the theater, where the color is truer, the visual detail finer and the audience situation more properly theatrical.Among the depressing clutch of cinma-vrit documentaries, "Johnny Cash" stands out both because its principal people are performers who belong onstage and because Elfstrom handles his camera with restraint unusual in a field much given to palming off trickery as truth.The movie follows Cash through parts of a few regular concerts, a prison concert, a concert and visit on a South Dakota Indian reservation and a recording session with Bob Dylan ("One Too Many Mornings"). Between times, Cash rests at home with his wife, June Carter, accepts a Country Music Record of the Year award, meets fans and auditions a couple of hopefuls.Although much time is given over to a visit to the Dyess Colony in northern Arkansas, where, in the mid-1930's, Cash spent his childhood, it never pretends that it is interpreting the "Johnny Cash phenomenon." At one point, Cash, who grew up in poverty and reported an income of $2-million in 1968, says "I've learned to adapt very well to prosperity," and indeed he has, and he is no fool, and the film knows when to leave well enough alone.We are given many remarkable performances (more good songs than on any combination of Johnny Cash records I've been able to put together) and many remarkable glimpses of a man who in performance is well worth looking at. With his fight pants, ruffled shirt and massive frock coat (like the costume of a misplaced 18th-century highwayman), his massive frame, deeply lined face and utterly expressionless eyes he seems perfectly self-contained and wholly without need for the accoutrements of amiable stage personality.He is superb onstage, reserved and very decent off stage with his fans (a fine and rigorously uncondescending filming of a meeting with autograph seekers) or with family and friends in Dyess. Privately he is not so impressive, as if he were straining toward a slightly unnatural posture of meditative depth, except when he is with Miss Carter  whose open-featured, humorous and intelligent good looks work to humanize the Johnny Cash presence and whose musical talent (for example, in the rendition of "Jackson") helps to make that presence interesting.The best sequence in "Johnny Cash: The Man, His World, His Music" doesn't feature Cash, or June Carter, or even Mother Maybelle or the Tennessee Three. Rather, it introduces a young man who is not, I believe, mentioned in the screen credits.His name is Don Freed, and he auditions two songs for Cash ("Bank of Mariposa" and "Come Away from the Roadside"). He plays the harmonica and the guitar, and he sings in a tight, pleading voice that seems to know all the conventions and truths of sadness. I think he is extraordinary, and if there were no other attraction (there are many), he would be reason enough for seeing the movie.

title: M.T.A. to Offer New Route For the 2d Avenue Subway
description: William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority, said yesterday that he would present to the Board of Estimate next week an alternative plan for the pro posed Second Avenue subway that would serve the needs of residents of both the Lower East Side and of Brooklyn.

title: Liquori Will Get Vocal Support In Meet at Philadelphia Tonight
description: What makes Marty Liquori run? My grandparents, the 20yearold Villanova jun ior from Cedar Grove, N.J., said recently. They follow all my races, and one of my grandmothers lights candles and prays for me every time I run.

title: William M. Emery, Founder Of Better Sleep Company
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N. J., Jan. 23William Mills Emery, president and chairman of the Better Sleep Manufacturing Company here, makers of sleep ing aids and comfort devices, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 72 years old and lived at 44 Pitts ford Way, New Providence.

title: AUGUSTS G. PRATT, ENGINEER, 88, DIES
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 23  Auguste G. Pratt, former chairman of the board of the Babcock & Wilcox Company, New York engineering concern, died apparently of a heart at tack at his home here last night, at 345 Walnut Street. He was 88 years old.

title: Pistons Win in Overtime
Art: Jewish Museum Retrospective for Artist of 36
description: SOME friends of mine with children of kindergarten age reported to me recently that their 5yearold son, Play School class of '69, was graduated last June in full academic regalia. The idea behind the ceremony seems to have been that with things going the way they are in the universities, this might he the last chance the boy would have to wear a cap and gown.

title: Former Tax Agent Guilty In $3,000 Bribe Charge
description: A former Internal Revenue Service agent was found guilty by a Federal Court jury in Brooklyn late Wednesday night of receiving a $3,000 bribe to refrain from further tax exam ination of several related Long Island corporations.

title: Richey, Graebner, Froehling Advance in Florida Tennis
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP)Cliff Richey, sec ondranked player in the United States, reached the semifinals of the Austin Smith tennis tournament today with a 62, 60 rout of Bill Higgins, the top ranked teaching pro in the country.

title: Angus Deming of Newsweek Marries Madlyn Ann Millimet
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Jan. 24Miss Madlyn Ann Milli met, who is on the editorial staff of Newsweek magazine, and Angus Deming, a general editor of Newsweek, were married here this afternoon in the chapel of the Brookside Congregational Church by the Rev. David B. Shirley.

title: Cutups and cutouts
description: Two architectural students at Yale turned l9by29foot, oneroom apartment over a ga rage into two bedrooms, a guest room, living room and a dining roomkitchen with the expenditure of $400and a lot of work. Andrus Burr and Peter Rose used plywood to reshape and rewall the apartment. They painted it white and cut openings with a saber saw for storage units for clothes and furniture. Two little sleeping houses with pitched roofs give each man privacy. The re sult, says Burr, is like a space capsule. It certainly not everyone's idea of heaven, but parents faced with the necessity of dividing, up a room for two or more children might find these young spacemaking ideas useful.

title: Business Index Rose in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Ac tivity rose last week to 360.9 from a revised 345.2 a week earlier. A year ago it was 346.0.

title: Brumberg Resigns as the Editor Of U.S. Journal on Communism
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  After 13 years as editor in chief of one of the most prestigious publications on communism, Abraham Brumberg will return next week to the fulltime pur suit of scholarship, and, time permitting, to his hobby, com posing Marxist jingles.

title: Brazil Reported Bidding For Bolivian Petroleum
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 24 (Reu ters) Brazil has joined four other contenders Spain, Ar gentina, Mexico and the Soviet Unionin offering to buy Bo livian petroleum products, the Government announced today.

title: Nancy Nims Is Bride Of Tames Mullins 3d
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 24 Miss Nancy Barbara Nims, daughter of Mrs. Thomas L. Nims of Darien, and the late Mr. Nims, was married here this afternoon to James Mc Kinley Mullins 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mullins Jr. of St. Louis.

title: Alan Endler to Wed Linda Herbert
description: The engagement of Miss Linda Gail Herbert to Alan Endler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Endler of Brockton, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Herbert of New York. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: Do We Need Those Troops in Europe?
description: WASHINGTONWith Viet namization of the Vietnam war sufficiently established in the conversation of this city that most statesmen can roll the word out without dropping a syllable, there now is a new semantic challenge: the Euro peanization of the defense of Europe.

title: Troops Act in Londonderry After Religious Violence
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Jan. 24 (AP)British troops erected barbedwire bar riers in the main streets here tonight after a series of violent clashes between Roman Catho lics and Protestants.

title: POWER BOAT UNIT TO GET AFFILIATE
description: The Council of the American Power Boat Association took a step toward acquiring the Na tional Drag Boat Association as an affiliate yesterday when it recommended that a tentative agreement for such action be directors of the drag racing passed along for consideration to the A.P.B.A. Executive Corn mittee. Authorization for ap proval or disapproval by the executive committee was taken

title: RadiationEmitting Products Now Under U.S. Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) Color television sets, micro wave ovens, sun lamps and other electronic products emit ting radiation are now under the control of Federal regula tions.

title: Count Your Balanchine Blessings
description: IT IS dangerously easy to take people for granted. Dance critics always take their hometown companies for granted and suspect that dance audiences fall into the same almost in evitable trap. When I was a Londoner, I took the Royal Ballet for granted; now, as New Yorker, I take New York City Ballet for grant ed. But once in a while I do have the grace to sit back and count my blessings. Let this be just such a once in a while.

title: Pedestrian Shot Near Home
description: A 48yearold man was shot in the arm yesterday morning while walking on the Lower East Side. But the man, Marion Mendez, of 577 Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, told the po lice that he was unaware that he had been wounded as he approached the intersection of Norfolk and Rivington Streets shortly after 11 A.M. When he returned home and removed his jacket, he saw blood and a puncture in his right fore arm, so he called the police and went to Beth Israel Hos pital for treatment.

title: The News  With a Dash of Dirt
description: EYEWITNESS NEWS is the catchy title that WABCTV (Channel 7) has bestowed on its two evening wrapups of local events, but to at least this eye witness the show might better be called Wiseguy News. Consider a typical performance by anchorman Roger Grimsby:

title: A fan's notes on the Amazing Knicks
description: CONSIDER one Knick fan. He has followed the team for years, has suffered with them when they were separate on the court, and now that they are togetherconsid ers them not only the best team in the N.B.A. but the best theater in town. Not the average Knick fan certainly but typical in that he long ago dis covered there was a certain kind of evening in New York when Madison Square Garden was the only place he wanted to be, and typical above all in this: like perhaps 90 per cent of the men who come to watch the Knicks, he once played the game of basketball himself, which is to say, a shocking number of his vivid mem ories are built around the feel of the ball, the sound of it on concrete or hardwood, the sight of it dropping through the net. So that, though sit ting in the stands and removed from the action, he is never quite a spec tator at the Garden, but as near to a participant as at onceremove is ever possible, his identification, his sus pense, his engagement almost total.

title: 2YearOld Is Rescued After 7 Hours in Well
description: MIAMI, Jan. 24 (UPI) Rescue workers pulled two yearold John Reynolds 3d tonight from a narrow well shaft. The child, covered with mud and sobbing hys terically, had hung suspended over deep water for nearly seven hours. The child, with a physician, was rushed to a nearby hospital. His mother wept quietly. Thank God. Oh, thank God.

title: No One Can Afford to Be a Playboy, Says Claude Terraii, and Yet. . .
description: HE'S an international eligible, deter mined not to be caught; a man about many towns, and a holder of the Croix de Guerre who plays with toys.

title: FLAT PLAN URGED BY COAST GUARD
description: Planning a long cruise for the day, week, or longer?

title: Soviet Skater Sets Mark
description: ALMA ATA, U.S.S.R., Jan. 24 (AP)  Valeri Muratov set a world record of 1 minute 19.25 seconds in the 1,000meter speedskating event today, ac Cording to Tass, the Soviet press agency. Last week Mura ??ov broke the 500meter world record at a national champion ship in Alma Ata.

title: Amateur Interest Key to Increase in FerroCement BoatBuilding
description: Ferrocement boat build ing should continue to make rapid advancements in the early part of the 1970's, it has been predicted by a noted naval ar chitect.

title: 2 New Lapstrake Models Highlighting Lymin's Line
description: Four boats, two of them new, are in the Lyman Boat Works. All are built of lapstrake marine plywood. The new ones are 30foot and 23foot versions of the company's successful 26foot Offshore, which also is on display. The other boat being shown is a 22foot run about.

title: Jocelyn V. Latz Bride Of LaRoy W. Master
description: Miss Jocelyn Violet Latz and LaRoy William Master were married here yester day afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cath edral by the Rev. Dennis Mc Neils, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS URGE END TO WAR
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 24 The Democratic State Com mittee urged President Nixon today to move promptly and decisively toward a complete military withdrawal from Viet nam.

title: Four Students Seek Rural Road Design To Aid Environment
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 24 A team of four students at the Harvard Graduate School of Design is trying to find out if rural highways can be laid out in ways that systematically avoid eroding the soil, polluting the air and harming both wild life and human communities along the road.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Defeats St. Francis, 7163, Here
description: Fairleigh Dickinson Univer sity's basketball team defeated St. Francis, 7163, last night at the 69th Regiment Armory. The victors held a 2927 half time lead.

title: Dr. Henry Acken, 70, Dies; Headed Obstetrics Group
description: UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 24Dr. Henry S. Acken, a gynecologist and past president of the medi cal board of the Methodist Hos pital in Brooklyn, died last night in a hospital here. He was 70 years old.

title: William Burke, ExDirector Of Madison Sq. Garden, 74
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24 (UPI)  William Burke, a for mer director of New York's Madison Square Garden and manager of some of the world's biggest ice shows, died at his home last night of emphysema.

title: Murphy Scores 33 Points
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 24 (UPI)Calvin Murphy scored 33 points tonight as Niagara University deefated Providence, 9485.

title: Yiddish Is Mapped by Computer Here
description: Yiddish is such a natural mode of expression that, as has often been said, it speaks for itself. But from one region to another, Yiddish changes in vocabulary, pronunciation and even gender.

title: FIVE LUXURY CRAFT DUE FROM DEAN
description: The bold silhouettes of au thentic North Sea trawlers with their traditional shippy high sheer and doughty superstruc tures will become part of the American yachting scene this spring.

title: Reserve Clause Breeds Bitterness
description: BITTER feelings about base ball's reserve clause, and bitter feelings towards those who challenge it, are noth ina new.

title: Dairy Spending By U. S. Drops
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)The Government spent $242million last year for dairy products, equivalent to 4.3 billion pounds of milk purchased by the Commodity Credit Corporation under farm price support programs.

title: LANCASTER BUILDER LEADER IN DIVERSITY
description: Trojan Boats; with luxury class lines in wood and fiber glass and combinations of both materials; has a diversity of boats on display. The Lan caster, Pa., builder's show boats include a new 34foot allfiberglass houseboat, a 36 foot tricabin cruiser in wood and fiberglass and a new 25 foot sport fisherman, also in fiberglass.

title: Miss. State Wins, 7977
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., Jan. 24 (UPI)Jack Bouldin hit a 10 foot jump shot with two sec onds remaining today to give Mississippi State a 7977 vic tory over Florida.

title: They Fight In Mideast With Arms
description: WASHINGTON  The heavy flow of jets and other modern arms to the Middle East since the 1967 ArabIsraeli war has all but eliminated one of the prindipal hopes of forcing the contending parties to make peace, in the view of a growing number of MidEast experts in Government and in academia.

title: Susan Schorr Plans Nuptials
description: GREAT NECK, LI., Jan. 24  Miss Susan Robin Schorr, a student at the Mills College of Education, and Joel Elliott Lehrman, who attends C. W. Post Col lege, have become engaged.

title: Owners at Seaside Face Peril of Uninsured Losses
description: F'RE ISLAND, L. T.Hun dreds of owners of sum mer homes that have been left vulnerable to dam age by future storms due to the erosion of protective dunes here face a complete financial loss because flood insurance cannot be obtained in the United States.

title: Single Pregnant Girls Ask Help, Not Reproach,
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  A dozen girls talked publicly here this weekend about what it's like to be young, single and pregnant.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: YANCEY, AT 209, LEADS BY STROKE
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 24Sunshine for the Bing Crosby golf tournamentthe end of inclement or Crosby weather associated with rain and gale windswas as news worthy today as Bert Yancey's 209 that gave him the 54hole lead.

title: Court on Protesters
description: In 1967, Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, then director of the Selective Service, sent a letter to draft boards throughout the country in which he encouraged them to accelerate induction of young men who turned in their draft cards in protest against the Vietnam war.

title: Temple Outswims Fordham
description: Temple overpowered Ford ham yesterday in swimming, 7232, at Fordham. Kyle Robin son of Temple led the scoring, winning the 200yard individual medley and the 200yard back stroke.

title: FIBERGLASS CLARK IS 14FOOT THISTLE
description: An addition to the Douglass & McLeod Thistle and High lander onedesign sailboats at the show is the. 14foot CLark., All three are fiberglass center board sloops.

title: Against educating for the future until the future is past
description: Of all the books spawned in re cent years and months by the crisis of the universities, Robert Paul Wolff's The Ideal of the University is surely one of the most important, one of the few that can without hesi tation be called essential. Wolff (who is professor of philosophy at Columbia and author of The Pov erty of Liberalism) brings an un compromising rigor of analysis to the continuing debate on the uses and misuses of the university. His critique is explicitly radical  ana lytically and rationally radical  aimed at uncovering the often un conscious assumptions by which the universities do business. The result is not an easy or a popular book, but that should be read.

title: Amateur Wins Dunlop Golf
description: JOHANNESBURG. South Af rica, Jan. 24 (AP)  John Fourie, a South African ama teur, heat some of the world's leading professional golfers to day in winning the Dunlop Masters golf championship with a 72hole score of 266. Gary Player of South Africa was sec ond with 272. Bob Charles, the lefthanded New Zealand star, was third with 274.

title: CareCenter Chief Sees 100,000 Child Addicts Here by Summer
description: The clinical director of Odys sey House, a therapeutic organ ization for drug addicts, pre dicted yesterday that juvenile heroin addition in New York City would rise to 100,000 chil dren by summer.

title: Pollution 1: Political Issue but In a Good. Cause
description: WASHINGTONOn the open ing day of the Congressional session last Monday, Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, made a long speech on how Americans, in their head long, heedless pursuit of wealth, had fouled their own house. But he was not entirely despairing, for he found a great awakening underway and a massive coali tion of interests forming to halt the pollution, and to cleanse and restore the nation's natural heritage.

title: Gandhi and King Honored
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 24 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi dedicated a memorial plaza here this week in memory of Gandhi and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Mrs. Gandhi who was not related to the leader of the Indian independ ence movement  said that although the two men had never met, their mission was the same: to put an end to ine qualities and hatreds.

title: Chiefs' Marsalis Cited
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 24 (AP)  Jim Marsalis, a former Tennessee State star, who helped lead the Kansas City Chiefs to the Super Bowl, will be named professional athlete of the year by the Tennessee Sports Hall of Fame Feb. 20. Roscoe Tanner, a Stanford University junior tennis star from Chattanooga, Tenn., will be named amateur athlete of the year at the same gathering.

title: Education
description: Each year, amid much trauma, well over one million high school seniors labor for three hours over the Scholastic Apti tude Tests, the multiplechoice examinations that are supposed to predict a candidate's verbal and matliematical capacity. The SAT's are required as an im portant college admissions clue by the more than 800 member institutions of the College En trance Examination Board, a 70 yearold nonprofit organization. The importance of the tests has grown as more and more high school graduates have tried to crash the selective, highpres tige colleges.

title: Drake Downs Louisville
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 24 (AP)  Jeff Halliburton's 16 point performance in the sec ond half paced Drake to an 8675 victory over Louisville today in a Missouri Valley Con ference basketball game. The triumph kept Drake in first place in the conference.

title: Even Maid Service Is Provided on Those Floating, Super Condomariniums
description: A new concept in luxury yachtingthe condomarin ium  aimed at attracting vacationers who want to dis cover the excitement and beauty of the sea without giving up their aircondi tioned, landbased creature comforts, opened for business at Treasure Cay on Great Abaco Island in the Bahamas last week.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than stores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Belay Those Experts
description: You've bought your first boat. You have learned the meaning of Red Right Re turning and stuff like that. You've decided against con ning it with a yachting cap and cigar, like some oafs you've seen, and you feel salty as hell.

title: Testimony in the Chicago Panther Slayings Raises Some New Questions
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 24  The finding last Wednesday of a special coroner's jury that the deaths of two Black Panthers in a predawn police raid Dec. 4 were justified were based, the verdict noted, solely and ex clusively on testimony pre sented by the police and the coroner's office.

title: OUSTERS UPHELD IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 24A Federal District Court judge has upheld the dismissal of 20 State Road Commission workers by Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr.

title: New and Recommended
description: HOUSE OF GOLD, by Elizabeth Cullinan. The long day's dying of old matriarch in Queens and its effects on the assembled family told with a fine homely realism and psychological subtlety.

title: European Notebook
description: If God existed and had thrown tons of steel, glass and cement mixed with forty hu man races in His garbage can and then emptied it over the shores of the Hudson. He would have created New York. If God existed and had thrown into His garbage can twelve million males and females mixed with steel cubes, and, after having agitated this shaker, had emp tied it on that rectangular swamp bordered by the sea, the East River and the Hudson, he would have then created New York. Greetings, New York! Greetings, rigid maiden of the Hudson's curves, and greetings to the garbage can and to the brother rats that are rummaging in it!

title: George Simpson Weds Diane de Coppet Here
description: Miss Diane de Coppet, daughter of Princess Karl Viktor zu Wied of Munich, Germany, was married yes terday afternoon in the Madi son Avenue Presbyterian Church to George Simpson of London. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: Royal Palm Is Won By Fast Hilarious
description: MIAMI, Jan. 24Johnny Rig ney, the old American League righthander, is finding horse racing considerably more lu crative than pitching for the Chicago White Sox. Fast Hilar ious, purchased by Rigney two years ago for $9,500, padded the family bankroll by another $21,092 today when he scored a frontrunning victory in the $32,450 Royal Palm Handicap before a crowd of 22,582 at Hialeah.

title: Foreign Affairs: Power's Logic or Vice Versa I
description: PARIS  France's Mediter ranean policy is not based on a simple calculation of the ArabIsraeli power equation but on two fundamentalsRussia and oil. It is designed to counter unimpeded Soviet penetration and the threat that Moscow could control access to that Middle Eastern oil on which French and West European in dustry depend.

title: HANK CRISP, 73, DIES; COACH AT ALABAMA
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 24 (AP)  Hank Crisp, who coached a generation of ath letes at the University of Ala bama, died last night shortly before he was to be inducted into the Alabama Sports Hall of Fame.

title: Booklet Lists Schools For the Sailing Devotee
description: With the rapid growth of sailing, there is a growing de mand for information on sail ing schools.

title: LITHUANIAN PRIESTS CHARGE PERSECUTION
description: A declaration by 40 Roman Catholic priests in Soviet Lithu ania, charging persecution of the church by the authorities, has been received by Catholic sources in the United States.

title: PROBLEMS EASED FOR CARTOPBOATS
description: When cartop boats are men tioned, one tends to think in terms of small craft carried on top of the family sedan or sta tion wagon. However, other types of vehicles are in increas ingly common use by outdoors menpickup trucks, small cars, sports cars and fourwheel drive vehicles with soft tons.

title: Steelers Lose Backfield Aide
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (AP) The Pittsburgh Steelers' of fensive backfield coach, John Bridgers, resigned today to take a similar job at the Uni versity of South Carolina.

title: A New Renaissance in Vieux Lyons
description: LAYONS, FranceIn the United States, urban renewal has often been used as a weapon to obliterate the past. Here in Lyons it has had the opposite effect. It has given this city one of the newest old tourist at tractions in France, a 27acre stretch of real estate now known as Vieux Lyons (Old Lyons).

title: Poetry In the Sixties
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 New Fiberglass Craft In Glastron's Exhibition
description: Four new fiberglass pleasure craft in the 14 to 19foot range are being exhibited by the Glas tron Boat Company of Austin, Tex. The price tags range from $1.089 to about $5.750.

title: Cornell Tuition and Fees To Increase $275 a Year
description: The Cornell University trus tees voted yesterday to raise the tuition and fees in most endowed divisions by $275 a year to a total of $2,600 a year. The increase will take effect after the spring term.

title: ChristJaner to Assume Post With National Group July 1
description: Arland F. ChristJaner, the president of Boston University, has resigned after three years in office to become the new president of the College En trance Examination Board, the rational organization that ad ministers standardized tests to millions of hopeful college ap plicants annually.

title: To Smoke or Not to Smoke
description: This book is clearly aimed at smok ers in their teens, and for reader appeal its gruesome frankness about emphysema and lung cancer com pares favorably with popular shock standards on TV and movie screens. It also contains enough ominous in formation about our deadly national habit to keep the average adult cocktailparty conversation happily occupied (over cigarettes) for at least 10 minutes.

title: It was fun and wildbut was it the complete, full life?
description: National leadership for the liberal religious community has thinned out. In a way, this has been going on for several years, but events coalesce, and sud denly we realize how dependent we are on some key personal ities to keep the lights on and the walk sweat.

title: Indiana Swimming Victor
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 24 (AP)Indiana's swimmers, last year's National Collegiate champions, won 10 of 13 events today to hand Ohio State an 8241 defeat. Three Hoosiers logged the fastest times in the nation so far this season: Mark Spitz with 1 min utes 43.3 seconds in the 200 yard freestyle; Larry Bardiere with a 1:57.2 in the 200yard individual medley, and Jack Horsley with a 1:57.3 in the 200yard backstroke.

title: NEWARK TO RECEIVE $5.6MILLION GRANT
description: NEWARK, Jan. 24Federal approval of a $5.6million grant for Newark's Model Cities pro gram will enable the city to begin housing, anticrime and health projects, the director of the program here said today.

title: Creezy
description: The 1968 Goncourt prize winner was a solid, Balzac like family history; 1969's Gon court went to this dazzling tra jectory of a love affair, It cor roborates the suspicion of at least one American reader that the French novel is still a re doubt of style in its most im aginative variations.

title: Runabouts in Vogue
description: Three new sports runabouts in lengths of 15, 18 and 20 feettwo in fiberglass and one in aluminumjoin the line of the Starcraft Company, Goshen, Ind. The firm has nine boats altogether at the show.

title: Saigon Musician Jailed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 (Reuters)A Saigon military court has sentenced a young South Vietnamese musician to five years at hard labor for com posing antiwar songs, the Souht Vietnamese press agency said today. The musician was identi fied as Phan Van Thang, alsoi known as Mien Duc Thang.

title: Submarine Escape Suit on Market
description: A submarine escape suit that allows a man to leave a submarine at depths of about 600 feet and then pro tects him while he is float ing on the surface has been developed by Beaufort (Air Sea) Equipment Company of Cheshire, England.

title: 14Foot Fiberglass Craft in Debut
description: A new fiberglass 14foot sailboat, to be known as Am flite 14, has recently been introduced. It carries a single 75 squarefoot sail with mast and booms of marine alum inum. Hull colors of blue, red and green are complemented by sail stripings of the same colors. Decks are pure white, as is the small cockpit. Philippine mahogany is used for the rudder, tiller, dagger board and cockpit handrails.

title: A Beautiful Show of a Mysterious Style
description: NEAR the foot of the stairs that lead up to the exhibition galleries at Asia House they have mounted a great bronze ritual sword fortytwo inches high, widebladed, with paired lions sculptured on Its handle and glowing with the patina of four thousand years. It looks as if it could easily have decapitated the concubines and the chosen youths who, fifty at a time along with an equal number of horses, were sacrificed and then ranged in a circle (the dead youths mounted on the dead horses) around the tombs of Scythian kingsall this according to Herodotus, who describes the technique of propping up the corpses. As a matter of fact, though, the sword could not have been so usedunless on the horsessince the method of execution for human beings was strangling. If such swords were ever bloodied, it was when cattle and horses and prisoners of war were slain so that their blood might be poured on as a ceremonial libation.

title: HUSSEIN HOPEFUL ON U.S. PROPOSALS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 21  King Hussein of Jordan has declared that he welcomes the American proposals for settle ment between Israel and Jor dan as a step forward. But the King, in an interview, also cautioned that if there is a solution it has got to be a general solutionnot a piece meal one.

title: The Dalai Lama's Tibet Lives On in Its Art
description: NEW DELHIFor the Communists to succeed in Tibet, the exiled Dalai Lama has said of the Red Chinese takeover of his highmoun tain country, it was necessary that the ancient Tibet should die. This meant strik ing at the basic traditions of Tibet, especial ly the allpervasive religious system and its outward manifestations.

title: Tea and Some Sympathy At Warsaw
description: WARSAW When the four members of the United States delegation walked up the red carpet to the second floor of the Communist Chinese Embassy last week to resume formal talks after a twoyear lapse, they found pots of tea, cigarettes pro duced in Shanghai, portralti and busts of Mao Tsetung, and smiles.

title: Ferrari Returns to Daytona Saturday
description: THE new word this season is antiPorsche, and it is particularly topical be cause the antiPorsche cam paign faces its first test next weekend at Daytona Beach, Fla. The occasion is the TwentyFour Hours of Daytonathe American ver sion of Le Manswhich be gins at 3 P.M. Saturday. The race, which prom ises to be one of the best ever at Daytona, opens the annual series of 11 en durance events in North America and Europe for the world manufacturers' cham pionship. Porsche is the de fending champion.

title: Blockbusting Curb Sought in Flatbush
description: A growing movement against blockbusting in the Flatbush and East Flatbush sections of Brooklyn will make its first mass appeal to thousands of homeowners today through the medium of the church service.

title: Boston Transit Aide Resigns
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)  Ed ward F. McLaughlin Jr., general counsel for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, resigned Tuesday after 20 years of public service. He said he will join a Boston law firm.

title: U.S. to Give U.N. $7.5Million For Fund on Population Control
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The United States took a major ac tion today to support efforts of the United Nations to find solu tions to the world's population problems.

title: Florida Builder's 16Footer Has Now Generation Dash
description: A 16footer powered by a 351inch HolmanMoody V drive is Correct Craft's entry among the highperformance boats on display at the Coli seum. Called the separator, the Orlando, Fla., builder's offering has sports car dash. Bucket seats which swivel 360 degrees, a curved plexiglas windshield, a wood grain instrument panel and two tachometers, among other items, create the GT look. To speeds produced by the eightcylinder power plant should be close to 40 miles an hour. Prices begin at $7,325.

title: Wesley Vazquez Is Married Here To Judge's Son
description: Miss Wesley Ann Vazquez and Howard Thomas Hogan Jr. were married yesterday morning at St. Ignatius Loy ola Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Vincent Hart per formed the ceremony, assist ed by the Rev. Donald Mc Phail, an Episcopal minister. A reception was held at the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: DryRun Method: Learning Water Skiing on Land
description: Nothing is more valuable to the water skiernovice, skilled orcompetitivethan a capable drier at the controls of the tow boat. A competent boat handler can enhance the skill of a skier, just as errors in judgment by the driver can be damaging and dangerous.

title: FRANKLIN E. GRIFFITH
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24  Franklin E. Griffith, a former delegate to the United Nations Conference of Mining Experts, died yesterday in Presbyterian University Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in McMur ray, Pa. He was the retired head. of the Mine Fire Division of the United States Burrau of Mines.

title: Greene being funny about Greene and serious about life
description: Many of Graham Greene's admirers feel his best work is in those novels of his middle period which present religious themes in terms of intense spiritual drama  Brighton Rock, The Heart of the Matter, The End of the Affair and The Power and the Glory. For such readers the early works are merely a prepara tion for the great achievement of the Roman Catholic novels, and every thing since has been a slight or severe disappointment

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan Reports Downing Jet
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 24 (Reuters)A military spokes man said tonight that an Is raeli aircraft was shot down by Jordanian groundfire during a raid today on Jordanian Army posts south of the Dead Sea. He said that six Israeli jets had taken part in the attack, and that the downed aircraft had been seen crashing west of the Dead Sea.

title: WAXING ANSWER TO WANING SHEEN
description: The best of all boat mainten ance, of course, is that which prevents or discourages dirt and stains from accumulating. The following tips are offered to boatmen who want to keep decks and hulls of fiberglass boats beautiful in spite of the onslaught of a dirty old world.

title: Mrs. Hamburg Has Child
description: A daughter was born on Jan. 13 in LyingIn Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. C. Bruce Hamburg of Forest Hills Gar dens, Queens.

title: Art Show to Aid Children's Workshop Tomorrow
description: The Fine Arts Workshop, which welcomes public school children to its Carnegie Hall studios for lessons in drama, music, dance and art, will benefit from tomorrow's pre view of theatrical drawings by Eugene Berman at the Larcada Gallery, 23 East 67th Street.

title: U.S. Role in Turkey Backed
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 24 (UPI) Premier Suleyman De mirel today defended the United States military presenct in Tur key and said, Nothing that will harm our independence and sov ereignty will ever come from the existence of these establish ments. Answering questions at a news conference, Dr. Dernirell said that what were called American bases by leftists in Turkey were in fact joint de Tense establishments.

title: Boats on Stamps Provide Novel World Cruise
description: Boatmen (and women), whether or not of frostbite inclination, may be comfort ably warm in pursuit of their hobby these wintry days with another avocation that promises pleasure with out the tasks  boats and boating on postage stamps.

title: Olympia,Troy, Marathon, Pompeii...
description: Names. How foreign they sounded when you learned them in school! How distant, remote: words made of letters, printed in a book.

title: After nine years
description: ATHENS, Ga. SEVERAL days after Hamilton (Hamp) Holmes and I entered the University of Georgia in 1961 under court order as its first two black students, I sat in a world history class, fighting desperately to stay awake and avoid confirming the stereotype that all blacks are lazy. The drowsiness was the result of my first few days on campus when white students, protesting our admission, rioted outside my dormitory.

title: Mantle Will Swing Yankee Bat Again
description: Mickey Mantle will be wear ing his familiar No. 7 uniform at the New York Yankees' camp in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., this spring. He will join a fac ulty of eight special instruct ors who will aid Manager Ralph Houk.

title: What's New in the Theater
description: THE HARANGUES, the Negro Ensemble Company's pro duction of four oneact plays with related themes by Joseph A. Walker, got one favorable, five mixed and three negative reviews. Clive Barnes: Joseph A. Walker has juxtaposed a remarkable series of white black vignettes in an eve ning that makes a plea for less racial racism and more racial understanding. Mr. Walker's people do not al ways talk like people, and his plots are far too obvi ously plotted. Yet he does have a wild dramatic spirit a sense of happening, a feel for involvement. The evening, as a whole, in terested mebut the final half really held me. It tore down barriers of accepted thought. It made me re assess prejudices so deep that they were passing as beliefs. There are many faults to the play, and unquestionably I enjoyed what Mr. Walker was try ing to say far more than the way in which he was saving it. But the evening with all its faults does offer challenges. Israel Hicks's staging is crisp and convincing, and the acting has just that easy ensemble style that makes the Negro Ensemble Company one of New York's special pleas ures. For Kerr, see Page 1.

title: Hawaii Studies Variety of Transport Systems
description: HONOLULU  Hawaii the newest state, is looking at a variety of methods for transporting to Waikiki hotels, by highway or water, the hundreds of passengers who are scheduled to alight daily from each jumbo jet within the next two months.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Retailers whose volume is holding close to last year's figures are not at all sure that the economy is in a state of recession. Many, however, are acting as if it were and appear to have adopted a cautious attitude in their advance buying.

title: Ojukwu's New Home
description: For two weeks following the collapse of Biafra the where abouts of the bearded, charis matic rebel leader, Gen Odumeg wu Ojukwu, remained a mystery. Nigerian sources claimed he had fled on one of the last planes to leave the enclave, disguised as a priest and on a stretcher. He was reported variously as in hiding in Portugal, in France and in Zambia.

title: Correction
description: The title of Robert A. Rosen stone's book about the Lincoln Battalion in the Spanish Civil War, reviewed on Jan. 18, should have read Crusade of the Left.

title: John Crawford 3d Weds Jane Rigg
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 24Miss Jane Adair Rigg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Holt Rigg, was mar ried here this afternoon to John Humphrey Crawford 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Craw ford Jr. of Short Hills.

title: G. V. Brunner Jr. Weds Miss DeVincent
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 24  Miss Joanne C. De Vincent and George V. Brun ner Jr. of Rochester were married here this morning in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Trinity. The Rev. James P. Flynn per formed the ceremony.

title: U.S. CHIPPENDALE TO BE AUCTIONED
description: Of five sales to be held this week at the ParkeBernet Gal leries, 9S0 Madison Avenue, perhaps the bestattended will be the Saturday afternoon auc tion of Early American furni ture with an important section of first quality Philadelphia Chippendale pieces.

title: Owner Urges Garden Ease Entry Rules
description: A LETTER from Elise B. Heinz, an Arlington, Va., attorney, suggested that if the Westminster Kennel Club had relaxed its entry re quirements for the show to be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 9 and 10, the embarrassment of falling short of the new 3.000dog limit would have been avoided. The list closed with 2,611 dogs. This is a whimofthe moment letter about Westminster, she wrote. I have a suggestion which you might pass along to someone involved in the management of that show. It is that the qualifying require ment for entry be liberalized to the extent of making one bestofbreed ribbon an al ternative to the present re quirement of a major.

title: Duvillard Injures Ankle And Skips Slalom at Megeve
description: MEGEVE, France, Jan. 24 Reuters)  Henri Duvillard of France withdraw today from the special slalom tomorrow in the Grand Prix de Megeve ski competition because of an ankle injury sustained in prac tice.

title: Piaskovy Stops Frenchman
description: BERLIN, Jan. 24 (AP)Ger hard Piaskovy of West Berlin retained his European super welterweight boxing title to night by knocking out Jean Baptiste Rolland of France in the eighth round of their sched uled 15round fight. Piaskovy weighed 155 pounds, Rolland 155.

title: Sarah E. Edwards Wed to C. N. Willits
description: READING, Pa., Jan. 24  Miss Sarah Eastland Ed wards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Edwards of Wyo missing, was married here this afternoon to Christopher Naudain Willits, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Cooper Willits of Paoli.

title: TACKLE BOX JUNK FISHERMAN'S GOLD
description: Like a lady's purse, a fisher man's tackle box can be ex pected to contain just about anythingssentials as well as apparent junk. But don't be too quick to criticize. You might be amazed at the ways in which such trash can be used.

title: Cole to Succeed Barnhill As Arkansas Athletic Head
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Jan. 24 (AP)John Barnhill is re tiring as athletic director at the University of Arkansas, end ing a 24year tenure In which Arkansas became one of the nation's football powers.

description: ST. GERVAIS, France, Jan. 24 (AP)Francoise Macchi con tinued the French domination of the World Cup competition today by winning the giant slalom of the 22d international women's Grand Prix.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (AP) Red N Blue Farm's Doc Kope, ridden by Frank Lovato, led all the, way today in winning the $28,425 Militia Handicap at Liberty Bell Park.

title: Bulky Gear Is Best Stored In Boat When Trailering It
description: One of the best places to carry bulky gear when trailer ing your boat to the water is in the boat itself. Remember, though, that as much care should be taken in loading this gear as you would take if the boat were in the water.

title: Lawyer Leaves $1.2Million To Small Town in Michigan
description: ALLEGAN, Mich., Jan. 24 (UPI)  A smalltown lawyer who apparently knew as much about the stock market and in vestments as he did Black stone's law books, left securi ties valued at more than $1.2 million for the benefit of Alle gan County residents.

title: In This Issue
description: GENERAL

title: Nigeria 1:
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  A German doctor who had spent the last few months of Biafra's existence taking care of starving children in a hospital in the heart of the enclave sat in a hotel lobby 60 miles away last week discussing the people who are still hungry there.

title: A NEW OUTBOARD NOT EXACTLY TOY
description: The sight of a child with a new toy has its summertime counterpart in the form of a fisherman unpacking his new outboard motor. The expression of anticipation on his face as he extracts his new pride and joy from the carton is some thing to see.

title: A Moderate Good Living Here Cost Single Person $3,006 in '69
description: A single person under 35 years of age could have bought goods and services ade quate for moderately good living in the metropolitan area for $3,006 last year, according to new Federal calculations.

title: The Honey Bunch
description: The Honey Bunch begins as a minigroup of high school girls of the 1930's, who hang out together in Norton, Oregon, where the pears come from. Honey McKittrick is the beau ty of the bunch; Susanna Swope has intellectual pretensions; Ja net Springer has drive. Now what is needed is enough lit erary perspective on the part of the author to see them in the scale of the present day, This, unhappily, is lacking, and so the Honey Bunch appear as a collective case of arrested development.

title: Inflation and Recession Rattle Tense Markets
description: IT WAS A momentous week in the world of business and financea period that vividly illustrated the tense state of the economy and the com plexity of the problems confronting it.

title: Ellen M. Jaffe Fiancee of R. E. Perlman
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 24 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leon ard S. Jaffe of the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Ellen May Jaffe, to Richard E. Perlman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ahraham N. Periman of Morris Plains, N. J. A March wedding is planned.

title: Brandt's Eastern Success
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt has pulled off a neat politi cal trick in his proposals for governmenttogovern ment negotiations to improve relations with Commu nist East Germany. Both his West German opponents of the Christian Democratic party, who said the proposals went too far, and East German Communist Chief Walter Ulbricht, who said they did not go far enough, have now felt obliged to accept them.

title: Record of the Appeal
Women's Tailors Sew Men's Furs
description: Men's fake fur coatsa big business todayare made mostly by women's coat makers.

title: Touring the Everglades
description: EVERGLADES, Fla.  The Na tional Park Service operates sight seeing boat trips from Everglades every day. The Mangrove Wilder ness trip to the inland waters of the back country costs $2.50 and lasts an hour and onehalf. There are five sailings daily between 9 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. The Ten Thousand Islands trip costs $3, lasts two and onehalf hours and is made aboard the en closed, 50passenger Manatee, which leaves the Ranger Station at 10 A.M. and 12:45 and 3:30 P.M.

title: The MinMin
description: In this novel set in Australia, Reg has vandalized the schoolhouse, so the coppers will surely send him away; his sister, Sylvie, is trapped by unending household tasks, helped not at all by an ailing mother and drink ing father. Like the aborigines' min min, an elusive light which beckons but remains unreachable, Sylvie's dream of further education seems futile. So the two run away deep into the Australian outback, a land of limitless sky and parched earth, a desert of gibbers and sometimes a willywilly. Their destination is the sheepstation of Gulla Tank and the sympathetic ear of a friend, Mrs. Tucker. In the honest frontier house hold of the Tucker family, Reg finds the meaning of discipline, and Sylvie the meaning of womanhood. With powerfully simple understatement Mavis Clark paints the harsh land down under and the people and wild things which survive there. Her strong, terse prose is reminiscent of Mary Patchett's Cry of the Heart and evokes tears. Her images are pragmatic and original: the rising moon looks like the round full yoke of a yellow egg, and an approaching train sounds like wind in the earth's stomach.

title: PEKING MAY ACT TO CURB BIRTHS
description: LONDON, Jan. 24Signs are accumulating from Peking that 1970 may see another bold at tempt to wrestle with China's population problem. This could be a byproduct of a policy advocated by Chairman Mao Tsetung  of breaking down the barriers between town and country.

title: West Virginia Banking Row Resumed
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 24A bill amending the state banking laws to allow for branch banking, mergers and formation of bank hold ing companies has been sub mitted to the 1970 session of the Legislature now in ses sion here.

title: CARESSE CROSBY, PUBLISHER, DIES
description: Caresse Crosby, who as edi for and publisher of the Black Sun Press in Paris fostered in the nineteentwenties such writers as Hart Crane, James Joyce and D. H. Lawrence, died Friday in Rome, near where she lived in her castle. She was 78 years old.

title: The Triumph of Ideas Over Art
description: DETROIT. AMONG the new artists who came to enjoy a special prominence in the nineteen  sixties, none currently wields so much influence or commands such conspicuous patronage and critical genuflection as Robert Morris. At the age of 38, Mr. Morris is an estab lished chef d'ecole. His the oretical pronouncements are avidly studied in the univer sities. Museums vie for the privilege of showing his work. Collectors are eager to honor his every whim, even whenas is now sometimes the casethe results are not exactly collectible, and crit ics hasten to confer on his endeavors those mas sive philosophical justifica tions, which, though they often tell us remarkably lit tle about the work in question, are always a sure sign that some new esthetic disturbance has made itself felt.

title: P. F. Moulton Fiance Of Margaret E. Milne
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Jan. 24Miss Margaret Elizabeth Milne, admission counselor at Wheaton College in Nor ton, Mass., and Peter Frank lin Moulton, who is studying for a doctorate in electrical engineering at the Massa chusetts Institute of Tech nology, are engaged.

title: FIBERGLASS TANKS TO SERVICE MARINA

For example, Lord Montagu, top earner among the owners, is raising the admission charge to Beaulieu Castle, Hampshire, from 60 to 84 cents, the largest escalation. The Duke of Marlborough, who has also done well financially in the past, plans to increase from 36 to 48 cents the price for visiting classic Blenheim Pal ace in Oxfordshire.

title: LESS MEANS MORE IN STOWING GEAR
description: Less is more to the small boat camper.

description: For the boatman, the weather services of the Federal Govern ment help make incometax day bearable. Like the farmer, he keeps his eye and ear on the weather. He may remember the times when the forecast was a bit off  and is apt to forget the much larger number of times when the forecaster was pretty much on the nose.

title: FRANCE STIRRED BY IMMOLATIONS
description: PARIS, Jan. 24A 17year old girl set fir to herself in a Roman Catholic high school in an exclusive district of Paris this morning. Then she leaped four stories to the street, to die soon afterward, the fifth suicide by fire in France in a week.

description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 24 (AP) Pete Maravich became the secondhighest scorer in college basketball history to night, but the luster was some what dulled when his Louisiana State team fell, 10996, before No. 2ranked Kentucky.

description: What sport Is more rugged than football, lacrosse or ice hockey? Bigboat racing. The first three are tough, all right, but the physical and mental effort required is not as unrelenting and prolonged as a race across the Atlantic or from Sydney to Hobart.

Whether the Pitts burg Steelers will be the draft ing agent or another team, will remain a conjectural matter right up to the opening of the draft meeting at the Belmont Plaza Hotel here at 10 A.M.

Do you think Julian Carillo's Mass for Pope John XXIII is a landmark in 20th century composition? Do you find these questions unan swerable on the basis of your listening experience?.

title: 154 New Vessels Made First Trips to City in 1969
description: There were 154 new vessels flying the flag of 32 countries that made their maiden voyages to the Port of New York in 1969, according to the Maritime Association.

description: How many dimples are on the cover of a golf ball? If you've ever been tempted to count them while waiting your turn at the first tee, don't bother. The answer is 336.

description: A new ninefoot trimaran, the Triumph, the polystyrene Snark sailboat and the seven foot Moby Dick, described as a whale of a tender, are being exhibited by Snark Products of Fort Lee, N.. J. Both the Tri umph and the Moby Dick are molded of ABS, a lightweight material said to exceed the im pact resistance of fiberglass.

title: $1BILLI0N IN BONDS ASKED TO SPUR JOBS
description: A $1billion human re sources bond issue and the es tablishment of a state economic council were urged yesterday by the Liberal party as steps to ward guaranteeing full employ ment.

description: 1 Mardi Gras Celebrations, Alabama and Louisiana. Until Feb. 10, Shrove Tuesday.

title: Weather Warnings Are Depicted and Defined on United States Coastal Charts

description: A 15member panel was ap pointed by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to monitor subway and bus service throughout the city and investigate operating delays, cleanliness on trains and platforms and reliability of schedules.

The ap proach generally is, not sur prisingly, strongly judgmental, and future socioliterary histo rians may find the subject worthy of exploration.

title: DAYAN SAYS RAIDS ARE CURB ON CAIRO
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 24De fense Minister Moshe Dayan today defined Israeli military operations against the United Arab Republic as part of a static policy aimed at halt ing, or at least diminishing, all Egyptian military activities.

title: CLEVELAND NEGRO WINS A FRANCHISE
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 Charles E. Johnson started selling hamburgers and French fries here this week, and a ninemonth controversy ended.

description: American boat owners have never accepted the phil osophy that you can't take it with you.

description: PORT COLBORNE, Ontario The United States and Canada are in growing disagreement over drilling for gas beneath Lake Erie.

title: City Says Protests Over Lack of Heat Pass 100 an Hour
description: Complaints by tenants of lack of heat were received by the city yesterday at the rate of more than 100 an hour as a force of 80 inspectors toured the city checking on the prob lem.

title: A Correction
description: An article In this section on Jan. 18 said that Dr. [Martin] Sweig admitted he attended two meetings at the S.E.C. [Secu rities and Exchange Commission] in the company of Parvin [Dohr mann Company] officers. This was incorrect. Speaker John W. McCormack said last October that his aide, Dr. Sweig, had ad mitted attending one meeting at the S.E.C. with Nathan M. Volo shen and company chairman Delbert W. Coleman. The Times regrets the error.

title: HORACE R. CAYTON, SOCIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Horace R. Cayton, sociologist and writer, who had taught at the University of California at Berkeley since 1959, died Thurs day in Paris where he was gathering material for a biogra phy of his friend, Richard Wright, author of Native Son. He was 66 years old and lived in Santa Cruz. Calif.

title: friedmanism, n. Doctrine of most audacious U.S. economist; esp., theory only money matters
description: HALFJOCULARLY, Milton Fried man says that his favorite country in the world is Japan, because he's such a tall man there. Friedman admits unhappily to being just 5 feet 3, but adds that when he was an undergraduate he measured at least 5 feet 4. He's been squashed down since then, he says.

title: Mostly for Those Who Don't Mind Getting a Little Wet: The AquaDart and Jet Board

But the idea of AquaDart10 years in devel opmentis strictly fun, even for frogmen, says Curtis Marshall of Leisuredyne, the company that produces the craft.
