title: MIAMIAN CREATES VARIED PATTERNS
description: At least one man. It seems, has bridged the widening gap between the traditional creative boatbuilder and the impersonal mass production of modern fib erglass boats. He is Les Strat ten of Miami, who seems to enjoy the best of both worlds.

title: Those Unkind Cuts
description: IN WASHINGTON there is much todo, if not much action, on the issue of honest labeling of con sumer goods, of forthrightly representing the content of a product offered to the pub lic in packaged form. Where the national purse is con cerned, such solicitude is wel come and overdue  but why should the application of such criteria stop there? In television there exists a form of misrepresentation that has long been a prime viewer annoyance and thus far no one, not the courts, the Fed eral Communications Com mission or the hapless set owner, has been able to do a thing about the problem: the butchering of movies on the home screen.

title: Injured From Elath Arrive in Tel Aviv by Helicopter
Series from Switzerland
description: SWITZERLAND'S 1970 Publicity Series will be released February 26. Three stamps will ob serve the anniversaries of Swiss organizations, two oth ers will be in observance of the United Nations. The mul ticolored stamps are from the presses of CourvoisierHelio. the Swiss security printers.

title: Oklahoma State Triumphs
description: BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 24 (UPI)  Oklahoma State played for the sure shot today and scored a 6562 victory over the University of Colorado, snap ping the Buffaloes' home court winning streak at 15.

title: Inflatable Boat Is Also Designed to Be a Tender
description: Japan's largest fiberglass boatbuilding plant has begun operations in the first alliance between American and Japan ese boating interests.

title: Game Wardens Curbed
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The state's game wardens, who patrol districts averaging 250 square miles, have been told they may drive only 50 miles a day. The Enforcement Divi sion Director, Kenneth A. Cross man, said Thursday he had imposed the restriction because of a shortage of gasoline money.

title: Boat Show Information: How to Reach Coliseum
description: PUBLIC HOURS  Today and next Sunday, 1 to 7 P.M.; to morrow through Friday, noon to 10 P.M.; Saturday, 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.

title: Quotes
description: DENIS HEALEY, British Defense Minister: I have nothing against diplomats and Foreign Secretaries. If they did not exist, we would not need defense forces and I would be unemployed.

title: METRIC PLAN TO TAKE DECADE IN AUSTRALIA
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 24 Australia will convert to the metric system of weights and measures over the next 10 years, Prime Minister John Gorton announced this week.

title: Name for Boston Auditorium
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)  The Boston War Memorial Audito rium is getting a new name. The Auditorium Commission, in a unanimous vote Tuesday, approved naming the structure for the late John B. Hynes, a former Mayor of. Boston.

title: Start Gloxinias From Seed
description: AMONG the most capti vating plants to grow indoors are species and hybrids of Sinningia popularly known as gloxinias. The giantflowered garden forms called florists' gloxi nias can be counted on to provide two months or more of truly spectacular bloom at least once a yearif properly cared for. Handsome hybrids otthe slippertype sinningias, with flowers slender in com parison to the wide bells of florists' gloxinias, are small enough to fit in a fiveinch pot at maturity.

title: Manhattan Trackrnen Win
description: Manhattan College, with 568 edge in the running events defeated Dartmouth yesterday in a dual track meet, 7039. Notable performances were Al Novell's 2 minutes 11.4 sec onds time in the 1,000yard run And Tom Donohue's 70 vaid Victory in the one mile run in 4:11.7.

title: East German Protest of Bonn's Meeting Delays Berlin Traffic 4th Day
description: BERLIN, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Traffic on highways into Berlin from West Germany was backed up for the fourth consecutive day today as East German officials con tinued delaying tactics at border checkpoints.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: Luxury Yacht to Boast Round Bed for Snoozers
description: A real show stopper at the Boat Show may be the round bed to be found in a luxuri ous 42foot motor yacht, built by Pacemaker Corpora tion.

title: Massachusetts Downs lona As Erving Sets Pace, 8682
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 24Julius Erving scored 24 points and pulled down 13 re bounds tonight as the Univer sity of Massachusetts overcame a 4335 deficit and defeated Iona, 8682, at Iona Prep.

title: ARMY TRACKMEN DEFEAT RUTGERS
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 Army won all 13 events and swept four of them in beating Rutgers, 9316, today in a track and field meet at the Army Field House.PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 24 Princeton University's track team captured eight of 13 events today and won the first quadrangle track meet in Jad win Gymnasium. The Tigers amassed 72 points to 28 for New York University, 17 for Fordham and 13 for Seton.

title: Think soup
description: It is oddand unfortunatethat during the last few decades hot soups have not had nearly the esteem in this country that they enjoy abroad. Here are two soupsBelgium's waterzooie and Mexico's caldo xochitl, as dissimilar as two soups can be but both fine for winter diningthat should reverse the trend.

title: Florida's Last Frontier
description: EVERGLADES, Fla.  A big building project is in the making in this Gulf Coast hamlet 36 miles southeast of Naples. Some oldtimers say that there has not been such a stir here since 1928, when the depot was built and the first passenger train puffed into town.

title: Richard Tucker Takes Another Bow
description: The question of whether Richard Tucker, the Jewish tenor who is the glory of Italian opera, will go on singing for ever was raised last night by no less an authority than Richard Tucker and answered by him.

title: OPENINGS
description: UNFAIR TO GOLIATHTo night, Cherry Lane, 38 Commerce Street, 7:30. A revue by Ephraim Kishon.

title: Griffin Asks Labor Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Robert P. Griffin, Republican Senator of Michigan, has intro duced a resolution to set up a special Senate committee to in vestigate improper atcivities in labormanagement relations. He said Thursday that it had been inspired by charges of wrongdo ing in the United Mine Workers.

title: Evanson Sloops Available In $795to$2,350 Range
description: Two sloops, both of fiber glass, are displayed by the P. Evanson Boat Company: The smaller of the two is the 10 foot  10  inch Robin Sailing dinghy, designed by Phil Rhodes. She has, a versatile cat/loop rig and is available with sails, for $795

title: No Songs For judge
description: Judge Julius J. Hoffman, 74, has not been partial to young folk singers who have tried to sing their protest songs at the Chicago trial of seven defend ants charged with conspiring to start a riot at the 1968 Demo cratic national convention. Even the lilting soprano of pretty pop star Judy Collins did not move him last week. No, no, no sing ing, he ruled, when Miss Collins broke into a rendition of Where Have All the Flowers Gone? during her testimony for the de fense. We are not here to be entertained.

title: Pentagon to Review Hiring At McDonnell Douglas Plant
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24 (AP) The Defense Department's con tract compliance office here will review employment prac tices at the hugh McDonnell Douglas Corporation starting Monday, an official announced.

title: A Czech Takes a Trip
description: IVAN PASSER, the 36yearold Czech writer  director whose Intimate Lighting (made in 1965 and shown here theatrically for the first time last year), was hailed as a sensitive human comedy about life in a small town, is preparing to make his Ameri can movie debut. He has joined with Theater Guild Films and producer Ed ward Spector to direct Scraping Bot tom, based on the Off Off Broadway play by David Scott Milton. The plan is to shoot it here next summer and Passer has been collaborating with Milton on the script.

title: A 10Foot Submarine Available for $14,750
description: A 10foot submarine that takes one person to depths of 250 feet, stays under for 90 minutes, and travels sub merged at two to two and onehalf knots is on display at the Coliseum.

title: MEDICAL JOURNALS TO STANDARDIZE
description: A secretary in Seattle has left her mark on medical literature.

title: PredictedLog Events Reduced by N.Y.Y.C.
description: The New York Yacht Club's power yacht division, which previously held predicted log during most of the club's an nual cruise, plans only four such contests at cruise time next summer, says Vincent C. Hall, the division chairman. Two will be just before the cruise rendevous is held at Newport in Long Island and Block Island Sounds. The other two will be during the cruise.

title: Miss Christina Prenter Mitchell Married to Charles E. Bascom
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., Jan. 24  Miss Christina Prenter Mitchell and Charles Evans Bascom were married this afternoon in the Sewickley Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Jack Maxwell.

title: Shareholders Find Cold Shower of Reality Bracing
description: The scene: You're the new president (and have been since last Oct. 25) of a research oriented, but somewhat profitless, battery manufac turer (the Yardney Electric Corporation). You're young (40), with good credentials (a Ph.D. in physics from Pennsylvania State Uni versity and 5 years with the Bell Telephone Laboratories).

title: RALSTON IS VICTOR OF 93GAME MATCH
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Arthur Ashe of the United States survived a rash of upsets today to gain the semifinals in the Australian open tennis championships, which lost its No. 1, 2 and 3 seeded players in quarterfinal action.

title: Bullets Top 76ers, 112111
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 24 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets scored the final 5 points of the game tonight, the last a free throw by Mike Davis with 19 seconds left, and beat the Philadelphia 76ers. 112111.

title: At their back stands reality ready to undo them
description: This is a collection of short stories, the first to be published in the United States, by the distinguished Indian novelist R. K. Narayan. Like his nov els, they deal (with the exception of the title story) with life in the city of Malgudi, which is Mr. Narayan's Yoknapatawpha County. They are all very specifically Indian, richly adorned with picturesque native cus toms and vivid local color, so that the casual reader with a limited appe tite for folklore might well form the misleading impression that this is all thpv are. He might also be misled by their brevity and simplicity into sup posing that they belong in the cate gory of Theophrastian vignettes.

title: Article 15  No Title
Detroit Whips Boston College
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24 (AP)A tough zone defense forced Bos ton College to shoot from out side and helped the University of Detroit to an 8067 victory today.

title: New York
description: ALBANY  Like many other young Assemblymen, Peter A. A. Berle, a 32year old freshman from Manhattan, was debating as if it meant something last Thursday. Why sir, he wanted to know, was the state's Con gressional redistricting plan completed before it was shown to the Democrats on what was theoretically a bipartisan reap portionment committee?

title: DALEY AIDE'S TALK RECALLED IN TRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 24A radi cal leader and a lawyer for the City of Chicago traded barbed aphorisms on the eve of the 1968 Democratic National Con vention here, a witness told the Chicago conspiracy trial today.

title: Zionist Calls on U. S. Jews To Back Israeli Demand
description: The head of the Zionist Or ganization of America last night called on American Jews to in itensify their efforts to influence Government opinion in favor of Israel's democratic position in the Middle East.

title: Washington: President Nixon's Politics and Ideals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  President Nixon undoubtedly knows, as he starts forward into his second year, that there are many more people in this country who want to believe in the noble ideals of his State of the Union Message than there are people who actually believe in them, and many more who share his anxiety about the physical and moral squalor of the age but are not prepared to pay the price of getting rid of it.

title: Jersey Law Perils Custom in Zoning
description: TRENTON  Apparently unaware of exactly what was involved, the overwhelming Republican majorities in the New Jersey legislature have approved a new law that could threaten zoning practices in New Jer sey communities where Ne groes and other minority groups have systematically been excluded.

title: Joanne Piskor Plans Nuptials
description: CANTON, N. Y., Jan. 24 Dr. Frank P. Piskor, president of St. Lawrence University, and Mrs. Piskor have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanne Mariett Piskor, to William Waddell Chase. He is the son of Mrs. John Waddell Chase of Groton. Conn., and the late Mr. Chase, who was a literary editor and critic.

title: Ensign to Wed Jan Van Gerven
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 24Mr. and Mrs. William L. Van Ger ven have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Jan Maria Van Gerven, to Ens. Alan Richard Kelsey, U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. Winfield F. Kelsey of East hampton, Mass.

title: DOUBELL SHATTERS WORLD 1,000 MARK
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Jan. 24 (AP)  Australia's Ralph Doubell broke a sevenyearold world indoor mark in the 1,000 yard run and Cathy Hammond of Sacramento, Calif., erased the world women's indoor mark in the 600yard run in the Al buquerque invitation meet to night.

title: BERGHORN SCORES AT BEAR MOUNTAIN
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 24Chuck Berghorn of Lake Placid scored a double victory as he led a field of 42 entrants in the Telemark skijumping tournament today.

title: Chess
description: THE 1969 Majorca, Spain, Interna tional, preeminent in its 18man field, starred a round robin down the line with the most experi enced battlers in Europe and South America. As a result, amazing surprises and sorry setbacks are recorded.

title: W. Germany Rated No.1 Riding Squad In World Standing
description: WEST Germany was the leading team in inter national horse show com petition last year and Alwin Schockemohle, a member of the squad, was the world's top rider.

title: MORMON LIBERALS EXPECT NO CHANGE
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 24 When the Mormon presidency passed this week to Joseph Fielding Smith, a 93yearold strict theologian, it ended for a time the hope of church liberals for a change soon in the prac tice of refusing membership in the priesthood to Negroes.

title: Dr. R. A. Schaefer Weds List of Entertainment Benefit Parties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Dr. Mary Jeanne Kreek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Francis Kreek of Washington, was married here at noon today to Dr. Robert A. Schaefer, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Schaefer of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and New Milford, Conn.

title: The Audacity of Raphael Ferrer
description: RAPHAEL FERRER at the Castelli Ware house and Tony De Lap at the Elkon Gal lery represent polar extremes in the esthetics of recent American sculpture. DeLap's new work is what might be called manneristphase Mini malgeometric, immaculate, jewellike. Ferrer is one of the most important and per haps the most flamboyant practitioner of the new style or nonstyle variously dubbed Casual, AntiFormal and AntiIllusion, a develop ment that emphasizes the artist's physical and intuitive involvement in the act of creation while rejecting neat formal calculations and the ideal of the finished work. Its ancestry may be traced (perhaps oversimply) to Du champ and Kurt Schwitters by way of Robert Morris.

title: Japan and Soviet in Pact
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Japan and the Soviet Union to day signed an agreement for the construction of a port near the Soviet town of Nakhodka, 60 miles southeast of Vladivos tok. This is t heir second econ omic cooperation agreement. The first was a plan for devel opment of forestry resources in Eastern Siberia.

title: Miss Robin Collins Bride in Michigan
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Jan. 24Miss Robin Suzanne Collins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Collins of Birmingham, was married here this morning in the Con vent of the Sacred Heart Chapel to Paul Anthony Ver mylen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vermylen of Saddle River, N. J., and Shoreham, L. I. The ceremony was per formed by the Rev. Robert McMurtrie.

title: And It Rained
description: You have to be alert with Ellen Raskin's books. They're always off beat and full of sly visual puns you can miss unless you're looking for them. The same's true with And It Rained. In idea it ranks with her Nothing Ever Happens on My Block and Spectacles, yet some how she has let her special sense of humor be upstaged by her sophis ticated wit.

title: Attack on Shadwan
description: Israel's campaign to neutralize Egypt's positions along the Suez frontwith daily bombings and shellings, and periodic commando strikes into the Egyptian heart landwas intensified last week in an airborne commando opera tion that led to the fiercest and costliest fighting since the 1967 war.

title: Montclair State Wins, 6462, In 2d Overtime for No. 14
description: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Jan. 24An 18foot jump shot by Phil Baccarella with 39 sec onds left in the second over time period tonight gave Mont clair State College its 14th straight victory, a 6462 tri umph over East Stroudsburg State.

title: McCurrachs Have a Son
description: RED BANK, N. J., Jan. 24 A son was born Jan. 7 to Mr. and Mrs. G.)Peter M. McCurrach in the River View Hospital here. Mrs. McCur rach is the former Miss Mary Elizabeth Harding, daughter of Gen. Stanley Harding, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Harding of Falls Church, Va. The child has been named for his father, who is a sys tems analyst with the Turner Construction Company, New York.

title: Article 5  No Title
Lora McNeill Elkinton Engaged
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., Jan. 24 Mr. and Mrs. Chalmers Handy have announced the engagement of Mrs. Handy's daughter, Miss Lora McNeill Elkinton, to John Hamilton Miller 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller 2d of Rumson, N. J.

title: Explosive Beginning
description: THE FIRST match in the Tennis Champions, Inc., $200,000 Classic may have ushered in a new era for the sport Friday night at Madi son Square Garden.

title: $100Million for Food Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24State of ficials disclosed today that they had a firm commitment of $100million in Federal aid to finance a statewide food stamp program for the poor, expected to begin July 1.

title: Yachts From Netherlands Exhibited by Van Breems
description: Two fiberglass keel saillit yachts imported from the Netherlands, the Contest 30 and the Contest 27, are being exhibited by Van Breems of Westport, Conn.

title: Police Training Meeting Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) A Government crimefight ing agency will conduct a na tionwide conference on law en forcement education and train ing Feb. 1 to 3 in Jacksonville, Fla., Attorney General John N. Mitchell has announced. Mr. Mitchell said Thursday about 150 officials and educators, in cluding representatives of state boards of education and police training commissions, would at tend the sessions, conducted by the Law Enforcement Assist ance Administration.

title: Pistol Pete Is Drawing a Bead on College Basketball's Career Scoring Record
description: BATON ROUGEHis long brown hair flopped toward his face, but Pistol Pete Maravich had no sideburns.

title: Patricia A. McCue Planning Wedding
description: BELMONT, Mass., Jan. 24  Mrs. Charles H. McCue has announced the engage ment of her daughter, Miss Patricia Ann McCue, to John Spencer Marwell. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian L. Marwell of New York. A wedding in August is planned.

title: YOUTHS TO PATROL A BROOKLYN AREA
description: Twentyfive young men  some with minor arrest records and many without highschool diplomassoon will be patrol ing the streets of Bedford Stuyvesant in Brooklyn.

title: GUSTAV ECKSTEIN
description: Dr. Eckstein's extraordinary book on the human body illuminates every facet of the marvelous subject with wit, wisdom, and a warm and truly superb literary style. Obviously this is a labor of love. . . . Dr. Eckstein is a scientist who writes like a philosophera some times witty philosopher. He uses sim ple analogies with powerful effect, and his discussion of the body's defense mechanisms, couched in military terms, is virtually worth the price of the book, which culminates in a sweeping study of the human head and its mysterious brain, its creativity that distinguishes man from the beasts. With great learn ing Dr. Eckstein ranges from Hippoc rates to Pavlov and Freud, and his book is magnificent in its field.

title: Soviet Reports Accident
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24 (Reuters) An undisclosed number of workers were killed in an acci dent at a woodworking factory here Thursday,.it was announced today. The announcement in the local Communist party newspa per, Moscow Pravda, said a commission of inquiry would investigate the accident, in which a shop roof collapsed after a steam engine explosion.

title: BERTRAM MAKES BID FOR FISHING MARKET
description: Bertram Yachts, in a bid for a greater share of the sport fishing market, is showing two new luxury sports fishermen in fiberglass. One is 38 feet, the other 35 feet long.

title: Bob Scheffing: Starting at Top
description: When Bob Scheffing was named general manager of the New York Mets last week, he received messages of congratulations from Michael Burke of the Yankees, his old friends on the Detroit Tigers, his for mer batboy in Georgia and the Baltimore Orioles.

title: How Companies Chip At the Cost Corners
description: Effective immediately, the memo read, air trans portation will be booked in economy or tourist facilities for business trips to both domestic and overseas destina tions.

title: MOTORS UNDERGO A  TO  Z TESTING
description: The outboard manufacturers aren't saying you should put your new motor through its paces in Death Valley's Fur nace Creek, but in case you do, they've made sure it will function at temperatures as high as 120 degrees.

title: A bank robber from Berkeley
description: Writing is a difficult, lonely business: nobody applauds at the completion of a successful paragraph; arranging words and shaping sentences lacks the immediate, tactile pleasure of mixing paint or arcwelding scrapmetal; on the average, more money can be earned pumping gas or clerking in shoe store. In the face of all this, perhaps an author de serves a pat on the back simply for putting in the hours.

title: MUSEUM POST GIVEN TO MRS. GASTEYER
description: Mrs. Carlin Evans Gasteyer has been appointed vice di rector for administration of the Brooklyn Museum, it was an nounced yesterday by Thomas S. Buechner, museum director. She succeeds David Saltonstall, who has been named program director for the Mellon Founda tion.

title: BoatingCamping Mixed At Westcheiter Show
description: The 10th annual Westches ter Boat, Sport and Camping Show will be held at the Westchester County Center in White Plains March 20 to 22, according to Edward L. Ceccolini, the producer.

title: Ulbricht Unbends a Bit on Talks With Bonn
description: BERLINFor the first time in 20 years it seemed last week as though the Germans, sepa rated by barriers of barbed wire, minefields, a chain of machinegun towers stretching 825 miles and a policy of mu tual hostility practiced by their two states, might be able to start talking to each other at the government level.

title: ADVICE OFFERED IN BUYING PAINT
description: With the price of almost ev erything at the Boat Show showing an inflationary trend, boatmen too are keeping an eye on the rising cost of up keep.

title: Back Away to Get Away
description: If you attempt to pull away from a dock in forward gear, your stern will bump against the dock. Instead, back away slowly from the dock and shift to forward only when you're well clear.

title: Like Radio City With Wings
description: The aviation world hadn't talked so much about anything since it put jet engines on air liners 11 years ago and ignited a revolution in travel.

title: Coins
description: CANADA, which has made numerous changes in its coinage in recent years, is now planning new designs for Its notes. It has been announced that the portrait of Queen Elizabeth, now on the face side of the $5, $10, $50 and $100 notes, will give way to the like nesses of politicians famous in the history of the Domin ion. For the time being at least, the Queen's picture will be retained on the $1, $2, and $20 bills.

title: Daughter for Paulevs
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 24A daughter was born Jan. 16 to Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Pauley in the Chester County Hospital here.

title: Rockefeller to Mayors: I Have No Pot of Gold
description: ALBANY  The day before he released his 197071 budget, Governor Rockefeller carefully set the stage for an effort to head off what had already de veloped as his most serious lead ership challenge  the coalition of bigcity mayors.

title: BAR PANEL URGES ACTION ON ETHICS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A study group of the American Bar Association called today for widespread changes in the machinery for disciplining er rant lawyers, which the panel said was frequently illfinanced, poorly coordinated and inade quate.

title: Hirohito's Allowance to Rise
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Emperor Hirohito and his fam ily will receive a 13 per cent increase in their official allow ance for living expenses April The imperial household agency said an eightman panel, presided over by Premier Eisaku Sato, decided to increase the allowance for the first time in two years, bringing it to near ly $164.000.

title: WESTLAWN GROUP TAKES DESIGNING
description: From Singapore comes a re quest for information on the laws of flotation; from Libya a question on basic types of hulls; from New Guinea an appeal for clarification on the Raynor and Colin Archer theories.

title: Trudeau without the Trudeaumania
description: OTTAWA.

title: British Team Deplores Misconduct in Nigeria
description: LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP)A British mission appointed by Prime Minister Wilson de plored today what it called the indiscipline and miscon duct of Nigerian soldiers flushed with victory in the former Biafran enclave.

title: Skippers to Observe Separate Handicap Rules in Two Great Lakes Events
description: Skippers who sail in both Mackinac races on the Great Lakes next summerthe De troit Bayview Yacht Club's event on July 11 and the Chicago Y.C.'s trip on July 18 will operate under separate handicap rules.

title: Pollution 2: Next to Motherhood For Votes in California
description: LOS ANGELESOne result of our instant communication en vironment is the instant clich. A phrase uttered over the air waves one day becomes a house hold word the next.

title: DRUG BILL CLAUSE DIVIDES SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 24  The Senate divided today over a proposal that Federal agents be authorized to break into buildings on narcotics raids without notice if they believed that a warning could result in their injury or destruction of the narcotics.

title: As I Live And Breathe
description: As I Live And Breathe

title: PARCHMENT NEXT, TRAILING BY NECK
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 24 (AP) Juvenile John, winner of the $100,000 added John B. Camp bell Handicap at Bowie Race Course last winter, tuned up today for next month's renewal by winning the $29,100 Bowie Handicap.

title: U. S., State and City Joining in Job Training
description: The complex and mammoth task of linking unemployed men and women to the thou sands of unfilled and available jobs in the city has taken a tentative step forward with developing Federal, state and city effort aimed at coordinat ing programs that educate, train and, finally, lead to em ployment.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CURT GOWDY, whose res onant voice is a familiar sound in every sports fan's household, has been host, since its inception, of Amer ican Broadcasting Company's perennially popular outdoor television series, The Amer ican Sportsman, which opens its sixth season this after noon at 4 P.M., New York time.

title: A SOLID APPROACH BEST FOR SPORT
description: Water skiing is a challenging but easytolearn summer sport. This explains the reason why upward of 10 million Ameri cans participate in the fun each year.

title: Bargain Buy in Sports
description: If current newboat prices average out at $2 to $2.50 a pound, as Messrs. Muir and Nelson of ChrisCraft were recently quoted as saying, boats are the biggest bargain in American sport, pound for pound.

title: Nuns' Racial Stand in South Is Hailed
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24  The Most Rev. Philip M. Han nan, Archbishop of New Or leans, has commended 23 relig ious communities that adopted a policy calling for nuns to stop teaching in schools that are not racially integrated.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: By ANNEMARIE SCHIRO

title: STRAND SHORTING IS EASY TO AVOID
description: When rigging up a new boat trailer, watch for strand short ing. After the ends of tail light wires have been stripped, it's a common practice to twist the strands of fine copper wire together before connecting them to the terminals.

title: Article 6  No Title
An Epitaph For Biafra
description: IT is possible to describe the fall of Biafra, a man might say, as one of those African tales of ignorance, savagery and contempt for human lifeour ignorance, Britain's sav agery, and Russia's contempt.

title: U.C.L.A. Romps by 11577
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (UPI) Topranked University of Cal ifornia, Los Angeles, sped to a 122 lead in less than four min utes tonight and went on to crush Wymoing, 11577.

title: Australia Postpones OilDrilling Plan
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 24 Plans to drill for oil in the Great Barrier Reef, one of the world's natural wonders, has been post poned pending a Government survey of effects on the en vironment if the drilling is al lowed.

title: Justo was conned from the start
description: Most novelists wind up in Hollywood; Budd Schulberg, however, developed there since his father was production head of Paramount until a well publicized, highly selfdrama tized fall. Not surprisingly, Schulberg has always been fas cinated with power, how it is achieved and how it is dissi pated, against a background of sham and chicanery. His heroes and heels, at once selfpitying and sociologically explicable, always revel in worlds that are about to be revealed. What Makes Sammy Run, though perhaps dated like any proto type, was not an unimportant book; and The Disenchanted was certainly not undeserving of its popular success.

title: Nancy D. Valentine to Be Wed To T. Dennis Bennett in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Richard Hewlett Valentine of New York of the engagement of his daugh ter, Miss Nancy Diane Valen tine, to T. Dennis Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hiram M. Bennett of Rochester.

title: Mary Crowley Plans Wedding
description: Lieut. (jg.) Mary Ellen Crowley and Lieut. John T. Clark Jr. plan to be married in August.

title: 8 Trains Canceled as Crews Protest Cold in Engine Cabs
description: Eight trains on the Hudson division of the Penn Central were canceled yesterday when engineers refused to operate them, according to a spokes man for the railroad.

title: Patton Film Premiere to Aid Arthritis Foundation
description: General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, retired, and Mrs. Bradley will be guests of honor at a supper dance Feb. 4 at the Plaza after the world premiere of Patton, the movie inspired by General Bradley's World War II col league, Gen. George S. Patton Jr.

title: THE STARTING FIVE
SAMPSON COUNSEL TAKES PACE FINAL
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 24 Jerry Koosman, the New York Mets' standout southpaw, vis isted with Carmine Abbatiello for a few races in the paddock tonight before making the presentation to the winning horse and driver in the $25,000 Early Bird Racing Series Final at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Art Notes
description: ASERIES of lively, though unscheduled art events has been occurring at the Museum of Mod ern Art this past yearand not exactly with MOMA's wholehearted cooperation. I'm referring to the demon strations put on by the de termined and somewhat stud iedly seedy disorganization known as the Art Workers Coalition. (The AWC, in case you've just come in, is a looseknit group of museo phobic artists, writers, film makers and epheaneralists, who seekwithout the aid of foundation moneyto re form the art world structure. They have presented MOMA with an 11point list of de mands, ranging from free ad mission at all times to the establishment of a section de voted Ito the work of black and Puerto Rican artists.)

title: GAINS ARE MADE IN FEDERAL DRIVE FOR NEGRO HIRING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  After several years of slow progress in the Government's efforts to open goodpaying jobs for minorities through law and executive action, there are signs of possible breakthroughs in several areas.

title: KEINO WINS MILE; LIQUORI IS THIRD
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 Seconds before the start of the invitation mile run at the Phila delphia Track Classic tonight, an announcement over the pub licaddress system proclaimed Marty Liguori as the world's No. 1 runner at 1,500 meters.

title: Microscopic View
description: Canada has an unusualdesign com memortaive coming out on February 18a microscopic view of the inside of a leaf. Designed by Israel Charney, the multicolored 6cent stamp will note Canada's participation in the In ternational Biological Program, a project involving scientists from ap proximately 60 countries which began in July, 1967. The stamp will be printed by the British American Bank Note Co., Ltd., Ottawa, by photogravure and steel engraving in green, light orange and blue.

title: Reader's Report
description: This is a remarkably spare and stirring chase that Mr. Sa las has concocted out of a hellbent sprint from the law. It abounds, in candid snapshots of the drug community (like a 3yearold on LSD), and it vis ualizes a Mexican border Wasteland whose menace to the protagonists grows heavier by the minute. If you are re minded of James M. Cain and the twofisted style of Black Mask, you get three gold stars for excellence of memory.

title: SOCIALISTS FACING DECISION IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24Battered by their defeat in last month's general election, the Japanese Socialists now confront a criti cal decision: whether to aban don doctrinaire Marxism and to seek out the independent voter actively by tackling concrete problems of the day.

title: SloanKettering Fashion Benefit Planned for Feb. 5
description: The annual luncheon and fashion show sponsored by the Thrift Shop of the Me morial SloanKettering Can cer Center will be held in the WaldorfAstoria's Grand Ballroom on Feb. 5. Mrs. Walter B. Delafield is chair man for the event, which is a means of obtaining rum mage for the Thrift Shop at 1410 Third Avenue at 80th Street.

title: Kerr on
description: IT would not simply be un kind but irrelevant to dwell on the lapse of judgment that caused the Opposites Company's produc tion of Hedda Gabler to en gage itself in the Off Broad way competition. The Oppo sites Company is clearly a selfhypnotized, indeed som nambulistic, association of amateurs who seem to have done all of their early re hearsing in a closet and are now hopelessly uncomforta ble to have been let out.

title: WILDCATS MOVE INTO 5756 LEAD
description: In a game decided in the final seconds, St. John's Uni versity staved off Villanova's secondhalf rally to score a 6057 victory in Alumni Hall, Queens, last night.

title: 3 More Executed In Iraq After Plot Against Baathists
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24 Three more men were executed in Baghdad at dawn today bringing to 44 the number shot or hanged since the leftist Baath Government in Iraq headed off a rightist plot on Tuesday.

title: GAS WAR TRAINING GIVEN FOREIGNERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Although the United States de cided recently to limit its use of chemical and biological weapons, the Army is continu ing to train foreign officers in C.B.W.

title: 41 American poets: a sympathetic reading
description: We learn about the poetry of our time in fits and starts, scraps and blanks. No single magazine or group of maga zines pretends any longer to magisterial inclusions and ex clusions of new poets, as the big little magazine quarter lies, Partisan, Kenyon and the others, did in the forties. I doubt that even the poets themselves can keep up with the many journals of their peers these days. Reviews. even the jumbo roundups that brave reviewers still undertake, are at best accidents of the season and of the editor and of the reviewer; many books come and go quite without no tice. Anthologies are probably what we most depend upon, but again these are likely to be partly accidental and part ly tendentious. Books about the poetry of our time usually and properly concentrate on the same figures: Berryman, Bish op, Jarrell, Lowell, Roethke, Wilbur.

title: Dartmouth Triumphs, 8883
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan 24 Alex Winn scored 35 points and grabbed 15 rebounds to lead Dartmouth to an 8883 victory over the University of Connect icut at Alumni Gym tonight.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: By Felicien Marceau. Translated by Jim Underwood. 240 pp. New York: Grossman Publishers. $5.95.

title: Jane: Everybody Expected Me to Fall on My Face
description: TWO hours before midnight on New Year's Eve, Lady Jane Seymour Brokaw Fonda Plemiannikov was not crying in her eggnog. She was coiled like Cleopatra's asp on the living room sofa of her father's lush townhouse on East 74th Street in a passionpurple sack sweater right out of Margie, a medieval belt her brother Peter wore in Spirits of the Dead, a leather mini skirt, and Barbarella boots that soared almost as high as her Panavision thighs. This is the end of a decade, she said confidently, and I find it very reassuring that in my adult life I've experienced the end of a decade with a future that looks very positive. I'm very optimistic about the world tonight.

title: SEARCH CONTINUES IN YABLONSKI CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The search for the person or group believed to have paid a large sum of money for the slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter continued to day amid indications that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was trying to get more evidence of a payment on a murder con tract before making further arrests.

title: DAVID ALAN NASS
description: STOWE, Vt., Jan. 24David Alan Nass, the 19yearold son of Samuel Nass, executive vice president and treasurer of Gim bels, in New York, was fatally injured in a skiing accident here yesterday afternoon.

title: Displays and Courses

title: Personality:
description: PITTSBURGH  One morning some years ago, soon after arriving at his of fice, Fletcher L. Byrom, pres ident of the Koppers Com pany, cancelled everything he had planned for the day and hurried to the Pittsburgh air port.

title: Lynn Goldman to Wed March 28
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 24  Miss Lynn Alexandra Goldman, who completed her junior year at the University of Denver, plans to be mar ried March 28 to Lawrence Schan, a senior at Pennsyl vania State University, where he is studying architecture.

title: New Sanitation Devices Approved in New York
description: Boatmen who have toilets on their craft and by law must have sewage handling devices installed by March 1 now have four additional. units approved for use on the waters of New York State.

description: NORTH PALM BEACH, Fla. On the shore of Little Lake Worth, a ranchstyle home basks in the Florida sun while a 16foot Evinrude out board, its mighty 100horse power engine stilled, rides gently at the end of the dock.

title: BIG HYDROGEN CLOUD IS SEEN NEAR COMET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) An orbiting astronomical ob servatory, OAO2, has discov ered a hydrogen cloud as large as the sun around a newly found comet, the National Aeronautics and Space Admin istration reports.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24  A military survey of race relations at United States Army bases throughout the world has concluded that all indications point to an increase in racial tensions.

title: 8 Former Major Leaguers Will Be Honored in Maine
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 24 (AP) Representatives of the world champion New York Mets and the Boston Red Sox will be on hand tomorrow when eight for mer major leaguers will be in ducted into the Maine Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: NO. CAROLINA STATE BEATS DUKE, 7776
description: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 24 (AP) North Carolina State went ahead at the half after being down by as many as 11 points and held on the rest of the way for a 7776 victory over Duke in an Atlantic Coast Con ference game today.

description: In his State of the Union message last week, President Nixon said that never has a nation seemed to have had more and enjoyed it less.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 24Fortynine countries have announced pledges of $215,423,580 for the World Food Program of the United Nations and its Food and Agri culture Organization.

title: Tenant Says Landlord Uses Addicts
description: A tenant in an East Side apartment building told a State Senate Housing Committee yes terday that young drug addicts undergoing rehabilitation were being used in his building as part of a plot to drive out the other tenants. One of the build ings owners, however, denied that his intention was to drive his regular tenants out.

title: Letters
description: COEDUCATION AT BENNINGTON

title: Schenk 3d in 5,000 Meters, But Leads in Title Skating
description: INSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 24 (AP)Ark Schenk of the Ne therlands finished third in the 5,000meter race today and took the lead after two events in the European speedskating championships. The final two events will be held tomorrow.

title: A Tyrolean Town Hosts The World's Best Skiers
description: O RTISEI, Italy  This will be one world ski championship in which the spectator does not have to be a spectator for a whole week h doesn't want to, said my guide, World War II Austrian Army infantryman. We have a network of 90 lifts here In the Val Gardena and nearby valleys. A spectator who wants to ski for a day or two can take off and find plenty of room on nearby slopes.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Stages of an Autobiography. By Malcolm Boyd. 276 pp. New York: Random House. $6.95.

title: Show Expected to Measure Success of the Next Decade
description: LIKE diamond bracelets and Mediter ranean vacations, yachting is par ticularly sensitive to economic fluctua tions. The year ahead will be distinguished so far as competition is concerned because it will contain both a match for the America's Cup, world sailing's greatest prize, and a Newport toBermuda biennial offshore race. Both events are usually spurs to increased interest in yachting. How much they will be stimulants in a period of eco nomic uncertainty remains to be seen.

title: An Icebound Nantucket Gets Airlifted Supplies
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Jan. 24 (UPI)An emergency air lift early today brought about 35,000 pounds of food sup plies to icebound Nantucket Island. Executive Airlines made six 20minute flights from Hyannis on the main land to the island 30 miles off Cape Cod, where perish able foods bad been running low.

title: Boat Show Calendar
description: TODAYU.S. 420 Association meeting, Japan Room, Coliseum 10 A.M.

title: Three Die in Louisiana As a Gas Line Explodes
description: HOUMA, La., Jan. 24 (UPI)  A leaking gas line ex ploded in a downtown man hole today, killing three per sons and demolishing half a city block.

title: Staten Island Man Slays Himself After Killing Wife
description: A 48yearold Staten Island man shot and killed his wife with a rifle yesterday at their home and then killed himself with the same weapon, the po lice reported.

title: Astronaut to Get Award
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Jan. 24 (AP)  Col. Frank Borman, the astronaut who read the story of the creation from Genesis while orbiting the moon on Christmas Eve, 1968, will re ceive the first Better World Award given by the Veterans of Foreign Wars Auxiliary.

title: Snowmobile Mark Set
description: EAGLE RIVER, Wis., Jan. 24 (UPI)Gaston Ferland of Val court, Quebec, set a snowmobile drag racing record over a guar termile during competition to day at the seventh annual world championship snow mobile derby. He turned in a 96.56 mileanhour showing, beating the 95.33 mark set last year by Duane Eck, Driggs, Idaho. Eck was second today.

title: GREECE RESUMING ALBANIAN TRADE
description: ATHENS, Jan. 24Greece's military  backed Government disclosed today that it had reaohed agreement with neigh boring Albania to resume trade relations, which were broken off 30 years ago. The two countries are technically still at war.

title: The Theater: 2 SuperHits Revisited
description: THE other day, it occurred to me apocalyptically that in a moment of sublime mu nicipal truth the crosstown traffic, the uptown traffic and the downtown traffic would become inextricably confused. The vehicles going that way and vehicles going this way would be stuck for ever in the streets of Man hattan. For some 20 hours people would blow their horns. Then, realizing the impossibility of bucking destiny, they would get out of their cars, leave their cabs, desert their trucks, shrug their shoulders and emigrate.

title: NAYAR BEATS REESE IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 24Anil Nayar of Boston, the national champion who heads the draw, reached the semifinals of the 2Sth annual invitation squash racquets tournament at The Apawamis Club today by de feating John Reese of the Sev enth Regiment Armory, New York, 155, 1512, 915, 156.

title: Search for Atlantis Leads to a Surprise
description: SOME men go to sea for adventure, some for experience and some for riches. Two youngwriters in their first venture afloat definitely found the first two, and there are strong indications that they might also come up with riches.

title: Article 1  No Title
Report by Staff of Mills's Panel Critical of Nixon Welfare Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 President Nixon's priority pro gram on welfare reform might break up poor working families, put some college students on welfare and indirectly finance the purchase of color television sets, a secret Congressional study says.

title: Bing Paces Pistons, 128122
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24 (AP)  Dave Bing continued his torrid scoring tonight in leading the Detroit Pistons to a 128122 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Hitting the Treebee Jackpot Without Tryingin Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGASWhile driving along the Vegas Strip recently, I found my eyes assaulted by a clutch of motel signs promising all manner of free coupons good for all manner of free thingsfrom viands and beverages to coin of the realm.

title: Americans Now Need Visas
description: BANGKOK, Jan. 24 (AP) Restrictions on American visits to Thailand have aroused con fusion and complaints among; United States businessmen here. The Americans are inter preting new visa requirements as an indication of a more as sertive Thai nationalistic atti tude in dealing with Washing ton.

title: Aluminum Craft Shown
description: A nineboat, allaluminum ex hibit of light fishing craft and cartoppers is being presented by the Appleby Manufacturing Company of Lebanon, Mo.

title: Britons Poised To Invade U. S.
description: LONDONThe british are coming! The British are coming! They will be marching on the Unit ed States in greater numbers than ever this year because of the removal of their annual limit of 50 ($120) on spend ing abroad. The restriction, which had been imposed since 1966 in order to reduce the flow of sterling from this country, discouraged many Britons from even contem plating a transAtlantic trip.

title: Perpetual master of the wrong subject
description: There are Marshall and Mad eline Slovin, the couple who talk so much about the prepa ration of the meal they serve their guests that they scarcely have time to eat it. There are Elliot Nardling, heir to a hair net fortune, and his wife Myr na, who gives parties at which there are never more than two people to whom any reason ably wellinformed person would dare address the ques tion What do you do? There is Roland Magruder, a whim sical freelance writer who gets as much out of refusing to attend a party as most people do by spending an entire eve ning at one.

title: Northwestern Wing, 6665
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 24 (UPI)Jim Sarno of North western dropped in the winning basket with 59 seconds to play and the Wildcats hung on for a 6665 triumph over Purdue as the Boilermakers missed four times on fieldgoal tries in the final minute.

title: Miss Delaney Wed in Jersey
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24 In St. Aloysius Roman Cath olic Church here this after noon, Miss Florence G. De laney, daughter of Mrs. Wil liam A. Delaney and the late Mr. Delaney, was married to James Francis Lynch. He is the son of Mrs. James F. Lynch and the late Dr. Lynch, who was a general practi tioner and surgeon, and a greatgrandson of Edward V. Hoos, Mayor of Jersey City at the turn of the century. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Lennon, assisted by the Rev. John Budwick.

title: FRAZIER IS STAR
description: An aggressive, challenging defense that Coach Alex Han num of the San Diego Rockets said wouldn't let us do what we wanted to, brought the New York Knickerbockers a 127114 victory last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: W. GERMAN SLED LEADS FOR TITLE
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 24 (UPI)  The West German team of Horst Floth and Pepi Bader opened its bid for the 1970 world twoman bobsled championship today by running away from the rest of the field in the first two heats of the competition.

title: Dartmouth Six Subdues Princeton in Overtime, 54
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 24 Ken Davidson scored his sec ond goal of the afternoon at 2 minutes 47 seconds of a sud Iden death overtime period to day to give Dartmouth hockey team a 54 victory over Prince ton at Baker Rink.

title: Semantics
description: When I returned to the University of Georgia, I had covered black stu dent demonstrations from Howard University to Vassar College, and I thought I understood the psyche of the Northern black  the hard, urban militant tradition which shaped it. But the South ern psyche, in my experi ence, had been different. The relationship of blacks to whites was different because Southerners just seemed to know each other better and, as a re sult, each had a better idea of where the other stood on issues. Southern black militancy, then, was rarely as violent as that of the North, and some think it worked better.

title: MANHATTAN SINKS SETON HALL, 9388
description: Playing its first game in the wake of the announced resigna tion of Coach Richie Regan, the Seton Hall Pirates sailed one of Manhattan's home courts last night only to be scuttled. 9388, by the Jaspers.

title: David, like Elie Wiesel, survived and must constantly justify his survival
description: Like Elie Wiesel himself, David, the narrator of A Beggar in Jerusalem and of the many tales interwoven in this novel, comes from a little town somewhere in Transylvania where a Jewish child studies the Talmud and is dazzled by the melancholy of its universe made up of legends. And like the author, born in 1928, at the age of 15 he is torn away from his home and thrown with his par ents and his sister into the death camp of Auschwitz.

title: Job Changes:
description: George M. Perry, 48 years old, has been elected presi dent of BeechNut, Inc., man ufacturer of specialty foods, beverages and confections. He formerly was group vice pres ident for food services and corporate acquisitions at the General Foods Corporation, where he was also a member of the corporate policy com mittee

title: New Guinea Landslide Kills 5
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The bodies of five men, including an American and an Australian, have been re covered from a huge landslide on the New Guinea Island of New Britain, it was reported tonight. The three other vic tims were Papuans. No names were given.

title: ExConvict Found Insane in Slaying Of Michigan Coed
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 24 (UPI)  Ernest L. Bishop Jr., charged with murdering a Uni versity of Michigan coed during a series of kilings that terror ized girls on two campuses, has been found not guilty of murder by reason of insanity.

title: Fordham Defeats Temple
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (UPI)Bob Cassou scored 5 points in the second overtime period tonight that gave Ford ham a 7064 victory over Tem ple at the Palestra.

title: Hippies Get in the Artists' Hair In Mexico's San Miguel Allende
description: SAN MIGUEL ALLENDE, MexicoThere is a certain sameness to many Mexican towns of 15,000 popula tion, but this one is different. Standing at an altitude of 6,400 feet, it has hills that are steeper than San Francisco's, terraced rows of adobe huts and treelined streets of great colonial homes that were built by Spanish grandees of another day and are now owned by Ameri cans. Some of the residents are quite distinctive, too.

title: Engagements
description: DIAMONDRUBINMr. and Mrs. Murray Rubin announce the engagement of their daughter, Janet to Bernard (Hank) Dia mond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Dia mond on January 15, 1970.

title: Bombers Strike in Delta And Northwest of Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 25Waves of United States B52 bombers at tacked suspected enemy bases along the Cambodian and Lao tion borders northwest of Saigon yesterday and early today, mili tary, spokesman said.

title: Dinghy Is Designed For Carriage Trade
description: A new luxury fiberglass dinghy designed by a naval architect, Philip C. Bolger, has been introduced by the Landsdowne Yacht Corpora tion of Neptune, N. J.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BANGOR, Pa., Jan. 24 Mrs. J. Hayden Jones has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Audrey Ann Jones of New York, to Reginald Wadsworth Cau chois Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Quogue, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Cauchois of Yonkers.

title: In a Game of Individuals, They Are a Community
description: The larger surprise deals not with ballplayers but with the Knicks them selves. Considering that their rela tionship to each other has been eulogized in the press, and that on the court they epitomize the cohesion and interaction of basketball at its best, it is difficult to deal with the fact that they do not say hello to each other upon arrival nor good night when after the game they leave. There is in fact a sense of iso lation about them, and later, on the road, the same thing will be evident. More often than not, they will eat alone, go off alone in airports, sit alone on planes. Few are close friends off the court, few see each other once the season ends. Though Bradley says there is profound re spect among them, an ability to listen to each other and criticize without rancor, and none of the players would dispute him on that, neither would they dispute Willis Reed when he says, We see enough of each other. On a team, like in a marriage, it can hurt more than help if you spend too much time together.

title: Lindsay Names an Aide For Crises Situations'
description: The appoinment of Theodore Gross as a $17,500ayear as sistant to Mayor Lindsay to work in the area of community problems and crises situations was announced yesterday.

title: Does Bernstein Really ant to Compose?
description: ILL tell you anything you want to know, says Leonard Bernstein, speaking several octaves lower than usual. That is, if my voice holds out. He has just risen from a lateafternoon nap after a full day's rehearsal with the Philharmonic, getting the concert version of Fidelio into shape. The previous night he had conducted the opening performance of Cavalleria Rusticana at the Metropolitan. He looks a wreck, and a superb case of laryngitis is setting in with a vengeance.

title: Testing Good Intentions
description: The emphasis placed on the American environment by President Nixon in his Message to Congress can be advanced from promise to performance in a number of threatened areas of the country. A test will come on specific projects to safeguard diminishing natural resources from commercial exploitation.

title: SCHOOL ELECTIONS ARE FOUGHT BY 200
description: Opposition to the forthcom ing local school board elections was voiced yesterday at a meet ing of Manhattan parents and community groups at Teachers College. Columbia University.

title: St. Peter's Routs Wagner As Rinaldi Excels, 12381
description: St. Peter's College, led by Rich Rinaldi's 32 points, crushed Wagner College, 12381, at Sut ter Gymnasium on Staten Is land last night.

title: U.S. Cigarette Ban Urged On Interstate Smuggling
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24Governor Rockefeller has urged Congress to pass a Federal law to fight the highly profitable inter state smuggling of cigarettes that he says has been draining New York revenues.

title: Article 8  No Title
Alcoa Combines Some Activities
description: The Aluminum Company of America has concentrated all its interests in real estate, housing construction and building products into a single unit, to be called Alcoa Building Industries, the par ent concern has announced.

title: Defense and steals have become hallmarks of the Knicks
description: TV announcer) and by the five New York area sportswriters (called the pack by the team) who travel with them, they board a bus outside the Garden 90 minutes after the game. Many of the players have used this time to stop into the Harry M. Stevens Bar at the north end of the Garden, where, one by one, they are ap plauded as they enter. Crowd ing around the bus, as they board, are perhaps 80 fans most of them kids but at least a quarter adultsscratching at the windows with pro grams, yearbooks or anything else that will bear an auto graph. The players take seats in a configuration that will re main constant through the trip, on the eight different buses they will ride: Holzman and Whelan in the front two seats, Reed alone just behind them, Frazier alone behind Reed, Stallworth, Barnett, Nate Bowman and Russell in the rear, the others in the middle. What's the count, captain? Holzman says, and Reed: All here, Red.

title: Roomy TriCabin Cruiser Seats 8 on Flying Bridge
description: The Royal 40, a new fiber glass tricabin cruiser, is being introduced as the queen of the Tollycraft Corporation's 1970 fleet. The cost is about $48,990 with twin Chrysler 300 horse power engines.

title: Five Black Priests Challenge South African Catholic Church
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 24  Five African clergymen have called here for more power for blacks in the Roman Catholic Church in South Africa.

title: Let's Go Boating!
BOATMEN TURNING TO SEA OF BOOKS
description: An odd and undesirable prop erty of water is that it tends to become hard and unyielding when the temperature falls be low 32 degrees Fahrenheit.

I., was mar ried here this afternoon to Joseph James Miner, son of Mrs. and Mrs. Joseph Martin Miner of Coventry.

title: Rebecca Banks Engaged to Wed E.R.Mowbray 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Bradford Banks of New York and Southbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Re becca Ringgold Banks, to Ed win Roland Mowbray 3d. He is the son of Mrs. John Stephen Hebb 3d and step son of Mr. Hebb, a partner in the Baltimore law firm of Miles & Stockbridge.

description: et's daytime estimate of him selfand to allow the reader to make a measure, too: Whit man and Emerson?

title: Pennsylvania Tuition Up
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (UPI)  A $200 tuition increase for University of Pennsylvania students and a rise in rental rates for university residence halls were announced Tuesday. The increases raised basic fees for undergraduate and profes sional students to $2,550 a year beginning in September. The increase rates for the men's dormitories and Hill Hall, the largest women's dormitory, will be $50. Those for other residences will be $100.

title: BAKKE CAPTURES SKI JUMP EVENT
description: EAU CLAIPE, Wis., Jan. 24 Bill Bakke ??ne softspoken red head from downstate Madison, got off to a flying start today in his hid for a berth on the United States Federation Inter nationale de Ski special jump ing squad.

title: Canadians Will Retire Another TransAtlantic Liner
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 24  The Port of Montreal began adjust ing this week to the loss from service of another wellknown transAtlantic liner, the 25,585 ton Empress of England, of C.P. Ships.

title: Etony Wins in Stretch Run, Pays $9.60 at New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 (AP) Etony took command in the stretch and steadily drew away today in the 27th running of the $20,000added Louisiana Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

title: U. S. Officials in Thailand Are Following Up Agnew's Visit by Renewing the Assurances He Offered
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 24 Three weeks after Vice Presi dent Agnew's brief stop in Thailand during his 11nation tour of Asia, a little of the good feeling engendered by his sympathetic attention to Thai grievances against the United States has worn off but Amer ican officials here are already beginning to renew the assur ances he offered.

title: Fitz Hugh Lane is the hero,
description: The publication of this volume in an extremely handsome format, co piously illustrated in color as well as black and white, and aimed at general distribution is, as the pub lisher's blurb writer states, a sign that the study of American art has reached a new maturity. For this is neither a comprehensive survey of 19thcentury painting nor a series of essays on the artists usually con sidered most important. The text is individualistic, not to say idiosyn cratic: It is an erudite and impas sioned argument for a specific es thetic and philosophical theory. In attempting to answer the old query, What is American about American art? Barbara Novak summarily ex cludes a startling number of the painters usually greatly admired.

title: Always Use Fresh Gas
description: Always use fresh gasoline in your outboard motor. Gasoline contains certain gum and var nish deposits. When kept in a tank too long, these deposits may cause carburetor trouble and sparkplug fouling.

title: A MATCHMAKER PLAYS KEY ROLE
description: Judith Kwaloff is a match maker. She matches wouldbe American yachtsmen with some 100 available charter yachts at a dozen or more British West Indies islands.

title: Inflation Is Always Someone Else's Fault
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon devoted just 18 sentences of his State of the Union mes sage to what looms as the ma jor political issue of the 1970 election year, and he got to the heart of the matter in a single line. It is tempting, the Pres ident told the assembled Con gress, to blame someone else for inflation.

title: Headliners
description: George Brown, who was seldom out of hot water while Britain's Foreign Secretary, was back in London last week after a private tour of the Middle East during which he was reported to have (A) told Premier Golda Meir, You are merely a Jewess from Russia who came to Israel via America, (B) ordered Maj. Gen. Chaim Herzog, former chief of Israeli intelligence, to wipe that silly grin off your face, (C) told the British Ambassador to Israel, John Barnes, to shut up during an argument at a dinner party given by Israeli Foreign Minister Abba Eban, and (D) stalked out of the dinner in a huff. Brushing off the reports as highly exaggerated, Mr. Brown, who is still Deputy Chairman of the Parliamentary Labor party, said, I am what God made me. I don't intend to change at the age of 55.

title: FIRSTTIME BUYER ASKED TO BE WARY
description: Every year nearly a million families purchase their first boat. Many begin by visiting boat shows and marine deal ers' showrooms. Others decide to buy when a friend offers to sell them his used boat, or when they spot a good deal in the classified ads.

title: South Vietnam Charges Foe Killed 4,619 Civilians in '69
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 (UPI)South Vietnam pro tested to the International Con trol Commission today charg ing that 4,619 civilians were killed and 14,412 injured by Communist terrorist acts in 1969.

title: SOUTAR CAPTURES BOWLING TOURNEY
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan 24 (UPI)Dave Soutar of Gilroy, Calif., won the biggest purse of his career today when he took the $11,111.11 firstplace prize in the $77,777.77 Showboat in vitation bowling tournament.

title: COMPUTER TO AID WITH SELECTIONS
description: An army colonel seeking a navigator for this year's Ber muda race, a retired Navy commander seeking five deck hands for a threetofiveyear voyage on a threemasted schooner and a Los Angeles doctor interested in a crew member, preferably female, for weekend cruising all have something in common. They are among the boat owners who have taken advantage of the recently instituted crew registration service offered by the Coast Navigation School of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Miss Keniston Future Bride
description: PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Jan. 24  Dr. Allen Hayward Keniston and Mrs. Keniston, also a physician who is known as Dr. Julia C. Ken iston, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sarah Keniston, to James Elder Michael, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Elder Michael of Gambier, Ohio.

title: 2,500 in Wales Protest So. African Rugby Visit
description: CARDIFF, Wales, Jan. 24 (AP)One of the biggest demonstrations of the South African rugby tour was staged here today before the Springboks were held to a 66 draw by Wales.

title: Author's Query
description: For an edition of the letters of the American novelist John Steinbeck (190268), we would appreciate receiving relevant materials.

title: Tourists in Rome Do As the Romans DoRide Scooters
description: ROME  Visitors in Rome are be ginning to move around the city the way many Romans doby motor  scooter. Scooter  for  hire advertisements have been popping up with increasing frequency on downtown street corners. To make sure the Ameri can visitors get the message, the ads are in English and carry a reproduction of a perky twowheel vehicle.

title: 11 Craft in Atiantic Exhibit
description: Four sailboats and seven row ing models, all of fiberglass, are being displayed by Atlantic Laminates, Inc., of Bellemore, L. I. They include, a new 7foot sailing dinghy, a new 7foot EconoDink rowboat and a new 8foot Super Mini I trihull row boat with a double hull.

title: Lefrak Wants to Go On Building in City
description: ONE of the plaques on a table next to Samuel J. Lefrak's desk in his penthouse office on Queens Boulevard reads: Some people see things as they are and ask why; I dream things that never were and ask why not.

title: Architecture
description: WE present with pleas ure a silver lining column today, or some evidence that civilization can prevail over cash flow. Here are a few happy endings, and one post script of ironic semisuccess.

title: Warm Yank Handshakes Put 2,000 Fans in Balmy Mood at Open House
description: No longer unbeatable and no longer aloof, the New York Yankees entertained 2,000 of their best customers yesterday at an Open House in Yankee Stadium.

title: PHILADELPHIA SET TO GET G.O.P. SLATE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 Pennsylvania's Republican party moved closer this week to an allPhiladelphia ticket for 1970 of the minority leader, Hugh Scott, for reelection to the Senate and Lieut. Gov. Ray mond J. Broderick for Gover nor.

title: Is South Africa next, after Vietnam is done?
description: It is 25 years since Cordell Hull, as Secretary of State, was lecturing the colonial powers in relation to dependent peoples who aspire to liberty. It is a dozen years since Richard Nixon, as Vice President, spent a month touring eight African states and came back to urge strong diplomatic links and a recognition of their development needs. It is 10 years since John Kennedy, as Presi dential candidate, paid $100,000 out of family funds for an airlift of 260 African students to American col leges, and so impressed men like Tom Mboya with this prompt gesture of practical help. Any number of anniversaries can be cited to suggest the time has come for a long and cool look at the relationship of the United States with independent Africa.

title: Lewis Krieger And Betty Baer Engaged to Wed
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24 Dr. and Mrs. Louis Baer have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Louise Baer of New York, to Lewis L. Krie ger, a partner of the New ark, N.J., law firm of Las ser & Krieger.

title: Impossible! Recession And Rising Prices?
description: WASHINGTONThis Admin istration has by its misguided economic policies achieved a truly remarkable economic para doxat one and the same time, almost unprecedented inflation coupled with an economic down turn. With those words last week, House Democratic leader Carl Albert of Oklahoma fore shadowed what will probably he a major thrust of the Democratic party's line in this election year.

title: Sports of The Times
description: THE SEASON had ended for the football team that represented a Job Corps unit in a schedule against California junior colleges. George Foreman, a defen sive tackle on that team, looked with grow ing disfavor on a growing waistline. So it didn't take much urging by Doc Broadus, the vocational guidance director, for big George to work out regularly in the gym.

title: The Puzzling Draft Numbers Game
description: WASHINGTONIt's a matter of life or death, a Georgetown University senior was saying last week, and you'd think they'd be able to give us more specific an swers. The young man's plaint is one heard frequently these days from men confused and dis illusioned by the new draft lot tery system.

title: Love is always too early and never too late
description: Love, like justice, is pretty much what we deserve but never quite what we would like. It is also blind, and has been known to arrive in the company of mercy and understand ing. It has the constant attention, along with war, murder and theft, of the poet and novelist, not because love is all that interesting, but be cause love demands the sacrifice of what we held most dear before love displaced it. This is why the love af fairs of the young have to be sur rounded by family feuds, cataclysms and a generous helping of scenery to protect their insipidity from grinning boredom. The advent of love into the lives of the elderly and the settled is another tale altogether.

title: My Trouble, Doctor, Is That I Like . . .
description: A FEW years ago one of the record magazines polled its critics on their most disliked composers. The name of Max Reger was on almost every list. To the young critics of the present day even if they have heard none of his music Reger represents everything wrong with postromanticism: selfindulgence, sentimen tality, gigantism, shocking taste. Nobody has a good word for him except a few Germanoriented musicians, such as Ructoir Serkin and William Steinberg; and they have been fighting a losing battle. Serkin played Reger's F minor Piano Concerto some seasons back, to vast indifference. In intellectual circles there was a feeling of amusement that Serkin should have wasted his time on so enormously vulgar a work.

title: Leesa Heydenreich to Be a Bride
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 24Miss Leesa Kirsten Hey denreich and Dennis Marion Campbell plan to be married June 13 at the First Lutheran Church here, of which the father of the future bride is minister.

title: Bridge
description: ADECLARER who can win the first trick in either hand and has no urgent reason to lead from one hand rather than from the other at the second trick may have to spin a mental coin. A good rule in such circumstances is to win in the stronger hand, thus automatically conserving the entry possibilities in the weaker hand.

title: SAFETY REMINDER: A CHECK ON SEATS
description: The seats in a fast powerboat receive more of a beating than the seats in any other kind of conveyance, and the reason is obvious.

title: PollutionControl Unit
description: The Carborundum Com pany has formed a pollution control division to coordinate and expand the company's manufacture and marketing of systems and equipment for the control, of air and water pollution.

title: Lake Havasu Event Gets Off to Spectacular Start
description: One of the most spectacular starts in boat racing occurs dur ing the annual outboard world championship at Lake Havasu City Ariz.

title: 5 Seized in Narcotics Raid Flee Jail
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Jan. 24  Five persons arrested in nar cotics raids Thursday escaped last night from the Monmouth County Jail Annex, but one was recaptured today.

title: Provocative and Promising
description: THERE is almost an embarrassment of performing riches in the two new Off Broadway double bills  Robert Hooks and Douglas Turner in The Harangues, Fred Stewart and Laurence Luckinbill in The Memory Bankand if I don't dwell on these performances in as much detail as I'd like, it's because they turn up in plays that are twothirds right. Plays that are twothirds right are ex tremely valuable plays, hinting at play wrights with futures, and our job is to see if we can find out where the other third went. If we can spot the lesion, the playwright may never make that mistake again, to everybody's profit and nexttime pleasure.

title: Observer: The State of the Family Message
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  The family being all assembled in the parlor for the an nual occasion, Great Mortgaged Father entered the chamber, took his place at the hearth and spoke as follows:

title: Virginia Cartmell Wed in Jersey
description: RUMSON, N. J., Jan. 24  Miss Virginia Cartmell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Cartmell, was married in St. George'sbytheRiver Episcopal Church here today Son to the R. A. Prenners

title: Johnson Saga in Sea Racing
description: The late Robert F. Johnson, Oregon lumber and housing development millionaire, pre ferred to talk about racing his two 73foot ketches in longdistance ocean races than about business.

title: Emergency Procedure
description: This log of aerial hugger mugger is in a class with the GradeA fancies of Dick Francis and Nicolas Freling whizbang adventure camou flaged with enough environ mental expertise to lull disbe lief. Our hero is Johnny Buege, a nonsked pilot, airport man ager and cool customer work ing out of Samuelstown, New Flamnshire. Mr. Frederics

title: What to Do About Jazz in Our August Cultural Centers?
description: THERE are indications and rumors in the air that one of our Cultural Centers or Performing Arts Centers is about to do something about jazz (as it is usually put). The rumors do not yet come, I hasten to add, from Lincoln Center (as they should) but from out there, from Washington, particular ly, and from elsewhere.

title: Kansas Fed Notes Gain InFarmNet
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 24 Farm income improved in 1969 over the 1968 level and could advance further in 1970 if conditions are favor able, but many uncertainties cloud the outlook, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.

title: Heartsblood
description: Dr. Matthew Kraft, a cardi ologist with a bad heart, wants to take the guesswork out of his prospective transplant. So he suggests that Andrew Essai, his most gifted underling, do nate his own heart to his boss. (Kraft has a contingent plan for Essai, so it isn't as though the young fellow will be to tally heartless.) Crazy? Let's call it megalomaniac, which Dr. Kraft certainly is, as well as a clinical genius, a choleric perfectionist, a godlike healer and a lousy human being. Actually, Kraft is only trying lit erally to do to his youngest ri val what his mentor, Professor Herman Lippschitz had at tempted to do to him: namely, cut his heart out. (Lippschitz, as he sabotaged the young Kraft's research, assured him that he was doomed to medi ocrity.)

title: Constitutional Question: Is There a Right to Abortion?
description: FOR years, reformers have tried to per suade state legislatures to except certain women from the general ban on abortion those women made pregnant by rape or incest, for example, or those likely to bear severely deformed child.

title: Letters: Uganda, the Pearl of Africa
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Japanese Budget for 1970 Includes a Sharp Increase in Military Spending
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24Japans military spending in 1970 will make its sharpest rise since World War II, according to the draft national budget presented by the Finance Ministry today.

title: Iraq Casts a Shadow
description: Iraq, site of some of the world's greatest ancient civilizations, once more is proving itself one of the most uncivilized of contemporary states.

title: Nixon's News Conference Postponed From Monday
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) President Nixon is postponing his next news conference from Monday until Thursday or Fri day so he can announce his veto of the $19.7billion appro priation bill for the Department of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Audrey Jones Will Be Bride
description: The wedding is planned for June 13 at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: MONTREAL TALLIES TWO EARLY GOALS
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (UP1) Bobby Rousseau's 25foot drive in the first period stood up the rest of the way and proved to be the decisive goal tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeat ed the Chicago Black Hawks, 41.

title: PortStarboard Carpet For JetPowered Board
description: A jetpowered craft known as the Jet Board has been carpeted for 1970 for added safety and to eliminate the need for waxing. A 6horse power motor provides speeds up to 10 miles an hour. The jetpower concept eliminates the need for a propeller.

title: States Widen Governors' Role In Effort to Benefit Taxpayers
description: Movements are under way in statehouses across the land to streamline archaic bureau cracies and put more power in the hands of Governors.

title: Opposition Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Nixon Administration has ex pected that its welfare reforms would run into trouble in the House Ways and Means Com mittee.

title: Japanese Steel
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24 (UP) Demand for iron and steel in Japan during fiscal 1970 will be close to 100 million tons in terms of crude steel, ac cording to the Japan Iron and Steel Federation. The federation said this estimate, based on the assumption that the nation's economic growth for the year will be 11 per cent, includes exports of 23 million tons, an increase of 10 per cent over the 1969 level.

title: A Violent Trail in Yablonski Case
description: WASHINGTON  Violence is part of the culture among the steep hills and hollows of the Southern Appalachian coalfields.
