description: Assemblymen Jerome Kretch mer, a Manhattan Reform Dem ocrat, is expected to be named today as the new head of the city's Environmental Protection Administration.

title: Israeli Ruling Raises Questions on Jewish Continuity
description: An important factor in the unity of the Jewish people over the centuries has been the close link between Jewish religion and culture, even in times of widespread nonobservance of religious law.

title: Alison Corning And L. J. Clarke Are Betrothed
description: LAUREL HOLLOW, L. I., Jan. 25Mr. and Mrs. Howard Corning Jr. of Laurel Hollow and Deer Isle, Me., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Southworth Corning, to L. John Clarke, son of Mrs. Jane L. Clarke and Dr. M. John Clarke of Buffalo. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Customs Bureau Names Its Chief Investigator
description: A veteran revenooer has been promoted to chief in vestigator for the Bureau of Customs.

title: BARGE PACT HERE EXPIRES SATURDAY
description: The tempo of labor negotia tions in the port's commercial tug and barge industry will be quickening this week. The cur rent threeyear agreement be tween the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers As sociation and Local 333, United Marine Division, National Mari time Union, expires at midnight Saturday.

title: 1969 Gain of 17% Listed In MachineTool Orders
description: The machinetool industry, the builders of the machinery that becomes the country's pro duction lines, is in excellent shape, according to an analysis of figures released yesterday in Washington.

title: Cahill's Son Seized In Marijuana Case
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 John P. Cahill, the 19yearold son of New Jersey's Governor, was arrested here last night on a charge of possession of mari juana.

title: Dominicans Out of Doldrums
description: SANTO DOMINGO  Four years of relative political sta bility and the end of a pro longed drought produced an upturn of the Dominican economy last year.

title: Bad Roads and Too Few Trucks Contribute to Ibo Food Shortage
description: AWOOMAMMA, Nigeria, Jan. 23The man lying on his back on the hospital bed had a long surgical scar running down the front of his body. He was so emaciated that where his stom ach should have been, the scar looked as if it rested on his backbone.

title: CITY BANK OFFERING COMPUTER TAX HELP
description: Beginning today, the 181 metropolitan area branches of the First National City Bank will offer a computerized per sonal income tax preparation service to its personal banking customers.

title: Canadians Vexed That Ills Linger
description: OTTAWA  Canada starts the New Year disabused of, or some may say freed from, the obsessive national illusion of 1969. This was the con viction that Pierre Elliott Tru deau as a combination of Lin coln and Batman would in stantaneously preserve the Canadian union and propel it into the glamorous new age heralded by his Just Society slogan.

title: Harold P. Packer, Counsel For Social Security Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Harold P. Packer, assistant gen eral counsel of the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare with particular responsi bility for the Social Security program, died of a heart attack today in Baltimore. He was 64 years old.

title: Karen Ellen Graff Is Bride on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 Miss Karen Ellen Graff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Graff, formerly of Great Neck, L. I., was mar ried here today to Henry Borenstein. He is the son of Mrs. Jake Borenstein, presi dent of the Jaybee Manufac turing Company, a hardware concern here, and the late Mr. Borenstein. The bride's father is a vice president of the National General Corpora tion, a holding company.

title: Ecuador Excited But Broke
description: QUITO, Ecuador Presi dent Jose Maria Velasco Iba rra took his countrymen on an exciting economic roller coaster ride last year that left Government officials dazed and the treasury badly shaken.

title: HUMPHREY CITES AGE OF CARSWELL SPEECH
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)  Former Vice President Hu bert H. Humphrey said today that President Nixon's Supreme Court nominee, G. Harrold Carswell, should be judged on his record and not be punished for an old speech endorsing white supremacy.

title: French Car Breaks Mark For Daytona Test Course
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)A sleek blue Matra 650 prototype from France be came the third racer today to better the course record at Day tona Beach during shakedown tests for the 24hour endurance race next weekend.

title: Lobbyist for
description: DISCUSSING his role as an education lobbyist at lunch in Washington re cently, Charles W. Lee larded his conversation with off hand  but attributed  quo tations from others. There was Shakespeare, John Ad ams, and the man to whom he referred with a sort of respectful famil iarity as Mr. Jus tice Coke. This it developed, wa F. no other than Sit Edward Coke, 17thcentury English jurist who, in Mr. Lee's words, was one of the founders of the English legal system.

title: Church Demands Change in Paraguay
description: ASUNCION, ParaguayA violent clash between the Roman Catholic Church and the ruling militarydominated Government rocked the busi ness sector here as the year ended.

title: Advertising: Eastern Air Alters Course
description: Eastern Air Lines is going to cut back on its national advertising and build up its specially tailored local ad vertising in an effort to get at the short  term revenue potential.

title: If Wishing Would Make It So
description: ABA, Nigeria  The Secre tary General of the United Na tions, U Thant, flew into Ni geria the other day for what was described as a look at the relief situation after the war. He was tired, so he spent the afternoon resting in Lagos. That night he attended a din ner.

title: EGYPTIAN VESSEL CRIPPLED AT SEA BY ISRAELI PLANES
description: JERUSALEM, Jan.25Israeli jets disabled an Egyptian ves sel near the island of Shadwan today, apparently in an ef fort to maintain a measure of control over the former Egyp tian outpost, which was neu tralized last week.

title: ROUD NAMED HEAD OF FILM FESTIVAL
description: Richard Roud, program di rector of the New York Film Festival since its inception in 1963, has been named director of the festival.

title: Mexico's Exports Offset Crop Loss
description: MEXICO CITYMexico's economic momentum is re flected in the campaign slo gan, Onward and Upward, coined by Luis Echeverria Al varez, the virtually unchal lenged presidential candidate of the governing Institutional Revolutionary party.

title: SIMON HELPS NETS BEAT PACERS, 9683
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 25 (AP)The New York Nets held Bob Netolicky, In diana's AllStar forward, score less today and defeated the Pacers, 9683, in an American Basketball Association game before 4,263 spectators.

title: Foreman Fights Here Tonight In 15th Bout in Seven Months
description: You hear it whenever boxing people are discussing the rela tive scarcity of polished fighters in recent years.

title: Ruby Klappholz Is Married to Dr. Alvin Newman
description: Miss Ruby Klappholz, a doctoral candidate in com parative literature at the Uni versity of Wisconsin, was married yesterday at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Cen ter in Brooklyn to Dr. Alvin Newman, a research fellow in medicine at the Johns Hop kins University. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, Rabbi Kurt Klappholz of Congregation Tifereth Is rael. The bride's parents make their home in Brooklyn.

title: HOTEL FIRE KILLS TWO DEAF MUTES
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP)  Two young deaf mutes who could not hear the cries of warning died of smoke inhala tion today in a fire at the Conrad Hilton Hotel here. Nineteen other persons were in jured.

title: Chile Slows Inflation Pace
description: SANTIAGO, Chile Hav ing institutionalized inflation, Chileans take pleasure in economic indicators that would alarm most other peo ple.

title: Argentines Fear Stability Is Illusory
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argen tina closed the year with solid economic gains  an increase in the gross national product of 6.6 per cent and an increase in in flation of only 6.7 per cent  but many fear that 1970, instead of being the first year of consolidated stability, could mark a return to the old pattern of spiraling in flation.

title: Points of View
description: FOR most Canadians, for eign ownership of the do mestic economy is a cause for alarm. It is by no means a recent concern, nor is it a passing fad. For about two centuries, Canadians have been literally obsessed with the question of their survival as a national entity. In the past, they feared for their physical survival as a sep arate nation on the North American continent. Today, the dominant fear is that Canada is being swallowed up economically and cultural ly by the United States of America.

title: CITY HIGH SCHOOLS ADVISED TO HALT PLEDGE TO FLAG
description: The High School Principals Association will urge the heads of the city's 63 academic high schools today to suspend the daily Pledge of Allegiance and salute to the flag when the new term starts next Monday.

title: OneSixth of Mankind
description: Five hundred and thirty million Indiansonesixth of mankindcelebrate one of the most remarkable political achievements of all time today: Their com pletion of twenty years of federal union under the democratic Constitution India adopted on Jan. 26. 1950, two and onehalf years after gaining independ ence from Britain.

title: Hole in Road Bars Traffic On Half of Brooklyn Bridge
description: The Manhattanbound lanes of the Brooklyn Bridge were closed at 10:45 o'clock last night after 10 motorists told the police that a large hole in the road had badly damaged the tiresand in at least one case an axleof their cars.

title: Steel Price Rises Face Uncertainty
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25The newest test of steel prices comes with the steel market in an uncertain state.

title: Hanoi Convoy in Ashau Valley Reported Attacked by U. S. Jets
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  A United States military spokesman said today that helicopter gunships and Air Force fighterbombers attacked yesterday what was described as the first convoy of North Vietnamese supply trucks sighted in South Vietnam's Ashau valley since last summer.

title: Polish Aide Back From Bonn
description: WARSAW, Jan. 25 (Reuters) Poland's Foreign Trade Minis ter, Janusz Burakiewicz, re turned home today after three ldays of talks with West Ger man ministers in Bonn on economic relations and on a new longterm cooperation agreement under negotiation. He is the first Polish Minister to officially visit West Ger many.

title: SUBSIDIZED TRANSIT URGED BY DR. RONAN
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, the head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said last night that mass transit should receive public subsidies, but he did not say whether the subsidies should come from state, local or Federal govern ment.

title: A.D.A. Chides Eastland
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Americans for Democratic Action accused Senator East land today, of trying to rail road the nomination of Judge Carswell through the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Wheeler and the Changing of the Military Command.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 With Gen. Earle G. Wheel er's term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff expiring on July 3, President Nixon will have an opportunity to make some major changes in the United States military command.

title: She Looks Like Model but Drills Teeth
description: IF an advertising agency were searching for some one to typify the Now Wo man of the Seventies, they might do well to consider the following facts about Marcel la (Marcy) Halpert:

title: Farming Is a Gamble to Average German
description: MORENHOVEN, West Ger many  Sigurd Krause, a farmer in this small village near Bonn, tossed his head back and snapped: Farming in West Germany today? It's one hell of a gamble!

title: RICHEY CONQUERS GRAEBNER IN FINAL
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 25 (UPI)  A racquet waving ruckus broke out today as Cliff Richey, the No. 2 ranked player in the United States, conquered Clark Graeb ner, the No. 4 man, 63, 75, in the final round of the Austin Smith tennis tournament.

title: $1Million in Marijuana Is Seized in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, N. M., Jan. 25 (UPI)  New Mexico state police said a twinengine plane, believed to he carrying more than $1million in marijuana, crashlanded early today at the Las Vegas airport.

title: Wages Up in Canada
description: OTTAWAWeekly wages paid in manufacturing indus tries in Canada averaged $115.74 in November, 1969, up 6.5 per cent from the level a year earlier. The average varied from $91.24 in the At lantic provinces to $135.10 in British Columbia. In Ontario, Canada's industrial heart land, the figure was $121.86.

title: Typhoid Carrier on Ship Believed Found in Canada
description: I VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Jan. 25Canadian health authorities said today that they were certain that they had tracked down the typhoid car rier that had brought about the quarantining of the liner Oronsay here for the last 12 days. However, the ship and her 1,600 passengers and crew men might not be cleared for departure for another week to 10 days.

title: NIXON IS WEIGHING OPTIONS ON TOXINS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Nixon has just re ceived an interagency report proposing three choices on the question of whether the United States should retain highly poisonous toxins in its chemicalbiological arsenal.

title: Tito Leaves on African Tripi
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25 (AP)President Tito left to day for a tour of Africa to gain, support for the policy of non alignment. He is scheduled to arrive in Tanzania tomorrow. After that he will visit Zambia, Kenya, Ethiopia, the Sudan, Egypt and Libya.

title: Personal Finance: Inflation Insurance
description: If you've been reading the housesforsale ads in the classified pages of your daily newspaper lately, nobody has to tell you that the prices people are askingand get tingfor houses are sky high.

title: U.S. Aid Heads for Lagos
description: BOSTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)A plane carrying 94,000 pounds of medical supplies for victims of the Nigerian civil war left here today for Lagos.

title: Ottawa Tax Reform Spurs Hot Debate
description: TORONTO  The business and financial communities of Canada met the Government's package for tax reform with intense criticism, some of it considered by observers to be exaggerated or inaccurate.

title: At 70, Work Adds Zest to Life
description: Every Friday morning, Harry Sanborn who used to be a dispatcher with the Pennsylvania Railroad, bids goodby to his wife in Ridgefield Park, N. J., and a little before 8 o'clock gets on bus that will have him at the Worth Street branch of Chase Manhattan Bank by 9.

title: SUB RESCUE VEHICLE CHRISTENED BY NAVY
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP)The Navy unveiled yes terday the world's first deep diving submarine rescue ve hicle in christening cerem onies at the Lockheed Ocean Laboratory on Harbor Island.

title: BADILLO POSTPONES CANDIDACY DECISION
description: Former Bronx Borough Presi dent Herman Badillo said yes terday that he would not de cide whether to run for Con gress until the Federal courts had reviewed the Congressional redistricting plan passed last Thursday by the State Legisla ture.

title: FLYERS TOP BLUES AS PARENT STARS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 (UPI)  A brilliant perform ance by Bernie Parent, the goalie, and scores by Reggie Fleming and Bobby Clarke carried the Philadelphia Flyers to a 20 victory today over the St. Louis Blues.

title: 15Mile Oil Slick Befouls Gulf Resort
description: GRAND ISLE, La., Jan. 25 An oil slick about 15 miles long and 20 feet wide oozed ashore here today, covering the beaches of this resort island in the Gulf of Mexico and killing birds and fish.

title: Music: Richter Plays for a Birthday
description: IT was a very short pro gram that the Russian pi anist Sviatoslav Richter gave last Saturday evening at the Grace Rainey Rogers Audi torium. He played but two works. Schurnann's Bunte Blatter runs about 35 min utes and Mussorgsky's Pic tures at an Exhibition, a half hour. That was all, ex cept for encores. At $15 a ticketthe concert was part of the series being given for the centennial of the Metro politan Museum of Artthis was not lavish generosity. But no complaints were heard, certainly not after Mr. Rich ter's dazzling performance of the Mussorgsky.

title: Caracas Proves Its Point on Steel
description: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Vene zuela  Government  owned steel plants have long been the butt of stage comics and the despair of economists in Latin America.

title: KAREN MIDDLETON, BENT WIN IN SKIING
description: JEFFERSONVILLE, Vt., Jan. 25Karen Middleton of Brat tleboro, Vt., and Chuck Bent, a Dartmouth junior, won Madonna Cup skiing honors today.

title: Brandt Flies to Berlin Talks
description: BERLIN, Jan. 25Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany flew into West Berlin tonight for consultations with the West ern Allies and the city's gov ernment as Communist harass ment on the isolated city's access roads continued.

title: Water for Texas Studied.
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex, Jan. 25 (UPI)A Texas legisla tive committee tomorrow will discuss ways to moisten dusty West Texas with ocean water stripped of its salt by nuclear energy. The committee will meet near Texas A. & M. Uni versity's Nuplex, a nuclear reactor that desalinizes water.

title: Idanna Pucci Wed in Florence
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 25 Idanna Pucci di Barsento and Count Hugues de Mon talembert, who met last June at a psychedelic party in New York, were married here today amid a crush of top hats and mink coats in the Pucci family chapel.

title: NATIONALITY RULE FOUGHT IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 25  The National Religious party de clared tonight that it would re sign from the Government coalition unless a law was in troduced in Parliament revers ing the High Court decision of Friday on the question of who is a Jew.

title: Eisenhower's Widow Says She Counseled Him in '56 Decision
description: Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower overrode objections from other members of the family in urg ing her husband to decide for himself on a second term early in 1956, she says in an article in the February issue of Read ers Digest.

title: Fire Destroys School
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 25 (AP)A fire of unde termined origin burned today through the Pine Cobble School, a private institution. The police described the building as in complete ruin.

title: Junior Stars Spark Okla. State, Drake
description: Junior college recruiting is becoming more prominent in basketball with every passing season.

title: Mountain of Surplus Butter Shadows Common Market
description: BONN, Jan. 25A stockpile of surplus butter so large that the Germans call it Butterberg looms as a symbol of the problems facing agriculture in Western Europe. The imagi nary mountain of butter weighs 400,000 tonsabout as much as the weight of all the people living in New York City or in Austria.

title: CHRYSLER WIDENS LAYOFF CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25The spec ter of more layoffs, this time among salaried staff as well as factory workers, hangs over Detroit.

title: Ads for London Abortions Stir Legal Questions,
description: BOSTON, Jan. 25The Mas sachusetts Supreme Court will be asked to rule on the legality of advertising that offers, for $1,250, to make all arrange ments for an abortion in Eng land.

title: ROBERTSON STARS AS ROYALS SCORE
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (AP) Tom Van Arsdale led a first quarter spurt as Cincinnati rolled up a 21point lead and Oscar Robertson netted 17 fourthquarter points to spark the Royals to a 129122 Na tional Basketball Association victory today over the Balti more Bullets.

title: PISTON RALLY FAILS, BULLS WIN BY 120111
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) The Chicago Bulls, ahead by 18 points late in the third quarter, had to put on a strong burst in the final three minutes to de feat the Detroit Pistons, 120 111, today in the first Sunday afternoon National Basketball Association contest played in Chicago.

title: CHARLES L. BAILEY
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 25 Charles Langdon Bailey, for merly of New Canaan and the former president of Aberdeen Management, Inc., sponsor of the Aberdeen Mutual Fund, died Thursday in Monaco. He had been a resident of Boulogne surSeine, France, for the last 10 years.

title: Regulationof Insurance Industry By U.S. is Pressed in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  There are growing signs that the Federal Government may be ready to move into regulation of insur ance companies, which in time could radically change the in surance business.

title: Wolfson Is Concerned On Eve of Leaving Jail
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)Louis E. Wolfson, whose family built a scrap iron business into a multi million dollar empire, is scheduled to leave jail tomor row and says Americans are entitled to know of inequities in our disgraceful penal sys tem.

title: SUBSTITUTE LIFTS SAGGING OFFENSE
description: BOSTON, Jan. 25  Cazzie Russell, one of the National Basketball Association's more potent offensive performers, put on a spectacular display of shooting today to pull his weary New York Knicker bocker teammates to a 10296 victors, over the Celtics before 10,136 fans at Boston Garden.

title: Susan M. Allen Is Bride Here
description: The marriage of Miss Susan Marie Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard James Allen of New York, to Arthur Stern 3d took place at the Car lyle yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stern Jr. of Larch mont, N. Y. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman of Temple EmanuEl peformed the ceremony.

title: How Genuine the Revolution in Peru?
description: LIMA, Peru  It is time to bring into truer focus the widely accepted image of the generals who rule Peru as some thing strikingly new under the LatinAmerican sun.

title: Gains Pressed in Caribbean
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad Limited in land and natural resources, largely deprived of their previous safety valves of emigration and forced to compete with stronger econ omies for costly investment funds, the islanders of the former British West Indies are measuring gains in terms of keeping their heads above water.

title: The Canadian Plains: Too Rich in Wheat
description: YELLOW GRASS, SaskatchewanIf a guy could just get diversified, that's the big problem now, said Bill Davis, speaking for himself and tens of thousands of other Canadans who grow grains on the northern plains.

title: Small Plane Safety Called Neglected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Two young engineering grad uates from Princeton University have accused the aircraft manu facturing industry and the Fed eral Aviation Administration of systematically neglecting struc tural safety in small private planes.

title: Books of The Times
description: TO extend the metaphor: Mr. Bellow's planet is layered over with a thick vegetation of elegant prose, in places lush, elsewhere tended and orderly, every where a thing to behold by itself. Beneath it is the crust of a plota seemingly absurd tale involving a Negro pickpocket who ex poses himself in an Upper West Side lobby, a pilfered scientific manuscript, a New Rochelle attic flooded in a search for hidden money, a fatal brain hem orrhage, the back seat bar of a silver RollsRoyce, fell latio in Mexico, philosophy in Westchester County. Beneath the crust is an as sortment of char acters, Bellowian urban types, ng stlich and articu late: a neurotic operator descend ed from Tommy Wilhelm of Seize the Day, a rutting female left over, perhaps, from Maurice Herzog's fantasies, a dying gynecologist, mad, toeless Israeli artist. And at the core, there to hold this fictional world together with his gravity, is Artur Sammler himself, 70plus, tall, smallheaded, oneeyed Jew ish journalist from Cracow by way of Bloomsbury and the holocausta Herzog gone exquisitely sane, and playing Prospero to his former role as mad King Lear.

title: Crealy Upsets Taylor and Gains Aussie Tennis Final With Ashe
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Jan. 26 (UPI)Dick Crealy of Australia upset Roger Taylor of England in a semifinal of the Australian open tennis championships today.

title: BAR PANEL IS SAID TO BACK CARSWELL
description: A committee of the American Bar Association made sub stantial progress yesterday toward deciding whether to approve the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court. There were strong indications that the committee would approve Presi dent Nixon's choice.

title: DR. O. C. HANSENPRUSS
description: DURHAM, N. C. Jan. 25 (AP) Dr. Oscar C. HansenPruss, an organizer of the Duke Uni versity School of Medicine, died yesterday. He was 69 years old.

title: Newsmen's Plane Crashes in Mexico; 19 of 20 Are Killed
description: POZA RICA, Mexico, Jan. 25  A twinengine plane filled with Mexican reporters covering the country's presi dential election campaign crashed and burned on a mountainside in heavy fog to day, killing 19 of the 20 per sons aboard.

title: Student Interrupts Hunter Gradudion, I First Under ExNun
description: The new president of Hun ter College, Mrs. Jacqueline Grennan Wexler, presided yes terday at commencement exer cises at which 450 baccalaure ate and 350 master of art de grees were awarded.

title: Lagos Attacks Reports Of Looting by Troops
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 25 (Reuters)The Nigerian Gov ernment said today that reports of looting, raping and indiscipline among troops were totally unfounded.

title: Car Makers Fight To Share Market
description: RIO DE JANEIROAmeri ca's Big Three car makers and West Germany's Volkswagen are slugging it out through subsidiaries for their places in Brazil's booming market.

title: KREMLIN'S MINDS GIVEN LOW RATING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Rob ert Conquest, a leading British authority on Soviet affairs, has warned a Senate subcommittee that the present Soviet leaders are intellectually thirdrate. He cautioned Western policy makers against assuming that the Kremlin would always react in a rational or coherent fash ion.

title: Darn Threat Ends in Wales
description: MAERDY, Wales, Jan. 25 (Reuters)A twoweek state of emergency caused by a dam aged dam on the Rhondda Riv er in Glamorgan, northwest of Cardiff, ended tonight. After in specting the control center, a government official said the people of the area could return safely to their homes.

title: FERNER TRIUMPHS IN SKI JUMPING
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 25  Christian Ferner, 20 yearold Harvard University economics student from Oslo, Norway, won the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial ski jump ing tournament today.

title: '20's ARE RECALLED BY JACKSON'S PIANO
description: One of thte fascinations of the Jazz Jamborees held each Sunday evening at Uncle John's Straw Hat, 316 West 49th Street, is the opportunity they afford to hear jazz musicians overlooked by most midtown jazz entrepreneurs.

title: NEW YORK IS VICTOR IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25The New York Metropolitan team won the Class A competition in the Howe Cup women's squash racquets matches by defeating Philadelphia today at the New Haven Lawn Club. Both de feated Boston by 31 scores.

title: Only 3,479 Have Signed Up Deadline Is Saturday
description: As the voter registration for local school board elections moved into its second and final week today, officials expressed keen disappointment at the low turnout so far. They expresied hope that the trend would im prove radically as the Saturday deadline approached.

title: City Prisoner Judged Stable Succeeded in Suicide on 2d Attempt
description: A 20yearold heroin addict, who hanged himself at the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island Saturday had tried to hang himself the pre vious day but was returned to a cell because a prison psy chologist, after an examination, did not consider the attempt a serious one.

title: Nixon, on Way to Ball, Is Detoured by a Fire
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)President Nixon, on the way by car to a ball, got a little extra excitement to night when his motorcade was diverted because of fire trucks answering an alarm in an apartment house next to his destination.

title: Pipkin and Hart Advance To MatchPlay Golf Final
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)  Bob Pipkin of Raleigh, N. C., and Dick Hart of Hinsdale, Ill., won two matches each today to gain a shot at each other in tomorrow's final of the Professional Golfers' As sociation matchplay champion ship.

title: Three Young Conductors Win Honors in Mitropoulos Contest
description: Phillippe Bender, 27 years old, of France, Mario Benzecry, 33, of Argentina and David Gil bert, 33, of the United States yesterday were named first prize winners in the 1970 Dimitri Mitropoulos Interna tional Music Competition.

title: Contract Signed for Bosporus Span
description: Dispatch of The Times, London.

title: Museum Here Honors Paleontologist
description: Dr. Edwin H. Colbert, cur ator of vertebrate paleontol ogy at the American Museum of Natural History, last night received the museum's gold medal for his research in the Antarctic. He was the sixth person to receive the award.

title: Wilson, Here, Asks U.S. British Drive on ocial Ills
description: Prime Minister Wilson, on the eve of his first visit to Wash ington in nearly two years, pro posed in a speech here last night a new special relation ship for the nineteenseventies between Britain and the United States.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Miss Mullane To Be a Bride
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 Miss Dianne Elizabeth Mul lane, who is associated with the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, and James Allan Magee, who is associated with the New York law firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Irvine, plan to be married March 21 in New York at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. Both are graduates of the University of Michigan Law School.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL DECLINES IN WEEK
description: Steel production declined by 1.1 per cent last week, com pared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester day.

title: Harlem Area Sealed Off As Police Hunt Snipers
description: Squads of policemen pressed a housetohouse search yester day for the snipers who lured two patrolmen Into an ambush in Harlem Sunday night and seriously wounded them.

title: Met Switches to Aida
description: The Metropolitan Opera will present Verdi's Aida tonight in place of the scheduled dou ble bill of Mascagni's Caval leria Rusticana and Leonca vallo's Pagliacci. The illness of Grace Bumbry and Teresa Stratas, leading singers in the double bill, necessitated the change. The Aida cast will include Gabrielle Tucci in the title role, Irene Dalis as Am neris, Franco Corelli as Rad ames, William Dooley as Amon asro, Ezio Flagello as Ramfis and Raymond Michalski as the King. Francesco MolinariPra delli will conduct.

title: Calley Fund Angers Senator
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)  Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of. Ohio, re signed from the American Le gion today because, he said, one post has started raising funds to defend Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with mur dering civilians at My Lai, South Vietnam. The post is in Cleveland, and Senator Young was a charter member of it.

title: 30 Arrested in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 26 (UPI)The police arrested 30 persons today in connection with the kidnaping last week of a 12yearold boy. The child was freed after his father paid a $160,000 ransom. The Minis ter of the Interior, Dr. Lorenzo Fernandez, said that the money, twothirds of which had already been recovered, was destined for Castroite guerrillas in Venezuela.

title: The Melons Give a Dinner at National Gallery
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Some guests couldn't help but have an uneasy feeling that any minute a bluecoated guard was going to tap them on the shoulder and say sternly: No food allowed in the exhibition rooms of the National Gallery.

title: Union Oil Net Is Off
Brandt Confers With Allied Officials in West Berlin as Soviet Defense Chief Sees Ulbricht
description: BERLIN, Jan. 26Chancellor Willy Brandt conferred today with the three Western allied commanders of Berlin as East Germany continued for the sixth day its onagainoffagain tactics of harassment on the city's access routes. Mr. Brandt also met with Mayor Klaus Schtz of West Berlin.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Jan. 22, 1970

title: Deal Exceeds 100 Planes
description: PARIS, Jan. 26The scope of the FrenchLibyan arms deal was widened a bit more today.

title: Yablonski Sons Expected to Appear Before U.S. Grand Jury
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 26The two sons of Joseph A. Yablon ski, murdered leader of an in surgent faction in the United Mine Workers of America, were reported today to be among more than 20 witnesses summoned to appear before a United States grand jury that convenes here tomorrow. The grand jury is to open a new phase of the broadening in vestigation into the contract slaying of the union official and his wife and daughter.

title: Excerpts From Keeney Remarks on the Humanities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Following are excerpts from a statement made today by Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney, chair man of the National Endow ment for the Humanities, at a joint SenateHouse sub committee hearing on the Arts and Humanities Act of 1965:

title: Ethics Panel Urges the Disclosure by House Members of Large Debts and Sizable Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  The House ethics committee, proposed today that Houses members and employes public ly disclose any large indebted ness and sources of sizable fees for speeches.

title: Transcript of the Nixon Statement
description: Following is the transcript of a television statement in Washington yesterday by President Nixon on his veto of the $19.7billion education and labor appropriation as recorded by The New York Times:

title: MEETING PLANNED ON POULTRY CHECK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  Mrs. Virginia H. Knauer, President Nixon's special as sistant for consumer affairs, said today that she would meet with officials of the Depart ment of Agriculture to discuss a recommended change in poul try inspection standards.

title: Article 3  No Title
4 Wives of Missing Pilots Tour Facilities in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  The wives of four United States airmen shot down over North Vietnam vis ited a military hospital here where wounded North Vietna mese prisoners are treated.

title: League Meets Today to Act on Pilots
description: Owners of some American League clubs held private strategy talks in San Francisco yesterday, in preparation for today's league meeting at which the fate of the Seattle Pilots should be decided. There are widely divergent views within the league on what ought to be done, and the exchange of ideas before the actual meeting takes place may have a decisive influence on the decision.

title: James Cunningham's Flexibility Demonstrated in Dance Program
description: The dancer James Cunning ham is like a piece of Silly Putty that can shatter, stretch, bounce or do a variety of other, and at times, contradictory things with movement. He is a superb performer but also in discriminately intoxicated with theater and theatrical effects, a condition that tends to diffuse his choreographic focus. Last night at the Cubiculo he pre sented three of his pieces un der the collective title Lions and Roaring Tigers.

title: Kentucky Victor at Rupp's 1,000th Game
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 26 (AP)  Adolph Rupp coached his 1,000th basketball game tonight, and his team gave him an 8671 victory over Alabama, but it was a tarnished gift.

title: $1.8BILLION BILL FOR OVERSEAS AID SET BY CONFEREES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  House and Senate conferees agreed today on a $1.8billion foreignaid appropriation for the current fiscal year and set the stage for a vote on the measure before the end of the week.

title: MRS. W. I. EMERSON JR.
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 26 Mrs. Constance Beard Emerson, wife of Willard Ingham Emer son Jr., a consultant to Stewart Capital Corporation, a venture capital investments concern in New York, died yesterday after a heart attack at her home, 5210 Congress Street. Her age was 39.

title: Students to Decorate IRT Station In Honor of Hunter's 100th Year
description: A group of Hunter College students met with the Transit. Authority yesterday and per suaded it to give them permis sion to decorate the 68th StreetLexington Avenue IRT station in honor of the college's 100th birthday, which is com ing in two weeks.

title: Press Panel Elects Head
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  Charles McDowell Jr. of The Richmond TimesDispatch was elected today as chairman of the Standing Committee of Correspondents, which super vises the administration of the House and Senate press galler ies. Mr. McDowell succeeds William McGaffin of The Chi cago Daily News, whose term had expired.

title: League of Theaters Proposes a Middle Contract
description: A socalled middle con tract designed to spur Broad way theater production, stem rising operating costs and cut ticket prices has been suggested by the League of New York Thea ters to theatrical craft and performer unions as well as guilds.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Newest Member

title: HIGH COURT CURBS USE OF THE DRAFT TO PUNISH CRITICS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  The Supreme Court ruled today that students who lose their draft deferments after turning in their draft cards may chal lenge their reclassification in court before induction.

title: Fillmore Hyde, Author, Is Dead; Former Director of N.Y.U. Press
description: Fillmore Hyde, author and editor, who was a former na tional amateur squash tennis champion, died Sunday at Fun chal, Madeira, where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: Georgia Court Rules Maddox Cannot Repeat as Governor
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (AP) The Georgia Supreme Court unanimously upheld today a provision of thr. state Constitu tion that prohibits a Governor from succeeding himself in office.

title: 2 LATIN COUNTRIES BEGIN PEACE TALKS
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 26  El Salvador and Honduras began peace negotiations here today in an effort to restore normal relations broken since the two countries fought a five day war last July.

title: OLD FOES DISCUSS HEALTH INSURING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The American Medical As sociation and some of its old adversaries met secretly here three weeks ago to explore pro posals for a national health in surance system, it was learned today.

title: G.E. Strikers in Schenectady Defy a Winter of Discontent
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y.  For 13 weeks, 13,000 workers at the huge General Electric plant here have been on strike. For 20 days this month the temperature here has been below freezing. But at Matt's bar and at Angelo's, where the bluecollar work ers drink boilermakers, the mood is more relaxed than desnairine.

title: DAVID RITTENBERG OF COLUMBIA DIES
description: Dr. David Rittenberg, profes sor of biochemistry at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and chairman of the department from 1958 to 1969, died at his home Saturday. He was 63 years old and lived at 560 Riverside Drive.

title: Designer Visits Show Seeking ShipShape Items
description: What does a worldfamed sailboat designer want most to see at the National Boat Show? It's not sailboats.

title: 3 Killed, Many Hurt In Train Derailment lat Alexandria, Va.
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 26 (AP)At least three persons were killed tonight and scores injured when five cars of a Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad passenger train derailed south of here.

title: Bahamas Flights Dropped
description: Suspension, of its service from Washington's Dulles In ternational Airport to Nassau and Freeport in the Bahamas, effective Sunday, was an nounced yesterday by Pan American World Airways. The flights being canceled were operated Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. The airline said it had lost $775,000 on them last year.

title: Ribicoff Assails France On Her Role in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (Reut ers)Senator Abraham Ribi coff, Democrat of Connecticut, accused the French Govern ment today of cynical double dealing, as Senators put in creased pressure on the Nixon Administration to meet Israeli requests for new fighter air craft.

title: Resignation of Tierney As I.C.C. Member Accepted
description: Paul Tierney's resignation as a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission was ac cepted yesterday with par ticular reluctance by Presi dent Nixon. His resignation become effective Feb. 28.

title: Women Testify in Abortion Law Test
description: A 34yearold writer told a Federal court hearing yester day that she had three abor tions between 1960 and 1967 because having an illegitimate child would have been the end of my life.

title: Louisiana Agency Calls Oil Spillage Exaggerated
description: GRAND ISLE, La., Jan. 26 (AP)The Louisiana Wild Life and Fisheries Commission, along with Coast Guard Capt. E. A. Poulter, sad tonight that the size and extent of the oil spillage off this island cty on the Gulf Coast had been proj ected out of proportion.

title: VETO EFFECT HERE DECRIED BY BROWN
description: President Nixon's veto of the health and education appropri ations bill could force a reduc tion in the city's Head Start and other programs for disad vantaged children, Dr. Nathan Brown, Acting Superintendent of Schools, said last night.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Davis Named Football Aide
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Tan. 26 (UPI)Michael Davis, former University of Utah tailback, has been signed as an assistant football coach at the University California, Riverside, Franklin E. Lindeburg, athletic director announced today. Davis played at Riverside City College before entering Utah in 1964.

title: MICHAEL F. GLYNN, EXAIDE TO DEWEY
description: Michael F. Glynn, a lawyer who had served with the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation and with the New York District Attorney's office, died Sunday night in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 3543 84th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Army Halts Rioting By Student Groups In West Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 26 The army was called out to day in Hyderabad, 120 miles north of here, after clashes be tween student groups accom panied by burning and looting in several sections of the city.

title: Average Discount Rates Climb At Weekly Treasury Bill Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported today.

title: HARNESS TRACKS PLAN TITLE SERIES
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 26Plans for a world championship for harness rac ing drivers were announced today by the Harness Tracks, of America.

title: Opposition Party in Seoul Chooses Its New Leader
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26 The opposition New Demo cratic party elected Yoo Chin San as its president today. He succeeds Dr. Yu Chin O, who resigned recently for health reasons.

title: UTILITY REPORTS RECORD INCOME
description: The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation and its subsidiaries achieved new highs in revenues and net income for 1969, according to a prelimin ary annual report made public yesterday. This was the 17th consecutive year the company has posted increased earnings.

title: Job Troubles Seen for Science Ph.D.'s
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 26  A Government science of ficial says that widespread fears of a shortage of jobs for scientists and engineers over the next decade may not be founded, but that many may have to do work they really do not want to do.

title: Tests Hint Gain on Dutch Elm Disease
description: Scientists in Ohio have iden tified two chemicals that make the elm tree a tasty treat for the European elm bark beetle. the main spreader of Dutch elm disease.

title: U.N. DENIES THANT ASSESSED LAGOS AID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26A United Nations spokes man today said that Secretary General Thant had made no assessment of the relief situa tion whatsoever during his visit to Nigeria.

title: AUSTIN F. J. NEWMAN
description: ROSELLE PARK. N. J., Jan 26 Austin F. J. Newman, for merly a supervisor for the New Jersey State Highway Depart ment and a member of the Roselle Park Borough Council for 10 years, died yesterday in Point Pleasant Hospital after a brief illness. He was 76 years years old and lived in Manas quan. He re?? in 1939.

title: School Board Ponders Superintendent
description: The members of the Board of Education met yesterday to consider the appointment of an Acting Superintendent of Schools but did not reach a de cision.

title: NORMAN SINGER GETS CITY U. DEAN'S POST
description: Norman Singer, general ad ministrator of the City Center of Music and Drama, was named last night by the Board of Higher Education to the new ly created post of dean of ad ministration of the City Uni versity's Graduate Division. The appointment becomes effective Sept. 1.

title: Giants Trade Jones to Browns and Obtain Kanicki, Ron Johnson and Meylan
description: The Giants called Homer Jones's signal for a long gainer yesterday  all the way to Cleveland.

title: Nixon News Conference Set for 6:30 P.M. Friday
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)President Nixon will hold his first formal news conference of the year in the East Room of the White House at 6:30 P. M. Friday, the White House announced today.

title: LeVander to Spurn 2d Term
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 26 (AP) Gov. Harold E. LeVander of Minnesota announced today that he would not seek a sec ond term. Governor LeVander, a 59yearold Republican, said that he would return to private life, which I have come to deeply appreciate.

title: 100 Riders Refuse to Pay In Penn Central TieUp
description: About 100 passengerg on a New YorktoStamford train that was stuck for more than an hour in the tunnel under Park Avenue last night refused for a time to surrender their tickets to the conductor.

title: Trackmen, Too, Have Winter Woes
description: Sloppy weather conditions, which have bogged motor and pedestrian traffic all winter, are clogging training schedules for track and field athletes along the east coast.

title: Article 2  No Title
Liberal Officials Score Law On Redistricting in State
description: The Liberal party leadership yesterday scored the new state redistricting law on Congres sional districts as of partisan gerrymandering characte'r de signed to give special advan tages to the Republican party.

title: Theater: Happy Musical
description: WITH a wellgroomed im pudence and a cheerful antic wit, a new musical, The Last Sweet Days of Isaac, arrived at the East Side Playhouse last night for what should be a long stay. It is one of the most prepos terous shows in New York and yet also one of the hap piest.

title: 76ers Rout Bucks,122 103, as Jones, Cunningham, Washington Net 78 Points
description: MILWAUKEE. Jan. 26 (UPI) Wally Jones, Bill Cunningham and Jim Washington combined for 78 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 122103, in a National Basketball Association same.

title: Foreman Knocks Out O'Halloran in 5th Round for 15th Consecutive Victory
description: The boxer, the slugger and the bleeder emerged as the win ners on last nights card at Madison Square Garden.

title: Germany's Trade Surplus Shows Decline for Year
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Jan. 26 (AP)  Preliminary figures show the West German trade surplus in 1969 totaled 15.6 million marks, down from 18.37 million marks in 1968. the Federal Statistics Office re ported today.

title: Books of The Times
description: LOOKING back he could see the Temple burning below, burning six million of its priests, he could see them climbing an immense blazing ladder: Jacob was having a bad dream. A dream from which Elie Wiesel has been trying to awake . . . into what? Into our historical ennui; into a reality paved with political platitudes? He who says I says every thing. Just as every man contains all men.

title: FIRST LESOTHO VOTE WILL BE HELD TODAY
description: MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 26 Tribesmen in the remote misty mountains here received in structions dropped from planes today on how to vote in the general election tomorrow. The leaflets emphasized the secrecy of the ballot. The election will be the first since Lesotho's in dependence from Britain in 1966.

title: Clay to Give Own Belt To Title Bout Winner
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 Cassius Clay said today he would give his world heavy weight championship belt to the winner of the Joe Fra zierJimmy Ellis title fight at Madison Square Garden Feb. 16.

title: Congress Warned of Peril In Neglect of Humanities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Congress was warned today that a growing imbalance of science teaching and research in relation to the humanities was dividing the nation; de stroying its values and making it impossible to solve society's most serious problems.

title: LOWER STANDARDS SATISFY MILITARY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Department of Defense ex pressed satisfaction today with the performance of 246,000 new standards men who have entered the armed forces since October, 1966.

title: Pan Am to Offer Seats Just for Nonsmokers
description: Pan American World Air ways said yesterday that it would provide a smokefree refuge for nonsmokers in its new 362passenger Boeing 747 jetliners.

title: Nelly Kokinos Picks Schumann And Bach for Piano Program
description: Talent is a good beginning, and Nelly Kokinos, a Rumanian born pianist who gave a Car negie Hall recital last night, has therefore begun. But it is only that, as much of her playing demonstrated. Miss Kokinos drew close to the keyboard, put her head down and ripped through most of the music on her program with little feeling for its content. Very often there was not enough accuracy to ex plain the breathless tempos she chose to attempt.

title: Court Allows Goldwater Judgment to Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  The Supreme Court denied to day a request by Ralph Ginz burg, the publisher, for a re view of a $75,000 libel judg ment won by Senator Barry Goldwater.

title: Prices Fall Sharply in Amex Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange tumbled sharply yes terday. Losses outnumbered advances by almost a fourto one margin in comparatively Quiet trading.

description: Fletcher L. Byrom, president and chief executive officer of the Koppers Company, was elected chairman of the Pitts burghbased concern yesterday. Douglas Grymes Jr., executive vice president and chief ad ministrative officer, will suc ceed Mr. Byrom as president.

title: Romney Says He'd Rather Stay In Cabinet Than Run for Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)  George Romney said today that he had no plans to run for Senator this year. But he declined to rule out the possibility that he or his wife might become a candidate if Michigan Republicans cannot agree on someone else.

title: Kekkonen Here En Route To a Vacation in Bahamas
description: President Urho Kekonnen of Finland stopped over here yesterday on his way to the Bahamas for a brief vacation.

title: In a New Environment
description: IN any gathering of state legislators, Jerome Kretch mer looked somehow out of place, both because of his 6foot4inch height and be cause of his dress, which never conformed to the ap parent tradition that legisla tors must dress as conserva tively as possible, whatever their politics.

title: Bridge:
description: PLAYERS from New York City captured almost all the titles in the American Bridge Association tourna ment played Saturday and Sunday at the McAlpin Hotel under the auspices of the Henry C. Parker Jr. Club and the BronxWestchester Asso ciates.

title: West German Thalidomide Maker Offers $27Million Settlement
description: BONN, Jan. 26Chemie Gril nenthal, the West German phar maceutical company that devel oped and sold thalidomide, offered today to pay $27.3mil lion (100 million marks) in an outofcourt settlement to West German children born with birth defects caused, it is al leged, by their mothers' use of the tranquilizer during preg nancy.

title: Dubcek Is Said to Have Quit Party Post
description: VIENNA, Jan. 26Reliable: sources in Prague said today that Alexander Dubcek had re signed from the Central Com mittee of the Czechoslovak Communist party before he left for his new assignment as Am bassador to Turkey yesterday.

title: Indonesian Students Defiant
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  Indonesian student leaders said today that they would continue demonstrations in Jakarta despite a ban by the Government. In a statement, the students said: The struggle will continue until the Govern ment reduces the prices of kerosene and gasoline to the level before Jan. 6.

title: The TeenAge Drug Problem
description: At a time when the drug problem among the very young is reaching critical proportions, New York City officials haveincrediblydemanded the closing of the one facility devoted solely to the rehabilitation of teenage drugusers.

title: In The Nation: The Education Boondoggle
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26I am afraid, said a Democratic headcounter recently, that we have enough votes to over ride.

title: WARFIELD IS DEALT FOR DRAFT CHOICE
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 (AP) Paul Warfield, the Cleveland Browns' star receiver, was traded today to the Miami Dol phins for their top choice in tomorrow's pro football draft.

title: Divinity Students Oppose Theological School Merger
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26 Twentyfive students at the Berkeley Divinity School here occupied the seminary chapel today to protest a decision of the board of trustees to merge with a larger theological school

title: Zambia Leader Accuses West of Arming South Africa
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 26 (AP)President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia tonight ac cused West Germany, France, Britain and the United States of arming South Africa to its teeth to enable it to attack black liberation movements.

title: Security for Whom?
description: Almost exactly 90 per cent of the contracts let by the Department of Defense are nonbid, negotiated contracts which guarantee the contractor a profit over and above costs. The various contractors follow various methods of calculating their costs and, since there is no uniform accounting procedure, there is no effective governmental audit of these contracts.

title: Fanny May Results Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The new rules for the mortgage auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association appar ently had the effect of stabilizing prices, the Association dis closed tonight.

title: Ashe Beats Crealy in 3 Sets For Aussie Open Tennis Title
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 27 (UPI)Arthur Ashe of Richmond, Va., became the first Negro to win the Austra lian open tennis championship today by defeating Dick Crealy of Australia, 64, 97, 62, at White City.

title: PAPAL TALK CHEERS BRAZILIAN PRELATE
description: ROME, Jan. 26A Brazilian Archbishop, noted for his sup port of social reform and his opposition to his country's military rulers, said today that an audience with Pope Paul VI had given him renewed courage.

title: Thieu, Elected by 37 % in '67, Asks Runoffs in Presidential Races
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26President Nguyen Van Thieu, who was elected in 1967 with only 37 per cent of the vote, proposed tonight that runoff elections be held if no presidential candidate won a majority on the first ballot in future elections.

title: Florence Will Close a 10Acre Area to Traffic Again
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 26 Color the center of Florence blue and the faces of its down town merchants an angry red.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Jan. 20:

title: Ignoring of Its Effects Is Decried by Economist
description: A bank economist who was one of the first to use the term recession in connection with the present business down turn said yesterday that he was worried lest those who made errors in overestimating the effects of the passage of the income tax surcharge a year and a half ago make the same kind of mistake again.

title: Screen: 'Other Voices':Documentary Studies Mental Treatment
description: "OTHER VOICES" is a cinma-vrit documentary, skillfully shot in black and white, dealing with the treatment of a few patients at the Delaware Valley Mental Health Foundation at Doylestown, Pa. The foundation, which occupies houses and house trailers in the Bucks County countryside, places some of its patients in residence with families who provide continual supervision as a background for the specialized, and, I believe, controversial therapy practiced by the foundation's director, Dr. Albert Honig. The filmmaker, David Sawyer, and his photographer and co-director. Robert Elfstrom, spent a year and a half visiting the foundation, photographing five patients during a major part of their residence.Dr. Honig calls his approach "direct confrontation." The doctor forces himself upon his patient's attention  arguing, yelling, bullying, embracing, wrestling. While the treatment pays full attention to psychological causes (everybody seems to have some kind of mother problem), direct assault is made upon the behavioral symptoms of the illness. Dr. Honig doesn't mind telling his patients what messes they are, and they respond in kind.Therapeutic sessions are highly dramatic, emotional, and sometimes violent. Dr. Honig is a large man who looks a little like Walter Matthau and sounds like a cross between Selma Diamond and Jackie Gleasonvangry. I assume he has a sense of humor. At least, when he sitsliterallyon the stomach of a frail looking young woman and compassionately asks, "What can I do to help you, you poor thing?" the answer, if he's not kidding, is painfully self-evident.One effect of Dr. Honig's approach is that the patient finds himself forced into a kind of dialogue, a posture as if he were being interviewed by a very bright, insistent and none-too-friendly journalist. As a result, and in spite of all the mauling, there seems to exist between patient and therapist (Dr. Honig and his assistants) a sense of real equality. "We're not attacking the patient; we're attacking the irrationality," Dr. Honig explainsand the method of attack and the rhetoric call to mind certain aspects of old-time religion.Most of the patients seem very intelligent (all of them must be backed by plenty of money), but one is retarded, and he also is given no quarter. Over the year and a half the patients change physically. One young man apparently achieves a superb recovery; anotherequally promisingonly succeeds with the suicide he had desired since the beginning.The intrusion of the camera and the filmmakers seem to disturb nobody (though it is never ignored). Few of the therapeutic sessions are private anyway. Obviously, Sawyer and Elfstrom were out to make a movie, and not just to record treatment. I think they have succeeded, but the movie is tactfully, perhaps necessarily, less interesting than its material. For the purposes of art, truth is always less real than fiction.

title: DeBusschere's Back Is Fine, He Faces Celtics Here Tonight
description: Dave DeBusschere raced up and down the gymnasium floor at Garden City, L. I., High School yesterday doing wind sprints. Then he shot baskets with a teammate, Bill Hosket.

title: Florida Brokerage Firm Is Suspended by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today a Florida brokerage firm and its president for violations of the registration and antifraud pro visions of the Federal Securities laws.

title: JUDGE IN SHAW TRIAL IS FOUND NOT GUILTY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP) The judge who presided at the Clay Shaw conspiracy trial was acquitted tonight on charges of providing women and sex movies for a stag party.

title: Samuels Makes His Campaign for Governor Official
description: Howard J. Samuels, who be gan putting together a cam paign organization 10 months ago, made it official yesterday by announcing that he would seek the Democratic nomina tion for Governor.

title: SpanishVatican Talks Open
description: ROME, Jan. 26Talks began here today between Pope Paul VI and Gregorio Lopez Bravo, Spanish Foreign Minister. At issue, it is believed, is Spain's traditional right to nominate three candidates for a vacant see.

title: A Society Star in a Movie's Bit Part
description: MOVIE audiences have a Ford in their future. If she doesn't end up as another face on the cutting room floor, Henry Ford 2d's elder daughter, Charlotte Ford Ni archos, will appear briefly as an admissions clerk at Mount Sinai Hospital in the Para mount Pictures film, Love Story.

title: COLLEGES TO GAIN ADDITIONAL SPACE
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion, in preparation for the open admissions program that goes into effect next Septem ber, approved last night the rental of 259,000 square feet of space for City, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges.

title: Palmer Golfer of Decade
description: Arnold Palmer was the over whelming choice yesterday as golfer of the decade in the Associated Press poll. The long hitting son of a former Latrobe, Pa., greenskeeper received 531 of the 633 votes cast by sports writers and broadcasters.

title: Jockey Loses by a Hair to Trainer and 16 Lengths to His Rivals
description: MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP)J. L. Smaliman's Laughing Bill won the feature race, a $10,000 sevenfurlong event, at Hialeah today, holding off Pilot Knob to score by a neck. Mile's Fancy was third, a length and a half behind the top pair and half a length in front of Tanrackin.

title: A Break Is Hinted in G.E. Talks
description: Talks aimed at settling the 13weekold General Electric strike were reported to be approaching a crucial stage yesterday.

title: Parents Hold DayCare Offices Three Hours to Demand Changes
description: More than 150 men, women and children took over the of fices of the Social Services De partment ??sion of day care, 80 Lafayette Street, for three and a half hours yesterday. They were protesting the lack of progress in talks with the city concerning changes in the guidelines for the operation of daycare centers.

title: Protest Saves ChampsElysees Mansions
description: PARIS, Jan. 26A public protest has saved the cen turyold mansions that form a base for the Champs Elyses. Marcel Dassault, the aircraft designer, has scrapped plans for a big con crete office building on his corner of the RondPoint, a plaza midway along the ave nue. Instead, he has returned to the drawing board to de sign an extension of the pres ent buildings into a harmoni ous whole, in their own early19thcentury style.

title: PRESIDENT, ON TV, VETOES SCHOOL AID AS INFLATIONARY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Be fore a nationwide television audience, President Nixon, with a flourish of his pen, vetoed tonight a $19.7billion measure. containing funds for health, education and antipoverty pro grams.

title: Israeli Jets Raid Canal Area
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 26 (Reuters) Israeli jets tonight attacked military targets in the southern sector of the Suez Canal front. an Israeli army spokesman said here. He added that all planes had returned safely.

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM PUSHES GAS IMPORTS
description: The Phillips Petroleum Com pany announced yesterday plans for the largescaie importation of liquefied natural gas from overseas sources into the United States.

title: Bank Merger Is Approved
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Jan. 26 (AP)The merger of the Rockland National Bank and the County National Bank of Middletown has been approved by the U.S. Controller of the Currency, the presidents of the two institutions said today.

title: GOODELL ASSAILS U.S. WAR SPENDING
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell told the Women's City Club yesterday that the time for rhetoric was past and the need now was for money muscle from Washington to meet the nation's urgent domestic needs.

title: Syria to Build a New Airport
description: DAMASCUS, Syria Jan. 26 (Reuters)A new airport will be built at Latakia on the Med iterranean coast in northern Syria, the Civil Aviation direc torate announced here yester day.

title: E.E.C. IS NEARING MONETARY UNION
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 26  The European Common Market gov ernments, acting to prevent new outbreaks of the currency turmoil that has plagued them over the last two years, took the first cautious steps today toward a monetary union.

title: NEW CHIEF TO HEAD POLICE IN CLEVELAND
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 26  Wil Liam P. Ellenburg, a retired De troit police inspector, was ap pointed Cleveland's police chief today, was sworn in and took office immediately.

title: PRINCETON TRIUMPHS OVER FORDHAM, 6954
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 26 Led by Jeff Petrie's career high of 39 points, Princeton scored a 6954 victory tonight over Fordham.

title: THURMOND PLANS TO QUIT WARRIORS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (UPI)Nate Thurmond, one of the top centers in pro basket ball, announced his retirement today at the hospital where he is recuperating from a knee op eration.

title: Burmah Oil Seeks LaPorte Industries
description: In a foreign takeover bid, the Burmah Oil Company an nounced yesterday that it was offering to acquire LaPorte In tries (Holdings), Inc., for stock valued at about $156million.

title: Alabama Files Suit
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 26 Gov. Albert Brewer asked the Supreme Court today to enjoin John N. Mitchell, the Attorney General and Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, from taking any further steps to desegregate schools in Alabama unless the same steps were taken in all the states.

title: Mortgage Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Wright Pitman, Democrat of Texas who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, has said the committee will inves tigate alternate ways of financ ing home mortgages in hear ings starting Feb. 2.

title: N. & W. Reports Rise
description: The Norfolk & Western Railwaythe nation's most profitable carrier in transpor tation operations  reported yesterday preliminary consol idated earnings of $87.5mil lion for 1969. In 1968, net income restated to reflect a rate divisions settlement with other lines, was $76.3million.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: U.S. Aides Say Decision on Help May Be Spurred by Libyan Planes Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  State Department officials said today that France's projected sale of supersonic aircraft to Libya had injected a new sense of urgency into the Nixon Ad ministration's consideration of fourmonthold requests from Israel for aid.

title: BATTLES INCREASE IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (AP)The United States Command reported today in creased battle action by both allied and enemy forces in all four military zones of South Vietnam.

title: Westchester Backs Pact For a Teaching Hospital
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 26 (UPI)The Westchester County Board of Legislators voted unanimously today to approve a $50million contract with New York Medical College as a means to improve county health facilities.

title: SEGREGATED PARK MAY GO TO HEIRS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Supreme Court ruled to day that a park established in a segregationist's will in 1911 for the exclusive use of the white citizens of Macon, Ga., could be returned to the donor's heirs in the face of a court order to admit Negroes.

title: Public Television Heads Agree On Pollution as Major Target
description: The men who run the coun try's public television stations agree that protection of the environment should be the primary subject of educational television programing.

title: Memorial Services
description: THORNHILLArthur. Memorial service for Arthur H. Thornhill will be held at 12 noon, Monday, February 9th at King's Chapel, Tremont and School Streets; Bos ton, Massachusetts. Please omit flowers.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON HAVE QUIET DAY
description: The London Stock Exchange was Quiet yesterday.

title: CAHILL'S SON FINED AFTER JUNE ARREST
description: BEACH HAVEN, N. J., Jan. 26 (AP)John P. Cahill, 19year old son of Gov. William T. Cahill, who was arrested on a marijuana charge in Philadel phia on Saturday, also was ar rested here last June 26.

title: Rockefeller U. Names Aide
description: Dr. James A. Shannon, a special adviser to the president of the National Academy of Sciences and a former director of the National Institutes of Health, has been appointed special assistant to the presi dent of Rockefeller University. He will assist the university in planning health research programs and will serve as a member of the city's Board of Health.

title: A.C.L.U. AIDS SINATRA ON JERSEY WARRANT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26  The New Jersey branch of the American Civil Liberties Union moved today to join Frank Sinatra in his fight against test ifying before the state's invest igation commission.

title: Brooklyn Lawyer Sworn As Aide to U.S. Attorney
description: Robert A. Morse, an assist ant United States Attorney dur ing the Eisenhower Adminis tration, was sworn in yester day as chief assistant United States Attorney for the East ern District of New York.

title: Newark Fire Aide Ousted In Mayoral Race Dispute
description: NEWARK, Jan. 26  Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio abruptly dis missed Newark's Fire Director, John P. Caufield, today after Mr. Caufield refused to step aside as a potential rival in the city's next mayoral contest.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Bedside Atom Smasher Is Used to Produce Radiation
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26A new research and diagnostic tech nique in which a bedside atom smasher is used to generate shortlife radioactive sub stances was described here today.

title: GRAIN HALT IS ASKED AS 3 ARE POISONED
description: ALAMOGORDO, N. M., Jan. 26 (UPI)Gov. David F. Cargo called today for a moratorium on the distribution in the state of mercurytreated grain, which has resulted in the poisoning of three children here.

title: At the Funts, a Nuttiness in Every Room
description: WHEN Allen Funt, television's Peeping Tom, bought his $165,000 duplex apartment five years ago, he decided then and there that it wasn't going to be like anybody else's.

title: Court Bids East Brunswick Teachers Return to Class
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 26The 530 teachers and 247 staff and maintenance workers of the East Brunswick Township public school sys tem were ordered today by Superior Court Judge David Furman to end their threeday workaction walkout and re turn to their classrooms.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: For Medical Research

title: The United States and Israel
description: President Nixon's message of reassurance on the Middle East to American Jewish leaders is, like Secre tary of State Rogers's December speech, a simple restatement of longstanding American policy. The two statements are perfectly compatible with each other and with the position taken by the previous Administration following the 1967 ArabIsrael war.

title: 2 Saved in Coast Air Crash
description: JACKSON, Calif., Jan. 26 (Reuters)Two men who sur vived on snow for two weeks were rescued today after being given up for dead in an air crash. Robert Star, 17 year old, and Gene Ebel!, 33, of Fresno, Calif., were taken to a hospital here suffering from frostbite, hunger and broken bones. They were in fair condition.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES SCHOOL DISTRICTS
description: A suit to compel the Board of Education to redraw the five decentralized school districts proposed for Manhattan was argued yesterday in State Su preme Court.

title: Marcos Is Unhurt as Youths in Manila Hurl Bottles in Riot Outside Congress
description: MANILA, Jan. 26  angry youths shouting Marcos pup pet and demanding reforms at tacked President Ferdinand E. Marcos with stones and bottles this evening as he emerged from the Congress building with Mrs. Marcos. Both escaped injury.

title: VIOLIST'S PROGRAM SPANS 7 CENTURIES
description: Milton Thomas, violist, of fered a program of consider able variety last night at Tully Hall. It ranged from 14thcen tury Italian dances (played un accompanied) all the way to Henri Lazarof's Cadence II for Viola and Tape (1969), a first performance.

title: DANIEL BURKE, 96, OF BIBLE SOCIETY
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 26 Daniel Burke, a lawyer and former president of the Ameri ca Bible Society, died today at his home, 66 Fernwood Road, after a long illness. He was 96, years old.

title: World Bank Lends Ceylon $5Million to Build Tourism
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 26 The World Bank has agreed to grant Ceylon a $5 million loan for a fiveyear tourism pro motion proposed by the Gov ernment for 197075. The loan will be repayable in 20 years.

title: Premier's Reply Is Seen as an Effort to Reduce Diplomatic Tension
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26Pre mier Goida Meir said tonight that President Nixon's message yesterday on AmericanIsraeli relations was a clear expressions of concern for Israel's security and integrity.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: Book Publishing: Industry in Turmoil
description: Book publishing, once a stately ocean liner of indus try, has been transformed into a jet of corporate flighti ness, moving executives and authors from one house to another faster than they ever moved before.

title: BLACK MILITANTS SPLIT IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Jan. 26  The Republic of New Africa, a militant black group head quartered here, has split, with factions forming behind each of the two brothers who cre ated it.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ALIKING for salt pork, whether lean or fat, and salt fish, is common among the older residents of sea coast New England. Although their grandchildren seem to prefer frozen pizzas and TV dinners, it gave me, as a mid dleaged New Englander, a twinge of nostalgic pleasure to discover on a recent hunt ing trip to North Carolina's Outer Banks that salt pork figures prominently in many of the oldtime recipes there.

title: Venezuela Bank Adds Card
description: The Bank of America an nounced yesterday than Banco Union, of Venezuela, would soon be issuing the BancUnion BankAmericard, becoming the 44th foreign area entering the BankAmericard system since 1968.

title: Executives Are Named By Marshall Field & Co.
description: A number of new executive appointments were announced yesterday in Chicago by Mar shall Field & Co., that city's largest departmentstore chain. Field's also owns stores in Seattle and Spokane.

title: Nixon Official Backs Trade With Reds
description: A highranking official of the Nixon Administration asserted here yesterday that there is no stigma attached to dealings by American businessmen with Communist nations.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS LEAD BROAD ROUT
description: Bluechip and glamour stocks weakened along a broad front yesterday as the DowJones in dustrial average slipped to its lowest closing since October, 1966.

title: Pro Football Gets FourYear TV Pact
description: Professional football achieved yesterday a degree of distinc tion reserved for Presidential messages to the nation, national conventions, elections and moonshots. Beginning this year, its games will be seen on all three major television net works, American, Columbia and National.

title: Japanese Workers Dismissed
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26 (Reuters) United States military authori ties in Japan today announced a dismissal of 3,741 Japanese employes to bases throughout the country. The United States previously announced dismis sal of 2,300 workers starting last October as part of a planned cutback in American defense spending.

title: Democrat Urges a Joint Party Drive
description: George N. Spitz, former con sultant to the Joint Legislative Committee on the Election Law, has proposed that Demo crats in Manhattan's 26th Sena torial District join forces in an experiment to demonstrate to the state that campaign costs can be cut.

title: Byzantine Era Mosaics Are Uncovered at Amman
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  Colored mosaic floors dating from the Byzan tine era have been discovered in the suburbs of Amman, the Jordanian Directorate of An tiquities has announced.

title: A Soviet Trade Delegation Arrives in Vienna for Talks
description: VIENNA, Jan. 26A Soviet delegation arrived here tonight for trade talks with neutral Austria.

title: Life Article About Fortas Wins Guild's Broun Prize
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) William Lambert's article in Life magazine that led to the resignation of Justice Abe Fortas from the Supreme Court has won the American News paper Guild's Heywood Broun Award of 1969.

title: Mrs. Eisenhower to Be Cited
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 26 (UDI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will present special awards Thurs day to Mrs. Dwight D. Eisen hower and Owen R. Cheatham, chairman of the executive com mittee of the GeorgiaPacific Corporation, to mark the open ling, of the 1970 heart fund cam paign. Mrs. Eisenhower through the ?? has identified hersei prominently with the work of ?? Heart Association. Mr. Cheatham will receive the as sociation's annual citation con ferred upon a distinguished American who, despite heart dsease, continues to make con tributions to the national wel fare.

title: Condolences in Crash
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26 (UPI) President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz sent condolences today to fami lies of 14 newsmen killed in a plane crash yesterday while covering the presidential elec tion campaign.

title: Poll Says Most Americans Favor AllVolunteer Army
description: A majority of Americans now support the concept of an all volunteer army, according to a poll by Louis Harris published in yesterday's New York Post.

title: Car Makers Unveil Model Of a New $22,500 Stutz
description: What's in a name? If the promoters of the newly formed Stutz Motor Car of America, Inc., are correct, there is enough nostalgia left to attract buyers for their new Blackhawk. The original Blackhawk was a contemporary of the more famour Bearcat model that was part of automotive folklore in the early nineteentwenties.

title: Guyana to See Moon Rocks
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Jan. 26The United States Ambas sador, Spencer King, said yes terday that rocks from the moon would go on exhibition here during next month's ob servance of Guyana's becoming a republic,

title: Jordan Considers Buying East Bloc Antiaircraft Guns
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 26 Jordan is studying the possi bility of purchasing some arms, particularly antiaircraft guns, from Eastern Europe.

title: SONATRACH IS CITED AS WINNER IN BIDS
