description: The Sinclair Mediterranean Petroleum Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Atlan tic Richfield Company, dis closed yesterday that it had been informed that Sonatrach, the Algerian national oil com pany, had been designated the successful bidder for Sinclair Mediterranean's oil titles in Algeria.

title: Diane Carol Kleine Is Affianced Cora A. Goldbaum a Future Bride
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 26 The engagement of Miss Diane Carol Kleine, daughter of Mrs. Edwin D. Kleine and the late Mr. Kleine, to Ed ward John Kuebert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Kue bert of Wantagh, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother.

title: City Seeks Release of Evidence Linking Car Makers to Pollution
description: The city asked the United States Supreme Court yester day to review a recent Depart ment of Justice settlement of an antitrust case that charged the country's automobile indus try with suppressing develop ment and installation of devices to reduce exhaust pollution.

title: Soviet Journalists Picketed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (UPI)A group of Soviet jour nalists was picketed tonight by 85 persons protesting the treat ment of Jews in Russia. The protesters briefly padlocked the door to the San Francisco Press Club, where the Soviet journalists attended a dinner.

title: Buttes Seeking Copper
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI)The Buttes Gas and Oil Company confirmed today that it was exploring for copper on three Mexican concessions in which it has interests ranging from 16 to 100 per cent. Buttes said it was too early to determine if it had any commercially feasible finds although preliminary re sults have been encouraging. Buttes said it had been core drilling in the states of Michao can, Jalisco and Sonora.

title: 2 Crewmen Lost, 3 Saved As Clam Dredger Capsizes
description: ATLANTIC CITY. Jan. 26 Two crewmen were lost and presumed dead and the captain and two others rescued today after their clamdredging rig broke loose from its mooring and the 80foot vessel, the Se wanhaka, capsized in the At lantic.

title: KIRK SCHOOL PLAN DENIED BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  The Supreme Court rejected today without com ment a plea by Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida that it re consider a decision that orders 14 Southern school districts to desegregate by Feb. 1.

title: In the Midst of the War, a Placid Beach
description: VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Jan. 25  Hunched low over their small motorbikes, four Americans in plastic helmets and motorcycle jackets roared down this afternoon from the hill overlooking this beach re sort and bounced over the sand to the edge of the sea.

title: 2 More Persons in France Commit Suicide by Fire
description: PARIS, Jan. 26 (Reuters) Two more persons committed suicide by fire in France today, bringing the total of selfimmo lations to seven in 10 days. The latest victims were a 20year latest victims were a 20year old youth in Marseilles and a 70yearold woman in Tarbes, in the Pyrenees.

title: Dow Jones Publications Appoints Executive Editor
description: Edward R. Cony, 46 years old, managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, has been appointed executive editor of Dow Jones Publications and News Services, and a member of the company's management committee.

title: SAUL STRESSES TREND TO FUNDS
description: Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, suggested yesterday that finan cial institutions had become the primary audience for some cor porate managers, replacing the traditional role of the individ ual stockholder.

title: Republic Up Slightly
description: Two of the country's big gest steel companies reported yesterday that their sales rose to records last year but their earnings advanced only slightly.

title: Albany Asked to Pay Ousted Teacher
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26  Dr. Ar thur J. Kraus, who was dis charged from the City College faculty in New York 37 years ago and who spent those years in penury while relentlessly seeking exoneration, came to the Capitol today in quest of a pension.

title: SUGAR FUTURES REGISTER A RISE
description: World sugar futures, which had been slightly lower last week, rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

title: Hagen's Snowmobile Leads In Race From Winnipeg
description: CROOKSTON, Minn., Jan. 25 Luverne Hagen of Roseville, Minn., took the first lap today of the 587mile St. Paul Winter Carnival 500 snowmobile mara thon. Of the 221 starters who left Winnipeg, Canada, at 8 A.M. today, 150 finished in the unusually mild temperature which hovered just above zero.

title: Screen: 'The Milky Way':Bunuel Weaves Surreal Spiritual Journey
description: WOMEN, pronounced St. Chrysostom, are "a necessary evil, a natural temptation, a desirable calamity, a domestic peril, a deadly fascination, and a painted ill."The good, fourth century mysoginist, just one of the dozens of saints, rascals, nuns, picaroons, inquisitors, heretics, bishops, whores and humble people who are either represented or evoked in Luis Buuel's marvelous new film, "The Milky Way," clearly had an ambivalent attitude towards women. Because of Buuel's similar preoccupation with things he professes to abhor, the fine, irascible Spanish film director ("Thank God I'm an atheist!") has often been suspected of ambivalent attitudes towards the Roman Catholicism he has renounced and the God he has denied.While there must always be a certain amount of ambiguity in any proclamation of atheism, there can be no further question about Buuel and the Church. That is, not after "The Milky Way," which has the form of a lovely fantasy and the density of a theological essay, and which often sounds like the sort of shaggy dog story that might be told in a seminary.The film, which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is shaped as a sort of surreal Pilgrim's Progress undertaken by two contemporary, not especially pious Frenchmen. Pierre (Paul Frankeur), a bearded, virile, respectful old man, and Jean (Laurent Terzieff), his younger, skeptical companion, are making a pilgrimage (for reasons never specified) to the tomb of the Apostle James at Santiago de Compostella in Spain.En route, they have a series of extraordinary encounters with personages out of the past, including Priscillian, the fourth century Spanish bishop, martyred for his Manichean unorthodoxies, and the Virgin Mary, who appears to them sitting in a tree.At one point they meet the devil, lounging in the backseat of a sports car that's just been wrecked. He is a typically Buuelian devil, both polite and practical, who suggests to the poor Pierre, whose feet hurt, that he take the dead driver's new shoes. Later, they come upon a Jansenist convent whose nuns, not very enthusiastically, are helping one of their order to realize her desire for crucifixion. They also act as seconds in a duel between a Jansenist and a Jesuit, are instructed in the virtues of chasity in marriage, and finally, when they reach Santiago, find, not the Celestial City, but an empty tomb.While Buuel is obviously fond of Pierre and Jean, he's not exactly obsessed with them. He doesn't hesitate to drop them from time to time to pursue with greater freedom his principal themereligion as a man-made phenomenon whose dogmas have been the bases for religious wars, inquisitions and madly irrational theological arguments conducted with the utmost reason.The movie is constantly side-stepping itself to show, among other things, why Jesus wore a beard (Mary thought it suited him), the Marquis de Sade tormenting a helpless young thing who persists in saying there is a God, Priscillian apologizing to the Communion host ("It was not I who reaped and kneaded Thee").Through all of the miracles and magical encounters, through all of the deadly nonsensical debates on the true meaning of the Trinity, and through all of the Alice-in-Wonderland-like discussions on the differences between consubstantiation and transubstantiation, Pierre and Jean maintain a saintly sanity that is, in itself, very funny and even moving.Unlike such an angry film as "Viridiana," in which Buuel used Freudian psychology to attack the Church (specifically its concept of charity and the subsequent evil of pity), "The Milky Way" goes about its business with a comic, masterly cool that is more remorseless than anything he's done before. The film is closer in tone to his early, surreal "Un Chien Andalou" and "L'Age d'Or" than to the later, non-ironic, malevolent but comparatively gentle "Nazarin" and "Simon of the Desert," which almost persuaded some people that Buuel was returning to the fold.One of the nicest things about "The Milky Way," and about the only thing that indicates the director's age (he'll be 70 this year) is its technical facility. Buuel employs no fantastic effects, though this is a livelier fantasy than, say, "The Wizard of Oz." Everything is photographed straightforwardly, in cheerful but not bilious color, and seen with documentary-like clarity.For what is, in effect, his "Greatest Story Ever Told," Buuel recruited a large cast of mostly French performers for many cameo roles, including Pierre Clementi (the Devil), Michel Piccoli (de Sade), Bernard Verley (Jesus), Edith Scob (the Virgin Mary) and Delphine Seyrig (the prostitute).Even if you're non-Catholic, as I am, "The Milky Way" can also be enjoyed as a kind of Pilgrim's Progress through the Buuel iconography. The film is packed with symbols that repeatedly recur in all of his films (dwarfs, doves, beggars, blind men, religious instruments, graves). And, if you're willing to do a little homework, the film can become so fascinating that you're likely to recall a disturbing remark made by one character, who materializes briefly and is identified in the cast only as The Lecturer. "My hatred of science," he says with bored resignation, "and my horror of technology will finally lead me to this absurd belief in God. . . ."

title: City College Students Flunk 37 Teachers on Ability
description: An evaluation handbook be ing distributed this week at City College lists 37 faculty members as not recommend ed, based on class ratings of their performance by students.

title: Entete Triumphs at Bowie in First Start and Pays $208
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 26En tete made the first start of her career an auspicious one today as she raced to victory as a 1031 shot at Bowie Race Course. Ridden by Bill Pass more, the 3yearold filly won the sixth race on the program, a $4,500 claiming event and re turned $208, $88.40 and $25.60 for $2 across the board wager.

title: U.N. Observer Terms Aid To Biafrans Insufficient
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 26 A United Nations observer who recently returned from the for mer Biafran region reported today that the current relief program for refugees there was obviously not enough.

title: Observer:
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Reuben Mills, winner of the Loser of the Year Award for 196970, was in town over the weekend. He had hoped to cash in on his award by making some guest appearances on television, but naturally none of the local TV hosts or hostesses wanted him.

title: New Gas Leak Is Found
description: HOUMA, La.,Jan. 26 (AP) The police cordoned off a four block area when a new gas leak was found today in the business district where an ex plosion Saturday killed three persons and heavily damaged businesses. City officials said the leak was found by inspec tors checking the area for fur ther leaks.

title: Lindsay Gives Kretchmer Environment Agency Post
description: Mayor Lindsay, confirming reports that circulated over the weekend, named Assemblyman Jerome Kretchmer yesterday as the new head of the city's En vironmental Protection Admin istration.

title: The Public Beach
description: A recent unanimous decision by the Oregon Supreme Court ruled that all dry sand areas of the Pacific sea shore in that state are reserved for public use. Thus, some 300 miles of wild and dramatically scenic beach are, in effect, to be preserved in their natural condi tion forever.

title: 33 Witnesses at Hearing Protest Proposed L.I.R.R. Fare Rise
description: Thirtythree witnesses at a public hearing here yesterday urged the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority not to grant new fare raises requested by the managers of the Long Island Rail Road.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Dr. Peter Lantos has been promoted to vice president of research and development for the Sun Chemical Corporation.

title: Advertising: Selling Flatware to the Bride
description: The fourpage ad that is part of the cover of Modern Bride magazine is all about a sterling silver flatware brand and starts off with this headline, From Oneida with love. Rather romantic.

title: The Washington Record
Judge Says Daley Is a Good Mayor
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26  Judge Julius J. Hoffman said today that, as far as he was con cerned, Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago was a good Mayor.

title: ESTHER ENG, OWNED RESTAURANTS HERE
description: Esther Eng, proprietor of Chi nese restaurants in Chinatown, who had produced and directed motion pictures in Hong Kong and brought Chinese opera companies to the United States, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hos pital. She was 55 years old and lived at 50 Bayard Street.

title: Pilots Now a Matter of State
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Jan. 26 (AP)A plan to be presented tomorrow to the American League to retain the Seattle Pilots will have broad impact on the state, Washingon Gov. Dan Evans said today. The Gov ernor would not elaborate but said that he had been in contact with those working on the proj ect in the development of the idea.

title: STREAK EXTENDED BY PRINCE BUTLER
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 26 Prince Butler, 4yearold son of Adios Butler and Lady Scot land, made his 1970 pacing record 3for3 by winning to night's $5,250, Class A3 fea tured mile in 2:03 3/5 at Roose velt Raceway.

title: More Taxi Riders Complaining of Driver Abuses
description: An increasing number or taxi riders, particularly wo men, are complaining daily to the Police Department's Hack Bureau about abusive and ob scene language used by some cab drivers.

title: SCHEINMAN GAINS IN CONCORD TENNIS
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 26  Some of the best young tennis players in the East went into action today at the Concord Hotel's annual in tercollegiate indoor tournament

title: Rift Over Guevara Discloses New Left in Hungary
description: VIENNA, Jan. 26The ex istence of a New Left among young intellectuals in Hungary has been brought into the open by a controversy over Ernesto Che Guevara, the revolutionary slain in Bolivia in 1967.

title: ARMY GIVES REPLY ON ROLE OF AGENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Army acknowledged today that its Intelligence Command had about 1,000 agents across the country who conduct security checks of Army and Govern ment personnel, but it denied that any widespread monitor ing of civilian political activity took place.

title: LEOPOLD CHAMBLISS, NEWARK BANKER, 73
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 26Leopold A Chambliss, a former Newark bank and hos pital official, died at Doctor Hospital here Saturday of a heart ailment. He was 73 years old and had lived at 550 Ocean Drive, Key Biscayne, since re tiring in 1958

title: Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: BANKER'S SON, 25, HELD IN SMUGGLING
description: A youth who is the son of a banker and a psychiatrist was ordered held in $100,000 bail here yesterday on charges of impersonating a Federal officer and smuggling hashish into the United States from Puerto Rico.

title: STREETWALKERS LEAVING DAYTON
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 26  Streetwalkers have not yet dis appeared from Dayton but police enforcement of a three monthold unlawfulassembly ordinance has made life so dif ficult for prostitutes that many have left town.

title: New I.D.S. Fund Unit Set
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 26 (UPI)  Investors Diversified Serv ices, Inc., announced today an agreement in principle with five European banks to create an international organization for distribution of mutual funds. The agreement provides for establishment of an in ternational holding company, I.D.S. International, with head quarters in Luxembourg. The new company will hold stock in various operating subsidia ries that will market mutual funds, except in the United States, Canada and Japan.

title: 4 KILLED IN RHODESIA IN GUERRILLA CLASH
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)An African member of the Rhode sian Security Forces and three African guerrilla infiltrators have been killed in a new bat tle in the remote Zambezi Val ley, the Government announced here today.

title: Suspect in Wilton Murder Formally Charged in Court
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP)Louis Cofone Jr., who was brought back from New Orleans over the weekend, was presented in Superior Court to day and formally arrested on a charge of murder in the strangling of a Wilton house wife.

title: CARROLL MOSES
description: Carroll Moses, who retired in 1952 as an internal auditor for The New York Times, died Thursday in Kings County Hos pital. He was 82 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: How Much Does It Cost?
description: In this period of skyrocketing prices, consumers need all the assistance they can get to make sure they receive maximum value for their shrinking dollar. An ambitious effort of New York City to help in this direction has now been challenged in the courts by a major group of food retailers.

title: Sven on Bullets Fined $500 Apiece After Game
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 26(AP) Seven members of the Balti more Bullets have been fined $500 apiece, the Associated Press learned tonight.

title: Sato's Party Backs Nuclear Ban Treaty
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26After a heated twohour discussion, leaders of the ruling Liberal Democratic party today gave the Government their agree merit on early signing of the treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: MRS. ANDREW HAPPER
description: Mrs. Marjorie Tietig Happer, widow of Andrew P. Happer, former Eastern area manager of United States Steel Corpora tion, National Tube Division, died yesterday at her home, 880 Fifth Avenue. She was 71 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: this sort endanger the commu nity itself.

title: Blast Damages Belfast Office
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  An explo sion blasted the offices of a taxi concern here early this morning, shattering its win dows and those in nearby houses. There were no reports of injuries.

title: Reagan Thrown by Horse
description: SACRAMENTO. Calif. Jan. 26 (UPI)  Gov. Ronald Rea gan suffered a sprained ankle Saturday when he was thrown by a horse while going over a jump at his Malibu ranch, a press aide reported today. I had a little argument with my horse and the horse won. Reagan observed to a group of touring Soviet journalists.

title: Putting a Bit of Whimsy Into Fashion
description: B.H. WRAGGE'S clothes are generally destined for sober suburbanites who live in station wagons during the day and dress up for country club evenings. But there are whimsical touches for summer:

title: Blast Shakes Beirut Offices
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 26 (UPI)A stick of dynamite blew out the windows today in a building housing a rightwing Lebanese newspaper and Bei rut's only Englishlanguage daily in the seventh attack at tributed to terrorists in Leba non in eight days. No casual ties were reported when the dynamite blew up in a yard near the offices of Al Hayat and The Daily Star.

title: Hunt for Typhoid Source Pressed on British Liner
description: VANCOUVER, British Co lumbia, Jan. 26  The British liner Oronsay, which sailed in to Vancouver Harbor 13 days ago with her colorful cruise banners flying, lay silent along side Pier B today, yellow quarantine flags telling a grim tale of frustrated medical de tectives.

title: Chicken and Tennessee Politics
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 23For the voters of Tennessee, a coonskin cap symbolized the late Senator Estes Kefauver, and a piece of fried chicken symbolizes John Jay Hooker Jr.

title: GRAVEDIGGER TALKS MAKE NO PROGRESS
description: Representatives of 1,700 striking gravediggers and the operators of 44 metropolitan area cemeteries met with state mediators for four hours yes terday, but made no progress toward ending a strike that has suspended nearly all burials here since Jan. 12.

title: Latins Hold Economic Parley
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 26 (Reuters)A conference of the InterAmerican Economic Council opened here today with LatinAmerican countries at tempting to arrive at a joint regional policy to seek closer ties with European Common Market nations.

title: Boeing Co. Reduces Quarterly Dividend To 10 Cents a Share
description: The Boeing Company's di rectors cut the quarterly divi dend yesterday to 10 cents a share from the 30 cents that the company had been pay ing Quarterly.

title: CITY INVESTIGATES PRISONER SUICIDE
description: The suicide of one prisoner and the attempted suicide of another during the weekend at the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island were under investigation yesterday by City Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath.

title: 40 Protest Annual Seal Kill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  About 40 persons picketed the Interior Department today in protest against the annual harvesting of fur seals on the Pribiloff Islands off Alaska. Under department supervision, natives of the islands slaughter tens of thousands of seals an nually for their fur, which is marketed in the United States.

title: SCHIENMAN ACQUIRES THE M'DONNELL FUND
description: Schienman, Hochstin & Trot ta, Inc., the brokerage concern, announced yesterday that it had acquired from McDonnell & Co. the management and distribut ing companies for the McDon nell Fund.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SELLS GOLD TO THE I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (Reu ters)Financial sources said today South Africa has already sold about $40million worth of newly mined gold to the Inter national Monetary Fund as a result of the continued failure of the free market price to rise above $35 an ounce.

title: 2 Sides Meet in Korea
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Jan. 26 (Reuters)The United Nations command and spokesmen for North Korea today exchanged charges of armistice violations but did not discuss the Dec. 11 hijacking of a South Korean air liner to the North.

title: Economic Impact of Vietnamization Plan Is Debated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 President Nguyen Van Thieu said in Saigon a couple of weeks ago that he was com piling a list of arms, materials and funds that he expected to get from the United States as American troops are withdrawn and South Vietnamese forces take over more of the fighting.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A SenateHouse conference committee agreed yesterday on a foreignaid appropria tions bill for the current fiscal year. The bill will call for $1.46billion in economic aid and $350million in military aid. The total, of $1.8billion, is a cut of nearly a third from the President's request of $2.6billion. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: SHOULD MORTGAGE HAVE FLUID RATE?
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26  Home mortgages with variable interest rates might be a way to funnel funds into housing, bankers suggested here today.

title: Ticket FixerUppers On Overtime at Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera, besieged by patrons demand ing refunds or issuance of tickets for performances lost or rescheduled as a result of the curtailed season, has added an emergency force of 35 workers to its subscrip tion department to handle the crush.

title: School at Soviet Embassy In Peking Is Opened Again
description: PEKING, Jan. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  The elemen tary school reopened at the So viet Embassy today.

title: Officer Killed in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 26 (Reuters)Brig. Pierino Yerei Okoya, one of Uganda's senior army commanders, and his wife were shot and killed yesterday at their home in the northern Ugandan town of Gulu, it was announced today.

title: Job Program for Negroes Defended in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26  The City of Philadelphia joined the Department of Justice today in defending the Nixon Admin istration's controversial Phila delphia Plan to increase mi nority employment in construc tion projects.

title: ORDERS DIP AGAIN IN DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  New orders received by man ufacturers of durable goods one of the key economic indi catorscieclined substantially in December for the third straight month the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: YIELDS ADVANCE IN BOND MARKETS
description: Interest rates moved higher yesterday as corporations con tinued to announce new bond issues and investors displayed little enthusiasm for yields al ready available in the capital markets.

title: In Memoriam
description: BERLINEREsther P. in loving memory SIDNEY DOROTHY HOWARD and RUTH

title: JAVITS BIDS JAPAN AVOID TRADE WAR
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26Senator Jacob K. Javits warned today that the Japanese faced a pos sible trade war with the United States and called on their country to live up to the re sponsibilities of its economic power and its new political maturity.

title: John Kingston, Emily R. Fuller To Wed May 16
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 26 Miss Emily Rutgers Fuller, who is with the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, plans to be mar ried on May 16 to John King ston, who is with Coenen & Co., Inc., investment bankers in New York.

title: One Network Assesses President's Statement
description: President Nixon's expected veto of funds for the De partment of Health, Educa tion and Welfare drew mini mum immediate reaction from the television networks last night.

title: Color TV Fire Risk Cited in 122 Models
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The National Committee on Product Safety listed 122 models of color television sets today as extraordinary fire hazards.

title: Paterno Receives Award From Writers Here Today
description: Joe Paterno, Penn State's head football coach, will receive the New York Football Writers' Association annual award as Eastern coach of the year at a ceremony today at the New York University Club.

title: Ethiopian Schools Reopen
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  The Haile Selassi University and all sec ondary and elementary schools here reopened today after dis turbances last month. But uni versity students did not go to classes only a few secondary school students in Addis Ababa attended class all day, informed sources said.

title: MEANY WILL FIGHT CARSWELL CHOICE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., said today that his organdation would oppose the confirmation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Su preme Court.

title: Eastern Cherokee Chief Resists Demand He Quit
description: CHEROKEE N. C. Jan. 26 The tribal council of the Eastern band of Cherokee In dians has asked the Cherokee chief to resign as leader of the 6,500member tribe and he has steadfastly refused.

title: Walker Says Firmness Policy Is Working
description: It is still too early for any letup in the Government's anti inflation campaign, despite evidence that the economy has begun to slow and the con tention in some quarters that a recession is already assured, Alfred Hayes, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

title: C.B.S. Will Comply With Subpoenas on Panthers
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that it would comply with a Govern ment subpoena for the news film of the complete program, in cluding portions not shown to the public, on the Black Panther party. The program was seen on Jan. 6 in the series called 60 Minutes.

title: Shareholders Capital Elects
description: John W. Sweetland has been elected executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Shareholders Capital Cor poration and a member of the company's board. He was a principal in a private real estate investment company prior to joining Shareholders Capital.

title: Stauffer Chemical Co. Appoints an Executive
description: The appointment of Dr. H. Barclay Morley as executive vice president of the Stauf fer Chemical Company was announced yesterday.

title: Goodman's Bill Would Reduce Waiting Time for Divorces
description: State Senator Roy M. Good man said yesterday he was introducing a bill in the Legis lature that would eliminate the concept of the guilty party from the state divorce law and cut the waiting time for divorce in cases of separation from two years to one.

title: CAHILL IN ACCORD ON CRIME CURBS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26The new Republican administration of Gov. William T. Cahill and the leaders of the overwhelmingly Republican legislative majori ties announced their agreement today on a proposed law that would give the State Attorney General the power to supersede county prosecutors in fighting organized crime and corruption in New Jersey.

title: West Side IRT Service Disrupted for 1 Hours
description: Service on the West Side IRT was disrupted for an hour and a half last night after the cars of a Brooklynbound express separated as the train was ap proaching 14th Street station in Manhattan.

title: Suspect in Bank Robbery In Deer Park Is Arrested
description: Federal agents and Suffolk County policeman arrested a 25 yearold suuspect yseterday in connection with the $2,605 rob bery of the Deer Park branch of the Security National Bank on Jan. 16, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Market Place:
description: THE STOCK of Walter Kidde & Co., Inc., skid ded to a new low for 1969 1970 yesterday at 33 and closed at 33 off 3 The selling represented a contin uation of a toboggan run for the stock on Friday when the shares plunged 6.

title: 68 Rival of Powell To Try Once More To Obtain His Seat
description: John H. Young, who was de feated by Representative Adam Clayton Powell by a 32 margin in a primary election two years ago, announced yesterday that he would try again in June to win the Democratic nomination for Mr. Powell's Congressional seat.

title: Directors Are Elected By Two Macy Divisions
description: Two store divisions of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., anounced yes terday the election of new di rectors and the realignment of executive committee responsi bilities.

title: Retreat From Responsibility
description: Lester B. Pearson, chairman of a special World Bank study committee, warned last year that the faltering performance of foreign assistance donors was creating a crisis in international development.

title: A Mysterious Odor In the City Baffles Even Expert Noses
description: A foul odor in the air caused hundreds of residents of Man hattan, the Bronx and western Queens to phone the police, Consolidated Edison and city and state agencies last night in an attempt to learn what the smell was.Except for Consolidated Edi sonwhich said its responding crews had not detected any escaping gas there was no immediate answer as to what the odor might or might not have been.

title: Hotel Fire Inquiry Pushed
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (UPI) Fire Commissioner Robert J. Quinn sent investigators on an inchbyinch search today of an area of the Conrad Hilton Hotel to find the cause of a fire that killed two guests and injured 38 persons. Officials, meanwhile, ordered the hotel management to stop storing furniture and other items near elevator banks and in corridors. It was in a stack of furniture in an elevator lobby on the ninth floor that the fire broke out Sunday.

title: Lindsay Proposes OffTrack Betting
description: A perennial City Hall revenue proposal  legalized offtrack betting in New York City made a new appearance in the political paddock yesterday un der the approving eye of Mayor Lindsay.

title: Foreign Affairs: Logic's Power or Vice Versa II
description: PARISThe French Govern ment reckons it can court the Arabs with armsas most re cently Libyabecause the very idea of an existing Middle East ern power balance is outmoded.

title: White House Police Don Dazzling New Uniforms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Presidential police force sheepishly saluted Prime Minister Wilson of Britain today in dazzling new oper ettalike uniforms ordered by President Nixon and designed by a Washington tailor, Jimmie Muscatello, and the Secret Service.

title: CALLEY CHARGES FOUND UNCLEAR
description: FORT PENNING, Ga., Jan. 27 (AP)The Army must spell out whether it will try to prove) that First Lieut. William L. Cal1 ley Jr. personally killed Viet namese civilians ordered others! to do it, or both, a military, judge ruled today.

title: III Tricia Nixon in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP)  President Nixon's daughter Tricia, ill with the flu, went by military plane Saturday to the Presidential home in Key Biscayne, Fla., for an indefi nite stay, the. White House disclosed today.

title: U.S. Is Reported to Have Hired Sihanouk Foes for '67 Missions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  The United States used a Cam bodian sect dedicated to the overthrow of the legitimate government of Cambodia on covert missions into that coun try in 1967, according to testi mony at the trial of a Green Beret captain convicted in 1968 of killing one of the members of the sect.

title: Ancient Tribe Is Upgraded by Recent Findings in Italy
description: PAESTUM, Italy, Jan. 15  When the Lucanians, a tribe of barbarians whom historians have tended to treat as rather pushy hillbillies, took over this busy port city from its Greek founders about 400 B.C., they changed its name from Posei donia to Paestum.

title: Church Grant to Black Clerics Called Separatist by Wilkins
description: Roy Wilkins, executive direc tor of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, charged yesterday that his organization and its case for racial integration had been ignored in a decision by a Massachusetts church body tol grant $1million to a new or ganization of black clergymen.

title: British Dealers Puzzled
description: LONDON, Jan. 27Active purchases by Communist China in world metal markets have contributed to heavy volume and soaring prices on the Lon don metal exchange. But deal ers are divided in their inter pretation of the buying spree.

title: 2 Subway Power Failures Delay RushHour Crowds
description: Thousands of subway riders were delayed last evening be cause of substation power fail ures on the IRT's Broadway Seventh Avenue line and the BMT's Broadway line.

title: Lennen & Newell Sues Ballantine
description: Lennen & Newell, which lost the P. Ballantine account to Grey Advertising last year, is suing the brewery for more than $1.37million charging breach of contract.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on SouthWest Africa. GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 2 Sign for Idiot's Delight
description: Rosemary Harris has been signed to costar with Jack Lemmon in the Center Theater Group production of Idiot's Delight, opening March 17 at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles. The Robert E. Sher wood Pulitzer prize winning play is being produced by Eliot Martin and directed by Garson Kanin.

title: Report Shows U.S. Pays Taxes To Nations Getting Military Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) In a twoyear period, while the United States committed ex tensive sums for the war in Vietnam, South Vietnam col lected $28million to $34mil lion in taxes from the United States Government.

title: AMEX IS REVISING ITS INDEX REPORT
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that starting Feb. 2 its stock price index will be reported in numbers rather than in dollars and cents. It said that the continuity of the system would not be affected.

title: I.B.M. LIFTS DIVIDEND TO $1.20 IN QUARTER
description: Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday raised the quarterly dividend to $1.20 a share, pay able March 10 to holders of record Feb. 11. It was the third cash increase since the stock was split twoforone in May, 1968.

title: None Hurt in Derailment Of Penn Central Train Here
description: Two cars of a Penn Central passenger train bound for Bos ton were derailed last night shortly after leaving Penn Sta tion.

title: SUFFOLK AUTHORIZED TO ACQUIRE AIRPORT
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 27 The Suffolk County Legislature authorized the County Execu tive today to acquire Suffolk Air Force Base and to seek en abling legislation in Albany for the county to set up an agency to run the field.

title: Man With 3d Heart Dies
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan 27 (AP)Gerald Rector, a 44year old former operating engineer, died today in University of Michigan Hospital, 11 days after receiving his third heart.

title: Profit of U.S. Steel Drops 13% for Year
description: Profit of the United States Steel Corporation, the world's biggest steel producer, declined 13 per cent last year, although sales and other revenues were the highest in history, the com pany said yesterday.

title: Knee Trouble Forces Miss Rubin to Retire
description: MIAMI, Jan. 27 (UPI)In a miniskirt Barbara Jo Rub in's legs look just fine, but on a horse her knees give her trouble. Today they forced her into early retirement.

title: Samuels Urges a State Surtax on Corporations
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Howard J. Samuels, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, suggested today that the state impose a surtax simi lar to the one the Federal Government is abandoning, but limit it to corporation profits.

title: Doctors and Lawyers Take Up Problem of Narcotics Victims
description: Citing the epidemic prolif eration of teenage heroin ad dicts here, a subcommittee of the Medical Society of the County of New York last night passed a resolution calling for emergency funds for separate and adequate treatment facili ties for teenage addicts.

title: Nixon and Agnew to Meet With 10 Mayors on Feb. 5
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 (AP)  President Nixon, Vice President Agnew and five Cabinet members will meet here Feb. 5 with a bipartisan group of about 10 Mayors to discuss city problems, Mayor Richard G. Lugar announced to day.

title: Spock Still Cares About Babies, Wishes More Women Did
description: I believe the two sexes are not go ing to get along well to the degree that men become passive and women be come more competitive with men, he said in an interview at his home here. That's what's wrong with unisex, even if it is becoming more fashionable.

title: PRERACE TESTING CALLED ACCURATE
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 27 The executive vice president of the United States Trotting As sociation and the chairman of the department of veterinary medicine at Ohio State Univer sity reported today the virtual infallibility of prerace blood tests conducted at two Ohio harness race tracks in 1969 to the delegates to the 16th annual convention of the Harness Tracks of America.

title: Harlem's Studio Museum Finds a Friend at the Bank
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, which collects art as well as money, is spreading a little of both around this week. It is sponsoring an art show and sale for the benefit of the fledgling Studio Museum, Harlem's only public art fa cility.

title: Steelers Select Bradshaw, Passer, as First Choice in Pro Football Draft
description: Terry Bradshaw, a big, blond quarterback from Lou isiana Polytechnic Institute, was the first of 442 college football players drafted by the 26 National Football League teams yesterday. The Pitts burgh Steelers chose Brad shaw as the twoday draft be gan yesterday morning at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

title: 2 Die as Gas Truck Explodes
description: BLAKELY, Ga., Jan. 27 (UPI) A leaking propane gas truck parked in a garage for repairs exploded today, killing two per sons, injuring six others and temporarily cutting longdis tance telephone lines. Fire touched off by the blast spread to two buildings. Firemen brought the blaze under con trol in two hours. The dead were identified as James Her man Clark, 58 years aid, and Thomas Edward Deal, 36.

title: FLORIDA ST. WINS IN 89TO83 UPSET
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP)  Florida State's defense tied up the 7foot2inch Artis Gilmore when it counted to night and the Seminoles upset Jacksonville, 8983

title: Boston U. Hockey Victor
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27John Danby scored three goals as Boston University defeated Boston College, 83, tonight at Boston Arena.

title: Auto Races on Ice Called Safer Than Commuting on Parkways
description: EVERY morning during the la icy spells the parkways and expressways are clut tered with cars that have skidded into other cars, light poles and retaining walls. No fun there. But there are any number of cheerful maniacs who enjoy driving on ice indeed, racing on ice. The fact is that ice racing About is safer than parkway com Motor muting. For one Sports thing, cars run solo against the clock; for another, the lake is cleared so that there is a minimum of hard objects to strike while skidding. Motor clubs that refuse to hiber nate when rallying slows down are filling in their win ters with occasional ice events. And unlike rallies, ice races provide a good show for spectators.

title: PROF. DJAPARIDZE OF PRINCETON DIES
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 27 Dr. David Djaparidze a special ist in Slavic philology, and a member of the Princeponpiphi versity faculty since 1960, died today in his New York City home, 340 Riverside Drive.

title: Film Code Ratings Revised to Include, Age and Label Shifts
description: Minor revisions have been made in the fourlabel movie rating system for audience suit ability initiated by the Motion Picture Association of America on Nov. 1, 1968. Announcement of the changes was made yes terday by Jack Valenti, associa tion president, in behalf of the M.P.A.A. and the other sponsors of the evaluation program, the National Association of Theater Owners and the International Film Importers and Distributors of America.

title: Agreement to End G.E. Strike Pressed by Federal Mediators
description: The General Electric Com pany and its striking unions were reported yesterday to be close to an agreement that could end the 93dayold strike.

title: RUDEL IS SELECTED FOR MAY FESTIVAL
description: Julius Rudel has been en gaged as music director of the Cincinnati May Festival Asso ciation for the festivals of 1971 and 1972. He succeeds Max Rudolf, who has resigned as music director of the Cincinnati Symphony and the Festival As sociation to become head of the opera department of the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia. Thomas Schippers will be the new music director of the Cincinnati Sym phony.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW FIRM TONE
Spring Bridal for Marie Einhorn
description: YONKERS, Jan. 27Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Einhorn have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Marie K. Einhorn, to Frank M. Werner. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules H. Werner of Malverne, L. I. A wedding in the spring is Planned.

title: University Aide Arrested
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 27 William E. Conley, special as sistant on minority affairs at Ohio State University, surren dered to the Columbus police this morning on a charge of re ceiving and concealing stolen property. Mr. Conley, a Negro, was released on a recognizance bond in the afternoon. Detec tives say they found $800 worth of stolen stereo equip ment and a stolen camera in his home.

title: 15 Football Stars Picked To Tour U.S. Military Bases
description: Four men who competed in a recent National and Ameri can Football League champion ship series are among 15 play ers named yesterday to tour United States military bases, hospitals and outposts in the far east, including the war zones of South Vietnam.

title: Contempt of Court
description: Until this week American labor had never opposed a Supreme Court nominee on any basis other than his labor record. When the old American Federation Labor mounted a successful campaign against Presi dent Hoover's designation of Judge John J. Parker forty years ago, its objection to confirmation stemmed from the judge's decisions in cases involving unions. That was also the spur when George Meany testified last year against President Nixon's nomination of Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr.

title: Charter Airline Requests C.A.B. to Dismiss Petition
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 27 (AP) Overseas National Airways asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to dismiss a peti tion for an enforcement action filed against it by the board's enforcement bureau last Friday.

title: Chicago Police Aide Says Ohio Professor Hit Him
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP)A high police official testified to day that a Cleveland professor hit him and threw a traffic bar rier toward a sergeant in street disorders the week of the Democratic National Conven tion in 1968.

title: Handling of Student Rioters Displeases Marcos
description: MANILA, Jan. 27President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who nar rowly escaped injury in last night's riot outside Congress, summoned the chiefs of police and the metropolitan military command to a meeting at the presidential palace this after noon. He expressed displeasure with police handling of the stu dents in the riot and directed the Police Commissioner to pre pare guidelines for preventing violence at future demonstra tions.

title: Thomas Darcey Becomes Fiance Of Susan Emery
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. A. Hamilton Emery 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Emery, to Thomas Francis Darcey of Washington, D. C. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. S. R. Darcey of Bethesda, Md., and Burnt Cabins, Pa.

title: LAKERS TURN BACK ROCKETS BY 124109
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (AP) The surging Los Angeles Lakers, behind Jerry West's 41 points and 13 assists, routed the San Diego Rockets, 124109, tonight in a National Basket ball Association game.

title: Schisgal Comedy to Open
description: Murray Schisgal's new com edy, The Chinese and Dr. Fish, will make its Broadway debut March 10 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. The Front Page, currently at the Barry more, will be transferred to the Longacre Theater on March 3. Paul Ford will replace Jules Munshin in the Ben Hecht Charles MacArthur newspaper play on Feb. 3.

title: Carswell Denies He Tried To Balk Club's Integration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  Judge G. Harrold Carswell de nied today allegations that his participation in the formation of a private golf club in Talla hassee in 1956 was part of an effort to prevent desegregation of the municipal facilities that the private club took over.

title: EXTENSION ASKED FOR REGISTRATION
description: A twoweek extension in the voter registration period for the city's local school board electionsa period now sched uled to end Saturday  was recommended to Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE grind of magazine and newspaper journalism takes its toll on the sensi tive observer. Renata Adlerwho came to the profession by the unlikely route of Bryn Mawr, the Sorbonne and Har vardwould be the first to say so. Indeed, she does say so in the valedictory, bitter sweet essays that serve as introductions to

title: 2 VICTIMS IN SNIPING HOLDING THEIR OWN
description: The two New York City pa trolmen wounded by sniper fire in Harlem on Sunday night were reported to have made some improvement yesterday after surgery.

title: Sports of The Times
description: FOR more than half of his 37year tenure as director of the Millrose Games, the always enthusiastic Fred Schmertz has dreamed of producing a Wanamaker Mile with a clocking under four minutes. Less prestigious indoor meets than his own have had such miles, but Schmertz never lost his optimism or his patience. As another glamorous Millrose offering gets ready to move into Madison Square Garden on Friday, Fearless Fred is getting uneasy because time is running out on him. He is 81 years old.

title: Von Braun to Go to Washington To Direct Space Mission Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Dr. Wernher von Braun, a key fig ure in developing the giant Sat urn 5 rocket, which sent men to the moon, will head the United States' planning effort for fu ture space exploration.

title: New Seattle Group Is Offered Chance to Buy Pilots for $9Million
description: Another chance to keep the Pilots in Seattle for the 1970 baseball season and beyond was put forth by the American League late last night at Berk Jey, Calif., where owners of the league's 12 clubs kept wrestling with the problem.

title: Styron Charges Black Pressure on Turner Film
description: William Styron, author of the 1967 Pulitzer Prize novel, The Confessions of Nat Turner, yesterday charged that the filming of the book, which has been temporarily postponed, was being influ enced by black pressure groups who opposed his treatment of the historic leader of a slave rebellion.

title: Popularity of Franchising Has Led to Increased Fraud, Business Bureau Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  The proliferation and popularity of franchise businesses have led to increased fraudulent prac tices in the field, a Senate sub comittee was told today.

title: Executive Changes
description: Francis H. Schott has been elected vice president and economist for the Equitable Life Assurance So ciety of the U. S. He succeeds Reynolds J. Nowell who has retired.

title: Assembly Races Under Way in Bronx and Queens
description: Democrats and Republicans have named candidates for the special election Feb. 17 to fill two vacant Assembly seats one in Queens and the other in the Bronxbut the Liberal party is refusing to participate in either.

title: AN ANTIWAR VOTE ASKED IN ASSEMBLY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Hoping for a lively debate, if not ap proval, 26 Assembly Democrats introduced a resolution today urging immediate withdrawal from Vietnam by United States troops.

title: JURY ON DE CARLO GETS CASE TODAY
description: NEWARK, Jan. 27Both pros ecution and defense lawyers summed up today in Federal Court in the case of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, reputed Mafia figure, and Daniel (Red) Cecere, who are on trial on conpiracy and extortion charges.

title: Railroad's Net Off
description: Earnings of the Southern Rail way slipped in the fourth quar ter of last year to $12.5million, or $1.73 a share, from the $14.4million, or $2.03 a share, of the same period of 1968.

title: Picketing at Northeastern U.
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27About 200 Northeastern University stu dents picketed peacefully for two hours this morning against recruiting on campus by Gen eral Electric and in support of G.E. strikers.

title: Giants Pick Files, a Linebacker
description: Jim Files is still 26 credits short of a marketing degree at Oklahoma but he is about to venture into the market place anyway. His first proj ect is to promote a bonus for a 6foot4inch, 235pound linebacker named Jim Files.

title: G.M. AND CHRYSLER CUT BACK OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27  The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation announced today major cut backs in automobile production for February.

title: Democratic Coalition Plans To Interview Candidates
description: The New Democratic Coali tion has slated 10 regional meetings across the state to hear candidates seeking Demo cratic nominations for state wide office this year.

title: Bridge:
description: Omar Sharif's Circus of Eu ropean stars and the Dal las Aces, the designated rep resentatives of the United States in the 1970 world championship, resumed play in Los Angeles last night with the Aces holding a slender advantage.

title: Ocean Container Industry Is Told to Clean House
description: The ocean container shipping industry was urged yesterday by one of its leaders to put its own house in order.

title: HICKS JOINS JETS; GIANTS GET SHAY
description: The professional football draft, a grab bag of potential talent, is usually accompanied by brisk trading.

title: Eddie Cantor Daughters Shepherding a Musical
description: Two of Eddie Cantor's daughters will figure prom inently in an Off Broadway musical, Lyle, opening March 4 at the new McAlpin Rooftop Theater in the Mc Alpin Hotel.

title: Lion in L.I. Bar Shows He Is a Nipper at Heart
description: MERRICK, L.I. Jan. 27 (UPI) A 20yearold animal trainer was arrested early today when his male lion cub bit two patrons at a Long Island bar.

title: Du Pont Shows Decline for Quarter and Year Monsanto in Dip
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., reported yesterday lower quarterly and 12month earnings despite record sales in 1969. The company attributed the earnings decline to higher costs, lower selling prices, par ticularly in textile fibers, and the cooling off of the country's economy.

title: Tests Indicate TV Program Improves Children's Skills
description: Sesame Streeta brisk, ribtickling television program that is designed to improve the the language, numerical and reasoning skills of preschool children, particularly those fro poor familiesappears to be achieving many of its goals.

title: Plumbers' Union Signs Accord To Assist Negro Apprentices
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The United Association of Plumbers and Pipefitters agreed today to place 500 minority members in line for highpaying journeymen jobs in areas where there is a labor shortage.

title: Border Curbs Continue
description: BERLIN, Jan. 27The East Germans intensified their par tial blockage of access to West Berlin today, but Western offi cials said they expected an early easing of the border trou ble as members of the West German Parliament wound up their fourday series of party and committee meetings in West Berlin.

title: Washington: For the Record
COMMERCE AGENCY SEES A SLOWDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Commerce Department, in a special economic forecast of its ownwhich may or may not prove different from the Nixon Administration's  pre dicted today that the year 1970 will not be a comfortable one.

title: MUSICUS IS NAMED CITY AGENCY HEAD
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of Milton Musicus, a career civil servant and currently head of the state's billiondollar health services improvement plan, as Administrator of Municipal Service.

title: Advertising: Agency Sets Sliding Fee Scale
description: Having added some new people to the staff, the Al Paul Lefton Company of Philadelphia and New York is going out for new busi ness armed with a bold idea. The company is ready to refund up to 20 per cent of its income to a client if agreedupon sales goals of a campaign are not reached.

title: In Memoriam
description: BECKERLillian D. Jan. 28, 1968. A, de voted sister is remembered by her family. KAMERMANAugusta B. Departed Jan. 28, 1968. Beautiful memories remain a precious possession everlastingly cherished by all who know her. ABE.

title: Tractor Driver Drowned
description: A heavy duty equipment op erator for the Department of Corrections drowned off Rikers Island Yvesterday when the tractor he was driving him an we patch and ran into the East Humphrey MacDonald. 38 year old of ??10 14th Road, ?? Queens.

title: Alioto Wins a Procedural Victory in Libel Suit Against Look
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 Mayor Joseph L. Alioto won an important procedural vic tory today in his $12.5million libel suit against Look maga zine, which said in an article published last September that the Mayor was enmeshed in a web of alliances with at least six leaden of la Cosa Nostra.

title: Japan Flies Siberian Route
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (UPI) A Japan Air Lines jet arrived in Moscow today, opening a new transSiberian air route be tween Europe and Toyko. The DC8 arrived at Moscow's Sheremetyevo Airport at 1:40 P.M., 25 minutes behind its estimated time of arrival after the 4,981mile flight.

title: Washington : The Power of the Presidency and Television
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  President Nixon has clearly decided to use the power of the Presidency, plus the power of network television, to com bat his opponents in the Demo crat  controlled Congress and presumably to establish a Re publican Congress in November.

title: South Carolina Governor To Obey Court on Schools
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., Jan. 27Gov. Robert E. McNair, contrasting sharply with other Governors from the Deep South, said today that he would comply with court orders to desegregate schools.

title: ROGER FIRESTONE OF TIRE COMPANY
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 Roger S. Firestone, fifth son of the founder of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, died last night after collapsing at his home in nearby Bryn Mawr. He was 57 years old. The cause, of death was acute lung con gestion.

title: New School Honors German
description: The West German consul gen eral in New York, Klaus Curtius, received yesterday an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from the New School for Social Re search, once a haven for schol ars persecuted by the Nazis. The school had previously hon ored former West German President Theodor Heuss and Chancellor Willy Brandt. Dur ing his six years of service here, Mr. Curtius helped estab lish the Heuss chair at the New School's graduate faculty of political science and social sci ence.

title: NIXON LINKS VETO OF EDUCATION BILL TO HIGH SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Nixon renewed today his case against the $19.7bil lion health, education and anti poverty appropriations bill, cit ing fresh economic statistics to bolster his arguments and offer ing a possible compromise.

title: INFORMER AIDING IN YABLONSKI CASE
description: CLEVELAND, Jan, 27The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been aided by a fourth man who backed out of a re ported murder contract in its investigation of the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter, a source close to the case said today.

title: Article 1  No Title
U.S. IS SAID TO GIVE ARABS ASSURANCE ON MIDEAST PLANS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27The United States has as sured Arab governments that President Nixon's message to American Jewish leaders Sun day did not in any way invali date the American proposals for a Middle Eastern settlement that had been advanced during recent Big Four and Big Two talks, diplomatic sources here said today.

title: Formal Courses Dropped In Experiment at M.I.T.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 27When a colony of large Norway rats invaded his neighborhood in Arlington, Va., a couple of summers ago, Larry Whitehead and his buddies rooted the rats out of their burrows with sticks, BB guns and smoke.

title: Paterno of Penn State Is Honored Again by Writers
description: Joe Paterno of Penn State received the New York Foot ball Writers Association coachoftheyear award yes terday for the second straight time in ceremonies at the New York University Club.

title: U.S. Rabbinical Body Decries Israeli Rule About Who Is a Jew
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 27 The largest Orthodox rab binic body in the United States condemned today the decision of Israel's highest court last week that persons who were nonJews under Jewish reli gious law could be registered as Jews by nationality.

title: lovine, $100,000aYear Reinsman, Can't Get Drives
description: WESTBURY, L. L, Jan. 27 Pat Iovine was not at Roosevelt Raceway this morning. Nor was he there tonight. In fact, the handsome, mustached horseman from Franklin Square, L. I., who, from 1954 through 1969 trained and drove trotters and pacers here, at Yonkers, Monticello, Freehold and oth er raceways, no longer is connected with the sport from which he used to earn up to $100,000 a year.

title: Lindsay Told of Pot Problem On Visit to a Home in Canarsie
description: Sig Rosner pointed to his 17 yearold daughter, Hela, who was sitting on the floor of the crowded living room of his Ca narsie home, and asked her in front of Mayor Lindsay and 50 civic leaders:

title: 20 Years Given Slayer of Stepchild, 3
description: George Poplis, a 41yearold drug addict, was sentenced yes terday to 20 years to life in prison for the fatal beating last March of his 3yearold step daughter, Roxanne Felumero.

title: Elmira G.I. Killed in Vietnam
Some May Be Allowed To Leave the Oronsay
description: VANCOUVER, British Co lumbia, Jan. 27While Cana dian health authorities pur sued eforts to track down the carrier of typhoid aboard the liner Oronsay, plans were being made today to disembark between 20 and 30 American passengers aboard. They want to aban don their delayed cruise on the British liner that has been in quarantine here for 14 days.

title: Music: DoubleBill of English Operas
description: IT was Thomas Scherman's idea to present two English oneact operas closely asso ciated in time and place, and so last night in Philharmonic Hall he and his Little Orches tra Society put on Ralph Vaughan Williams's Riders to the Sea and Gustav Holst's At the Boar's Head.

title: PRICES OFF AGAIN IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices ended mostly lower in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: China Stockpiling Strategic Materials
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 27The Chinese Communist authorities have launched a new austerity drive in the country in con junction with programs for stockpiling food and strategic materials and developing re gional selfsufficiency.

title: ADDITIVE IS FOUND OF GENETIC IMPORT
description: A New York University chem ist has found that a common air pollutant and food additive is capable of changing the chemicals that comprise heredi tary material.

title: DURYEA PROPOSES NARCOTICS CURB
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Warning that 250 children between the ages of 14 and 16 years old might die this year from the use of heroin or other drugs, Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea said today he would propose a special program of treatment for teenage addicts.

title: S.E.C. Commissioner Says Rate Decision Is Due Later
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 22 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission will not have a de cision ready on Whether to re vise the structure for minimum stock brokerage rates for sev eral more months, Commissioner James J. Needham said today.

title: National Orchestral Association Plays 2 Nonrepertory Novelties
description: As a training orchestra, the National Orchestral Association is not expected to spend its time learning nonrepertory pieces, but at least once a sea son it tackles a novelty. Last night in Carnegie Hall it tackled two, in one of the more interesting programs of its sea son.

title: The Screen: Ake Falck's 'A Time in the Sun' Opens:Young Bride's Illness Reversed by Love
description: AT the very first, as the credits come on, it looks like a kind of micro-cinematography. Somewhat later, atter we know the characters, it devotes such close attention to fragments of human anatomy that it seems at times to be recalling those "geography of the body" movies that in provincial film societies used to substitute for art (and sex).But much later, after the hero and heroine have married and settled down to her pregnancy, the area of vision has widened to include rarely less than a bed, a body, or a corner of a cozy apartment. And it becomes apparent that Ake Falck's "A Time in the Sun," which opened yesterday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, has a visual program, a pleasant one, to match its decently sentimental story.The story concerns a handsome, successful young writer who meets a lovely young nurse who is dying of Hodgkin's disease. He marries her anyway, and gets her pregnantwhereupon she has both the baby and a complete reversal of the symptoms of her illness. Such a story, though in this case based on fact, pertains more to fantasy than to fiction. The film is wholly aware of its fantastic potential (the writer calls the girl his "princess"), and it is just as aware of each exploitable turn in its tale of suffering and success.As with most women's pictures (a genre I highly admire), there is a fair blend of agony and ecstasy in "A Time in the Sun." But as with most women's pictures, the ecstasy is chiefly agony, and in health as in sickness the heroine has a pretty sloppy time of it.The misery of Hodgkin's disease and the radiation treatments (nausea; uncontrollable itching) is matched by the pain and anxiety of childbirth. The film stays close to both, but it exploits neither. Indeed, it understands the process of physical recovery as being an escape from the body's tyranny.Thus, the kinds of detail Falck chooses to photograph change as the characters' frames of reference change. He is especially good at figuring intimacy in terms of the camera's space (husband and wife virtually lean into the frame during their happy marriage idyl, and that frame closely defines the limits of their world). But he is especially bad at opening his film up, and two such sequences, a dance at the beginning and the new father's outdoor exaltation near the end, almost nullify the stylish discipline of the rest.But "A Time in the Sun" is really interesting only for its female lead. Grynet Molvig, a 28-year-old Norwegian pop singer whom I have not seen before, plays the afflicted girl with such intelligent, restrained, sustained directness that she achieves a performance of unusual excitement, which is totally in the service of her characterization. An attractive, unglamorous blond who looks a little like the late, wonderful Nicole Berger ("Shoot the Piano Player." "Story of a Three Day Pass"), Miss Molvig wholly avoids tricks or easy appeals to sympathyin a role that might have invited both. Her qualities suggest a thoroughly understood humanity, and they make me feel good about the profes-of acting.

title: CITY DISPUTES RONAN OVER SUBWAY CARS
description: A controversy over whether the city should provide 200 or 300 new subway cars for the transit system developed yes terday between the Metropoli tan Transportation Authority, and Mayor Lindsay.

title: Arab Press Is Angered By DANA ADAMS SCHMIDT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 27 President Nixon's message to American Jewish leaders on Sunday has raised the ques tion among Arab political lead ers and some Western diplo mats here whether the even handed Middle Eastern policy laid down by Secretary of State William P. Rogers has now been reversed.

title: What Spurs Desertion?
description: No one knows how many thousands of New York families have been broken up because the husband earned so little that he decided his wife and children would be better off on welfare. The one thing experts do agree on is that the number is large. They also agree that New York's experience is not unique. Every other large city has seen its welfare rolls grow through what is wryly called fiscal abandonment.

title: 1,000 Federal Vehicles To Use Natural  GasFuel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 More than 1,000 Federal vehicles will be converted this year to burn natural gas in a system that cuts noxious exhaust emissions by about 80 per cent, Government officials told Con gress today.

title: CLEON JONES'S PAY DOUBLED BY METS
description: The New York Mets con tinued to divide the treasure yesterday. They signed Cleon Jones, the No. 1 batter in their eightyear history, for $50,000 twice what he made last season.

title: MAN WANTED IN U.S. JUMPS BAIL IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 27Israeli police authorities said today that Dick Scott, an American immigrant to Israel who is wanted in California on a drug charge, jumped bail last Thurs day and probably had left the country.

title: YACHTSMEN TAKE DIVERGING VIEWS
description: A major accomplishment of the National Boat Show has been the bringing together of two individuals whose worlds would probably never have crossed so dissimilar are their ideas, their backgrounds and their deeds.

title: New Books Today
description: FICTION

title: Jesse Gray to Enter Primary In Move to Win Powell's Seat
description: Jesse Gray, the Harlem rent Strike leader, announced yester day that he would enter the Democratic primary against Adam Clayton Powell, who has held the seat in Manhattan's 18th Congressional District since 1944.

title: MORE RISES LISTED ON STEEL PRODUCTS
description: Price increases continued to spread yesterday for important categories of steel products.

title: Nigerian Red Cross Says It Is Widening Relief Drive
description: LAGOS, Nigerian Jan. 27 The Nigerian Red Cross said today that it was sending more men and equipment into the former Biafran territory to bring a greater urgency and vigor to the relief effort there.

title: Ametek, Inc., Elects
description: Robert L. Noland, executive vice president and director of Ametek, Inc., has been elected president of that diversified industrial corporation. He suc ceeds Dr. John H. Lux, who was elected chairman of the board, while continuing as chief executive officer.

title: C.B.S. Says Lagos Held Two
description: Two C.B.S.  TV newsmen, Morley Safer and Gerald Miller, were arrested in Lagos. Nigeria, yesterday and were held for three and onehalf hours, the network reported here. The two men were not told why they had been arrested, the network said, but their passports and ac creditation were taken from them and they were ordered to return to the police today.

title: Japan to Sign Pact Curbing the Spread Of AArms Tuesday
description: TOKYO, Jan. 27The Japanese Government has decided to sign the treaty barring the spread of nuclear weapons next Tuesday, Government sources reported today. The Japanese Ambassa dors in Washington, London and Moscow are to be in structed to sign the treaty on that day.

title: NARCOTICS RAIDS WITHOUT WARNING VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  The Senate approved today a modified no knock statute under which Federal agents could break into a home with out warning or identification if they feared narcotics were about to be destroyed inside.

title: Toy With Smoking Exhaust Draws Store Pickets
description: Opponents of air pollution picketed a department store yesterday to protest a toy plas tic truck, about a foot long, that emits smoke from its ex haust pipe.

title: 700 Phone Workers Protest Suspension of a Union Aide
description: About 700 installers, repair men and plant workers staged a oneday strike yesterday at the New York Telephone Com pany's central exchange build ing, 228 East 56th Street, to protest the suspension of a shop steward. The building serves the midtown area.

title: City Council Votes to Revamp Its Own Committee Structure
description: A new committee structure more closely attuned to the organization of the city admin istration was approved yester day for the City Council.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: 3 ARAB LANDS SAID TO OPPRESS JEWS
description: PARIS, Jan. 27  Delegates from 26 countries appealed to world opinion today to save the handful of Jews remaining in Iraq, Syria and the United Arab Republic.

title: DEMOCRATS OFFER L.I.R.R. FARE PLAN
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Demo cratic legislative leaders said today that they hopedwith the aid of Nassau County Re publicansto hold Long Island Rail Road Fares at current lev els and eliminate double fares on New York City's transit sys tem.

title: ART WORKS GIVEN TO SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 A collection of 19th and 20th (century art objects to be housed in the M. H. de Young memorial museum here has been presented to this city by Tullah Hanley, a Hungarian born former dancer whose hus band, the late Thomas Edward Hanley, was a Pennsylvania oil and gas heir.

title: Bombing Suspect's Motion Denied by Federal Judge
description: A Federal judge denied a mo tion yesterday by Jane L. Al pert, one of three persons fac ing trial on charges of bomb ing office buildings here last year, to suppress as evidence package of tear gas cart ridges, a box of bullets and three passports seized in her apartment last Nov 14.

title: People of Lesotho Vote In First General Election
description: MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 27 Pony trains stood by tonight to deliver the vote in Lesotho's first general election since independence from Britain in 1966.

title: TASMINEX NICKEL UP ON REPORTS OF FIND
description: LONDON, Jan. 27Frenzied buying broke out today on the London Stock Exchange as un confirmed reports quickly spread of another huge West Australian nickel strike.

title: Motel Trial Jury Chosen
description: FLINT, Mich., Jan. 27An allwhite jury of seven women and five men has been chosen for the trial of three suspended policemen and a private guard involved in the Algiers Motel incident in the 1967 Detroit racial riot. Selection of the jury was completed this afternoon in the Federal District Court here. The defendants are ac cused of conspiracy to violate the rights of 10 persons in the Detroit motel.

title: MRS. STEPHEN WEISS, ACTIVE IN CHARITIES
description: Mrs. Suzanne Lipskin Weiss, an active horsewoman and joint district commissioner with Whitelaw Reid of the Pur chase Pony Club, died while sleeping Monday afternoon at her home in Purchase, N.Y. She was 34 years old. The cause of death was not known.

title: Congressmen Clash With Minnesota Governor Over Limits on Atomic Waste
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  Gov. Harold LeVander of Min nesota and two members of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy clashed today over Minnesota's asserted, but not established, rights to set more rigid limits on radio active discharges from nuclear power plants than the Atomic Energy Commission requires.

title: 8Part N. E. T. Series Will Look at Generation Gap
description: National Educational Televi sion will launch an eightpart cycle of dramas next month, abut a generation questioning its legacy.

title: SURPRISES SPARK NEW COMPOSITIONS
description: The program at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum last night, entitled An Evening of New Music from the University of Connecticut, featured resi dent musicians and composers of the school and offered a couple of lively and welcome surprises, along with long stretches of dry scholasticism.

title: Distinctive Captures Second in Row at Hialeah and Pays $3.20
description: MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP)Her bert Allen's Distinctive, unable to win a race last year, scored his second straight victory of 1970 at Hialeah Park today as he outran Outspan, a 21to1 shot, to win by 1 lengths. Outspan was 1 lengths in front of Spiral Staircase. In his previous start here, Distinctive won by 13 lengths.

title: HungerPanelAsks$246,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, has asked for a $246,000 budget for his Select Committee on Nutri tion and Human Needs during the next year. Senator McGov ern's request came in a resolu tion sent to the Senate Rules Committee.

title: Y.W. C.A. Courting Change During Its Centennial Year
description: The cooking classes have shifted from petitfours to casseroles and the sewing lessons have abandoned the tucks and folds of the bustle for the mini, but in 100 years the Young Women's Chris tian Association has never changed as much as it is try ing to do today.

title: '68 YIPPIE PLANS STUNNED MAILER
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 27Wow! said Norman Mailer when he first heard the Yippie strategy for the 1968 Democratic Nation al Convention here.

title: For Ricci, the Midi Look Is a Look for Success
description: PARIS, Jan. 27So many women are grinding their teeth over the new, longer hems in the springsummer couture collections here that you hear the critics carrying on everywhere.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JAN. ??

title: LACY KUX, PARTNER IN BROKERAGE FIRM
description: Lacy Kux, a limited partner of the New York Stock Ex change firm of Hirsch & Co., died of a heart attack Monday at his home, 54 Washington Mews. He was 73 years old.

title: Pacers Defeat Bucs, 8887, On Keller's 2 Free Throws
description: INDIANAPOLIS. Jan. 27 (UPI) Bill Keller's two tree throws with 8 seconds to play gave the Indiana Pacers an 8887 American Basketball Associa tion victory over the New Or leans Bucs tonight.

title: British Soccer
description: ENGLISH CUP FourthRound Replays Burnley 1, Chelsea 3. Northampton 2, Tranmere 1. ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: But Revenues Gain
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany of New York, Inc., showed a decline in net income for 1969 despite the fact that op erating revenues topped the $1 billion level for the first time in any calendar year. The giant utility first reported $1billion or more in revenues for the 12 months ended last June 30.

title: Scott Names 6 Floor Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The Senate minority floor leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsyl vania, named six assistant mi nority whips today, one for each region of the nation, to help the Republican floor leaders. The new regional whips are Edward W. Brooke of Massa chusetts, Charles H. Percy of Illinois, Edward J. Gurney of Florida, Jack Miller of Iowa, Clifford P. Hansen of Wyoming and Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon.

title: Jersey S. C . I . Orders 3 to Begin Jail Terms for Silence at Inquiry
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Three reputed Cosa Nostra fig ures who were sentenced to jail until they answered the State Commision of Investiga tion's questions were ordered by the Commission today to begin serving their sentences.

title: BUDGET COMMISSION ELECTS 7 TRUSTEES
description: The Citizens Budget Com mission elected seven mem bers to its board of trustees yesterday.

title: Auto Industry Blues
description: Since last summer a leading economist, a monetarist, has been forecasting a recession this year. Recently he addressed a Detroit civic group. It is good to speak to a body of believers, he be gan. Latterday Economic medievalists may Analysis debate whether the gross nation al product after adjustment for price increases declined or merely stood still in the final quarter of last year. The number showed a slight decline, but it will almost certainly be revised.

title: Venture for Bohack Set With Ferkauf
description: The Bohack Corporation, a New York supermarket chain, announced yesterday a two way corporate move involving an investment of $1million by Eugene Ferkauf, founder of the Korvette discount stores and the purchase by Bohack of a chain of small discount stores in which Mr. Ferkauf has a substantial interest.

title: Miss Elaine Wilson, Teacher, Is Affianced
description: BETHPAGE, L. I. Jan. 27  Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wil son have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Marie Wilson, to Kevin M. McNamee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Mc Namee. Both families live here.

title: Thieu Weighs Tet Truce
description: SAIGON, Wednesday, Jan. 28 (AP)  President Nguyen Van Theiu is planning to order a ceasefire for the Tet lunar new year but has not decided the length or timing, a Govern ment spokesman said today.

title: Nixon Commends Patrolman on Fight To Wear Flag Pin
description: Patrolman Patrick Dolan has received a letter of congratula tions from President Nixon for his successful fight to continue wearing an American flag pin on his police uniform, just above his row of five citations for heroism.

title: Records Achieved
Anna Louise Strong to End Her Newsletter From China
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 27 (Reu ters)  Anna Louise Strong, the American author who has lived in China for almost 12 years, says she will soon stop putting out her Peking news letter because she is 84 and the writing grows ever harder.

title: Superagency Chief
