description: I STILL occasionally wear white shirts, Milton Musicus said yesterday. I see from looking around City Hall I better start changing the color of my shirts and widening my ties unless I still want to maintain the aura of Albany.

title: Abortion Hearing Gets View of 8 Catholic Doctors
description: The director of gynecology and obstetrics at Georgetown University Hospital told a Fed eral Court hearing yesterday that an abortion, other than to save a mother's life, was poor biology and poor science.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Daniel Lowenstein To Wed Miss Yagi
description: WATSONVILLE, Calif., Jan. 27Miss Sharon Sachi lco Yagi, a social worker with the Stanislaus County Wel fare Department in Modesto, and Daniel Hays Lowenstein, a lawyer for California Rural Legal Assistance in the Mo desto office, will be married Feb. 14 in Watsonville.

title: Nixon and Wilson Discuss Major Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27In what has become an almost an nual rite of BritishAmerican friendship, Prime Minister Wil son arrived here amid pomp and ceremony for a round of talks with President Nixon and other senior United States offi cials.

title: Senator Ford, Radio Comedian, Dies
description: GREENPORT, L. I., Jan. 27 Senator Ford, the vaudeville comedian who starred on the Can You Top This? radio program in the 1940's, died of cancer of the lung and throat at the Eastern Long Island Hos pital here tonight. He was 82.

title: U.S. COURT IS ASKED TO RULE ON FLAG USE
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn said yesterday he would seek the convening of a threejudge constitutional court to rule on the use of peace symbols in conjunction with the American Flag.

title: Haggis for Scots' Fling To Come From Queens
description: The American  Scottish Foundation won't dine on real Scottish haggis after all the Department of Agricul ture turned it back.

title: Mrs. Jones Advances
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 27The Wimbledon cham pion, Mrs. Ann Jones of Britain, defeated the New Zealander, Cecilie Fleming, 62, 61, in the first round of the Benson and Hedges open tennis tournament today.

title: EXJUDGE ACCUSED IN PERJURY TRIAL
description: Former Criminal Court Judge Benjamin H. Schor set a $3,500 price tag on obtaining a liquor license for a Queens tavern, a witness testified at his trial on a perjury charge.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) The Pentagon announced to day the names of 19 American servicemen killed in Vietnam. The list included Specialist 4 Nathaniel Thomas, of the Army, of Elmira, N. Y.

title: Gypsies in Britain Win Fight for Camping Sites
description: LONDON, Jan. 27Gypsies won their long fight today for the right to official sites on which to station their caravans.

title: SERVICE REDUCED IN HEALTH CENTER
description: The Gouverneur health center, target of increasing demands for community control by Low er East Side residents, operated under heavy police guard yes terday after another in a series of disturbances there.

title: Sales at Homes on Credit Show a Rise
description: Companies that sell mer chandise doortodoor had a good year in 1969 and are an ticipating even better busi ness in 1970, despite the cur rent economic slowdown.

title: Ousted Pentagon Aide Hired To Expose Defense Waste
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)  A. Ernest Fitzgerald, the Pentagon efficiency expert who lost his job after telling Congress about pyramiding costs of the C5A cargo jet, was hired today by a business man's organization to crusade against wasteful military spend ing.

title: People
description: William T. Brooks and Daniel H. Dolgins elected senior vice presidents of Cunning ham & Walsh, Inc.

title: Schuman Now Basking in Total Sunshine
description: William Howard Schuman, looking too contented to be confused with Napoleon on Elba or Lyndon Johnson on the LBJ Ranch, sounded a bit smug about his new life.

title: New Hearings Sought
description: Donald S. Sherwood, a Long Island Rail Road commuter from Freeport, L. I., filed suit yesterday in an effort to force further hearings on a proposed Long Island Rail Road fare in crease.

title: 2 TV MAKERS ACT ON FIRE HAZARDS
description: The R.C.A. Corporation and the Magnavox Company, two of the major television set makers accused of making color models with extraordinary fire hazards, took measures yes terday to correct such prob lems.

title: Veto on Education
description: President Nixon's dramatic attempt on television to justify his veto of the health, education, welfare and labor appropriations bill failed to make a per suasive case. His oversimplified political appeal Served only to obscure the situation with broad gen eralities.

title: George Spencer Berger to Wed Miss Robin Rosborough May 9
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 27  Mr. and Mrs. Corwith Davis have announced the engagement of Mrs. Davis's daughter, Miss Robin Ros borough, to George Spencer Berger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer M. Berger of Guilford, Conn. The prospec tive bride is the daughter also of the late Angus Baker Rosborough, who was Florida general agent for the Massa chusetts Mutual Life Insur ance Company.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: President's Message

title: Market Place.
description: JOHN M. HARTWELL, whose mutual funds took a beating with the rest of the performance funds in the 1969 bear market, is about to reverse himself again.

title: Garden Seeking a Cerdanfiaduano Bout
description: The boxing promoters at Madison Square Garden have begun negotiations to import Marcel Cerdan Jr., the son of the middleweight champion who died in an Azores plane crash in 1949, from France for a welterweight bout in May with Donato Paduano of Montreal.

title: Two Oil Strikes Reported
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 27 (UPI) The Apache Corporation an nounced today two apparent new oil discoveries in the Hi light field in Campbell County, Wyoming. If they bear out initial expectations, Apache will have brought in four suc cessful wells in the Hilight field within a year. One of the Jatest wells drilled flowed at 698 barrels a day and the other at 330 barrels a day in early tests.

title: BUS SERVICE TO OPEN FOR LINCOLN CENTER
description: Lincoln Center for the Per forming Arts has announced the establishment of a new bus service to the upper East and West Sides of Manhattan for the convenience of patrons go ing home after evening per formances at Lincoln Center. The service, which will begin Tuesday and will replace the bus service currently sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera, will operate seven nights a week through June 27.

title: N.B.C. Will Create Programs For Idaho Schools' Television
description: In what could set a precedent for commercial television broadcasters, the National Broadcasting Company an nounced yesterday that it had contracted with the state of Idaho to design, construct and operate an educational tele vision production center. It will be located in Boise, the capital.

title: NEGROES TRAINED FOR SCIENCE LAB
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 27Through a manyfaceted program to in volve the black community in construction and operation of the world's largest atom smash er, leaders of the project believe they are demonstrating that an enterprise devoted to basic re search can also serve as a social force.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS CONTINUE TO SLIDE
description: Stock prices continued to slide yesterday, again carrying leading market indicators to their lowest levels since Octo ber, 1966, when the bear mar ket of 1966 bottomed out.

title: U.S. Bill Rates Register a Drop At Treasury's Monthly Auction,
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last, month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: HOUSING AIDE LEFT IN MIDST OF CRISIS
description: The city housing official most directly responsible for carry ing out Mayor Lindsay's emer gency procedures to restore heat to freezing apartments quit his post quietly the day after the Mayor declared the state of emergency.

title: Cole Porter Revisited
description: Cole Porter's musical You Never Know will be given for two performances under the sponsorship of the Stage Di rectors and Choreographers Workshop Foundation on Feb. 16 and 17 at the auditorium of the Library and Museum of Lincoln Center for the Perform ing Arts.

title: An Informal Innovator BY ALDEN WHITMAN
description: Once in the 1920's Dr. Lewis Perry picked up three hitch hikers on his way from Exeter to Boston and the riders took turns guessing his occupation. One thought him a traveling salesman, the second suggested he was a veterinarian and the third pronounced him a boot legger because your car is big you're alone and you seem to know a good many people along the road.

title: House Votes $1.8Billion Foreign Aid Appropriation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The House of Representatives approved a $1.8billion foreign aid appropriation today with out debate and sent the meas ure to the Senate for final legislative action, which is ex pected tomorrow.

title: COSTA RICA IMPOSES ELECTION RALLY BAN
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 27The National Electoral Tri bunal banned all further politi cal rallies in this national capi tal today, to avoid violence before next Sunday's national elections.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: New U.S. Pullback From South Vietnam Is Beginning Today
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (AP)The withdrawal of 50,000 more American troops will begin tomorrow with 3,000 marines from 19 units leaving over a fiveday period, the, United States Command an nounced today.

title: YARBOROUGH SEEKS 3D TERN IN SENATE
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 27Sen ator Ralph W. Yarborough, Democrat of Texas, announced for reelection today. He pledged that, before doing any cam paigning, he would do what he could to get Congress to over ride President Nixon's veto of the health and education ap propriation bill.

title: Jets Get NamathFan Cornerback
description: In selecting Steve Tannen of Florida in the first round of the draft yesterday, the Jets acquired a guitarplay ing, clothesconscious cor nerback who loves the idea of playing in New York with Joe Namath.

title: Soviet Calls for the Acceptance Of Its Mideast Peace Formula
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 27The So viet Union today urged accept ance of its Middle East peace proposals to prevent what it de scribed as a new and possibly more dangerous war from breaking out between the Is raelis and the Arabs.

title: 7th Avenue's Flip View of Summer Fashions
description: SOMEBODY'S got to take her dancing when she looks like thisor else she can milk the cows. Torn Nasarre, the designer for Junior Sophisticates, was talking about the mannequin in the short, bouncy blue plaid dress with the white lace apron and the kerchief on her head.

title: Air Force Removes Insignia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The United States Air Force, reluctantly yielding to Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird and the Government of Nigeria, has removed its insignia from heavy cargo aircraft for a relief airlift to Lagos, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Pan Am to Introduce 747s To San Juan Service Feb. 7
description: Pan American World Air ways will start its second Boe ing 747 route on Feb. 7 with daily flights between Kennedy International Airport and San Juan, P. R., except Tuesdays and Wednesdays.

title: Providence Sextet Beats Army in Overtime by 32
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 27 Army lost to Providence in hockey, 32, today in a sudden death overtime as the cadets could not get a shot on goal in the extra period.

title: 3 Women Die in Derailment of HighSpeed Train Near Alexandria, Va.
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 27 (AP)  A highspeed train rounding a curve just out side Alexandria overturned its last five cars over a steep, muddy embankment early today, killing three women and injuring 41 oth er passengers.

title: Interest Rates Advance; Chrysler Plans Offering
description: Interest rates once again climbed higher yesterday, pushed upward largely by the prospect of still more bonds for sale. The Chrysler Corporation announced plans yesterday to sell $150million of debt securities during the week of March 9. The maturi ty of the securities was not disclosed, and some dealers speculated the offering, like Ford's last week, might in clude both notes and bonds.

title: I.B.M. Executive Named To Head N.Y.U. School
description: William R. Dill, an execu tive of the International Busi ness Machines Corporation, has been appointed dean of New York University's Grad uate School of Business Ad ministration, it was an nounced yesterday.

title: Israeli Air Cargo Is Seized By Swiss as War Materiel
description: GENEVA, Jan. 27The Swiss announced today that a shipment of aircraft parts found aboard an El Al airliner during a stopover in Geneva on Saturday had been seized as war materiel.

title: Dr. Lewis Perry, ExPrincipal Of Phillips Exeter, Dead at 93
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 27 Dr. Lewis Perry, who built Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire into a major prepa ratory school in 32 years as its principal, died here yesterday in a nursing home. He was 93 years old.

title: Theater:Joy Opens Run
description: WHAT a nice drama critic like me was doing at a show like Joy at first mild ly puzzled me. The show, or whatever you want to call it, opened last night at the New Theater. It is only fair to saywho needs to cliffhang? that at last Joy won me over. But not at first.

title: Commerce Agency to Guarantee $82Million Loans for Tankers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  The Commerce Department an nounced today that it would guarantee loans of more than $82million for the two largest tankers in the American flag fleet, to be built by Sea train Lines, Inc., at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Bob Hope Raises $2Million at Gala for the Eisenhower Medical Center
description: President Nixon and for mer Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson and Harry S. Tru man were honorary chairmen in absentia. Tickets were $1,000 each and there were 1,500 guests jammed into the Waldorf  Astoria's ballroom. And in all, Bob Hope's gala for the Eisenhower Medical Center took in more than $2 million, becoming one of the biggest money raisers of this or any other social season.

title: ARGENTINA VISITORS GIVE LIVELY CONCERT
description: A chamber orchestrasized group of lively guests from Ar gentina made its local debut last night at Tully Hall. The En samble Musical de Buenos Aires, formed in 1966, is on the way to becoming a fixture in its home city, and is now ventur ing on its first United States tour.

title: Arbitrators Absolve St. John's Of Teachers' Antiunion Charge
description: St. John's University was cleared by an arbitration panel yesterday of charges of antiunion activity and viola tions of academic freedom in the first decision In a dispute stemming from the dismissal of 33 faculty members in 1965.

title: LatinAmerican Cities Experience a Huge Subway Building Boom
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27  Latin America is experiencing a boom in subway building like ly to cost the nations of the area at least $1billion during the next decade.

title: ASHE HEADS HOME WITH AUSSIE TITLE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 27 (UPI)  Arthur Ashes the first American to capture the Aus tralian tennis championship since 1959, headed for a skiing vacation at Sun Valley, Idaho, today and a well deserved rest.

title: S.E.C. TAKES ACTION IN 2 SEPARATE CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UN) The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended the reg istration statement filed in 1968 by the Scientific Research De velopment Company of Salt Lake City after finding that it contained false statements.

title: Examiner Denies Bid On Broker Bargaining
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27  A National Labor Relations Board examiner denied today a motion by three brokerage firms to dismiss proceedings prompted by a group of rebel stock salesmen, who are seeking to establish a legally constituted bargaining unit.

title: Murphy Is Headed for Dublin And Donnybrook Over Track
description: Frank Murphy, who has an eye for pretty Irish lasses, has never met Bernadette Devlin. But before Murphy departs Dublin later this week, he may wish he had.

title: Text of President's Message to the House Explaining Veto of Appropriations Bill
description: I return herewith, without my approval. H.R. 13111, an act, making appropriations for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare and related agencies for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1970, and for other purposes.

title: Fire Levels 15 Old Buildings
description: SONORA, Calif., Jan. 27 (Reu ters)Fifteen buildings dating from the 1849 Gold Rush were destroyed today in a fire in the center of this town of 3,000 per sons, 135 miles east of San Fran cisco.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN TUMBLE IN PRICE
description: A number of factors com bined yesterday to send grain futures tumbling on the Chica go Board of Trade.

title: Nation's Trade Improved in December
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  The gradual inprovement in the nation's trade position con tinued in December, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: Reserve Chief's 1965 Fight Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The dramatic story of one of the greatest struggles in the long career of William Mc Chesney Martin Jr. as Chair man of the Federal Reserve Board has been placed on the public record a few days be fore Mr. Martin is to retire and be replaced by Arthur F. Burns.

title: CITY BALLET GIVES 1ST DIVERTIMENTO
description: For some reason, perhaps to whet the appetites of its true loyalists, the New York City Ballet saves George Balan chine's lovely Mozart ballet, Divertimento No. 15, for the end of each season.

title: LEE IS DISMISSED AS WARRIOR COACH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 (UPI)The San Francisco War riors dismissed Coach George Lee today and named Al Attles, a guard, as interim player coach for the remainder of the season.

title: Jewish Burial Group Says Gravediggers Foil Help
description: A group calling itself the Emergency Committee for Jew ish Burial appealed yesterday for an immediate end to a strike of gravediggers that began Jan. 12.

title: CHABAN DEFENDS LIBYAN JET DEAL
description: PARIS, Jan. 27  Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas de clared today that the Mirage aircraft sold to Libya had been meant solely to defend that country's territory and that if any of the jets appeared on the ArabIsraeli fighting front, re maining deliveries would be embargoed.

title: Sutton Sees Point of No Return On Commercial Rents in City
description: Sharp differences were ex pressed yesterday over whether the city should regulate com mercial and business rents.

title: Humphrey on WQXR
description: Former Vice President Hu bert H. Humphrey will discuss politics and personalities with Harrison E. Salisbury, assistant managing editor of The New York Times, when he appears at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow on WQXR Radio's Insight series.

title: Oil Companies Report an Irregular Pattern in Their Earnings
description: Of four major oil companies reporting yesterday for 1969, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Gulf Oil Cor poration showed lower earn ings while the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Cit ies Service Company made moderately more money than the year before.

title: COMBUSTION GETS ATOMIC CONTRACT
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., took the lead yesterday in 1970 nuclear powerplant orders with the announcement that the Southern California Edison Company had chosen it to sup ply two 1.1million kilowatt nu clear steam supply Systems.

title: Register for the School Vote!
description: With only four days remaining for voter registra tion for the community school board election, every effort must be made to reverse the appallingly apathet ic showing to date.

title: Court Would Not Oppose Offer in Thalidomide Trial
description: ALSDORF, West Germany, Jan. 27 (AP)  A criminal court today held open the pos sibility of ending the thalido mide trial through a $27.3mil lion settlement out of court.

title: Knicks Trounce Celtics Here, 133100
description: The New York Knicks stepped back two months last night and recaptured for 48 thrilling minutes the nearperfect form that marked their early 18game winning streak that set a Na tional Basketball Association record.

title: TOWBOAT WORKERS TURN DOWN OFFER
description: Negotiations for a new con tract for the port's commercial towboat and barge industry came to a standstill yesterday following union rejection of a management offer.

title: Gambler Refuses to Reply To Newark Jury's Questions
description: NEWARK, Jan. 27  A re puted Mafia gambler invoked the Fifth Amendment today in refusing to answer questions asked by a Federal grand jury investigating organized crime.

title: 6 Alleged Mafiosi Indicted in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 28 Six men allegedly associated with Mafia families were in dicted today by a Nassau Coun ty grand jury investigating or ganized crime, and District At torney William Cahn said that six other men being sought as material witnesses had disap peared.

title: Bonn Is Sending High Officials to Moscow and Warsaw to Speed Negotiations
description: BONN, Jan. 27Foreign Minister Walter Scheel an nounced today that West. Germany was sending State Secretary Egon Bahr, one of its highest officials, to Moscow tomorrow in an attempt to ac celerate negotiations on a pact renouncing the use of force.

title: Extrudo Increases Prices For Its Polyethylene. Film
description: The Extrudo Film Corpora tion, an affiliate of the Enjay Chemical Company, announced yesterday it would raise prices by one to two cents a pound across the board for polyethy lene film, effective Jan. 30.

title: State Department Names Groups to Spur Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  The State Department formed 13 task forces today to re vitalize the diplomatic service and to reassert leadership in the formation of foreign policy, which has become diffused among many departments since World War II.

title: American Women's Ski Squad Looms as Strongest Since 60
description: SIX GIRLS have been named to represent the United States in the Federation Inter nationale de Ski world cham pionships at Val Gardena, Italy, starting on Feb. 7.

title: Providence Five Wins
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 28 Craig Callen's jump shot with eight seconds remaining gave Providence College a 5857 vic tory tonight over St. John's in an overtime contest before a capacity crowd of 3,500.

title: Montclair State Loses
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 28 Montclair State College suf fered its first loss of the season in a New Jersey State Col lege Conference contest tonight is Newark State downed the Indians, 8578.

title: BUCKS SET BACK ROYALS, 126114
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 28 (UPI) Don Smith scored 7 of Mil waukee's first 10 points in the fourth quarter to break open a close National Basketball As sociation game and lead the Bucks to a 126114 victory to night over the Cincinnati Royals.

title: South African Reserves Dip
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 28 (AP)  South Africa's gold reserves dipped $4.6mil lion to $1.07billion, the reserve bank's weekly statement dis closed today. The drop ap parently caused by sales of gold abroad, followed reports from Washington that South Africa has sold gold to the International Monetary Fund.

title: Lindsay Urges Alliances in Congress to Aid Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Mayor Lindsay, who put to gether a new political coalition to win reelection last Novem ber urged House members from New York City today to form new alliances with Con gressmen from other areas to expand Federal programs for the cities.

title: Theater: Schary Drama
Fordham Downs Navy
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md. Jan. 28 (UPI)Charlie Yelverton scored 19 points and John Zanzelari added 16 tonight as Fordham handed Navy its 13th loss in 15 games this season with a 7563 victory.

title: Light of Peace at Diamond Ball to Aid Students
description: No one would say exactly how many there were, but about one out of every 10 men at last night's Diamond Ball at the Plaza was there for reasons totally unrelated to dining, dancing or worthy causes, in this case the In stitute of International Edu cation.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ALLAN COAGE, a 26yearold baker from Queens, is America's top judo player, a threetime national heavyweight champion, and a 1967 PanAmerican Games gold medalist. Outside this country, however, these credentials are not distinguished: Coage has done poorly in worldclass competition, and Japan, for example, is filled with young players who could throw Coage around all day. And so, Coage is preparing to abandon the roll machine at the Pechter Baking Company and spend at least the next two years at Nihon University in Tokyo to learn the game.

title: Australia Names 2 Envoys
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 28 (AP)Sir James Plimsol has been named Australia's Ambas sador to the United States and Sir Laurence McIntyre will be the country's new Permanent Representative at the United Nations, Foreign Minister Wil liam McMahon announced to day.

title: CityOriented Educator
description: Man; in the News

title: 4 FROM U.S. BOW IN NEW ZEALAND
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 28 (AP)  Four American players were ousted today in the Benson and Hedges open tennis tournament.

title: Samuel Soskin, Brooklyn Rabbi Active in Civil Rights, Is Dead
description: Rabbi Samuel D. Soskin, who two decades ago came from Fort Worth, Tex., to become spiritual leader of Temple Beth Emeth of Flatbush died Tues day night at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. His age was 63.

title: A Correction
description: Robert D. Lilley, an executive vice president of the American Telephone & Telegraph Co., and Kenneth H. Straus, senior vice president for domestic and international corporate buying of R. H. Macy & Co.. Inc., have been elected to the board of R. H. Macy. An article yesterday erroneously said that they had been named to the hoard of Macy's New York division of R. H. Macy.

title: Guide on Unit Pricing Available to Grocers Here
description: The City Department of Con sumer Affairs yesterday mailed its final guidelines for regula tion of unit pricing to food re tailer associations and some large chains.

title: Carswell Again De ends Racial Views
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  G. Harrold Carswell completed his testimony today before the Senate Judiciary Committee, having apparently satisfied majority of its members that his nomination to the Supreme Court should be approved.

title: Nixon's Veto Contest Is Viewed as Prearranged Formal Joust
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 There was more ceremony than tension in President Nixon's first veto contest with Con gress, and he prevailed today by an even larger margin than his aides had expected.

title: Nixon Is Criticized on Auto Pollution
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 28 Democratic Senators on a com mittee investigating smogfree cars accused the Nixon Admini stration today of dawdling on antipollution efforts.

title: Politician Backs Marijuana
description: SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 28 (UPI) The 53yearold chair man of the Rockland County Liberal party yesterday ad mitted that he had used mari juana some 10 to 12 times in the last 10 years and called for its legalization.

title: Inmont Executive Resigns
description: The Inmont Corporation an nounced yesterday that Frank B. Cameron has resigned as an executive vice president. The company said that Mr. Cameron resigned to go into business for himself. No successor has been named.

title: The Flag and the School
description: The High School Principals Association, in urging their members to suspend the daily Pledge of Allegiance and flag salute, has done little to bring reason to bear on a confused issue.

title: 24 Killed in Gun Battle In Mexican Badlands
description: IXTEPEC, Mexico, Jan. 28 (UPI)Twenty escaped con victs and four law enforce ment officials were killed today during a fivehour gun battle in the badlands 310 miles southeast of Mexico City, the Defense Department. announced. Another 20 con victs survived and fled.

title: 2 HORSES ARE OUT OF SATURDAY PACE
description: WESTBURY. L. I., Jan. 28 Good Chase developed a cough this morning and the pacer was withdrawn from Saturday night's $12,500 junior freefor all onemile handicap event at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: MEYERSON NAMED PENN'S PRESIDENT
description: Martin Meyerson, president of the State University of New York at Buffalo, was appointed president of the University of Pennsylvania yesterday.

title: SST Is Said to Face Critical Budget Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 President Nixon's new budget is expected to trim the Ad ministration's earlier spending plans for the supersonic transport plane and force an other, possibly critical delay in production of two proto type aircraft.

title: REGIONAL REGIMES FOR ITALY BACKED
description: ROME, Jan. 28The Italian Chamber of Deputies, its mem bers weary and redeyed after a 66hour parliamentary ses sion, completed action this morning on a controversial bill to give broad legislative and administrative powers to 14 new regional parliaments and governmentsat least two of them with Communist majori ties.

title: Wholesale Prices of Food Are Up 2% in January
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Government reported to day a 2 per cent rise in the wholesale prices of processed foods this month, indicating further inflation for American consumers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
BISHOP ODD HAGEN, LED METHODIST UNIT
description: Bishop Odd Hagen, president of the World Methodist Council since 1966, died yesterday after a short illness, according to word received from Stockholm. He was 64 years old.

title: MAYORS DENOUNCE NIXON'S CUTBACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Executive Committee of the United States Conference of Mayors accused the Nixon Ad ministration tonight of depart ing from the moral commit ments of two decades in its recent cutback of ongoing urban renewal projects.

title: Garden Thronged for Songfest In Aid of Vietnam Moratorium
description: A capacity crowd of 21,000 was at Madison Square Garden last night to see performers ranging in style from East Har lem to Las Vegas in a benefit for the Vietnam Moratorium Committee.

title: Cuite: City Hall's Quiet Man
description: For City Hall's invisible man, Thomas J. Cuite, who uses the power levers ever so quietly, today's mood is one of here we go again.

title: MERGERS OF UTILITIES STIRRING CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) A consultant for the Justice Department says the current pattern of electric utility merg ers, if left unchecked, will re sult in power industry giants impossible to reglate.

title: Market Place: A Mutual Fund Assays Success
description: CURRAN W. HARVEY, a stocky, browneyed 41 yearold with a piercing gaze, runs one of the most unusual mutual funds in the industry.

title: BERNARD GROSSMAN, A NEURORADIOLOGIST
description: Dr. Bernard Lewis Grossman, a specialist in neuroradiology, died of a heart attack Tuesday in his home at 275 Hoym Street, Fort Lee, N. J. He was 38 years old.

title: MPSLIMS SEEK WRIT TO BAR PROSECUTION
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 28  A panel of three Federal judges sought to determine to day whether the Black Muslim organization constituted a re ligion or a foreign nation.

title: TREASURY OFFERS NOTES AT 88%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Treasury offered today a choice of three securities with interest rates ranging from 8 to 8 per cent to holders of $5.6billion of bonds maturing, in February and March.

title: L. I. U. Defeats Hofstra
description: Dave Bell's career and game high of 37 points wasn't enough to stop Long Island University, which took a 7064 verdict over Hofstra last night on the winner's court in Brooklyn. It was the ninth vic tory in 14 games for the Black birds this year.

title: Flyers Tie Hawks, 22
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (UPI) Gary Dornhoeffer's goal six min utes into the last period gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 22 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: Miss Lois Margaret George Fiancee of Dr. Paul Kaufman
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Scott George of Washington and Tokyo, have made known the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Lois Margaret George, to Dr. Paul Leon Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. I. Kaufman of New York. An April wed ding is planned.

title: Japan Joint Venture
description: TOKYO, Jan. 28 (AP) Japan's Nissan Motor Company, the Toyo Kogyo Company and the Ford Motor Company today established a joint ven ture to manufacture and mar ket automatic transmissions for cars in Japan, informed sources said.

title: Jersey S.C.I. Jails 3
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26Two or New Jersey's reputed Mafia racketeers and an alleged en forcer for the mob were jailed for indefinite terms today for refusing to testify before the State Commission of Investiga tion, and one of them said he had changed his mind and now was willing to give testimony.

title: Orthodox Rabbis Back Aid to Religious Schools
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 28 Leaders of Orthodox Judaism called on the New York Legis lature today to repeal the so called Blaine Amendment in the State Consitution, which prohibits aid to religiously sponsored schools.

title: 93 Guilty in a Controversial 17Year Tokyo Trial
description: TOKYO, Jan. 28Seventeen years and nine months after a bloody clash between police men and a rampaging May Day mob among the wide lawns and gnarled pine trees of the Im perial Palace Plaza, the Tokyo District Court today handed down a verdict partly upholding rivi prosecution's main chargerioting.

title: Bufman Hails Rise of Florida Theater
description: COCONUT GROVE, Fla. In 1963, when Zev Bufman, an Israeliborn producer, leased the Coconut Grove Play house in this Miami suburb, he was the inheritor of fail ure.

title: Foreign Aid Bill Sent To President by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP)The Senate today sent to President Nixon a $1.8 billion foreign aid appropria tions bill containing one of the lowest allotments ever for the program.

title: White House Services Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) President and Mrs. Nixon will join in worship services at the White House Sunday morn ing conducted by the Rev. Dr. M. L. Wilson, pastor of Con vent Avenue Baptist Church in New York City and president of the Council of Churches of the City of New York. Music will be provided by the Tudor Singers of the University of Wisconsin School of Music.

title: Seattle Interests Given 9 More Days to Raise Money to Keep Pilots There
description: The net result of two days of deliberation in Berkeley, Calif., about the future of the American League's 12th fran chise was another nineday extension to enable Seattle in terests to raise the money needed to keep the Pilots there.

title: Advertising: SSC&B Buying 49% of Lintas
description: The longexpected, much awaited news came out yes terdaySSC&B is acquiring 49 per cent of Lintas, the in ternational advertising agen cy network, from Unilever.

title: POTATO FUTURES HOLD FIRM TREND
description: Futures prices of Maine po tatoes, which had risen on Tuesday after dropping for some time, held firm yester day. This was true particularly in the May contract, the most active month, with 1,624 con tracts traded out of the day's total of 1,875.

title: RUBLE REPORTED IN WIDENING ROLE
description: PARIS, Jan. 28An uncon firmed French News Agency re port from Moscow said today the Soviet Union has intro duced a transferable ruble, a reform long sought by Eastern European countries to restruc ture trade in the Comecon bloc.

title: Bomb Scare Cuts Ballet
description: A telephoned bomb threat forced the cancellation of George Balanchine's ballet Episodes at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Cen ter last night. A caller reported during the intermission that a bomb would go off in the thea ter at 10:15 P.M. The remainder of the ballet was canceled and the angry audience, which was not told the reason for the can cellation until afterward, was evacuated. The police searched the theater but did not find a ??mb

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 29, 1970

title: Villanova Triumphs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) Villanova lost all but 2 points of an 11point lead in the final; six minutes, but the Wildcats' handed thirdranked St. Bona venture its first defeat of the season, 6462, tonight at the Villanova fieldhouse.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
Samuels Interrupts Campaign to Aid Son in Trial
description: Howard J. Samuels interrupt ed his campaigning for the Democratic nomination for Gov ernor yesterday to be with his 17yearold son, who has been charged with possessing mari juana.

title: 20Year Term Possible
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28  Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, a reputed Mafia chieftain, and Daniel (Red) Cecere were found guilty tonight of trying to collect pay ment of extortionate loans from the late Louis B. Saper stein.

title: Irving Trust Director
description: Hamilton B. Mitchell, presi dent and chief executive officer, of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., has been elected to the board of the Irving Trust Company. Mr. Mitchell, 53 years old, has served in his current post with tober, 1968. Earlier, he was Dun & Bradstreet since Oc president and principal execu tive officer of the Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation.

title: Oil Industry Warnedon Pollution
description: The automobile industry has told the oil industry that lead will have to be eliminated as an additive to gasoline to reduce air pollu tion, the chairman of a major oil company said here yesterday.

title: Observer: Dubious Honor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Several Egyptian soldiers were executed the other day because they had performed badly in combat against Israeli raiders. News dispatches said the pur pose was to make an example of them.

title: Commons Gets Bill Setting Equal Pay for Women
description: LONDON, Jan. 28British women won a longsought vic tory today when the GovernI anent introduced legislation re quiring equal pay for equal work by the end of 1975. Em ployers protested that their wage bill would increase by 5 per cent, or $2.4billion.

title: 154 Passengers Disembark From Cruise Ship Oronsay
description: VANCOUVER. Jan. 28One hundred and fiftyfour Austral ians and New Zealanders from the cruise ship Oronsay left Vancouver by charter flight to night for their homelands.

title: A Proposal for the Budget
description: President Nixon will submit his budget for fiscal 1971 to the Congress on Monday. The form ultimately imposed on this budget by the Congress may well turn out to be the most crucial element in the economic outlook for the coming year. More than that, the deci sions focused in the budget will determine whether the reordering of national priorities, to which the President committed himself in his State of the Union address, really occurs or evaporates as so much rhet oric as have some earlier declarations of high purpose.

title: DEMOCRATS LOSE ON 2 FARE ISSUES
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Republi cans in both houses of the Leg islature defeated today a Dem ocratic attempt to eliminate double fares on the city's tran sit system and to head off a fare increase on the Long Is land Rail Road.

title: Wilson Joins Nixon for a Meeting of the National Security Council
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Prime Minister Wilson of Britain participated in an ex traordinary session of Presi dent Nixon's National Securi ty Council today, exchanging views on the roles of London and Washington in Europe's political and military evolu tion over the years to come. Later, at a news conference ending his twoday visit here, the British leader parried questions about the possi bility of a cutback in Ameri can troop strength in West tern Europe after the middle of next year, but said he certainly foresaw no military disengagement by the Unit ed States from the Continent. The White House press sec retary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said that general subjects of EastWest relations and the problems and plans of the North Atlantic Treaty Or ganization were discussed during the 90minute meet ing. Mr. Wilson was not the first foreign leader to par ticipate in a National Security Council meeting. The late Prime Minister Harold Holt of Australia attended one with President Lyndon B. Johnson. But the presence of the British Prime Minister in the high policymaking body seemed de sgned to underline the confi deift relations existing between the British Government and the Nixon Administration.

title: U.S. TROOPS UNCOVER BIG NEW ARMS CACHE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)United States troops searching through a huge enemy arms cache in the jungles northwest of Saigon uncovered two and a half tons of arms and nearly 250,000 rounds of ammunition, American head quarters said today.

title: Music: Pittsburgh Has Another Baton
Appellate Court Denies Request For New Judge in Panther Trial
description: In a 4to0 decision, the Ap pellate Division refused yester day to remove State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh as the presiding judge at the, conspiracy trial of 16 Black Panthers.

title: Article 1  No Title
Executive Changes
description: William M. Wolfson has joined Halle & Stieglitz, Inc., as vice presidentcorporate finance. He formerly was president of Peoples National Fund, Inc., a home improvement finance company.

title: WITHDRAWALS RISE AT SAVINGS UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Savings withdrawals at savings and loan associations in De cember exceeded receipts by $383million, contrasted with an excess of receipts of $178 million in the 1968 month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: SALES MAKE GAINS AT CHAIN STORES
description: Leading chain stores and catalogue houses staged a moderate recovery in their lag ging sales last month. Volume improved sufficiently for them to achieve a 12.2 per cent rise over December of 1968.

title: SENATE APPROVES NARCOTICS CURBS BY 82TO0 VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Senate approved unanimously today a bill designed to pro duce an intensified Federal attack on illicit narcotics traf fic and use, while also reducing penalties for lesser drug vio lations.

title: 21 Arrested in Steal to Order CarTheft Ring
description: The smashing of a Mafia dominated, interstate ring that stole more than $5million worth of Cadillacs, Lincoins and other luxury cars in three years was announced yester day by the Brooklyn District At torney, Eugene Gold. He said 21 persons, including three women, have been arrested.

title: 65% in Poll Support Nixon Policy on Vietnam
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 28 Support for President Nixon's. Vietnam policies is holding firm, the Gallup Poll reported today.

title: 9 Lost in Lake Erie Crash
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (UPI)  A twoengine TAG Airlines plane to Detroit with nine per sons aboard crashed into ice covered Lake Erie today. The Coast Guard said there were no survivors.

title: Les Nouvelles Mathematiques
description: Last December French spokesmen both here and Paris indignantly denied a New York Times report that France was selling 50 Mirage fighter planes to Libya.

title: NETS BEATEN, 108107, IN FINAL 2 SECONDS
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 28 (UPI)  Lou Dampier sank one of three free throws with two seconds remaining tonight to give the Kentucky Colonels a 108107 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets before 5,228 fans at Island Garden.

title: Ford Sets 20% Cut In February Output
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28The Ford Motor Company will rut its February car production by 20 per cent with a series of plant closings it was announced today

title: Books of The Time
description: ON April 28, 1967, Leslie A. Fiedler, his wife, his son and his daughterinlaw were arrested in their home by Buf falo police and charged with maintaining a premise where marijuana was used. I never would have thought it, an old friend told him. You're the kind, Leslie, who always gets away . . . Oh hell, you'll just write a book about it and make lots of money. Here is the book. Yet his arrest seems oddly peripheral to it. We learn of his legal briefs; of the young girl who spied on his family with an electronic device; of the credit world that judged him guilty before his trial; of the University of Am sterdam, which canceled his invitation to teach a term abroad. But Being Busted really about all the other times Mr. Fiedler got away, times when he was a tourist at someone else's war. He looks at his materialism (the longing for sleek and shiny comforts) and his politics (ves tigial, nostalgic: little more than a function of my desire not to grow old), at his intellectual style (that ambivalence prized by the old, despised by the young) and his professional role (the teacher teaches himself, diffidently at first, shame lessly after a while).

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Transit as State Issue

title: Disorders Feared in Britain
description: LONDON, Jan. 28  Top cricket officials will meet to morrow with James Callaghan, the Home Secretary, to try to work out ways to prevent anti apartheid demonstrators from disrupting a planned British tour this summer by a South African cricket team.

title: NIXON SUSTAINED IN FUND BILL VETO BY LARGE MARGIN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28By an unexpectedly large margin, the House of Representatives upheld today President Nixon's veto of a $19.7billion appro priations bill for health, edu cation and antipoverty pro grams.

title: Galaxy Gravity Waves Reported
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28A report of intense gravity waves ap parently coming from the core of the Milky Way is so con trary to physical theory and present knowledge of the uni verse that theorists have found it hard to believe.

title: Rioting Ended in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 28 Order was restored today in Hyderabad, 120 miles north of here, after two days of rioting in which at least 24 persons were injured and property worth several hundred thou sand dollars was destroyed.

title: Treasury's 3 New Note Issues Rise Quickly to Slight Premium
Paul Smart, 79, Given Herreshoff Trophy in Sailing
description: Paul H. Smart of Noroton, Conn., a 79yearold Star; Class luminary who still races and only Tuesday was re elected chairman of the United States Olympic Yachting Com mittee, was the principal figure of the principal event asso ciated with, but not part of, the National Boat Show yes terday.

title: Hummer's Stature On Princeton Five Continues to Grow
description: PRINCETON continues to list its best tall basket ball player this way: John Hummer, senior, forward, 6 feet 7 inches, from. Arling ton, Va. The name, the class, the position and the home town are correct. But don't bet that Hummer is only 67. Pete Carril his coach said yesterday, We won't measure him until after the season. I guess he's some what over 67. None of the Ivy League coaches or players is satisfied that Hummer is only 67. They know he acts as if he were the best 69 or 610 player in the East and they know he may turn out to be the most important individual in the Ivy League race de spite the fact that Princeton has lost its first two league games to Penn.

title: CENSORSHIP DENIED BY U.S. COMMAND
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)The United States command today denied charges that unfavorable news reports were censored by the Armed Forces Vietnam Network.

title: Washington: For the Record
Mrs. Joanne F.Langdon Wed to John Pirovano
description: McLEAN, Va., Jan. 28Mrs. Joanne Field Langdon, a great greatgranddaughter of Mar shall Field, founder of the Chicago department store, was married here last Friday to John Pirovano, who attend ed Harvard with her brother, Marshall Field 5th, publisher of The Chicago SunTimes and The Chicago Daily News.

title: Economist Sees Relaxing Of Reserve's Credit Curbs
description: A leading economist predict ed yesterday that the Federal Reserve will soon start to re lax its tight rein on credit and that higher stock prices and some lower interest rates will be among the results.

title: Paid Less Than Subordinates, 2 City Rent Officials Step Down
description: Two top rentcontrol law yers at the Housing and De velopment Administration have stepped down from their posts because they were making low er salaries than some of their subordinates, sources within the agency said yesterday.

title: TV Review
description: THE Danny Thomas special, Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow, was an expen sive if traditional vaudeville show with the accent largely on yesterday. Bob Hope and Juliet Prowse appeared in an old chestnut about a romance that had gone on for 16 years, and the inevitable sketch about the generation gap, with the Thomas TV family, suffered from the same antiquity.

title: 3 Convicted of Murder Here In '67 Slaying of Realty Men
description: Three men were convicted of murder yesterday in the holdupslaying in November, 1967, of two brothers in their Bronx real estate office.

title: Caroline Metcalf to Wed in April
description: PRINCETON. N. J., Jan. 28 Miss Caroline Walker Met calf and Peter Martin Saylor plan to be married in April.

title: Engagements
description: HARTWIG  GOTTLIEBThe engagement Is announced between Hans, son of Mrs. Hartwig, of 30, Winchester Road, Harrow, England, and the late Mr. F. Hartwig, and Patricia, elder daughter of Dr. and Mrs. B. Gottlieb, of 18 Audley Road, London, W. 5.

title: Donaldson, Lufkin Set To Acquire Moody's Unit
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jen rette, the brokerage concern, announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements to acquire the investment ad visory business of Moody's In vestors Services.

title: LIPA M. RUTENBERG, SOVIET TRADE AGENT
description: Lipa M. Rutenberg, a former Russian Jewish revolutionary and Soviet trade representative here, died last Thursday in Mos cow, according to Soviet press reports. He was 76 years old.

title: CONSERVATIVE FILES FOR SENATE PRIMARY
description: Kevin P. McGovern, a Brook lyn lawyer, announced his can didacy yesterday for the Con servative party nomination for the Senate seat held now by Charles E. Goodell.

title: EWBANK'S GOAL: BUILD SECONDARY
description: If the quality of the Jets' new rookies is anything like the caliber of their college ma jors, the team's defensive back field problems may be ended.

title: I.N.A. Corp. Buys Blyth; Asarco to Sell an Interest
description: Blyth & Co., one of the na tion's leading investment bank ing houses, was acquired yes terday by the I.N.A. Corpora tion, an insurance holding con cern, for $55million in I.N.A. convertible prererred stock.

title: MILITANCY ENTERS CINCINNATI STRIKE
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 28  A 24day strike of city employes took a militant turn today as more than 1,000 strikers and sympathizers marched on City Hall and demanded a settle ment.

title: London Getting a Black Cultural Center
description: LONDON, Jan. 28Several derelict buildings in a rundown part of London are being con verted to create what is de scribed as Britain's first Black House for black cultural and business activities. The $600,000 project is being fi nanced in large part by a rich young white man.

title: Hershey's Job Reported Offered To Private Researcher for Navy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Nixon Administration's long search for a new director of Selective Service appeared to day to be at an end.

title: ELECTRICITY OUTPUT ROSE 12.5% IN WEEK
description: The nation's electric power production rose 12.5 per cent in the week ended Jan. 24 from the level in the corresponding 1969 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute.

title: I.B.M. Elects Directors
description: John N. Irwin 2d and Gilbert E. Jones have been elected to the board of the International Business Machines Corporation. Mr. Irwin is a partner in the New York law firm of Patter son, Belknap & Webb and a director of the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation. Mr. Jones is senior vice president and chairman of I.B.M.'s manage ment committee.

title: Catering to Terribly Expensive Tastes
description: COS COB, Conn.The next time your baby sitter gives you advice take it. Mrs. Scott Bartlett did, and now she has a flourishing catering establishment in this Greenwich suburb with the pecu liar name.

title: In The Nation: Unto the Least of These
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28It is a good thing that neither the Bill of Rights nor the Magna Carta is the pending business of the Senate these days. If either were to be presented to the world's greatest deliberative body, in its present mood of political panic and myopia, it would undoubtedly be voted down as a needless restraint in the war on crime.

title: U.S.O. Campaign Head
description: The U.S.O. of New York City announced yesterday the ap pointment of Morris D. Craw ford Jr., chairman of the board of Bowery Savings Bank, as the service agency's 1970 cam paign chairman.

title: Nun Robbed of $40 By Narcotics Addict In a Bronx Church
description: A nun was robbed of $40 yes terday by a narcotics addict who lunged at her with an 11 inch knife in a Bronx church while a mass was being cele brated.

title: WILLIAM CLEVELAND JR.
description: NEWTON, Pa., Jan. 28 William H. Cleveland Jr., direc tor of religious studies and theate arts at the George School died apparently of a heart attack Monday. He was 60 years old.

title: Teachers Resume Work Today Alter East Brunswick Walkout
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 28  In the face of threat ened contempt of Superior Court charges, the 530 public school teachers and 247 other school system employes here decided to return to their jobs tomorrow.

title: HERMAN WECKLER, AUTO MAKER, DIES
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28  Her man Weckler, a leading figure in the automobile indus try for nearly half a century, who rose to be second in com mand of Chrysler Corporation died yesterday in Detroit's Grate Hospital. Mr. Weckler, who entered the hospital Sun day, was 81 years old.

title: G.E. Talks Weigh Contract Language
description: Negotiators for the General Electric Company and its strik ing unions sought yesterday to reach a consensus of contract language and conclude an agreement that would settle the 94dayold walkout of 133, 000 workers.

title: CAUTION IS URGED ON NICKEL SHARES
description: LONDON, Jan. 28 (UPI) The Stock Exchange Council warned investors today against excessive speculation in various Australian nickel shares.

title: Personal Finance
description: With all the talk about higher commission rates for the small investor, the M.I. Pers have virtually been ig nored. Yet their numbers are at record levels.

title: Bridge:
description: THE play of a hand often focuses on the potential of a particular suit. A case in point is the spade suit on the diagramed deal, reported by Wellington Sun from a team game in Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

title: JAPANESE CONCERNS REPORT G.E. ORDERS
description: TOKYO, Jan. 28 (AP)The General Electric Company has asked for additional compo nents and parts from Hitachi, Ltd., and the Tokyo Shibaura Electric Company, Toshiba, the Japanese companies said today.

title: AFRICANS URGE HELP FOR FREEDOM DRIVES
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 28 (Agence FrancePresse)A threeday meeting of leaders of East and Central African states ended here today with a call for increased aid to black lib eration movements.

title: Fire Set in Jewish Center, Swastikas Painted on Walls
description: Six swastikas were painted on walls and doors of a Bronx synagogue early yesterday and a tablet was set afire before the vandals escaped.

title: ExJudge Repeats Testimony That Led to Charge of Perjury
description: Former Brooklyn Criminal Court Judge Benjamin Schor took the stand in his own de fense yesterday to repeat, un der a new oath, the testimony on which perjury charges against him were based.

title: Prague Dismisses Cernik, A Leader of '68 Reforms
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 28Oldrich Cernik, one of the leaders of the 1968 liberal reform movement in Czechoslovakia, was Dusted as Premier today and replaced by Lubomir Strougal, a conservative. Dr. Strougal, a 45yearold party official, has been a driving force in the purge of liberals. He is regarded as a rival to Dr. Gus tav Husak, the party leader.

title: BELGRADE TO FREE AUTHOR YEAR EARLY
description: The family of Mihajlo Mi hajlov, the Yugoslav author im prisoned on charges of insult ing the Soviet Union and de riding his government, reported yesterday that he had been told he would be released on March 4, almost a year before his sentence expires.

title: Track Stars Selected in Pro Football Draft
description: John Carlos and Willie Dav enport, Olympic track medal ists with sketchy football backgrounds, were included in the dragnet yesterday as pro fessional football concluded its annual draft of 442 college players.

title: Amid Bitter Souvenirs of Biafran War, Sao Tome Dresses Up for 500th Centennial of Discovery
description: SAO TOME, Jan. 25Proud red and green Portuguese ban ners have been planted on the main square by the sea to mark the fifth centennial of the dis covery of this palmstrewn equatorial island by Portuguese navigators.

title: BISHOP ODD HAGEN, LED METHODIST UNIT
description: Bishop Odd Hagen, president of the World Methodist Council since 1966, died yesterday after a short illness, according to word received from Stockholm. He was 64 years old.

title: Chicago 7 Judge Bars Ramsey Clark As Defense Witness
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 Judge Julius J. Hoffman barred Ram sey Clark, the former United States Attorney General, from testifying today as a witness for the defense in the Chicago conspiracy trial.

title: FILES AND GRANT FIRST TWO CHOSEN
description: Up on the 18th floor of the New York Coliseum, the walls are covered by pictures of giants. Young Roosevelt Brown Young Frank Gifford. Old Y. A. Tittle.

title: ISRAEL WILL ACT TO REVERSE COURT
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 28  Is raeli Government leaders de cided tonight to introduce leg islation reversing a recent Supreme Court ruling on the question of who is a Jew.

title: Seaboard Railroad Lists 185% Earnings Rise
description: The Seaboard Coast Line Railroad reported yesterday that its earnings climbed last year by 185 per cent to $38, 485,000 or $4.25 a share from $13,464,000, or $1.49 a share in 1968.

title: Office Queen Wins Mimosa Stakes by 8 Lengths at Hialeah and Pays $4.80
description: MIAMI, Jan. 28 (AP)Stephen A. Calder's Office Queen, strong favorite in a 16horse field of 3yearold fillies, ran away with the $35,400 Mimosa Stakes at Hialeah today, scor ing by eight lengths over the Briardale Farm's Devilish Angel, a 36to1 shot, before a crowd of 17,096.

title: BISHOP ODD HAGEN, LED METHODIST UNIT
description: Bishop Odd Hagen, president of the World Methodist Council since 1966, died yesterday after a short illness, according to word received from Stockholm. He was 64 years old.

title: U.S. Calls for Restoration Of CeaseFire in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The State Department said today there was urgent need for scrupulous restoration of the United Nations ceasefire in the Middle East by both Israel and the Arab states.

title: Volpe Asks Aid for All Transit Modes
description: Secretary John A. Volpe of the Department of Transporta tion said yesterday that his staff was drafting preliminary ideas for a national transpor tation trust fund  poten tially a multibilliondollar pool of Federal aid to assist virtually all modes of public transpor tation.

title: From Ungaro, Soft Angles and Curves
description: PARIS, Jan. 28The new est looking accessories turning up at the Paris springsummer haute couture collections this week are not on the models but down in the audience on the wrist of a New Yorker. They are the rope bracelets being worn by a young fashion editor who has already been asked half a dozen times where she found them. The answer is at Bonniers on Madison Avenue.

title: STEEL COMPANIES POST PROFIT DIP
description: Three big steel companies reported yesterday that their earnings declined last year, but, like most of the steel in dustry, they also reported rec ord sales and other revenues for 1969.

title: East Germans' Curbs On Berlin Route Lifted
description: BERLIN, Jan. 28The East Germans ended their slow down of border controls on the highway to Berlin early this morning.

title: F.D.A. May Require A Warning With Pill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration is considering a requirement that drug man ufacturers furnish warnings of possible health hazards directly to women using oral contraceptives, an F. D. A. official said today.

title: I.T.T. Sets Meeting Date
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation an nounced yesterday that its 1970 annual stockholders meeting would be held on May 19, in the SheratonLincoln Hotel in Houston. This will be the com pany's first meeting in Texas.

title: Budget as Politics: Groups Here Bring Pressure to Restore Cuts
description: All budgets are political doc uments, Mayor Lindsay told newsmen last week, and his observation offers an insight into the anguished, recrimina tionfilled annual recurrence of the city's budget gap.

title: 30 Children Die as Train Strikes Bus in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica. Jan. 28A railcrossing crash about 25 miles from here today killed 30 school children and injured 30, three seriously.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: THE International Game fisherman, a monthly newsletter for those inter ested in big game angling and fishing tournaments, was born a few months ago in Miami.

title: Miss Hanks Paints Bright Arts Picture
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said today that the Ameri can arts picture was brighter under President Nixon than it had ever been, with the Chief Executive, the national legisla ture and the average citizen displaying a surge of enthusi asm for culture.

title: Kings Triumph Over Rangers, 54, on Goal by Lonsberry in Final Second
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28In a wild finish that precipitated a 15minute debate over the validity of a coal by the Los Angeles Kings as the final buzzer sounded, the New York Rangers incurred a hectic 54 loss tonight before 7,762 con fused spectators.

title: EDWARD F. DANNER
description: OMAHA, Jan. 28State Senator Edward F. Danner, the only Negro member of the Nebraska Legislature collapsed Monday on a downtown street here and died shortly after ward. He was 69 years old.

title: Mt. Etna Erupts After Lull
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Jan. 28 (AP)  Mount Etna, Europe's tallest and mostactive volcano, shot molten rock high into the air today, following a four month lull. Experts said the eruption was part of the volanco's normal cycle of ac tivity.

title: Held Rescued in Snowmobile Race
description: ISLE, Minn., Jan. 28 The St. Paul winter carnival's 587mile international snow mobile race lost its chance for a foreign winner today as Dan Oberg of Sweden and Talevi Vekhonen of Finland both blew their SkiDoo en gines.

title: City Says Revenue Expected From Stock Tax Is Lagging
description: The slowdown in trading in the stock market has cost New York City more than $14 million so far this fiscal year  a year in which the city figured to he hardpressed even if its income forecasts held up.

title: President Is Elected By National Shoes, Inc.
description: The election of Sherman N. Baker as president and chief executive officer, effective Feb. 1, was announced yes terday by National Shoes, Inc. Mr. Baker formerly was executive vice president and president of the company's J. Baker division.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS KIRK'S SCHOOL PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Supreme Court flatly re jected today a plea by Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida that it set national standards for school desegregation.

title: Hardening of Opinion Seen
description: LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) Leading tennis officials pre dicted today a hardening of world opinion toward South Africa following her refusal of a visa to Mr. Ashe.

title: Policemen Kill Bronx Man Who They Say Opened Fire
description: Two policemen shot and killed a Bronx man last night after he allegedly shot at them, the po lice said.

title: Satellite Launching Delayed
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 28 (UPI)  The launching of an Intelsat 3 commercial communi cations satellite originally set for Feb. 18 has been indefinitely postponed, the space agency reported today.

title: Article 3  No Title
Alleghany Sets Redemption
description: The Alleghany Corporation, a holding company, announced yesterday it would redeem at $10.50 a share all of its 6 per cent convertible preferred stock, effective May 4. Each share of preferred  there are about 240,000 shares is con vertible into 4.7 shares of Alleghany common on payment of $3.75 per common share re ceived. The conversion privilege expires April 28 at 3:30 p.m.

title: Meyerson Linked Overseas
description: M. H. Meyerson & Co., Inc., announced yesterday the open ing of a direct overseas leased channel between the concern's Jersey City headquarters and Bank Widemann & Co., of Zurich. Switzerland. This is be lieved to be the first link be tween an American overthe counter trading house and the Continent.

title: BISHOP ODD HAGEN, LED METHODIST UNIT
description: Bishop Odd Hagen, president of the World Methodist Council since 1966, died yesterday after a short illness, according to word received from Stockholm. He was 64 years old.

title: Adelphi Is Victor
description: KINGS POINT, L. I. Jan. 28 Adelphi University rallied in the second half tonight to de feat Kings Point, 6960.

title: Reform Groups Appeal
description: Two major bodies of Reform Judaism in the United States asked the Israeli Government yesterday to resist attempts by a vocal minority to overturn last week's decision by Israel's high court permitting citizens to register as Jewish by na tionality rather than by religion.

title: RollCall Upholding Veto
Miss Sanderson, M. A. Kruming Plan Marriage
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 28 Miss Barbara Stewart San derson and Martin Alexander Kruming will be married here April 25.

title: State Is Suing to Hasten Control of Jet Pollution
description: The Rockefeller administra tion sought court action yes terday to expedite the instal lation of jetengine devices that would eliminate the bulk of smoke pollution caused by jet airliners.

title: German Food Prices Up
description: BONN, Jan. 28 (AP)Food prices in West Germany rose by an average of 3.5 per cent dur ing 1969 over the previous year, the Agriculture Ministry announced today. It said meat was up by 5.9 per cent, fresh vegetables by 10.9, fresh fruit by 9.8 and potatoes were up by 41.2 per cent.

title: Stocks Decline in Amex Trading; Selling Pressure Erases Gains
description: The American Stock Ex change ended lower yesterday in moderate trading as in creased selling pressure in the afternoon erased most of the earlier gains.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Israeli Brings Old Sounds Into the Electronic Age
description: Some of the sounds that fill El Avram, the Israeli nightclub on Sheridan Square, are, as might be expected, the old, traditional sounds of the eastern Mediterranean the lively, sparkling rhythms of the bouzouki or the keen ing cry of the owl. But the source of those sounds is not at all what might he ex pected.

title: Drop Laid to Writeoffs on Naval Contracts
Ralph Blomeley, Engineer; Industrial Insulation Expert
description: Ralph Blomeley, president of Blomeley Engineering Corpora tion, died yesterday at Rich mond Memorial Hospital, Prin cess Bay, S. I. He was 73 years old and lived at 4927 Arthur Kill Road, Richmond Valley, S. I.

title: Addict, 12, Found After 3Day Spree
description: The 12yearold daughter of a wealthy East Side psy chiatrist was found yesterday morning in an Upper West Side apartment building, still drugged from a narcotics binge that began when she ran away from home Mon day.

title: Bernard Korn, Fire Chief And Distance Swimmer
description: UNION CITY, N. J., Jan. 28 Bernard Korn, a retired Union City fire chief who was known for his longdistance swims, died yesterday in Englewood Hospi tal. He was 76 years old and lived at 809 New York Avenue here.

title: Tigers Name Farm Pilots
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28 (AP)The Detroit Tigers have named managers for two of their farm clubs today. Joe Lewis, a pitcher in the farm system for four seasons, will manage Batavia, N. Y., in the New York Penn League. Al Lakeman, a National League catcher for eight seasons, will manage Bristol, Va., in the Appalachian League.

title: DEMOCRATS NAMING BUDGET TRUTH UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 28 (AP) President Nixon's State of the Union Message is fuzzy, misleading and in some in stances patently inaccurate, a cochairman of the Democratic Policy Council's Committee on National Priorities declared to day.

title: Chess:
description: THE world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot Tigran Petrosian, the grand master from whom he wrest ed the crown last year, matched skills again during the last days of 1969.

title: P.G.A. Pays Final $50,000 of Michigan Purse Sponsors Reneged
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan, 28  Golf professionals who discovered there were no funds availabie to pay them when they fin ished the $100,000 Michigan Classic last September have now been fully reimbursed by their own organization.

title: Camden Gets U.S. Rowing
description: The National Association of Amateur Oarsmen said yester day the 1970 national rowing championships would be held Aug. 20 through 23 on the Cooper River at Camden, N. J.

title: Boxer Is Disqualified for Hitting Referee in Toronto
description: TORONTO, Jan. 28 (Cana dian Press)Humberto Trott man, a Panamaborn boxer who lives in New York, was disqualified and his purse was suspended here last night after he had struck the ref eree, Sammy Luftspring, dur ing a match with a Toronto fighter, Clyde Gray.

title: Elly Ameling Sings Debussy's Fetes In Tully Hall Debut
description: The recital given by Elly Ameling at Alice Tully Hall last night was her first in New York, but it will surely not be the last, for she proved that when her voic4.3 and tempera ment are put to the service of a song that suits both equally well the results can be capti vating.

title: Selma Police Aide Indicted
description: SELMA, Ala., Jan. 28 (UPI) Police Capt. Nolan Chambers was indicted yesterday by the Dallas County Grand Jury on first degree murder charge in the death of a Negro man last month. Lloyd Bizzell, 41 years old, died in a local hospitall after his arrest Christmas on a charge of being drunk and disorderly. Mayor Joe Smith erman said the man suffered certain wounds because of ficers had to use force in the arrest.

title: City Schools Given Instructions In Aiding Students in Childbirth
description: The Department of Health has sent instructions to all city elementary and secondary schools on what to do if a pregnant student goes into labor or gives birth while in school.

title: Bellport Suspends 8
description: BELLPORT, L. L. Jan. 28 The Bellport School Board has suspended eight black students for being involved in fights with students and teachers at the high school here, which was reopened today after being closed for a week and a half because of racial disorders.

title: JOHN A. M'CABE, 74, BROOKLYN SURGEON
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Jan. 28Dr. John A. Mc Cabe, a surgeon who was for merly director of surgery at the St. Catherine's and Green point Hospitals in Brooklyn, died today at Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre. He was 74 years old and lived here.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: I.R.S. AGENT HELD IN BRIBERY CASE
description: An Internal Revenue Service special agent attached to the Intelligence Division in White Plains was arrested yesterday on charges of having accepted $4,000 in bribes from three reputed Mafia figures in West chester.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WITTIEST MUSICAL IN YEARS. CLIVE BARNES N.Y. TIMES THE SMARTEST, SUNNIEST MOST DELIGHTFUL NEW MUSICAL IN TOWN. WALTER KERR, N.Y. TIMES A MUSICAL COMEDY OF EXCEP TIONAL QUALITY.RICHARD WATTS. JR., N.Y. POST

title: Marilyn Hayes, '64 Debutante, Is Affianced to Ronald C. Barr
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Jan. 28 The engagement of Miss Marilyn Hayes to Ronald C. Barr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Barr of Delray Beach, Fla., and Brookville, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Clifford Haves.

title: Anticrime Bill for Capital Approved by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  A House Dist riot subcommit tee approved today anticrime legis lation that would create a new Superior Crourt in Washington. and give it jurisdiction over all local cases, both civil and criminal.

title: BISHOP ODD HAGEN, LED METHODIST UNIT
description: Bishop Odd Hagen, president of the World Methodist Council since 1966, died yesterday after a short illness, according to word received from Stockholm. He was 64 years old.

title: Brown Six Beats Yale, 31
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 28 Brown University's hockey team, paced by Curt Bennett, defeated Yale University to night, 31, in an Ivy League game.

title: Poodle Trials on Saturday Are Pleasant Interlude
description: JANUARY, which began with the national specialty of the American Spaniel Club at the Statler Hilton Hotel, will end on Saturday with another, lesser dog fixture, the obedience trials of the Poodle Obedience Training Club of Greater New York, at the same hotel. Except for noncham pionship match events, in be tween in the canine line here abouts. The situ ation will be remedied with almost too much to spare with Westminster in Madi son Square Garden Feb. 9 and 10 and its many breed satellites on Feb. 7 and 8.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID SUBURB OF CAIRO; SHOPPERS WATCH
description: CAIRO, Jan. 28  Israeli fighterbombers attacked tar gets as close as six miles from the center of Cairo today. The United Arab Republic Govern ment asserted that three civil ians were killed and 12 wounded.

title: THREE QUESTIONED IN BROOKLYN INQUIRY
description: Three reputed underworld figures were questioned yester day by a special Federal grand jury investigating organized criminal activities in Brooklyn.

title: MARKET NUDGING A 39MONTH LOW
description: Everybodys trying to fish for the bottom of this market, a Wall Street broker declared yesterday as both bluechip and glamour stocks displayed weakness.

title: Nixon Gives Reception For House Supporters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  One way to get invited to the White House as a member of Congress is to side with President Nixon on a rollcall vote on a major issue.

title: A Plea of Not Guilty Entered For Manson
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (UPI) A Superior Court judge en tered a plea of not guilty today on behalf of Charles Manson in the murder of Sharon Tate and six others. His trial was set for Feb. 9.

title: GRIFFITH GAINS DECISION IN BOUT
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (AP) Emile Griffith, a fivetime world champion, hammered out a un animous 10round decision to night over Doyle Baird in a middleweight fight at the Cleve land Arena.

title: SAIGON NEWSMEN WERE U. S. AGENTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)  American officials said today that two United States Government agents were infiltrated into the Saigon press corps but were withdrawn aft er their identity had been ex posed.

title: Athens Denies Trade With Reds Indicates Coolness to the West
description: ATHENS, Jan. 28  Sources in the militarybacked govern ment vigorously denied today that the drive to increase trade with Communist nations im plied any political alienation from the West.

title: Ruritania, D.C.
description: How oddly he is suited, observes Portia in Shake speare's Merchant of Venice. I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany . . .

title: Stocks Firm in London Trading; Nickel Shares Again Top Action
Arrest in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 28The 18 yearold son of Elisha C. Freed man, City Manager here, was arrested at his home yesterday for selling what was believed to be LSD to an undercover police agent.

title: LIQUID RESERVES UP FOR WEST GERMANY
description: FRANKFURT, Jan. 28 (Reu ters)  The West German central bank said today that West Germany's liquid mone tary reserves rose by 872 mil lion marks (approximately $235.44million) to 21.49 bil lion marks (approximately $5.80billion) in the week to Jan. 23, (The mark was quoted at 27.13 today).

title: Police Seek Clues in Killing Of Clergyman in Brooklyn
description: The police were seeking chiles yesterday in the holdup slaying of the Rev. Franklin Diggs, who was found dead in his apartment Tuesday at 191 Willoughby Street in Brooklyn.

title: Records Set in 1969 by Westinghouse Electric
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation achieved new highs in sales and earnings in 1969, Donald C. Burnharn, chairman, reported yesterday. Sales and revenues for the final quarter of 1969 also topped 1968 levels.

title: Westchester Riders May Fight Governor at Polls
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 28  Westchester commuters are turning to politics in their con tinued fight against deteriora ting service on Penn Central trains.

title: British Troops on Alert in Belfast After a Policeman Is Hurt in Clash
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, Thursday. Jan. 29 (Reuters)  British troops were on a full alert here early today after a fifth night of demonstrations by Protestant extremists.

title: At First, All He Wanted Was a Frog
description: PAULINE TRIGERE, the fashion designer, collects turtles. Eleanor Perry, the screen writer, collects lady bugs. Charles Croft, the pro prietor of Leah's Antiques, collects frogs. None of these animals are real, of course, although some of them are remarkably lifelike. In Mr. Crott's case, the frogs led to the antiques rather than vice versa. In order to get the frog, I had to buy the whole box and started accumulating things, Mr. Croft said recently in his tiny store at 1014 Amster dam Avenue (between 109th and 110th Streets). To date Mr. Croft has 24, including one in old bronze for which he paid $225 and a celluloid one that he bought for 50 cents because it reminded him of the tree frogs in his native Louisiana.

title: South Africa Denies Visa to Arthur Ashe
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28  The Govern ment refused today to give a visa to Arthur Ashe, the Ameri can Negro tennis player, to play in the South African open championships.

title: LEGISLATORS VETO THE MACHINE AGE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Man was declared the victor over the machine today, two years and thousands of votes after elec tronic voting boards were in stalled in the Legislature to flash out each member's vote.

title: Rosenberg Trial Drama Due in April
