description: Inquest, a new version of the play by Donald Freed about the Rosenberg trial in the nineteenfifties, when the couple were charged with conspiracy to commit espio nage, found guilty and exe cuted, will he brought to Broadway on April 16.

title: GERALD SWEETMAN
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 28 (AP)Ger ald Sweetman, Finance Minister of Ireland in the nineteenforties and nineteenfifties, was killed today in an automobile accident. He was 61 years old.

title: Jaspers 8243 Victors
description: After playing a half of slow down, St. Francis decided to play a half of regular ball against Manhattan last night, but the Jaspers won, 8243, on St. Francis's home court, the 69th Regiment Armory.

title: PAUL M. CUENIN, 47, GILLETTE EXECUTIVE
description: BOSTON, Jan. 28Paul M. Cuenin, executive vice president of International Operations for the Gillette Company, died of a heart attack Monday in Frank furt, Germany, a spokesman for the company said here.

title: Frazier, Ellis Co Spar Before Congressmen
description: MIAMI, Jan. 28  Joe Frazier and Jimmy Ellis will take their training chores to the House Office Building in Washington next Monday night to spar before mem bers of Congress. The reg ular sparring partners will provide the opposition for the exhibition, which is scheduled to start at 6:30 o'clock.

title: YABLONSKI JURY HEARS INFORMER
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 A young former Tennessean who has been identified as a key police informer in a plot to kill Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter testified to day before a Federal grand jury.

title: Officer Fiance Of Miss Marks
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 28 Miss Margaret Ann Marks. daughter of Col. Edwin H. Marks Jr., U.S.A., chief of staff at the United States Military Academy and Mrs. Marks, plans to he married in July to Second Lieut. James Fulford Love, U.S.A., a 1969 graduate of the acad emy. He is the son of Col. James W. Love. U.S.A., chief of staff at Fort Dix, N. J., and Mrs. Love.

title: Canada's Reserves Rise
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 28 (Canadian Press)Canada's official for eign exchange reserves rose by! $1,800,000 last month to $2,615, 100,000 mainly through an ac cumulation of United States! dollars, the Bank of Canada re ported today. Gold holdings in the reserves rose by $100,000 to $872,300,000 at the end of December. Canada's net credi tor position in the International Monetary Fund rose to $293, 100,000 from $259,500,000 at the end of November.

title: VALENTI OPPOSED TO CURB ON FILMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Book publishers claimed com plete license under Supreme Court standards, and the United States Catholic Confer ence called for a halt to the smut flood in testimony, this morning before a House sub committee considering anti obscenity legislation. But the highlight of the hearing was Jack Valenti explaining the Mo tion Picture Association code.

title: 2 SHIPPING LINES INDICTED BY U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 Two federally subsidized ship ping companies were indicted here today for violations of the Federal Corrupt Practices Act in contributing money to poli tical campaigns of House and Senate members.

title: Judge to Make Proposal On Hoe Next Thursday
description: Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan announced yesterday that he would make a preliminary proposal for reorganization of R. Hoe J. Co., makers of print ing presses and saws, next Thursday.

title: Song of the Late Commuter Starts Day on L.I.R.R.
description: Long Island Rail Road commuters singing at the station while waiting for late trains in the morning?

title: CONTEST WINNERS AT PHILHARMONIC
description: There were three firstprize winning conductors on the po dium during last night's Gala Concert that wound up the Dimitri Mitropoulos Internation al Music Competition. That is usual in this prestigious con test. They had been chosen from a field of 30 contenders in trials held here this month. Each carried off a gold medal, $5,000 in cash and an appoint ment as an assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic for next season.

title: Italian Bobsled Sets Pace
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 28 (UPI)Nevio De Zordo and his three Italian teammates led the field today in training for the world fourman bobsled championships. De Zordo was only threehundredths of a second ahead of the Rumanian sled, piloted by Ion Panturu, and sixhundredths ahead of the No. 2 United States sled. piloted by Fred Fortune of Lake Placid, N. Y.

title: Ashe Voices Surprise
description: DES MOINES. Iowa, Jan. 28 (AP)  At a news conference today prior to competing in exhibition matches with the United States Davis Cup team here, Mr. Ashe said he was sur prised at South Africa's refusal of the visa.

title: Widow Says Blaiberg Suffered More Than Was Publicly Seen
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 28 (Reu tersPhilip Blaiberg, the South African heart transplant pa tient, led a double life with his new heart, appearing of ficially in excellent health but spending much of his time in bed or in the hospital fighting for survival, his widow was quoted as saying In an inter view published here.

title: CANADIENS DOWN NORTH STARS, 54
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 28 (UPI) Two goals by Bobby Rousseau led the Montreal Canadiens to a 54 National Hockey League vic tory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Two Jets Undergo Surgery
description: Paul Seiler and Jimmie Jones, a pair of reserve line men for the New York Jets underwent operations yester day to repair leg injuries.

title: M.T.A. Signs Contract to Buy 240 New Cars for Subway
description: Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials signed a con tract yesterday to buy 240 air conditioned, highspeed subway cars.

title: SouthWest Africa Vigorous
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaWhen viewed against the problems that SouthWest Africa has had to face in its struggle for an economic iden tity, the development of the territory today is nothing short of dynamic. Political un certainty, which has plagued SouthWest Africa for years, has played a significant part in the recent buildup of the territory's economic re sources and the development plans now being carried out.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Old Debts Thwart Ghana's New Ideas
description: ACCRA, Ghana  Kafu dide is an expression in Twi, one of Ghana's lan guages, that means the debt or still must eat.

title: Market Place:
description: IT IS A SAD BUT incon trovertible fact that one cannot buy mutual funds mindlessly and expect to profit over the short term.

title: Chiefs Get $7,755 Each
description: Each member of the Kansas City Chiefs will receive $7,755, 79, a record, as a winning share from the American Football League championship game. Milt Woodard, president of the A.F.L., announced yesterday.

title: Sudan Working on Debts
description: KHARTOUM, The Sudan The new revolutionary Gov ernment in the Sudan fares a stiff battle to restore the economy in the year ahead.

title: Fiduciary Trust Elects
description: Francis C. Smithers, 32 years old, formerly vice president banking and securities serviceg. at the Fiduciary Trust Com pany of New York, has been elected executive vice president in charge of operations. He will continue to direct banking and securities services. Mr. Smith ers will take over the manage ment of onerations from R. Minor Eager, who has been serving as first vice president, and secretary. The latter will continue as secretary until he leaves the company next June 30.

title: G.E. NEGOTIATORS REPORT ACCORD IN 95DAY STRIKE
description: J. Curtis Counts, Federal mediation chief, announced last night that a basis for agree ment had been reached between the General Electric Company and the striking electrical unions.

title: Laurie M. Bullot Is Married Here
description: Miss Laurie Marie Bullot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Bullot of Rye, N.Y., was married here yesterday to David Kittredge Levington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham J. Levington of New York and Beverly Hills, Calif. Criminal Court Judge Fred erick L. Strong performed the ceremony in his cham bers.

title: Conservation Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 In 1956, Russell Errol Train shot an elephant and was chased by a rhinoceros. Life was never the same after that. For the safari that Mr. Train took to Africa turned him into a conservationist and led him down a path that convinced him to give up the secure life of a judge of the Federal Tax Court to devote full time to saving the en vironment. That path led today to the White House as President Nixon appointed the blueeyed, red faced Under Secretary of the Interior as the first chairman of the newly created Council on Environmental Quality.

title: Car Brake System Controlled by Radar Is Tested by Volpe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe rode through snarled rushhour traffic today in a car equipped with radar controlled brakes that are ap plied automatically to prevent collisions.

title: South Africa to Study Crash
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 29 (UPI)South Africa set up a special board of inquiry today into a trainbus collision near here yesterday that killed 23 children on their way home from school. The accident also injured 13 children, six criti cally. All the children were on the bus.

title: Skelton Opens a White House Series
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Red Skelton played the White House tonight, and President and Mrs. Nixon were at home. The occasion was the first in a series of Evenings at the White House, in which, every month or six weeks, the Nixons will invite famous en tertainers to perform for an audiente of invited guests.

title: W. J. HOLLOWAY, EXGOVERNOR, 81
description: OKLAHOMA CITY. Jan. 29 William Judson Holloway Sr., eighth governor of Okla homa, died yesterday after be ing stricken in downtown Ok lahoma City near his law of fice. He was 81 years old.

title: Schoolboy Gets 100 Points
description: FBARB, La., Jan. 29 (AP) Greg Procell, a 5foot11inch senior, scored 100 points to night to lead Ebarb High School to a 13979 victory over Eliza beth High School.

title: Rockefeller Calls Nixon Plan On Water Pollution Inadequate
description: Governor Rockefeller con tended here yesterday that the $10billion program proposed by President Nixon to clean up the nation's water would be far from adequate.

title: HAYAKAWA SPEAKS AS MILITANTS SHOUT
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP)Mili tants stormed a building at Northeastern University, where S. I. Hayakawa, San Francisco State College president, was speaking tonight, broke win dows and shouted obscenities.

title: Jack Carter Divorced
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (UPI) Jack Carter, the comedian. was divorced today by Paula Stewart, actress, after nearly nine years of marriage. Miss Stewart was awarded the fam ily home, $500 monthly support for a son, Michael, 3, and ali mony at $1,400 monthly the first year, $1.200 a month for the second and $1,000 monthly for the next five years.

title: Africa Finds New Reason for Hope
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaAfrica is en tering the seventies with the kind of hope that follows a long siege of disasterthe conviction that since things have gone so badly they are bound to get better.

title: Miss Hundemann Prospective Bride
description: Miss Patricia Gail Hunde mann, who is with the Boyle Midway division of Ameri can Home Products, Inc., here, plans to be married to David Curtis Neldner, who is attending the Army's non commissioned officers school at Fort Benning, Ga.

title: BIG BOARD WARY OF MIDWEST PLAN
description: The New York Stock Ex change has renewed its opposi tion to any.form of public own ership of member firms that would preclude their close su pervision by the exchange.

title: Vote for 19YearOlds Gains
description: DENVER, Jan. 29 (UPI)The Colorado House of Representa tives passed today by one vote a constitutional amendment giving the vote to 19yearolds. Supporters expressed optimism about its chances in the Senate. The proposal will be placed on the general election ballot in November if it is approved by the Senate.

title: No Nuremberg Trials For Rebels, Gowon Says
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 29 Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the Nigerian leader, promised to day that his Government would conduct nothing like Nurem berg trials of the leaders of the Biafran secession.

title: Point of View
description: SOME 10 years have gone by since the wind of independence swept Africa and focused world attention on the problems of the con tinent's development.

title: ...but a Need for Action
description: The Public Service Commission is less far advanced in its consideration of other utility rate cases of extreme importance to millions of New Yorkers, chief among them Consolidated Edison's plea for a rise $117 million in electricity bills.

title: Apollo 13 Rocket Tested
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 29 (UPI)Two astronauts put the Apollo 13 rocket through a successful mock launching to day in a key test for the start of America's third lunar land ing expedition April 11. John L. Swigert Jr., a civilian, and Maj. Charles M. Duke Jr. of the Air Force spent about an hoiir at the controls of the Apollo 13 command ship during the final part of an abbreviated count down, and then simulated the start of the trip to the moon.

title: Dr. Robert Woodbury, Served International Labor Office
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 29 Dr. Robert Morse Woodbury, economist and author, who re tired in 1953 as chief statis tician of the International Labor Office in Geneva, died Jan. 17 at his home here. His age was 80.

title: $155 a Month at 72 Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, introduced a bill today to establish a mini mum income of $155 a month for persons 72 or older.

title: Weapons Include Polaris
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Navy officials confirmed to night that the Nathaniel Greene normally carries nuclear Polaris missiles but would not com ment on whether such weapons were on board when the ship went aground.

title: Canadian Bill Rate Off
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press)New 91day Govern ment of Canada Treasury bills auctioned today: $135,million at an average price and yield of 98.097 and 7.78 per cent. Last week, $140million, same term, 98.094 and 7.79 per cent. 182day: $40million at 96.275 and 7.76 per cent. Last week, $35million, same term, 96.245 and 7.82 per cent.

title: Toledo Downs Colgate, 9976
description: TOLEDO, Jan. 29 (AP)To ledo rallied late in the first half and then outscored Colgate in the second half tonight to post a 9976 victory.

title: Call for Action Radio Services Are Now Carried in 22 Cities
description: John W. Gardner, chairman of the National Urban Coali tion, announced yesterday the expansion to 22 cities of a broadcastoriented project de signed to make the institutions of government more responsive to citizens' complaints.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Responding to the firing at an Ameri can reconnaissance plane over North Viet nam, American fighterbombers attacked a missile site inside North Vietnam on Wednes day, the United States command in Saigon announced early today. One of the attack ing planes and a rescue helicopter were shot down. Washington officials said the incident did not reflect a change in American pol icy. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: ExHead of City Tax Commission Is Indicted on a Perjury Charge
description: A man who served two years as president of the city's Tax Commission was indicted on perjury charge yesterday, ac cused of having falsely denied to a grand jury that he paid former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus at least $1,300 in an effort to influence a de cision of the City Planning Commission.

title: India Gives Disputed Chandigarh City to Punjab State
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 29The Indian Government, in an of fort to avert the selfimmola tion of a Sikh leader, awarded the city of Chandigarh to Pun jab State today, but sought to appease the rival claimant, Haryana State by giving it a fertile and prosperous piece of Punjab territory.

title: Nuclear Submarine Is Floated off Bar She Struck in Fog
description: CHARLESTON. S. C., Jan. 29 (UPI)The nuclear submarine Nathanael Greene, inching through Charleston Harbor in a dense fog ran aground on sandbar today under the lee of Fort Sumter, and it took tug boats seven hours to get her afloat again.

title: Philadelphia Aide Indicted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (UPI) S. Harry Galfand, Philadel phia Director of Commerce and City Representative, was in dicted by a Federal grand jury today on stock fraud charges. The 18count indictment ac cused Mr. Galfand and two business partners, Albert B. Gerber and Morise Thal, of fraud in the public sale of 105, 911 shares of preferred stock of the Commonwealth Financial Corporation for $1.5million in March, 1966.

title: DUANE POPE GIVEN A DEATH SENTENCE
description: CHAPPELL, Neb., Jan. 29 (UPI)Duane Earl Pope was sentenced today to die in Ne braska's electric chair for the murders of three persons in a bank robbery in Big Springs in 1965.

title: Mrs. Eisenhower Gets Heart Award
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI)Mrs. Dwight D. Eisen hower, whose husband died in 1969 after several heart attacks, was honored at the White House today as the nation's foremost heart vol unteer.

title: Angry Italians Rename Town on a Polluted River Stinkville
description: COCCOLIA, Italy, Jan. 23 Last fall the 600 furious inhab itants of this tiny agricultural town 15 miles southwest of Ravenna renamed their home Puzzolia. freely translata ble as Stinitville.

title: Guinea Maintains Isolation Course
description: CONAKRY, GuineaLife is still very hard for most of Guinea's 3.5 million people. The last 12 months saw little, if any, improvement in their standard of living, and the country continues to exist in what is virtually a wartime economyalmost everything is in short supply.

title: Dartmouth Sends Art for Show Here
description: An art exhibition that will amount to a quick survey course of the trends of the last one hundred years will open at M. Knoedler & Co. on Feb. 9 with a champagne reception to benefit Dart mouth College's Hopkins Center Art Galleries.

title: Armstrong to Build Plant
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germ any, Jan. 29 (UPI)The Arm strong Cork Company has an nounced plans to build a plant at Muenster, West Germany, to manufacture hoard and tile for integrated ceiling systems. The cost is estimated at $13.5mil lion. The company did not dis close the planned capacity of the plant.

title: A SLOW ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29A premature release of President Nixon's Economic Report to Congress disclosed tonight that his new budget would total $200.8billion.

title: Harvard Fights Move by State To Open Stadium to Pro Team
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29Harvard University is under a legis lative threat of having its stadium taken by eminent do main for the Boston Patriots.

title: Basil Liddell Hart, 74, Is Dead; Military Theorist and Writer
description: LONDON, Jan. 29Capt. Sir Basil Liddell Hart, one of the world's leading military writers and thinkers, whose basic ideas on tank warfare were adopted ??y the German Army in its 1940 ??litzkrieg through France, died today at his home in Mar ow, Buckinghamshire. He was 4 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: TO be able to take home after the game a printed record of the deals with an expert commentary on them is an attraction to most club duplicate players. This serv ice is sometimes provided by the organizers of special events, such as the Nassau Suffolk Bridge Association's charity game tonight in aid of the American Contract Bridge League's Charity Foundation.

title: Executive Changes
description: Donald E. Williams has been elected president of the Baer Securities Corporation, an affiliate of the private banking firm of Julius Baer & Co., Zurich. Switzerland.

title: N.Y.U. Tops Lafayette, 7572; Princeton Victor Over Cornell
description: Leopards never change their spots and the species from Lafayette ran true to form by losing, 7572, to New York University last night at the University Heights gym for their 10th setback in 15 games this season.

title: Inventor Accuses Auto Makers Of Inertia on Engine Pollution
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 29The major automobile manufac turers were attacked today by William P. Lear, the inventor, for failing to develop vehicles that emitted lower levels of pollutants than standard mod els do.

title: BILL BIDS STATES ACT ON LAND USE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Senator Henry M. Jackson in troduced a bill today that would provide Incentives to the states to adopt landuse plans to protect the environment and also provide penalties for fail ure to adopt plans acceptable to the Federal Government

title: Reports on Skiing Conditions
ITALIAN SKIER, 18, WINS RACE, APPEAL
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Jan. 29 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni of Italy won the giant slalom of the men's ski meet today after a jury disqualified him for missing a gate and then overruled itself following the testimony of Austrian skiers.

title: Pound Circulation Declines 28.64Million in the Week
description: LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: Uranium Bolsters Outlook in Niger
description: NIAMEY, NigerImprove ment in this semiSaharan land is a matter of whether the struggle to survive is easier in one year than an other. On this basis, 1969 was better than most for Niger.

title: Record Coffee Crop Strengthens Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Al though political matters are uncertain, economic prospects for this East African country have been brightened for the 1970's by a strong recovery last year in production and trade.

title: C.A.B. Denies Airline's Plea For Japan Charter Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board denied today the application of the New Yorkbased supplemen tal airline, Overseas National Airways, for authority to oper ate passenger charter flights to Japan from March 1 to Sept. 30 during the Osaka Expo '70.

title: Pioneer Women's Lunch
description: The annual midwinter luncheon of the Brooklyn Council of Pioneer Women will take place Feb. 11 in the Sutton Ballroom of the New York Hilton. Rehaveam Amir, Israeli Consul General will be guest speaker. Pioneer Wom en at 189 Montague Street, Brooklyn, provides social services in Israel for women, youth and children in over 1,000 childcare and immi grant rehabilitation centers.

title: Liberian Prospects Bright
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Reduced debt burdens and higher output of iron ore and rubber in 1969 have made prospects for this West Af rican republic the brightest, relatively, that they have been in many years.

title: Soviet Orders a Drive on Work Shirkers
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29  The Soviet Union's labor organiza tion called today for a nation wide crackdown on workers ac cused of shirking on the job.

title: NIXON APPOINTS 3 IN POLLUTION WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Nixon announced today the membership of the new Council on Environmental Quality amid stern demands from Capitol Hill that he use the council as its architects in Congress intended.

title: Two Testify That Professor Was Beaten at Convention
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) Two free lance photographers testified yesterday that they saw a deputy superintendent of police beat an antiwar leader during street violence the week of the 1968 Democratic Na tional Convention.

title: In South Africa, Gold Losing Glitter
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  After nearly two years with its economic head buried firmly in the goldmine dumps of the Witwatersrand, South Africa has pulled out and acknowledged the dollar is king.

title: PAPERBOARD OUTPUT ROSE 3.7% IN WEEK
description: Paperboard production rose 3.7 per cent with 526.6 tons in the week ended Jan. 24, from 508,000 tons in the correspond ing 1969 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

title: Mrs. Blaiberg Denies Suffering of Husband
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 29, (Reuters)  Mrs. Philip Blaiberg, widow of the heart transplant patient, denied today that her hus band had lived a double life after his operation.

title: Tigers Win, 7958
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 29 Princeton's basketball cocap tains, John Hummer and Jeff Petrie, scored a total of 42 points tonight to lead the Tigers to a 7958 Ivy League victory over Cornell. The tri umph was the Tigers' 10th against six losses, while Cor nell lost for the 10th time in 14 contests.

title: L.L.R.R. TRAINMEN THREATEN STRIKE
description: Long Island Rail Road train crews, saying they were afraid of physical assault by com muters angered by the new fire increase, threatened yes terday to refuse to operate trains on Monday unless they were given police protection on every run.

title: MAYOR WILL SEEK NEIGHBORHOOD AID
description: Mayor Lindsay plans to allo cate $3million in the 197071 capital budget to neighbor hood stabilization programs in six areas with a total popula tion of about 600,000, accord ing to reliable City Hall reports.

title: Bunker Says Enemy Remains A Force to Be Reckoned With
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 29The United States Ambas sador, Ellsworth Bunker, today described 1969 as a year of meaningful progress in South Vietnam, but conceded that the enemy is still a military force to be reckoned with.

title: Silent Majority,, U.S.I.A. Film, Fails To Stir Foreigners
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Silent Majority, a con troversial film produced by the United States Information Agency to show that President Nixon has ample public sup port for his policies in Vietnam, has been less than a smash hit abroad.

title: SUNS TURN BACK HAWKFIVE, 111102
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 29 (AP) Connie Hawkins scored 15 of his 24 points in the fourth period to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 111102 National Basket ball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: Italians Seek Oil
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tan zaniaAn offshore search for oil and natural gas is to be made by AGIP, subsidiary of the Italian National Hy drocarbon Agency, under an agreement recently signed with the Tanzanian Govern ment. The 12millionacre area to be explored includes the islands of Zanzibar, Pem ba and Mafia.

title: Laird Says Volunteer Plan Would Cut Forces a Third
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird suggested today that creating an allvolunteer armed force might require a slash of about onethird in the size of the nation's active duty armed forces.

title: Millrose Games at Garden Tonight Attract 8 Olympic Champions
description: Four world recordholders with different running styles, backgrounds and personalities will enter the same race to night, and the 600yard run finally may shed its role as track and field's orphan event.

title: Study Reports Some Have Heart Attack Without Knowing It
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 A Government study shows that a surprisingly large number of heart attacks occur without the victims' being aware of them.

title: A Mixed Earnings Trend Is Shown in Reports of Big Oil Concerns
description: Earnings reports issued yes terday by large oil companies continued to follow the mixed trend indicated in reports pre viously issued by other com panies.

title: Ivory Coast May Triple Output by 75
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Still West Africa's most pros perous country, the Ivory Coast maintained strong growth last year and moved ahead with new development that may well triple output in the next five years.

title: Conspiracy Laid to U.M.W., But Jury Denies Damages
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 29 A Federal court jury con cluded here today that the United Mine Workers of Amer ica had conspired to unrea sonably restrain trade in the coal industry.

title: PerShare Total Down to $1.78 From $2.06 in the 1968 Period
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29  The General Motors Corporation's fourthquarter profits, $510mil lion or $1.78 a share, fell 14 per cent from the $596mil lion or $2.06 a share the year hefore, and were the lowest fourthquarter G.M. profits since 1914.

title: Downtown Bank Robbed
description: A man handed a woman teller in a bank in the financial section a threatening note and a bag yesterday afternoon and demanded money. The teller. whose identity was withheld by the police, put $4,000 in the bag, and the thief took it and fled. The bank was the Under writers Trust Company Bank branch at 100 William Street.

title: Radical Socialists Offer a French Reform Plan
description: PARIS, Jan. 29  France's Radical Socialist party, once a powerful force on the left but now decrepit and conservative, sought today to revitalize itself and to revolutionize the French political scene with an auda cious program of economic and social reform.

title: An Office Building To Rise 50 Stories On W. 57th Street
description: A $40million, 50story office building will soon begin to rise on 57th Street west of Fifth Avenuethe largest postwar office tower yet built on the crosstown thoroughfare.

title: Mrs. Jones, Miss Melville Gain in Auckland Tennis
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 28 (AP)Mrs. Ann Jones of England, the Wimbledon champion, defeated Robyn Leggs of New Zealand 60, 60 today in the quarterfinal round of the Benson and Hedges open tennis tournament.

title: Party to Aid Health Unit
description: The eighth annual winter cocktail party to benefit the Brooklyn Association for Mental Health will be held on Sunday at the Empress Manor in Brooklyn. Mrs. Catherine T. Alexander, founder and secretary of the board of directors of the as sociation, is chairman of the event, which will honor two volunteers, Arthur B. Bren ner and George Meares, for their support and service to the mental health cause.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS EXPANSION OF ABM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon has decided to seek an expansion of the Safe guard missile defense system and of the funds to be requested for it from Congress in the next budget, Administration officials say.

title: 2 RARE HAGGADAHS TOP AUCTION PRICES
description: Two manuscript Haggadahs were among the stellar items auctioned yesterday in the sale of part of the Hebraica collection of the late Michael Zagayski of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The sale, held at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, realized $161.035.

title: Duquesne Victor, 8367
Running in U. S. Affords Doubell Chance to Catch Up on Reading
description: Ralph Doubell can't take a copy of Lawrence Durrell's Justine back to Australia with him, but the customs officials have nothing against track trophies.

title: Sordid School Compromise
description: Congress is now grappling with the sordid conse quences of the compromises which the Administration used as bait to persuade the House to sustain Presi dent Nixon's veto of the education annronriations bill.

title: PRICES DIP AGAIN IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped to their lowest level in six months yesterday as the list continued to decline in comparatively quiet trading.

title: For Corned Beef Fans
description: IN the menu below, the dish I marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Nasser Said to Visit Soviet
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29  President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic flew secretly to Moscow last week for four days of talks with the Soviet leaders, ac cording to information reach ing here from diplomatic sources in Cairo.

title: Badillo on Hospital Board
description: Herman Badillo, former Bronx Borough President, has been named to the board of trustees of the 600bed BronxLebanon Hospital Center, Seymour Mil stein, president of the board, announced yesterday. Mr. Ba dillo recently became a partner in the law firm of Stroock, Stroock and Lavan. The center, one of the largest voluntary in stitutions in the city, has a staff of almost 2,000.

title: Coup Retards Brazzaville
description: BRAZZAVILLE, the Congo Unsettled political condi tions continue to hamper economic development in the Congo.

title: '50 SECURITY ACT REVISED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) The House approved today a revision of the Internal Se curity Act to keep subversives out of sensitive defense plants.

title: U.S. Banks to Aid Exports by Latins
description: CARACAS. Venezuela, Jan. 29  A pool of $100million has been created by 11 top United States banks this week to finance nontraditional LatinAmerican exports in an effort to unshackle the region's dependence on customary sales to world markets.

title: Hong Kong Concern Opens
description: Robert Fleming & Co., Ltd., a London merchantbanking concern, and Jardine, Matheson & Co., Ltd., of Hong Kong have opened a jointly owned invest mentmanagement and finan cialservices concern in Hong Kong, it was announced yes terday. The concern, owned equally by both parents, is called Jardine Fleming & Co., Ltd.

title: SENATORS DEBATE NEWSPAPER PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The Senate refused today to postpone consideration of legis lation that would immunize from antitrust prosecution all existing and many prospective joint operations of a separately owned newspapers.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: State Aid to City

title: New Books Today
description: GENERAL

title: Mangan Wins Tasmanian Golf
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 29 (AP)  Tony Mangan, an Aus tralian pro, won the $840 Tas manian open golf tournament for the second successive year today with a sevenunderpar 66 for the oneday event. Thir teen in the field of 60 bettered par 73 and four others tied it. Jerry Stolhand of the United States had a 72. Jesse Vaughn, another American had a 73.

title: TV and Radio to Carry Nixon Parley Tonight
description: President Nixon's White House news conference scheduled for 6:30 P.M. to day will be carried live on television and radio.

title: Assault on Wife of a Legislator. Linked to Colorado Racial Row
description: DENVER, Jan. 29The wife of a Colorado legislator was recovering today from a con cussion and more than 100 knife wounds from an unknown attacker who was apparently reacting to her husband's role in a racial controversy.

title: CREDIT CONTINUES TIGHT, DATA SHOW
description: The Federal Reserve, despite a growing body of opinion that it ought to modify somewhat its severe tightcredit policy, has not, yet taken any substantial steps to do so, according to the weekly banking data pub lished yesterday.

title: Sandy Koufax Named Ballplayer of Decade
description: Sandy Koufax was named Baseball Athlete of the Decade yesterday in a poll of sports writers and broad casters taken by The Asso ciated Press.

title: DR. ALFRED CORVIN, TAUGHT PSYCHIATRY
description: Dr. Alfred T. Corvin, a psy choanalyst, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home, 300 Central Park West. He was 60 years old. His office was at 360 East 65th Street.

title: NANCY RICHEY KEEPS TOP TENNIS RANKING
description: Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and Julie Heldman of New York remained 1, 2 in the rec ommended national rankings announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis As sociation Women's Ranking Committee.

title: CZERMANSKI, ARTIST WHO ESCAPED NAZIS
description: Zdzislaw Czermanski, painter and political cartoon ist, died Tuesday at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 70 years old and lived at 436 East 77th Street.

title: Cairo Denies Egyptians Had A Role in Libyan Jet Talks
description: CAIRO. Jan. 28 The chief spokesman for the Egyptian Government, Dr. Ahmed Esmat Abdel Meguid, has denied a re port published last Saturday that key Egyptian military ex perts posing as Libyans had taken part in recent negotia tions by Libya to purchase Mirage aircraft from France.

title: McDonnell Douglas Net Drops; 2 Railroads and an Airline Gain
description: Despite a fourthquarter drop 58.4 per cent earnings of the McDonnell Douglas Cor poration last year increased 24:1 per cent over 1968.

title: Tenant Charged With Arson In Apartment House Fire
description: A man who the police said had been loud and boisterous was charged yesterday with setting a fire in his apartment that forced 16 families to flee from their homes and resulted in the treatment of three fire men for smoke inhalation.

title: Nigeria Absorbs Financial Cost of War
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Put to the test of a brutal and de structive civil war, the eco nomic structure and promise of the Nigerian nation appear to have emerged almost un scathed.

title: C.B.S. Newsman Expelled By Nigeria After Questioning
description: Morley Safer, a correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, left Nigeria yesterday on orders from Government au thorities in Lagos, who had re fused to renew his expired visa, according to C.B.S. News. The authorities in Lagos gave no reason for the expulsion.

title: Stability Helps Algeria to Modernize
description: ALGIERS  Political sta bility at home has enabled President Houari Bourne dienne's regime to continue laying the foundations of modern economy, with the emphasis on oil and other industries.

title: Panel of 45 to Study State University's Plans for Future
description: A panel of civic, government, labor and educational leaders was named yesterday to make a comprehensive study of the State University's nlans.

title: Knicks Crush Pistons by 127106 With a 40Point Burst in Third Quarter
description: Although they took a deci sive lead early in the second period, the New York Knicker bockers rode to victory over the Detroit Pistons last night in Madison Square Garden on the strength of a 40point third quarter that led to a 127106 triumph.

title: Anne Baxter Is Divorced
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP)Anne Baxter ended her 10year marriage to the Honolulu land developer Ran dolph Galt in Superior Court today, citing irreconcilable dif ferences. Mr. Galt, who is 40 years old, and the 46yearold actress have two children.

title: Hershey Reflects on 30 Years of Draft
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 After drafting millions of men into the military during three wars and the periods of peace in between, Gen. Lewis Blaine Hershey will retire next month, convinced that the values he learned as an Indiana farm boy at the turn of the century and the struc ture he created for the Se lective Service System three decades ago are still sound.

title: Dr. Andrew Eggston, Head Of Hospital Laboratories
description: Dr. Andrew A. Eggston, a pathologist and hematologist, died Monday at Lawrence Hos pital in Bronxville, N. Y. He was 80 years old and lived at 120 Elmsmere Road, Mount Ver non. N. Y.

title: British Officials Gloomy Over Tensions in Ulster
description: LONDON, Jan. 29The re newal of sectarian strife in Northern Ireland evoked deep pessimism in London today and prompted restrictive meas ures in Belfast.

title: Wings Down Flyers, 43
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29 (UPI) Gordie Howe scored one goal and assisted on two others to night as the Detroit Red Wings fought off a determined third period attack and scored a 43 National Hockey League vic tory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: RHODESIAN LEADER CAUTIONS ZAMBIANS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 29Prime Minister Ian D. Smith hinted today at reprisals against Zambia if she contin tied to harbor and assist ter rorists.

title: The Wheelers and Dealers
description: THE chain reaction really started last week when the Chicago Bears made a move that totally surprised the pro fessional football folks. The experts had figured the upcoming draft of collegians with their usual unerring accuracy. The Pittsburgh Steelers would exercise their first choice by picking Terry Bradshaw, the marvelous Louisiana Tech quarterback. The Bears, selecting second, were a cinch to go for Mike Phipps, the Purdue quarter back, to solve their manifold problems in that position.

title: ADDONIZIO BEGINS REELECTION RACE
description: NEWARK, Jan. 29  Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, who is un der Federal indictment on charges of extortion and in come tax evasion, formally de clared himself a candidate for reelection today.

title: JERSEY SCHOOLS STILL IN TURMOIL
description: Teachers walkouts and threat ened bc cott of classrooms con tinued yesterday to plague plague the public school sys tems of a number of New Jersey communities.

title: Bill in Albany Would Require Screening of Judiciary Aspirants
description: Perry B. Duryea Jr., Speaker of the Assembly, and Assem blyman Stephen C. Hansen of Manhattan, both Republicans, announced yesterday they would introduce a bill requir ing the screening of all candi dates for the State Supreme Court.

title: CHASE DROPS PLAN TO BUY U.S. LEASING
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that a plan to acquire United States Leasing, International, Inc., had been discontinued by mutual agree ment.

title: Kaunda Assumes Control Of Zambian Industries
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 29 President Kenneth Kaunda took virtual control of Zambia's mining, industry and com merce today.

title: Antiwar Group Planning Feb. 14 Parley on Tactics
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) A student antiwar group an nounced today a conference, open to the entire antiwar movement, in Cleveland Feb. 1415 to plan a spring ac tion campaign.

title: Cairo Calls Economy Healthy
description: CAIRODespite the strains and costs of sharpening war fare with Israel, the economy of the United Arab Republic showed resilience and achievement in 1969.

title: Bar Asks Broadening of Mandatory Auto Insurance
description: The New York State Bar As sociation has approved a plan requiring every automobile owner to carry insurance cover ing medical payments and in come loss for passengers in his own car.

title: 200 Block a Wharf At Santa Barbara In Pollution Protest
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 29Two hundred students blocked access to this city's main pier overnight in a sit down demonstration protesting oil operations in the Santa Bar bara channel.

title: Port Agency Aide Retiring
description: Ian B. Packman, general superintendent of the Port of New York Authority's central maintenance engineering divi sion, is retiring today after nearly 21 years with the agency.

title: Romney Terms Busing Superficial Compromise
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29 (UPI) George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, said today that busing was not the correct method for overcoming the problems of segregation in schools.

title: Soviet Sends 162 Icons For Auction in London
description: LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Soviet Union has sent a collection of 162 icons to London for sale at auction Feb. 25.

title: PANEL EXAMINES NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Is the idea of an individual's having a single, lifelong career outmoded?

title: SHAHN'S PORTRAIT PAINTED IN MUSIC
description: Paintings have inspired a fair number of musical composi tions, but rarely, if ever, has the artist himself sat for Musical portrait. Last night at Philharmonic Hall, Leonard Bernstein led the New York Philharmonic in the first per formance anywhere of William Schuman's reflections on the character of the late Ben Shahn. The work is called In Praise of Shahn, Canticle for Orchestra, and it was commis sioned by friends of the artist shortly after his death last year.

title: Viscountess de Noailles of Paris, Patron of AvantGarde, Dies
description: PARIS, Jan. 29Viscountess de Noailles, one of Paris's most celebrated hostesses and a pa tron of the avantgarde arts since the nineteentwenties, died here today of an embolism. Her age was 67.

title: Governor Will Seek Panel on Narcotics
description: Governor Rockefeller plans to offer legislation today to create a 15member special commis sion to recommend new state laws regulating the use of mari juana and other drugs.

title: Wagner Seeks Separation From Wife in Suit Here
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner filed a separation suit yesterday against his wife the former Barbara Cavanagh. They were married July 26. 1965.

title: Suits on Services Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Justice Department's antitrust division expects to he bringing more cases in the near future involving price fixing on services, rather than products.

title: 5.3% JOBLESSNESS HELD NIXON LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon has set a polit ical ceiling of 5.3 per cent on the national unemployment rate this year, Senator Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, said today.

title: Congenial B.B.C. Shows Clay Beating. Marciano
description: LONDON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Cassius Clay defeated Rocky Marciano tonight in a revised version of their filmed and computerized fight.

title: There's Nothing Like Same Old Stand
description: Happiness to a National Boat Show exhibitor is keep ing the great location he had last year and the year be fore that and the year be fore that. It's security and prestige rolled into one.

title: Gary Teacher Strike Goes On
description: GARY, Ind., Jan. 29 (AP) A court order for striking teachers to return to their classrooms failed to end a boy cott of Gary's public schools today. The city's six senior high schools, six junior high schools and 18 of 33 elemen tary schools were unable to muster enough teachers to conduct classes. The boycott started Jan. 6 after Local 4, American Federation of Teach ers and the school board failed to agree on a 1970 contract.

title: New York Financial Writers Elect Sloane as President
description: The election of Leonard Sloane as president of the New York Financial Writers' Asso ciation, Inc.. was announced yesterday. Mr. Sloane, a finan cial and business reporter for The New York Tinics, succeeds Ted Ward, financial editor of The New York Post.

title: Pacers Top Stars, 127123
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 29 (UPI)  Roger Brown scored 34 points tonight and led the In diana Pacers to a 727123 Am erican Basketball Association victory over Los Angeles.

title: Bronx Pharmacist Is Held In Travel Agency Fraud
description: A 34yearold Bronx phar macy owner was indicted yes terday on charges of grand larceny in connection with the alleged embezzlement of 67,000 from a travel agency for which he acted as an agent in his store at 850 East 169th Street.

title: Libya's Success. Story Being Revised
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Brisk and efficient Plans for eco nomic and social develop ment of this underdeveloped country, which struck it rich with oil in the 1960's, came to an abrupt halt last Sep tember 1, when a group of army officers in their 20's deposed the government of King Idris.

title: C.A.B. Warns Major Airlines To Reform Sharing of Revenue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Civil Aeronautics Board threat ened the major airlines today with a $1millionaday fare cut unless they came up with a more equitable plan for sharing revenues with local airlines on throughfare tickets that involve: two or more carriers.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Vocal Trap
U.S. Steel Planning To Match Increase
description: The United States Steel Corporation and the Kaiser Steel Corporation said yester day that they would match the price increases of about 3 per cent on flatrolled sheets al ready announced by most of the steel industry.

title: Advertising: Agency Tries New Approach
description: Marion Harper Jr., founder and deposed head of the world's largest ad agency combine, is back in the busi ness.

title: Hartke Scores Tax Policy
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 29 (UPI)Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, said to night that the high tax and high interest policies of the Nixon Administration threat ened the American economy with its worst recession since the period following World War II. Mr. Hartke, speaking at a dinner in honor of Repre sentative John Brademas of In diana, called on the President to order the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates at once.

title: FRANCIS W. JAMES SR.
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 29 Francis Wadsworth James Sr., who retired in 1967 from his management consulting firm at 267 Fifth Avenue, New York, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 135 Leroy Avenue here.

title: Ransom Cards 70 to Lead By Stroke in Senior Golf
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Jan. 29 (AP)Henry Ran som posted a twounder par 70 on the 6,800yard National Country Club course today to take a onestroke lead in the 72hole $40,000 Ford Profes sional Golfers' Association se niors championship.

title: President Is Elected By the Inmont Corp.
description: The election of William R. Barrett Sr. as president and chief operating officer of the Inmont Corporation was an nounced yesterday. Herbert B. Woodman will continue as chairman and chief execu tive officer.

title: SEALE, PEACEABLE, RETURNS TO TRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29Bobby G. Seale returned to the Chicago conspiracy trial today and fi nally got a chance to speak out at length.

title: Oil Industry Cleared in Spill
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 29 (AP)  The Louisiana Stream Control Commission cleared the petroleum industry today of any blame in the oil slick that smeared Grand Isle beaches last Sunday. The Commission chair man, Clark Hoffpauer, said that tests by four laboratories had proved that the oil spill on Grand Isle was not caused from . . . oil operations.

title: Edith F. Mendelson Plans Nuptials
description: Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Men delson of Brooklyn have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Florence Mendelson, to Dr. Michael Charles Gelfand. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Harold Gelfand of New York. A wedding in the spring is planned.

title: Kinshasa Recuperating Swiftly
description: KINSHASA, the Congo  Helped by record copper earnings, new high levels of trade and an upsurge in for eign investor interest, the Congolese economy is show ing signs of moving from ra pid recovery into vigorous health.

title: Foreign Cars Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) Registrations of new foreign passenger cars increased al most fivefold between 1957 and 1968, the Commerce De partment reported today. The department said a total of 986,000 foreign autos were registered in 1968 compared with 207,000 in 1957. West Germany accounted for about 60 per cent of the imports, with Volkswagen registrations totaling 563,500 in 1968.

title: Israeli Cabinet Votes to Reverse High Court Definition of a Jew
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29The Israeli Cabinet today reversed the intent of the recent high court ruling that would allow person to register himself as Jew without meeting Orthodox Jewish criteria for acceptance as one.

title: Crime Fight Plan Advanced in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that New Jersey's legis lative leaders had reached bi partisan agreement on a pro posed state antitrust law to prevent the infiltration of legit imate businesses by organized crime.

title: SCHOR PERJURY CASE IS SENT TO THE JURY
description: Perjury charges against for mer Brooklyn Criminal Court Judge Benjamin Schor went to the jury yesterday after three days of testimony before Jus tice Thomas S. Agresta in the criminal section of the Queens Supreme Court.

title: Fashion Steps ack and Catches Up to Chanel
description: PARIS, Jan. 28Coco Cha nel, who let the nineteen sixties slide by without changing her style one whit, strode right back into fashion today. The elderly couturiere probably did not even know she was ever out of it. After all, for Chanel there is only Chanel.

title: Rosalind Oppenheim Dies; Photographer and Teacher
description: GLEN COVE, L. 1., Jan. 29 Rosalind Oppenheim, a free lance photographer and teacher of photography, died at Com munity Hospital here yesterday after a brief illness. Miss Op penheim, who was 56 years old, lived in Woodbury.

title: The President's Policy on Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Mayor Henry W. Maier of Milwaukee, who was here this week to lobby for more Fed eral aid to the cities, remarked sadly, as many mayors have done, that the Federal Govern ment has no urban policy. Yet it is possible to detect through the words and actions of mem bers of the Ad ministration, from President Nixon down to assistant, secretaries, an ap proach to urban troubles that is emerging in bits and pieces.

title: Budget Is Balanced In Gambia Again
description: BATHURST, Gambia  Gambia once again managed to balance its books for the fiscal year 1969, but the tiny West African country is not resting on its laurels.

title: M.T.A. IS ASSAILED AT QUEENS HEARING
description: A public hearing last night on transportation problems in Queens was almost unanimous in accusing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of failing to provide adequate subway and bus service.

title: Big Six Mayors Tour Yonkers And Find Common Problems
description: Mayor Lindsay got a look at another city's troubles yes terday as he and the mayors of the state's six largest cities toured the inner core of Yonk ers while its Mayor, Alfred B. DelBello, ticked off the cata logue of woes arising from the city's being taxed to its limits and still short of vital serv ices.

title: Coast Students Protest Dropping of Professor
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif . . . Jan. 29  A student demon stration forced a shutdown of the fivestory administration building at the University of California campus here today.

title: BORMAN WILL HELP PEROT FORM GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Col. Frank Borman, the astro naut who commanded Apollo 8 on man's first circumnaviga tion of the moon, announced plans today to leave the space program and join a Texas bil lionaire in starting a foundation to promote public debate on pressing national issues.

title: BRUINS CONQUER NORTH STARS, 65
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) Bobby Orr, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, regis tered a goal and three assists tonight and Phil Esposito add ed two goals as the Boston Bruins posted a 65 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Reserve Report
description: (In Billions) Daily Averages

title: 15 Americans Leave Oronsay; Length of Quarantine Criticized
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Jan. 29  A group of 15 Americans, the first cleared by Canadian health authorities, disembarked from the typhoid quarantined cruise liner Oron say today, generally cheerful after their 14day confinement in Vancouver harbor. Some, however, criticized Canadian authorities for delaying their release so long.

title: Pennsylvania Democrats Name Two for Governor and Senator
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 29 Robert P. Casey, the state auditor general, was endorsed today for the governorship by the Pennsylvania Democratic organization.

title: No Relief for the Riders...
description: The muchabused riders on all the mass transit lines in the metropolitan area are on the verge of open rebel lion. The latest affront is the Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority's order for higher fares on the Long Island Rail Road, effective tomorrowan order so certain to stir additional outrage that the Long Island trainmen are threatening to strike unless they get police protection.

title: ScrippsHoward Aide To Retire Here Sunday
description: ScrippsHoward Newspapers announced yesterday that Mark Ferree, who has been executive vice president in the New York offices since 1952, would retire Sunday.

title: U.S. PLANES MAKE RETALIATORY RAID IN NORTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 30United States fighterbombers attacked an antiaircraft missile base 90 miles inside North Vietnam on Wednesday after an unarmed American reconnaissance plane was fired upon by missiles, they American command announced here early today.

title: Rosenthal Is Seeking Democratic Senate Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal of Queens has de cided to enter the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York as an active but undeclared candidate.

title: MiniStates CashLaden
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaThe three ministates of southern Africa  Bot wana, Lesotho and Swazi landenter the year with a solid cash position through an important new deal with the country that influences their economic destinies, South Africa.

title: PRESIDENT QUITS AT TRANSAMERICA
description: The Transamerica Corpora tion announced yesterday that Edward L. Scarff, president, had resigned to head a new subsidiary of Donaldson, Luf kin & Jenrette, Inc., the New York brokerage concern.

title: Sierra Leone Again Has Surplus
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone This small West African country is hoping that it is over the worst of its new nation growing pains.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKS SAFEDRIVING LAW
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29Governor Rockefeller proposed today highway safety program to cope with the shameful record of automobile accidents, with special emphasis on curbing drunken drivers.

title: Economic Problems Still Beset Dahomey
description: COTONOU, Dahomey  After another 12 months of political instability and social unrest, Dahomey's serious economic problems are no nearer a solution.

title: End Paper.
description: A history of the last decade hot from the mouths of the men and women who made it. All the causes that animated those years find their spokesmen in this encyclopedic handbook: the sitins, the civil rights strug gle, the peace marches, the campus revolts, the poverty programs, voters' registration drives, the development of nonviolence. They are presented in all their fervor and in a biting and fiery advocacy that turns cold print into flame.

title: Lindsay to Discuss Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) Mayor Lindsay will be the leadoff witness Monday at House Banking Committee hear ings into alternate ways of fi nancing home mortgages, it was announced today.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater OPENING TONIGHT

title: TAKEOVER CURB ASKED BY CELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)  Representative Emanuel Cel ler, chairman of the House Ju diciary Committee, advocated today legislation curbing take overs of banks, utilities, insur ance companies and other regu lated companies.

title: STATE MAY EASE BOAT SEWAGE LAW
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29The Re publican majority in the Legis lature is preparing to com promise in the first major test of antipollution sentiment in year of increasing political rhe toric about environmental pro tection.

title: British Physicist, 30, Cited by Foundation
description: Dr. Brian D. Josephson, 30 yearold theoretical physicist from Cambridge University, received the 1969 Research Corporation Award last night at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel here.

title: Marsh & McLennan Moving
description: Marsh & McLennan, Inc., an nounced yesterday it would move its New York head quarters into the new, 51story McGrawHill building now un der construction in Rockefeller Center. The international in surancebrokerage concern has been situated for nearly 70 years in the city's Wall Street insurance center.

title: The Screen: Youths Opposed to War, Etc.
Theater: Young Writer
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Control Data Corporation
description: Consolidated net earnings of Control Data Corporation last year are estimated at $52.6 million, or $3.55 a common share, up from $44.1million, or $2.99 a share, for 1968, Wil liam C. Norris, chairman and president, reported yesterday. Earnings for both periods have been adjusted to reflect acquisi tions recorded as poolings of in terests.

title: Harvests Hearten Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia Efforts to speed development in this still largely feudal istic land were encouraged last year, by good harvests that have increased prospects for a needed rise, in exports in 1970.

title: Test Drug Is Termed Promising As Weapon for Fighting Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)  A hitherto littleknown ex perimental drug called BCNU is proving to be one of the most promising of the new anticancer weapons developed by a Government testing pro gram, the National Cancer In stitute said today.

title: Foreign Affairs: Nixon and the Europeans
description: PARISThe successive visits to Washington of Prime Minister Wilson, President Pompidou and Chancellor Brandt reflect re newed U.S. interest in Europe and the growing concern of Eu rope with itself. Almost unob trusively a change has come about in both goals and meth ods of superpowers and powers. This change is bound to be re flected in President Nixon's con versations.

title: Only Copper Sales Brisk for Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia  The way we have been going in the past five years shows clearly that the majority of us have decided to make Zam bia a nation of paupers or beggers.

title: Stengel Joins Mets Here to View an Impossible Film
description: A dozen Mets, led by Casey Stengel, attended a premiere of the team's annual film yesterday. And for the first time in eight years, it had a happy ending.

title: International Paper
description: The International Paper Com pany realized a 15.6 per cent increase in earnings last year on a sales gain of 12.9 per cent, both setting new records for the year.

title: Damascus Then Buzzed
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29  A Syrian MIG21 swept low over Haifa today, shattering dozens of windows in the Mediter ranean port city.

title: Jersey Standard Plans to Raise $450Million in Stock Offering
description: In the second massive corporate financing project in two weeks, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) an nounced yesterday that it plans to raise between $400million and $450million through an offering of additional capital stock.

title: Demand Deposit Charges Slipped a Bit in December
description: Charges to demand deposits at New York banks slipped to a $4,198,200,000,000 seasonally adjusted annual rate in Decem ber from $4,207,500,000, in No vember, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday. In December, 1968, the rate was $4,076,800,000,000.

title: Store Sales Advance 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Department of Commerce re ported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $509million, an in crease of 7 per cent above the $475million sales for the cor responding week of last year. Total retailstore sales for the latest week were an estimated $5,896,000,000, an increase of 2 per cent above the $5,756,000, 000 for the comparable week in 1969.

title: 3 Indicted for Plot In Yablonski Death
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 29The Federal grand jury investigating: the murder of Joseph A. Ya blonski returned an indictment today naming the three suspects arrested here eight days ago as the killers, hired by persons unknown for fees of up to $1.700.

title: SOHIO ENLARGES ESTIMATE ON OIL
description: In a doublebarreled mixture of good and bad news, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced yesterday the most successful test results yet re ported from an oil well on Alaska's North Slope and a sharp decline in 1969 earnings as a result of its merger with the B.P. Oil Company. Ameri can subsidiary of British Pe troleum, Ltd.

title: Togo Women Give Economy Vitality
description: LOME, Togo  In this small West African country, women run most of the busi nesses, while for men the chief form of steady employ ment is government jobs that pay more in prestige than money.

title: William N.Smith Fiance Of Barbara B. Boeger
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 29Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam A. Boeger Jr. have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Benton Boeger, to William Neville Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Lyle Smith of Oklahoma City.

title: Barbara Ann Brown Is Affianced
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 29Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Brown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Brown, to James David McNitt 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McNitt of Green wich, Conn. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Met's Latest Headache: Unsold Seats
description: The normally soldout Met ropolitan Opera, which opened its belated and shortened 85th season a month ago yes terday, has suffered a severe falling off in ticket sales. Company officials blame con fusion resulting from the threeandahalfmonth post ponement for the empty seats and say attendance is now Picking up rapidly.

title: 39 Killed and 100 Hurt in Iran as Avalanches Sweep Vehicles Off Road
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29 (AP)A series of snow ava lanches swept down on the Amoz Maraz highway in the Elburz Mountains 50 miles northeast of here yesterday, burying about 100 vehicles, Iranian officials said.

title: U.S. WIRETAPPING RESTRAINED IN '69
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The first public accounting of the Justice Department's wiretap activities against organized crime, made public today, shows that electronic eaves dropping under the Nixon Ad ministration's law  and  order regime has been limited and re strained.

title: Couple in Buffalo Sue Over Birth Pill Effects
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 29 (AP)A husband and wife filed a $1 million suit in Federal court today against a drug manu facturer, contending the com pany's oral contraceptive pill caused various ailments, includ ing a blood clot on a lung, to the wife.

title: Police Quell Florida Protest
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 29 (UPI)The police used tear gas today to quell a rockythrow ing uprising by several hundred black students, evidently en raged over the closing of their high school by courtordered integration. Windows in cars and in Lincoln High School were smashed by rocks and bricks.

title: Point of View
description: IN 1947, the United Nations Trusteeship Council re ceived a petition which viv idly described what used to happen to some young girls of the Bikum tribe in the Bamenda Province of what was then the British administered Cameroons.

title: Commodities: Traders Take Profits, Sending Corn Prices Down
description: Trading in soybeans and wheat futures settled into relatively tight range and most dealings were on a local or commercial basis on the Chi cago Board of Trade yesterday. Except for soybean oil, public participation was light in most commodities.

title: Senies Trim Warriors
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 29 (AP)  Dick Snyder's 24 points, 6 in the final quarter, sparked the Seattle Sonics to a 105101 vic tory over San Francisco to night, their first over the War riors in four games this season.

title: Colonels Sink Pipers, 122102
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 29 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels registered a 122102 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Pipers.

title: Aid for Power Plant
description: ACCRA, GhanaIncreased production and export of electric power from the Volta River Dam at Akosombo is being helped by some $15 million of financing by the World Bank, the United States, Canada and other donors. Installation of two additional generators will bring the power plant to its full capacity of 825 mega watts.

title: Mass Sports Movement May Return to China as Political Struggles Subside
description: PEKING  There are signs that the mass sports movement may be on its way back in Communist China.

title: Martin Finishing Up at Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 William McChesney Martin Jr. will preside tomorrow over his last meeting of the Federal Reserve Board after almost 19 years as Chairman of the body that governs the nation's central bank and makes the nation's monetary policy.

title: Arnerican Home Products Corp.
description: Record fourthquarter and an nual sales and earnings were posted by the American Home Products Corporation whose six major operating divisions con tributed with peak sales last year. William F. Laporte, chair man, also announced yesterday an increase in quarterly divi dend to 37 cents a share,)

title: Brightower Closes
description: Brightower, the new play by Dore Schary, which opened Wednesday night aL the John Golden Theater, closed after one performance. Robert Lan ing and Geraldine Brooks were costarred in the Michael Byron and Mel Weiser production.

title: A Discussion
description: To gain an insight Into the com plexities of economic development as they appear to Africans, a panel of four experts on Africa was brought together last month for a taperecorded discussion in Accra, Ghana.

title: Dance: Extension of Robbins's Ideas
description: JEROME ROBBINS offered us and the New York City Ballet another Chopin ballet at the New York State Thea ter last night, and nothing would be easier to suggest than that it is a simple spin off from last season's Chopin masterpiece, Dances at a Gathering. But great cho reographers repeat them selves but rarely, and then only by mistake.

title: Nicklaus Captures Lead by a Stroke With 65 in WilliamsSan Diego Open
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29Jack Nicklaus made it look easy to day by carding a 7underpar 65 that gave him the firstround lead by a stroke in the $150,000 Andy WilliamsSan Diego open tourney. The 30yearold Ohio an laughed when asked if he might repeat his victory of a year ago with spectacular golf during the next three days.

title: Last Vestige of Prague Spring
description: Almost exactly two years after Alexander Dubcek became First Secretary of the Czechoslovak Commu nist party, he has resigned from that party's Central Committee. Symbolically, his departure from his last party position marks the end of the remarkable period in Czechoslovak history that began when Mr. Dubcek replaced Antonin Novotny.

title: Tanzanian Development Moves Ahead
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tan zaniaHelped by a recovery in trade and a large inflow of foreign aid from both West and East, Tanzanian develop ment gained a momentum last year that promised to con tinue through 1970.

title: Don't Let Irritating Laxatives Aggravate Your Hemorrhoids!
description: New York. N.Y. (Special)Today, grateful thousands are hailing TONEI the unique laxative pill that helps make elimination more regular, thoroug?? comfortable! Andwithout undue strain, irri tation, or weakening aftereffects.

title: Japanese Auto Exports Up
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29 (Reuters) The Japanese motor vehicle in dustry raised exports in 1969 by 40.1 per cent to a record of 858,068 units, the Japan Auto mobile Industry Association said today. This was made up of 560,431 passenger cars, 290,872 trucks and 6,765 buses.

title: Con Edison Pleads Guilty to Polluting East River in 1968
description: The Consolidated Edison Company and the Van Iderstein Company, renderers of animal fats, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to charges of polluting New York City waterways.

title: FLORIDA DASH WON BY HOBEAU RACER
description: MIAMI, Jan. 29 (AP)  The Hobeau Farm's Knight Of The Road charged from last place to score an impressive victory today in the feature at Hialeah Park before a crowd of 14.691.

title: Cold Weather Forecast Keeps Weekend Ski Prospects Bright
description: Two days to go and all is well.

title: Flames Destroy 12 Buildings In Heart of Town in Vermont
description: SWANTON, Vt., Jan. 29 (UPI)  Flames spurred by high winds destroyed 12 buildings on five blocks of the business district today in this town on the Canadian border.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: STRIKE AUTHORIZED BY MACY'S WORKERS
description: The union representing 9,000 employes at six Macy's depart ment stores in the metropolitan area announced yesterday that members had authorized their leaders to call a strike.

title: DOW INDUSTRIALS NEARING 1966 LOW
description: Steady pressure on bluechip stocks drove the DowJones in dustrial average down 10.49 points yesterday to a final read ing of 748.35.

title: Metals Producers Set RecordsJ. & L. Posts a 20% Dip for Year
description: Earnings reports from the metals industry were mixed yesterday. While several pro ducers and fabricators of non ferrous metals set records in 1969, the nation's seventh larg est steel company suffered a 20 per cent drop in net income for the year and a loss for the fourth quarter.

title: Lawyer Is Winner Of $250,000 Prize In the State Lottery
description: Richard E. Landau, a young lawyer in a Manhattan firm, was selected yesterday as win ner of the $250,000 superprize in the New York State Lottery.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Pollution. President Nixon anounced the members of his new Council on Environ mental Quality. Russell E. Train, Under Secretary of the Interior Department, is chair man, and Robert Calm and Gordon J. F. MacDonald are the two other members.

title: Frederica Fairman to Be Wed In August to I. I. Marshall 3d
description: Mrs. John H. Pyle of Pasa dena, Calif., and Fred W. Fairman Jr. of New York have announced here the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Frederica Fairman, to John Irwin Marshall 3d, son Of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill. The wed ding will take place in Au gust.

title: Rhodesia Adjusts and Gains
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia Rhodesia has gone from very bad agricultural season to a very good one and seems likely to have increased its gross national product by at least 7 per cent over the last year.

title: Fairleigh Bows, 5852
Synagogue Honors Gen. Clay
description: Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retired, was honored yesterday for his compassion toward the Jews in liberated Germany during World War 11. At a convoca tion in the New York Chamber of Commerce building, 65 Lib erty Street, sponsored by the Wall Street Synagogue and a committee of bankers and bro kers, General Clay was given peace and humanitarian medallion inscribed in English and Hebrew.

title: UNICEF Is Sending Food And Medical Aid to Nigeria
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 29The United Nations Children's Fund, or UNICEFF, has chartered two planes tc fly 10 tons of special high protein food and 20 tons of medical supplies to Nigeria for children in the former Biafran region, a spokesman announced today.

title: Mr. Mort: High Style On Budget
description: STANLEY HERMAN sent hemlines tumbling down at Mr. Mort yesterday, and the world didn't come to an end. In fact, the long dresses looked pretty. The short dresses looked pretty, too.

title: WILLIAMS REBUFFED IN EXTRADITION BID
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29  Robert F. Williams, the black militant leader, lost a minor point to day in his battle against extra dition to North Carolina on a kidnapping charge.

title: Mitchell Urges the House To Act on Drug Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Attorney General John N. Mitchell urged the House today to act quickly on a major drug control bill that cleared the Senate 82 to 0 yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
METEORITE ASSAY STIRS NEW THEORY
description: CHICAGO. Jan. 29Analysis of a meteorite recently found in France has led to a sug gestion that a great stellar ex plosion may have accompanied, or immediately preceded, the formation of the solar system. This has been calculated by Dr. Gerald J. Wasserburg of the California Institute of Tech nology.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE SHOWS 7.6% DROP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Intercity truck tonnage and freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Jan. 24 were both below the corresponding week last year.

title: STOCKS PRICES DROP ON LONDON MARKET
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned slightly lower yesterday in slow trading. Aus tralian issues rallied after ini tial weakness.

title: Egyptians See Aswan as Money Reservoir
description: CAIRO  The mammoth Aswan High Dam, a billion dollar venture that some skeptics thought could not be built and others said should not be built, will be put into full operation this year and become a pillar of the Egyptian economy.

title: Tunis Optimistic Despite Flood Damage
description: TUNIS  Two major events affected the economy of Tunisia and indeed the lives of her 4.7 million people in 1969: The September October floods and a major shift in agricultural policy.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE polished machinery of Iris Mur doch's 13th novel spins around a wager. All human beings have stag geringly great faults which can easily be exploited by a clever observer, says Julius King, ne Kahn, a biologist who has just divorced himself from the biological war fare game on the principle that while people don't deserve to survive, they are destroying them selves quite fast enough without my assistance. Ev eryman loves him self so astronomi cally more than he loves his neighbor. Anyone can be made to drop any one. . . . Would you like a demonstra tion? All right, why not? replies Morgan Foster, fe brile, quasifemale Murdoch heroine, exlover of Julius, shaky on the emotional pins, brighteyed adventuress and philological scholar. You're completely mad, of course. But whoever could you try it on? It must be people we both know.

title: Sentenced for Nixon Threat
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 29 (AP)A young marine from New York, John Edward Haley, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison today for threat ening the life of President Nixon. He was sentenced under the Federal juvenile statute be cause he was 17 when threat ening letters were written to the President last summer.

title: Africa, Too, Has a Hot Mutual Fund
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  Business, says 33 yearold David Abramson un derstatedly, is a most pleas ant way of occupying the day.

title: REA Express Guard Accused of 12 Years of Looting
description: For 12 years Ernest H. Nelson nursed a grudge against his employer, the REA Express, and according to the police yester day, he worked it off stealing from shipments entrusted to the company.

title: Directory to Dining On Japanese Food
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

title: Governor Discloses Penn Central Plans At a G.O.P. Dinner
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced last night a longrange capital improvement plan for the Harlem and Hudson divi sions of the Penn Central, one quarter of which is to be paid for by the railroad and the re mainder by the $2.5billion mass transportation bond issue of 1967.

title: PRESIDENTS TO GET A MUSIC LIBRARY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The first official White House music library for this and fu ture Presidents and their fami lies, perhaps the finest ever assembled, was announced to day.

title: ADDICTION FOUGHT IN BUSINESS RANKS
description: The president of the Com merce and Industry Association of New York indicated yester day that there was a narcotics addiction problem in business offices, too. He compared in dustry'l recently acquired awareness of it to the discovery in the nineteenfifties that al coholism wasn't limited to hums on the Bowery.

title: Dirksen Honor Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Senate Public Works Committee approved today bill to name two Federal build ings in Chicago for the late Senator Everett McKinley Dirk sen, Republican of Illinois. They are the Federal office building and courthouse already completed and an office build ing yet to be constructed.

title: RABELAIS BOOKED INTO CITY CENTER
