description: JeanLouis Barrault, an out standing figure in the French theater, is bringing his produc tion, Rabelais, to the Cite Center Theater for an engage ment of 16 performances be ginning May 19 and ending May 31.

title: A Sturdy Kenya Builds on Capitalism
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  For the 10.8 million Kenyans enumerated in a population census last August, 1969 was, economically, a year of truth.

title: CONSUMERS POWER LISTS RECORD SALES.
description: The Consumers Power Com pany reported yesterday record sales of electricity and gas for 1969. Net income was above the 1968 level.

title: MAXWELL E. KAPS
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 29 Maxwell E. maps, a commis sioner of the North Jersey Water Supply District for the last six years and previously a legal counsel to the New Jersey State Assembly, died yesterday at the Jersey City Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived at 82 Tonnelle Avenue here.

title: Fuentes, Pilot RightHander, Is Dead of Gunshot Wounds
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 29 (AP)Miguel Fuentes, 22 year  old right  handed pitcher for the Seattle Pilots, died today la gunshot wounds received in a bar at Loiza Aldea, his home town 20 miles east of San Juan.

title: Driver Scores With a 67Cent Win Bet
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 29 Bill Dawkins rolled the money through his fingers this morning at Roosevelt Raceway. He had scored with a 100to1 shot, named Effi cient. He drove the pacer to a $215.60 payoff last night in the ninth race to set up the largest exacta in metropoli tan harness racing history $1.282.60.

title: Order Challenged
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the Hartford Fire Insurance Com pany and three of Hartford Fire's stockholders have filed suit in Superior Court in Hart ford, Conn., to set aside the recent order of the Connecticut Insurance Commissioner bar ring the $1.5billion acquisition of Hartford Fire by I.T.T.

title: Fagin Suspect, Father of Four, Arrested in Boys' Narcotics Ring
description: A man suspected of being Fagin who employed boys from 11 to 15 years of age who were arrested Tuesday for sell ing heroin in Coney Island, was taken into custody yesterday and charged with criminal pos session of dangerous drugs for sale.

title: Francis Irate at Goal Ruling
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 Still smoldering over the dis puted lastsecond goal that provided the Los Angeles Kings with a 54 victory last night, Emile Francis, the gen eral manager and coach of the New York Rangers, con tended today that an im proper red goallight system existed in The Forum.

title: PRICES STILL SKID IN BOND MARKETS
description: Big corporations continued to announce major financing pro grams, and bond prices con tinued to skid yesterday.

title: Governor Is Seeking to Avert Bankruptcy in the Arts
description: New York State's or chestras, operas, dance com panies, museums and other cultural organizations face a combined deficit this year of $70million.

title: Lawyer Seized in Theft
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 29 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today that a California lawyer had been arrested at Brownsville, Tex., in the theft of $460,000 in municipal bonds. He was identified as Patrick Stephen Murray Mitton, 48 years old, of Escondido, Calif. He was held on charges of unlawful

title: 4 U.S. AGENTS POSED AS SAIGON NEWSMEN
description: SAIGON, Jan. 29 (AP)Four United States Government in vestigatorsnot twowere in filtrated into the Saigon press corps to spy on the newsmen, official sources conceded today.

title: 13th Law Day Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) President Nixon issued prolamation today designating Friday, May 1, as the 13th An nual Law Day, U.S.A.

title: U.S. Rail Strike Possible As Talks Are Suspended
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Negotiators for the nation's railroads and four shopcraft unions broke off a series of contract talks today. A nation wide rail shutdown by Monday appeared possible.

title: Central African Republic Seeks a Port
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic  The Central Afri can Republic suffers consid erably front its geographical location.

title: Westinghouse and Budd Get Sao Paulo Subway Contract
description: Officials of the Westinghouse Electric International Corpora tion said yesterday that an American consortium including Westinghouse and the Budd Corporation had signed a con tract to supply 198 subway cars for the new transit system of Sao Paulo. Brazil.

title: Miss Joya Utermohlen, Skater, Engaged to Lieut. Robert Jenks
description: The engagement of Miss Joya Utermohlen to Lieut. Robert Darrah Jenks, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Meylan Jenks of Wilton, Conn., and the late Edward North Jenks, has been announced by the fu ture bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Theodoor Uter mohlen of New York.

title: . . . No Place for Haste . . .
description: The Public Service Commission, long a dumping ground for brokendown Republican politicians, finally being reouganized to make it an effective protector of the public interest. Unfortunately, at the very start of that shakeup, the commission finds itself obliged to rush out a decision on the New York Tele phone Company's application for $175 million in rate increases.

title: CUITE UPBRAIDS 2 COUNTY CHIEFS
description: Two of the city's Democratic county leaders were accused yesterday of instrusion into the affairs of the City Council.

title: Cameroon Young but Mature
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon  One of Africa's quiet coun tries, the Federal Republic of Cameroon completed a decade of independence last year with two major achieve ments to its credit.

title: Lady Furness of Morgan Twins, Society Figures, Is Dead at 65
description: Lady Furness, the former Thelma Morgan and twin of the late Mrs. Reginald Vanderbilt, collapsed and died yesterday in Manhattan while on the way to a doctor's office. She was 65 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Blues Down Kings, 32
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI)Phil Goyette, the West ern Division's leading scorer, tallied two goals tonight, in cluding the decider with 10:47 remaining to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 32 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings. Goyette now has 20 goals for the sea son and 55 points, fourth best over all in the National Hockey League.

title: Morocco Battling Drought
description: RABAT, MoroccoSince disaster to Morocco's agricul tural economy is always pos sible because of drought, at tempts to insure against the vagaries of climate will con tinue to get top priority in the Government's planning. This will focus especially on the construction of dams and irrigation networks.

title: French Money Reserves Up by 57Million Francs
description: PARIS, Jan. 29 (Reuters) The Bank of France said today France's gold and convertible currency reserves rose by 57 million francs in the week to Jan. 22.

title: Carswell Called Foe of Women's Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  G. Harrold Carswell was ac cused today of harboring not only racist beliefs but also sexist views in opposition to equal rights for women.

title: Retailers Report Substantial Gains
description: Four of the country's largest retail companies reported yes terday substantial sales gains for January over the yearago month.

title: U.S. Denies Violation
description: PARIS, Jan. 29The United States affirmed today that it sends reconnaissance planes over North Vietnam with fighter escorts, but denied that this violated the 1968 understand ing that halted the bombing raids.

title: Bethlehem Steel Appoints 7 Officers to New Posts
description: The Bethelehem Steel Corpo ration announced seven ap pointments in steel operations and sales yesterday.

title: Gaither Resigns as Coach
description: TALLAHASSEE. Fla., Jan. 29 (UPI)Alonzo S. (Jake) Gaither' who overcame brain tumors, blindness, a broken leg and a new breed of socially aware black athletes to build a foot ball power at Florida A. & M. University, resigned today after 25 years as the Rattlers' head football coach.

title: Portugal Steps Up Colonial Spending
description: LISBON  A major hy droelectric project now un der construction in western Mozambique is expected to provide enough cheap elec tric power for the develop ment of much of southern Af rica during the 1970's.

title: Laboratory Tests Clear Oil Industry Of Louisiana Spill
description: BATON ROUGE, Jan. 30 (AP)The petroleum industry was not responsible for the oil spill that coated Grand Isle beaches last Sunday, the Loui siana Stream Control Commis sion said yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: THE simplest hands to bid are often the hardest to play, and vice versa. Bidding to a grand slam requires good partnership undertanding and judgment, but the play is gen erally straightforward. Con versely, a onelevel contract is easy to reach but can of fer many varations in the play.

title: Justice Gets Driving Permit
description: CARSON CITY, Nev. Jan. 30 (AP)Nevada Supreme Court! Chief Justice Jon Collins, whose driver's license was suspended for six months for refusing a: blood alcohol test, has been !given a restricted driving per mit. The permit will allow the 16yearold justice, who lives in Reno, to drive to and from work.

title: Preserving Press Diversity
description: The Senate has passed overwhelmingly the News paper Preservation Act. But, even before the bill goes to the House, the need for any such measure has been rendered extremely dubious by Federal Court approval in Tucson of a joint publishing arrangement for the separately owned morning and afternoon papers that Arizona city.

title: Bus Terminal Manager Resigns After 22 Years
description: Lee C. Webb, manager of the Port of New York Au thority's bus station at the George Washington Bridge, retired this week after 22 years with the bistate agency. He has held his pres ent job for seven years, and before that he was the first manager of the bus terminal at Eighth Avenue and 41st Street.

title: PRESIDENT COUNTS ON NEGRO SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  In hopeful phrases that recalled one of the earliest news con ferences of his Presidency. President Nixon expressed the belief tonight that, in time, he could win the respect and al le lance of the black commun ity.

title: WALL ST. DIP HITS MARKETS ABROAD
description: PARIS, Jan. 30  An icy wind has whistled over many security markets of the world this month, influenced to some extent by the frigid tempera tures in Wall Street.

title: Pan Am Uses Hijack Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Federal Administration said today that Pan American World Airways had become the third airline to use an elec tronic antihijacking system de veloped and tested by the agen cy. Eastern Airlines and Trans World Airlines already use the detection device.

title: AN ITALIAN NEWSMAN EXPELLED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30The So viet Union today ordered the expulsion of Ennio Carretto, the Moscow correspondent for La Stampa of Milan, Italy, for what it termed violation of the norms of foreign journal ists in the Soviet Union.

title: 8 Banks Set for Bahamas
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved applications by eight banks to establish branch es in Nassau, the Bahamas, it was announced yesterday. They are the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company, the Ameri can Security and Trust Com pany, the First National Bank of Memphis, the First National Bank of St. Paul, the Liberty National Bank and Trust Com pany, the Bank of the South west, the SeattleFirst National Bank, and the Valley National Bank of Arizona.

title: Tensions Rising in BrownstoneEviction Disputes
description: A snug, baywindowed brownstone half a block west of Central Park has become the battleground for a fierce struggle between a group of tenants and their landlord. The weapons: fists, threats, va grants, broken locks, intermit tent heat, mysterious phone calls in the middle of the night.

title: Ellen J. Rubinstein To Marry in Paris
description: Miss Ellen Judith Rubin stein, a reference librarian with McGrawHill, Inc., here, and Allison Franklin Butts plan to be married next month in Paris, where the future bridegroom is a law yer with the New York firm of Hughes, Hubbard & Reed.

title: Rabin Denies Aim of Israeli Raids Is to Oust Nasser
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Yitz hak Rabin, the Israeli Ambassa dor to the United States, insisted today that his nation's recent air strikes on the outskirts of Cairo were aimed principally at persuading the United Arab Re public to curtail its artillery and commando raids across the Suez Canal and at convincing the Egyptian people that their country was not capable of launching largescale military operations against Israel.

title: Hanoi Aide Rules Out Any Forced Concessions
description: PARIS, Jan. 31 (UPI)The chief adviser of the North Vietnamese delegation at the peace talks here returned to day from consultations in Hanoi and said that his Gov ernment was ready for seri ous negotiations. However, he said that Hanoi would make no concessions at the negotiating table under United States military pres sure.

title: Environmental Pathfinders
description: President Nixon has appointed a firstrate team for his Council on Environmental Quality, newly created by Congress. Russell E. Train, its chairmandesignate, is a distinguished veteran of the environmental wars. tie served as president of the Conservation Foundation before becoming Under Secretary of the Interior. Gordon J. F. MacDonald, who had already been named to head the National Academy of Sciences' environ mental study board, is a respected scholar and an expert on the kind of oil pollution that made a mess of Santa Barbara. And Robert Cahn, Washington corespondent for The Christian Science Monitor, has done an outstanding job of reporting and analyzing environmental questions. He won a Pulitzer Prize in the process.

title: CHARGE OF PERJURY DENIED BY FREYBERG
description: Michael Freyberg, a former president of the city Tax Com mission, denied yesterday that he had attempted to influence a City Planning Commission de cision by bribery.

title: Sergei J. Denham Dead at 73; Was Director of the Ballet Russe
description: Sergei J. Denham, director of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo from 1938 until the mid nineteensixties, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital. Mr Denham was injured Thursday night when he was struck by a bus at Madison Avenue and 57th Street. He was 73 years old and lived at 1200 Fifth Avenue.

title: Vatican Says Dutch Hierarchy Challenges the Pope
description: ROME, Jan. 30  A French cardinal charged today that the attack on clerical celibacy, led by the Dutch branch of the Roman Catholic church, had as its real aim the undermining of Papal authority and reduc tion of the church to deca dence.

title: Amy S. Kessler, Student, to Wed
description: Miss Amy Suzzanne Kess ler, a doctoral student in the history of art at Cornell University, plans to be mar ried to Elliott Stephen Lew itt, a senior in the honors program at Hobart College in Geneva. N. Y.

title: A Shattered Illusion
description: The illusion that the Middle East could go on indefinitely in a more or less tolerable state of nowar, nopeace has been shattered this week along with the windows of Haifa and Damascus where Israeli and Syrian jets exchanged ominous feints.

title: HENRY FERRIES
description: MADISON, N. J., Jan. 30 Henry Stark Ferriss of 133 Green Village Road, a lawyer for 14 years for the Title Guar anty Trust Company in New York City, died yesterday at his home after a short illness. His age was 72.

title: HOWARD A. MARPLE
description: WALDOBORO, Me., Jan. 30 Howard A. Marple, retired head of the public relations depart ment of the Monsanto Company of St. Louis died in a hospital yesterday at the ape of 70.

title: Talks Collapse in Strike by Cincinnati's Employes
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 30All night talks aimed at ending a fourweek strike of city em ployes collapsed early today.

title: Article 1  No Title
ATOMICPLANT FEAR DEPLORED BY A.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) The Atomic Energy Commis sion reported today that con struction of new nuclear plants for peaceful uses did not fare very well in 1969 and said one major reason was public fear of such installations.

title: Democrats Plan Magazine
description: A group of individuals asso ciated with the 1968 presiden tial campaigns of Senator Eu gene J. McCarthy and the late Robert F. Kennedy plans to publish a monthly magazine dealing with liberal and reform ideas within the Democratic Party. The magazine. The New Democrat, is to be edited by Stephen Schlesinger, the 27 yearold son of Arthur M. Schle singer Jr., the historian. Mr. Schlesinger said yesterday that at present we're in the midst of a fundraising campaign, but that the first issue should anpear in April or May.

title: Negro Proposed for a Seat on Exchange
description: Joseph Louis Searles 3d re signed yesterday as a member of the Lindsay administration and was then proposed for membership on the New York Stock Exchange. If he is ap proved, as is expected, he will become the first Negro to hold a seat on the nation's leading securities market.

title: Nixon to Decide in Month On Israel's Arms Requests
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  While insisting that he was not partial to either side in the continuing conflict in the Mid dle East, President Nixon said this evening that he would decide within a month how many more weapons the United States would sell to Israel.

title: HELPWANTED INDEX CONTINUES TO DROP
description: Industry's quest for employes continues to lag, according to the National Industrial Confer ence Board. The board's help wanted advertising index in December dropped for the third consecutive month to 216 per cent of the 19571959 aver age, a decline of 6 points from the November figure and 9 points under the level of De cember, 1968.

title: SitandCook Barbecue Can Serve 12
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30A Connecticut family of eight was granted a patent this week for a barbecue at which all eight can sit down to cook and eat.

title: New Shows Add to Casts
description: Performers for two forthcom ing shows were signed yester day. Cathryn Damon will have a featured role in the new Lee ThunaKenneth JacobsonRhoda Roberts musical, Show Me Where the Good Times Are, opening March 5.

title: George Munson Fiance Of Victoria T. Kilbourn
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Van Dusen Kilbourn have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Tucker Kilbourn, to George Rice Munson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Townsend Munson of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: NEWTON D. RICH
description: WINTER PARK, Fla., Jan. 30 Newton Dyckman Rich, for mer president and board chair man of the L. E. Myers Com pany, a Chicago contracting company, died of a heart at tack at his home, 400 Lake wood Drive here, yesterday morning. He was 78 years old.

title: EAST COAST STATES REPORT FLU CASES
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Outbreaks of influenza and in fluenzalike illnesses in the East Coast states of Connecti cut Georgia and Florida were reported today by the National Communicable Disease Center.

title: RAIL TIEUP BEGINS ON UNION PACIFIC
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Jan. 31A strike against Union Pacific Railroad started at mid night last night and industry spokesmen said they would move to shut down the nation's entire rail network.

title: STOCKS RETREAT ON LONDON BOARD
Counseling Ordered for Samuels Son in Drug Case
description: Howard J. Samuels Jr., 17 yearold son of a contender for Governor, went to Manhat tan Criminal Court yesterday morning to face the same kind of charges brought each month's against hundreds of other New York youths.

title: Governor Seeks to Extend School Vote
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30Governor Rockefeller asked the Legisla ture today to extend for two weeks the period of voter reg istration for the New York City local school board elections. They are scheduled to end to morrow night.

title: Big Board Plunges To a SixYear Low
7 PANTHERS CITED BY CHICAGO JURY
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30  The seven Black Panthers who sur vived a predawn police raid here were indicted today on charges of attempted murder.

title: Egyptians Deny Report Of Nasser Visit to Soviet
description: CAIRO, Jan. 30 (AP)Egyp tian oficials today denied a report that President Gamal Abdel Nasser had made a secret visit to Moscow last week The report of the visit was printed today in The New York Times in a dispatch from Beirut, Lebanon.

title: Norman Thomas Award Presented to Union Chief
description: Paul Jennings, president of the International Union of Elec trical Workers, which is on strike against the General Elec tric Company, received last, night the first Norman Thomas Award presented by the So cialist Party, U.S.A.

title: Karen Budge Is 6th
description: GARMISHPARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 30 (AP)Fran coise Macchi led the French women on another victorious ski run in the KandaharWorld Cup downhill today, but their performance failed to detract from the best United States' showing of the season.

title: Music: Kuerti Recital
description: THREEFOURTHS of Anton Kuerti's recital in Alice Tully Hall last night was spent on largescale works. The other fourth was devoted to the 12 etudes that make up Chopin's Op. 25, and it was in these relatively short pieces that the pianist was in his element.

title: A Romney May Enliven Michigan Election Year
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30  We need a riproaring campaign, said Sander Levin, a 3Syear old Democratic State Senator who is today's best bet to chal lenge Michigan's Governor in November.

title: Constance Meyer, Alan Buerger Engaged
description: Miss Constance Meyer, a fashion coordinator with Al lied Graphic Arts, Inc., here, plans to be married in June to Alan H. Buerger, a student at Columbia.

title: N.B.C. Employe's Fined
description: CHICAGO, (AP)A former broadcasting network employe was fined $1,000 today for hid ing a microphone in a room where a committee at the Democratic National Conven tion of 1968 was meeting. Miss Enid Roth, 38 years old, of New York City pleaded nolo contendere, by which she re fused to admit or contest a Federal charge of illegal elec tronic interception of commu nications.

title: DENTON BUTT
description: OLD LYME, Conn., Jan. 30 (UPI)Denton Butt, a radio and television announcer and actor, died Wednesday. He was 68 years old.

title: Long Island Bank Deal Set
description: The Long Island Trust Com pany of Garden City and the Island State Bank of Patch ogue announced yesterday a plan to merge. The $277mil lion Long Island Trust would exchange its shares on an as yet undetermined basis for those of Island State, a $40 million institution. In a sep arate development, the Federal Reserve Board denied yester day for anticompetitive rea sons an application for the merger of the Bank of West bury Trust Company into Long Island Trust.

title: 5 Queens Stores Burned
description: A threealarm fire severely damaged five stores on Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, Queens yes terday. The blaze started in card shop at 17231 Hillside Avenue, fire officials said, and spread to neighboring stores, including a laundry, a liquor Istore and a delicatessen. No injuries were reported.

title: 23 at Metropolitan Museum Picket Over Park Plans
description: Twentythree people protest ing further building expansion in Central Park last night pick eted a private reception held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in honor of Arthur A. Houghton Jr., chairman of the board, and C. Douglas Dillon, the president.

title: January Weather Here 10 Degrees Subnormal
description: Temperatures during Jan uary were more than 10 de grees below normal, the Weather Bureau said yester day in a summary for the month.

title: Nets Win and Snap Rockets' Streak at 15
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 30Unable to generate the mo mentum for the fastbreaking game that had given them 15 straight victories, the Denver Rockets bowed tonight, 11598, to the New York Nets, a club they expected to rout.

title: BERKELEY NAMES A NEGRO MILITANT
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 30 Harry Edwards, who as a Negro militant tried to organize an Olympics boycott in 1968, was appointed today as an unten ured member of the sociology faculty at the University of California.

title: WASHINGTON SENATE VOTES FOR ABORTION
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Jan. 30 (AP)The Washington State Senate passed today a bill legal izing abortion after adding amendments that might run into opposition in the House.

title: American Who Jumped Bail In U.S. and Israel to Return
description: ATHENS, Jan. 30Richard C. Scott, an American who jumped bail on marijuana charges two years ago in Cali fornia, asked American consu lar authorities in Athens, where he was arrested Wednesday, to send him back home.

title: 2 Companies Admit Polluting Harbor; Each Is Fined $750
description: NEWARK, Jan. 30Two of 13 companies accused of pol luting the tributary waters of New York Harbor pleaded guilty in Federal Court here today and were fined $750 each.

title: Cochran Joins Chargers
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) John (Red) Cochran, a National Football League coach of 13 years, was appointed today of fensive backfield coach of the San Diego Chargers. Cochran replaces Charlie Waller, who was promoted to head coach during midseason.

title: CAB. CUTS FARES ON MOST AIRLINES
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered a 6.35 per cent rollback in most domestic air fares yes terday after the nation's larg 1 est domestic airlines rejected a new faresplitting plan pro posed by the C.A.B.

title: Market Place
description: PASSENGERS on Penn Cen tral commuter cars con tinue to fume over a Butcher & Sherrerd recommendation of the railroad's stock men tioned in this column on Jan. 9.

title: CATV CURB IMPOSED ION PHONE COMPANIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The Federal Communications Commission announced today that telephone companies may not sell cabletelevision service directly to consumers in areas where they provide phone serv ice.

title: Nixon Says Carswell's Speech Would Not Have Barred Choice
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  President Nixon said tonight that he would still have nom inated G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court if he had known that he had espoused white supremacy in a 1948 po litical speech [Question 7, Page 14.]

title: Lincoln Hospital Faced With TakeOver
description: Lincoln Hospital, which serves 350,000 people in a pre dominantly Puerto Rican and Negro neighborhood in the South Bronx, was threatened yesterday with a takeover Monday morning by its com munity advisory board.

title: FRANCIS DONALDSON, ENGINEER, 88, DEAD
description: Francis Donaldson, vice pres ident and a director of Mason & HangerSilas Mason Co., Inc., engineers and contractors of 500 Fifth Avenue, died Wednes day at his home, 7 Tanglewylde Avenue, Bronxville, N. Y. His age was 88.

title: Sports of The Times
description: YOU want me to sign something? asked Casey Stengel. I work here, said the hotel maintenance man; tentatively offering a pen and a scratch pad. Cost you four . . . teen . . . thou . . . sand dollars, said Stengel.

title: U.S. Flag Design on Car Leads to Arrest in Corning
description: CORNING, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) State police arrested Allen Smith of Hinsdale today on a charge of contemptuous dis play of the American flag be cause his small foreign car was painted with stars and stripes.

title: Mobil Orders Tanker
description: A 126,000ton tanker de signed to carry 930,000 barrels of crude oil from the Alaskan port of Valdez to the nation's West Coast will be built for the Mobil Oil Corporation. The ves sel, scheduled for delivery in 1972, will be built by the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Corn pany, Chester, Pa. The price was not disclosed.

title: Aide of Brandt Confers With Gromyko 6 Hours
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (Reu ters)  Egon Bahr, a close adviser of Chancellor Willy Brandt, spent six hours with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today discussing the prospects for a nonag gression treaty.

title: Freedom for Debray Urged
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Argentina's writers asked President Alfredo Ovando Candi today to free Regis De bray, the 29yearold French writer who was sentenced to 30 years of prison for his al leged participation in the guer rilla movement led by Ernesto Che Guevara three years ago.

title: 3 CHOREOGRAPHERS SHOW THEIR WORKS
description: The choreographers Rosalind Pierson. Margaret Beals and Carla de Bola are quite dis similar temperamentally, but they shared a program and a highly similar approach to choreography last night at Cooper Union Great Hall. Each decided to mirror closely in movement the musical or spoken accompaniment to her dances. The results generally lacked imaginative subtlety.

title: SPECIALISTS SCAN 1970 NEW ISSUES
Banco de Ponce Expanding Here
description: Almost 10 years ago, when the Banco de Ponce became the first Puerto Rican hank to open a branch in New York City, the banking establishment here watched with interest as the newcomer moved in where other banks had feared to tread.

title: JAPAN'S SURPLUS TOPS $2BILLION
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30Japan reg istered a record suplus of $2.28billion in its international payments balance in 1969, the Government reported today.

title: Nixon Invites Baltimore Boy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Jimmie Holland, 12 years old, of Baltimore, who is suf fering from leukemia, will be a guest of President Nixon this Sunday at services in the East Room of the White House. The service will be conducted by. Dr. Mannie Lee Wilson, pastor of the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in New York and Presi dent of the New York Council of Churches. He will be the first Negro minister to conduct services at the White House.

title: BUCKS TURN BACK BULLS BY 121105
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) Lew Alcindor tallied 27 points as the Milwaukee Bucks breezed to a 121105 victory over the Chicago Bulls in a National Basketball Association game to night.

title: Windward Passage Ahead In Florida Yachting Race
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)The 73foot ketch Windward Passage, the scratch boat, moved to a fourminute lead tonight in the St. Peters burgtoVenice race opening the Southern Ocean Racing Conference season.

title: VON RUDER CLIPS RECORD IN 1,000
description: The quartermile may be too short for Marty McGrady and the halfmile too long, but the 600 is just right.

title: What Awaits Mr. Rogers
description: KANO, NigeriaWhen he sets off shortly on his African trip, Secretary of State Rogers will quickly observe a fundamental truth, obvious enough but nev ertheless impressive when seen for oneself: Black Africa is not a homogeneous place but a col lection of territories that vary enormously in their qualities and their problems.

title: Theater: A Smooth and Elegant Brass Butterfly
but Trouble on the Rails
description: The strike begun early today by the railroad shop craft unions represents an outrageous abuse of power by a minority of a minority in rail labor. The tragedy is that all labor is likely to pay a heavy price public indignation if the shoperafts persist in their arbitrary rejection of Secretary of Labor Shultz's plea Far a weeklong truce to explore new peace avenues.

title: AMERICAN IS NAMED TO HEAD PERGAMON
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) An American was named to day to direct Pergamon Press, Ltd., a publishing group for merly headed by a British mil lionaire. Robert Maxwell.

title: CRIME FORCE HERE CRACKS DRUG RING
description: The first major crackdown by the Federal anticrime strike force in Brooklyn has brought about the seizure of $175,000 worth of illegal cocaine and the breaching of an international cocainesmuggling ring, Federal authorities announced yester day.

title: Stomp Closing for 2 Weeks
description: Stomp, the musical at the New York Shakespeare Festi val's Public Theater, will take twoweek vacation starting Mon day. Performances will be re sumed Feb. 17.

title: CHRYSLER REPORTS LOSS FOR QUARTER
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30  The Chrysler Corporation today re ported a loss for its fourth quarter of $4.4million, or 10 cents a share, dropping net in come in all 1969 to $88.8 million, or $1.87 a share.

title: NEGROES AN ISSUE IN F15 CONTRACT
description: The Secretary of the Air Force, Robert C. Seamans Jr., went to St. Louis yesterday to seek assurance from the Mc DonnellDouglas Corporation, the recent winner of a $1.1 billion plane contract, that it would comply with Federal nondiscriminatory employment policies.

title: AMEX PRICES SLIP IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices continued to drop yes terday on the American Stock Exchange in slow trading.

title: Barnes Testifies on Che!
description: Clive Barnes, drama critic of The New York Times, testified yesterday that the play Che! was low in quality but still retained redeeming social val ues and should not be closed on obsenity grounds. Mr. Barnes said that the play was essentially political. Testimony had to be curtailed when one of the defendants, 23yearold Mary Shelley, complained of feeling ill. Mr. Barnes was asked to return Monday morn ing for further testimony.

title: Vermont Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  Fireravaged Swanton, Vt., was designated a disaster area today by the Small Business Administration. The designa tion permits owners of homes, business, churches and charit able institutions whose prop erty was damaged or destroyed to apply for reconstruction or rehabilitation loans at 3 per cent interest. The business dis trict of the town was almost completely destroyed by fire on Wednesday.

title: Miss Palumbo, G.E.K. Smith Jr. Plan Marriage
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 30 Miss Ernestina Sylvia Palum bo and G. E. Kidder Smith Jr. of San Francisco plan to marry in France in March at MarlyleRoi, near Paris.

title: Commodities: Cotton Futures Mixed
description: Cotton futures closed mixed yesterday in a steady market. Early in the day there was commission house buying, but prices eased later as liquidation increased.

title: Lesotho Leader Arrests Opponent After Election
description: MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 30 The Prime Minister of Lesotho declared a state of emergency today and arrested his leading political opponent, who had just claimed victory in the first gen eral election since indepen dence in 1966.

title: Klein May Curb Advance Access to Data
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The White House, unhappy about the premature publication of details from President Nixon's annual Economic Report in The Washington Post today, will reconsider whether to continue the practice of giving economic writers an advance look at such comlpicated docu ments.

title: A Troop Ship Heads for Mothball Fleet
description: The first vessel in a small and still active United States] fleet of troop ships sailed into oblivion yesterday.

title: Art: 2 Men's Dazzlin Abstractions
description: THE reigning school of color abstraction in con temporary American painting has developed, in recent years, into a curious amal gam of hedonistic visual sen sation and dispassionate (not to say cold) intellectual anal ysis. Color in the most deli cious combinations fills the spectator's field of vision, yet the forms containing this color are clearly arrived at by a process of intellectual deduction far removed from the dictates of feeling. Often these forms seem hardly ar rived at through any process of pictorial decision. They suggest, at times, the work ings of a computer that has been overfed some stray geo metrical data.

title: AL HATTAB FAILS AT HIALEAH AGAIN
description: MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP)  Al Hattab, an odds  on favorite, was beaten again today, tiring in the final strides to finish third as Ghost Train nosed out Futura Bold at Hialeah. En tered against lesser company, the crowd of 14,254 made Al Hattab the 35 choice and he looked like a winner when he turned for home with a clear lead.

title: MASTER VIRTUOSI OPENS ITS SEASON
description: The Master Virtuosi of New York opened a special truncated season at Philharmonic Hall at night a few months after having announced there would he none at all. At the end of last season, this chamber or chestra conducted by Gene For roll found itself with a loyal audience of subscribers but no Maecenas to pay the inevitable concert deficits for 196970.

title: CITY TEAM CITES SUBWAY DECLINE
description: A special survey by the city's Transportation Administration reported yesterday that the sub ways were intolerably dirty, sometimes unsafe and often so late that fewer and fewer people were using the system.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
MRS. R. A. DUCHARME JR.
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 30  Mrs. Madeline Fortin Ducharme, wife of Dr. Raymond A. Ducharme Jr., associate pro fessor of education at Smith College and formerly assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University died yes terday here aftera brief illness. She was 39 years old.

title: Czech Leader Promises No Show Trials
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 30  Dr. Gus tav Husak, the Communist party chief, assured Czechoslo vaks today that the party would not degrade itself by staging show trials of pro eressives.

title: BARNETT GETS 26 FOR NEW YORKERS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 After breezing into the final 10 minutes of play with a seeming ly insurmountable 18point lead, the New York Knickerbockers almost dissipated all assets and had to battle to subdue the Philadelphia 76ers, 104100, to night before 13,191 fans, the Spectrum's largest National Basketball Association crowd of the season.

title: Brandt, Ending 100 Days, Spurs Domestic Reforms
description: BONN, Jan. 30Chancellor Willy Brandt has marked his hundredth day in office with a significant domesticpolicy, decision by his Cabinet to liberalize West Germany's laws against political demonstrators.

title: Boycott of Brooklyn School Protests Teacher Cutback
description: More than 400 of the 669 pupils at Public School, 226 23d Avenue and 60th Street in Brooklyn, were absent yes terday because of a parent organized boycott protesting reduction in the teaching staff.

title: Gains in Cup Standing
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Jan. 30 (AP)  Gustavo Thoeni, Italy's 18yearold Al pine skiing expert, closed in on Patrick Russel of France, the World Cup leader, by winning the giant slalom today for his second consecutive victory.

title: U.S. Denies Agents Posed as Newsmen To Spy on the Press
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30The United States Mission said in a statement issued here today that four agents fraudu lently accredited as newsmen had been on a mission com pletely unrelated to the local Vietnamese and foreign press corps or their activities.

title: VANDALS ATTACK MACKELL'S HOME
description: Vandals made a predawn foray on the home of Queens istrict Attorney Thomas J. Mackell yesterday, breaking a window and spraypainting two slogans  Off Pig Mackell and Free the Panther 21 or There Will Be White Riots.

title: Hedy Lamarr Suit Dismissed
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 (UPI) A $5million suit filed by Hedy Lamarr against a depart ment store, charging false ar rest for shoplifting in 1966, has been dismissed in Superior Court here. A court commis sioner ruled yesterday that the 55yearold acress failed to prosecute the suit against the May Company.

title: The Man Who Mediated the 95Day G.E. Strike
description: THIRTY years ago a Uni versity of Southern Cali fornia law student and a young Duke University law school graduate, whose girl friends were roommates, be came acquainted at a party following the U.S.C. Duke Rose Bowl game. Since then, the two couples have mar ried and become close personal friends. Last year, the Duke graduate, Richard M. Nixon, was inaugurated as President of the United States. And seven days later the former U.S.C. student, J. Curtis Counts, was picked to be director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: LAWREN HARRIS, 85, A CANADIAN PAINTER
description: VANCOUVER, B. C., Jan. 30 Lawren Harris, a member of the Group of Seven, Canadian painters who joined in the 1920's in an effort to develop a distinct Canadian style, died yesterday at his home here. He was 85 years old.

title: Plan to Void Election of Boyle Denied by Labor Department
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Labor Department described as premature today a report that it was considering invalidating the reelection of W. A. Boyle to the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America.

title: Chief of Aetna Life and Casualty Named Also to President's Post
description: Aetna Life and Casualty, which found itself without a president earlier this month with the surprise resignation of John A. Hill, filled the va cancy yesterday by electing its chairman and chief executive; officer, Olcott D. Smith, to the !additional post.

title: Fine Arts at Skidmore to Gain At Preview of Exhibition Here
description: Art works by wellknown women artists will be exhibit ed Monday through Sunday, Feb. 8, at the National Arts Club, 5 Gramercy Park South. A number of the artists are expected to attend the open ing of the show, which is sponsored by the Skidmore College art department and the Skidmore Arts Committee.

title: New Budget Policy Seeks To Fix Nation's Priorities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30An attempt by the Government to create a more scientifically ex act framework for deciding what the nation can afford and what it cannot afford was dis closed by President Nixon to day in his Economic Report to Congress.

title: To Waltz and Schmaltz Vienna Is Adding Salz
description: VIENNA, Jan. 31  Is the celebrated Viennese charm nothing but schmaltzy com placency?

title: Wilbur L. Arthur, Ex Aide Of The Chicago Daily News
description: Wilbur L. Arthur, Eastern ad vertising manager of The Chi cago Daily News from 1937 to 1960, died yesterday at Yale New Haven Hospital. He lived at 200 Drum Hill Road, Wilton, Conn.

title: Pentagon Extends Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  The Pentagon ruled today that eligible enlisted men may be discharged up to three months early to attend recog nized vocational or technical schools. The ruling was an ex pansion of a 10yearold policy that, until now, applied only to men planning to attend college.

title: Haughton Pleased By His New Crop Of Harness Colts
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 30 Although Billy Haughton will be less than 15 miles away from Roosevelt Race way tomorrow night, he will not appear at the track to drive either Meadow Elva in the featured $12,500 fourth race or Mizelle Smokey in the $3,000 fifth.. Both pacers are among the 24 standard breds in the Haughton barns here.

title: Utility Plans to Add Largest Generator
description: The American Electric Pow er System committed itself yesterday to the largest sin gle generating unit in the history of the electric power industry.

title: CHANGES BACKED IN MONEY PARITY
description: WASHINGTTON, Jan. 30 The Council of Economic Ad visers gave cautious and con ditional support today to ideas for small and frequent changes in currency exchange rates but emphasized that the United States cannot move its own parity with respect to other currencies.

title: Panel Will Review Federal Regulation of Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 A presidential commission charged with a thorough examination of needed changes in our fin ancial institutions and regula tory structure will be ap pointed shortly, the Adminis tration said today.

title: End of the G.E. Siege . . .
description: The tentative settlement of the fourteenweek strike of nearly 150,000 General Electric workers represents a triumph for mediation. The company and the twelve unions that had formed a coalition to battle it on the picket line might, if left to their own devices, have staggered on for many more weeks without any real attempt at collective bargaining.

title: SENATE APPROVES NEWSPAPER PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Senate approved a bill today that would exempt from anti trust prosecution all existingil and many prospective joint op erations of two separately owned newspapers. The vote was 63 to 14.

title: INDUCEMENTS SET IN ZAMBIA MINES
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 30 New inducements for the ex pansion of the mining industry were announced by Zambia's Minister of Finance, Elijah Mu denda, in his budget speech here today. But details of new mineral taxation, which will re place the present royalty and export tax system, were not disclosed by the Minister, who said legislation soon would be, introduced to give effect to them.

title: Attack on Legislator's Wife Shocks Colorado Governor
description: DENVER, Jan. 30Gov John A. Love said today he was horrified at the attack on the wife of the Democratic leader of the Colorado House of Rep resentatives.

title: JUDGE CITES PERIL OF U.S. REVERSALS
description: A judge of the state's high est court said last night that decisions of the United States Supreme Court and other Fed eral courts that reversed con victions in the state courts had created a serious imbalance in the administration of crim inal justice.

title: Books of The Times
description: THERE is something arresting about publishing that is absent from the manufacturing of seamless hose or even from the exploits of the herring fleet. That is true, I think, because publishing is a waterway that drains from so many streams, some bright, some muddy. Tech nological development in press work and composition, the economics of cost and distribution, the ever sly game of contracts and royalties, the changes in popu lar taste and val ues, the esthetics of print and de sign, the lottery element that ex ists in the best seller, and the hu man factor that includes the run ning battle be tween editor and author and be tween the artistic impulse and the commercial oneall contribute to the mak ing of a richly flowing and sometimes turbulent current in the national landscape.

title: Excerpts From Presidential Council's Report on Economic Strategy and Outlook
description: The American economy began 1969 with production, incomes, and prices in creasing rapidly from the momentum of earlier inflationary fiscal and monetary policies. As the year moved along, how ever, the economy began to respond to the constraints of policies which had been changed to combat inflation. The huge budget deficit had been closed with the aid of a tax increase in mid 1968, and the new Administration fur ther tightened fiscal policy in 1969 by a sharp pruning of projected Federal outlays. Monetary policy also shifted its direction, becoming increasingly re strictive during the year.

title: Sweden Grants Asylum To Taiwanese Professor
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 30 (UPI)  A Taiwanese law professor, who defected in protest against the Chinese Nationalist regime of Generalissimo Chiang Kai shek, was granted political asylum here today.

title: Airport at Indianapolis Damaged by 747 Jets
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 30 (UPI)An estimated total of $5,000 to $7,000 in dam age to runways and other landing equipment resulted from practice takeoffs and landings by two 747 Jumbo jets at Weir Cook Airport in Indianapolis earlier this month, airport officials have estimated. The jets belonged to Trans World Airlines. The airline said it would pay for the damage.

title: Neighborhoods: Alexander's Divides West Side
description: Two years ago Commu nity Planning Board 7, which covers Manhattan's West Side from Lincoln Center to Columbia University, put forth the idea that Broadway and 96th Street would be an ideal site for a major depart ment store. No one objected.

title: Two Unions' Panels Approve Agreements With G.E.
description: Bargaining committee of the two striking electrical unions gave their approval yesterday to new agreements with Gen eral Electric that will cost nearly $1billion and will pro vide $1.05 an hour in higher wages and improved benefits.

title: TAX BREAK ASKED TO HELP MORTGAGES
description: The chairman of the Franklin Society Federal Savings and Loan Association, one of the largest in New York State, pro posed yesterday that Congress stimulate housing by giving savers a tax break.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION LOWEST SINCE 61
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP)  The nation's auto makers re ported today their smallest new car production for a January since 1961.

title: Death Toll in Avalanches In Iran Is Now Put at 43
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 30 (AP) The bodies of 43 victims have been recovered following a series of snow avalanches that swept more than 120 vehi cles off a highway northeast of here yesterday and Wednes day.

title: BATTLE IN VIETNAM NOW IN QUESTION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 31 (AP)Offi cers said today that reports yesterday of a major battle be tween United States soldiers and enemy battalions near Tay ninh had been made by a unit commander and that we are not convinced of the accuracy of the reports.

title: Salvador and Honduras Agree To Troop Pullback After Clash
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 30 (AP)E1 Salvador and Hon druas agreed today to an im mediate pullback of troops along their border.

title: Feminine Hand at Helm Today in Boating Seminar
description: Predictedlog competitors, fearing their sport may he getting too stodgy, are doing something about it. With their annual seminar sched uled to start at 10:30 this morning in the Snuth Amer ica Room of the Coliseum, they have asked an attractive 23yearold girl to he the nrincinal sneaker.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Plains, N. Y., won the 76mile race and a purse of $4,050. Killion had won the national Vee championship here last November. Jim McDaniel of Atlanta placed second, today with Tom Davey of Tenafly, N. J. third. Killion averaged 85.92 M.P.H.

title: DR. MAURICE S. CALMAN
description: Dr. Maurice S. Calman, a re tired oral surgeon and a mem ber of the Board of Aldermen in 1917 died Tuesday at the home of his son, Dr. Clarence M. Calman in Glen Rock, N. J. He was 83 years old and lived at 658 West 188th Street.

title: Defense Nears End of Chicago 7 Case
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30The de fense in the Chicago conspiracy trial neared the end of its case today in a session marked by the appearance of several prominent witnesses.

title: Submarine Is Undamaged
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 30 (UPI)The Navy said today that the nuclear submarine Nathanael Greene suffered no damage in running aground and remaining in the mud for seven hours near the mouth of Charleston Harbor. Four tug boats pulled the 425foot bal listic missile submarine out of the mud at high tide last night.

title: FIVE ARE ARRESTED IN SUBWAY PROTEST
description: Five persons were arrested by transit police at the height of the rush hour last night on a charge of holding open the gates to the IND subway sta tion at 53d Street and Madison Avenue and urging patrons to ride free.

title: 2 Slain as 2,000 Filipinos Storm Presidential Palace
description: MANILA, Saturday, Jan. 31 Some 2,000 students and young people, hoisting revolu tionary placards and upside down Philippine flags, tried last night to storm into the grounds of Malacanang, the presiden tial palace, and battled with policemen into the morning.

title: KENNETH I. WOOD
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 30 Kenneth I. Wood, research consultant for the United Com munity Funds and Councils of America, died yesterday at the Stamford Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 232 Seaton Road.

title: BRITON CARDS A 67 ON ONLY 28 PUTTS
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30Tony Jacklin, who is going to Lon don to see the Queen next month, moved into a tie with Jack Nicklaus today for the lead in the $150,000 Andy Wil liamsSan Diego open golf tournament.

title: National Airlines Jets Grounded By Strike of 3,500 Employes
description: MIAMI, Saturday, Jan. 31 (AP)About 3,500 ground em ployes of National Airlines went on strike at 12:01 A.M. to day, grounding the line's 53 jets. The strikers are members of the Air Line Employes Asso ciation, which has been work ing without a contract since last spring.

title: Virgil Graham Dead at 68; Led Electronic Tube Work
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Jan. 30 Virgil M. Graham, former technical relations director for Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., who was a leader in standardiz ing electronic tubes, died yes terday. His ace was 68.

title: WHITE CROSS DEAL WITH ZALE IS OFF
description: The White Cross Stores, Inc. said yesterday that in view of an apparently unfavorable tax ruling from the Internal Rev enue Service, it appeared clear that its hoard of directors would have to cancel the pro posed merger with the Zale Corporation.

title: Bombings in Montevideo
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 30 (UPI)The police reported seven firebomb attacks in the early morning hours against. homes of executives of the state's Social Security Bank. No injuries were reported, but there was damage to doors, windows and, in sonic cases, interiors.

title: State's Schools Ordered To Continue Flag Pledge
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30School administrators throughout the state were instructed by the Department of Education today to continue the daily salute to the flag by students and let the courts decide how to deal with dissenters.

title: Lower East Side Loop Offered For 2d Ave. Subway by M.T.A.
description: The Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority announced a new plan yesterday for the pro jected Second Avenue subway route to Lower Manhattan that included both a direct line and a loop through the Lower East Side bulge.

title: Churches Provide $100,000 Bail Here For Black Panther
description: Mrs. Afeni Shakur, who is one of 16 Black Panther party mem bers who have been in jail since last April on bombing conspi racy charegs, was released last inght in $100,000 bail.

title: Laurentiis Quits Making Films; Woes Mount for Italian Industry
description: ROME, Jan. 30  Italian film makers, many of whom believe their industry has been crippled by the abrupt withdrawal of American financing, got some bad news today.

title: TV: Play Examines Fate of Dismissed Executives
description: THE Canadian Broadcasting Corporation contributed a poignant and alltootrue play last night to the National Educational Television Play house on Channel 13. It was George Salverson's story of the plight of men around the age of 50 who may lose their jobs for any number of rea sons and then learn they are too old to obtain another position consistent with their experience and standard of living.

title: Fanny May Payment Is Sought by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  The Senate today passed a bill directing the Federal National Mortgage Association to pay $68mil lion to the Treasury.

title: Tug Contract Talks Discontinued Here; Strike Vote Coming
description: Negotiations for a new con tract for the port's commercial towing industry took a turn for the worse yesterday.

title: FRANK V. BRACH, 80, LED CANDY CONCERN
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) Frank V. Brach, a founder and chairman of E. J. Brach & Sons, one of the largest candy companies in the country, died here yesterday at the age of 80.

title: Butcher & Sherrerd Given 5Day Suspension by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended Butcher & Sherrerd a Philadel phia brokerdealer, and censured a partner after finding viola tions of the registration provi sions of Federal securities laws.

title: U.N. Vote Condemns South African Role In SouthWest Area
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30  A resolution con demning South Africa's ille gal presence in SouthWest Africa was adopted today by the Security Council after a heated debate in which the So viet Union and the United States accused each other of slander.

title: U.C.L.A. Trims Calif., 8772
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI)John Vallely scored 25 secondhalf points tonight to lead No. 1ranked University of California, Los Angeles, to an 8772 Pacific8 conference vic tory over California. The tri umph was the 15th without a loss for the Bruins this season.

title: Mutual Fund Cited In S.E.C. Complaint
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had filed a complaint in United States District Court in Los An geles against the Enterprise Fund, Inc., a Los Angelesbased mutual fund, and the Share holders Management Company, its principal underwriter.

title: XEROX DATA PLANS TO CUT PRICES 20%
description: Xerox Data Systems, a sub sidiary of the Xerox Corpora tion, announced yesterday it was cutting 20 per cent from its prices for computer system interface units.

title: NEW SCHOOL LINES FOR MANHATTAN VOIDED BY COURT
description: The new decentralized school district lines drawn for Man hattan were voided yesterday by a state judge who said that they failed to create integra tion and maximum hetero geneity as required by law.

title: Antiaues: Tinker and His Dam Shows Tin Crafts
description: TIN, painted and plain, is the subject of the cur rent exhibition, The Tinker and His Darn, at the Mu seum of American Folk Art.

title: POMPIDOU TO GET NO CITY WELCOME
description: President Pompidou of France will not be accorded an official welcome by the city when he comes here on March 2, Mayor Lindsay's office said yesterday.

title: British 91Day Bill Rate Off
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) The average rate of discount lat today's tender of British treasury 91day bills fell to 7.510 per cent from 7.524 per cent last week. This week's 100million offer of 91day bills met applications of 242 695,000. Next week 100mil lion bills will be offered re placing 100million of matur ities.

title: CHANDIGARH MOVE BRINGS VIOLENCE
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 30The Government's award of the dis puted city of Chandigarh to Punjab State induced a Sikh Punjabi leader today to call off his threat to burn himself to death, but it touched off wide spread arson and violence in Haryana State, the rival claim ant for the city. The army was brought in tonight to restore order.

title: Girl Hears a False Note In Pledge of Allegiance
description: The way they say it, it's as if there is liberty and jus tice, but there isn't.

title: Text of President Nixon's Annual Report to Congress on the State of the Economy
description: TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES: For many years the American people have been seeking, through their Gov ernment, the road to full employment with stable prices.

title: Underground Nuclear Blast
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 30 (AP)A lowyield nuclear ex plosion was set off today 1,000 feet deep at the Nevada Test Site, the Atomic Energy Com mission said. The test, the sec and announced this year, was in a vertical shaft at Yucca Flat and had a force of less than 20.000 tons of TNT.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: U Thant in Nigeria

title: Prominent Blacks Endorse Newark Mayoral Candidate
description: A group of prominent black officeholders and artists en dorsed efforts today to elect Kenneth A. Gibson as the first black mayor of Newark, along with a slate of black and Puerto Rican council candidates.

title: City U. Announces Plan for Expansion Of Jewish Studies
description: Plans to expand Jewish stud ies at the City University of New York were announced yes terday by the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, vice chancellor for aca demic affairs.

title: Business Records
Carlos, Amateur in Track, Lets Lawyer Seek Football Dollars
description: John Carlos is not talking about professional football because he is an amateur runner, and amateur runners are not supposed to talk about money. But if he were talking about money, well, we'd start at a million dol lars and maybe work down toward $600.000.

title: Marine Killed in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Lance Cpl. Erick W. Beattie of Staten Island, a marine, has been killed in action in Viet nam, the Pentagon announced today.

title: 11 Will Bow Friday At 18th Piarist Ball
description: The Hungarian Piarist Alumni Association will hold its 18th annual ball Friday at the Plaza. Dr. George Teleg dy and Baroness Francis Neuman de Vegvar are co chairmen of the dinner dance, which will help the school building fund of the Piarist Fathers.

title: DR. KURT ROSENBERG
description: Dr. Kurt Rosenberg, a gyne cologist, died Wednesday in Boulevard Hospital, Long Is land City, Queens. He was 55 years old and lived at 14 Green way South, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Billie Sol Estes Loses Bid For Parole in Prison Term
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Billie Sol Estes lost today his first bid for parole from a 15 year Federal prison term.

title: MRS. PAUL LANES
description: Mrs. Ruth Kony Lanes, member of the board of visitors to Creedmoor State Hospital, died Thursday of a heart attack in Flushing Hospital. She was the wife of Paul Lanes, a factor ing executive, and lived at 3620 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: The 3 Economists Who Mold Nixon Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The chairman and two mem bers of the President's Coun cil of Economic Advisers, whose report on the economy will accompany Mr. Nixon's message to Congress Monday, collectively represent several decades of economic study for government, business and academia.

title: MOOGISTS TRY ON BACH AND BEATLES
description: The Moog synthesizer may well become the musical instru ment of the Seventies. If so, it will have to come up with something better than what was offered by Gershon King sley's First Moog Quartet last night in Cargenie Hall.

title: Jacksonville Routs St. Peter's; Army to Face N.Y.U. Today
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)Jacksonville's 7foot2 inch Artis Gilmore raked in 30 rebounds and scored a career high of 46 points tonight as the sixthranked Dolphins downed St. Peter's of Jersey City, 124101, in a fastbreaking bas ketball game.

title: L.I.R.R. Riders Express Anger Over Timing of Fare Increase
description: Long Island Rail Road com muters heaped abuse on ticket sellers yesterday as the railroad put its fare increase into effect one day early on some tickets.

title: For the Cook Who Wants to Co Skiing
description: A FTER a day on the ski slopes, an Iowa scalloped chicken casserole prepared in advance to pop in the oven and served with a broccoli dish and caramel nut cake the cook, to relax by the fire.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: PRICES TO FARMERS ROSE LAST MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  Prices that farmers received for their products rose one third of one per cent during the month ended Jan. 15 and put further pressure on the Administration's attempt to curb the cost of living.

title: Buffalo Names CoCaptains
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 30 (AP) Prentis Henley of Buffalo, defensive end, and Charles Donnor of nearby East Aurora, a center, were elected co captains today of the 1970 University of Buffalo football team.

title: St. John's Appointment
description: Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, president of St. John's Univer sity, yesterday announced the appointment of the Rev. Joseph I. Dirvin as vice president for university relations. Mr. Dirvin will coordinate the departments of public relations develop ment and ??.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEES ABOUT $50BILLION IN GROWTH IN 1970
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  President Nixon projected to day a growth of the national economy by about $50billion this year, with both less infla tion and less real growth than in 1969.

title: Public and Pompidou Are at Odds on Mideast
description: PARIS, Jan. 30According to an opinion poll just pub lished here, 55 per cent of the Frenchmen interrogated said that France should not sell arms to any country in the Middle East.

title: Tiffany & Co. Will Accept Bank Americard
description: Tiffany & Co., which carries sterling silver but not silver plate, yesterday gave its nod to a hit of plastic. Walter Hoving, chairman of the Fifth Avenue jewelry, sil ver and china company, an nounced that starting March 1 a credit cardthe Bankamer icardwould be welcomed by Tiffany, in its main branch on 57th Street and also in its branch stores in California, Chicago and Houston.

title: Executive Changes
description: Hugo Heuermann of the trust investment depart ment of the Chemical Bank has been promoted vice president.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: HERBERT A. BELL, RADIO MAKER, DIES
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 30Herbert A. Bell, an im portant figure in the infant radio industry of the 1920's, died of a heart attack at St. John's Hospital here today. He was 79 years old.

title: Mrs. Tessa Browning Remarried in London
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) Field Marshal Viscount Mont gomery's son married the daughter of Daphne Du Mau rier, the author, today in a Kensington registry office.

title: Stock Prices Drop To a SixYear Low
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange fell yesterday to their lowest levels in more than six years.

title: KIRK WANTS ORDER ON SCHOOLS IGNORED
description: TALLAHASSEE. Fla., Jn. 30 (AP)Gov. Claude Kirk Jr. is sued executitve orders today prohibiting busing by two Flor ida counties to implement Fed eral courtordered school deseg regation plans.

title: SNEAD'S 71 FOR 142 LEADS SENIOR FIELD
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)Sam Snead took a threestroke lead after 36 holes in the Professional Golfers Association's senior championship today with his second 71 for a 142 as rain and the flu bug cut the field to 90.

title: Teteak New Wisconsin Aide
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 30 (UPI) Dick Teteak, the head foot ball coach at Beloit College, was named an assistant coach at the University of Wisconsin, Elroy Hirsch, the athletic direc tor, announced today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) James R. MacAnally, senior vice president of the Union Pa cific Railroad, Omaha, died yes terday while on a business trip here shortly after suffering a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title: Allegra Kent Rejoins City Ballet As the Favored Muse in Apollo
description: Allegra Kent, back at the New York City Ballet after an absence of some months, danced her first Terpsichore of the sea son in Balanchine's Apollo at the State Theater last night.

title: Texas Instruments Increases Earnings
Predictions on the Nation's Output
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The following table shows the probable levels of the gross national product in future years (assuming reasonably steady economic growth) and the manner in which it might be divided among different uses. The table, prepared by the Council of Economic Advisers, was designed to show that essential continuation of present trends and claims on national output would use up the entire output through 1972 and that excess output beginning 1973 would be relatively small.

title: Summer Bridal For Miss Pham And S. B. Young
description: Mr. and Mrs. Do Binh Pham of Saigon have an nounced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Thi Hoa Pham, to Stephen Bon sai Young. He is the son of Kenneth Todd Young, a for mer United States Ambassa dor to Thailand, and Mrs. Young of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Frenn Betters World Mark For 35Pound Weight Throw
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP)George Freon, a 28year old schoolteacher, broke the listed world record for the 35 pound weight throw today with a heave of 71 feet 3 inches.

title: Connecticut Judge's Son Guilty in Heroin Case
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 30 A Circuit Court judge who once ordered the arrest of a group of Connecticut parents for serving liquor to teenagers at parties in their homes watched today as his own son pleaded guilty to a heroin charge.

title: Now When You Buy Stainless Steel, It May Be a Bed or a Desk
description: COPPER is too fragile, aluminum too light, gold too symbolic, silver too weak, bronze is out of fash ion and platinum inacces sible, said Maria Pergay, a 39yearold French sculptor designer. Nothing is more beautiful than steel. Mrs. Pergay actually arrived at this belief two years ago after Uginox, a major French stainless steel producer, approached the artist to design furniture that would promote the use of stainless steel in high fashion furniture. The results  12 sinuously or geometrically shaped chairs, tables, chaises, desks and bencheswent on view this week at the Galerie Air France. And there is more to come that will be shown at Harvey Probber next month.

title: CAIRO SAYS ISRAELIS KILLED 4 CIVILIANS
description: CAIRO, Jan. 30 (Reuters) A military spokesman here said that Israeli warplanes killed four civilians todayincluding a woman and her childbefore Egyptian pilots intercepted them over the Suez Canal and drove them off. He added that three Egyptian soldiers had been wounded in the attack, on positions at the northern sector of the canal, near the town of Ismailia.

title: A Graphic Display at Columbus Circle
description: TO report on any exhibition at the New York Cultural Center, formerly Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art, involves a preliminary embarrassment, because the new name suggests that this problem child of architec ture and philanthropy has changed character to become a City institution where the arts flourish as one great constellation. One feels obligated to point out that this is a case of there being no thing in a name, and that one is not responsible for the implied recommendation.

title: Topics: How the Administration Can Curb Inflation
description: I am the last one to deny the utility of clichs to public of ficials. But a clich cannot be substituted for a policy. I fear that this may be happening with respect to the Administra tion's inflation policy.

title: In Lagos, It's Business (From Bananas to Oil) as Usual
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 30 It is indeed a wonderful thing that the war has ended, a taxicab driver said the other day as he careened perilously around corners in this vibrant capital, horn honking constant ly, but now Nigeria needs better highways.

title: James R. MacAnally, 62, Uninn Pacific Official. Dies
description: James R. MacAnally, 62, Uninn Pacific Official. Dies

title: U.N. Pact Drafted to Tighten Hallucinogen Curbs
description: GENEVA, Jan. 30A United Nations commission approved a draft treaty today to place hal lucinogenic drugs under strict international controls.

title: L.I. Parents Held Liable for Injury Caused by Son, 10
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 30 A 14yearold boy and his father were awarded $280, 000 by a State Supreme Court jury today for injuries suffered by the boy when he was shot in the head by another youth six years ago.

title: COMPANY TO BUY THE NEWARK NEWS
description: Media General, Inc., a rapidly expanding Southern communi cations corporation, has agreed to acquire The Evening News of Newark and two of the New Jersey newspaper's other prop erties, a newsprint processing company and an engraving plant.

title: Negroes in Pittsburgh Achieve Accord on Jobs in Construction
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30An agreement to employ 1,250 Negroes as journeymen in the construction industry in Alle gheny County over the next four years was announced here today.

title: The Washington Record
White House Concerned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The White House said today that the infiltration of the agents into the press corps in Saigon had not been in accord with the public information policy of this Administration. Ronald L. Ziegler, the press sec retry, told reporters that he was concerned about the matter and so was the Pentagon's top pub lic affairs official, Assistant Secretary Daniel Z. Henkin.

title: Givenchy, 1970: The Approach Is Positive, the Look Is Softer
description: DAMS, Jan. 30  The Giv enchy collection today may be the dark horse of the springsummer haute couture collections, which wind up tomorrow, and what a horse it is too.

title: Oppenheimer Names 3 General Partners
description: Oppenheimer & Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, an nounced yesterday that it had admitted as general part ners Anthony Bruan, 26 years old; Donald Kramer, 32, and Stephen Robert, 29.

title: Florida State Gets Parcells
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 30 (UPI)Florida State University today signed Bill Parcells, an assistant coach at West Point, to coach Seminole linebackers next season. Parcells succeeds Bobby Jackson, who recently resigned to join the Kansas State staff.

title: Rolling Stones Sue Owners Of First Coast Concert Site
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 (UPI)The Rolling Stones and their promoters today filed an $11million suit against owners of the originally scheduled site of their Dec. 6 free concert, which drew 200,000 fans and was marred by a fatal onstage stabbing.

title: Margin Is 13 Lengths
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 30 (UPI) Sea Castle, the 910 favorite of 7,914 fans, romped to a 13 length victory in the Glendale Purse at the Bowie race course today.

title: PORSCHES CAPTURE NEXT THREE SPOTS
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30Factory cars from Ferrari of Italy, Porsche of West Ger many and Matra of France swept the first eight qualifying positions today for the 24 Hours of Daytona, presaging one of the hardestfought en durance races of recent years.

title: A NIXON COPTER PAD COST ARMY $342,358
description: MIANI, Jan. 30 (AP)Army Engineers spent $342,358 to build a 150foot square heli copter landing pad just off President Nixon's waterfront Key Biscayne compound, an, official of the company that built it said today.

title: Record Payoff for Meet
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30A 621 shot and a 281 shot ran 1, 2 in the third race at Liberty Bell race track today to form the largest exacta payoff of the winter meeting, $1,109.40.

title: Millicent Evans McEntee, A Shakespearean Actress
description: MOORESTOWN. N. J., Jan. 30Mrs. Millicent Evison Mc Entee, a former Shakespearean actress, died yesterday in the Greenleaf Extension, a Quaker nursing home here, at the age lof 93. She lived at Mount Rose, in Hopewell, and was the widow of Francis D. McEntee, an actor and a producer.

title: Met's Eighth Week Includes Traviata With Phyllis Curtin
description: Phyllis Curtin will make her first appearance as Violetta this season in the Metropolitan Opera's production of La Tra viata on Feb. 16, and Richard Tucker will sing the title role in Don Carlo for the first time this season on Feb. 20.

title: 2 More French Fire Suicides
description: PERPIGNAN, France, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  A young teacher and a mechanic have burned themselves to death near here in the last 24 hours, bringing to 10 the number of suicides by fire in France in the last two weeks, the police said today.

title: 4 Shows Set Opening Dates
description: Premiere dates for one Broad way and three Off Broadway shows were announced yester day. The double bill of Grin and Bare It and Postcards will open March 9 at the Belasco Theater. Exchange will be presented Feb. 8 at the new MercerO'Casey Theater; Jump ing Fools will start Feb. 9 at the Fortune Theater, and I Dreamt I Dwelt in Blooming dale's will begin Feb. 12 at the Provincetown Playhouse.

title: Earlier Clashes Over the North Conceded
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30  The United States com mand acknowledged today that there had been periodic airto ground engagements in North Vietnam since the bombing halt 15 months ago that had not been made public because they were considered to be insig nificant.

title: Verga's 26 Points Set Pace As Cougars Win, 11798
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan. 30 (AP)Bob Verga scored the first 10 points of the game to night and paced the Carolina Cougars over the Pittsburgh Pipers, 11798, in an American, Basketball Association game.

title: Exjudge Schor Acquitted of Perjury Charges in S.L.A. Inquiry
description: Benjamin H. Schor, former Criminal Court judge in Brook lyn, was acquitted yesterday morning of charges that he lied to a grand jury investigating ir regularities in the State Liquor Authority in 1966.

title: STARKER PLAYS BACH IN MUSEUM CONCERT
description: Not many concerts are sell ing out these days, but the combination of Bach, Starker and Ruzickova turned the trick last night at the Metropolitan Museum.
